{"pertussis": [{"archive_id": "8144942", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update: Canada (NT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8144942", "date": "2021-01-28 13:55:33", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE: CANADA (NORTHWEST TERRITORIES)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021 11:33 a.m. CT\nSource: CBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/whooping-cough-pertussis-deh-cho-1.5871447\n\n\nThe NWT's [Northwest Territories'] chief public health officer has declared an outbreak of pertussis, or whooping cough, in the Dehcho region after a total of 7 cases were confirmed in 2 communities. The cases were confirmed in Jean Marie River and Fort Simpson, according to an advisory issued Wednesday [13 Jan 2021] morning. Last week, officials advised of 4 people that had been diagnosed in Fort Simpson [https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/4-people-diagnosed-whooping-cough-fort-simpson-1.5861325].\n\nPertussis is a vaccine-preventable disease that affects the lungs and respiratory tract. It's particularly dangerous to children under one year of age.\n\nThis is the 2nd year in a row the territory has declared a pertussis outbreak. An outbreak declared in January 2020 in the Yellowknife and Tlicho regions led to at least 55 confirmed cases [https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/whooping-cough-nwt-1.5585871].\n\nResidents of Jean Marie River and Fort Simpson are being asked to confirm their pertussis vaccinations as soon as possible by contacting their health centre, the advisory states. While the vaccine is safe and effective, the advisory says, immunity from it may fade over time. Boosters are typically offered in Grade 7, and then every 10 years as an adult. Pregnant women are also advised to get a vaccine between 27 and 32 weeks of their pregnancy, regardless of their last dose, in order to protect the newborn.\n\nAccording to the advisory, the 1st symptoms of pertussis appear 7-10 days after exposure but may take as long as 21 days to develop. They include mild fever; runny nose; red, watery eyes; sneezing; and mild cough. The cough becomes worse about 10 days after exposure, 'leading to severe, repeated, and forceful coughing spells that end with a whooping sound before the next breath,' the advisory says. The cough tends to be worse at night and may lead to vomiting or difficulty breathing, and babies and small children may turn blue.\n\nAnyone who thinks they may have been exposed to someone with pertussis or is showing symptoms is asked to contact their health centre as soon as possible.\n\nAnyone confirmed to have pertussis is strongly advised to stay at home, and in particular away from infants, young children, women in the last 3 months of pregnancy, and large public gatherings until their antibiotic treatment is completed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An outbreak of pertussis is reported above in the villages of Fort Simpson and Jean Marie River, Dehcho Region, Northwest Territories (NWT), Canada. Dehcho is one of 5 administrative regions of the NWT. Fort Simpson is its administrative seat, with 1200 residents who are predominantly Indigenous people (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Simpson). Jean Marie River is a village of 77 predominantly Indigenous people in the Dehcho Region of the NWT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Marie_River). The other NWT regions with their regional seats are the Inuvik Region (Inuvik), Sahtu Region (Norman Wells), North Slave Region (Behchoko and Yellowknife), and South Slave Region (Fort Smith and Hay River). A map showing the location of Dehcho can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_regions_of_the_Northwest_Territories.\n\nIn 2020, we reported pertussis outbreaks, probably a result of inadequate immunization, in communities with predominantly Indigenous peoples in the Qikiqtaaluk Region of Nunavut (Pertussis update (03): Canada (NU) 20200620.7491247); in Yellowknife, the North Slave Region of the NWT (Pertussis update (02): USA (MN,PA,OR), Canada (NT) 20200208.6969310); and in Tlicho Region, NWT (Pertussis update (01): USA, Canada 20200102.6868270).\n\nRoutine pertussis immunization of infants, children, and adolescents with DTaP-IPV-Hib-containing vaccine is provided at 2, 4, 6, and 12-23 months of age (generally given at 18 months of age), followed by a booster dose of either DTaP-IPV or Tdap-IPV vaccine at 4-6 years of age (school entry) and a booster dose of Tdap vaccine at 14-16 years of age (https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/healthy-living/canadian-immunization-guide-part-4-active-vaccines/page-15-pertussis-vaccine.html).\n\nRoutine pertussis immunization of adults with one dose of Tdap vaccine is provided to all adults 18 years of age and older. One dose of Tdap vaccine is also administered in every pregnancy, ideally between 27 and 32 weeks of gestation (https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/healthy-living/canadian-immunization-guide-part-4-active-vaccines/page-15-pertussis-vaccine.html).\n\nRoutine vaccinations for babies, children, and adults are offered free of charge (https://www.ontario.ca/page/vaccines). - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNorthwest Territories, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/266]", "summary": "\n\nRoutine pertussis immunization of infants, children, and adolescents with DTaP-IPV-Hib-containing vaccine is provided at 2, 4, 6, and 12-23 months of age (generally given at 18 months of age), followed by a booster dose of either DTaP-IPV or Tdap-IPV vaccine at 4-6 years of age (school entry) and a booster dose of Tdap vaccine at 14-16 years of age (https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/healthy-living/canadian-immunization-guide-part-4-active-vaccines/page-15-pertussis-vaccine.html). In 2020, we reported pertussis outbreaks, probably a result of inadequate immunization, in communities with predominantly Indigenous peoples in the Qikiqtaaluk Region of Nunavut (Pertussis update (03): Canada (NU) 20200620.7491247); in Yellowknife, the North Slave Region of the NWT (Pertussis update (02): USA (MN,PA,OR), Canada (NT) 20200208.6969310); and in Tlicho Region, NWT (Pertussis update (01): USA, Canada 20200102.6868270). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRoutine pertussis immunization of adults with one dose of Tdap vaccine is provided to all adults 18 years of age and older. Communicated by:\nProMED from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An outbreak of pertussis is reported above in the villages of Fort Simpson and Jean Marie River, Dehcho Region, Northwest Territories (NWT), Canada. Anyone confirmed to have pertussis is strongly advised to stay at home, and in particular away from infants, young children, women in the last 3 months of pregnancy, and large public gatherings until their antibiotic treatment is completed. The NWT's [Northwest Territories'] chief public health officer has declared an outbreak of pertussis, or whooping cough, in the Dehcho region after a total of 7 cases were confirmed in 2 communities. \n\nResidents of Jean Marie River and Fort Simpson are being asked to confirm their pertussis vaccinations as soon as possible by contacting their health centre, the advisory states. \n\nPertussis is a vaccine-preventable disease that affects the lungs and respiratory tract. According to the advisory, the 1st symptoms of pertussis appear 7-10 days after exposure but may take as long as 21 days to develop. California is not currently experiencing a pertussis epidemic. If you could correct this posting, it would be most appreciated.\n\n--\nKathleen Harriman, PhD, MPH, RN\nChief, Vaccine Preventable Diseases, Epidemiology Section\nCalifornia Department of Public Health, California\n<Kathleen.Harriman@cdph.ca.gov>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Harriman for correcting the record that no epidemic of pertussis is currently occurring in California. ProMED-mail regrets the confusion that the posting on 24 Jul 2019 in error of a 2014 report when there actually was an epidemic of pertussis in California may have caused. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nCalifornia, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n California Department of Public Health, California\n<Kathleen.Harriman@cdph.ca.gov>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Harriman for correcting the record that no epidemic of pertussis is currently occurring in California. PERTUSSIS UPDATE (08): AMERICAS, EUROPE, AUSTRALIA, CORRECTION\n***************************************************************\n \n\n--\nKathleen Harriman, PhD, MPH, RN\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "AUSTRALIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7491247", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (03): Canada (NU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7491247", "date": "2020-06-20 12:32:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): CANADA (NUNAVUT)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 28 May 2020 14:30 EDT\nSource: Nunatsiaq News [edited]\nhttps://nunatsiaq.com/stories/article/faced-with-whooping-cough-case-nunavut-issues-public-health-advisory-for-sanikiluaq/\n\n\nDue to a case of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, daycare [centres] in Sanikiluaq will remain closed 'for the time being,' Nunavut's chief public health officer said today [28 May 2020]. The public health advisory is intended to prevent the spread of this highly contagious infection within the Hudson Bay community of about 900, Dr Michael Patterson said during the Government of Nunavut's [GN] update on COVID-19 on Thursday [28 May 2020]. But 'we do not think this represents a risk or a threat to any other communities in Nunavut', Patterson said.\n\nWhooping cough can be spread easily from person to person, he said. 'Anyone can get whooping cough, but the most severe cases are in young children,' said Patterson. 'For that reason, the daycare in Sanikiluaq will remain closed for the time being.' Normally the GN would not take this action, but the decision was based on the possible risk of infection, he said. Daycares in Nunavut are slated to reopen on 1 Jun 2020 as part of the easing of COVID-19 restrictions in the territory. 'If we open up the daycares and there is transmission of pertussis in Sanikiluaq, then we have exposed children to an increased risk of transmission and acquisition of pertussis,' said Patterson. For children in daycares, Patterson said pertussis is 'far more dangerous than COVID', so 'that's the rationale for doing it the way we did'.\n\nAs well, he recommended that everyone in Sanikiluaq continue social distancing, as they have been doing for COVID-19, 'at least until we know if there are any other cases in Sanikiluaq'. Whooping cough is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, which can cause uncontrollable, violent coughing that often makes it hard to breathe. Nunavut has been hit by several outbreaks of whooping cough in recent years, with the most recent big outbreak taking place in 2017 (https://nunatsiaq.com/stories/article/65674whooping_cough_outbreak_over_say_nunavut_health_officials/).\n\nEvery year in Canada, there are 1 to 3 deaths due to whooping cough, mostly in babies under the age of 3 months who have not been immunized, according to Health Canada (https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/vaccine-preventable-diseases/pertussis-whooping-cough/health-professionals.html).\n\n[byline: Jane George]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 18 Jun 2020 13:30 EDT\nSource: Nunatsiaq News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://nunatsiaq.com/stories/article/whooping-cough-outbreak-continues-in-nunavut-community/\n\n\nAn outbreak of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, continues in the Hudson Bay community of Sanikiluaq. Nunavut's Health Department said today [18 Jun 2020] that the status of Sanikiluaq's pertussis outbreak remains unchanged since a previous public health advisory about the outbreak on 8 Jun 2020.\n\nThe number of confirmed cases is still fewer than 5, the Health Department told Nunatsiaq News in an emailed statement. About 900 people live in Sanikiluaq. 'Health staff have been conducting contact tracing and investigation of symptoms to determine if there are additional undetected cases of pertussis within the community,' the department said. 'Health staff has also been reviewing and updating pertussis vaccinations for community members.'\n\nDue to the outbreak, no daycare is open in Sanikiluaq, although others in Nunavut have reopened. But there are no other public health measures currently in place in Sanikiluaq that are 'not otherwise implemented elsewhere'.\n\nYou can learn more about whooping cough by reading the pertussis fact sheet available on the Department of Health's website (https://www.gov.nu.ca/sites/default/files/pertussis_fact_sheet_eng_2.pdf).\n\n[byline: Jane George]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sanikiluaq is an Inuit community with a population of 882 residents in 2016 located on the north coast of Flaherty Island in Hudson Bay, on the Belcher Islands, in the Qikiqtaaluk Region of Nunavut, Canada (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanikiluaq). The Qikiqtaaluk Region, or Baffin Region, is the easternmost administrative region of Nunavut, Canada (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qikiqtaaluk_Region). A map showing the location of Sanikiluaq can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sanikiluaq,+NU,+Canada. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Nunavut Territory, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/265.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n[byline: Jane George]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sanikiluaq is an Inuit community with a population of 882 residents in 2016 located on the north coast of Flaherty Island in Hudson Bay, on the Belcher Islands, in the Qikiqtaaluk Region of Nunavut, Canada (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanikiluaq). \n\n[byline: Jane George]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Due to a case of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, daycare [centres] in Sanikiluaq will remain closed 'for the time being,' Nunavut's chief public health officer said today [28 May 2020]. Nunavut's Health Department said today [18 Jun 2020] that the status of Sanikiluaq's pertussis outbreak remains unchanged since a previous public health advisory about the outbreak on 8 Jun 2020. Source: Nunatsiaq News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://nunatsiaq.com/stories/article/whooping-cough-outbreak-continues-in-nunavut-community/\n\n\nAn outbreak of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, continues in the Hudson Bay community of Sanikiluaq. PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): CANADA (NUNAVUT)\n***************************************\n \n\nYou can learn more about whooping cough by reading the pertussis fact sheet available on the Department of Health's website (https://www.gov.nu.ca/sites/default/files/pertussis_fact_sheet_eng_2.pdf). \n\nEvery year in Canada, there are 1 to 3 deaths due to whooping cough, mostly in babies under the age of 3 months who have not been immunized, according to Health Canada (https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/vaccine-preventable-diseases/pertussis-whooping-cough/health-professionals.html). If we open up the daycares and there is transmission of pertussis in Sanikiluaq, then we have exposed children to an increased risk of transmission and acquisition of pertussis,' said Patterson. The public health advisory is intended to prevent the spread of this highly contagious infection within the Hudson Bay community of about 900, Dr Michael Patterson said during the Government of Nunavut's [GN] update on COVID-19 on Thursday [28 May 2020].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2020-06-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-06-18 00:00:00", "2020-05-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "sanikiluaq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sanikiluaq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Belcher Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6749235", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (10): Americas (USA, Canada)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6749235", "date": "2019-10-27 17:19:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (10): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Kentucky)\n[3] USA (Nevada)\n[4] USA (New York)\n[5] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] New York (Jefferson County)\nDate: Thu 10 Oct 2019\nSource: WWNY TV [edited]\nhttps://www.wwnytv.com/2019/10/10/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-jefferson-county-health-officials-say/\n\n\nThere's a pertussis outbreak in Jefferson County. Public health officials say there have been 23 confirmed cases of the disease [pertussis], also known as whooping cough, since 1 Jun [2019]. People who caught the disease range in age from 5 months to 15 years.\n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. The most common symptom is uncontrollable coughing spells often followed by a characteristic 'whoop' sound. An infected person can spread the disease starting when symptoms begin to 3 weeks after the coughing begins. Coughing frequently lasts for several weeks. County Public Health Director Ginger Hall says pertussis is highly communicable and can be prevented by the vaccine known as Tdap, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 116 229 residents in 2010, is on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of New York, adjacent to Lake Ontario and the St. Laurence River; its county seat is Watertown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_New_York). A map that shows the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: WPSD Local6 [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. In Kentucky, there have been 8 confirmed cases this year [2019].\n\nData from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show a rise in cases in Kentucky and a decrease in vaccinations. The latest CDC data show that from 2017 to 2018, the number of Tdap vaccinations decreased by 1.4%. The number of cases of whooping cough increased to more than 10 cases per 100 000 people.\n\nKnight [a nurse at the Purchase District Health Department] said the lack of vaccines for adults and a false sense of security [are] contributing to this increase. 'If your child was the one that couldn't have the immunization, you would want everyone else around them to have it,' Knight said. 'And to keep them in mind that you're doing it for your child, because you don't want them to get this disease.'\n\n[Byline: Abisola Adeyemo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kentucky is a state (actually a commonwealth) located in the east south-central region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky). A map showing the location of Kentucky can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kentucky. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: U.S. News & World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/nevada/articles/2019-10-22/whooping-cough-outbreak-closes-private-reno-high-school\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak has prompted the closure of a private high school in Reno [Nevada] until next week. The Washoe County Health District says it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Bishop Manogue High School. Additional cases are probable.\n\nDistrict officials say the Catholic school is cooperating with an investigation into the highly contagious respiratory disease and agreed to close the school until Monday [28 Oct 2019] to protect students and staff.\n\nDistrict Health officer Kevin Dick said late Monday [21 Oct 2019] that the outbreak is 'very serious.' He says it underscores why all students are required to be vaccinated for the disease, which is called 'pertussis' and is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing that makes it hard to breathe.\n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York (Sullivan County]\nDate: Sat 26 Oct 2019\nSource: The Daily Freeman [edited]\nhttps://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/sullivan-county-issues-whooping-cough-advisory/article_5a363f6e-f80b-11e9-a36f-27221984eceb.html\n\n\nSullivan County Public Health Services confirmed that 3 cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been identified in children of varying ages in the county this week.\n\nPublic Health Director Nancy McGraw called this an important advisory. 'As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,' she said.\n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. It is separated from the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along its southwest boundary by the Delaware River, and its county seat is the city of Monticello (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sullivan_County,_New_York). A map showing the location of Sullivan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sullivan+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Alberta (South Zone)\nDate: 16 Oct 2019\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttps://calgary.ctvnews.ca/health-officials-declare-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-southern-alberta-1.4641826?fbclid=IwAR1ebNkeYH3oS7yXMFRCjYhj2JgZXmhzi_KWA1pgyG0_hx5kkdeLuqeiBvs\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond.\n\nOfficials say 15 new cases of the illness have been discovered in the past 2 weeks, bringing the total number of confirmed illnesses to 42 for the whole year [2019]. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n'They are locally acquired,' said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, 'Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.'\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Under these rules, those under the age of 16 will not be permitted, and there will be only 2 visitors per patient allowed. Anyone with symptoms such as a cough or runny nose are reminded not to visit.\n\nAccording to AHS, an outbreak is called when 2 or more cases of illness are identified that have a common epidemiological link, such as same location, unit, floor, caregiver or transmission within the unit of the facility.\n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].\n\n[Byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lethbridge is the 3rd largest city in the province of Alberta, Canada, southeast of Calgary. Alberta is divided into 5 health zones; a map showing the location of these zones can be found at https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/ahs-map-ahs-zones.pdf. The cities of Lethbridge and Raymond are located in the South Zone. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. [5] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n \n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond. \n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. \n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others. \n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,' she said. \n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area. \n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].", "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (11): Americas (USA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6771300", "date": "2019-11-10 14:28:50", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (11): AMERICAS (USA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] Nevada (Washoe County)\n[2] Virginia (Fauquier County)\n[3] Oregon (Washington County)\n[4] Missouri (Jefferson County)\n[5] Ohio (Warren County)\n[6] Pennsylvania (Indiana County)\n\n******\n[1] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 29 Oct 2019\nSource: KOLO TV [edited]\nhttps://www.kolotv.com/content/news/Washoe-County-reports-5th-case-of-whooping-cough-564054981.html\n\n\nThe Washoe County Health District has confirmed a 5th case of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, at Bishop Manogue High School.\n\nAfter 4 previous cases were reported, Bishop Manogue H.S. agreed to close from 22-27 Oct 2019 to reduce the transmission of the disease. School has since resumed, and there have not been any changes announced in class schedules or sports and activities.\n\nStudent athletes participating in fall sports must meet 3 requirements:\n1. They cannot exhibit any signs or symptoms of pertussis.\n2. The students must be up to date on pertussis vaccinations.\n3. The athletes must complete a course of physician-prescribed antibiotics prior to their competition date.\n\nUnvaccinated students will not be allowed on campus until the families provide proof of a TDAP vaccination and 7 days have passed since the vaccination was received. If a student declines to be vaccinated, they will not be allowed to return to school until after 21 days following the last reported case.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Fauquier County)\nDate: Wed 30 Oct 2019\nSource: Fauquier Now [edited]\nhttps://www.fauquiernow.com/fauquier_news/article/fauquier-county-has-a-surge-of-whooping-cough-cases-2019\n\n\n'Whooping cough' cases have spiked among Fauquier County children in the last 6 weeks, according regional health officials. The Rappahannock-Rapidan Health District 'has investigated a total of 25 reports of pertussis illness in children, with ages ranging from under 1 to 17 years' since mid-September [2019], spokeswoman Lorrie Andrew-Spear said Wednesday [30 Oct 2019]. Last year [2018], the health district reported a total of 10 cases in its 5 counties.\n\n'Fauquier County Health Department staff are working closely with local health care providers, Fauquier County schools and daycare centers to identify, treat and exclude cases from group activities,' Ms. Andrew-Spear wrote in a press release. 'It is important to keep ill children away from others when necessary to prevent the spread of illness. 'Additionally, the Fauquier Health Department has sent letters home with all children/students who attend daycare centers or schools with identified cases of pertussis.'\n\nMost of the recently-diagnosed children 'have been previously vaccinated, so it is important to be aware that you can still get pertussis if you have been vaccinated in the past, she said. 'The effectiveness of the vaccine varies and may decrease over time. 'This does not mean that you should not get the vaccine. The current vaccine prevents illness for the majority who receive it and also helps to prevent severe respiratory illness, hospitalizations and or death in infants and immune-compromised or elderly patients.' Ms. Andrew-Spear urged anyone with pertussis symptoms to 'seek medical evaluation and avoid public or group settings.'\n\nFor more information, call Fauquier Health Department at 540-347-6400 and ask to speak with a public health nurse or contact RRHD District Epidemiologist Daniel Ferrell at 540-316-6278.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fauquier County, with a population of 65 203 residents in 2010, is in northern Virginia and is a part of the Washington, DC metropolitan area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fauquier_County,_Virginia). A map showing the location of Fauquier County can be found at (https://www.google.com/maps/place/Fauquier+County,+VA). The includes 5 counties in northern Virginia: Culpeper, Fauquier, Madison, Orange, and Rappahannock (http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/rappahannock-rapidan/). A map showing Virginia counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Oregon (Washington County)\nDate: Fri 1 Nov 2019\nSource: Oregon Live [edited]\nhttps://www.oregonlive.com/health/2019/11/3-tualatin-high-school-students-diagnosed-with-whooping-cough.html\n\n\nThree cases of whooping cough were discovered at Tualatin High School recently. Those cases add to one at Northeast Portland's Grant High School, where a student was diagnosed with the illness earlier this week.\n\nWashington County has seen 36 confirmed or suspected cases of the illness so far this year [2019], county health department spokeswoman Wendy Gordon told The Oregonian/Oregon Live.\n\nAccording to the Oregon Health Authority, 93% of Washington County children between the ages of 13 and 17 have received booster shots for whooping cough, also known as pertussis, which also guards against diphtheria and tetanus.\n\nIn all of 2018, officials say, Washington County tracked just 24 cases. In 2017, Washington County saw 41 cases, more than twice as many as the 20 that were reported in 2016. Health officials say the up-and-down yearly pattern is typical of the disease. The previous year, 2015, saw a whopping 107 cases of whooping cough in Washington County, a sharp spike over the previous year's 37.\n\nIn Multnomah County, health officials have documented 61 suspected or confirmed cases of pertussis since the beginning of the year. Last year [2018], 38 cases had been discovered by Halloween.\n\nThere is a vaccine for the disease, which children are required to receive at least 4 times before beginning kindergarten, according to the Oregon Health Authority. Starting at age 7, kids should get at least one booster shot, the agency says.\n\n[Byline: Eder Campuzano]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washington County, with a population of 529 710 residents in 2010, is one of 36 counties in the U.S. state of Oregon and is part of the Portland-Vancouver-Hillsboro, OR-WA Metropolitan Statistical Area. A map showing the location of Washington County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Washington+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Missouri (Jefferson County)\nDate: 4 Nov 2019\nSource: Fox2 Now [edited]\nhttps://fox2now.com/2019/11/04/fifteen-students-test-positive-for-whooping-cough-at-festus-schools/\n\n\nA Jefferson County school district has an outbreak of whooping cough. So far, more than a dozen cases have been reported.\n\nPertussis or whooping cough began to appear at the Festus High School and Intermediate School around mid-October [2019]. District officials say 59 students have reported symptoms: 15 have tested positive for whooping cough, while 22 tested negative, and 22 were waiting for results. 14 of the students attend the high school and one student at the intermediate school.\n\nThe district was asked whether unvaccinated students were the cause of the outbreak. The district says that's not the case. Less than half a percent of the student population is unvaccinated. None of those who tested positive to pertussis displayed symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 218 733 residents in 2010, is located in the eastern portion of the U.S. state of Missouri and is a part of the St. Louis metropolitan area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_Missouri). A map showing the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+MO. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Ohio (Warren County)\nDate: Thu 7 Nov 2019\nSource: Dayton247 Now [edited]\nhttps://dayton247now.com/news/local/whooping-cough-cases-confirmed-at-3-springboro-schools\n\n\nSpringboro Schools has sent out a warning to parents, confirming that cases of pertussis or whooping have now been found at the high school, the junior high, and at Springboro Intermediate. Two separate alerts have gone out to parents after cases were 1st reported. Those alerts only involved the high school.\n\nIf a child is experiencing persistent cough or if you have any questions or concerns, contact a physician. Whooping cough is a vaccine-preventable disease. If your child is not up to date, you can contact the Warren County Health Department for assistance at 513-695-2097.\n\n[Byline: Rebeckah Chenoweth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Warren County, with a population of 212 693 in 2010, is in the U.S. state of Ohio and is part of the Cincinnati, OH-KY-IN Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_County,_Ohio). A map showing the location of Warren County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Warren+County,+OH. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] Pennsylvania (Indiana County)\nDate: Fri 8 Nov 2019\nSource: Indiana Gazette [edited]\nhttps://www.indianagazette.com/news/local/whooping-cough-reported-in-area-schools/article_ca3f8d88-0238-11ea-9ace-7bafa8487e2a.html\n\n\nA medical problem is getting attention in area classrooms, as reported this week by at least 3 area public school districts. 'It has come to our attention that you (or) your child may have been exposed to a person who has pertussis (whooping cough),' said a letter sent out Tuesday [5 Nov 2019] by Penns Manor Area Superintendent Daren Johnston.\n\n'The Indiana School District has been notified of a few confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) in our district,' Director of Education Robert J. Heinrich Jr. confirmed Thursday [7 Nov 2019] in an email to the Gazette.\n\nAs letters posted on Marion Center Area and Penns Manor Area websites point out, in rare cases, especially in infants less than one year of age, whooping cough can be fatal.\n\nA spokesman for the Pennsylvania Department of Health said several cases have been reported in Indiana County. 'We have been working closely with the (Indiana County) school districts and other school districts in the area to prevent the spread of illness,' department Press Secretary Nate Wardle said Thursday [7 Nov 2019] afternoon. 'Department of Health template letters with recommendations have been provided to area school districts for distribution to faculty and families of students.'\n\nIn online postings by Weimer and Johnston, the letters hew closely to what Wardle's department has sent out.\n\n'If you (or) your child is coughing, promptly contact your (or) your child's doctor,' the Penns Manor superintendent posted. '(The) doctor may obtain a nasopharyngeal culture to test for pertussis. In addition, if the doctor suspects pertussis, an antibiotic will be given to your child to lower the chance of spreading the disease to others.' Johnston stressed in his letter that the child continue taking that antibiotic even after he or she is back in the classroom, something that is allowed to happen 5 days after the child began taking it.\n\n'The department encourages everyone to check and make sure they are up to date on all immunizations, which include the DTaP vaccine for children under 7, and the Tdap vaccine for older children and adults,' he said. As noted in department talking points quoted in the Penns Manor and Marion Center letters, both vaccines combine diphtheria, tetanus and acellular pertussis vaccine. 'If you are not sure your child is properly immunized, promptly contact his or her doctor,' both superintendents included in their letters. Both letters referred parents and physicians to a toll-free Department of Health number, (877) 724-3258.\n\n[Byline: Patrick Cloonan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indiana County, with a population of 88 880 in 2010, is located in the central-western part of the U.S. state of Pennsylvania and is also included in the Pittsburgh-New Castle-Weirton, PA-WV-OH Combined Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana_County,_Pennsylvania). Date: Fri 1 Nov 2019\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Culpeper", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Warren County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washoe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Louis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Multnomah County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fauquier County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fauquier", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6969310", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (02): USA (MN,PA,OR), Canada (NT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6969310", "date": "2020-02-08 18:27:29", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (02): USA (MINNESOTA, PENNSYLVANIA, OREGON), CANADA (NORTHWEST TERRITORIES)\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Minnesota\n[2] Pennsylvania (Lehigh Valley)\n[3] Oregon (Deschutes County)\n\nCanada\n---\n[4] Northwest Territories (Yellowknife and Tlicho communities)\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Minnesota\nDate: Wed 8 Jan 2020\nSource: DL-Online [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.dl-online.com/business/healthcare/4855170-Infant-dies-of-whooping-cough-in-Minnesota\n\n\nMinnesota health officials have confirmed an infant death related to pertussis, also known as whooping cough. The infant was diagnosed with pertussis in August 2019 and died in November [2019] after being hospitalized for 3 months. The last pediatric death related to pertussis in Minnesota was in 2013.\n\n'We were extremely saddened to hear that this child passed away,' Kristen Ehresmann, director of infectious disease at the Minnesota Department of Health (MDH), said in a news release. 'Pertussis continues to be a concern in Minnesota, and we want to do everything we can to prevent future tragedies like this.'\n\nAnyone can get pertussis, but it is most severe in infants. Preliminary data for 2019 shows there were 25 cases of pertussis in infants less than 6 months old in Minnesota. Of those, 8 were hospitalized, and 2 of the hospitalized cases were severe. 'Infants who get pertussis can get very sick, and many need to be hospitalized,' Ehresmann said. 'The severe cases often require lengthy hospital stays with weeks to months in an intensive care unit. It can be devastating for the family.'\n\nHealth officials are emphasizing the importance of vaccination, especially during pregnancy, to help prevent pertussis. The tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis, or Tdap, vaccine is recommended during the 3rd trimester of each pregnancy. This recommendation has been around since 2012. Ehresmann explained that when the Tdap vaccine is given during pregnancy, the mother's body creates antibodies to fight off the pertussis bacteria. Some of those antibodies are passed to the baby before birth and offer short-term protection until the baby can start to receive their own vaccines.\n\nIn 2018 and 2019, Minnesota had 41 cases of pertussis among infants less than 6 months of age. Upon review, only 18 (44%) of the mothers received Tdap during pregnancy. 'We're missing opportunities to vaccinate during pregnancy and protect vulnerable infants from a serious disease,' Ehresmann said in the release. 'We are working with partners to make sure healthcare providers and pregnant women have the information they need to ensure on-time vaccination with this safe and effective vaccine.'\n\nMany infants who get pertussis are infected by older siblings, parents, or other caregivers. These people often do not know they have the disease because symptoms can be less severe in adolescents and adults.\n\nThere are 2 pertussis vaccines, and your age determines when you get each vaccine. The diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis, or DTaP vaccine, is given to children starting at age 2 months. The Tdap vaccine is given to adolescents at age 11-12 years and adults. Families should talk to their healthcare provider to see what vaccines they need and when. People who have completed some or all of the recommended vaccinations for pertussis may still get the disease but will generally have a milder illness.\n\nFor more information, go to http://www.health.state.mn.us/diseases/pertussis/index.html.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota, with an estimated population of over 5.6 million residents in 2019, is a state in the Upper Midwest, Great Lakes Region, of the United States; nearly 55% of its residents live in the Minneapolis-Saint Paul metropolitan area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota). A map showing the location of Minnesota can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Minnesota. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania (Lehigh Valley)\nDate: Wed 8 Jan 2020\nSource: The Morning Call [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.mcall.com/news/local/east-penn/mc-nws-more-whooping-cough-east-penn-20200108-4jlkr4vvnvfxdby26embsxj63m-story.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases since 15 Nov [2019] in the East Penn School District has climbed to 17, with a new case this week at Emmaus High School. The majority of cases, 12, were in high school students, according to the district. There have also been 2 cases at Lower Macungie Middle School, one at Macungie Elementary, and 2 at Shoemaker Elementary.\n\nWhooping cough, or pertussis, is a very contagious disease of the lungs and airways. Pertussis can be treated with antibiotics and prevented with vaccines. The state requires school children or school staff suspected of having whooping cough or have a confirmed case to be excluded from school or daycare for 3 weeks from the start of their symptoms, or for 5 days after starting antibiotics.\n\nIn a Tuesday [7 Jan 2020] letter posted on the high school's website, the district referred parents to state Health Department guidelines that recommend they contact a doctor if their child coughs frequently or experiences fits. 'The best way we currently have to protect against the spread of pertussis is by being fully immunized,' the letter states.\n\nPertussis vaccines are effective but not perfect, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nLehigh County has the highest rates of pertussis in the state, according to the Health Department: 30.5 pertussis cases per 100 000 people, according to 2015-2017 data posted on the department's website. Northampton County had a rate of 11.5 cases per 100 000 people. A Health Department spokeswoman said no other pertussis outbreaks have been reported in Lehigh and Northampton counties this year [2020].\n\n[byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The East Penn School District is a public school district located in Lehigh County, Pennsylvania, that operates one high school (Emmaus High School), 2 middle schools (Lower Macungie and Eyer middle schools), and 7 elementary schools (Shoemaker, Macungie, Alburtis, Jefferson, Lincoln, Wescosville, and Willow Lane) in the Lehigh Valley region of eastern Pennsylvania (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Penn_School_District). A map showing the location of the East Penn School District can be seen at https://www.google.com/maps/place/East+Penn+School+District,+PA.\n\nThe Lehigh Valley (also known as the Allentown-Bethlehem-Easton, PA-NJ Metropolitan Statistical Area) consists of Carbon, Lehigh, and Northampton counties in eastern Pennsylvania and Warren county on the western edge of New Jersey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lehigh_Valley). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Oregon (Deschutes County)\nDate: Sat 11 Jan 2020 [updated 13 Jan 2020]\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttps://ktvz.com/news/2020/01/11/summit-hs-pertussis-case-reported-other-parents-advised/\n\n\nParents of students at Bend's Summit High School were sent a letter Friday [10 Jan 2020] warning of recent possible exposure to pertussis, also known as whooping cough, at the school. A student at Ridgeview High School in Redmond recently contracted pertussis, prompting a similar letter to parents and guardians. Other cases among those reported in the county (and to parents) last year [2019] included students at Redmond's Obsidian Middle School and Bend High School.\n\nDeschutes County Health Services reported a total of 67 presumptive and confirmed pertussis cases in 2019, a rise from previous years, a representative said Saturday [11 Jan 2020]. They were primarily in school-aged children.\n\nFriday's [10 Jan 2020] letter to Summit parents and guardians, from Bend-La Pine Schools health services supervisor Tami Pike, advised them to take steps to prevent or reduce the risk of developing the illness. If a child has a respiratory illness, the district advised parents to have their medical provider evaluate the student and let them know of the pertussis exposure. State and county health officials said when pertussis is suspected and antibiotics are prescribed, the student may not attend school until they've completed at least 5 days of the prescribed medication, to ensure they are no longer contagious, Pike said.\n\nThe best prevention against pertussis is up-to-date Tdap immunizations, Pike said. But she added that 'vaccines are not 100% effective, and it is still possible to become ill with pertussis; however, illness tends to be less severe in those people who are vaccinated.' Those with questions were urged to contact Deschutes County Health Services' Communicable Disease Line at 541-322-7418.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bend (2010, population 76 693) and Redmond (2010, population 26 215) are cities located in Deschutes County, in the center of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[4] Northwest Territories (Yellowknife and Tlicho communities)\nDate: Wed 15 Jan 2020\nSource: CBC [edited]\nhttps://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/yellowknife-tlicho-region-whooping-cough-1.5428641\n\n\nThe chief public health officer of the Northwest Territories has declared a whooping cough outbreak in Yellowknife and in Tlicho communities. There are 20 lab-confirmed cases of whooping cough in those regions as of Wednesday [15 Jan 2020], according to a news release sent Wednesday afternoon.\n\nLast month [December 2019], the Health Department announced 8 confirmed cases of whooping cough in the Tlicho region. Those cases were 'isolated and treated,' the department said at the time.\n\nWhooping cough is preventable with a vaccine, according to the department. Residents can get the free vaccine from their healthcare provider. Immunity may fade over time, so booster shots are offered every 10 years. Pregnant women should get an immunization between 27 and 28 weeks of pregnancy, regardless of when they last had a booster shot, says the advisory notice. The Health Department said people who suspect they have whooping cough should notify their healthcare provider and stay at home.\n\nIn 2015, there were 21 confirmed cases of whooping cough in the Northwest Territories, including in the Tlicho region, Hay River, Yellowknife, and the Beaufort Delta region. At the time, the office of the chief public health officer said the majority of those cases were linked to travel outside the NWT.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Yellowknife, on the northern shore of Great Slave Lake, about 400 km (250 mi) south of the Arctic Circle, is the capital and only city, as well as the largest community, in the Northwest Territories (NWT), Canada (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowknife). The Tlicho, also known as the Dogrib, are a Dene First Nations people living in 6 settlements in the NWT (Behchoko, population 2227 residents; Whati, population 522 residents; Gameti, population 291 residents; Wekweeti, population 136 residents; Dettah, population 245 residents; and Ndilo, population 2007 residents. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6868270", "date": "2020-01-02 20:32:33", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (01): USA, CANADA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] North Carolina (Harnett County)\n[2] Illinois (Cook County)\n[3] Michigan (Wexford County)\n[4] Maine (Cumberland County)\n\nCanada\n---\n[5] Northwest Territories (Tlicho region)\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] North Carolina (Harnett County)\nDate: Tue 10 Dec 2019\nSource: WTVD ABC11 [edited]\nhttps://abc11.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-confirmed-at-harnett-county-school/5744936/\n\n\nSeveral confirmed cases of whooping cough have been reported in Harnett County. Rebecca Campbell, the school nurse at Western Harnett High School, alerted parents to the outbreak. According to an announcement sent out Monday [9 Dec 2019] night, there are several confirmed cases of the highly contagious infection.\n\nStudents who have been directly exposed in class or on the school bus were sent home with a letter explaining what steps to take if they develop symptoms, which include a deep cough that could last for weeks or months. The illness is most dangerous for small children or those with weakened immune symptoms.\n\nConcerned Harnett County residents should contact their physicians or the county health department at (910) 893-7550.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Harnett County (2010, population 114 678) is located in the US state of North Carolina and is a part of the greater Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill, NC, Combined Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harnett_County,_North_Carolina). A map showing the location of Harnett County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Harnett+County,+NC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Illinois (Cook County)\nDate: Tue 17 Dec 2019\nSource: OakPark.com [edited]\nhttps://www.oakpark.com/News/Articles/12-17-2019/Pertussis-on-the-rise-in-Oak-Park-and-River-Forest/\n\n\nLocal cases of pertussis, otherwise known as whooping cough, have popped up in Oak Park in higher numbers this year [2019] than any year in the previous decade. According to Michael Charley, public health director of the Oak Park Health Department, as of 16 Dec [2019], there are 10 confirmed cases in Oak Park, which has averaged 3.1 cases per year between 2008 and 2018.\n\nWithin public schools, according to Charley, District 200 has 5 confirmed cases (4 students and one teacher), and District 97 has 2 confirmed cases, both students. In River Forest, District 90 has 3 confirmed cases of pertussis as of 16 Dec [2019]: 2 at Roosevelt Middle School and one at Willard School. It could not be confirmed at time of publication whether the confirmed cases in D200, D97, or D90 were in vaccinated or unvaccinated children.\n\nIn 10 Dec and 16 Dec [2019] memos to D90 parents, the steps the district was taking to help prevent further infections were outlined, and information from the Cook County Department of Public Health was forwarded.\n\n'Please be assured that all of the district's nurses are aware of this situation and are monitoring the situation,' read the memo. 'Our nurses are following the recommended protocols of the Illinois Department of Public Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).'\n\nThe custodial staff at all D90 locations have been intensifying disinfection of classrooms, bathrooms, desks, door handles, and other common areas throughout the school.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) website, pertussis diagnoses have been on the rise since the early 1980s. The CDC has identified several explanations for this, including 'increased awareness, improved diagnostic tests, better reporting, more circulation of the bacteria, and waning immunity.'\n\nAdditionally, according to the CDC, there is evidence that the bacteria that causes pertussis is 'changing at a genetic level,' though studies suggest that the current vaccines are still effective even as the bacteria transforms.\n\nHowever, the currently used pertussis vaccines may be less effective than those used prior to the 1990s, which could account, in part, for pertussis cases being on the rise since the 1980s. The vaccines currently given, DTaP and Tdap, are acellular vaccines, which contain only some organic material from _Bordetella pertussis_, the bacteria that causes the disease. These vaccines may not provide protection as effective as DTP, a whole-cell vaccine, which contains the entire inactivated _B. pertussis_ organism.\n\nIn the 1990s, according to the CDC, doctors in the United States switched from DTP, the whole-cell vaccine, to DTaP and Tdap, the acellular vaccines, because they had less major and minor side effects. But this change may have left Americans slightly less protected against the disease. According to the CDC website, 'Acellular pertussis vaccines may not prevent colonization (carrying the bacteria in your body without getting sick) or spread of the bacteria.' Additionally, waning immunity to the vaccine can leave even vaccinated people less protected than they might believe.\n\nAccording to the 10 Dec [2019] Cook County Department of Public Health's memo regarding the Roosevelt Middle School student with pertussis, required vaccinations for the illness should be given at ages 2, 4, 6, and 15 months. A booster should be given between the ages of 4 and 6. However, according to the memo, 'immunity begins to wane 3-5 years after the last shot. Protection can be completely gone by the time a child enters middle school.'\n\nThe CDC confirms this, estimating that 'in the 1st year after getting vaccinated with Tdap, it protects about 7 out of 10 people who receive it. There is a decrease in effectiveness in each following year. About 3 or 4 out of 10 people are fully protected 4 years after getting Tdap.' For this reason, states the Cook County Department of Health, a Tdap booster is recommended for preteens at age 11 or 12. The department states that being up-to-date with Tdap is especially important for teens who will be around babies.\n\nRecommendations from the CDC also include Tdap for children 7-10 years old who are not fully vaccinated with DTaP, adults 65 years and older who are in close contact with young infants, and healthcare workers. It is recommended that pregnant women should receive a dose of Tdap during each pregnancy between 27 and 36 weeks of gestation.\n\n[Byline: Maria Maxham]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oak Park River Forest High School, or OPRF, is a public 4-year high school located in Oak Park, Illinois, a western suburb of Chicago, Illinois, in the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oak_Park_and_River_Forest_High_School). Oak Park has a population (2010 US Census) of 51 878 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oak_Park,_Illinois). A map showing the location of Oak Park can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Oak+Park,+IL.\n- Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Michigan (Wexford County)\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2019\nSource: 9and10 News [edited]\nhttps://www.9and10news.com/2019/12/20/7-cases-of-whooping-cough-confirmed-in-wexford-co-since-october/\n\n\nThe health department confirmed several cases of whooping cough in northern Michigan. Seven cases have been confirmed in Wexford County since October [2019]. They say a number of other cases were reported in surrounding counties.\n\nThe health department says that number is likely to rise as lab results come in, along with more reports from the community.\n\n[Byline: Chris Clor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US state of Michigan is divided into an Upper and Lower Peninsular. The Lower Peninsula (LP) is the southern of the 2 major peninsulas that make up the US state of Michigan. Wexford County (2010, population 32 735) is in the northern portion of the LP; its county seat is Cadillac (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wexford_County,_Michigan). A map of Michigan counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/michigan.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Maine (Cumberland County)\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2019\nSource: Washington Times [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2019/dec/20/officials-confirmed-10-maine-students-have-whoopin/\n\n\nHealth officials have confirmed that 10 students in a Maine high school have whooping cough. There were initially 3 reported cases of pertussis at Freeport High School, then 5, and now 10, the Portland Press Herald reported. Superintendent of Schools Becky Foley notified Regional School Unit 5 of the situation Thursday [19 Dec 2019] in an email.\n\nThere are no cases at any other school in the region, and the holiday break will serve as an opportunity to prevent further spread of the illness, according to Foley's email.\n\nFoley also urged parents to ensure that their families' vaccinations are up-to-date before school resumes session 2 Jan [2020].\n\n[Byline: Everett Piper]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Freeport (2010, population 7879) is a town on the Atlantic coast in Cumberland County, Maine, United States, known for its numerous outlet stores, about 17 miles north of Portland, the most populous city in Maine and the seat of Cumberland County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cumberland_County,_Maine). A map showing the location of Freeport can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Portland,+ME/Freeport,+ME+04032. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[5] Northwest Territories (Tlicho region)\nDate: Fri 13 Dec 2019\nSource: CBC [edited]\nhttps://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/whooping-cough-pertussis-nwt-confirmed-1.5396024\n\n\nThere are 8 confirmed cases of whooping cough in the N.W.T.'s Tlicho region, warns the health department in a news release Friday [13 Dec 2019]. The department says that as of Friday [13 Dec 2019], the 8 lab-confirmed cases are 'being controlled,' and there haven't been hospitalizations. It also says the cases are 'localized' but did not list the affected community or communities. 'All confirmed cases have been isolated and treated,' states the news release.\n\nWhooping cough is preventable with a vaccine, according to the department. Residents can get the free vaccine from their healthcare provider.\n\nIn 2015, there were 21 confirmed cases of whooping cough in N.W.T., in the Tlicho region, Hay River, Yellowknife, and the Beaufort Delta. At the time, the office of the chief public health officer said the majority of these cases were linked to travel outside the N.W.T.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Northwest Territories (NWT) (2019, estimated population 44 826) is a federal territory of Canada bordered by the territories of Nunavut to the east and Yukon to the west, and by the provinces of British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan to the south; Yellowknife is the territorial capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_Territories). Aboriginal peoples are in the majority in NWT. The Tlicho region, where there are 8 confirmed cases of whooping cough, may refer to the place where the Tlicho people live, between Great Slave and Great Bear Lakes in the NWT (https://www.google.com/maps/place/Great+Slave+Lake). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n At the time, the office of the chief public health officer said the majority of these cases were linked to travel outside the N.W.T.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oak Park River Forest High School, or OPRF, is a public 4-year high school located in Oak Park, Illinois, a western suburb of Chicago, Illinois, in the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oak_Park_and_River_Forest_High_School). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Freeport (2010, population 7879) is a town on the Atlantic coast in Cumberland County, Maine, United States, known for its numerous outlet stores, about 17 miles north of Portland, the most populous city in Maine and the seat of Cumberland County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cumberland_County,_Maine). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Harnett County (2010, population 114 678) is located in the US state of North Carolina and is a part of the greater Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill, NC, Combined Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harnett_County,_North_Carolina). In this update:\nUSA\n---\n [4] Maine (Cumberland County)\n\nCanada\n---\n \n\nConcerned Harnett County residents should contact their physicians or the county health department at (910) 893-7550.\n\n--\n According to Michael Charley, public health director of the Oak Park Health Department, as of 16 Dec [2019], there are 10 confirmed cases in Oak Park, which has averaged 3.1 cases per year between 2008 and 2018. Source: Washington Times [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2019/dec/20/officials-confirmed-10-maine-students-have-whoopin/\n\n\nHealth officials have confirmed that 10 students in a Maine high school have whooping cough. PERTUSSIS UPDATE (01): USA, CANADA\n**********************************\n Within public schools, according to Charley, District 200 has 5 confirmed cases (4 students and one teacher), and District 97 has 2 confirmed cases, both students. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< USA\n---\n Canada\n---\n According to the 10 Dec [2019] Cook County Department of Public Health's memo regarding the Roosevelt Middle School student with pertussis, required vaccinations for the illness should be given at ages 2, 4, 6, and 15 months. [5] Northwest Territories (Tlicho region)\n\n******\n \n\n\nThere are 8 confirmed cases of whooping cough in the N.W.T.'s Tlicho region, warns the health department in a news release Friday [13 Dec 2019]. In River Forest, District 90 has 3 confirmed cases of pertussis as of 16 Dec [2019]: 2 at Roosevelt Middle School and one at Willard School. [Byline: Maria Maxham]\n\n--\n [Byline: Chris Clor]\n\n--\n [Byline: Everett Piper]\n\n--\n \n\nThere are no cases at any other school in the region, and the holiday break will serve as an opportunity to prevent further spread of the illness, according to Foley's email. ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n \n\nAdditionally, according to the CDC, there is evidence that the bacteria that causes pertussis is 'changing at a genetic level,' though studies suggest that the current vaccines are still effective even as the bacteria transforms. Local cases of pertussis, otherwise known as whooping cough, have popped up in Oak Park in higher numbers this year [2019] than any year in the previous decade. Date: Tue 10 Dec 2019\n \n\nRecommendations from the CDC also include Tdap for children 7-10 years old who are not fully vaccinated with DTaP, adults 65 years and older who are in close contact with young infants, and healthcare workers. \n\nStudents who have been directly exposed in class or on the school bus were sent home with a letter explaining what steps to take if they develop symptoms, which include a deep cough that could last for weeks or months. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Northwest Territories (NWT) (2019, estimated population 44 826) is a federal territory of Canada bordered by the territories of Nunavut to the east and Yukon to the west, and by the provinces of British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan to the south; Yellowknife is the territorial capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_Territories). Date: Fri 13 Dec 2019\n The department says that as of Friday [13 Dec 2019], the 8 lab-confirmed cases are 'being controlled,' and there haven't been hospitalizations. Date: Tue 17 Dec 2019\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "7879-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00",
