"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6832722", "date": "2019-12-10 10:45:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (13): AUSTRALIA, USA\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAustralia\n---\n[1] Queensland\nUSA\n---\n[2] Illinois (Cook County)\n[3] Arkansas (Washington County)\n[4] Colorado (Boulder County)\n[5] Pennsylvania (Indiana County)\n[6] Virginia (Shenandoah Valley)\n\nAustralia\n---\n[1] Queensland\nDate: Fri 29 Nov 2019 11:07 AEST\nSource: ABC (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-11-30/whooping-cough-spike-queensland-vaccination-pregnant-babies/11747546\n\n\nRoyal Brisbane and Women's Hospital (RBWH) acting director of infectious diseases, Andrew Redmond, said Queensland is experiencing a spike in whooping cough cases.\n\nSo far this year [2019], Dr Redmond said there had been more than 1500 Queenslanders diagnosed. Of those, 190 presented to the emergency department, up from 124 the same time last year [2018]. 'This year across the state we've had roughly a 50 per cent increase in diagnoses of whooping cough, which is really terrible news,' Dr Redmond said. '[It is] an unexpected and unwanted rise.' The condition causes severe respiratory problems and can be fatal for babies.\n\nDr Redmond said more education was needed to improve vaccination rates in pregnant women. 'I think a lot of people engaging in good obstetric care know about it, but not everyone knows about it,' he said.\n\n(Only 34 per cent of women take up recommended vaccinations in pregnancy. Respiratory infections are the leading cause of death in babies up to 6 months old. Pertussis (whooping cough) is the most common fatal infection in babies under 2 months. 42 per cent of babies hospitalised for pertussis are under 6 months old.)\n\nRBWH obstetric physician and director of women's and newborn services, Karin Lust, said babies with whooping cough often got very sick with terrible coughing and reductions in their oxygen that could result in problems breathing and feeding. 'It's very tragic for families and obviously it is awful to see your child unwell, it is very distressing,' she said. Dr Lust said getting the vaccination while pregnant was the best protection, reducing the risk of infection by 90 per cent.\n\n'Whooping cough vaccination during pregnancy boosts maternal antibodies, which are transferred to the foetus through the placenta, providing some immunity to the newborn baby until they can receive their 1st dose of vaccine around 6 weeks of age.'\n\nThe vaccination schedule changed recently, meaning expectant mothers can get vaccinated earlier, from 20 to 32 weeks. 'It gives women a greater window of opportunity to actually have their vaccination so that they don't miss out on the protective benefits for their newborn baby,' Dr Lust said. 'Also, it actually will afford babies who are born premature a level of immunity as well.'\n\n[Byline: Louisa Rebgetz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Queensland, located in the northeast of the country, is the 2nd-largest and 3rd-most populous state in Australia, with a population of 5 million residents in 2018 that is concentrated along the coast, particularly in the state's South East, where Brisbane, the capital and largest city in the state is located (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queensland). A map showing the location of Queensland can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Queensland,+Australia. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Queensland, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/285]\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[2] Illinois (Cook County)\nDate: Mon 2 Dec 2019 1:05 PM CST\nSource: CBS [abridged, edited]\nhttps://chicago.cbslocal.com/2019/12/02/oak-park-river-forest-high-school-reports-another-case-of-whooping-cough/\n\n\nA 3rd student at Oak Park River Forest [OPRF] High School has been diagnosed with whooping cough, school officials said. Workers are 'diligently performing extra sweeps to clean and sanitize the building,' OPRF said in a statement. A 4th case involving an adult was also reported.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oak Park River Forest High School, or OPRF, is a public 4-year high school located in Oak Park, Illinois, a western suburb of Chicago, Illinois, in the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oak_Park_and_River_Forest_High_School). Oak Park has a population of a 51 878 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oak_Park,_Illinois). A map showing the location of Oak Park can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Oak+Park,+IL. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Illinois, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1545]\n\n******\n[3] Arkansas (Washington County)\nDate: Mon 2 Dec 2019 2:50 PM CST\nSource: Northwest Arkansas Democrat Gazette [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.nwaonline.com/news/2019/dec/02/second-student-at-fayetteville-s-washin/\n\n\nA 2nd Washington Elementary School student has a confirmed case of pertussis, the School District announced [Mon 2 Dec 2019]. The 1st case of pertussis, or whooping cough, was announced Tuesday [26 Nov 2019?].\n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health requires students in the same school with a student who has a confirmed case of pertussis who have an exemption for the pertussis vaccine or no record of the vaccination to be excluded from school for 21 days from the date of exposure.\n\nAt least 6 students in the School District have been diagnosed with pertussis since last spring [2019].\n\n[Byline: Dave Perozek]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washington County, with a population of 203 065 residents in 2010, located in the Ozark Mountains is a regional economic, educational, and cultural hub in the Northwest Arkansas region; Fayetteville is the county seat (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_County,_Arkansas). Washington Elementary School is in Fayetteville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fayetteville_Public_Schools). A map showing the location of Washington County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Washington+County,+AR. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Arkansas, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8804]\n\n******\n[4] Colorado (Boulder County)\nDate: Tue 3 Dec 2019 4:25 PM MST\nSource: CBS4 [abridged, edited]\nhttps://denver.cbslocal.com/2019/12/03/boulder-78-cases-pertussis/\n\n\nThe Boulder County Health Department provided more information about an ongoing pertussis outbreak, also known as whooping cough. They say there have been 78 cases so far this year [2019]. Officials tell CBS4 May [2019] had the highest number of cases at 23. They add the last epidemics in their area happened in 2013 (230 cases) and 2012 (170 cases). They warned of an outbreak at Boulder High School, but say 5 schools have at least one case.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Boulder, with a population of 97 385 residents in 2010, is the county seat and the most populous city of Boulder County, Colorado, United States; it is located at the base of the foothills of the Rocky Mountains 25 miles (40 km) northwest of Denver and is the home of the main campus of the University of Colorado (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boulder,_Colorado). A map showing the location of Boulder can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Boulder,+CO. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519]\n\n******\n[5] Pennsylvania (Indiana County)\nDate: Wed 4 Dec 2019 12:28 AM EST\nSource: Pittsburgh Post-Gazette [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.post-gazette.com/local/region/2019/12/03/State-declares-whooping-cough-outbreak-indiana-county/stories/201912030150\n\n\nThe state Department of Health will hold a free whooping cough vaccination clinic [Thu 5 Dec 2019] in Indiana, Pennsylvania, after a rare whooping cough outbreak spread through 4 school districts in Indiana County, infecting as many as 45 people since August [2019].\n\nThough there was one early case in the county in early August [2019], the outbreak spread quickly in the 4 school districts, sending staff scrambling to understand what whooping cough -- also known as pertussis -- is and how it spreads.\n\n'This was my 1st experience,' said Robert Heinrich, director of education for Indiana Area School District, which has had 6 or 7 cases of the disease, including one faculty member.\n\nPenns Manor Area and Marion Center Area school districts -- which both border Indiana Area School District -- have had whooping cough cases, too. The 4th school district is Blairsville-Saltsburg School District, which straddles both Indian and Westmoreland counties.\n\nThe free, walk-in vaccination clinic will be administering the 'Tdap' vaccination shot -- for tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis -- from 2 to 6 pm [Thu 5 Dec 2019] at the Indiana County State Health Center, 75 N Main St, Indiana.\n\nThe state is encouraging anyone from 10 to 64 years old in the county to take advantage of the clinic, particularly anyone who is pregnant or works or lives with or around pregnant women or infants, who are the most susceptible to the worst effects of whooping cough.\n\nBut the vaccine's potency can fade after that without an adolescent or adult booster shot. That may be what explains the outbreak's spread in Indiana County, which has one of the highest vaccination rates in the state for the Tdap vaccine at 97.6% for kindergartners and 99% for 12th graders, but a lower 88.8 % rate for the county's 8th graders. Indiana Area's 6 or 7 cases have all been of students who had previously been vaccinated, though they may not have been vaccinated since kindergarten.\n\n'There does appear to be a gap for students there between kindergarten and 12th grade who are headed to college,' said Nate Wardle, a department of health spokesman. 'That could be a sign of where this is coming from.' High school senior vaccination levels may jump because they are preparing to head to colleges and universities, which require tetanus shots, which means they would probably get the whole Tdap booster then, Mr Wardle said.\n\nHow it spread across 4 school districts is still being studied, Mr Wardle said, though some of the earliest cases could have been kids at the same movie, mall, vocational technology center, or some other gathering point. 'We don't have any information as to what the exact cause was yet,' he said. Mr Heinrich said Indiana Area has tried to piece together what put their cases in common, too. 'We couldn't find a pattern whether it was a group of wrestlers, cheerleaders, or some specific building,' he said.\n\nMr Wardle said the last outbreak like this occurred 3 years ago, during the same time of year, with a similar number of cases, and also among school kids, in Chambersburg, Franklin County.\n\nThe district has responded to each case with letters home to all of the students' families in the buildings where the students attended -- the district has had cases in 4 of its 6 buildings so far -- providing basic information about the disease and listing a contact number for the state health department.\n\nThe district also specifically reached out to the families of students who were either immuocompromised or not yet vaccinated to warn them again of the dangers of staying unvaccinated. Though state law says in cases like this the school district may exclude unvaccinated students, the district has not yet done that.\n\nBut once a student or the one faculty member was confirmed with whooping cough, they were told to stay home at least 15 days from the onset of symptoms, or for 5 days after they began taking antibiotics, which is included in the state law, too.\n\nThe district had all of the cases closer to the beginning of the year, but has one unconfirmed case still being investigated from just last week, Mr. Heinrich said. 'The state told us it's not unusual to have a few cases every now and then around the state,' he said. 'But this many in this area is unusual.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indiana, with a population was 13 975 residents in 2010, is the county seat of Indiana County in the U.S. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and is part of the Pittsburgh metropolitan area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana,_Pennsylvania). A map showing the location of Indiana can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Indiana,+PA. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31419>]\n\n******\n[6] Virginia (Shenandoah Valley)\nDate: Mon 9 Dec 2019\nSource: WSLS 10 News [edited]\nhttps://www.wsls.com/news/2019/12/09/whooping-cough-on-the-rise-in-shenandoah-valley/\n\n\nA highly contagious respiratory infection is on the rise in parts of the Shenandoah Valley. Authorities say in certain parts of the area there's more than 100 reported cases of pertussis or whooping cough.\n\nCentral Shenandoah Health District says they've had about 134 case investigations over the past week, a big increase over their usual number this time of year.\n\nThe outbreak is in Waynesboro and Staunton.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Waynesboro, with a population of 21 006 residents in 2010, (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waynesboro,_Virginia) and Staunton, with a population of 23 746 residents in 2010, (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staunton,_Virginia) are independent cities about 12 miles apart, located in the Shenandoah Valley in between the Blue Ridge and Allegheny Mountains within Augusta County in the Commonwealth of Virginia. A map showing the location of Waynesboro and Staunton can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Augusta+County,+VA. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Virginia, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25001]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Queensland, located in the northeast of the country, is the 2nd-largest and 3rd-most populous state in Australia, with a population of 5 million residents in 2018 that is concentrated along the coast, particularly in the state's South East, where Brisbane, the capital and largest city in the state is located (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queensland). ' \n\nThe state is encouraging anyone from 10 to 64 years old in the county to take advantage of the clinic, particularly anyone who is pregnant or works or lives with or around pregnant women or infants, who are the most susceptible to the worst effects of whooping cough. \n\nBut once a student or the one faculty member was confirmed with whooping cough, they were told to stay home at least 15 days from the onset of symptoms, or for 5 days after they began taking antibiotics, which is included in the state law, too. \n\n'Whooping cough vaccination during pregnancy boosts maternal antibodies, which are transferred to the foetus through the placenta, providing some immunity to the newborn baby until they can receive their 1st dose of vaccine around 6 weeks of age.' Pertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6584396", "date": "2019-07-24 10:17:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (08): AMERICAS, EUROPE, AUSTRALIA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Pertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia, corr. 20190725.6586026\nThe report below stating that California is having a pertussis epidemic was published in 2014 when there actually was an epidemic. California is not currently experiencing a pertussis epidemic. ProMED-mail regrets the error. - Mod.ML]\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (California)\n[2] USA (Blaine County, Montana)\n[3] Canada (Sudbury, Ontario)\n\nEurope\n---\n[4] UK (Northern Ireland)\n[5] France (Burgundy-Franche-Comt\u00e9/Dijon)\n\nAustralia\n---\n[6] Queensland (South West)\n\n******\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (California)\nDate: Sun 16 Jun 2019\nSource: The Daily Journal, City News Service [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.smdailyjournal.com/news/local/health-officials-warn-of-state-wide-whooping-cough-epidemic/article_9139f5b3-fe29-5708-a279-5129cca30418.htm\n\n\nCalifornia is currently experiencing a whooping cough [pertussis] epidemic, according to the California Department of Public Health. Public health officials said more than 800 new cases have been reported in the last 2 weeks.\n\nSome 3458 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the health department this year as of June 10 2019 - more cases than were reported in all of 2013, according to department officials.\n\nHealth officials said whooping cough is cyclical and that cases peak every 3 to 5 years. The last peak was in 2010, so this year [2019] could be another peak year, officials say.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[California, with a population of about 40 million residents, is the most populous U.S. state in the Pacific Region; its $3.0 trillion economy is the largest sub-national economy in the world, larger than the United Kingdom, France, or India (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California). A map showing the location of California can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/California. Mod.ML]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204\n\n******\n[2] USA (Blaine County, Montana)\nDate: Thu 20 Jun 2019 6:56 PM MDT\nSource KRTV, MTN News [edited]\nhttps://krtv.com/news/montana-and-regional-news/2019/06/20/whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-blaine-county/\n\n\nReports of whooping cough cases in Blaine County were confirmed by local health officials Thursday afternoon [20 Jun 2019].\n\nIn a media release posted to the Blaine County Health Department Facebook page [https://www.facebook.com/blainecountyhealthdepartment/photos/a.1541451082808457/2406512599635630], an official with the department corroborated that several cases had been reported in the county. According to the release, the department is currently working with local healthcare providers 'to identify and appropriately treat cases and contacts based on recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and the Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services (DPHHS).'\n\nBlaine County includes the town of Chinook and is adjacent to Hill and Choteau counties. It has a population size of over 6600.\n\n370 cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, have been identified in the state of Montana since 1 Jan 2019, Montana DPHHS data shows. That number is up from 28 reported whooping cough cases by this time in 2018. According to the Montana DPHHS website, 17 counties have reported cases of whooping cough so far this year.\n\nThe most up-to-date information listed on the Montana DPHHS website [https://dphhs.mt.gov/Portals/85/publichealth/documents/CDEpi/StatisticsandReports/CurrentActivity/MontanaPertussisSummary.pdf] confirms 3 cases of whooping cough in Blaine County. An official with Blaine County Health Department would not, however, specify as to the exact number of confirmed cases in the area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Blaine County, with a population of 6491 residents in 2010, is located on the northern border of the US state of Montana. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population was 6491. A map showing the location of Blaine County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Blaine+County,+MT. Mod.ML]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Montana: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/33919]\n\n******\n[3] Canada (Sudbury, Ontario)\nDate: Fri 14 Jun 2019 2:33 PM ET\nSource: CBC [edited]\nhttps://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/whooping-cough-health-unit-1.5176145\n\n\nThe Sudbury Health Unit is alerting the public to increased reports of whooping cough in the area. 12 whooping cough, or pertussis infections have been reported so far in 2019, Public Health Sudbury & Districts said in a press release. The health unit said the disease goes unreported, especially among teens and adults who don't often seek health care for symptoms.\n\nThe health unit adds that infections tend to occur in cycles, with peaks occurring every 2 to 5 years. The last local peak in the Sudbury area was 2015, when 27 cases were reported.\n\nVaccinations are offered free of charge to infants, children, and adolescents, the health unit said, and is required for school attendance. Fully vaccinated adults can still get the infection due to decreased immunity over time, however, are unlikely to experience severe symptoms.\n\nFor more information about pertussis and vaccination, visit https://www.phsd.ca or call Public Health Sudbury & Districts at 705.522.9200 (toll-free 1.866.522.9200) ext. 301.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ontario is sometimes conceptually divided into 2 regions, Northern Ontario and Southern Ontario. Sudbury, officially called Greater Sudbury, with a population of 161 531 in 2016, is a city in Northern Ontario. A map showing the location of Sudbury can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Greater+Sudbury,+ON,+Canada. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ontario, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29468]\n\nEurope\n---\n[4] UK (Northern Ireland)\nDate: Tue 25 Jun 2019\nSource: Belfast Telegraph [edited]\nhttps://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/annual-cases-of-whooping-cough-almost-trebles-in-northern-ireland-38249413.html\n\n\nNorthern Ireland has seen a significant increase this year in cases of whooping cough. The Public Health Agency (PHA) recorded 44 cases to [19 Jun 2019], compared to 16 reported during the same period last year [2018].\n\nJust over 1/5 were in infants under 6 months of age and so too young to be protected by their routine childhood immunisations. The PHA urged pregnant women here to receive the vaccine between 16 and 32 weeks of their pregnancy.\n\nA spokesman said: 'Whooping cough continues to circulate in Northern Ireland and every 3 to four 4 it is normal to see increased activity, which is what we are experiencing this year [2019]. It is therefore really important that women receive the pertussis vaccine during every pregnancy so that their baby is protected against whooping cough in their 1st months of life.'\n\n[Byline: Christopher Leebody]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Northern Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/197]\n\n******\n[5] France (Burgundy-Franche-Comte/Dijon)\nDate: Wed 3 Jul 2019 22:44 CEST\nSource: Le Bien Public [in French, trans. Corr SB, edited]\nhttps://www.bienpublic.com/cote-d-or/2019/07/03/fontaine-les-dijon-plusieurs-cas-de-coqueluche-confirmes\n\n\nThis Wednesday morning [3 Jul 2019], several parents in Cote-d'Or [Burgundy-Franche-Comte/Dijon] attending a welcoming ceremony for children in the institutions infancy and schools of Fontaine-les-Dijon received a briefing note from the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of Burgundy-Franche-Comte (BFC). This message indicated that 'several cases of whooping cough have been reported for children attending a kindergarten school in Fontaine-les-Dijon, some of whom attend the Les Saverney leisure center. This bacterial respiratory disease is very contagious and likely to cause complications, especially in the most fragile (infants, people with respiratory diseases. or immunosuppressed). It requires the implementation of measures to prevent its spread.\n\nThe ARS BFC added that as a precaution, it advised parents to: 'Check, with the help of your doctor, that your child is well vaccinated against whooping cough and if necessary, have the vaccine updated by the doctor; Check with your doctor if your child has a cough by reporting this situation of group cases of whooping cough.'\n\nIn detail, the ARS BFC, contacted on this subject on [Wed 3 Jul 2019], told us that 'since the end of May [2019], 9 confirmed cases of pertussis' have been reported to him 'among the students of the nursery school of the Portfolios of Fontaine-les-Dijon and Les Saverney leisure center. The institution continued: 'Children have benefited from medical treatment adapted to this respiratory disease caused by a bacterium, responsible for frequent and prolonged coughing spells. No cases have been reported in other schools or recreation of Fontaine-les-Dijon.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fontaine-les-Dijon, with a population of 9123 in 2016, is a commune in the Dijon arrondissement, Cote-d'Or department, Bourgogne-Franche-Comte region in eastern France, 317 km (197 miles) southeast of Paris (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fontaine-les-Dijon). A map showing the location of Fontaine-les-Dijon can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/21121+Fontaine-l\u00e8s-Dijon,+France. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/65161\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[6] Queensland (South West)\nDate: Tue 23 Jul 2019 8:24 AM\nSource: Balonne Beacon [edited]\nhttps://www.balonnebeacon.com.au/news/worst-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-years-spreads-aro/3786696/\n\n\nDoctors across the southwest are on alert as the region suffers its worst outbreak of whooping cough in recent history. So far this year [2019], the South West Hospital and Health Service has come across 21 cases of whooping cough (pertussis), up from zero cases in 2017 and only 3 by this time last year [2018].\n\nMost of the outbreaks have been in schools around the southwest, and cases have been recorded in schools on the Darling Downs as well.\n\n'Symptoms of whooping cough vary but typically start out like a cold with a runny nose with sneezing, tiredness, and characteristic coughing bouts developing over several days,' Darling Downs Public Health Unit acting director Dr Katie Panaretto said. 'In teens and adults, the infection may cause a persistent cough, but for babies and young children, whooping cough can be life-threatening.'\n\n'If you or a family member have these symptoms, it's important to go to the GP or local health centre and be tested,' Dr Panaretto said. 'Call ahead to explain you think you might have whooping cough and follow any infection control measures you're advised of. In the meantime, stay away from others, particularly babies who aren't protected until they have received 3 vaccinations at 6 months of age, and pregnant women.'\n\nIn response to the spike in both diseases, health authorities are reminding every resident to make sure their vaccinations are up to date. The whooping cough vaccine is still offered through the National Immunisation Program, meaning pregnant women, and children of certain ages can get the jabs for free. 'Since this program was introduced to Australia, there has been a drop in severe disease and deaths from whooping cough,' Dr Panaretto said.\n\n[Byline: Jorja McDonnell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South West Queensland is a remote region, noted for its cattle grazing, cotton farming, opal mining, and oil and gas deposits, in the Australian state of Queensland, south of Central West Queensland and west of the Darling Downs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_West_Queensland). Darling Downs is a farming region on the western slopes of the Great Dividing Range in southern Queensland, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darling_Downs). A map of the regions of Queensland can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darling_Downs#/media/File:Qld_region_map_2.PNG. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Queensland, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5377]", "summary": "No cases have been reported in other schools or recreation of Fontaine-les-Dijon.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fontaine-les-Dijon, with a population of 9123 in 2016, is a commune in the Dijon arrondissement, Cote-d'Or department, Bourgogne-Franche-Comte region in eastern France, 317 km (197 miles) southeast of Paris (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fontaine-les-Dijon). are experiencing this year [2019].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-01 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-06-20 00:00:00", "6491-03-25 (USA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6677444", "date": "2019-09-18 10:31:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (09): AMERICAS (USA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Montana (Missoula County)\n[2] Michigan (Upper Peninsula)\n[3] Alabama\n[4] Montana\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Montana (Missoula County)\nDate: Wed 7 Aug 2019\nSource: KPAX [edited]\nhttps://www.kpax.com/news/missoula-county/missoula-area-whooping-cough-outbreak-continues\n\n\nA few months [ago] parts of Western Montana were dealing with a whooping cough outbreak. The Missoula City-County Health Department even had to hire extra nurses to handle the rising number of cases. The outbreak is continuing with local health officials saying that the numbers are still rising.\n\nLocal health officials said back in the spring [2019] that they expected the pertussis cases to slow down during summer break. But now, they say that even more cases are coming in -- with the most recent one reported Monday [5 Aug 2019].\n\n'There's a little bit of a concern that it's still around, and that we have had some cases,' said Cindy Farr with the Missoula City-County Health Department. 'More of our cases that we've seen through the summer ... were not directly linked to other cases of pertussis, which is telling me that we still are seeing it in the community.'\n\nMTN News reported in May [2019] that there were 125 confirmed cases of pertussis in the Missoula area. That number has since risen to 160 cases. Farr says they hired extra nurses to go to schools this spring -- and she's hoping they won't have to do that again.\n\n'A lot of kids are going in for their sports physicals right now, so this might be a good time to chat with your doctor about whooping cough,' Farr advised. 'And make sure that you're aware of what symptoms to watch out for in case we do see a resurgence of it once the school year starts.'\n\nFarr says babies should be vaccinated, and pregnant women, people between the ages of 10 and 12, and adults should receive the TDAP booster. She added that close contacts are the highest when children are in school. The TDAP vaccine takes 2 to 3 weeks to become effective, so she's encouraging parents to bring their children in before classes start back up.\n\n[People] can contact the local health department at (406) 258-3363 for more information about immunizations. Vaccinations are available at the Missoula health department on West Alder Street. Most insurance plans are accepted, and they offer a sliding scale [for the] uninsured.\n\n[Byline: Katie Miller]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Missoula, with a population of 73 340 residents, is a city and county seat of Missoula County in the western part of the US state of Montana and is home to the University of Montana, a public research university (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missoula,_Montana). Missoula can be found on a map at https://goo.gl/maps/gQEPpFRmdrCRRo5J6. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Upper Peninsula)\nDate: Fri 16 Aug 2019\nSource Upper Michigan's Source [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.uppermichiganssource.com/content/news/Pertussis-546780941.html\n\n\nPertussis, known as whooping cough, is circulating in several UP [Upper Peninsula of the US state of Michigan] communities, public health officials said Friday [16 Aug 2019].\n\nDr. Teresa Frankovich, the medical director of 4 Upper Michigan health departments, is asking that all UP adults check their immunization status and their children's immunization status. Frankovich says this is particularly important before kids head back to school, where it is even easier for pertussis to circulate.\n\nShe says there have been 10 cases in the past month or so, and 80% of the cases have been in children. Cases have occurred in the Dickinson-Iron, Delta-Menominee and Marquette County Health Department districts. Most medical providers and all health departments have vaccine on hand.\n\nFrankovich notes that children normally receive the DTaP vaccine, which provides protection against pertussis, at 2, 4, 6 and 12-15 months of age, and a booster dose at 4-6 years of age. 'Some parents may not realize that another booster dose (called Tdap), is now required for children at 11 years of age. This one-time booster is also recommended for adults who have not had a pertussis vaccine since childhood and is recommended for pregnant women with each pregnancy.' Frankovich said.\n\n'Because young infants are at highest risk for serious disease with pertussis, it is particularly important that expectant or new parents be vaccinated as well as grandparents and others who have close contact with young children.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Upper Peninsula (UP) is the northern of the 2 major peninsulas that make up the US state of Michigan; the UP is bounded on the north by Lake Superior, on the east by Ontario, Canada, on the south by Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, and on the west by northeastern Wisconsin; the Mackinac Bridge connects the Lower Peninsula of Michigan with the UP (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Peninsula_of_Michigan). There are 15 counties in the UP, which include Dickinson, Iron, Delta, Menominee and Marquette. A map of Michigan counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/michigan.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Alabama\nDate: Wed 21 Aug 2019\nSource: WDHN [edited]\nhttps://www.dothanfirst.com/life-health/health/cases-of-whooping-cough-confirmed-at-extendicare/\n\n\nThe Extendicare Health and Rehabilitation Center has confirmed cases of the bacterial infection known as the 'whooping cough.' 'We have a few confirmed cases here at the Extendicare, and there [have] been cases in Houston and Henry County,' said Shenika Ford, Extendicare Administrator.\n\nCases of pertussis, better known as whooping cough, are popping up in the Wiregrass. Extendicare Health Center said they are working closely to end the spread of whooping cough. 'We [are] working closely with Geneva Alabama Department of Public Health to contain the spread of whooping cough,' she said.\n\nWhooping cough does not only affect children but teenagers and adults as well. If an affected person coughs or sneezes, the bacteria spread within a matter of seconds.\n\n[Byline: Donna Williams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Extendicare is a rehabilitation facility with 78 private and 30 semi-private rooms for long-term care residents and 32 private skilled nursing beds located in Dothan, Alabama (https://www.extendicarehealth.com/rehabilitation/). Dothan, with a population of 65 496 at the 2010 census, is near the state's southeastern corner, approximately 20 miles (32 km) west of the Georgia state line and 16 miles (26 km) north of Florida state line (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dothan,_Alabama). A map showing the location of Dothan can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Dothan,+AL. Dothan is the county seat of Houston County, which is adjacent to Henry and Geneva counties. A map of Alabama counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/alabama.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Montana\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2019\nSource: Havre Daily News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.havredailynews.com/story/2019/08/27/local/whooping-cough-diagnosed-in-hill-county/525128.html\n\n\nPertussis -- better known as whooping cough -- has swept across the state, with health departments diagnosing almost 12 times as many cases as last year [2018] at this time, and 2 cases have been diagnosed in Hill County by the end of last week [24 Aug 2019], Hill County Health Department Kim Larson said.\n\n'Right now, Montana has 442 cases of pertussis this year [2019],' she said. 'At the same time last year we only had 37 in the state of Montana, so there is a big increase this year.'\n\nIn recent months, Blaine County has diagnosed 13 cases of pertussis; Liberty and Chouteau counties have each diagnosed 1; and Havre, 2 cases, the Montana Department of Health and Human Services website says. It added that Missoula County leads the state with 165 cases.\n\nBlaine and Chouteau county health departments were unavailable for comment as of [the] print deadline today [27 Aug 2019], but the Health and Human Services site shows no new cases reported in those counties since the Havre Daily News' last story on the issue [23 Jul 2019]. Liberty County Health Nurse Melissa Kantorowicz said the county has not had any new cases diagnosed since that date. Larson said the Hill County Health Department has its nursing staff investigating the cases. She added that the nursing staff has already contacted people whom they are monitoring for symptoms.\n\nWhooping cough is not normally diagnosed this time of year, she said, but with the school year starting and several other counties having diagnosed cases, people could have contracted the disease from multiple places and at any time.\n\nLarson said if people have any other questions, they can call the Hill County Health Department at 400-2415.\n\n[Byline: Derek Hann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Montana, with a population of about 1.06 million residents in 2018, is a state in the northwestern USA, bordered by Idaho to the west, Wyoming to the south, North Dakota and South Dakota to the east, and the Canadian provinces of British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan to the north (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montana). Blaine, Liberty, Chouteau and Hill counties are located in north-central Montana, and Missoula in western Montana; Havre is the county seat of Hill County. A map of Montana counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/montana.shtml. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nMontana, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228\nMichigan, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225\nAlabama, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/205]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nMontana, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228\nMichigan, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225\nAlabama, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/205] Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Missoula, with a population of 73 340 residents, is a city and county seat of Missoula County in the western part of the US state of Montana and is home to the University of Montana, a public research university (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missoula,_Montana). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Montana, with a population of about 1.06 million residents in 2018, is a state in the northwestern USA, bordered by Idaho to the west, Wyoming to the south, North Dakota and South Dakota to the east, and the Canadian provinces of British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan to the north (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montana). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Upper Peninsula (UP) is the northern of the 2 major peninsulas that make up the US state of Michigan; the UP is bounded on the north by Lake Superior, on the east by Ontario, Canada, on the south by Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, and on the west by northeastern Wisconsin; the Mackinac Bridge connects the Lower Peninsula of Michigan with the UP (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Peninsula_of_Michigan). \n\n'Because young infants are at highest risk for serious disease with pertussis, it is particularly important that expectant or new parents be vaccinated as well as grandparents and others who have close contact with young children.'\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Extendicare is a rehabilitation facility with 78 private and 30 semi-private rooms for long-term care residents and 32 private skilled nursing beds located in Dothan, Alabama (https://www.extendicarehealth.com/rehabilitation/). \n\n\nPertussis -- better known as whooping cough -- has swept across the state, with health departments diagnosing almost 12 times as many cases as last year [2018] at this time, and 2 cases have been diagnosed in Hill County by the end of last week \n\nWhooping cough is not normally diagnosed this time of year, she said, but with the school year starting and several other counties having diagnosed cases, people could have contracted the disease from multiple places and at any time. \n\nIn recent months, Blaine County has diagnosed 13 cases of pertussis; Liberty and Chouteau counties have each diagnosed 1; and Havre, 2 cases, the Montana Department of Health and Human Services website says. ' USA\n---\n \n\nCases of pertussis, better known as whooping cough, are popping up in the Wiregrass. \n\n'There's a little bit of a concern that it's still around, and that we have had some cases,' said Cindy Farr with the Missoula City-County Health Department. ' https://www.uppermichiganssource.com/content/news/Pertussis-546780941.html\n\n\nPertussis, known as whooping cough, is circulating in several UP [Upper Peninsula of the US state of Michigan] communities, public health officials said Friday [16 Aug 2019]. Frankovich notes that children normally receive the DTaP vaccine, which provides protection against pertussis, at 2, 4, 6 and 12-15 months of age, and a booster dose at 4-6 years of age. "6814919", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (12): Americas (Canada, USA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6814919", "date": "2019-12-03 12:33:48", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (12): AMERICAS (CANADA, USA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nCanada\n---\n[1] Ontario (Timiskaming)\nUSA\n---\n[2] Illinois (Ogle County)\n[3] Pennsylvania (Lehigh County)\n[4] Pennsylvania (Delaware County)\n[5] Ohio (Springboro)\n[6] Oregon (Clackamas County)\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[1] Ontario (Timiskaming)\nDate: Mon 11 Nov 2019 2:15 PM EST\nSource: Northern News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.northernnews.ca/news/local-news/thu-investigating-whooping-cough-cases-in-temiskaming-shores\n\n\nThe Timiskaming Health Unit is investigating 7 cases of whooping cough (pertussis), with exposures at Ecole Catholique Sainte-Croix, Ecole Catholique St-Michel, and Ecole Secondaire Catholique Sainte-Marie. Public Health Nurses are contacting parents and guardians of students who have the highest risk of exposure.\n\nCheck with your health care provider or the Timiskaming Health Unit to ensure you and your family are up to date on your whooping cough (pertussis) vaccination. The vaccine is free in Canada and part of the routine immunization schedule for infants, children, and teenagers. The vaccine is given at 2, 4, 6, and 18 months of age. A booster dose is needed between 4 and 6 years of age and again at 14-16 years of age. Immunity decreases over time, therefore one booster dose of vaccine is recommended for adults. You may review your immunization record online at (http://timiskaminghu.com/281/Immunization).\n\nPregnant or immunocompromised individuals should follow-up with their healthcare provider to confirm their history of vaccination against whooping cough (pertussis). A booster of the pertussis vaccine is recommended for all pregnant women in their 3rd trimester.\n\nIf you develop symptoms of whooping cough in the next 21 days, please follow-up with your healthcare provider and notify the Timiskaming Health Unit. For further information or if you have any comments or concerns, please call the Timiskaming Health Unit at 705-647-4305 or toll free at 1-866-747-4305.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Timiskaming, with a population of 32 251 residents in 2016, is a district in northeastern part of the Canadian province of Ontario, just west of the similarly-named Temiscamingue county in Quebec (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District). A map showing the location of Timiskaming can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Timiskaming+District,+ON,+Canada. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ontario, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62149]\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[2] Illinois (Ogle County)\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019 5:44 PM CST\nSource: WIFR [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.wifr.com/content/news/Ogle-County-investigates-pertussis-outbreak-at-Oregon-High-School-564864322.html\n\n\nThe Ogle County Health Department is investigating a pertussis outbreak at Oregon High School. The department says there are 8 positive cases of whooping cough at Oregon High School. Health officials are working with the school to prevent the further spread of the disease.\n\nFor more on the outbreak, contact the Ogle County Health Department at 815-562-6976.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ogle County, with a population of 53 497 residents in 2010, is located in the US state of Illinois; its county seat is Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ogle_County,_Illinois). A map showing the location of Ogle County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ogle+County,+IL. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Illinois, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46919]\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania (Lehigh County)\nDate: Thu 14 Nov 2019 5:33 PM EST\nSource: The Morning Call [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.mcall.com/news/local/east-penn/mc-nws-east-penn-whooping-cough-20191114-dd326itnmjf7pge6rx72fzipwq-story.html\n\n\nEast Penn students in elementary, middle, and high schools have been diagnosed with pertussis, or whooping cough, the district informed parents in a letter [Thu 14 Nov 2019].\n\nThe letters were sent to the parents of students at Emmaus High School, Lower Macungie Middle School, and Wescosville and Shoemaker elementary schools. They noted that a student in the school was diagnosed with pertussis and was under a physician's care. 'At this time, there is not an ongoing public health threat,' said Brittany Lauffer, a spokeswoman for the state Health Department.\n\nDistrict spokeswoman Laura Groh said in an email that at least one of the infected students was fully vaccinated. 'Just because students get the vaccination, does not guarantee they will not get it,' she wrote. Pertussis vaccines are effective but not perfect, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nLehigh County has the highest rates of pertussis in the state, according to the Health Department -- 30.5 pertussis cases per 100 000 people, according to 2015 to 2017 data posted on the department's website. Northampton County had a lower rate, at 11.5 cases per 100 000 people.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lehigh County, with a population of 349 497 residents in 2010, is located in the Lehigh Valley region of the U.S. state of Pennsylvania; its county seat is Allentown, the state's 3rd-largest city behind Philadelphia and Pittsburgh (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lehigh_County,_Pennsylvania). The East Penn School District is a public school district in Lehigh County that operates one high school (Emmaus High School), 2 middle schools (Eyer Middle School and Lower Macungie Middle School), and 7 elementary schools (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Penn_School_District). A map showing the location of the East Penn School District can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/East+Penn+School+District,+PA. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240\n\n******\n[4] Pennsylvania (Delaware County)\nDate: Sun 24 Nov 2019\nSource: Daily Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.delcotimes.com/news/wallingford-swarthmore-battles-outbreak-of-whooping-cough/article_d7a3bc0a-0ee1-11ea-a498-b797ac65639e.html\n\n\nWallingford-Swarthmore School District officials are urging parents and caregivers to be on the lookout for any signs of whooping cough, a highly contagious respiratory disease. The precautionary notices were issued based on 7 confirmed cases of the disease involving district students since the start of 2019.\n\nOn [15 Nov 2019], the principals of several schools, including Strath Haven high school and middle school and Swarthmore-Rutledge Elementary School, advised families their children could have been exposed to whooping cough, also known as pertussis. That was followed by a broader notice from Superintendent Lisa Palmer on [22 Nov 2019] providing additional details about the situation. 'All of the confirmed cases are under the care of their physicians,' she wrote. 'We have been assured that they are either in process of completing the appropriate course of antibiotics or have already done so. Confirmed cases of pertussis have increased nationally over the past few years. Our district's identified cases are reflective of this national increase.'\n\nPrior to wide availability of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s, roughly 200 000 children were sickened with the disease each year, resulting in about 9000 fatalities, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Now, the number of cases reported annually in the US ranges from 10 000 to 40 000. In 2017, for example, the CDC reported there were 18 975 cases and 13 fatalities in a nation of more than 330 million. A recent peak year for whooping cough was 2012 when there were 48 277 cases identified in the US -- the largest number since 1955 when there were 62 786.\n\n'Since learning of each confirmed case, we have worked closely with the PA [Pennsylvania] Department of Health to ensure that all procedures and protocols related to pertussis are implemented,' Palmer stated, adding that the district has stepped up its cleaning and is using a disinfectant known to be effective against the disease.\n\n[Byline: Neil A Sheehan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wallingford-Swarthmore School District is a suburban public school district, consisting of as one high school, one middle school, and 3 elementary schools, in south-eastern Delaware County, Pennsylvania in the United States that serves the boroughs of Swarthmore, Rose Valley and Rutledge, and the township of Nether Providence (Wallingford), with a population of 21 430 residents, including 3539 pupils (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallingford-Swarthmore_School_District). A map showing the location of the Wallingford-Swarthmore School District can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Wallingford-Swarthmore+School+District,+PA. - Mod.ML\n\n\n******\n[5] Ohio (Springboro)\nDate: Fri 15 Nov 2019\nSource: WKRC Local 12 [abridged, edited]\nhttps://local12.com/health/medical-edge-reports/infection-control-specialists-warning-of-whooping-cough-spreading-in-tri-state\n\n\nThere are new concerns as a highly contagious illness spreads in the Tri-State [Cincinnati metropolitan area, including Ohio, Kentucky, and Indiana].\n\nCases of pertussis, or whooping cough, are rapidly spreading. Springboro Schools sent a letter home to parents saying 26 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed at the schools so far. 17 of them have been treated and those students have been released to go back to school.\n\nSpringboro Schools spokesman Scott Marshall said those treated stayed home for at least 5 days, but they want to let the community know that they are recommending vaccinations for families because to very young children and also to older adults, this illness can be life-threatening.\n\n[Byline: Liz Bonis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Springboro, with a population of 17 409 residents in 2010, is an affluent suburb of Cincinnati and Dayton that is located mostly in Warren County in the US state of Ohio (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springboro,_Ohio). The Springboro School district operates 6 schools serving approximately 6000 students: Clearcreek Elementary, Dennis Elementary, Five Points Elementary, Springboro Intermediate, Springboro Junior High School, and Springboro High Schools (http://www.springboro.org/AboutUs.aspx). A map showing the location of Springboro can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Springboro,+OH. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ohio, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3590]\n\n******\n[6] Oregon (Clackamas County)\nDate: Wed 20 Nov 2019\nSource: West Linn Tidings [abridged, edited]\nhttps://pamplinmedia.com/wlt/109-education/444106-358759-pertussis-cases-on-rise\n\n\nClackamas County health officials see twice as many with whooping cough this year [2019] than they did in 2018. More than 46 cases of pertussis have been reported in the county this year [2019] and 2 in West Linn.\n\nWith cold and flu season officially underway, health officials in Clackamas County and the tri-county region [Clackamas, Multnomah, and Washington counties] have observed an uptick in cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, since July [2019].\n\nAs of the week of [4 Nov 2019], between 45-50 cases of pertussis have been reported to the county, which is double the number of cases [in 2019 than] last year [2018].\n\nOf those, most have been school-age children. On [7 Nov 2019], the Clackamas Community Health Division released a statement to West Linn High School students citing a case of pertussis.\n\n'There have been a few cases, I believe, at West Linn High School and there have been a number of cases at several high schools in the county and in the region,' said Dr Sarah Present, a Clackamas County health officer. [On 20 Nov 2019] the district announced another case at Bolton Primary School.\n\n'We are in a hot year for pertussis and we know that we have a communitywide spread of it, and we actually have more cases of it in Clackamas than we do in the other 2 counties (Multnomah and Washington) in our region with which we share data.'\n\nAccording to Present, pertussis is unusual in that it is hard to initially diagnose because its earliest symptoms are the same as the common cold. It isn't until the 2nd week of infection that more aggressive symptoms begin to manifest. 'Whooping cough does follow 3- to 5-year waves, and we're at a time to have an uptick in pertussis. The amount that we've had, in Clackamas County, in particular, has been the most we've had in many, many years,' Present said.\n\n'And it is at many elementary schools and middle schools. But when we have a case that's seen at a school, we know that those are places where kids, many of whom are going to be susceptible to getting it, are in close contact with other kids, so it's a high-risk for transmission place,' she said. 'When we do have cases, we want to make sure that the whole school community that could have been exposed to know that they could have been exposed.'\n\n'There are a few misconceptions or misperceptions about pertussis that are important to know,' Present said. 'One thing we have noticed is that while the pertussis vaccine is a recommended health vaccine and most people are vaccinated, and it is absolutely the best way of protecting against pertussis, it's not 100% and the immunity does wane over time. So, we recommend a pertussis booster around 11 or 12 years old, and not as many people get that booster.'\n\nPresent stressed that getting the vaccine is by far the best way to protect against contracting pertussis, but she also said everyone's immunities are different and having been vaccinated is not a protection guarantee. In order to protect other students and the community, Present recommends those who have been exposed to pertussis to stay home if they start to show signs of getting sick, even if they are mild, and to get tested by a healthcare provider. If a case is confirmed, County officials caution that the patient should stay home until they've completed a full course of antibiotics.\n\n[Byline: Claire Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Clackamas County, with a population of 375 992 residents in 2010, is in the US state of Oregon and is part of the Portland-Vancouver-Hillsboro, OR-WA Metropolitan Statistical Area; Multnomah and Washington are adjacent counties (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clackamas_County,_Oregon). A map showing the location of Clackamas County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Clackamas+County,+OR. not 100% and the immunity does wane over time.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": Europe, Americas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6520307", "date": "2019-06-14 12:40:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (07): EUROPE, AMERICAS\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nEurope\n---\n[1] England (Northumbria)\n[2] Spain (Valencia)\n\nAmericas\n---\n[3] USA (Maine)\n[4] USA (California): waning immunity after vaccination with DTaP\n[5] Canada (British Columbia)\n[6] Argentina (Cordoba)\n\n******\nEurope\n---\n[1] England (Northumbria)\nDate: Mon 3 Jun 2019 09:32 BST\nSource: Northumberland Gazette [edited]\nhttps://www.northumberlandgazette.co.uk/health/cases-of-whooping-cough-are-first-for-nhs-trust-1-9800077\n\n\nLast year [2018], 2 cases of whooping cough were identified by Northumbria Healthcare -- the 1st in its history and attributed to 'waning vaccination rates'. They were reported by Dr David Tate, director of infection prevention and control, as he presented his annual report for 2018-19 to the latest board meeting of the trust, which runs hospitals in Northumberland and North Tyneside.\n\nThe 2 unrelated incidents, which were also the 1st Dr Tate had seen in his career, were in November 2018 and March this year [2019], with one affecting a baby.\n\nIn response to a question from a board member, he said that Public Health England recognises that work needs to be done on the issues around social media and its impact on falling vaccination rates. However, there were a number of positives, with Dr Tate concluding: 'There's nothing I'm particularly concerned about, but obviously infection control is a constant and ongoing battle.'\n\n[Byline: Ben O'Connell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10158\nNorthumberland is the northernmost and the least densely populated county in England, bordering Cumbria to the west, the Scottish Borders to the north, and the North Sea to the east (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northumberland). A map showing the location of Northumberland can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/V2AwuJc7oyGToSeG9. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Spain (Valencia)\nDate: Wed 5 Jun 2019 19:02 CEST\nSource: La Vanguardia, Agencia EFE report [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.lavanguardia.com/local/valencia/20190605/462700160795/sanidad-detecta-un-brote-de-tosferina-en-requena-con-7-casos-confirmados.html\n\n\nThe Conselleria de Sanitat [Ministry of Health of the Generalitat Valenciana] has detected an outbreak of whooping cough in the town of Requena, which has affected 7 people aged between 10 and 44 years.\n\nAccording to sources from the Conselleria, the outbreak was declared on [27 May 2019] and to date there are 7 confirmed cases, although none have required hospitalization and all are evolving without complications.\n\nThe proceedings were initiated that same day, with the application of the protocol for pertussis surveillance and outbreak control, which includes recommendations for treatment and isolation of cases, and identification of contacts to review their vaccination status and administer prophylaxis antibiotic if applicable.\n\nThat same day, this information was also communicated to the school management so that they could send the parents an informative circular about whooping cough and its prevention, so that they could check the children's immunization status and contact their doctor or pediatrician in case of being high-risk contact.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kathryn Soderholm\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map Valencia, Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/65125\nRequena, with a population of about 22 000 residents in 2018, is a municipality in eastern Spain, in the province of Valencia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Requena,_Valencia). A map showing the location of Valencia can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Valencia#/media/File:Valencia_in_Spain.svg. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAmericas\n---\n[3] USA (Maine)\nDate: Fri 7 Jun 2019\nSource: Press Herald [edited]\nhttps://www.pressherald.com/2019/06/07/pertussis-cases-continue-to-increase-in-maine/\n\n\nMaine continues to experience a high rate of pertussis, with 39 new cases reported in May [2019] and a total of 208 cases so far this year [2019], well ahead of the 123 cases in the 1st 5 months of 2018, according to a report released [Fri 7 Jun 2019] by the Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nPertussis is a persistent public health problem in Maine, as the state has the worst per-capita pertussis rate in the nation. Maine's pertussis rate of 33.16 per 100 000 in 2018 was more than 8x the national average. Maine had 446 pertussis cases in 2018, but 2019 could eclipse last year, which was the worst year for pertussis since 2012.\n\nRecent outbreaks occurred at Portland schools in May [2019], as well as earlier this year [2019] at Falmouth High School and Thornton Academy in Saco. Schools have been the source of many outbreaks this year, and 51 percent of all cases in 2019 -- 106 of the 208 cases -- have occurred in those between the ages of 11 and 19.\n\nMeghan May, associate professor of microbiology at the University of New England, said low vaccination rates in Maine are 'absolutely' a contributing factor, but there doesn't seem to be any one reason that pertussis is a problem in comparison to other infectious diseases such as measles. 'It's a multifaceted problem with several different dynamics,' said May, who has researched pertussis. 'We don't know why it's pertussis here and not measles.'\n\nMaine is especially vulnerable to the return of infectious diseases such as pertussis, public health experts have said, because of the state's dangerously low levels of immunization rates in schools. Maine has consistently been among the worst in the nation for parents forgoing vaccines for non-medical reasons for students entering kindergarten, according to data from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe pertussis vaccine's effectiveness wanes, which is why pediatricians recommend a booster shot in middle school. Though Maine now requires the booster for incoming 7th-graders, it was among the last states in the nation to add the middle school booster, in 2017-18. And like all other school-required vaccines, parents can opt out of the pertussis booster or other immunizations for their children by signing a form. That will change for the 2021-22 school year.\n\nMaine lawmakers passed a bill this spring and Gov. Janet Mills signed into law a measure that, starting in 2021, would eliminate philosophic and religious exemptions to school-required vaccines. Maine had 5.6 percent of parents signing philosophic or religious exemptions to vaccines for children entering kindergarten in 2018-19, according to the Maine CDC. 43 elementary schools had 15 percent or higher non-medical opt-out rates, putting those schools at increased risk of infectious disease outbreaks. Peter Michaud, counsel for the Maine Medical Association, which represents doctors before the Legislature, said over time, the new law will improve vaccination rates and Maine's pertussis rate should decline. 'We are taking the steps that are available to us to protect Maine's children,' Michaud said. 'In the meantime, parents who have children who need their vaccines shouldn't wait until the law goes into effect. They can protect their children from contagions now.'\n\n[Byline: Joe Lawlor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map Maine, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/222\nMaine, with a population of about 1.34 million in 2018, is a state in the New England region of northeastern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maine). A map showing its location can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Portland,+ME. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] USA (California): waning immunity after vaccination with DTaP\nDate: Mon 10 Jun 2019\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Response and Policy) [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2019/06/whooping-cough-cases-tied-waning-vaccine-protection\n\n\nA child who has never been vaccinated against pertussis, or whooping cough, is 13 times more likely to suffer from an infection of _Bordetella pertussis_ than is a child who is up-to-date on his or her vaccines.\n\nBut new evidence from a decade-long study at Kaiser Permanente shows that vaccinated children were 5 times more likely to suffer from whooping cough if it had been more than 3 years since their last vaccine dose. The research was published today [10 Jun 20190] in Pediatrics [1].\n\nDTaP vaccine, which protects against pertussis, diphtheria, and tetanus, is given in 5 doses between the ages of 2 months and 6 years. In this study, researchers from Kaiser Permanente Northern California followed children born between 1999 and 2016 who were diagnosed as having whooping cough.\n\nThe researchers identified 738 pertussis cases, with 99 cases in unvaccinated children, 36 in under-vaccinated children, 515 in fully vaccinated children (5 DTaP doses), and 88 in children who had received 6 doses of DTaP.\n\nMore than 80% of cases occurred in fully vaccinated children. Children only partially vaccinated were 1.9 times more likely to contract whooping cough than fully vaccinated peers.\n\n'Although noncompliance with the vaccination schedule is an important public health problem that leads to increased pertussis risk, most children in our study received all their recommended DTaP doses,' the authors wrote. 'Our results reveal that waning of DTaP immunity was an important cause of pertussis in children.'\n\nIn 2010 and 2014, California experienced 2 large pertussis outbreaks, with more than 9000 cases each.\n\nThis is the 3rd study completed by this researcher group to provide evidence of waning pertussis immunity, and the authors said results are consistent with other recent data that showed the odds of pertussis increased by 33% for every additional year after the third or the fifth DTaP dose.\n\nKathryn Edwards, MD, of the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, said in a commentary on the study [2] that the waning efficacy is likely because DTaP is an acellular vaccine, which replaced a whole-cell vaccine, DTwP, in 1997. Whole-cell vaccines, Edwards explains, generate more protective T-cell responses. After the introduction of a whole-cell pertussis vaccine in the United States, annual rates of the disease dropped from 150 per 100 000 in the 1940s to 1 per 100 000 in the 1970s in the United States.\n\nThough efficacious, DTwP caused more reactions than DTaP, including febrile seizures and local injection-site reactions.\n\nDTwP is no longer available in the United States or other high-income countries, so other strategies to boost pertussis immunity must be explored, including maternal vaccination and an intranasal booster dose of the vaccine, Edwards said.\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Soucheray]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[References\n-----------\n1. Zerbo O, Bartlett J, Goddard K, et al. Acellular pertussis vaccine effectiveness over time. Pediatrics. 2019. pii: e20183466. doi: 10.1542/peds.2018-3466. [Epub ahead of print]; https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2019/06/06/peds.2018-3466\n2. Edwards KM. Challenges to Pertussis Control. Pediatrics. 2019. pii: e20191276. doi: 10.1542/peds.2019-1276. [Epub ahead of print]; https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2019/06/06/peds.2019-1276.long. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\n\n******\n[5] Canada (British Columbia)\nDate: Fri 7 Jun 2019 9:30 AM PDT\nSource: Williams Lake Tribune [edited]\nhttps://www.wltribune.com/news/majority-of-ihs-2019-whooping-cough-cases-in-thompson-cariboo/\n\n\nParents in the Williams Lake [British Columbia] area are being warned their children may have been exposed to pertussis, also known as whooping cough. School District 27 distributed letters from Interior Health [IH] this week [week of 3 Jun 2019] for parents outlining the symptoms and the fact pertussis can spread easily.\n\nThere have been about 30 cases throughout the IH region, and the majority of them have been in the Thompson-Cariboo so far in 2019, said Dr Karin Goodison, medical health officer with IH. 'What we know about pertussis is, it sort of goes through cycles,' Goodison said. 'Every 3 to 5 years we see more cases. Last year [2018] we did not see many at all, but in 2016 and 2017 we saw a lot of cases. In 2019 we are starting to see some clusters of cases so we are going to be keeping an eye on that.'\n\nVaccines are helpful in preventing pertussis, but they are not 100 per cent effective, Goodison added. 'Unfortunately it's one of our vaccines that doesn't work as well as some of our other vaccines. Your chances of getting pertussis are much lower if you are a vaccinated, but you still can get the infection if you are exposed to someone who has it, particularly if it's been quite a while since you were immunized.'\n\nPeople at the highest risk are those who are under the age of one [year] and pregnant women, Goodison said. 'When we are looking at offering pertussis immunization, our goal of the program is to protect those groups of people.'\n\nOverall in the Thompson-Cariboo, about 77 per cent of 2 year olds are up-to-date with pertussis immunizations and 74 per cent of 7 year olds, Goodison confirmed. 'That's pretty good, compared to the rest of Interior Health, but we would like to see it higher.'\n\nIf a person has had a persistent cough or been exposed to someone they know that has been diagnosed with pertussis, they should visit a care provider to get tested. 'We see a few more cases throughout the spring and summer typically, so it's kind of got a seasonal pattern. It's quite interesting to look at it over time. If you look back in 2016 and 2017, the Thompson-Cariboo Shuswap had a very similar rate of illness as it does right now.'\n\nWork is being done to develop a better vaccine, recognizing that the protection from pertussis is not as long lasting, she added. In Canada, children are immunized for pertussis under the age of 2 and again when they are in school.\n\n[Byline: Monica Lamb-Yorski]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of British Columbia, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18209\nThompson-Cariboo, with a population of 118 618 in 2011, is a federal electoral district in the province of British Columbia, Canada; about 3/4 of the population in this district live in the city of Kamloops (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamloops--Thompson--Cariboo). A map of Thompson-Cariboo can be found at https://www.elections.ca/res/cir/maps2/mapprov.asp?map=59013. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] Argentina (Cordoba)\nDate: Tue 11 Jun 2019\nSource: Filo News [in Spanish, machine trans., abbreviated, edited]\nhttps://www.filo.news/actualidad/Se-triplicaron-en-Cordoba-los-casos-de-tos-ferina-o-tos-convulsa-20190611-0013.html\n\n\nThe [Cordoba] Provincial Health Ministry has verified a total of 56 cases of whooping cough in 2019, caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, against the 19 registered in the same period last year [2018].\n\n64% of the cases correspond to children younger than 6 months whose mothers had not been vaccinated.\n\nThis year [2019], the outbreak of respiratory diseases came earlier, with more serious illnesses. And it not only has to do with the lack of vaccination but also with a specific issue of the germ that is mutating and there tend to be increased cases every 4 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kathryn Soderholm\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Argentina: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54247\nThe city of Cordoba, is the capital of Cordoba province and the 2nd most populous city in Argentina after Buenos Aires with a population of 1.33 million residents in 2010, in the geographic center of Argentina, about 700 km (435 mi) northwest of the Buenos Aires (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C\u00f3rdoba,_Argentina). earlier, with more serious illnesses.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-11-25 00:00:00", "1276-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25
