{"location": "Northumberland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6402556", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (03): Australia (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6402556", "date": "2019-04-03 17:29:40", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): AUSTRALIA (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Apr 2019\nSource: Camden Haven Courier [edited]\nhttps://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/5984322/health-warning-after-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nThe Port Macquarie-Hastings local government area has recorded a staggering 11 cases of whooping cough over the past 4 weeks. That is just under half the 23 cases for the Mid North Coast.\n\nThe Mid North Coast local health district has issued an urgent warning for all pregnant women and parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time. Children with symptoms should see a doctor. If a doctor diagnoses whooping cough in a school-aged child, parents should let their school know and keep their child at home until they have taken 5 days of antimicrobials.\n\n'Keep coughing children away from babies. Whooping cough vaccines give good protection against infection, but immunity fades. If your school-aged child has younger siblings, it's a good idea to check they are up-to-date with their vaccines,' said Greg Bell, acting director, North Coast Public Health Unit. Public health units can provide advice to schools managing whooping cough outbreaks.\n\nSymptoms can start like a cold, followed by a worsening cough that occurs in bouts; this may be followed by vomiting or 'whooping' breaths. The cough can last for many weeks and can be worse at night. Some newborns may not cough at all but may stop breathing or have difficulties feeding. Small babies can get very sick and may need treatment in a hospital.\n\n[Byline: Letitia Fitzpatrick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up-and-down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNew South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up-and-down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe Mid North Coast local health district has issued an urgent warning for all pregnant women and parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time. If a doctor diagnoses whooping cough in a school-aged child, parents should let their school know and keep their child at home until they have taken 5 days of antimicrobials. \n\nSymptoms can start like a cold, followed by a worsening cough that occurs in bouts; this may be followed by vomiting or 'whooping' breaths. PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): AUSTRALIA (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6495490", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (06): Canada, USA, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6495490", "date": "2019-05-31 05:20:09", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (06): CANADA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nCanada\n---\n[1] New Brunswick (Fredericton)\n\nUSA\n---\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\n[3] Montana (Lake County/Flathead Reservation)\n[4] Montana (Missoula County)\n[5] Maine (Portland)\n\nNew Zealand\n---\n[6] Gisborne\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[1] New Brunswick (Fredericton)\nDate: Tue 21 May 2019\nSource: CBC [edited]\nhttps://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/whooping-cough-fredericton-outbreak-immunization-clinics-1.5144046\n\n\nThere are now 22 confirmed cases of whooping cough in the greater Fredericton area, including 19 school-aged children from several schools, says the regional medical officer of health. That's nearly double the number of cases from last month [April 2019], when Dr Na-Koshie Lamptey declared a whooping cough outbreak for the capital region.\n\nPublic health will be offering immunization clinics over the next week for those most at risk of the bacterial respiratory infection easily spread through droplets in the air from coughing and sneezing, Lamptey said on Tuesday [21 May 2019]. That includes people who have been in close contact with any of the confirmed cases and do not have a primary care provider who can immunize them, she said.\n\nNo details about the affected individuals have been released, but the affected schools include: Garden Creek Elementary, Park Street Elementary, Gibson-Neill Memorial Elementary, Nashwaaksis Middle School, Fredericton Christian Academy, and George Street Middle School.\n\nThe clinics will also be for infants without a primary care provider, as well as preschoolers and adults who don't have the recommended booster dose or a primary care provider. Health officials did not provide any information about the locations or times of the clinics.\n\nIn New Brunswick, children should have doses of the pertussis vaccine when they are 2, 4, 6, and 18 months old and again at age 4, followed by a booster dose in grade 7, said Lamptey. Adults should receive one dose of a pertussis-containing vaccine, because immunity from the vaccine decreases over time.\n\nDr Na-Koshie Lamptey, regional medical officer of health, said parents who seek medical attention should tell their primary care provider that they and their children may have had contact with a confirmed case of whooping cough. Last month [April 2019], Lamptey said 10 children and 2 adults in the Fredericton health region had been diagnosed since January [2019]. Normally, the region, which encompasses the Upper St John River Valley, sees no more than one case a year, while the entire province sees about 27 confirmed cases. A whooping cough outbreak was also declared at Moncton High School in March [2019] after 5 cases were confirmed.\n\nVaccination is free.\n\n[byline: Bobbi-Jean MacKinnon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\nDate: Wed 22 May 2019\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicle [edited]\nhttps://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/health/whooping-cough-on-the-rise-in-montana-gallatin-county/article_c5e54701-e339-59c2-832c-39c656547add.html\n\n\nMontana health officials have recorded 265 people sick with whooping cough so far this year [2019] with a new wave of cases in Gallatin County over the last week. 'For a little perspective, this time last year [2018] we were at 21 cases,' said Stacey Anderson, a state preventable disease epidemiologist with the Department of Public Health and Human Services. 'This is a vaccine-preventable disease,' Anderson said. 'If a person is not up-to-date on their pertussis vaccine, it's a good time to do so.'\n\nThe state's tally of cases as of 16 May [2019] lapped last year's [2018] total of 143. That has health workers behind the scenes trying to stop its spread.\n\nMatt Kelley, public health officer with the Gallatin City-County Health Department, said 34 county residents were diagnosed with pertussis since January [2019], a jump of 7 cases in less than a week. That includes a new Belgrade illness the department began investigating Tuesday [21 May 2019]. 'We're seeing it community-wide,' Kelley said. 'We have cases at MSU [Montana State University], within the Bozeman School District, and we have cases that don't seem to be related to any of the above.' That stands out from previous years where outbreaks were centralized.\n\nKelley said after the department learns of a new case, it finds people who could be exposed and, in some cases, advises they get antibiotics to avoid the illness. He said people with symptoms should reach out to their doctor and get tested. 'We're hoping for the best but planning for additional cases because I'm sure we'll see them,' Kelley said. 'We're trying to build a wall of protection around the people who are most vulnerable.' The situation isn't the same statewide. Anderson said 16 counties reported pertussis cases since January [2019] with Missoula County leading the pack. But there's concern that number will increase.\n\nThe infection typically has a spike in cases every 3-5 years. Kids in school have their last required pertussis vaccine in 7th grade. Anderson said it seems to have a weaning protection after roughly 3-4 years. She said so far this year [2019], most Montanans with the infection have been between 16 and 18 years old. Montana's last pertussis peak happened in 2013 with 663 cases. Anderson said the illness resurfacing every few years is likely a perfect storm of its natural cycle and people who may be due for a vaccination. 'There's some concern we're kind of falling into that cycle,' she said.\n\n[byline: Katheryn Houghton]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Montana (Lake County/Flathead Reservation)\nDate: Wed 22 May 2019\nSource: KULR8 [edited]\nhttps://www.kulr8.com/regional/pertussis-cases-in-lake-co-grow-to-includes-infants/article_402d9020-54ba-5d3b-ac98-4bfdcde7b99b.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Lake County has now grown to 19, and health officials said on Wednesday [22 May 2019] that 4 of the cases are infants.\n\nThe following post is from the Lake County Public Health Facebook page:\n\nLake County/Flathead Reservation has bumped up to 19 confirmed pertussis cases. The outbreak is now considered to be community-wide.\n\nAges: [less than] 1 year = 4 [cases] (3 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 7 months); 1-4 years = 5 [cases]; 5-10 years = 6 [cases]; and [greater than] 10 years = 4 [cases].\n\nVaccination status: unvaccinated = 13 [cases].\n\n[byline: Angela Marshall]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Flathead Indian Reservation, located in western Montana on the Flathead River, is home to the Bitterroot Salish, Kootenai, and Pend d'Oreilles tribes; it has land in 4 of Montana's counties: Lake, Sanders, Missoula, and Flathead (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flathead_Indian_Reservation). See map at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lake+County,+MT. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Montana (Missoula County)\nDate: Fri 24 May 2019\nSource: Newstalk KGVO [edited]\nhttps://newstalkkgvo.com/pertussis-numbers-slowing-134-patients-confirmed-as-of-friday/\n\n\nOfficials at the Missoula City County Health Department are breathing a sigh of relief, as the numbers of confirmed cases of pertussis are slowing dramatically. Director Ellen Leahy drew the comparison from a week ago to Fri 24 May [2019]. 'In this last few days, the number of new cases has dropped from about 6 per day to just one per day for the last several days,' said Leahy. 'We're encouraged by that, of course, but we're still doing a lot of follow-up work on the known cases.'\n\nLeahy contrasted the number of double-digit confirmed cases from previous weeks to the past few days. 'We have 134 cases total as of Thursday night [23 May 2019], and going into the week, we had 125, so the number of new cases is slowing down,' she said. 'This is a very encouraging sign, but there is a bit of a caveat, and that is that we changed our protocol again going into the week. Our follow-up is still very assertive, but our case-finding is less so, so that may affect it a little bit. But when you look at the current epidemic from the beginning, you see kind of a peak area for a couple of weeks, and now you're starting to see it go down.'\n\nThere were concerns that the pertussis vaccine's effectiveness was beginning to wane; however, with patient numbers dropping, healthcare officials are more optimistic that the outbreak may soon be over. At one point, the Health Department had brought in 10 extra nurses to assist with the pertussis outbreak.\n\n[byline: Peter Christian]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Missoula, with a population of 73 340 residents, is a city and county seat of Missoula County in the western part of the US state of Montana and is home to the University of Montana, a public research university (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missoula,_Montana). Missoula can be found on a map at https://goo.gl/maps/gQEPpFRmdrCRRo5J6. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Maine (Portland)\nDate: Wed 29 May 2019\nSource: News Center Maine [edited]\nhttps://www.newscentermaine.com/article/news/local/at-least-3-cases-of-whooping-cough-confirmed-at-portland-schools-but-more-likely/97-d9a45e22-0c6e-4c62-9614-3016c3b1ed1e\n\n\nPortland schools confirmed 3 [4?] cases of whooping cough in the district on Wednesday [29 May 2019], but there are likely more.\n\nTess Nacelewicz, Communications Coordinator for Portland Public Schools, issued a statement on 29 May [2019], saying there has been one confirmed case of pertussis at Longfellow Elementary School, 2 confirmed cases at Lincoln Middle School, and one confirmed case at Deering High School. There is also a 2nd 'presumed' case at Longfellow and a 3rd case 'being tested' at Lincoln.\n\nThe student with pertussis from Deering has been treated with antibiotics and has since returned to school. Students in the same classes as the affected individual have not shown signs of any symptoms, and Nacelewicz says faculty is not aware of any other suspected cases at the high school.\n\nPortland Public Schools has reported the incidents to the Maine Center for Disease Control, according to Nacelewicz. The CDC has spoken with school nursing staff, and a letter was sent to parents and staff (including custodial staff) at each school. Nacelewicz says there are no recommendations for keeping students out of schools, and though immunized students can and do contract pertussis, these infections are usually less serious.\n\n[byline: Chloe Teboe]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Portland, with a population of 67 067 as of 2017, is a city in the US state of Maine; it is the most populous metropolitan region in northern New England (an area comprising the states of Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont), and the Port of Portland is the largest tonnage seaport in New England (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Maine). A map showing the location of Portland can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Portland,+ME. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nNew Zealand\n---\n[6] Gisborne\nDate: Wed 29 May 2019\nSource: Gisborne Herald [edited]\nhttp://gisborneherald.co.nz/localnews/4119079-135/immunisation-stressed-after-five-whooping-cough\n\n\nHauora Tairawhiti has confirmed there have been 5 confirmed cases of whooping cough in the past month [May 2019?]. This is much higher than usual, and the district health board is warning there are likely to be other cases in the community. The 5 cases include two 2 year olds and a baby.\n\nTairawhiti medical officer of health Margot McLean says immunisation rates in the district are not high enough to prevent outbreaks of [this] serious disease. 'Parents sometimes get scared by negative information about vaccines on social media. They may not realise that the vaccines are made to prevent very serious illnesses. These illnesses are making a comeback because of our low rates of immunisation. Childhood vaccinations are all free, and if children have missed vaccinations, they can go to their health centre and catch up.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hauora Tairawhiti covers the same area as the Gisborne District (also known as Gisborne Region), with a population of 49 100 residents, 45% of whom are Maori; 75% of the population lives in the city of Gisborne (https://www.hauoratairawhiti.org.nz/about-us/who/tairawhiti/). Tairawhiti is said to have the highest level of economic deprivation and poorer health than any other district, contributed in part by low immunization rates (https://www.hauoratairawhiti.org.nz/about-us/who/tairawhiti/). Date: Wed 22 May 2019\n Date: Wed 22 May 2019\n Date: Wed 29 May 2019\n Date: Wed 29 May 2019\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2019-05-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-29 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2019-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-22 00:00:00", "2021-05-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Gallatin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vermont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12939", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lake County / Flathead Reservation", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gisborne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Hampshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missoula", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kootenai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22385", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lake County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Longfellow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Gisborne Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missoula County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6294469", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update: USA, Panama, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6294469", "date": "2019-02-04 16:10:14", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE: USA, PANAMA, FATAL\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nUSA\n---\n[1] California (Marin County)\n\nPanama\n---\n[2] Ng\u00e4be Bugl\u00e9 (Loma Yuca)\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] California (Marin County)\nDate: Wed 26 Dec 2018\nSource: KPIX 5, CBS local [edited]\nhttps://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2018/12/26/whooping-cough-outbreak-sweeps-marin-county/\n\n\nMarin County has been hit by a recent spike in cases of pertussis, better known as whooping cough. Marin County Health Department says there have been 241 confirmed cases of the sickness, which is the highest number the county's seen in 8 years.\n\n'It's bad. Luckily, my kids are vaccinated, but that doesn't mean other kids aren't at risk,' said SG, a parent in the area. The contagious respiratory infection primarily affects young children.\n\nWhooping cough starts out like a cold, but the bouts of coughing are much worse. Doctors say the bouts often leave kids gasping for air in between fits, hence that name. 'The problem with pertussis is when young babies are exposed, the effects can be very serious. In 2010, there was an outbreak of pertussis and 10 infants died of the disease that year,' said Dr. Matt Willi, Public Health Officer for Marin County.\n\nThe health department says almost every single school in the county has had at least one confirmed case of whooping cough. At Sir Francis Drake High School, 56 cases were confirmed. 'It's probably been about half of the kids in each class,' said Sir Francis Drake sophomore Isaac Dorfmaan. 'It's been really common this year (2018).' The health department says any child with a confirmed case immediately gets sent home from school for 3 days and is put on antibiotics before notifying the child's parents.\n\nThe department says low vaccination rates in the county are partly to blame for the high number of cases. Officials suggest parents keep a close eye on their kids' coughs. If you hear that distinctive, high-pitched 'whooping' sound, take your child to the doctor immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Marin County, with a population of 252 409 residents in 2010, is located in the San Francisco Bay Area of the U.S. state of California, across the Golden Gate Bridge from the city of San Francisco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_County,_California). A map showing the location of Marin County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Marin+County,+CA. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nPanama\n---\n[2] Ng\u00e4be Bugl\u00e9 (Loma Yuca)\nDate: Sat 2 Feb 2019\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-ngabe-bugle-panama-80926/\n\n\nHealth officials in Panama are reporting an outbreak of pertussis, or whooping cough in the Ng\u00e4be Bugl\u00e9 region since mid-December (2018), according to an El Siglo report (computer translated). To date, 81 confirmed cases have been reported, including 9 fatalities in children under 2 years of age.\n\nAccording to the head of the Department of Epidemiological Surveillance Ministry of Health, Israel Cedeno, the children died due to complications and were registered in the Loma Yuca sector of the region.\n\nWhooping cough, also called pertussis, is a highly contagious respiratory illness that spreads by coughing and sneezing while in close contact with others. Left untreated, it can spread from a single infected person for several weeks, with people in the early stage of illness being the most contagious.\n\nWhooping cough can be a serious illness. Symptoms usually begin appearing as cold symptoms such as a cough, runny nose, sore throat and usually little or no fever. After several days, the cough may become more severe; it may come in spasms or as a series of coughs without a chance to breathe between coughs. There may be a gasp or 'whoop' and/or gagging or vomiting at the end of the coughing spasm. Infants, particularly those less than 6 months of age, who contract whooping cough are at increased risk of complications, hospitalization and death.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ng\u00e4be-Bugl\u00e9 is the largest and most populous of Panama's 3 'comarcas ind\u00edgenas' (Ember\u00e1-Wounaan, Guna Yala, Ng\u00e4be-Bugl\u00e9) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ng\u00e4be-Bugl\u00e9_Comarca). 'Comarcas ind\u00edgenas' are administrative regions, equivalent to provinces, for an area with a substantial Amerindian population; 2 smaller 'comarcas' (Kuna de Madugand\u00ed and Kuna de Wargand\u00ed) are subordinate to a province and considered equivalent to a 'corregimiento' (municipality) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comarca#Panama).\nLoma Yuca, with a population of 544 residents in 2010, is a municipality in the Ng\u00e4be-Bugl\u00e9 'comarca' (https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loma_Yuca). A map showing the location of Loma Yuca can be found at https://impresa.prensa.com/opinion/Loma-Yuca-eligio-representante_0_746925413.html. A map showing the location of Ng\u00e4be-Bugl\u00e9 can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ng\u00e4be-Bugl\u00e9+Comarca,+Panama. - Mod.ML]\n\n[\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nPanama: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n ML]\n\n******\nPanama\n---\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Marin County, with a population of 252 409 residents in 2010, is located in the San Francisco Bay Area of the U.S. state of California, across the Golden Gate Bridge from the city of San Francisco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_County,_California). ML]\n\n[\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nPanama: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18] In this posting:\nUSA\n---\n [1] California (Marin County)\n\nPanama\n---\n Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-ngabe-bugle-panama-80926/\n\n\nHealth officials in Panama are reporting an outbreak of pertussis, or whooping cough in the Ng\u00e4be Bugl\u00e9 region since mid-December (2018), according to an El Siglo report (computer translated). PERTUSSIS UPDATE: USA, PANAMA, FATAL\n************************************\n USA\n---\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [2] Ng\u00e4be Bugl\u00e9 (Loma Yuca)\n\n******\n \n\nThe health department says almost every single school in the county has had at least one confirmed case of whooping cough. \n\nWhooping cough, also called pertussis, is a highly contagious respiratory illness that spreads by coughing and sneezing while in close contact with others. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\nWhooping cough starts out like a cold, but the bouts of coughing are much worse.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "PANAMA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loma Yuca", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ng\u00e4be - Bugl\u00e9", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Panama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6481018", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (05): USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6481018", "date": "2019-05-22 13:41:04", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (05): USA\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] California (Orange county)\n[2] North Carolina (Orange, Chatham, and Durham counties)\n[3] Wyoming (Campbell county)\n[4] Montana (Missoula county)\n[5] Washington (Whatcom county)\n\n******\n[1] California (Orange county)\nDate: Fri 19 Apr 2019\nSource: Fox News [edited]\nhttps://www.foxnews.com/health/california-baby-dies-whooping-cough\n\n\nA baby in California has died after contracting whooping cough, officials said, marking the 1st such death in Orange county in more than a decade. A news release posted on [Thu 18 Apr 2019] by the county's health officials did not identify the child or list the baby's age. 'We are deeply saddened by this loss of life and send our condolences to the family,' Dr Nichole Quick, interim county health officer, said in the news release.\n\nThe health department counted 171 cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, in 2018, including 8 cases involving infants under 3 months. 7 of those children required hospitalization. The illness is a very contagious disease that spreads through coughing or sneezing, but it can take up to 3 weeks for symptoms to appear. Late-stage symptoms may include rapid coughing followed by a high-pitched 'whoop' sound, vomiting and exhaustion.\n\n'The best way to prevent pertussis is to be up-to-date on vaccinations,' Quick said. 'Children should receive 5 doses of DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and whooping cough (pertussis)] as part of their routine vaccination schedule starting at 2 months of age. Pregnant women during each pregnancy, regardless of when their previous pregnancy occurred, are strongly recommended to receive Tdap vaccine during their 3rd trimester. Vaccination during this time stimulates production of maternal antibodies that are passed on to the infant, offering protection to the baby against pertussis during the first few months of life.'\n\n[Byline: Alexandria Hein]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1174\nOrange county, with a population of about 3 million residents, is located just south of Los Angeles along the Pacific coast in the US state of California. This is compared to one case in all of 2018 and 0 in 2017.\n\nOfficials say that there have been 13 reported cases statewide so far this year [2019]. Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Montana (Missoula county)\nDate: Mon 20 May 2019 10:46 AM MDT\nSource: KPAX, MTN News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://kpax.com/health-news/2019/05/20/missoula-area-whooping-cough-cases-rise-to-125/\n\n\nLocal health officials report there are now 125 confirmed pertussis cases in the Missoula area. Cases are being reported across all ages and due to the duration of the outbreak, it is possible for people who were exposed earlier in the outbreak to be re-exposed.\n\nThe Missoula City-County Health Department is continuing to work closely with schools to identify close contacts of confirmed cases. Confirmed whooping cough cases have been reported in approximately 20 schools -- including in the Florence and Frenchtown school districts.\n\nIf you are experiencing symptoms of pertussis, see your provider right away. If you or a family member has been identified as exposed, you will receive instructions from the Health Department. The best way to protect against pertussis is by getting vaccinated. Make sure that you and your family are up to date on your immunizations. If you need information on your immunization status, contact your provider or the Health Department.\n\nNeed to get vaccinated? The Missoula City-County Health Department, located at 301 West Alder St., carries the pertussis vaccine (DTaP & Tdap) and can bill most insurance plans, including Medicaid. They offer a sliding fee scale for those who are uninsured or underinsured. Call the Immunization Clinic at 406-258-3363 for more information. The clinic offers walk-in hours at the following times: 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Wednesday.\n\nIf you have not been contacted by the Health Department, no action is needed at this point.\n\nIf you have additional questions, please contact (406) 258-INFO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Montana, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7022\nMissoula, with a population of 73 340 residents, is a city and county seat of Missoula County in the western part of the U.S. state of Montana and is home to the University of Montana, a public research university (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missoula,_Montana). [1] California (Orange county)\n [5] Washington (Whatcom county)\n [4] Montana (Missoula county)\n [4] Montana (Missoula county)\n Date: Wed 1 May 2019 4:10 PM EDT\n \n\n'Increased pertussis activity is something we watch closely because it can be so tough on infants,' said Clay Van Houten, infectious disease epidemiology unit manager with WDH. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2019-04-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-01 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Missoula county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missoula City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bellingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://goo.gl/maps/N5Z9Ksn6cs1iunPdA. - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whatcom County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Campbell county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Campbell County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Frenchtown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missoula County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6404428", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (04): Canada, Australia, USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6404428", "date": "2019-04-04 15:43:57", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (04): CANADA, AUSTRALIA, USA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nCanada\n----\n[1] British Columbia (Vancouver Island)\n[2] Ontario\n\nAustralia\n----\n[3] New South Wales (Illawarra Shoalhaven)\n\nUSA\n----\n[4] California (LA County)\n\n******\nCanada\n----\n[1] British Columbia (Vancouver Island)\nDate: Tue 12 Mar 2019\nSource: Vancouver Sun [edited]\nhttps://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/whooping-cough-on-the-rise-in-b-c-vaccinations-urged-for-children\n\n\nBritish Columbia [B.C.] Health Minister Adrian Dix announced last month [February 2019] B.C. is considering a vaccination registration system in the province's schools after a measles outbreak. As of last week there have been at least 17 confirmed measles cases this year [2019]. In addition to the measles, there have been 2 reported cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, on Vancouver Island this week.\n\nThe spread of communicable diseases increases when less than 90 to 95% of the population is immunized. 'That (a lower rate of immunization) is considered to be a contributing factor' to the increase of pertussis, said Dr. Manish Sadarangani, director of the vaccine evaluation centre at the B.C. Children's Hospital.\n\nChildren should be immunized against pertussis at 2, 4, 6 and 18 months, in preschool, and in Grade 9, he said. And pregnant women are immunized to protect their newborns up to the age of 2 months, he said. Pertussis after age 15 or so causes a bad cough that's annoying but not dangerous. But a baby with whooping cough could cough till they're blue or vomiting and that could lead to a lack of oxygen. In a worst case, that can be fatal, he said.\n\n'There is a push to have requirements for people to have all their (vaccination) documents before they go to school,' said Sadarangani. A Health Ministry spokeswoman said pertussis is among the diseases that it recommends immunizing against.\n\nPertussis in B.C., like elsewhere, 'remains an endemic disease' that goes through cyclical peaks every 3 to 5 years, according to the B.C. Centre for Disease Control website. It says there has been a 'gradual increase in overall pertussis activity' since 2012 and that 'may reflect changes in population-level immunity.'\n\nIn B.C., there were fewer than 13 confirmed cases per 100 000 population in 2017, which was slightly lower than the fewer than 20 cases in 2015 and 2016. But it's higher than rates of fewer than 5 to 10 per 100 000 in 2008 through 2014, according to the Centre. The highest rates were in Vancouver Island and Interior health authorities, particularly in Kootenay Boundary, South Vancouver Island and Okanagan regions, it said.\n\nIn 2017, the highest rates of pertussis were among babies one year and under, children 10 to 14 years old, and children 5 to 9. The lowest rates were recorded for children one to 4 years old, children 15 to 19, and adults 20 and older, it said.\n\nAn Angus Reid Institute poll released last month [February 2019] showed 70% of respondents believed vaccines against deadly diseases should be mandatory for schoolchildren. And a B.C. petition signed so far by more than 45 000 people is calling for mandatory vaccination for babies and kids. In its report, Angus Reid notes that reasons for not vaccinating children include philosophical, religious or personal reasons. It notes some parents believe chiropractic practices and naturopathy are alternatives to vaccination, which Health Canada says is not true.\n\nSadarangani said it's rare for people to receive a medical exemption for vaccinations, perhaps for a child sick with cancer, and it's important to immunize those who can be vaccinated to help protect those who can't be, the so-called herd immunity. He said if he would meet families who choose not to immunize, 'I would try to talk to them to find out the reason.'\n\n[Byline: Susan Lazaruk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A recent news report (22 Mar 2019) confirmed a 5th case of pertussis in south Vancouver Island (https://www.vicnews.com/news/island-health-confirms-5th-case-of-whooping-cough-in-south-island/). Vancouver Island, the largest island on the West Coast of North America, with a population in 2016 of 775 347 residents, is part of the Canadian province of British Columbia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vancouver_Island). Nearly half the population lives in the metropolitan area of Greater Victoria, the capital city of British Columbia. - Mod.ML]\n\n----\n[2] Ontario\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2019, 6:08 AM\nSource: Quinte News [edited]\nhttps://www.quintenews.com/2019/03/17/whooping-cough-found-in-northumberland-county/\n\n\nThe Health Unit was notified this week that one case of whooping cough had been confirmed with laboratory testing, and that 3 other family members in the same household are ill with symptoms. Those ill were either not vaccinated or partially vaccinated against the virus.\n\nThe current cases of whooping cough are recovering at home, Rock says, and the Health Unit has been following up with anyone who may have been in contact with the family. At this time, there does not appear to be any additional cases, but she encourages anyone who develops symptoms to contact their health care provider or emergency room to arrange for testing.\n\nThe Health Unit is also holding immunization clinics for students or people who do not have a health care provider. To learn more, or to book an appointment, call the Health Unit toll-free at 1-866-888-4577, ext. 1507.\n\n[Byline: Tim Durkin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ontario is one of the 13 and most populous of Canada's provinces and territories; it is located in east-central Canada and is home to the nation's capital city, Ottawa, and the nation's most populous city, Toronto, which is also Ontario's provincial capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n[3] New South Wales (Illawarra Shoalhaven)\nDate: Tue 12 Mar 2019 , 11:30 AM\nSource: Illawarra Mercury [edited]\nhttps://www.illawarramercury.com.au/story/5949408/public-health-unit-issues-whooping-cough-alert-for-illawarra-parents/?cs=12\n\n\nKanahooka High School parents have been urged to be on the lookout for symptoms of whooping cough after a confirmed case in a student at the school. In a recent letter to parents, Illawarra Shoalhaven Local Health District public health director Curtis Gregory said symptoms included a dry cough, sore throat, runny nose and a cough which was often worse at night or which came in bouts.\n\nHealth data reveals there were 69 confirmed cases of whooping cough throughout the Illawarra Shoalhaven Local Health District in January and February [2019]. That compares to 13 cases in the first 2 months of 2018; although there were 105 cases in January and February 2017.\n\nAcross NSW [New South Wales], 1112 cases have been reported so far this year [2019].\n\n[Byline: Lisa Wachsmuth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Illawarra (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illawarra) is a coastal region situated south of the city of Sydney and north of the Shoalhaven (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Shoalhaven) in New South Wales Australia. A map of these regions can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Shoalhaven,+NSW,+Australia. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nUSA\n----\n[4] California (LA County)\nDate: Sat 16 Mar 2019\nSource: LA Times [edited]\nhttps://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-ln-whooping-cough-vaccine-20190316-story.html\n\n\nNearly 50 students at Harvard-Westlake School have been recently diagnosed with whooping cough, in an outbreak that has forced school officials to send students home at the 1st sign of illness.\n\nBut all of the sick students had been vaccinated against the disease, according to school officials. In fact, all 90 people who have recently come down with pertussis - the official name for whooping cough - in Los Angeles County this year had been immunized against it, according to county officials.\n\nIt turns out that 4 years after someone receives the booster shot in about the 7th grade, the vaccine's protection nearly vanishes, endangering high schoolers such as those at Harvard-Westlake, said Dr. James Cherry, a UCLA expert on pediatric infectious diseases. 'It is not surprising at all,' Cherry said of the recent cases.\n\nThe outbreak is a real-life example of something that experts have been noticing since doctors switched to a new form of the pertussis vaccine in 1997: Immunity wanes quickly.\n\nThe pertussis outbreak raises questions about how to best administer a vaccine when its protection fades so quickly. People now in high school are one of the 1st generations to receive only the new, shorter-lived form of the vaccine, making them test cases for these problems.\n\nThese recent whooping cough cases also serve as a contrast to the measles outbreaks across the country, which are mostly among people who declined vaccinations. In those cases, immunization probably would have prevented most of the illnesses.\n\nLos Angeles County officials announced last month [February 2019] that there were 3 clusters of whooping cough cases among adolescents across the county: 46 students have been diagnosed with pertussis at Harvard-Westlake, where enrollment is about 1600. A total of 18 students there have not been vaccinated against pertussis, but none of them has caught the illness, school spokesman Ari Engelberg said; 10 students at St. Anastasia Catholic School in Westchester also caught pertussis. All had been vaccinated, according to school officials;\n\nUnder California law, children must receive all of their doses of whooping cough vaccine to be allowed to attend school, unless they have a medical reason not to be vaccinated. By the time they turn 6, most children have received 5 doses of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular-pertussis vaccine, or DTaP. Then they must get a booster before entering 7th grade. The immunizations are concentrated in the earliest years of life because babies are the most likely to die from whooping cough, named for the sound people make when they're gasping for air. 'Deaths virtually all occur in the first 2 months of life,' Cherry said.\n\nBut studies have found that immunity drops quickly after getting the shot. One study from Kaiser Permanente found that protection fell an average of 42% a year after the last childhood dose at about age 6.\n\nThe rapidly waning immunity is linked to the kind of vaccine children receive, experts say. Before 1997, children received a form known as whole cell, which sometimes caused side effects, such as convulsions and severe fevers. So officials switched to the current acellular vaccine, which has fewer side effects but does not provide immunity for as long.\n\nEven the middle school booster, intended to extend immunity, protects about 80% of people who receive it for about a year but mostly stops providing immunity after that, another Kaiser study found.\n\nL.A. County public health officials said the recent cases may be focused in young adults because they are more susceptible to the illness because they received only the acellular vaccine.\n\n'There is no increase in the current overall number of cases compared to past years, but the number of reported clusters has risen in 11- to 18-year-olds,' officials said in a statement to The Times. 'Waning immunity is a well-recognized phenomenon ... [and] seems to be the most plausible explanation for the recent clusters seen by the department.'\n\nSome scientists have suggested that it would make more sense to administer the vaccine in a targeted fashion, such as before an outbreak or when one has just begun. But Dr. Armand Dorian, chief medical officer at USC Verdugo Hills Hospital, said waiting to administer it when an outbreak has begun doesn't make sense. At that point, antibiotics are needed. 'It's too late to do brush clearance. You have to come in with a helicopter and douse a fire,' he said. Dorian said that even though the vaccine's immunity wanes, increasing coverage rates in the community would help prevent pertussis outbreaks.\n\nIn the 2017-2018 school year, 96% of kindergartners had all their doses of the pertussis vaccine and 98% of 7th-graders had received the booster, according to state data. Both of those percentages dropped slightly from the previous school year.\n\nDoctors recommend that pregnant mothers get an additional dose of the vaccine so they can protect their newborns. But only 52% of new mothers in 2016 were vaccinated, according to a report from the California Department of Public Health.\n\nIf vaccination rates were higher, Dorian said, pertussis would not be able to enter a community in the 1st place. The bacterium is much more likely to spread among people who have not been vaccinated.\n\nPeople who have been vaccinated and still get pertussis also contract a less severe form of the illness that is likely to be less contagious. So it's possible that the recent outbreaks originated with someone who had not been immunized, even though the disease is now spreading among people who have been vaccinated, Dorian said. 'Once there's a chink in the armor and that unvaccinated population grows, then the actual protection of the vaccination significantly drops, even for those who are vaccinated,' he said.\n\nThe real concern now is that a baby could contract whooping cough. Pertussis kills about 20 people in the United States each year, almost all of them infants. The last person to die from pertussis in California was a baby in San Bernardino County in 2018. 'It's a cough, a whooping cough, which means it loves to spread,' Dorian\nsaid.\n\n[Byline: Soumya Karlamangla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Los Angeles county is the most populous county in the US, with more than 10 million inhabitants as of 2017 and is the 3rd-largest metropolitan economy in the world, with a nominal GDP of over USD 700 billion; its county seat is the city of Los Angeles, with a population of about 4 million residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_County,_California). Harvard-Westlake School has 2 campuses, the middle school in Holmby Hills and the high school in Studio City, located in the city of Los Angeles, with approximately 1600 students enrolled in grades 7 through 12 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard-Westlake_School). - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Los Angeles county is the most populous county in the US, with more than 10 million inhabitants as of 2017 and is the 3rd-largest metropolitan economy in the world, with a nominal GDP of over USD 700 billion; its county seat is the city of Los Angeles, with a population of about 4 million residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_County,_California). ' \n\nChildren should be immunized against pertussis at 2, 4, 6 and 18 months, in preschool, and in Grade 9, he said. It's a cough, a whooping cough, which means it loves to spread,' Dorian\nsaid. \n\nHealth data reveals there were 69 confirmed cases of whooping cough throughout the Illawarra Shoalhaven Local Health District in January and February [2019]. \n\nIt turns out that 4 years after someone receives the booster shot in about the 7th grade, the vaccine's protection nearly vanishes, endangering high schoolers such as those at Harvard-Westlake, said Dr. James Cherry, a UCLA expert on pediatric infectious diseases. ' \n\nThese recent whooping cough cases also serve as a contrast to the measles outbreaks across the country, which are mostly among people who declined vaccinations. \n\nIn B.C., there were fewer than 13 confirmed cases per 100 000 population in 2017, which was slightly lower than the fewer than 20 cases in 2015 and 2016. \n\nEven the middle school booster, intended to extend immunity, protects about 80% of people who receive it for about a year but mostly stops providing immunity after that, another Kaiser study found. Last year [2017], there were 46 cases of whooping cough, and this year there have already been 13.\n\nMesa County Public Health offers DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis] and Tdap [booster] immunizations and accepts all major health insurance plans. They do have programs for those without insurance, and they said cost should not be a barrier to protecting your family. To learn more, visit Mesa County Public Health's immunization section of their website (https://health.mesacounty.us/services/family/immunizations/#1485903122632-690d846f-da4d).\n\n[Byline: Colette Bordelon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mesa county, with a population of 146 723 residents in 2010, is one of the 64 counties of the US state of Colorado, on the state's western border to the US state of Utah; Mesa county's seat is the city of Grand Junction (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesa_County,_Colorado). According to the release, a couple of teens in the community are being treated for the illness.\n\nThe statement shared information on recognizing the symptoms and the steps to take to confirm and care for the person who's ill.\n\n[Byline: Deb Brazil]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Vernon county, with a population of 29 773 residents in 2010, is in the southwestern region of the US state of Wisconsin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vernon_County,_Wisconsin); its county seat is Viroqua, with a population of 4362 in 2010 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viroqua,_Wisconsin. A map showing the location of Viroqua can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/dLiu2PAXfF62. - Mod.ML]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Wisconsin, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13558]\n\n******\n[3] Maine (Cumberland county)\nDate: Sat 3 Nov 2018\nSource: Kennebec Journal and Morning Sentinel/centralmaine.com, Portland Press Herald report [edited]\nhttps://www.centralmaine.com/2018/11/02/scarborough-school-officials-issue-whooping-cough-warning/\n\n\nFollowing a pertussis outbreak at Scarborough High School [Cumberland county], parents are urged to keep kids home if they have a cough and to update family vaccinations. An outbreak of whooping cough at Scarborough High School last month [October 2018] has health officials warning parents to take precautions.\n\nThree high school students had confirmed cases of pertussis in October [2018], but none of the cases appeared to be connected, Superintendent Julie Kukenberger said. 'We obviously want to be hyper-vigilant so families can be aware and take steps to protect their children,' she said. Pamela Gill and Lisa Verzoni, both registered nurses, sent an email Friday morning [2 Nov 2018] to the Scarborough school community on behalf of the health services staff. 'Students attending the high school may have been exposed,' the nurses wrote. 'It is important to inform the entire school community of the recent pertussis cases.'\n\nSchools in neighboring York county reported a spike in the highly infectious disease in September [2018], according to the Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention. While cases reported statewide are down so far this year [2018] -- 262 through September compared to 317 during the same period last year -- 97 cases this year [2018] were in York county alone, and 25 of those cases were reported in September [2018].\n\nThe nurses recommended keeping children home from school and other activities if they have a cough and may have been exposed to pertussis. Other recommendations included making an appointment with a health care provider as soon as possible and informing them if a child has been exposed to pertussis. They also urged everyone to make sure their families' vaccinations are up to date.\n\n[Byline: Kelley Bouchard]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Scarborough, with a population of 18 919 in 2010, is a town in Cumberland County on the southern coast of the US state of Maine, 7 miles (11 km) south of the city of Portland (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarborough,_Maine). A map showing the location of Scarborough can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/ER5EFU9Rfgs. And a map of Maine counties can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Maine#/media/File:Maine-counties-map.gif. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York county)\nDate: Tue 20 Nov 2018\nSource: Brinkwire, Portland Press Herald report [edited]\nhttps://en.brinkwire.com/news/new-maine-pertussis-cases-jumped-in-october-the-highest-monthly-total-this-year/\n\n\nYork county continues to be a hot spot for the infectious disease, also known as whooping cough, and low vaccination rates are thought to be a factor.\n\nPertussis cases in Maine ballooned in October [2018], and with 64 cases reported statewide it was the worst month so far this year [2018] for the infectious disease, which produces a violent cough.\n\nThe October figures bring the total number of pertussis cases to 332 for the 1st 10 months of 2018, according to the Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention. Maine consistently has among the highest rates of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- in the nation.\n\nThe state is on pace to nearly match the 410 pertussis cases in 2017, which was the most since 557 cases were recorded in 2014. Maine's pertussis rate of 27.7 cases per 100 000 population was the worst in the nation in 2017 and more than 5 times the national average, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nScarborough, Biddeford, and Kennebunk schools reported pertussis outbreaks this fall [2018], and on [8 Nov 2018] the Middle School of the Kennebunks canceled its annual community Thanksgiving dinner to avoid potentially exposing the community, especially babies and senior citizens, to the disease. An outbreak is defined as 3 or more cases in one location, such as a school, day care facility, church or workplace.\n\nYork county has been a hot spot for pertussis, with 37 of the 64 cases in October [2018] recorded in Maine's southernmost county, including an outbreak at Ninny's House Childcare in Buxton.\n\nHealth experts cite 3 major reasons why Maine is vulnerable to pertussis infections: parents opting their children out of school-required vaccines; the waning effectiveness of the vaccine, which requires a booster shot; and Maine being late to adopt a required booster shot for middle school students. The state didn't establish the requirement until the 2017-18 school year.\n\nDr Laura Blaisdell, a Yarmouth pediatrician and vaccine researcher, said the high rates of pertussis are 'most likely related to low vaccination rates. We can and should do better.\n\nVaccines are overwhelmingly safe and research has proved that they do not cause autism, but myths that the vaccines are contributing to autism have persisted since the late 1990s.\n\nMaine typically has one of the highest rates of parents opting out of school-required vaccines for children entering kindergarten. Opt-out rates increased for the 2017-18 school year to 5 percent of kindergartners for non-medical reasons, on philosophic or religious grounds. Democratic lawmakers have said they intend to introduce bills that would make it more difficult for parents to forgo vaccines for schoolchildren, after Gov.-elect Janet Mills assumes office in January [2019]. Mills has said she's open to bills that would improve 'Maine's disturbingly low rates of vaccination in some parts of the state.' Outgoing Gov. Paul LePage vetoed an attempt to make it more difficult to opt out, and a Legislature override effort fell 5 votes short.\n\n[Byline: Joe Lawlor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Maine, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/222]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2018\nSource: KDLT News [edited]\nhttps://www.kdlt.com/2018/11/16/cases-of-pertussis-on-the-rise-in-south-dakota/\n\n\nThere has been an increase in the number of cases of pertussis reported. So far this year [2018], 90 cases have come in to the Health Department -- the highest number reported since 2014, when the state saw 109 cases. The most affected counties include Edmunds (19), Brown (15), Minnehaha (13), and Hughes (12).\n\n'Pertussis is a very serious illness so it is important to take precautions like ensuring you and your children are current with all recommended vaccines,' said Dr Joshua Clayton, state epidemiologist for the department, in a press release.\n\nMore information about pertussis and its control can be found on the department's website at http://doh.sd.gov/diseases/infectious/diseasefacts/Pertussis.aspx.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are 66 counties in the US state of South Dakota (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_South_Dakota). A South Dakota county map can be seen at https://geology.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of South Dakota, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243]\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[6] Saskatchewan\nDate: Fri 9 Nov 2018\nSource: paNOW [edited]\nhttps://www.panow.com/article/802344/whooping-cough-cluster-south-pa\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough in the Rosthern, Wakaw, Hague, Hepburn, and Waldheim areas in recent weeks prompted the Health Authority to run special drop-in immunization clinics in Rosthern the last 2 days.\n\nThe Saskatchewan Health Authority said in an email to paNOW, the majority of children are not up to date or only partially immunized against pertussis.\n\nThe cluster of cases since [1 Oct 2018] had seen a total of 22 people with the disease, and one infant had been hospitalized. Over half of the cases were among children under the age of 5. 36 per cent of the cases involved children between 5 and 14 years, with the remainder between 15 and 19 years.\n\nThere was no specific number on the amount of people who attended the special drop-in clinic in Rosthern Thursday and Friday [8, 9 Nov 2018] although Dr Chokani said things had been 'steady.'\n\n[Byline: Glenn Hicks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rosthern, Wakaw, Hague, Hepburn, and Waldheim are small towns located in the center of the Canadian province of Saskatchewan; a map showing their location can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/ePT6Jrsf4SR2. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Saskatchewan province, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/262]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mesa county, with a population of 146 723 residents in 2010, is one of the 64 counties of the US state of Colorado, on the state's western border to the US state of Utah; Mesa county's seat is the city of Grand Junction (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesa_County,_Colorado). [5] South Dakota\n\nCanada\n---\n ML]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of South Dakota, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243]\n\n******\n ML]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201]\n\n******\n ML]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Wisconsin, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13558]\n\n******\n \n\nYork county has been a hot spot for pertussis, with 37 of the 64 cases in October [2018] recorded in Maine's southernmost county, including an outbreak at Ninny's House Childcare in Buxton. \n\n[Byline: Glenn Hicks]\n\n--\n \n\nThree high school students had confirmed cases of pertussis in October [2018], but none of the cases appeared to be connected, Superintendent Julie Kukenberger said. \n\nScarborough, Biddeford, and Kennebunk schools reported pertussis outbreaks this fall [2018], and on [8 Nov 2018] the Middle School of the Kennebunks canceled its annual community Thanksgiving dinner to avoid potentially exposing the community, especially babies and senior citizens, to the disease. Pertussis cases in Maine ballooned in October [2018], and with 64 cases reported statewide it was the worst month so far this year [2018] for the infectious disease, which produces a violent cough. Date: Fri 9 Nov 2018 03:59 PM CST\nSource: News8000 [edited]\nhttps://www.news8000.com/news/vernon-county-confirms- Date: Wed 31 Oct 2018 04:55 MDT\nSource: Western Slope Now [edited]\nhttps://www.westernslopenow.com/news/local-news/mcph-warns-about-whooping-cough/1565265741 \n\nHealth experts cite 3 major reasons why Maine is vulnerable to pertussis infections: parents opting their children out of school-required vaccines; the waning effectiveness of the vaccine, which requires a booster shot; and Maine being late to adopt a required booster shot for middle school students. PERTUSSIS (10): USA, CANADA\n***************************\n \n\nThe state is on pace to nearly match the 410 pertussis cases in 2017, which was the most since 557 cases were recorded in 2014. So far this year [2018], 90 cases have come in to the Health Department -- the highest number reported since 2014, when the state saw 109 cases. USA\n---\n Canada\n---\n Area Schools released a statement today [9 Nov 2018] notifying parents of confirmed cases of whooping cough (pertussis) in Vernon county. [Byline: Colette Bordelon]\n\n--\n [Byline: Deb Brazil]\n\n--\n [Byline: Kelley Bouchard]\n\n--\n [Byline: Joe Lawlor]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n'Pertussis is a very serious illness so it is important to take precautions like ensuring you and your children are current with all recommended vaccines,' said Dr Joshua Clayton, state epidemiologist for the department, in a press release.
