Liberia, USA, Canada, Australia, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6349721", "date": "2019-03-05 17:01:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (02): LIBERIA, USA, CANADA, AUSTRALIA, FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this post:\nLiberia\n---\n[1] Grand Bassa and Margibi counties\n\nUSA\n---\n[2] Maine (Hancock, York, Waldo counties)\n[3] South Dakota (Sioux Falls)\n[4] California (Los Angeles county)\n\nCanada\n---\n[5] New Brunswick (Westmorland county)\n\nAustralia\n---\n[6] Tasmania\n\n******\nLiberia\n---\n[1] Grand Bassa and Margibi counties\nDate: Thu 7 Feb 2019\nSource: Front Page Africa (FPA) Online [edited]\nhttps://frontpageafricaonline.com/health/grand-bassa-county-whooping-cough-outbreak-one-dies-over-300-infected/\n\n\nAt least one child has died and over 300 infected by whooping cough [pertussis] in district Two, Grand Bassa county.\n\nAccording to reports, these cases have been discovered in Kpawootroh town, Gargar Town, and several other towns within the district. The outbreak is happening in an area bordering Margibi county, and reports suggest that several cases have also been discovered there. Alexander PM Joe, Officer in Charge [OIC] of district Two health center, confirmed to FrontPage Africa [FPA] that they discovered that there's an increase of the diseases in the area, with a several hundred children already infected.\n\n'Since January this year [2019], most the babies that we have been treating have been affected with whooping cough and as a result of that one child has died already,' Joe told an FPA reporter who visited the area. 'The sign and symptoms of whooping cough are red eye and uncontrollable cough as well as constant running down of tears. 'We have communicated with the Grand Bassa County Health team about the situation but we are hopeful that they are going to help in the soonest possible time.' He warned that if nothing is done quickly, there could be further in the number of cases, which may cause more deaths. 'The lack of drugs is a major problem at this health center but it is a nationwide issue. We are hoping that the Ministry of Health intervenes quickly as to have the lives of over 300 babies saved,' the OIC stressed.\n\nA mother of 4 children, also confirmed that the lives of her kids are at serious risk. 'My son is also affected with this same whooping cough; I am worrying because one child has died already. I don't want my son to leave me,' she said. 'I am calling on all the health institutions to come to our aid before this disease goes out of hand.' Another parent whose 2 children are infected, is also worried that the current challenges facing the health sector would make it difficult to seek referral treatment in Buchanan city.\n\nThe outbreak comes as the major referral hospital in the county's capital \u00ad- the Liberian government hospital \u00ad- faces enormous challenges and is struggling to keep its doors open to patients. There are lots of challenges ranging from the lack of fuel allotment and essential drugs so we are constrained, said Dr Abraham Jawara, Medical Director of the hospital. Last week [week of 28 Jan 2019], Dr Jawara warned that outpatients were told to purchase their own drugs while inpatients have already been asked to transfer to other health centers.\n\n[Byline: Elton Wrionbee Tiah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Liberia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54\nGrand Bassa, with a population of 224 839 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Bassa_County) and Margibi, with a population of 199 689 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margibi_County), are 2 adjacent counties of Liberia's 15 counties on the north to central coast of Liberia. Buchanan is the capital of Grand Bassa county. A map of Liberia's counties can be found at http://investliberia.gov.lr/new/page_info.php?&7d5f44532cbfc489b8db9e12e44eb820=NDIw. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[2] Maine (Hancock, York, Waldo counties)\nDate: Fri 15 Feb 2019 1:00 AM EST\nSource: Bangor Daily News (BDN) [edited]\nhttps://bangordailynews.com/2019/02/15/news/hancock/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise-in-maine-with-nearly-30-percent-in-hancock-county/\n\n\nReported cases of whooping cough spiked in Maine last month [January 2019] to more than twice what that had been the prior year [2018], according to the state's public health agency. Overall, Maine had 55 reported cases of pertussis last month, up from 24 in January 2018, according to the Maine Center of Disease Control and Prevention's latest disease surveillance report released earlier this week [week of 4 Feb 2019].\n\nOf the 55 cases, 39 were in just 3 of Maine's 16 counties. Hancock county had the most with 16, York county had 13, and Waldo county had 10. More than half the cases affected children and teenagers between 11 and 19 years old, according to the Maine CDC.\n\nThe CDC last month [January 2019] declared only one outbreak of pertussis at an unidentified K-12 school in York county. Of nearly 450 reported cases of pertussis in Maine in 2018, York county had the most, with 174 reported cases. 20 outbreaks were identified in Maine last year [2018], with 9 occurring in York county and 4 in Hancock county.\n\nIn Hancock county, concern about the spread of pertussis last month [January 2019] prompted school officials with Regional School Unit [RSU] 24, which serves 9 towns, and at Ellsworth Elementary Middle School to send out notifications to parents. One case was confirmed at the Ellsworth school, but information about whether any cases were confirmed at RSU 24 schools was not made public. According to a report in the Ellsworth American weekly newspaper, 11 cases of whooping cough were reported at George Stevens Academy in Blue Hill between early November [2018] and mid-January [2019].\n\n[Byline: Bill Trotter]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Maine, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/222\nHancock county, with a population of 54 418 residents in 2010 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hancock_County,_Maine), Waldo county, with a population of 38 786 residents in 2010 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waldo_County,_Maine), and York county, with a population of 197 131 residents in 2010 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/York_County,_Maine), are located in the US state of Maine; Ellsworth is the county seat of Hancock county. A map showing the location of Maine counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/maine.shtml. Jackson Laboratory, Mt. Desert and Bar Harbor are located in Hancock county. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] South Dakota (Sioux Falls)\nDate: Thu 21 Feb 2019 4:43 PM EST\nSource: Argus Leader [abridged, edited]\nhttps://eu.argusleader.com/story/news/education/2019/02/21/pertussis-south-dakota-school-district-whooping-cough-symptoms-vaccinations/2937752002/\n\n\nPertussis cases are increasing in South Dakota, with the state already seeing 27 cases early in 2019. In particular, the Sioux Falls School District has seen 10 cases in 11 different schools since December [2018].\n\nWe spoke with Dr Joshua Clayton, the state epidemiologist for the South Dakota Department of Health, to find out what you need to know. Nationwide, there are between 10 000 and 40 000 cases of pertussis per year on average. Out of the 27 cases in South Dakota so far in 2019, 18 of them have been in children under 5 years old, Clayton said.\n\nWhy is South Dakota seeing more pertussis cases? Pertussis outbreaks tend to be cyclical, with spikes occurring every 3 to 5 years in general, Clayton said. In 2014, there were 109 cases, but that number dropped to as low as 9 in 2017 before skyrocketing to 162 cases in 2018. 'Every 3 to 5 years we do see an increase,' Clayton said. 'Part of that is due to waning immunity.' Unlike some vaccines, pertussis vaccines are only 85 percent effective, Clayton said, meaning there is a chance people who have been vaccinated will still get sick. Immunity typically only lasts about 2 years before beginning to decline.\n\nMolly Satter, the health services coordinator for the Sioux Falls School District, said 9 out of the 10 cases seen in the district this winter [2018-19] were up to date on their shots. Of the more than 23 000 students enrolled in the district, upward of 98 percent are fully vaccinated, she said.\n\nIn addition, the CDC says getting the pertussis vaccine can help prevent infection and lessen the severity of symptoms, even if you do get the disease. Before the pertussis vaccine was introduced in the 1940s, about 200 000 children contracted pertussis and 9000 died each year from it. Now, out of the 10 000 to 40 000 cases seen nationwide each year (https://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph-2017.jpg), only 20 people die each year.\n\n[Byline: Katie Nelson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of South Dakota, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16863\nSouth Dakota is a US state in the midwestern region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Dakota). Sioux Falls, with an estimated population of 187 200 residents in 2019, is the most populous city in South Dakota and is its fastest-growing metro area, with a population increase of 22% between 2000 and 2010 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_Falls,_South_Dakota). A map showing the location of Sioux Falls and South Dakota can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sioux+Falls,+SD. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] California (Los Angeles county)\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2019\nSource: The Chronicle, Harvard-Westlake school student newspaper [edited]\nhttp://hwchronicle.com/whooping-cough-outbreak-continues-to-grow/\n\n\nAs the number of whooping cough cases at school grows, the next step may be to limit interschool activities, according to the Los Angeles County Health Department Office of Communications and Public Affairs.\n\nThe whooping cough outbreak has now reached 30 students across both campuses [of the Harvard-Westlake School] between [16 Nov 2018] and [22 Feb 2019], according to an email sent to parents of students who are in a class with a student who has pertussis.\n\nAccording to the Office of Communications and Public Affairs, school closure due to the whooping cough outbreak is not probable, and there is not a number of cases at which the Health Department would tell the school to close.\n\n[Byline: Sophie Haber]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4259\nLos Angeles county is the most populous county in the US, with more than 10 million inhabitants as of 2017 and is the 3rd-largest metropolitan economy in the world, with a nominal GDP of over USD 700 billion; its county seat, is the city of Los Angeles, with a population of about 4 million residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_County,_California). Harvard-Westlake School has 2 campuses, the middle school in Holmby Hills and the high school in Studio City, located in the city of Los Angeles, with approximately 1600 students enrolled in grades 7 through 12 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard-Westlake_School). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[5] New Brunswick (Westmorland county)\nDate: Sun 3 Mar 2019 9:23 AM EST\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttps://globalnews.ca/news/5016793/nb-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nNew Brunswick has declared a whooping cough outbreak at Moncton High School [Westmorland county] after at least 5 cases of the highly contagious disease were diagnosed at the school.\n\n'Recognizing that this is highly unusual and that there are likely many other undiagnosed cases in the school, I have officially declared a pertussis outbreak at your school,' wrote Dr Yves A Leger, the Medical Officer of Health in the province's east region, in a letter sent to parents on [Sun 3 Mar 2019].\n\nLeger is recommending that if a parent or their child has a cough that they see a healthcare provider as soon as possible. 'Do not assume that it is merely a cold or the flu,' Leger writes in the letter. 'A simple test can be done to confirm if you have pertussis or not.' He recommends wearing a mask when arriving at the clinic and avoiding infants and pregnant women. Leger says that guardians should mention they are from the Moncton High School community and there have been many cases of whooping cough. It is also recommended that guardians should verify their child's immunization records.\n\nIn addition to routine childhood vaccines, an adolescent booster dose of the whooping cough vaccine is required and provided through the province's immunization clinics in Grade 7. Leger says that an adult booster dose at age 18 or later is also required.\n\nAccording to the region's immunization program statistics, Leger says up to 30 per cent of students have not received their adolescent booster dose. In an effort to change that, Leger says that the province will be holding an immunization clinic at the school on [20 Mar 2019]. In the case of a school closure, the clinic will be held on [21 Mar 2019]. Permission forms are set to be distributed after the March break.\n\nThe Medical Officer of Health says that if guardians are unsure whether their child has received their adolescent does that they should contact their usual provider or reach out to the local public health officer at 506-836-3502 or by email at <vaccine@gnb.ca>.\n\n[Byline: Alexander Quon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Brunswick, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14640\nMoncton, with a population of 71 889 residents in 2016, is the largest city in the Canadian province of New Brunswick (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moncton). A map showing the location of Moncton can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Moncton,+NB,+Canada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[6] Tasmania\nDate: Wed 20 Feb 2019 10:30 AM AEDT\nSource: The Advocate [edited]\nhttps://www.theadvocate.com.au/story/5914371/whooping-cough-reported-at-north-west-school/\n\n\nA North-West primary school has reported a case of whooping cough. Somerset Primary will send a note with more information home with the oldest child in each family on [Tue 19 Feb 2019].\n\nStatistics from Communicable Diseases Prevention Clinical Director Dr Faline Howes suggest that Tasmania is in the midst of an outbreak. There have been 124 notifications of whooping cough in January this year [2019]. This is an increase from 103 in December 2018, and 84 in November.\n\nDr Howes said Tasmanian outbreaks usually last for months and involve people of all ages over the whole state, with babies under 6 months of age being most at risk of life-threatening diseases. Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, is an infection caused by bacteria that affects the lungs and airways.\n\nLast year [2018] there was an outbreak of the disease on the coast prompting a warning for people to check their vaccinations were up to date.\n\n[Byline: Meg Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Tasmania, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64991\nTasmania, with a population of around 526 700 in 2018, is an island state of Australia, 240 km (150 mi) to the south of the Australian mainland, separated by Bass Strait; Hobart is the state capital and largest city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tasmania). A map showing the location of Tasmania can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/j6EeDyWEgyw. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4259\nLos Angeles county is the most populous county in the US, with more than 10 million inhabitants as of 2017 and is the 3rd-largest metropolitan economy in the world, with a nominal GDP of over USD 700 billion; its county seat, is the city of Los Angeles, with a population of about 4 million residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_County,_California). 17:37:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (09): USA, ITALY, AUSTRALIA, SOUTH AFRICA\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Alabama (Shelby & Jefferson Counties)\n[2] Colorado (Mesa county)\n\nItaly\n---\n[3] Lombardy (Bergamo)\n\nAustralia\n---\n[4] Western Australia\n\nSouth Africa\n---\n[5] National\n\n******\n[Note that while many of these reports are from last month, they reflect our increasing trend to put out monthly updates on pertussis if there are no special circumstances that would warrant more rapid reporting. - Mods. MPP/ML]\n\nUSA\n---\n[1] Alabama (Shelby & Jefferson counties)\nDate: Fri 3 Aug 2018\nSource: Trussville Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.trussvilletribune.com/2018/08/03/state-health-department-investigates-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-jefferson-shelby-counties/\n\n\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health [ADPH] is investigating an outbreak of pertussis, or whooping cough, in several facilities located in Jefferson and Shelby counties.\n\nAccording to the ADPH, 9 children have been confirmed as testing positive for the illness, with 22 people reported to have pertussis-like illness. These cases were reported after visiting facilities and events in Jefferson and Shelby counties.\n\nThese are: Shades Valley Community Church in Jefferson county from [1 Jun-15 Jul 2018]; YMCA Legacy Day Camp in Jefferson county from [4-8 Jun 2018]; Church of the Highlands (Grants Mill location) in Jefferson County from [27 Jun-22 Jul 2018]; Church of the Highlands (Greystone location) in Shelby County from [28 Jun-19 Jul 2018]; YMCA (Greystone) in Shelby County from [4-14 Jul 2018]; Mount Laurel Elementary Summer Singers Camp in Shelby County from [9-13 Jul 2018]; Mount Laurel Library in Shelby County on [16 Jul 2018]; and Winshape Camp at Double Oak Community Church in Shelby County from [16-20 July 2018].\n\nThe ADPH advises those who have been to the facilities in Jefferson and Shelby counties to contact their doctor and to fill out the pertussis questionnaire.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Alabama can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/205. Jefferson county, with a population of 658 466 residents, is the most populous county in the US state of Alabama; its county seat is the city of Birmingham (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_Alabama). Shelby county, with a population of 195 085 residents, is located immediately southeast of Jefferson county in the state of Alabama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shelby_County,_Alabama). A map of Alabama counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/alabama.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Colorado (Mesa county)\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018 6:00 PM MDT\nSource: KKCO/KJCT [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/Whooping-Cough-on-the-rise-23-cases-so-far--489575191.html\n\n\nMesa County Public Health Department says the number of whooping cough [pertussis] cases this year [2018] is one of the worst yet and continues to grow. 'It's a highly contagious respiratory illness,' said Katie Nelson with Mesa County Public Health. 'As of [20 Jul 2018] we have had 23 cases of whooping cough,' said Nelson. That's significant because it brings us to the same number of cases we saw throughout the entire year in 2017.\n\nMesa county has seen more cases in 2017 and 2018 than in any other year for the past 5 years. In 2013 we had 10 cases; in 2014 there were 19; in 2015 there were 9; in 2016 there were 11; and in 2017 there were 23 cases.\n\n'Unfortunately an infant in California did die due to whooping cough,' said Nelson.\n\nIt's a huge worry for local parents. [...]\n\nMesa County Public Health wants all residents, especially pregnant mothers and those around children, to make sure they are up to date on their immunizations. 'It can be fatal for infants and young children their lungs are still developing so diseases like this are really hard for them and their little bodies,' said Nelson.\n\n[...]\n\nSo cover the cough, wash your hands, and stay home if you're sick. Mesa County Public Health [hosted] a couple back to school vaccination clinics including whooping cough immunizations [on 4 and 8 Aug 2018].\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Bennett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Colorado can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201. Mesa county, with a population of 146 723 residents, is located in the US state of Colorado; the county seat is the city of Grand Junction (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesa_County,_Colorado). A map of Mesa county can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/CR99EyKyBYH2. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nItaly\n---\n[3] Lombardy (Bergamo)\nDate: Fri 3 Aug 2018 10:20 CEST\nSource: The Local [edited]\nhttps://www.thelocal.it/20180803/two-newborn-babies-die-of-whooping-cough-in-northern-italy\n\n\nLocal media reported on [Thu 2 Aug 2018] that 2 newborn babies have died of whooping cough in Bergamo near Milan. The children were born in May and June [2018], and died in a neonatal intensive care unit around a month after their birth. They had been born and received initial treatment in 2 different hospitals and were transferred to the neonatal unit at the Papa Giovanni XXIII hospital after being diagnosed with whooping cough.\n\nLombardy's Councillor for Welfare, Giulio Gallera, confirmed that the 2 cases occurred at different times and geographical locations, but said: 'There is no outbreak [of the disease] in the Bergamo area. The only protection remains the vaccination of mothers.'\n\nHe said that an already planned campaign would begin the [week of 6 Aug 2018] in Bergamo to raise awareness of the recommended vaccines for pregnant women, which include the whooping cough vaccine. Neither of their mothers had had difficulties during their pregnancy or childbirth, but neither had been vaccinated against the disease, l'Eco di Bergamo reported. Tests showed that the women had also suffered from whooping cough, which had not been diagnosed -- in adults, the symptoms of the disease can be similar to those of a common cold or flu virus.\n\nThe whooping cough inoculation was also among 10 made compulsory for Italian children starting at a state school in a controversial law passed last year [2017]. Parents had been set a July [2018] deadline to supply schools with doctor's notes proving the vaccination, but the new health minister said that a confirmation from parents would be sufficient.\n\nThis raised concerns from some, including Italy's National Health Institute, that it would be impossible to prove the children had received the inoculation, but Health Minister Giulia Grillo stressed that parents should not make false declarations.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Italy can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35892. Bergamo, with a population of about 120 000, is the 4th-largest city in Lombardy, northern Italy, approximately 40 km (25 mi) northeast of Milan in the foothills of the Bergamo Alps north of the city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bergamo). A map showing the location of Bergamo can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/TAdXH4AokG32. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[4] Western Australia\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2018 6:13 AM AWST\nSource: The West Australian [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/regional/tourist-town-hit-by-whooping-cough-cluster-ng-b88919183z\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough in Margaret River has led medical experts to remind people to update their vaccinations. 9 cases of whooping cough have hit the popular WA [Western Australia] tourist town within the past 2 months.\n\nThe illness, which can be fatal for very young babies and children, can be vaccinated against, and news of the cluster of Margaret River cases comes as it was revealed the tourist town was a 'hot spot' for low vaccination rates in the under 5s.\n\nWA Country Health public health physician Dr Clare Huppatz predicted there were likely to be more people suffering from whooping cough in the region who had not been diagnosed. 'What we see in Margaret River, is what we see in most of the state, and that is from time to time we have an increase or cluster of cases,' she said. 'That is because it is a disease which is easily transmitted from droplets spread through coughing. So people who are not vaccinated or waning immunity are more likely to get it.'\n\nUnder the WA schedule, children are due to be vaccinated between 6 and 8 weeks old, 4 months and 6 months, before they have a booster shot at 3.5 years old and in year 8. Pregnant women can get a free vaccine shot during their 3rd trimester. Dr Huppatz said although the vaccine was not 'perfect' it was proven to help stop the spread among infants. 'Those newborn kids, who cannot be vaccinated, can end up in hospital and with a serious disease,' she said. 'So everyone getting vaccinated helps protect them.'\n\nIn March 2018, Health Department figures showed the number of cases of whooping cough in WA had fallen 20 per cent since the tragic death of [a] baby 3 years ago. [The baby] was only 32 days old when he died in March 2015 from whooping cough complications, prompting his parents to successfully campaign for a free vaccine for pregnant women in WA. At the time, [the baby's] mum, director of the Immunisation Foundation of Australia, said it was reassuring whooping cough in WA was declining. But she said no one could afford to be complacent because the disease still posed a real risk to babies and young children, particularly if they were not immunised.\n\n[Byline: Mitchell Woodcock]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Australia can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64511. Western Australia, Australia's largest state, occupies the entire western 1/3 of Australia; the state has about 2.6 million residents, of whom the vast majority (92 percent) live in the south-west corner, 73 percent of the population living in the Perth area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia). Margaret River is a town, with a population of about 4400 residents, located 277 km (172 mi) south of the city of Perth, the state capital, in the Margaret River valley, a wine region; the Indian Ocean coast, 9 km (6 mi) west of the town, is a renowned surfing location (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_River,_Western_Australia). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nSouth Africa\n---\n[5] National\nDate: Wed 22 Aug 2018 3:14 PM SAST\nSource: IOL (Independent Online, South Africa) [edited]\nhttps://www.iol.co.za/ios/news/national-increase-in-whooping-cough-cases-16688373\n\n\nIf you've had a particularly bad cough while suffering from the flu, you could have been one of the many people badly affected by 'pertussis', otherwise known as whooping cough.\n\nThe [South Africa] National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) reported that there has been an increase in confirmed cases of whooping cough among children under the age of 5 [years], across the country.\n\n'Pertussis, commonly known as 'whooping cough' is a vaccine-preventable disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ and is notifiable according to the Health Act. An increase in pertussis cases has been reported from sites in kZN [KwaZulu-Natal], Western Cape, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, and North West.\n\nOf the [37] pertussis cases identified between May and July 2018, 20 (54 percent) were aged under 3 months.\n\nThese sites form part of a pneumonia surveillance programme.\n\n'Clinicians are advised to be on the alert for cases, to conduct diagnostic testing where appropriate, to notify cases and prescribe post-exposure prophylaxis to close and high-risk contacts of suspected or confirmed cases,' said the NICD in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Arthi Gopi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of South Africa can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179. South Africa is the southernmost country in Africa; its 9 provinces can be found on a map at https://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Date: Mon 30 Jul 2018 6:00 PM MDT\nSource: KKCO/KJCT [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/Whooping-Cough-on-the-rise-23-cases-so-far--489575191.html\n\n\nMesa County Public Health Department says the number of whooping cough [pertussis] cases this year [2018] is one of the worst yet and continues to grow. "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/205", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shelby "Birmingham", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6226635", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (11): USA, Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6226635", "date": "2018-12-28 20:40:36", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (11): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nUSA\n---\n[1] California (Santa Cruz County)\n[2] Montana (Flathead County)\n[3] Ohio (Tuscarawas, Harrison, and Carroll counties)\n[4] Washington (Okanogan County)\n[5] South Dakota (Minnehaha and Lincoln counties)\n\nAustralia\n---\n[6] New South Wales\n[7] Tasmania\n[8] Queensland\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] California (Santa Cruz County)\nDate: Fri 23 Nov 2018\nSource: SF Gate [edited]\nhttps://www.sfgate.com/news/bayarea/article/Whooping-Cough-Cases-Soaring-Public-Officials-Say-13416575.php\n\n\nPublic health officials are warning Santa Cruz County residents of a recent uptick in whooping cough cases. The Santa Cruz County Health Services Agency reports that there have been 66 confirmed whooping cough cases since 1 Sep [2018].\n\n'The number of local pertussis (whooping cough) cases has increased dramatically in recent months,' health officials said in a news release. Most of the cases came from school outbreaks, according to the release. Officials didn't say how many cases of the highly contagious illness were reported before 1 Sep [2018].\n\nOfficials are working with schools, families, and clinicians to stop outbreaks and prevent more from happening, according to the news release. People can protect themselves from the illness by getting a whooping cough vaccine, according to the release. People should also wash their hands, sneeze into their elbows, and stay home from work or school if they're sick.\n\nThe symptoms of whooping cough are often confused with the common cold at 1st. Violent coughing can start one to 2 weeks after the cold symptoms. The illness is treated with antibiotics.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Santa Cruz County, with a population of 262 382 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the US state of California, forming the northern coast of the Monterey Bay, with Monterey County forming the southern coast; its county seat is Santa Cruz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Cruz_County,_California). A map showing the location of Santa Crux County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Santa+Cruz+County,+CA. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Montana (Flathead County)\nDate: Wed 28 Nov 2018\nSource: NBC Montana [edited]\nhttps://nbcmontana.com/news/local/health-department-reports-rise-in-pertussis-activity-in-flathead-co\n\n\nThe Flathead City-County Health Department reported a recent rise in pertussis activity. According to a press release, 32 cases have been reported to the department this year [2018], and department officials told NBC Montana that 5 cases were reported Wednesday [28 Nov 2018].\n\nPertussis can only be confirmed through a nasal swab test. It's a notifiable infectious disease, meaning cases must be reported to the health department. If a case is confirmed, the patient and members of their household are given antibiotics, Dennison said. The Flathead City-County Health Department will also investigate the case to determine others who might have been in contact with the patient and could be at risk.\n\nDennison said most cases reported to the health department this year [2018] have been among elementary- and middle school-age children. 'We've had multiple schools in Flathead County that have been impacted with pertussis,' Dennison said.\n\nIf a student is diagnosed with pertussis, the school will notify parents. 'If your child is considered to be a contact, you will be contacted by the health department,' Dennison said.\n\nWhile the health department reported an increase in pertussis activity in Flathead County, data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System shows that cases in the state are down from this time last year [2017]. Last year [2017], 98 cases of pertussis were reported in Montana through 18 Nov [2017]. This year [2018], 59 cases have been reported through Nov. 17 [2018].\n\nThe number of cases has trended down nationally since 2012. According to CDC data, 48 227 cases were reported in 2012; 28 639 cases were reported in 2013; 32 971 cases were reported in 2014; 20 762 cases were reported in 2015; 17 972 cases were reported in 2016; and 18 975 cases were reported in 2018.\n\nThere is a vaccine for pertussis, and in Montana, children are required to be vaccinated to enter preschool or kindergarten. Children are also required to get another pertussis-containing vaccine before starting 7th grade.\n\nDennison said adults should make sure their pertussis vaccine is up-to-date. Even if it doesn't prevent the illness, it could mitigate the symptoms.\n\n'It's concerning, the fact that it's so highly contagious and that it is a very dangerous illness,' Dennison said. 'We don't want it to happen, and we try to limit the spread of it.'\n\n[Byline: Marian Davidson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Flathead County, with a population of 90 928 residents in 2010, is located in the US state of Montana on the Canada-US border of British Columbia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flathead_County,_Montana). A map showing the location of Flathead County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Flathead+County,+MT. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Ohio (Tuscarawas, Harrison and Carroll counties)\nDate: Thu 6 Dec 2018\nSource: Times Reporter [edited]\nhttps://www.timesreporter.com/news/20181206/akron-childrens-new-philadelphia-office-sees-spike-in-pertussis-cases\n\n\nIn recent weeks, pediatricians from the New Philadelphia office of Akron Children's Hospital Pediatrics have confirmed 14 cases of pertussis (whooping cough), a very contagious and potentially deadly illness, especially for newborns and others at high risk.\n\nAkron Children's is working with public health officials in Tuscarawas, Harrison, and Carroll counties to see if there is any link between the patients, such as sharing the same schools or day-care centers.\n\nDr. Andrew Newburn, a pediatrician at the New Philadelphia office, said the recent spike in cases is a reminder of the importance of getting immunized for pertussis, using good hygiene when coughing and sneezing, and seeking immediate treatment when parents notice symptoms consistent with the disease. 'While pertussis vaccines are the most effective tool to prevent this disease, no vaccine is 100% effective,' said Newburn. 'When pertussis circulates in a community, there is a chance that a fully vaccinated person, of any age, can catch this disease, but your symptoms will typically be much less severe.'\n\nPertussis is caused by a type of bacterium called _Bordetella pertussis_. The bacteria attach to the cilia, the tiny hair-like extensions that line part of the upper respiratory system, and release toxins that damage the cilia and cause airways to swell. Pertussis is spread by coughing and sneezing. Infected people are most contagious up to about 2 weeks after the cough begins.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend the pertussis vaccine for all babies, children, teens, and pregnant women. The 2 kinds of vaccines used today also help protect against other diseases: the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (DTaP) vaccine is for babies and children younger than 7 [years of age]; the tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is for older children and adults.\n\n'Since the 1st dose of DTaP vaccine begins at 2 months of age, newborns are especially at risk for pertussis, a very important reason for parents and caregivers to get vaccinated if they have not already done so,' said Newburn. 'About half of babies younger than one year who get the disease need care in the hospital. The younger the baby, the more likely they will need treatment in the hospital.' The 5 DTaP doses are recommended at 2, 4, and 6 months; 15-18 months; and 4-6 years.'\n\nInitially, pertussis starts with cold-like symptoms, including a mild cough or fever. After one to 2 weeks, the symptoms of pertussis typically include rapid fits of cough followed by a high-pitched 'whoop' sound, vomiting during or after coughing, and exhaustion after coughing fits.\n\n'Babies may or may not cough,' Newburn said. 'A significant complication (along with the cough) is 'apnea,' or a pause in the breathing. In worst-case scenarios, the disease may cause them to stop breathing and turn blue.'\n\n'Pertussis can usually be successfully treated with a 5-day course of antibiotics,' said Newburn. 'A good general rule for older children is that if a cough is not getting better after 7 days, or if there are other characteristic findings consistent with pertussis, it's wise to make a doctor's appointment. With babies, don't wait to seek care.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuscarawas (population 92 582 residents), Harrison (population 15 864 residents), and Carroll (population 28 836 residents) are adjacent counties in the eastern-central region of the US state of Ohio; New Philadelphia, with a population of 17 288 residents in 2010, is the county seat of Tuscarawas County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Philadelphia,_Ohio). A map showing the location of New Philadelphia can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/New+Philadelphia,+OH+44663. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Washington (Okanogan County)\nDate: Thu 20 Dec 2018\nSource: KOZI [edited]\nhttps://kozi.com/pertussis-alert/\n\n\nOkanogan County Public Health has 13 confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) in the Oroville, Tonasket, and Omak area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Okanogan County, with a population of 41 120, is a county located in the US state of Washington along the Canada-US border; its largest city is Omak. A map showing the location of Okanogan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Okanogan+County,+WA. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota (Minnehaha and Lincoln counties)\nDate: Fri 21 Dec 2018\nSource: Ketoland News [edited]\nhttps://www.keloland.com/news/local-news/whooping-cough-shows-up-at-lincoln-high-school/1670459958\n\n\nSouth Dakota is seeing a lot more cases of whooping cough. One place it has shown up is at Lincoln High School, in Sioux Falls. Thursday [20 Dec 2018] the district sent a note to parents, letting them know that their child may have been exposed to the illness in the past few weeks.\n\nA November [2018] report says the state has confirmed 120 cases. That's a 700% increase compared to the last 5 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sioux Falls, with a population of 183 000 residents in 2018, is the most populous city in the US state of South Dakota (located in the Midwestern region of the USA) and is the county seat of Minnehaha County and also extends into Lincoln County to the south. A map showing the location of counties in South Dakota can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_South_Dakota. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[6] New South Wales\nDate: Mon 26 Nov 2018\nSource: Northern Star [edited]\nhttps://www.northernstar.com.au/news/deadly-disease-endangers-babies/3585332/\n\n\nA deadly disease has again reared its ugly head, and anyone thought to be suffering is urged to stay home from work or school and see their GP immediately.\n\nNew South Wales Health is urging all pregnant women and new parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time.\n\nDespite almost 95% of infants in NSW now vaccinated against the disease, outbreaks still occur every 3-4 years as community immunity wanes, and recent high numbers indicate an outbreak may be on the way. An outbreak earlier this year [2018] on the Northern Rivers saw 21 cases within 4 weeks\n\nDr Vicky Sheppeard, NSW Health's Director of Communicable Diseases, said that in October 2018, almost 800 people in NSW were notified with whooping cough (pertussis), the highest number since October 2016. 'Whooping cough is challenging to control at the community level, as it is a highly infectious disease, and immunity against whooping cough wanes over time, regardless of whether that immunity is from having the disease or as a result of vaccination,' Dr Sheppeard said. 'This means that the number of people susceptible to whooping cough in the community builds up over time, and this can cause periodic spikes or larger outbreaks of the disease. The aim of whooping cough control is to protect infants, who are at highest risk of severe disease or death if they contract whooping cough. Whooping cough vaccination is effective in preventing severe infection.'\n\nA GP can test for whooping cough and prescribe antibiotics. People suspected of whooping cough should stay home until they have completed a 5-day course of antibiotics.\n\nSince NSW Health introduced free whooping cough vaccination for pregnant women in April 2015 to protect infants in the 1st weeks of life, there have been no infant deaths from whooping cough in NSW, compared to 4 deaths in the previous 6 years. 'People in close contact with newborn infants, such as grandparents, partners, and close family members, should ensure that they have had a whooping cough vaccine in the previous 10 years,' Dr Sheppeard said. 'Those that need to get vaccinated should do so at least 2 weeks before any infant contact.'\n\nIn May this year [2018], federal health minister Greg Hunt urged all parents-to-be to get vaccinated. His comments came in the wake of the infant who contracted the illness and died when he was just 32 days old.\n\nFor more information, see http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/infectious/whoopingcough/pages/default.aspx.\nFind a whooping cough fact sheet at http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/whoopingcough/Pages/factsheet.aspx.\n\n[Byline: Alison Paterson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[New South Wales, with a population of over 7.9 million residents in 2018, is a state on the east coast of Australia, bordering Queensland to the north, Victoria to the south, and South Australia to the west; its state capital, Sydney, with a population of 5.1 million residents, is Australia's most populous city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_South_Wales). A map showing the location of New South Wales can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/New+South+Wales,+Australia. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[7] Tasmania\nDate: Mon 26 Nov 2018\nSource: Weekly Times Now [edited]\nhttps://tendaily.com.au/lifestyle/health/a181126mag/pregnant-women-warned-after-whooping-cough-outbreak-20181126\n\n\nPregnant women in Tasmania are being urged to get vaccinated for whooping cough after a spike in the bacterial disease that can be deadly for newborns. There have been 170 whooping cough cases throughout the state since early August [2018], and 239 this year [2018], compared to 40 reported cases in 2017.\n\nCases are most prevalent in the state's north, including around Devonport, but are also increasing in the south. 'Schools are reporting student and staff illness with children aged under 14 years most affected, particularly those from 5-9 years old,' director of public health Mark Veitch said on Monday [26 Nov 2018].\n\nWhooping cough vaccines are free for pregnant women, with the disease life-threatening to newborn babies. The vaccine is also free for children aged 6 months, 2 years and 4 [years].\n\nThe last Tasmania-wide whooping cough outbreak was in 2012, with more than 1200 notified cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tasmania, with a population of 526 700 residents in 2018, is an island state of Australia, located 240 km (150 mi) to the south of the Australian mainland, separated by the Bass Strait; just over 40% of the population resides in the Greater Hobart precinct, which forms the metropolitan area of Hobart, the state capital, and largest city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tasmania). Health officials say all 4 individuals are within a single household and risk to the community is low. However they are concerned about the risk of more cases. All family members with a 'close' contact to those with whooping cough have been notified by GCHD and offered post-exposure prophylaxis with antibiotics.\n\nThe Grant County Health District urges parents to have their children vaccinated against whooping cough with the Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] shot.\n\n[byline: Brian Neale]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population was 89 120 in 2010, is located in the center of the US state of Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_County,_Washington). That's the highest number of reported cases in the region since at least 2010. The only years that came close were 2013, 2014, and 2017 when 5 to 6 cases were reported each year.\n\n'And the reports we get are probably just the tip of the iceberg,' EIPHD epidemiologist Ken Anderson told EastIdahoNews.com. 'I'm sure there are more out there that just don't get reported.' Other years, there have [been] few or sometimes no cases reported.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bonneville county, with a population of 104 234 in 2010, is located in the US state of Idaho; its county seat and largest city is Idaho Falls (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonneville_County,_Idaho). 'Most of the recent pertussis cases have occurred in school-aged children, with infants at the greatest risk for severe complications,' said Dr Matt Willis, Marin county's public health officer, in a press release.\n\nDuring April and May 2018, 36 pertussis cases were reported to the Marin County Department of Public Health, which is located north of San Francisco.\n\nPreviously, on [26 Mar 2018], the Marin County Health and Human Services' Communicable Disease Prevention and Control investigated 65 cases of pertussis in Marin county. The county reported 44 pertussis cases in 2017, and 30 cases in 2016. The largest pertussis outbreak in California was in 2010 when more than 9000 cases were reported.\n\n'Other Bay Area counties are also seeing more pertussis this spring [2018],' Dr Willis said. 'Only time will tell if we're heading for another outbreak of the magnitude of 2010.'\n\nThere were 17 972 reported pertussis cases in the United States in 2016, including 6 infant deaths, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\n[byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Marin county, with a population of 252 409 in 2010, is located across the Golden Gate Bridge just north of the city of San Francisco in the San Francisco Bay Area of the US state of California (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_County,_California). PERTUSSIS (07): USA\n*******************\n During April and May 2018, 36 pertussis cases were reported to the Marin County Department of Public Health, which is located north of San Francisco. \n\nThe state has recorded 145 cases of whooping cough between the start of the year [2018] and [30 Apr 2018]. The Grant County [Washington] Health District [GCHD] announced on Tuesday afternoon [22 May 2018] that it is investigating 4 confirmed cases of whooping cough. The county reported 44 pertussis cases in 2017, and 30 cases in 2016. Most of the recent pertussis cases have occurred in school-aged children, with infants at the greatest risk for severe complications,' said Dr Matt Willis, Marin county's public health officer, in a press release. \n\nAnyone with questions about whooping cough can call the Calhoun County Public Health Department at 269.969.6363. Bonneville county, which abuts Madison county to the north, can be located on a map at (https://www.google.com/maps/place/Bonneville+County,+ID,+USA). http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10484.] [4] California (Marin county)\n [4] California (Marin county)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 "2018-07-20 04:51:31", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (08): AUSTRALIA, USA, CANADA, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nAustralia\n---\n[1] Victoria (Geelong)\n[2] New South Wales (Dungog, Clarence)\n\nUSA\n---\n[3] Oregon (Lane county)\n[4] California (San Bernardino county)\n\nCanada\n---\n[5] Ontario (Parry Sound district)\n\nDominican Republic\n---\n[6] San Crist\u00f3bal, Santo Domingo Norte, Santiago\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[1] Victoria (Geelong)\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2018\nSource: Bay 93.9 [edited]\nhttps://www.bay939.com.au/news/local-news/94044-push-for-booster-shots-as-whooping-cough-cases-climb\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases across Greater Geelong has risen, prompting calls for adults to get their booster shots. There have been 55 cases in the Geelong region so far this year [2018], slightly more than the 51 recorded at the same time last year [2017].\n\nBarwon Health says the booster vaccine can help stop the spread of the infection. Health officials say one in every 200 babies who contract whooping cough will die, and immunisation is the best way to reduce the risk.\n\n[byline: Rebecca McDonald]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Geelong is a port city, with an estimated urban population of 192 393 residents in 2016, in the state of Victoria, Australia, 75 km (47 mi) south west of the state capital, Melbourne on the Bellarine Peninsula (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geelong). A map that shows the location of Geelong can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Geelong+VIC+3220,+Australia. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] New South Wales (Dungog, Clarence)\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2018 7:00 AM AEST\nSource: Dungog Chronicle [edited]\nhttps://www.dungogchronicle.com.au/story/5443209/whooping-cough-cases/\n\n\nSeveral cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in children from the Dungog and Clarence Town areas.\n\nDr Kat Taylor, a Hunter New England Health physician said while the local outbreak was not particularly unusual, it was a reminder for people to keep vigilant as the contagious bacterial disease can have severe implications. The disease, also known as pertussis, can be life threatening for babies.\n\n'Whooping cough has been on the rise generally in NSW [New South Wales] for the past 10 years,' she said. 'There is always whooping cough about in the community and at times there is a bit more than others.\n\n'The year [2018] to date [6 Jun 2018] figures for the Lower Hunter area show there have been 59 cases notified which is slightly up, with 18 more cases than this time last year [2017].' Whooping cough is a notifiable condition which means general practitioners, schools and day care centres must notify the public health unit when a case is diagnosed. 'It's a reminder to check your vaccination status particularly if you are working with children and keep coughing children away from school or daycare,' said Dr Taylor.\n\n[byline: Michelle Mexon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Dungog and Clarence are country towns, with populations of about 2100 residents each, in Dungog Shire, the Hunter region of New South Wales, Australia, about 215 km (134 mi) north of Sydney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dungog,_New_South_Wales and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Town,_New_South_Wales). Dungog can be located on a map at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Dungog+NSW+2420,+Australia. The Hunter region, also commonly known as the Hunter Valley, is one of the largest river valleys on the NSW coast, and is most commonly known for its wineries and coal industry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter_Region). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[3] Oregon (Lane county)\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2018\nSource: KLCC 89.7 [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/worst-pertussis-outbreak-county-five-years\n\n\nAlmost 3 dozen Adams Elementary School students are staying home from school due to an outbreak of whooping cough.\n\nThe Register Guard reports that Adams is one of 8 schools in Eugene and Springfield to experience whooping cough outbreaks this spring. On [Tue 5 Jun 2018], Lane county health officials contacted 35 Adams' families to let them know their children are not allowed on campus during the outbreak because they don't meet immunization requirements against the highly contagious respiratory disease.\n\nLane County public health spokesman Jason Davis tells the Guard that 'it's been the worst pertussis season in 5 years in the county and that 'we are absolutely not out of the clear yet.'' So far, the county has investigated 142 whooping cough cases. Positive lab tests have been returned in 108 of those. Usually, 20 confirmed cases are reported in the county in a typical year.\n\n[byline: Anni Katz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane county, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast in the US state of Oregon; its county seat is the city of Eugene, with a population of 156 185 residents, (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). Springfield is a smaller city, with a population of 59 403 residents, within the Eugene-Springfield Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield,_Oregon). A map showing the location of Lane county can be located at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR,+USA. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] California (San Bernardino county)\nDate: Tue 17 Jul 2018, 2:37 PM PDT\nSource: KMIR [edited]\nhttps://kmir.com/2018/07/17/first-confirmed-whooping-cough-death-in-a-california-infant-since-2016/\n\n\nThe California Department of Public Health (CDPH) announced [Tue 17 Jul 2018] pertussis, better known as whooping cough, claimed the life of a San Bernardino county infant. This is the 1st confirmed infant death from the disease since 2016, when 2 deaths occurred.\n\n'This baby's death is a tragedy for the family and for California as a community, as this is a preventable disease,' said Dr Karen Smith, CDPH director and state public health officer. 'This serves as a grim reminder that whooping cough is always present in our communities, and immunizations are the 1st line of defense.'\n\nEach year, 50-200 California infants are hospitalized with pertussis. CDPH and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend that expectant mothers receive the whooping cough booster shot (also called Tdap, or tetanus, diphtheria and acellular pertussis vaccine) at the earliest opportunity between 27 and 36 weeks of every pregnancy, even if previously immunized. Getting immunized during pregnancy boosts a mother's immunity and passes on protective antibodies directly to their babies before birth. This helps protect newborns until they are old enough to begin receiving their own whooping cough immunizations at 6 to 8 weeks of age.\n\n'No baby should have to be hospitalized due to a vaccine-preventable disease, and certainly no baby should die,' said Dr Smith. 'To give babies the best protection, I urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated against whooping cough as early as possible during the 3rd trimester of every pregnancy.'\n\nTo avoid the spread of whooping cough, CDPH also recommends that:\n- parents immunize their babies against whooping cough as soon as possible. The 1st dose is recommended at 2 months of age, but can be given as early as 6 weeks of age;\n- California 7th grade students [should] receive the whooping cough booster, Tdap;\n- adults should receive a whooping cough booster once in their lives.\n\nMore information about pertussis is available on CDPH's website.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[5] Ontario (Parry Sound district)\nDate: Thu 5 Jul 2018, 7:00 AM ET\nSource: CBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/whooping-cough-powassan-health-unit-vaccination-1.4734371\n\n\nConfirmed cases of whooping cough have been identified in Powassan and surrounding area. The North Bay Parry Sound District Health Unit says it has confirmed a few cases of pertussis -- commonly called whooping cough -- in the Powassan area.\n\nDr Jim Chirico, medical officer of health, is urging parents and guardians to check that their children have been vaccinated. Whooping cough vaccine's immunity drops substantially over time. If they haven't, he says, contact the health unit or a doctor.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Powassan is a municipality with a population of about 6400 residents in the Canadian province of Ontario, located near North Bay in the Almaguin Highlands region of Parry Sound District, about 330 km (205 mi) north of Toronto (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powassan). A map showing the location of Powassan can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Powassan,+ON+P0H+1Z0,+Canada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nDominican Republic\n---\n[6] San Crist\u00f3bal, Santo Domingo Norte, Santiago\nDate: Wed 27 Jun 2018\nSource: Hoy Digital [in Spanish, machine trans, edited]\nhttp://hoy.com.do/mueren-dos-ninos-por-tosferina-en-el-robert-reid-cabral/\n\n\nTwo children under 2 [years of age] died in the last week at the Robert Reid Cabral Children's Hospital because of whooping cough, a contagious and vaccine-preventable disease. The dead are a girl aged 15 months from the community of Cambita, San Crist\u00f3bal and another one of 3 months, who lived in La Romana.\n\nAlso, another 28 children have been admitted with this disease, which calls the attention of the pediatricians of the hospital, since the vaccine that immunizes is included in the Expanded Program of Immunizations (PAI).\n\nThe official website of the Ministry of Health, in the epidemiology component, defines pertussis as an endemic respiratory disease that commonly affects children under the age of 5, with infants under 6 months of age at the highest risk of complications, but also it can affect teenagers and adults. The use of the vaccination scheme with DPT [diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus] or pentavalent [diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, and _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b (Hib)] is the main prevention measure, while pertussis outbreaks tend to occur every 3 to 4 years, according to official information.\n\nSo far this year [2018], 29 probable cases of whooping cough have been reported, 7 in the last 4 epidemiological weeks. As many as 9 out of 10 cases correspond to children under 1 year of age. Santo Domingo Norte and Santiago are the demarcations that register the highest number of cases.\n\nFaced with this situation, the Ministry of Health instructed the provincial directorates and corresponding health areas to ensure adequate research and response to preventable diseases.\n\n[byline: Altagracia Ortiz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nKathryn Soderholm\n<kathryn.soderholm@gmail.com>\n\n[The Dominican Republic, with a population of about 10 million residents, occupies the eastern 2 thirds of the island of Hispaniola, in the Greater Antilles archipelago in the Caribbean region; the western third of Hispaniola is occupied by the country of Haiti (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominican_Republic). San Crist\u00f3bal, a city and province, is located near the southern coast on the Caribbean Sea; the city is about 30 km (19 mi) west of the nation's capital, Santo Domingo (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Crist\u00f3bal,_Dominican_Republic). La Romana is a city and province on the southern coast on the Caribbean Sea, about 125 km (78 mi) east of Santo Domingo (https://www.google.com/maps/dir/La+Romana,+Dominican+Republic/Santo+Domingo,+Dominican+Republic). The city of Santiago, in the north central region of the country, is the 2nd-largest city in the Dominican Republic and the 4th-largest city in the Caribbean (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santiago_de_los_Caballeros). Santo Domingo Norte is a city immediately north of Santo Domingo (https://www.google.com/maps/place/Santo+Domingo+Norte,+Dominican+Republic). - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12\nDominican Republic: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/24]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Anni Katz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane county, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast in the US state of Oregon; Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5790855", "date": "2018-05-09 16:25:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (06): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\n[2] Oregon\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/redmond-whooping-cough-cases-prompt-letters-to-parents/734169668\n\n\nFour Redmond School District (RSD) students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and 'recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.'\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. 'Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,' Mucha said. 'It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.'\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: KLCC [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/public-health-officials-warn-whooping-cough-outbreak-eugene\n\n\nLane County Public Health has confirmed 10 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, at Sheldon High School in Eugene [Oregon].\n\nDr. Patrick Luedtke with Lane County Public Health says pertussis can spread quickly among those who are not vaccinated. Luedtke: 'We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.'\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Lane County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018, 10:54 AM\nSource: WITN [edited]\nhttp://www.witn.com/content/news/Ten-confirmed-cases-in-Carteret-County-whooping-cough-outbreak-480817891.html?ref=891\n\n\nHealth officials in one Eastern Carolina county are warning parents to be on the lookout for whooping cough.\n\nThe Carteret County Health Department says so far there have been 10 confirmed cases of the highly contagious respiratory disease. The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). An adjacent county, north of Carteret County, Craven County, with a population of 103 505 residents in 2010, is also located in the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is New Bern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craven_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. 'Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],' said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. 'There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.'\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n'Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,' Treague said. 'Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.'\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake.
