post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Georgia\n[2] Oregon\n[3] New Mexico\n[4] Utah\n[5] Vaccine efficacy\n---\nChina\n---\n[6] Hong Kong\n\n******\n[1] USA (Georgia)\nDate: Mon 12 Mar 2018\nSource: WBRC [edited]\nhttp://www.wbrc.com/story/37707905/whooping-cough-raising-concerns-in-southwest-georgia\n\n\nHealth leaders said the number of whooping cough cases is climbing in Southwest Georgia. Since January [2018], 3 cases have been confirmed in Thomas, Mitchell, and Colquitt Counties.\n\nMonday [12 Mar 2018], the Southwest Health District said the entire region could be at risk for the disease if they are not vaccinated immediately. 'We could walk around for a week thinking we have a cold or a sinus infection, and it could really be pertussis,' said Rebecca Snow, District Immunization Coordinator. Snow said this is alarming because adults could have the whooping cough and spread it without knowing. 'This could be in an infant, medically, or immune-comprised person; it could be pretty serious,' said Snow.\n\n'So far this year [2018], we've had 3 cases, one of which included a 5-month-old. The other 2 are associated with a 5-month-old,' said Snow.\n\nThe Southwest District covers 14 counties, including Dougherty, Worth, Lee, and Terrell Counties. They are encouraging all residents to go to their local health department to get vaccinated as soon as possible.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Southwest Georgia is a 14-county region in the U.S. state of Georgia. It has a 2010 census population of 496 433 and is the least populated region in Georgia, just slightly behind Southeast Georgia; additionally, the area has historically been the poorest region of the state since at least 1995, when over 25% of the residents were in poverty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Georgia#Counties).\n\nThe city of Albany (population 77 434) is the most populous city and the region's sole metropolitan area. Southwest Georgia includes the following counties: Baker, Calhoun, Colquitt, Decatur, Dougherty, Early, Grady, Lee, Miller, Mitchell, Seminole, Terrell, Thomas, and Worth (http://www.southwestgeorgiapublichealth.org). A map showing the location of Southwest Georgia can be found at https://www.georgiastandards.org/Learning/Pages/ETC-RESA/RESA.aspx. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Oregon)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2018\nSource: Portland Tribune [edited]\nhttp://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/389159-280065-newberg-whooping-cough-problems-are-escalating\n\n\nYamhill County Public Health officials have confirmed 5 new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, at Newberg High School, bringing the total to 7 since mid-January 2018.\n\nAccording to Yamhill County Health and Human Services (HHS) Deputy Director Lindsey Manfrin, the situation is considered an outbreak per Oregon Health Authority investigative disease guidelines.\n\nThe Public Health arm of HHS shared the information with parents in a letter dated 26 Feb [2018], encouraging families to continue adhering to the precautions it has been recommending since notifying the community of the 1st confirmed case in early January [2018].\n\nThe 3 primary recommendations are to consult a health care provider if they or their children have symptoms of pertussis, to ensure families are up to date on their vaccinations and that pregnant women should receive the Tdap booster with every pregnancy to prevent infecting newborns after they are born.\n\nThe notification letter stated that people exposed to the infection could currently be symptomatic or become so between 4 to 21 days after close contact exposure. It also stated that close contact exposures did occur with members of the boys' basketball and wrestling teams.\n\nFor more information, call the Public Health office at 503-434-7525.\n\n[Byline: Seth Gordon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Yamhill County, with a population of 99 193 in 2010, is a county in the northwestern part of the U.S. state of Oregon in the Willamette Valley; the county seat is McMinnville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Oregon). Yamhill County is part of the Portland-Vancouver-Hillsboro, OR-WA Metropolitan Statistical Area. A map showing the location of Yamhill County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Yamhill+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] USA (New Mexico)\nDate: Wed 21 Mar 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/new-mexico-pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-64114/\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) reported this week a community-wide outbreak of whooping cough in McKinley County.\n\nAs of 14 Mar 2018, NMDOH reports 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 15 probable cases. These cases have primarily occurred in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\nEarly diagnosis and treatment of potential cases and immediate reporting of cases to NMDOH for public health investigation and contact management will help in limiting more cases from occurring. Healthcare providers should be vigilant for possible additional cases among their patients, especially infants and caregivers of infants.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alert\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 in 2010, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is the city of Gallup. A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] USA (Utah)\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2018\nSource: KSL [edited]\nhttps://www.ksl.com/index.php?sid=46294465&nid=148&title=3-draper-schools-warn-parents-of-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\n12 students have confirmed cases of whooping cough at 3 schools in Draper, officials said. Parents of Corner Canyon High School students were warned of an outbreak in late March [2018] after 5 students were diagnosed with the respiratory disease, according to Salt Lake County Health Department spokesman Nicholas Rupp. Corner Canyon is now reporting 7 cases, Draper Park Middle School reports 2 cases, and Oak Hollow Elementary reports 3.\n\nParents of Corner Canyon High School students were notified Thursday [5 Apr 2018] by the Salt Lake County Health Department of an outbreak of whooping cough at the school. The letter directs people with cold symptoms to contact their health care providers.\n\nOut of 2200 students at Corner Canyon High, 105 students are exempt from vaccination either because of parental choice or medical conditions, according to Rupp. 21 of 1491 students at Draper Park Middle School and 35 of 658 students at Oak Hollow Elementary are also vaccine-exempted. 'As a health department, we support parental choice. We just have to remind those parents who make this particular choice that the ramifications may be that their student is not able to attend school. For pertussis, it is 21 days after the last student confirmed case is no longer symptomatic,' Rupp said. The health department's medical officer has not recommended that any unvaccinated students remain at home during the outbreak, according to Rupp. Those seeking immunization can contact their health provider or call the Salt Lake County Health Department at 385-468-7468.\n\n[Byline: Liesl Nielsen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] USA (vaccine efficacy)\nDate: 29 Mar 2018\nSource: Medpage Today [edited]\nhttps://www.medpagetoday.com/infectiousdisease/vaccines/72078\n\n\nThe surprising resurgence of whooping cough in the United States in recent years cannot be blamed on shortcomings in the current vaccine, a new study finds. Rather, incomplete coverage among children -- possibly fueled by the anti-vaccination movement -- is responsible for the pertussis increases, along with natural population turnover and slowly waning protection from the vaccine, researchers say.\n\nIn the study published online in Science Translational Medicine, the team found little evidence that the switch in the 1990s from the whole cell to the combined acellular pertussis vaccine contributed to the resurgence in whooping cough [1].\n\nDuring the 1970s and 1980s, an average of 2000 to 3000 pertussis cases were reported annually, according to figures from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [https://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/surv-reporting/cases-by-year.html].\n\nIn 2003, pertussis cases in the U.S. increased to more than 10 000 for the 1st time in almost 4 decades and have not dropped below this number since. In 2012, there were 48 277 reported cases, followed by 28 639, 32 971, 20 772, and 17 972 cases in 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016, respectively.\n\nThe CDC recommends a series of 5 pertussis shots to be given before age 7, combined with the diphtheria and tetanus vaccines (DTaP), with a booster dose (Tdap) recommended around the age of 11. 'The conventional wisdom has been that the current vaccine may not protect for very long, but we found strong evidence that this is not the case,' study co-author Aaron King, PhD, of the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, told MedPage Today. 'A small fraction of people who get the vaccine appear to be capable of being infected again after a relatively short period of time. But this is such a small number that the overall efficacy of the vaccine is quite high.'\n\nThe researchers employed disease-transition models and statistical analysis to examine 3 potential modes of failure: primary vaccine failure; failure in the duration in the waning of vaccine-induced protection with time and failure in the degree of protection, also known as vaccine 'leakiness. We formulated transmission models comprising competing hypotheses regarding vaccine failure and challenged them to explain 16 years of highly resolved incidence data from Massachusetts,' the researchers wrote. 'Our results suggest that the resurgence of pertussis is a predictable consequence of incomplete historical coverage with an imperfect vaccine that confers slowly waning immunity.'\n\nSpecifically, the team examined age-stratified pertussis incidence data from Massachusetts from 1990 through 2005, which was before the introduction of the Tdap booster, employing statistical methods for extracting information from the data that could be generalized to the entire U.S. and to western Europe.\n\nKing explained that the introduction of the 1st pertussis vaccine in the late 1940s led to what the researchers refer to as a honeymoon period where very low disease incidence was seen. The analysis suggested that the resurgence of pertussis in recent decades signals the end of this honeymoon period.\n\nPertussis was a common, and deadly, childhood disease before the 1950s. But the combination of the introduction of the vaccine and natural immunity among a large percentage of adults who had the disease as children led to dramatic declines in incidence.\n\nKing said the cyclical increase in pertussis cases in recent decades does not support the idea that the vaccine is ineffective or that changes in the vaccine have contributed to the resurgence: 'The roots of the resurgence go back 2 decades before the switch from the whole cell vaccine was made. What we are seeing is in part due to the fact that we are not vaccinating enough people and in part due to the decline in adults with naturally acquired immunity.'\n\nHe said that even though protection from the pertussis vaccine gradually wanes over time, it lasts far longer than many in the field have suggested. 'For 90% of people who get the vaccine, immunity is lasting longer than 10 years, and for over half, it is lasting an entire lifetime.'\n\nThe finding that schoolchildren now represent a core transmission group has implications for public health efforts to address the pertussis resurgence, the researchers noted. 'Efforts aimed at curtailing transmission in the population at large, and especially in vulnerable infants, are more likely to succeed if targeted at schoolchildren, rather than adults.'\n\n[1. Domenech M, et al. The impact of past vaccination coverage and immunity on pertussis resurgence. Sci Transl Med 2018; DOI: 10.1126/scitranslmed.aaj1748. Available at: http://stm.sciencemag.org/content/10/434/eaaj1748.full.]\n\n[Byline: Salynn Boyles]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The abstract from the referenced journal article is extracted below:\n\nAbstract\n-----------\nThe resurgence of pertussis over the past decades has resulted in incidence levels not witnessed in the United States since the 1950s. The underlying causes have been the subject of much speculation, with particular attention paid to the shortcomings of the latest generation of vaccines. We formulated transmission models comprising competing hypotheses regarding vaccine failure and challenged them to explain 16 years of highly resolved incidence data from Massachusetts, United States. Our results suggest that the resurgence of pertussis is a predictable consequence of incomplete historical coverage with an imperfect vaccine that confers slowly waning immunity. We found evidence that the vaccine itself is effective at reducing overall transmission, yet that routine vaccination alone would be insufficient for elimination of the disease. Our results indicated that the core transmission group is schoolchildren. Therefore, efforts aimed at curtailing transmission in the population at large, and especially in vulnerable infants, are more likely to succeed if targeted at schoolchildren, rather than adults. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] China (Hong Kong)\nDate: Tue 13 Mar 2018\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/540411/cluster_of_bordetella_pertussis_cases_in_prince_of_wales_hospital.html\n\n\nThe following is issued on behalf of the Hospital Authority:\n\nThe spokesperson for Prince of Wales Hospital made the following announcement today 13 Mar [2018]:\n\nThree babies (2 male and one female, aged 28 days to 30 days) in a postnatal ward presented with respiratory symptoms since February 25 [2018]. Appropriate viral tests were arranged for the babies, and the test results were positive for _Bordetella pertussis_. Two of them have been discharged, while the remaining one is under isolation treatment with stable condition.\n\nIn accordance with prevailing infection control guidelines, the hospital has performed contact tracing, and no new cases were found. The hospital infection control team has discussed the matter with the Centre for Health Protection and the following enhanced infection control measures have been adopted:\n- Thorough cleaning and disinfection of the cubicle concerned;\n- Enhanced environmental hygiene in the ward; and\n- Carrying out stringent infection control measures, including reminding families of babies and visitors to wear surgical masks and wash hands.\n\nThe cases have been reported to the Hospital Authority Head Office and the Centre for Health Protection for necessary follow-up. The hospital will continue to closely monitor the condition of patients in the ward.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hong Kong is located on the southeastern coast of China and can be seen on the map at http://healthmap.org/r/1s3-. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [5] Vaccine efficacy\n---\nChina\n---\n But the combination of the introduction of the vaccine and natural immunity among a large percentage of adults who had the disease as children led to dramatic declines in incidence.\n\nKing said the cyclical increase in pertussis cases in recent decades does not support the idea that the vaccine is ineffective or that changes in the vaccine have contributed to the resurgence: 'The roots of the resurgence go back 2 decades before the switch from the whole cell vaccine was made. The hospital infection control team has discussed the matter with the Centre for Health Protection and the following enhanced infection control measures have been adopted:\n- Thorough cleaning and disinfection of the cubicle concerned;\n- Enhanced environmental hygiene in the ward; and\n- Carrying out stringent infection control measures, including reminding families of babies and visitors to wear surgical masks and wash hands. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Yamhill County, with a population of 99 193 in 2010, is a county in the northwestern part of the U.S. state of Oregon in the Willamette Valley; the county seat is McMinnville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Oregon). Date: Wed 21 Mar 2018\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 USA, Nigeria, Australia, Indonesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5645483", "date": "2018-02-22 20:06:41", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, NIGERIA, AUSTRALIA, INDONESIA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Idaho\n[2] Wisconsin\n\nNigeria\n---\n[3] Adamawa\n\nAustralia\n---\n[4] Queensland\n\nIndonesia\n---\n[5] East Java\n\n******\n[1] USA (Idaho)\nDate: Wed 7 Feb 2018\nSource: Idaho State Journal [edited]\nhttps://idahostatejournal.com/members/whooping-cough-cases-reported-including-in-twin-falls-kimberly-and/article_b821f717-a5d0-5843-912a-9ce87911a654.html\n\n\nA case of whooping cough has been reported at Canyon Ridge High School, the school district announced [Fri 2 Feb 2018]. The district was notified [Thu 1 Feb 2018] by South Central Public Health District. 'We are working with local health officials to monitor the situation, and at this time, the school will remain open and operating normally,' Twin Falls School District spokeswoman Eva Craner wrote in a statement.\n\nWhooping cough - also known as pertussis - is also affecting other Magic Valley communities. An outbreak was reported [Mon 29 Jan 2018] at multiple Kimberly schools and it's affecting Minidioka County schools, too. Across south-central Idaho, 13 cases of whooping cough among children or adults have been reported since [Mon 1 Jan 2018]. Those are just cases confirmed by a medical provider or laboratory. Three school districts have been affected: 3 students in Kimberly, one student in Twin Falls and 2 students in Minidoka County.\n\nIt's hard to compare the number of cases with previous years because they ebb and flow, said Logan Hudson, nurse manager at South Central Public Health District. 'It's difficult with pertussis because it sort of cycles.' In 2014, there were 53 cases reported here in south-central Idaho. But numbers dropped to just one case in 2016 and 6 last year. 'We know that (pertussis is) always in the community,' Hudson said. 'It's never not here. It's whether cases are identified.'\n\nThose affected can return to school after 5 days of antibiotic treatment. In Twin Falls, Canyon Ridge High will send home letters to parents with information about the reported case of whooping cough. School employees have been directed to be diligent about cleaning and sanitizing surfaces, Craner wrote in a statement, to help stop the spread of illnesses. Each of the school district's 16 campuses also has a plan to help prevent the spread of infectious diseases. The Minidoka County School District found out about its 2 confirmed cases of whooping cough - both at Minco High School in Rupert - a couple of weeks ago, Superintendent Ken Cox said. Notices in English and Spanish were sent home to parents, he said. 'This is something we take seriously. As soon as it was confirmed, we made sure parents were made aware of it.'\n\nIn Kimberly, students or school employees who exhibit symptoms of whooping cough will be required to go home, Kimberly School District Superintendent Luke Schroeder wrote in a Tuesday letter to staff and parents. They won't be allowed to return to school without written documentation from a health care provider. Twin Falls students who are coughing are also asked to stay home. 'In addition, with flu season in full swing we are urging caution for families and advise that everyone practice healthy habits like regular hand washing,' Craner wrote in the statement. It's extremely important for community members to know the difference between influenza - also known as the flu - and whooping cough, Hudson said. 'Right now, we're seeing both. It's a stronger than usual influenza year, along with pertussis. We want people to go to the doctor for any kind of cough illness, but pertussis tends to last a lot longer,' he said.\n\nSouth Central Public Health District recommends students and teachers should watch for symptoms and update their immunizations if they're not current on the pertussis vaccine. Children are required by state law to receive immunizations before entering preschool through 12th grade schools. But parents can fill out a state exemption form if they choose not to immunize their child. They must cite a reason for their decision such as a philosophical, medical or religious objection. Under state law, immunization requirements include 4 doses of the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DTaP) vaccine for children born before 1 Sep 1999, and 5 doses for children born after 1 Sep 2005. In addition, children entering 7th grade must receive one dose of DTaP. For adults, the Centers on Disease Control and Prevention recommend one DTaP dose in their lifetime. The exception is pregnant women, who should receive one dose during every pregnancy. Oftentimes, people will get a tetanus shot after sustaining a wound or cut, Hudson said, but it may not include the pertussis protection.\n\n[Byline: Julie Wooton-Greener]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Magic Valley is a region in south-central Idaho consisting of Blaine, Camas, Cassia, Gooding, Jerome, Lincoln, Minidoka and Twin Falls Counties (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic_Valley). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Wisconsin)\nDate: Wed 21 Feb 2018\nSource: Florence Forest News [edited]\nhttps://www.florence-forestnews.com/2018/02/21/florence-county-pertussis-count-continues-to-rise/\n\n\nPertussis has increased to 17 laboratory-confirmed cases for 2018 in Florence County. The Health Department, following CDC guidelines, continues to contact each case to assure household contacts are treated and anyone symptomatic (coughing) is tested. Confirmed cases are isolated for 5 days while taking antibiotic treatment and may not participate in school or work.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Florence County, with a population of 4423 residents in 2010, is located in the northeastern part of U.S. state of Wisconsin, bordering on the north the Upper Peninsula of the U.S. state of Michigan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_County,_Wisconsin#Geography).\n\n******\n[3] Nigeria (Adamawa)\nDate: Sun 21 Jan 2018\nSource: Reliefweb [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/nigeria/adamawa-state-integrated-disease-surveillance-and-response-idsr-nigeria-emergency-0\n\n\nOutbreak investigation of 71 cases of suspected cases of pertussis (whooping cough) were reported from Kasuwan Gada (41 cases) in Lokuwa ward and Blue house (30 cases) in Vintim wards of Mubi North LGA of Adamawa State - The LGA health department was able to mobilize amoxicillin and paracetamol to support case management but no erythromycin or azithromycin. The communities were sensitized on the need for completion of routine immunization, prompt treatment of cases of pertussis and how to reduce the transmission within communities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mubi North is a Local Government Area (LGA) of Adamawa State, Nigeria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mubi_North). A map showing the location of Mubi North can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mubi+North+Local+Government+Secretariat. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Australia (Queensland)\nDate: Tue 13 Feb 2018 3:03am\nSource: ABC [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-02-13/whooping-cough-cases-spike-northern-queensland/9443528\n\n\nQueensland's peak medical body is urging people to ensure their vaccinations are up to date after a spike in whooping cough cases in northern Queensland, including the recent diagnosis of a high school student. Parents were notified late last week [week of Sun 4 Feb 2018] after the Cairns student was suspected of suffering from whooping cough. That diagnosis has since been confirmed and is one of 37 cases in the north of the state this year [2018]. Only 10 cases had been reported by this time last year [2017].\n\nAustralian Medical Association Queensland Council of General Practice chairman Richard Kidd urged all Australians, particularly those in northern Queensland, to vaccinate against largely preventable diseases in the wake of the recent spike. 'In pre-vaccination times [whooping cough] would kill at least one person in 10, and today sadly we will still see babies that will die because they haven't had the opportunity to get vaccinated,' he said.\n\n'For older children and adults who haven't been vaccinated, there's still a risk of dying from whooping cough.'\n\nConfirmed cases [annually] of whooping cough in northern Queensland, as [of] 13 Feb 2018: 2015 - 23; 2016 - 24; 2017 - 10; 2018 - 37.\n\n[Byline: Anna Hartley, Sharon Molloy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Indonesia (East Java)\nDate: Sat 17 Feb 2018 08:04 pm\nSource: The Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/02/17/east-java-targets-to-vaccinate-10m-following-diphtheria-outbreak.html\n\n\nThe East Java Health Agency has targeted to vaccinate 10 717 765 residents aged between one and 19 years old in 2018 following a diphtheria outbreak in the province. The province has set aside Rp 89 billion (USD 6.5 million) to finance the program, dubbed the Outbreak Response Immunization.\n\nAgency head Kohar Hari Santoso said on [Sat 17 Feb 2018] that the agency had also involved religious figures affiliated with major organizations such as the Religious Affairs Ministry, the Indonesia Ulema Council and Muslim groups in anticipation of resistance based on religious reasons, such as doubts over the halal status of the injection. '[Some people have] doubts over vaccinations. We have anticipated this by involving religious figures. [Vaccination] is important,' he said.\n\nEast Java saw the highest number of diphtheria cases in 2017, which stood at 460 cases, 16 of whom died, up from 352 in 2016.\n\nThe vaccination program will be conducted in 3 phases. The 1st phase is set to be carried out between February and March [2018]. The 2nd and 3rd phases will be conducted between April and May and October and November [2018], respectively.\n\n[Byline: Aman Rochman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[East Java is a province of Indonesia located in eastern Java; it includes the island of Madura, which is connected to Java by the longest bridge in Indonesia, the Suramadu Bridge, as well as the Kangean and Masalembu archipelagos located further east and north, respectively (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Java). Its capital is Surabaya, the 2nd largest city in Indonesia and a major industrial center. USA (Indiana)\nDate: Sat 24 Feb 2018\nSource: Washington Times Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.washtimesherald.com/news/local_news/whooping-cough-on-the-rise-in-daviess-county/article_dd4eec36-4695-5ad7-bf87-bab9146c0061.html\n\n\nThe amount of whooping cough cases in Daviess County has already doubled from last year's numbers [2017]. 'We usually only have one to 2 cases a year,' Daviess County public health nurse Kathy Sullender said. 'This year [2018] we have already had 4 cases. Three of the 4 cases had not received a vaccination,' Sullender said. 'The one that was vaccinated had a very mild case.'\n\nFor questions about any vaccine or to schedule shots, call the Daviess County Health Department at 812-254-8666.\n\n[byline: Kristi Sanders]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Daviess County, with a population of 31 648 residents in 2010, is located in the US state of Indiana; its county seat is Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daviess_County,_Indiana). A map of Daviess County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Daviess+County,+IN. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Ohio)\nDate: Tue 27 Feb 2018\nSource: Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.org/news/93519-local-whooping-cough-cases-reported-vaccine-encouraged\n\n\nOfficials from the Logan County Health District reported [Tue 27 Feb 2018] that cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, are on the rise in the community, with 4 local cases confirmed, and the Tdap and DTap vaccines are encouraged for area residents.\n\nThese vaccines are available at the health district, 310 S Main St, during regular immunization clinic hours, from 9 to 11 am. Thursdays and from 2 to 6 pm the 1st Thursday of each month. Call 651-6186 to register.\n\nTo learn more about whooping cough and the vaccines to prevent it, visit <www.cdc.gov/whoopingcough> or talk to your health care professional.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Logan County, with a population of 45 858 residents in 2010, is located in the central portion of the US state of Ohio; its county seat is the city of Bellefontaine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logan_County,_Ohio). Logan County can be found on a map at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Logan+County,+OH. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Idaho)\nDate: Sat 3 Mar 2018\nSource: WENY [edited]\nhttp://www.weny.com/story/37626183/health-department-treasure-valley-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise\n\n\nReports of pertussis (also known as whooping cough) are on the rise in Ada and Canyon counties. Over the past 4 months, 89 cases have been reported -- 70 of those cases include Ada County residents, while 19 are Canyon County residents.\n\nWhooping cough cases tend to peak every 3 to 5 years. The last peak was in 2014-2015, when nearly 300 cases of whooping cough were reported in Ada and Canyon counties. 'The latest cycle of whooping cough began hitting Ada County back in October of last year [2017], while Canyon County cases began increasing in January of this year [2018],' Myron said [Christine Myron with the Central District Health Department in Boise].\n\n[byline: Steve Bertel]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ada County, with a population of 392 365 residents in 2010, is located in the south western part of the US state of Idaho; its county seat and largest city is Boise, the state capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ada_County,_Idaho). The adjacent Canyon County, with a population of 188 923 residents in 2010, is part of the Boise Metropolitan Statistical Area in the US state of Idaho (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canyon_County,_Idaho#Adjacent_counties). A map of Idaho counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/idaho.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Armenia\nDate: Fri 23 Feb 2018 17:34\nSource: News.am [edited]\nhttps://med.news.am/eng/news/17236/2-month-old-armenia-boy-dies-of-pertussis.html\n\n\nA 2 month old boy died of pertussis in Armenia's Nork infectious clinical hospital. The child, just as 2 other children in the family, was not vaccinated because of parents' refusal, the Armenian health ministry said in a statement.\n\nThe illness started 2 months ago, but parents rejected hospitalization despite doctor's instructions. The laboratory tests revealed that twins -- boys 2 months old -- were infected by their 2 year old sister.\n\nMore cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, have been recorded in Armenia over the recent 2 months. There are already 12 laboratory confirmed cases this year [2018] compared with 3 in the same period last year [2017]. Eight of 12 affected children were not vaccinated or were partially vaccinated. The disease mainly affects children under one [year of age].\n\nThe Armenian health ministry recalled that vaccination is the only efficient and safe prevention for pertussis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nork Republican Infectious Clinical Hospital is one of more than 40 hospitals in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, with a population of about 1 million residents in 2017 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_hospitals_in_Yerevan). A map of Armenia can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Armenia. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Australia (Queensland)\nDate: Wed 28 Feb 2018 3:29 PM\nSource: Noosa News [edited]\nhttps://www.noosanews.com.au/news/noosa-told-to-vaccinate-to-stop-whooping-cough-out/3348673/\n\n\nNoosa children are in the firing line of a severe whooping cough outbreak more than double the intensity of previous years, as council and health experts urge parents to vaccinate. 'So far this year [2018], there have been 37 cases of whooping cough notified to Queensland Health for residents of the Noosa Council area,' Noosa Council's environmental health coordinator Geoff Atherfold said. 'Most of these cases have been children. In past years there have been up to 12 whooping cough notifications for a similar period,' he said.\n\nThe council is supporting Queensland Health experts' warning for residents to stay vigilant and vaccinate. 'The target to prevent outbreaks of vaccine-preventable disease is 95 per cent,' Mr Artherfold said. 'In the Noosa Shire area we are short of the target with 89 per cent of one year old children vaccinated, so we encourage all parents to ensure that their children are vaccinated,' he said. 'This is for both the safety of their own children but also for the safety of other children they come into contact with.'\n\nMr Artherfold said whooping cough is a highly contagious respiratory infection that can cause serious, and sometime life-threatening, health issues, particularly in babies. 'We all have a responsibility to help prevent an outbreak.' Free vaccinations are available for women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy and for babies at 2, 4 and 6 months of age with booster doses for children at 18 months, 4 years, and during their 1st year of high school. Adults are advised that they can also obtain boosters to ensure that they are protected and in doing so they are helping to protect others. The vaccine for whooping cough is combined with that for diphtheria and tetanus and is available from all general practitioners.\n\nFor more information visit your doctor or http://conditions.health.qld.gov.au/HealthCondition/condition/14/33/150/whooping-cough-pertussis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Noosa Shire, with a population of 52 149 residents in 2016, is an Australian resort area on southern Queensland's Sunshine Coast, located about 136 km (85 mi) north of Brisbane, the state's capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shire_of_Noosa). A map of Noosa can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Noosa,+QLD,+Australia. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] New Zealand (Bay of Plenty)\nDate: Thu 1 Mar 2018\nSource: Bay of Plenty Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/bay-of-plenty-times/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503343&objectid=12002417\n\n\nA total of 5 people in the Bay of Plenty have been hospitalised with whooping cough this year[2018] amid a national epidemic. This compares with 12 hospitalisations recorded for the whole of 2017, 6 of which were in Western Bay.\n\nToi Te Ora Public Health has also been notified of 98 Bay of Plenty cases of whooping cough in 2018. There were a total of 129 cases notified in 2017. 'We do have an epidemic and I think that's the 1st and most important thing - that everyone is aware,' Bay of Plenty medical officer of health Dr Neil de Wet said.\n\nNationally, 2140 cases of whooping cough were notified in 2017 and 876 so far this year [2018]. Since November 2017, across the Bay of Plenty and Lakes districts, 231 cases have been notified.\n\nDr Symon Roberton, director of Papamoa Pines Medical Centre, said he was seeing increasing numbers of whooping cough cases at his centre during this significant outbreak. There had been about 40 confirmed cases at Papamoa Pines since December 1 last year [2017], the GP said, and probably another 40-50 who were diagnosed clinically but did not require further investigation as they presented well after treatment times or during their infectious periods. 'This is one of the problems with the disease in that the early symptoms are much like a cold or viral illness and why prevention via immunisation is so important. Treatment does not help symptoms but limits the infectious period.\n\n[byline: Scott Yeoman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Bay of Plenty is a region on the northern coast of New Zealand's North Island https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_of_Plenty. PERTUSSIS (04): USA, ARMENIA, AUSTRALIA, NEW ZEALAND\n****************************************************\n Source: WENY [edited]\nhttp://www.weny.com/story/37626183/health-department-treasure-valley-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise\n\n\nReports of pertussis (also known as whooping cough) are on the rise in Ada and Canyon counties. \n\nWhooping cough cases tend to peak every 3 to 5 years. {"archive_id": "5532117", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (01): USA, Austria, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5532117", "date": "2018-01-02 05:22:32", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (01): USA, AUSTRIA, NEW ZEALAND\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Michigan\n[2] California\n[3] North Carolina\n\nAustria\n---\n[4] Styria\n\nNew Zealand\n---\n[5] Gisborne\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Michigan\nDate: Mon 18 Dec 2017 6:56 PM EST\nSource: TV6, Upper Michigan's Source, WLUC [edited]\nhttp://www.uppermichiganssource.com/content/news/Six-cases-of-Pertussis-are-confirmed-in-Marquette-County-463999573.html\n\n\nThe 6 cases of pertussis confirmed in Marquette county is cause for concern. The Marquette County Health Department [MCHS] said this bacterial illness, known as whooping cough, is preventable through vaccines. However officials said it is hard to contain because the illness is spread without knowing one has it. Symptoms include congestion and violent coughing. The illness is treatable through antibiotics making it less contagious, but the coughing can last for months.\n\nAlthough whooping cough is mostly found in schools, the MCHS is warning the county to be aware of symptoms. 'But the whole community needs to think about this because kids travel for sports events and those kinds of things so it's a good time to again double check to make sure your family is vaccinated,' said Dr Terry Frankovich, the medical director.\n\n[byline: Nicole Buchmann]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Marquette county, with a population of 67 077 residents in 2010, is located in the Upper Peninsula of the US state of Michigan and is the largest Michigan county in land area, as well as the most populous county in the Upper Peninsula (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquette_County,_Michigan). The county seat is the city of Marquette. A map of Marquette county can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Marquette+County,+MI. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nMarquette county, Michigan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/19633]\n\n******\n[2] California\nDate: Tue 19 Dec 2017 5:39 am PST\nSource: East Bay Times [edited]\nhttps://www.eastbaytimes.com/2017/12/19/whooping-cough-strikes-east-bay-high-school/\n\n\nWhooping cough has sickened a hand full of students at Foothill High School -- a reminder that the once rare respiratory disease in California has made a comeback in the past 8 years.\n\nSchool officials confirmed this week that a 'single digit' number of Foothill students are believed to have contracted the highly contagious respiratory disease, also called pertussis. The symptoms start out like a common cold but can transform in serious cases to fits of coughing and a whooping sound while gasping for air.\n\nPleasanton school officials said they are declining to disclose the exact number of cases because county health officials think doing so would make it easier for the public to identify the infected individuals. In all of Alameda county, there have been 98 pertussis cases so far this year [2017], and there were 77 cases in 2016, according to county and state public health departments.\n\nOn [14 Dec 2017], the Pleasanton school system finished emailing notices about whooping cough to families of students in the Foothill classes with a student suspected of being infected, said spokesman Patrick Gannon. The message told the families that students may have been exposed to the bacterial disease and should take steps to minimize the risk and monitor for symptoms, he said.\n\nProtective measures include people getting vaccinations and covering noses and mouths when coughing or sneezing to prevent the spreading of droplets with the contagious bacteria, health officials said.\n\nWhooping cough had been relatively rare in California until an outbreak in 2010, when there were more than 9447 cases with 10 deaths, the most in 65 years in the state. Other states also reported a surge that year. In California, the number of cases declined after 2010, but surged again to 11 203 cases in 2014 with 365 of them in Alameda county, state health officials reported. As of [3 Dec 2017], California has reported 2084 cases. Alameda county has had 98 cases so far this year, according to Alameda County Public Health Department.\n\nScientists and medical experts have suggested the increase in cases may be related to fewer parents vaccinating their children, and the effectiveness of the vaccines wearing off in youngsters as they reach their early teen years. Particularly vulnerable are high school students who have only received acellular pertussis vaccines even if they received a so-called Tdap booster before they were in the 7th grade, according to the state Department of Public Health.\n\nPertussis cases also appear to rise and drop in cycles that last from 3 to 5 years, health officials added.\n\n[byline: Denis Cuff]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Alameda county, with a population of about 1.5 million residents in 2010, is located in the San Francisco Bay Area of the state of California in the United States; its county seat is the city of Oakland, across the San Francisco Bay Area, from the city of San Francisco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alameda_County,_California). The city of Pleasanton, with a population of 70 285 residents in 2010, is a suburb of Oakland and was named the third wealthiest city in terms of earnings in the United States in 2013 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pleasanton,_California). Alameda county can be found on a map of California at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Alameda+County,+CA. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAlameda county, California: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4295]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 12:16 PM EST\nSource: BlueRidge Now, Time-News Online [edited]\nhttp://www.blueridgenow.com/news/20171220/whooping-cough-cases-at-56-what-you-need-to-know\n\n\nAccording to Thursday's report [21 Dec 2017] from the health department, 56 cases have now been identified.\n\nCases of whooping cough, or pertussis, continue to climb in Henderson county. As school is out for the holidays and families get together to celebrate, health officials are keeping a close eye on the outbreak, now at 52 cases.\n\nThe outbreak, spread across a majority of county schools but also found in the community, has raised questions since the first cases appeared at the end of November [2017].\n\nKim Horton, communications specialist with the Henderson County Department of Public Health, says that one check in the win column is that there have been no cases resulting in death or patients entering the intensive care unit.\n\nStudents in Henderson county are required to take the vaccine to attend school, unless a religious or medical exemption is made, and again before entering the 7th grade. The majority of cases in the county have been found in people who have been vaccinated. Those who have had the vaccine can still get whooping cough, but will have milder symptoms.\n\nHorton said the vaccine itself, modified to be less potent several years ago because of some severe side effects, is one of waning immunity. Pertussis is classified as a vaccine-modified disease instead of a vaccine-prevented disease.\n\n[byline: Derek Lacey]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Henderson county, with a population of 106 740 residents in 2010, is located in the Blue Ridge Mountains of the south western part of the US state of North Carolina; its county seat is Hendersonville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henderson_County,_North_Carolina). A map showing the location of Henderson county can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Henderson+County,+NC. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nHenderson county, North Carolina: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6334]\n\n******\nAustria\n---\n[4] Styria\nDate: Thu 21 Dec 2017\nFrom: Daniela Schmid <daniela.schmid@ages.at> [edited]\n\n\nDetection of a pertussis outbreak at an early stage allows prompt action including chemoprophylaxis and vaccination of close contacts, in order to limit spread and reduce further transmission to those who are most at risk of severe or complicated infection.\n\nWe inform you of an outbreak of _Bordetella pertussis_ in a kindergarten in Styria, Austria, in November 2017. 4 clinically suspected cases among a total of 27 kindergarten children were confirmed through detection of _B. pertussis_ DNA from nasopharyngeal swabs and notified to the public health authorities. 2 other cases were identified among siblings of the kindergarten children-cases.\n\nCases occurred between [4 and 25 Nov 2017]. The case-patients are aged between 3 and 8 years (male to female ratio 1:1), including 5 unvaccinated with pertussis containing vaccine and 1 patient with an unknown vaccination history.\n\nNasopharyngeal secretion, collected by swabs from 23 kindergarten children (17 vaccinated with at 2+1 doses schemata, 2 unvaccinated, 4 unknown) and 3 supervisors (all 3 vaccinated), defined as contact persons of the outbreak cases, were tested for _B. pertussis_ by PCR and routine culture technique. 3 children and 1 supervisor tested positive by pertussis-PCR and negative by culture. 3 of these 4 contact persons were vaccinated against pertussis. It is well known that is more difficult to recover the organism in vaccinated compared with unvaccinated children (Bamberger ES, Srugo I. What is new in pertussis? Eur J Pediatr 2008; 167(2): 133-9; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2151776/).\n\nThe public health authority offered antibiotic chemoprophylaxis to pertussis-PCR positive contact persons and vaccination with pertussis containing vaccine to the unvaccinated. 3 of the 4 pertussis positive contact persons accepted the prophylactic antibiotic treatment, the other decided to stay at home until the end of the maximum incubation period following latest contagious exposure.\n\nNo further cases have been reported since the onset of the last case on [25 Nov 2017].\n\nThis outbreak is occurring in the context of a continuously increasing trend of _B. pertussis_ infections in Austria (179 cases in 2009; 1291 cases in 2016). Based on a survey conducted in 2013 on vaccine uptake of birth cohorts, we assume that vaccine coverage in children and adolescents in Austria is below the recommended threshold of 90 per cent.\n\n--\nDaniela Schmid\nDepartment of Infectious Disease Epidemiology and Surveillance\nAustrian Agency for Health and Food Safety\nVienna\nAustria\n<daniela.schmid@ages.at>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Daniels Schmid for this firsthand report.\n\nStyria is one of 9 states located in south eastern Austria; the capital is Graz, with a population of 276 526 residents in 2015 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria). Styria can be found on a map at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Styria,+Austria. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nStyria, Austria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4075]\n\n******\n[5] New Zealand (Gisborne)\nDate: Sat 30 Dec 2017 8:32 AM NZDT\nSource: Gisborne Herald [edited]\nhttp://gisborneherald.co.nz/localnews/3160090-135/whooping-cough-on-the-rise\n\n\n[A mother] is relieved her daughter is getting better after contracting whooping cough. Health officials warn people to watch out for the disease, after a rise in the number of people with it here and in other areas. Hauora Tairawhiti medical officer of health Margot McLean says New Zealand is in the early stages of a whooping cough epidemic. The best celebration [for the mother] this new year will be enjoying the good health of her baby daughter, who has spent 3 of her 8 weeks of life battling whooping cough. Before Christmas, she was admitted to Planet Sunshine at Gisborne Hospital, where the frightening coughing fits finally started to subside. [The baby] is her 1st child. 'Watching my baby struggling to breathe, her lips blue and her face turning pink, then purple, is terrifying. I wouldn't wish this on anyone. 'When she coughed she would choke. The nurses showed me how to sit her up and rub her back. If that didn't work, I would blow on her face. I couldn't leave her side and I was worried when I fell asleep.'\n\n[The mother an her baby] are not alone, says Margot McLean. New Zealand is in the early stages of a whooping cough epidemic and other areas have also seen a rise in cases. 'In the past 2 weeks, 2 babies have been admitted to Gisborne Hospital with whooping cough.'\n\nWhooping cough causes prolonged bouts of coughing that can end in vomiting or breathlessness. 'It can be very serious, especially for those under one.' The best prevention is immunisation. 'Pregnant mums should get their free immunisation between 28 and 38 weeks of pregnancy. Babies receive their 1st free immunisation at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 5 months. Don't delay with vaccinations, as young babies are the most at risk and need to get their protection as soon as possible.'\n\nDr McLean says [the mother] did the right thing. She was immunised while pregnant, giving [her baby] some protection through the shared bloodstream. This might have prevented [her baby] becoming more unwell when she contracted whooping cough at five weeks, just before her first vaccination.\n\nWhooping cough spreads through coughing and sneezing. People with whooping cough are infectious from 6 days after exposure to the bacteria, when symptoms are like a normal cold, to 3 weeks after the ''whooping'' cough begins, unless treated with antibiotics. Dr McLean says many babies catch whooping cough from older siblings or parents, often before they are old enough to be vaccinated. 'That is why staff from maternity, neonatal and Planet Sunshine teams at Gisborne Hospital are all immunised. If babies catch whooping cough, they might not be able to feed or breathe properly, become so ill they need to go to hospital, and could end up with complications such as pneumonia and brain damage.'\n\nAnyone with a cough that does not go away should avoid contact with babies and young children, and get advice from a health professional or from Healthline 0800 611 116.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Gisborne, with a population of 36 600 residents in 2017, is a coastal city in the Gisborne Region in the north eastern part of the North Island of New Zealand (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gisborne,_New_Zealand). Gisborne can be found on maps at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Gisborne,+New+Zealand and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1967. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\n--\nDaniela Schmid\nDepartment of Infectious Disease Epidemiology and Surveillance\nAustrian Agency for Health and Food Safety\nVienna\nAustria\n<daniela.schmid@ages.at>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Daniels Schmid for this firsthand report. \n\n[byline: Nicole Buchmann]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Marquette county, with a population of 67 077 residents in 2010, is located in the Upper Peninsula of the US state of Michigan and is the largest Michigan county in land area, as well as the most populous county in the Upper Peninsula (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquette_County,_Michigan). \n\n[byline: Denis Cuff]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Alameda county, with a population of about 1.5 million residents in 2010, is located in the San Francisco Bay Area of the state of California in the United States; its county seat is the city of Oakland, across the San Francisco Bay Area, from the city of San Francisco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alameda_County,_California). \n\nAnyone with a cough that does not go away should avoid contact with babies and young children, and get advice from a health professional or from Healthline 0800 611 116.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Gisborne, with a population of 36 600 residents in 2017, is a coastal city in the Gisborne Region in the north eastern part of the North Island of New Zealand (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gisborne,_New_Zealand). ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nHenderson county, North Carolina: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6334]\n\n******\nAustria\n---\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Derek Lacey]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nMarquette county, Michigan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/19633]\n\n******\n ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAlameda county, California: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4295]\n\n******\n \n\nNasopharyngeal secretion, collected by swabs from 23 kindergarten children (17 vaccinated with at 2+1 doses schemata, 2 unvaccinated, 4 unknown) and 3 supervisors (all 3 vaccinated), defined as contact persons of the outbreak cases, were tested for _B. pertussis_ by PCR and routine culture technique. Otago\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Colorado\nDate: Wed 3 Jan 2018 06:44 PM MST\nSource: Western Slope Now [edited]\nhttp://www.westernslopenow.com/news/local-news/whooping-cough-outbreak-in-mesa-county/899932967\n\n\nThose with Mesa County Public Health want to warn you of a local outbreak of pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Getting vaccinated or even washing your hands, can keep you one step ahead of contracting pertussis. However, once the disease is caught, it can spread extremely easily.\n\n'We've had 22 cases of pertussis reported in Mesa county since the beginning of November [2017],' said Andy Tyler, Regional Epidemiologist with Mesa County Public Health. During the same time period last year [2017], Mesa county had just one case of whooping cough.\n\nFor more information about what vaccination is best for you depending on your age, those with Mesa County Public Health say to give them a call at (970) 248-6900.\n\n[Byline: Katerina Chryssafis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mesa county, with a population of 146 723 residents in 2010, is located in the western portion of the US state of Colorado; its county seat is Grand Junction (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesa_County,_Colorado). A map of Mesa county can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/YWwdkjVvm232. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nMesa County, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201]\n\n******\n[2] Minnesota\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2018\nSource: Grand Rapids Herald-Review [edited]\nhttp://www.grandrapidsmn.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-confirmed-at-local-schools/article_e59db2ec-f260-11e7-a742-6b79e92512b1.html\n\n\nSeveral confirmed or probable cases of whooping cough have been reported in Itasca county. Statewide, the number is nearing 800, according to the Minnesota Department of Health statistics. On [Thu 4 Jan 2018], Independent School District 318 sent a message informing parents that a few confirmed cases have been identified in local schools.\n\n[Byline: Britta Arendt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Itasca county, with a population of 45 058 residents in 2010, is located in the US state of Minnesota; its county seat is the city of Grand Rapids (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Itasca_County,_Minnesota). School administrators placed the calls and sent letters to parents [Mon 8 Jan 2018] saying the Wake County Human Services Department had confirmed that a 3rd unidentified student had been diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nIn a statement posted on the Apex High School website, officials said they are working to limit the spread of the illness. 'We are working closely with the county health department and following state health protocols,' the statement said.\n\n[...]\n\nSchool officials said the recent case is the 3rd such incident reported in recent weeks.\n\nLast month [December 2017], the school sent a letter to parents notifying them about the first whooping cough diagnosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wake County, with a population of about 1 million residents in 2015, is located in the central portion of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is the city of Raleigh, which is also the state capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wake_County,_North_Carolina). Wake county can be found on a map at https://goo.gl/maps/PVytf77CiDM2. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nNorth Carolina, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/235]\n\n******\n[4] North Carolina\nDate: Sun 13 Jan 2018 7:02 PM EST\nSource: WYFF [edited]\nhttp://www.wyff4.com/article/two-cases-of-whooping-cough-confirmed-in-bunbombe-county/15156186\n\n\nHealth officials have confirmed 2 cases of pertussis, known as whooping cough, in Buncombe county. Buncombe County Health and Human Services said the 2 cases do not appear to be connected to each other, or to a recent outbreak in Henderson county.\n\n[...]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Buncombe county, with a population of 238 318 residents in 2010, is located in the western portion of the US state of North Carolina; its county seat is the city of Asheville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buncombe_County,_North_Carolina). Buncombe County can be found on a map at https://goo.gl/maps/giRf379dzVJ2. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nVenezuela\n---\n[5] Orinoco Delta\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2018\nSource: [in Spanish, trans., edited]\nhttp://www.correodelcaroni.com/index.php/mas/salud/item/61730-reportan-casos-de-tos-ferina-en-comunidad-warao-del-delta-del-orinoco\n\n\nThe Warao community of Bonoina, located in the Orinoco canals, in Delta Amacuro, reports an approximate of 10 whooping cough infections in children and adults. 'It's a suffocating cough and the problem is that in dispensaries there are medicines,' said Trino \u00c1vila, a resident of the town.\n\n\u00c1vila pointed out that they have not yet been confirmed by the State in the absence of specialists the Orinoco Delta. His family is one of those affected by the recent illness. 'I didn't know what to do, without medicines, far from the city, isolated in these rivers ...desperation takes over one,' he lamented.\n\nAncestral knowledge came to pass and a wise Warao recommended that he bury a dry coconut filled with brown sugar and place a burning stove over it all night long. When unearthing it, there is a syrup, product of the mixture of both ingredients, and with that he cured his children.\n\n[...]\n\nA total of 25 000 Waraos live in the Antonio D\u00edaz municipality of Delta Amacuro, hidden between canals, islands, and mangroves of the Orinoco River that flow into the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. They survive from agriculture and fisheries, in the absence of basic state services and now face an epidemic of whooping cough.\n\n[Byline: Oriana Faoro]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Orinoco Delta is one of the 8 natural regions of Venezuela and it covers the whole of Delta Amacuro state and a few square kilometers of Monagas state and Sucre state, comprising all the mouths of the Orinoco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orinoco_Delta). A map of this region can be found at http://www.exploremargarita.com/maps/map_delta.htm. The Warao are an indigenous people inhabiting northeastern Venezuela, Trinidad and Tobago, Guyana, and Suriname, with a lifelong and intimate connection to the water; most of the approximately 20 000 Warao inhabit Venezuela's Orinoco Delta region (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warao_people). - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOrinoco Delta, Delta Amacuro, Venezuela: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63687]\n\n******\nNew Zealand\n---\n[6] Otago\nDate: Mon 29 Jan 2018\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttps://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/health/whooping-cough-cases-south\n\n\nPublic Health South is keeping a close eye on whooping cough cases, with 24 probable and confirmed cases so far this month [January 2018]. 'These have occurred throughout the district and involve all age groups,' medical officer of health Marion Poore said. 'None of the cases has required admission to hospital.'\n\nThere has been a significant increase in cases nationally, with 2075 confirmed, probable, and suspected cases last year [2017]. Cases had been trending upwards since November [2017], and last month [December 2017] the Ministry of Health declared a national outbreak of the disease.\n\n'We encourage parents to ensure that all infants and children are vaccinated on time,' Dr Poore said.\n\n'The majority of confirmed cases is in the 20-29 age group,' Dr Poore said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Otago, with a population of 224 200 residents in 2017, is a region of New Zealand in the south of the South Island (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otago); Dunedin is the 2nd-largest city in the South Island and the principal city of the Otago region (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunedin). nationally, with 2075 confirmed, probable, and suspected cases last year [2017].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-01-06 {"location": "Itasca County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grand Junction", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5291495", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (09): USA, Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5291495", "date": "2017-09-02 19:48:22", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (09): USA, CANADA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\nUSA\n----\n[1] Montana (Ravalli County)\n[2] Michigan\n[3] Alabama\nCanada\n----\n[4] Alberta\n\n******\n[1] Montana (Ravalli County)\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017 04:04 PM MDT\nSource: NBC Montana [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcmontana.com/news/keci/ravalli-co-public-health-tracks-whooping-cough-cases/615161618\n\n\nThe following release was sent out by Ravalli County Public Health: Ravalli County is experiencing an outbreak of pertussis. This August [2017] there are currently 5 confirmed cases in an isolated population cluster to date.\n\n'Contacts of confirmed cases are being tested and/or prophylaxed (treated to prevent illness),' stated Dr Carol Calderwood, Health Officer for Ravalli County Public Health. 'We are working to identify, educate, and treat before more people become symptomatic.'\n\nRavalli County Public Health is working proactively with local physicians to identify close contacts of confirmed cases. A close contact is a household member of a confirmed case, anyone who has been within 3 feet for an hour, or has been coughed on directly. Public Health wants the public to be aware, especially with the current smoky conditions, upcoming flu season, and increased congregation (school, fair, sports, etc.), to take steps to protect themselves and their loved ones.\n\n'We are advising that people experiencing a progressive cough be seen. Also, any person in close contact to a person with confirmed pertussis should be seen by their primary care provider or at a walk-in clinic,' stated Calderwood.\n\nUntreated, exposed people may be spreading pertussis even before they become symptomatic. Pertussis has an incubation period of 21 days. An untreated close contact is able to spread the disease for that period.\n\nContacts without symptoms and taking the 5-day course of antibiotics may continue their normal activities. Contacts with symptoms and taking antibiotics should remain home until all treatment is taken. Contacts not yet taking prophylaxis should remain home. 'If you are a close contact not receiving treatment we are asking that you stay home for 21 days,' Calderwood reiterated.\n\nWith cooperation between Public Health and the community, this current cluster can be quickly contained. Public Health is also working closely with community partners to have proactive intervention plans in place; including exclusion protocols, to help protect our most vulnerable citizens. As always, you may also contact Public Health at 375-6671 with questions or to obtain vaccination.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ravalli County, with a population of 40 212 residents in 2010, is located in the southwestern part of the U.S. state of Montana; it is often referred to as the Bitterroot Valley, with the Sapphire Mountains on the East and the Bitterroot Mountains and is on the West on the western side of the Continental Divide (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ravalli_County,_Montana). - Mod.ML\n\n******\n[2] Michigan\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017 11:11 AM\nSource: The Daily Reporter [edited]\nhttp://www.thedailyreporter.com/news/20170825/whooping-cough-outbreak-continues\n\n\nThe Branch-Hillsdale-St. Joseph Community Health Agency [CHA] is continuing their investigation into an outbreak of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- in St Joseph County.\n\nThe CHA has treated approximately 233 people for pertussis with antibiotics over the last month [August 2017], according to CHA Prevention Services Director Val Newton.\n\nThe outbreak began in June [2017] with one Amish family and spread through that community. Newton said the treatment has been confined to the Amish, with the exception of one case. 'We are investigating to see if there might have been contact,' she said.\n\nAn Amish family volunteered their home for an immunization clinic because of the outbreak. 'There are 34 people who received 60 vaccines,' Newton said. 'This family has offered us the use of an Amish community building for us to do monthly immunizations.'\n[Byline: Don Reid]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Branch, Hillsdale and St Joseph are adjacent counties on the southern border of the U.S. state of Michigan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Michigan). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Alabama\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017\nSource: WVTM13 [edited]\nhttp://www.wvtm13.com/article/alabama-health-officials-say-whooping-cough-cases-still-on-the-rise/12007918\n\n\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health on [Mon 14 Aug 2017] issued a new warning about growing number of whooping cough cases.\n\nHealth officials say immunization data shows an increase from 113 reported cases of pertussis in 2016 to 151 reported cases so far in 2017. Pertussis cases have occurred across the state, including multiple outbreaks in Calhoun and Chambers counties.\n\n'Patients should be aware that this is a serious disease that can affect people of all ages,' said Dr Karen Landers, Assistant State Health Officer. 'It can even be deadly for babies less than a year old. That's why it's especially important for parents and grandparents who are in close contact with infants to make sure they are up to date on their vaccinations.'\n\nThe CDC says the best way to protect against the whooping cough is the vaccine:\nAll students 11 [years of age] and older entering the 6th grade in Alabama schools must have a tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine. Each pupil 11 or older who enters the 6th grade will be required to have a new certificate of immunization. This is because of the change from tetanus-diphtheria (Td) to (Tdap) vaccine. The Tdap vaccine will protect adolescents from pertussis and keep them from spreading disease to siblings, other family members and other students. The Tdap school requirement will go up by one higher grade each school year. For example, Tdap is now required for students entering 7th grade through 10th grade in 2014-2015, and will be required for students up through 12th grade in 2016-2017.\n\n- Adolescents who have already received a booster dose of Td are encouraged to\nreceive a dose of Tdap. A 5-year interval from the last Td dose is encouraged, but an interval as short as 2 years may be used if pertussis immunity is needed.\n- All adults should receive a booster dose of Td every 10 years. Tdap is licensed for only one lifetime dose per person. Adults who have never received a dose of Tdap should substitute it for their next booster dose.\n- A dose of Tdap is recommended for adults who expect to have close contact with an infant younger than 12 months of age.\n- Healthcare workers who have direct patient contact should receive a dose of Tdap.\n- New mothers who have never received Tdap should get a dose as soon as possible after delivery. If vaccination is needed during pregnancy, Td is usually preferred over Tdap.\n- Adolescents and adults who require a tetanus-containing vaccine as part of wound management should receive a dose of Tdap instead of Td if they have not previously received Tdap. If Tdap is not available or was previously administered, Td should be administered.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The U.S. state of Alabama, located in the southeast along the Gulf of Mexico, has 67 counties, a map of which can be found at (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Alabama). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Alberta\nDate: Thu 24 Aug 2017\nSource: Medicine Hat News [edited]\nhttp://medicinehatnews.com/news/local-news/2017/08/24/whooping-cough-continues-to-spike/\n\n\nThe number of people affected by an outbreak of whooping cough continues to increase in southern Alberta, including Medicine Hat, says Alberta Health\nServices [AHS].\n\nA total of 305 cases of whooping cough (pertussis) have been diagnosed in the south zone, said Dr. Lena Derie-Gillespie, medical officer of health in the AHS south zone. The number of cases only in Medicine Hat was not available.\n\nOf the 305 cases, there are 257 related to the initial outbreak that was in the western part of the south zone, in particular communities that don't have high immunization rates, said Derie-Gillespie, who declined to name a specific community.\n\nMedicine Hat was initially considered a 'cluster' and not considered related to the outbreak. 'In the last couple weeks we are seeing outbreak cases that are occurring outside of that west zone,' said Derie-Gillespie. 'We consider now the entire zone (including Medicine Hat) is part of the outbreak.'\n\nIn an outbreak, most cases are among unimmunized people particularly in children, said Derrie-Gillespie. In diagnosed cases, of those who have been immunized, there seems to be a spike in the kids about 11-and 12-years-old. 'This does not mean that the 11-and 12-year-olds are most at risk to get pertussis,' she explained. 'The younger unimmunized ones are still most at risk.'\n\nThis age group may be experiencing 'waning benefits' from the last vaccine, she said. To address this, those between the ages of 10 and 12 can register to receive a booster dose of the vaccine. Booster doses will be administered by appointment at clinics in Medicine Hat today, Aug. 30 and Aug. 31 [2017]. These will take place at Higdon Hall on the Medicine Hat Stampede Grounds. Clinics will also take place in Brooks on [Wed Thu 30 and 31 2017]. To make an appointment, call the local community health office at 403-502-8215.\n\nPregnant women in their 3rd trimester are also offered the vaccine routinely as their pregnancy progresses in order to offer some protection to newborns, who are particularly vulnerable.\n\nIf you get whooping cough you will be infectious for 3 weeks starting from the early symptoms, said Derrie-Gillespie. With symptoms that could seem like just a cold initially, there is a judgment call about the point at which you need to seek medical attention and a diagnosis. However, take all the precautions you would to avoid spreading germs: Hand hygiene, coughing into your arm and washing your hands regularly.\n\nIf you are not well don't go about mixing with other people in the community, particularly around babies, said Derrie-Gillespie. If you have a cough that is lasting a long time or symptoms that seem a little different to your normal colds, or if you know you were exposed to someone with pertussis, stay home and call your health-care provider or Health Link for instructions, said Derrie-Gillespie.\n\n[Byline: Gillian Slade]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South Zone, with a population of 281 934 residents in 2010, is the area south of Calgary, the largest city in the Canadian province of Alberta (http://www.albertahealthservices.ca/about/southzone.aspx). Medicine Hat is a city with a population of 63 230 residents in 2016 in South Zone east 295 km (183 mi) southeast of Calgary, halfway between Winnipeg and Vancouver; it has been known for its large natural gas fields (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medicine_Hat). A map of Alberta can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Alberta,+Canada. - Mod.ML\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [Byline: Don Reid]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Branch, Hillsdale and St Joseph are adjacent counties on the southern border of the U.S. state of Michigan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Michigan).
