(10): Canada, USA, Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5360305", "date": "2017-10-04 18:19:15", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (10): CANADA, USA, AUSTRALIA\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nCanada\n---\n[1] Alberta\n[2] Nunavut\n[3] Saskatchewan\nUSA\n---\n[4] Kentucky\n[5] Oregon\nAustralia\n---\n[6] South Australia\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Alberta)\nDate: Mon 2 Oct 2017 3:47:39 PM MDT\nSource: Whitecourt Star [edited]\nhttp://www.whitecourtstar.com/2017/10/02/whooping-cough-appearing-in-whitecourt-schools\n\n\nMultiple cases of whooping cough [pertussis] have been confirmed in Pat Hardy Elementary School, Hilltop High School, and Ecole St Joseph School [in Whitecourt, Alberta]. All 3 schools have notified parents through a letter.\n\n'Of course, those students with pertussis are immediately refrained from attending school,' said Lisa Bakos, communications officer with Northern Gateway Public Schools. She added that regular janitorial duties have been scaled up at Hilltop and Pat Hardy to prevent the spread of the infection. Bakos advised that parents read the letter carefully and that students continue to keep themselves clean. 'Hand washing, of course, is always so important in schools,' she said.\n\nDr Kathryn Koliaska, a north zone medical officer with Alberta Health Services, said the levels of whooping cough in Alberta fluctuate year to year and that outbreaks in schools are not uncommon. 'There's obviously large groups of kids together in schools,' Koliaska said.\n\nThe group most vulnerable to whooping cough is babies, especially during their 1st year of life. Koliaska encouraged parents to immunize their infants and for pregnant women or anyone who spends extended time around newborns to immunize themselves.\n\nWhooping cough symptoms include persistent coughing, gagging and vomiting following coughing and spasms of coughing followed by a 'whoop' sound.\n\nHowever, Koliaska said going to the doctor is the surest way to diagnose whooping cough. 'It's very hard to tell the difference symptom-wise from a common cold,' Koliaska said. 'Of course, the test takes a couple of days, so it will also be the conversation at your doctor's office.'\n\nAs of [28 Sep 2017], the north zone has 83 confirmed cases with Alberta having 744 overall. For further information on whooping cough, call Health Link at 811.\n\n[Byline: Peter Shokeir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://www.map-of-canada.org/canada-map-795.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.\nWhitecourt, with a population of 10 204 residents in 2016, is a town in Woodlands County in the central portion of the Canadian province of Alberta, approximately 177 km (110 mi) northwest of Edmonton, the capital city of Alberta (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whitecourt). A map of Alberta, showing the location of Whitecourt can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Whitecourt,+AB,+Canada. Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Canada (Nunavut)\nDate: Mon 25 Sep 2017 1:10 PM EDT\nSource: Nunatsiaq Online [edited]\nhttp://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674nunavut_confirms_new_cases_of_whooping_cough/\n\n\nLess than 6 months after the Government of Nunavut [GN] declared that the territory's most recent outbreak of whooping cough is over, health officials say they've confirmed new cases of the respiratory infection in the Kivalliq community of Arviat, population about 3000. A spokesperson with Nunavut's Department of Health could not specify the number of cases, but said it was low. The infection is currently confined to Arviat only.\n\nHealth officials are asking Nunavummiut -- especially the parents of babies and young children -- to take note, given that the infection can spread easily.\n\nAdults or children with those symptoms should visit their local health centre right away, health officials said; early diagnosis and treatment of whooping cough are important to making a full recovery.\n\nIf you've ever considered getting vaccinated against pertussis, now's the time: the GN encourages all Nunavummiut to ask community health care staff about getting a free vaccination. Anyone showing signs of the infections should also stay home from school or the workplace, to prevent the spread of the illness.\n\nNunavut's latest outbreak began in May 2016 in Pond Inlet, when 4 cases of whooping cough were first confirmed. Gradually the infection spread to other community members and other communities in the Baffin region. By the fall of 2016, Nunavut's health department had tracked more than 100 cases of pertussis in 11 communities throughout the Baffin and Kivalliq regions.\n\nIt wasn't until April 2017 that the health department declared the outbreak over.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Rogers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, with a population of almost 36 000 residents, is the northernmost territory of Canada and is Canada's largest in area and the second least populous of its provinces and territories (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut). Its capital is Iqaluit on Baffin Island. Arviat, with a population of 2657 in 2006, is a predominantly Inuit hamlet located on the western shore of Hudson Bay in the Kivalliq Region of Nunavut (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arviat). A map of Canada showing the location of Arviat can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Arviat,+NU,+Canada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Canada (Saskatchewan)\nDate: Thu 21 Sep 2017\nSource: Toronto Metro, The Canadian Press report [edited]\nhttp://goo.gl/qV17Sr\n\n\nThe Five Hills Health Region [Saskatchewan] is confirming 67 lab-proven cases of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough due to the sound people who have it make while coughing. Medical health officer Dr Mark Vooght said he wasn't aware of any cases that resulted in hospitalization, but the illness can be quite serious for young children and those with compromised immune systems. Risks include obstruction of airwaves, sepsis, and serious infection.\n\nVooght said many people only get checked out when they're very sick -- even bed-bound -- and have had whooping cough for a while. In February [2017], the Five Hills Health Region confirmed an outbreak of whooping cough involving school-aged children. 5 people were affected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Five Hills Health Region is located in south-central portion of the Canadian province of Saskatchewan and serves a population of approximately 54 000 people in an area that extends from Lake Diefenbaker to the United States border (http://www.fhhr.ca/about.htm). A map of the Five Hills Health Region can be found at http://www.fhhr.ca/about.htm. The city of Moose Jaw, with a population of 33 274 residents in 2011, is located in the Five Hills Health Region and is 77 km (48 mi) west of Regina, the capital of Saskatchewan. A map of Canada showing the location of Moose jaw an be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Moose+Jaw,+SK+S6J,+Canada.- Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] USA (Kentucky}\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017 11:52 PM CEST\nSource: WDRB [edited]\nhttp://www.wdrb.com/story/36479199/whooping-cough-cases-in-infants-spike-in-jefferson-county\n\n\nJefferson County [Kentucky] health officials say they have seen a dramatic spike in whooping cough in children under age one [year of age].\n\nIn a release, the Department of Public Health and Wellness is stressing the importance of immunization schedules for children. 6 cases have been reported so far in September [2017] in infants.\n\nHealth officials say the best way to prevent whooping cough is through the DTaP vaccination for children. A Tdap booster is suggested for adolescents and adults to protect against whooping cough, tetanus and diphtheria. It is recommended that infants receive the DTap immunization at 2, 4 and 6 month. Boosters are recommended at ages 15-18 months and at 4-6 years. Health officials say children should get a single dose of Tdap at 11 to 12 years of age. And they say pregnant women should receive a single dose of Tdap during every pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks.\n\nHealth officials recommend parents, siblings, and caregivers of infants be immunized against whooping cough with the Tdap vaccine. Families are urged to check with their doctor to see if children are up to date with immunizations.\n\nFamilies without insurance are urged to contact the Department of Public Health and Wellness at 574-6520.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. Jefferson County, with a population of 741 096 residents in 2010, is located in the US state of Kentucky, includes the city of Louisville and is known as Louisville/Jefferson County Metro. A map of Louisville/Jefferson County Metro can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+KY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] USA (Oregon)\nDate: Sun 17 Sep 2017 7:07 PM PDT\nSource: Columbian [edited]\nhttp://www.columbian.com/news/2017/sep/17/officials-face-pertussis-in-ashland-schools/\n\n\nJackson County [Oregon] health officials are responding to an outbreak of whooping cough in Ashland schools. Jackson County Medical Director Dr Jim Shames told the Mail Tribune last week that there are 2 confirmed cases and 1 suspected case. All 3 had contact with one another.\n\nSchool and health officials have not said where the outbreak of the contagious respiratory illness, also known as pertussis, has occurred. A joint statement from the Ashland School District and Jackson County Health Department said employees and students may have had contact with a person with confirmed pertussis during the 1st 2 weeks of school. Health officials said Oregon law requires children who have been exposed to pertussis but are under vaccinated to be excluded from school for 21 days.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing and sneezing. Young children, especially infants who have not had all their vaccinations, can be particularly susceptible.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jackson County, with a population of 203 206 in 2010, is located in the southwestern portion of the US state of Oregon, on the border with California (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_County,_Oregon). Ashland, with a population of about 21 000, is a city in south-central Jackson County, about 16 miles (26 km) north of the California border (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashland,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Ashland can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ashland,+OR+97520. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] Australia (South Australia)\nDate: Tue 12 Sep 2017 3:31 PM ACDT\nSource: Northern Argus [edited]\nhttp://www.northernargus.com.au/story/4911825/whooping-cough-spreads/\n\n\nThe respiratory infection whooping cough is sweeping through Riverton [South Australia] with an outbreak of the disease over recent weeks.\n\nA total of 21 students from Riverton Primary School and 1 student at Riverton Kindergarten have been confirmed to have contracted the infection since the start of August [2017]. Riverton Primary principal Cheryl Glendie said she had been in almost daily contact with both the Health Department and the Education Department since the 1st reported case last month [August 2017].\n\n'I report every single case to the Health Department every day so that we keep right on top of it,' she said. Ms Glendie said she had reported the 1st case of whooping cough to SA [South Australia] Health on [7 Aug 2017] with the infection at its worst over a 2-week period.\n\nThe infection has been sweeping through the school for around a month, but Ms Glendie believed that it was now beginning to wind down. She said that the outbreak had caused quite a disruption to the school. 'It is quite annoying because it has a disruption to the kids' learning programs,' she said. 'I have certainly spent a lot of time (dealing with the outbreak) and I would rather be dealing with their NAPLAN [National Assessment Program - Literacy and Numeracy] results. 'I would rather be talking about that than whooping cough!'\n\nNo staff at Riverton Primary have contracted the infection.\n\nThe virus [pertussis is caused by a bacterium, _Bordetella pertussis_, not a virus] however, has begun to travel into surrounding towns with confirmed cases of Riverton Primary students from Saddleworth and Marrabel contracting whooping cough.\n\nHealth Minister Jack Snelling urged South Australians to get vaccinated for the infection back in June [2017] as the number of reported cases was rising at an alarming rate. At the time, the state had seen a 50 per cent increase in the number of reported cases compared to 12 months ago as 860 South Australians contracted the disease compared to 571 at the same time last year [2016]. Health experts were concerned that cases of whooping cough would reach a 5-year high.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63238. Riverton, with a population of 810 in 2013, is a small town in southeastern South Australia (SA) about 100 km (62 mi) north of Adelaide, the capital city of the state of SA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riverton,_South_Australia). A map of south Australia showing the location of Riverton can be found at (http://www.australiaab.com/distance/29005348-29189024). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Five Hills Health Region is located in south-central portion of the Canadian province of Saskatchewan and serves a population of approximately 54 000 people in an area that extends from Lake Diefenbaker to the United States border (http://www.fhhr.ca/about.htm). ' PERTUSSIS (10): CANADA, USA, AUSTRALIA\n**************************************\n \n\nNunavut's latest outbreak began in May 2016 in Pond Inlet, when 4 cases of whooping cough were first confirmed. \n\nHealth officials are asking Nunavummiut -- especially the parents of babies and young children -- to take note, given that the infection can spread easily. \n\nHealth officials say the best way to prevent whooping cough is through the DTaP vaccination for children. Ms Glendie said she had reported the 1st case of whooping cough to SA [South Australia] Health on [7 Aug 2017] with the infection at its worst over a 2-week period. \n\nHealth officials recommend parents, siblings, and caregivers of infants be immunized against whooping cough with the Tdap vaccine. \n\nSchool and health officials have not said where the outbreak of the contagious respiratory illness, also known as pertussis, has occurred. Adults or children with those symptoms should visit their local health centre right away, health officials said; early diagnosis and treatment of whooping cough are important to making a full recovery. On the recommendation of the Health Department, the school canceled all athletic contests and other activities that would expose students in other counties or school districts to Neillsville School District students, Gaier said. Athletics are most affected, with a couple of field trips also canceled.\n\nThe Clark County Health Department also advised the school district not to cancel classes, stating students would be better off at school than congregating at home, Gaier said. The district will monitor students for symptoms of whooping cough, he said.\n\n[Byline: Karen Madden]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neillsville, with a population of 2463 in 2010, is a city in Clark County in the southcentral portion of the U.S. state of Wisconsin. According to Clark County Public Health's website, those infected can't return to school until they complete a 5-day course of antibiotics. Henderson County has been fighting to contain the outbreak of whooping cough, known formally as pertussis, since the 1st case was reported in mid-November 2017 at Hillandale Elementary School, about 4.5 miles southeast of downtown Hendersonville.\n\nIn the month since, the respiratory infection has spread beyond the schools and is impacting the community at large. As of 8 Dec 2017, more than 1000 people in Henderson County had been in close contact with somebody with whooping cough, which is 'easily spread when someone with the infection coughs or sneezes,' according to a press release from Henderson County.\n\nNo cases of whooping cough have been reported in Buncombe County, according to Dr. Jennifer Mullendore, medical director at the Department of Health and Human Services. Anybody, including people who have been vaccinated, can contract whooping cough though the symptoms may be milder for those with vaccinations. The infection is particularly dangerous for infants, pregnant women and anyone with a compromised immune system.\n\n[Byline: Sam DeGrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Last month (November 2017) Henderson County reported 8 cases in students with whooping cough at 5 schools (ProMED-mail post Pertussis (11): USA, Australia, New Zealand, Canada 20171203.5479380); now the total is 21 cases. In a letter released Friday [15 Dec 2017] through social media, school officials confirmed the cases.\n\n'If there's one infection in the school and the kid is not properly been diagnosed for it, potential is there for him to go, or her to go and continue to infect other kids,' says Sparrow Urgent Care Physician, Song Yu. Yu says whooping cough can be a very serious illness, especially in young children. 'We recommend treatment within the 1st 7-10 days; the problem is though until you get the symptoms that are obvious, you're not going to have that until week 2 or 3,' says Yu.\n\nThe administrator at Grand Ledge Public Schools released a letter stating there have been confirmed cases of the disease in the school system. That letter asked parents to get their students vaccinated before entering kindergarten and to keep children at home if they show any signs of the illness.\n\nAlthough most children are given the vaccine for whooping cough during routine childhood immunizations, booster doses are required over time. GLPS is working with the Barry/Eaton Health Department, and they ask you to check your child's immunization records. If your child has not been protected against this illness, it is recommended that you go to your doctor to have them immunized. If you have any questions about the issue, you can contact the Barry/Eaton District Health Department. For more information, visit http://www.cdc.gov/feature/pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grand Ledge, with a population of 7786 in 2010, is a city mostly in Eaton County in the U.S. state of Michigan, 12.7 miles (20.4 km) directly west of downtown Lansing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Ledge,_Michigan). "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (07): USA, FRANCE, CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\nUSA\n----\n[1] USA\n[2] Washington (Grant County)\nFrance\n----\n[3] Arras, Pas-de-Calais\nCanada\n----\n[4] Yukon\n\n******\n[1] USA\nDate: Mon 3 Jul 2017\nSource: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences [edited]\nhttp://www.pnas.org/content/114/27/7101.full\n\n\nCitation\nAloea C, Kulldorffb M, Bloom BR. Geospatial analysis of nonmedical vaccine exemptions and pertussis outbreaks in the United States. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2017;114(27):7101-7105. doi: 10.1073/pnas.1700240114. Epub 2017 Jun 20\n\nSignificance\n------------\nPertussis has been on the rise in the United States, and, in 2012, the United States had the highest number of reported pertussis (whooping cough) cases since 1955. This study provides evidence of spatial clustering of nonmedical vaccine exemptions in kindergarteners and spatial clustering of pertussis cases in children age groups 5 years and younger and 10 to 14 years at the community level. The results suggest that states should reconsider allowing nonmedical vaccine exemptions. The data also suggest a need for the creation of a longer-acting pertussis vaccine or improved regimen and a revised vaccination schedule for the current acellular pertussis vaccine.\n\nAbstract\n------\nBecause of increased numbers of recorded pertussis cases in the United States, this study sought to understand the role of nonmedical vaccine exemptions and waning immunity may have had on the resurgence of pertussis in the United States at the community level. We used geospatial scan statistics, SaTScan, version 9.4, to analyze nonmedical vaccine exemptions of children entering kindergarten in 2011 and 2012 and reported pertussis cases in 2012 for children in age groups 5 years and younger and 10 to 14 years. Eight statistically significant clusters of nonmedical vaccine exemptions in kindergarteners and 11 statistically significant clusters of pertussis cases in children and adolescents were identified and geospatially linked. Forty-five percent of the counties in the study had high rates of nonmedical vaccine exemptions. The proportion of kindergarteners with nonmedical vaccine exemptions was 2.8 times larger in the identified exemption clusters. In addition, 31 counties had geographic clusters of high rates of pertussis in children ages 10 to 14 years old, consistent with waning immunity. Our findings are consistent with the view that geographic clusters of nonmedical vaccine exemptions and waning immunity may have been factors contributing to community-level pertussis outbreaks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Wed 28 Jun 2017\nSource: KHQ [edited]\nhttp://www.khq.com/story/35771723/grant-county-health-district-investigates-confirmed-whooping-cough-cases\n\n\nGrant County Health District staff are investigating 12 confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough), with additional tests pending. All confirmed cases are within the Ephrata and Moses Lake community. No one has been hospitalized at this time.\n\nAll family members and those in close contact with those who have it have been notified by the health district and have started post-exposure prophylaxis. In an effort to control the spread of the disease, the health district has recommended antibiotics for anyone who has come in close contact with those individuals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 89 120 residents, is in the center of the U.S. state of Washington; the county seat is Ephrata, and the largest city is Moses Lake. A map of Grant County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Grant+County,+WA and a HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Arras, Pas-de-Calais\nDate: Tue 4 Jul 2017\nSource: La Voix du Nord [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://www.lavoixdunord.fr/187058/article/2017-07-04/six-cas-de-coqueluche-diagnostiques-dans-une-ecole-et-un-autre-dans-une-halte\n\n\nSix cases [of pertussis] are now confirmed at the Saint-Jean-Baptiste school - Sainte-Croix, Ozanam Street [in the city of Arras, France]. To prevent the concern of parents, a health surveillance procedure has been initiated at the Regional Health Agency (ARS).\n\nThe director of the Saint-Jean-Baptiste school (where 247 children are enrolled), Christophe Leuwers, takes the problem seriously but does not want to dramatize: 'What worries us the most are families who have already taken off for the holidays, and they will have to be contacted so that they can arrange a visit with their doctor for a medical check.'\n\nOnly one [additional] case was identified and medically monitored at the Torchy Nursery, located in the social center of the same name. The ARS was informed, and the city provided individual information to families, children and supervisors. Children were also checked for their vaccines. A health watch is being provided by a pediatrician.\n\nIt is difficult to distinguish whooping cough from a cold or a recurrent cough. A parent of a student, who is a doctor, 1st suspected this contamination in the school where a sibling seemed to be infected a fortnight ago. The family has since been followed medically, and the children have been confined to their homes.\n\n[Byline: Nicolas Andre]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arras, located in Northern France, is 182 km (113 miles) north of Paris, with a population of 43 693 residents, and the capital city of the Pas-de-Calais department, which forms part of the region of Hauts-de-France (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arras). A map of Pas-de-Calais that shows the location of Arras can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arras#/media/File:Pas_de_Calais.png and a HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Yukon\nDate: Mon 17 Jul 2017\nSource: Yukon News [edited]\nhttp://www.yukon-news.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-continue-to-rise-in-the-yukon/\n\n\nYukon's Chief Medical Officer of Health, Dr. Brendan Hanley, says the Yukon's pertussis or whooping cough outbreak continues to grow at a steady rate. 'We do have over 30 cases that are confirmed,' said Hanley. 'And it does not yet appear to have peaked.'\n\nHanley said it seems outbreaks of whooping cough happen every few years when herd immunity drops. 'Every 4-5 years, you can almost predict that you'll see pertussis popping up in the community,' he said.\n\nIt's important that people know that pertussis is still spreading, and it's useful for people to know how to protect themselves and others. Hanley said there are 3 main pillars for protection: immunization, staying away from others until you're no longer contagious, and using antibiotics to reduce the spread of the disease.\n\nImmunization is the most effective way to lower the risk of whooping cough, said Hanley. It's especially important for infants and pregnant women to get the vaccine, he said. While antibiotics can help reduce the spread of whooping cough, people are still contagious for approximately 5 days after they start the treatment. 'Pertussis is very contagious, and, unfortunately, it's contagious for quite awhile,' said Hanley. He urges people to keep this in mind when they start thinking about going back to work or sending their kids to daycare or other group settings.\n\n[Byline: Jamie-Lee McKenzie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Yukon is the smallest and westernmost of Canada's 3 federal territories (the other 2 are the Northwest Territories and Nunavut). Yukon borders the U.S. state of Alaska to the west. The territory has the smallest population of any province or territory in Canada, with 35 874 residents; Whitehorse is the territorial capital and Yukon's only city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yukon). A map of Yukon can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Yukon+Territory,+Canada and a HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.\n\nFor a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arras, located in Northern France, is 182 km (113 miles) north of Paris, with a population of 43 693 residents, and the capital city of the Pas-de-Calais department, which forms part of the region of Hauts-de-France (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arras). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 89 120 residents, is in the center of the U.S. state of Washington; the county seat is Ephrata, and the largest city is Moses Lake. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Yukon is the smallest and westernmost of Canada's 3 federal territories (the other 2 are the Northwest Territories and Nunavut). We used geospatial scan statistics, SaTScan, version 9.4, to analyze nonmedical vaccine exemptions of children entering kindergarten in 2011 and 2012 and reported pertussis cases in 2012 for children in age groups 5 years and younger and 10 to 14 years. This study provides evidence of spatial clustering of nonmedical vaccine exemptions in kindergarteners and spatial clustering of pertussis cases in children age groups 5 years and younger and 10 to 14 years at the community level. \nPertussis has been on the rise in the United States, and, in 2012, the United States had the highest number of reported pertussis (whooping cough) cases since 1955. Source: KHQ [edited]\nhttp://www.khq.com/story/35771723/grant-county-health-district-investigates-confirmed-whooping-cough-cases\n\n\nGrant County Health District staff are investigating 12 confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough), with additional tests pending. PERTUSSIS (07): USA, FRANCE, CANADA\n***********************************\n [3] Arras, Pas-de-Calais\nCanada\n [4] Yukon\nDate: Mon 17 Jul 2017\n [1] USA\n[2] Washington (Grant County)\n Because of increased numbers of recorded pertussis cases in the United States, this study sought to understand the role of nonmedical vaccine exemptions and waning immunity may have had on the resurgence of pertussis in the United States at the community level. Source: Yukon News [edited]\nhttp://www.yukon-news.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-continue-to-rise-in-the-yukon/\n\n\nYukon's Chief Medical Officer of Health, Dr. Brendan Hanley, says the Yukon's pertussis or whooping cough outbreak continues to grow at a steady rate. Eight statistically significant clusters of nonmedical vaccine exemptions in kindergarteners and 11 statistically significant clusters of pertussis cases in children and adolescents were identified and geospatially linked. Our findings are consistent with the view that geographic clusters of nonmedical vaccine exemptions and waning immunity may have been factors contributing to community-level pertussis outbreaks. [4] Yukon\n\n******\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Nicolas Andre]\n\n--\n [Byline: Jamie-Lee McKenzie]\n\n--\n In this update:\n\nUSA\n Jun 20\n\nSignificance\n The data also suggest a need for the creation of a longer-acting pertussis vaccine or improved regimen and a revised vaccination schedule for the current acellular pertussis vaccine. Columbia\n\n******\n[1] USA (Idaho) Ada County\nDate: Tue 21 Nov 2017 03:29 PM\nSource: Idaho Statesman [edited]\nhttp://www.idahostatesman.com/news/local/article185832943.html\n\n\nThe Central District Health Department is warning heathcare providers in Ada County to be on alert for a rise in whooping cough cases.\n\nHealth care officials say whooping cough cases, also known as pertussis, have increased in recent months compared to case loads last year [2016]. In the last 3 months, 14 pertussis cases were reported in Ada County. That's twice the number compared to the same time last year [2016].\n\nMost cases are in kids and young adults between 13 and 20-years-old, and one-quarter are older than 40. Some people had been vaccinated against pertussis and showed a milder cough than the traditional 'whoop' so many recognize. That's why health care providers are urged to test all instances of a cough, according to a news release from St. Luke's.\n\nThe Association for Professionals in Infection Control and Epidemiology says the number of cases is on the rise. Two thousand and twelve saw a peak with more than 48 000 reported cases. In 2015, nearly 21 000 cases of pertussis were reported. While that's a decrease compared to 2014, annual case numbers are still significantly higher.\n\n[APIC] says there are many factors that may account for the rise in pertussis cases: Not all babies get the vaccination to protect them; Protection against whooping cough decreases over time, and teens and adults can become infected repeatedly; and pertussis rates among adults have risen 400 percent since 1990.\n\n[Byline: Christina Lords]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ada County, the most populous county in Idaho with a population of 392 365 residents in 2010, is located in the southwestern part of the U.S. state of Idaho (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ada_County,_Idaho). The county seat and largest city is Boise, the state capital. A map of Ada County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ada+County,+ID. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Illinois)\nDate: Tue 28 Nov 2017 04:17 PM\nSource: Belleview News Democrat [edited]\nhttp://www.bnd.com/news/local/article186941543.html\n\n\nUp to 7 schools in Champaign County [Illinois] have confirmed whooping cough cases, with a total of 40 cases so far. The Champaign-Urbana Public Health District confirmed 40 cases of pertussis, 27 of which have been confirmed since mid-October [2017]. Rantoul High School has 20 confirmed cases alone, according to the News-Gazette. The latest confirmed cases involve 2 students in Mahomet, Illinois: A 3rd-grader and 7th-grader have each come down with pertussis, a contagious bacterial disease that can take weeks for recovery. Treatment is a 5-day course of antibiotics, which is often delayed since pertussis starts with symptoms similar to the common cold. Last year [2016] Champaign County saw only 7 cases.\n\n[Byline: Elizabeth Donald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Belleville, with a population of 42 034 residents in 2015, is the county seat of St. Clair County, Illinois; the city, adjacent to Scott Air Force Base, is home to military and federal civilian personnel, defense contractors, and military retirees (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belleville,_Illinois). Health officials say they expect more people to come down with the illness before the outbreak is over. 'We're expecting to have more cases and at some point that will die down,' said Dr. Diana Curran, Medical Director for Henderson County Department of Public Health.\n\nMolly McGowan Gorsuch, a spokesperson for the school district, said the students who tested positive for pertussis attend Hillandale Elementary, Clear Creek Elementary, Bruce Drysdale Elementary, Rugby Middle, and East Henderson High schools.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi, Brookley Cromer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Henderson County, with a population of 106 740 residents in 2010, is located in the Blue Ridge Mountains of southwestern part of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Hendersonville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henderson_County,_North_Carolina). At least 40 cases have been reported in the past 28 days -- the majority among primary school children living around Murwillumbah and Tweed Heads.\n\nChildhood vaccination rates in the northern NSW local health district are as low as 50 percent in some areas. Northern NSW Public Health Unit acting director Greg Bell said in the past 7 days alone 13 cases of whooping cough were confirmed, and that those represent only a portion of the potentially fatal disease in the community.\n\n[Byline: Clarissa Bye]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Murwillumbah, with a population of 9245 residents in 2016, is a town in far northeastern New South Wales, Australia, just south of the Queensland border, 848 km north-east of Sydney and 132 km south of Brisbane (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murwillumbah). The Ministry of Health (MoH) has issued a warning to New Zealand after declaring a national outbreak of whooping cough. A total of 1315 cases have been reported since the beginning of 2017.\n\nOutbreaks of the disease occur every 3 to 5 years. New Zealand's most recent national outbreak was between August 2011 and December 2013, with about 11 000 cases. Up to 3 babies and young children died during this period, with hundreds needing hospital treatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6] Canada (British Columbia)\nDate: Fri 1 Dec 2017 06:00 AM\nSource: Times Colonist [edited]\nhttp://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/schools-battle-whooping-cough-as-island-cases-rise-to-107-1.23109886\n\n\nRoyal Oak Middle School and Prospect Lake Elementary are the latest schools to have a confirmed case of whooping cough. It brings the total number of cases on south Vancouver Island to 107. That's a spike from 79 cases for all of 2016. There were 213 cases in 2015 and 47 in 2014.\n\nIn September [2017], 5 schools -- Lansdowne, Central and Shoreline middle schools, as well as Craigflower and Cloverdale elementary schools -- had confirmed or suspected cases of whooping cough. An independent school also had a case.\n\nPertussis vaccinations are recommended for children at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months and 18 months, in kindergarten and then in Grade 9. The B.C. [British Columbia] Centre for Disease Control reported that last year [2016], 76 percent of 2-year-olds had up-to-date immunizations in Island Health's south Island area. Adults are advised to get a booster shot.\n\n[Byline: Cindy E. post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Virginia (Henrico County)\n[2] Washington (Skagit County)\nCanada\n---\n[3] British Columbia\n[4] Alberta\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Virginia (Henrico County)\nDate: Wed 7 Jun 2017 3:54 pm EDT\nSource: 8News, WRIC [summ., edited]\nhttp://wric.com/2017/06/07/henrico-parents-notified-of-increase-in-pertussis-cases/\n\n\nSchool officials in Henrico County [Virginia] notified parents at Glen Allen High School this week [week of 5 Jun 2017] that they have been informed of multiple cases of pertussis among students. The health department added that it is seeing an increase in the respiratory illness, also known as 'whooping cough,' in the broader community as well.\n\nIf you have any questions, you may contact your child's pediatrician or Laura Young, Henrico Health District's Epidemiologist, at 804-501-5216 or <laura.r.young@vdh.virginia.gov>. A fact sheet about pertussis can be accessed at http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/epidemiology/epidemiology-fact-sheets/pertussis-whooping-cough/.\n\n[Byline: Will Armbruster]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Virginia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8793. Henrico County, with an estimated population of 320 717 residents, is in the US Commonwealth of Virginia and included in the Greater Richmond Region. A map showing the location of Henrico County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Henrico+County,+VA.] - Mod.ML\n\n******\n[2] Washington (Skagit County)\nDate: Thu 15 Jun 2017 5:47 PM PDT\nSource: KING-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.king5.com/news/northwest-washington-state-hit-with-whooping-cough/449433756\n\n\nA total of 9 cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, have now been confirmed in Skagit County [Washington] and health investigators are looking at additional possible cases.\n\nAt this time, the cases do not appear to be linked to any specific school or other public gathering place.\n\nPublic Health is urging you to make sure you're vaccinated against the illness. If you suspect you have whooping cough, contact your health care providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4652. Skagit County, with a population of 116 901 residents in 2010, is in the US state of Washington and is included in the Seattle-Tacoma, WA Combined Statistical Area in the Puget Sound region (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skagit_County,_Washington). A map showing the location of Skagit County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Skagit+County,+WA. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[3] British Columbia\nDate: Wed 7 Jun 2017 2:17 PM PDT\nSource: The Similkameen Spotlight [edited]\nhttp://www.similkameenspotlight.com/local-news/warning-issued-for-princeton-families-interior-health/\n\n\nAn increase in the number of cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, is being seen in the Princeton area [British Columbia]. Interior Health would like to remind the public about the importance of making sure your immunizations are up to date.\n\nThe pertussis vaccine is part of the routine childhood vaccinations that are given at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, and 18 months old, and again at age 4 to 6 years (before kindergarten). A pertussis vaccine is also given to teens at 14 to 16 years of age (grade 9) in British Columbia. The vaccine is safe and effective and parents are advised to check their child's immunization record to make sure they are up to date. It is especially important that infants receive the first dose of pertussis vaccine on time and without delay to protect them from serious pertussis complications.\n\nInformation about accessing immunization records can be found at ImmunizeBC (http://www.immunizebc.ca. To discuss pertussis immunization for children or to book an appointment, contact your local public health centre. Adults who have never been immunized for pertussis can contact their local health centre to inquire about getting the vaccine.\n\n[Byline: Andrea Demeer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Similkameen Country roughly coincides with the basin of the river of the same name in the Southern Interior of the Canadian province of British Columbia. The Similkameen Country is mostly in the traditional territory of the Similkameen subdivision of the Okanagan people, the Upper Similkameen Indian Band being in the town of Princeton, which has a population of 2828 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princeton,_British_Columbia). Princeton is approximately 60 miles (97 km) north of the Canadian border with the US state of Washington. For a map of this area, see https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Nighthawk,+WA,+USA/Princeton,+BC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Alberta\nDate: Thu 15 Jun 2017 5:56 PM MDT\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttp://globalnews.ca/news/3531965/whooping-cough-outbreak-expands-across-southern-alberta-as-cases-rise-provincewide/\n\n\nAlberta Health Services (AHS) says a whooping cough outbreak in southern Alberta has now impacted 38 people. The outbreak was originally declared last week [week of 5 Jun 2017] after 17 cases were detected in communities with low immunization rates.\n\n'This outbreak is in the same area where we are seeing outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases on a regular basis,' Dr Vivien Suttorp, a medical officer of health for AHS South zone said in an interview on [7 Jun 2017]. At the time, the outbreak had been contained to the western part of the AHS South zone and was limited to the communities around Lethbridge, Coaldale, and Fort Macleod. This week, however, cases related to the outbreak have been detected across southern Alberta, including 3 cases in Medicine Hat.\n\nNo outbreaks have been declared in Alberta's 4 other zones but AHS says there have been 178 cases across Alberta so far this year [2017], including 18 in Calgary, 27 in Edmonton and 77 in the province's central zone, which includes Red Deer.\n\nAccording to AHS, immunization is the best protection against whooping cough. The vaccine is part of Alberta's routine childhood immunization schedule. Doses of the DTaP vaccine -- which delivers protection against diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus and polio -- are recommended for all children at ages 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 18 months, between 4 and 6 years, and again in grade 9.\n\nAdults are urged to get a booster at some point and it's recommended pregnant women get the vaccine during their third trimester of pregnancy. The vaccine is covered by Alberta Health and can be accessed through community health centres or public health offices.\n\n[Byline: Heather Yourex-West]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South Zone, with a population of 281 934 residents in 2010, is the area south of Calgary, the largest city in the Canadian province of Alberta; the South Zone includes the city of Lethbridge, with a population of 92 729 residents in 2016 (http://www.albertahealthservices.ca/about/southzone.aspx). A map of Alberta can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Alberta,+Canada. - Mod.ML]\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A fact sheet about pertussis can be accessed at http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/epidemiology/epidemiology-fact-sheets/pertussis-whooping-cough/.\n\n[Byline: Will Armbruster]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Virginia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8793. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South Zone, with a population of 281 934 residents in 2010, is the area south of Calgary, the largest city in the Canadian province of Alberta; the South Zone includes the city of Lethbridge, with a population of 92 729 residents in 2016 (http://www.albertahealthservices.ca/about/southzone.aspx). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4652. In this posting:\nUSA\n---\n Doses of the DTaP vaccine -- which delivers protection against diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus and polio -- are recommended for all children at ages 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 18 months, between 4 and 6 years, and again in grade 9.\n\n Date: Thu 15 Jun 2017 5:56 PM MDT\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttp://globalnews.ca/news/3531965/whooping-cough-outbreak-expands-across-southern-alberta-as-cases-rise-provincewide/\n\n\nAlberta Health Services PERTUSSIS (06): USA, CANADA\n***************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Canada\n---\n USA\n---\n Canada\n---\n The pertussis vaccine is part of the routine childhood vaccinations that are given at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, and 18 months old, and again at age 4 to 6 years (before kindergarten). \n\n'This outbreak is in the same area where we are seeing outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases on a regular basis,' Dr Vivien Suttorp, a medical officer of health for AHS South zone said in an interview on [7 Jun 2017]. [4] Alberta\n\n******\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Andrea Demeer]\n\n--\n [Byline: Heather Yourex-West]\n\n--\n ML\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n******\n ML]\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod. This week, however, cases related to the outbreak have been detected across southern Alberta, including 3 cases in Medicine Hat.\n\n Date: Wed 7 Jun 2017 3:54 pm EDT\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2828-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "okanagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Skagit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Edmonton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henrico County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Calgary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5241451", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (08): Malaysia, USA, Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5241451", "date": "2017-08-10 22:41:23", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (08): MALAYSIA, USA, CANADA\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\nMalaysia\n----\n[1] Sabah\nUSA\n----\n[2] Washington\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New York\n[5] Indiana\nCanada\n----\n[6] Alberta\n\n******\nMalaysia\n----\n[1] Sabah\nDate: Tue 8 Aug 2017\nSource: MIMS [edited]\nhttps://today.mims.com/topic/siblings-infected-with-pertussis-isolated-\n\n\nUp to 2 foreign siblings - reported to have contracted whooping cough (pertussis) in Keningau, Sabah - have been placed in isolation, announced Health Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam. The siblings are 2-years-old and 7-months-old, respectively. He added that, on top of isolating the siblings for 2 weeks, health authorities would conduct immunisation tests in the affected area.\n\n'We will test the immunisation status of the people around there and ensure that all of them are vaccinated. We also ensure that these (infected) children are being isolated, so that they don't spread to others until we are confident that the risk of spreading will not be there,' asserted Subramaniam. 'This will usually take not more than 2 weeks,' added Subramaniam, after solemnising the foundation stone laying ceremony of Sekolah Jenis Kebangsaan Tamil (SJKT) Heawood, in Sungai Siput, last week [week of Sun 30 Jul 2017].\n\nPrior to this, Health Director-General Datuk Dr Noor Hisham Abdullah commented on the state of the non-Malaysian siblings as well. According to him, the siblings - who were receiving treatment at the Keningau Hospital - had never received their whooping cough immunisations.\n\nPresident of Malaysian Paediatric Association (MPA), Dr N Thiyagar said some vaccines wear off as children grow older. He added that teenagers in some countries have been encouraged to take vaccinations for the cough. 'We especially encourage teenagers and the elderly to be vaccinated, so they don't become a source of infection for young children,' advised Thiyagar. 'The elderly are also encouraged to get the jab because their immune system would have weakened and make them susceptible to various infectious diseases, including pertussis,' he elaborated.\n\nIn Thiyagar's personal experience, most pertussis cases were among babies who were too young to be immunised. The majority of cases are also made up of babies who fail to complete the 3-dose regime when they catch the infection.\n\nAn internal circular from the Keningau Health Office to the Health Department went viral on [Fri 4 Aug 2017]. It requested that a pertussis outbreak be declared after the detected cases. This leaked memo largely sparked anxiety amongst the Malaysian society. At that time, State Health director Dr Christina Rundi, neither denied nor confirmed the matter. She merely stated that the internal circular was not meant for the public eye.\n\nNoor Hisham advised the public to stay calm as the incident in Sabah was remote. 'The State Health Department has stepped up prevention and control by visiting their homes and giving immunisation to the children,' he said.\n\nNoor Hisham explained that the bacterium, _Bordetella pertussis_, causes whooping cough. This airborne infection, subsequently, causes inflammation of the mouth, nose and throat. It has the potential to infect every individual, but children who are not fully immunised are more prone to contracting this infection.\n\n[Byline: Reshmin Kaur Cheema]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sabah, with a population of about 3.5 million residents, is one of the 2 East Malaysian states situated on the northern coast of the island of Borneo, bordering the Malaysian state of Sarawak to the southwest, and Kalimantan of Indonesia to the south; Kota Kinabalu is the capital city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabah).\nKeningau, with a population of about 200 000 residents, is a district and 5th largest town in Interior Division, Sabah (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keningau). A map of the administrative divisions of Sabah can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabah and a map of Malaysia at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/147. - Mod.ML]\n\n*****\nUSA\n----\n[2] Washington\nDate: Wed 9 Aug 2017\nSource: iFiberone [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/whooping-cough-up-exponentially-in-grant-county/youtube_2e5f61a8-7d5c-11e7-ace0-bfffd03c7829.html\n\n\nWhooping cough among school-aged children is way up over last year in Grant County [Washington].\n\nAs of today, 63 people have pertussis in our area, a stark contrast to just several cases at this time in 2016. 42 of those cases are in Moses Lake, 19 are in Ephrata and two are in Warden.\n\nTheresa Adkinson with the Grant County Health District isn't sounding the alarm yet but there is grave concern, 'I wouldn't consider it a crisis, but it is a concern. We're trying to control the spread of it and we're focused on protecting our high risk groups.'\n\nAdkinson and other health officials recommend that you get your child vaccinated as soon as possible at your local health clinic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 89 120 residents, is in the center of the U.S. state of Washington; the county seat is Ephrata, and the largest city is Moses Lake. A map of Grant County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Grant+County,+WA and a HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Fri 4 Aug 2017\nSource: WXII News [edited]\nhttp://www.wxii12.com/article/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise-in-forsyth-county/11458787\n\n\nHealth officials in Forsyth County said they have noticed higher than usual activity of pertussis, also known as 'whooping cough,' reported in Forsyth County since June [2017]. The Forsyth County Department of Public Health is urging people to update their vaccine.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious but preventable bacterial infection that causes uncontrollable, violent coughing lasting up to 10 weeks. Although easily spread in schools, the disease does not only affect children; adults can develop whooping cough and are often not diagnosed until later in the illness.\n\nSymptoms [include]: Severe fits of coughing, including rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched, 'whoop' sound; Coughing fits followed by vomiting; Exhaustion after coughing fits; Apnea (temporarily stopped breathing-usually in infants). Symptoms can vary by individuals. Contact your doctor if you suspect you or your child is experiencing pertussis symptoms.\n\nState law requires all kindergartners and rising 7th grade students be up to date on their pertussis vaccination before the beginning of the school year. Children under 7 years of age should receive 5 doses of DTaP. DTaP is a vaccine series that helps children younger than age 7 develop immunity against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. It is recommended that the DTaP series begin at 2 months of age, and continue at 4 months, 6 months, 15-18 months, and 4-6 years of age.\n\nFor older children and adults a different vaccine, the Tdap, is given. Children 7 through 10 years of age should receive one dose of Tdap if they were not fully vaccinated with DTaP. Adolescents through age 18 should receive one dose of Tdap, preferably between the ages of 11 and 12. Everyone 19 years of age or older should receive one dose of Tdap.\n\nThe Tdap vaccine is highly recommended for the following populations: Women who are pregnant or may become pregnant; Anyone who has close contact with infants under 12 months of age (parents, siblings, grandparents, household contacts, child care providers); [and] Anyone with a pre-existing, chronic respiratory disease.\n\nPertussis vaccine (DTaP and/or Tdap) is available through all state immunization providers, including private healthcare providers, and may be available at no cost for those with Medicaid or no insurance at the Forsyth County Department of Public Health. The immunization clinic is a walk-in clinic and does not require appointments.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Forsyth County, with a population of 350 670 residents, is located in the northwestern portion of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is the city of Winston-Salem (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forsyth_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina showing the location of Forsyth County and Winston-Salem (in red) can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winston-Salem,_North_Carolina#/media/File:Forsyth_County_North_Carolina_incorporated_and_unincorporated_areas_Winston-Salem_highlighted.svg and a map of the U.S. at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York\nDate: Fri 4 Aug 2017 9:08 AM EDT\nSource: Westchester News12 [edited]\nhttp://westchester.news12.com/story/36062668/monroe-woodbury-warns-of-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nParents in Orange [County, New York State] were alerted [Fri 4 Aug 2017] about a whooping cough outbreak after officials confirmed several students contracted the potentially serious infection.\n\nMonroe-Woodbury school officials confirmed that 3 high school students are sick with pertussis, a potentially serious bacterial respiratory infection also known as whooping cough. The district posted a notice to its website after the Orange County Health Department confirmed the cases. Parents also were notified by email.\n\nOfficials say the affected students were up-to-date with their immunizations, but that the DTap vaccine - which wards against whooping cough - doesn't provide 100 percent coverage while children age. Health officials say booster vaccines may help curb the spread of infection.\n\nPertussis is particularly dangerous for infants and expectant mothers. Health experts say it starts off like a regular cold, but eventually causes a severe, high-pitched cough.\n\nOfficials say the students may have been infected while playing sports together. News 12 is told they are being treated and that the outbreak seems to be contained.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nOrange County, with a population of 372 813 residents, is located in the Mid-Hudson Region of the Hudson Valley region in the U.S. state of New York; Rockland County borders it to the southeast and the U.S. state of New Jersey to the southwest (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_County,_New_York). A map of New York State showing the location of Orange County (in red) can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_County,_New_York#/media/File:Map_of_New_York_highlighting_Orange_County.svg and a map of the U.S. at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Indiana\nDate: Thu 27 Jul 2017 9:56 AM\nSource: The Indy Channel rtv ABC6 [edited]\nhttp://www.theindychannel.com/news/health/health-dept-warning-of-increase-in-whooping-cough\n\n\nThere have been more than double the cases of whooping cough in the 1st half of 2017 compared to the same timeframe in 2016, the Indiana State Department of Health said [Thu 27 Jul 2017]. The health department is urging Hoosiers to take precautions against it, primarily through vaccinations.\n\nThere were 66 cases of whooping cough in the 1st half of 2016, compared to 136 cases in 2017. Children under 7-years-old should get the DTaP vaccine. Children and adults over 10-years-old should get the Tdap vaccine. Pregnant women are also urged to get one dose of Tdap during each pregnancy to protect the infants.\n\n[Byline: Matt McKinney]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indiana, with a population of about 6.6 million residents, is a US state located in the midwestern and Great Lakes regions of North America, bordering Lake Michigan to the northwest, Michigan to the north, Ohio to the east, Kentucky to the south and southeast, and Illinois to the west (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana). A map of the U.S. showing the location of Indiana (in red) can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana#/media/File:Indiana_in_United_States.svg and a map of the U.S. at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nCanada\n----\n[6] Alberta\nDate: Wed 26 Jul 2017 7:22 pm\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttp://globalnews.ca/news/3627235/whooping-cough-almost-killed-him-as-a-baby-now-an-outbreak-is-putting-him-at-risk-again/\n\n\nWith nearly 400 cases of whooping cough this year [2017] across Alberta, a Canmore family is sharing their son's experience with the disease. Thirteen years ago, [their son] became ill with whooping cough. At just 7-weeks-old, he nearly died. 'It was awful. He couldn't breathe,' [his] mother said. The memory of that time still brings the Canmore mom to tears. 'I will never forget it - they had to suck out his lungs. A 7-week-old baby and they had to suck out his lungs just so he could breathe.' [The mother] says her son spent 22 terrifying days in hospital, fighting to survive an infection that can be fatal for babies. 'Children can still die from pertussis (whooping cough) even in the care of a physician. We were certainly told that when [her son] was in the oxygen tent and going through that process,' said [the son's] dad.\n\nIt's what health officials in southern Alberta are most afraid of as an outbreak of whooping cough continues more than a month after it was 1st declared. There are 168 cases now connected to the outbreak in the south zone, while there have been 394 cases so far this year [2017] province-wide. 'We have had infants in the past who have died (from whooping cough) at a very young age, so that's what we're hoping to avoid with all of this - we want to protect those most vulnerable,' said Dr. Karin Goodison, Alberta Health Services Medical Officer of Health for the south zone.\n\nThe best protection against whooping cough is immunization, but in pockets around the province, Goodison says vaccination rates are very low. As a result, outbreaks of diseases like whooping cough, measles and mumps have become common. 'Once it starts in that area, we get a large number of cases in high concentration and that's when we get an impact on our immunized populations.'\n\n[Byline: Heather Yourex-West]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sabah, with a population of about 3.5 million residents, is one of the 2 East Malaysian states situated on the northern coast of the island of Borneo, bordering the Malaysian state of Sarawak to the southwest, and Kalimantan of Indonesia to the south; Kota Kinabalu is the capital city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabah).
