Adolescents through age 18 should receive one dose of Tdap, preferably between the ages of 11 and 12. [2] Washington\n [4] New York\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Borneo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/147", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kalimantan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winston-Salem,_North_Carolina#/media/File:Forsyth_County_North_Carolina_incorporated_and_unincorporated_areas_Winston-Salem_highlighted.svg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Warden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Winston - Salem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Forsyth County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5085227", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (05): New Zealand, USA, Australia, Spain", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5085227", "date": "2017-06-05 18:17:19", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (05): NEW ZEALAND, USA, AUSTRALIA, SPAIN\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Otago, New Zealand\n[2] Webster County, Missouri, USA\n[3] Louisiana, USA\n[4] Cairns, Queensland, Australia\n[5] South Australia, Australia\n\n******\n[1] Otago, New Zealand\nDate: Mon 22 May 2017\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttps://www.odt.co.nz/regions/central-otago/pertussis-cases-spike-then-ease\n\n\nA spike in pertussis in Central Otago may be due to greater awareness or part of a national cycle, Southern District Health Board (SDHB) medical officer of health Dr Naomi Gough says. Notifications of suspected pertussis, also known as whooping cough, and confirmed cases in Central Otago had both increased since about March [2017], Dr Gough said.\n\nShe said in Otago there would normally be 3 or 4 notifications of suspected pertussis, which typically included 1 or 2 confirmed cases, every week. In the past 3 weeks there had been 25 notifications of possible pertussis in Central Otago, of which 6 were confirmed. Most of those were from people who had in fact been sick about a month ago, and the spike had now settled, Dr Gough said.\n\nThere had also been a spike in Central Otago in March [2017], and in Dunedin and Invercargill earlier in the year [2017]. There had been no increase in pertussis this year in Queenstown or Wanaka.\n\nDr Gough said the reasons for the increase could be twofold. The first group of reasons was increased awareness of pertussis, the SDHB asking GPs to report all cases of suspected pertussis, and improvement in the testing for pertussis.\n\nSecondly, there seemed to be a 4-yearly cycle of pertussis outbreaks nationally. The last significant outbreak in Central Otago was about 4 years ago, Dr Gough said. She said it was important to note pertussis was always in the community and its circulation and spikes were normal, although the SDHB was increasingly noticing clusters of pertussis in communities.\n\nBut it was also important to remember how highly contagious the bacterial infection was, and the importance of taking adequate measures if someone got sick with it. People with pertussis were typically contagious for about 3 weeks and could be prescribed a 5-day course of antibiotics. They were advised to stay at home until they had finished taking the antibiotics.\n\nIt could be ''annoying'' to have to stay at home, but whooping cough was very dangerous to young unimmunised babies and to older people and those who were undergoing chemotherapy or had otherwise compromised immune systems, Dr\nGough said. She said some people with pertussis had only minor coughing and might not realise they had the disease.\n\nShe recommended families check their immunisations were up-to-date, and also consider getting influenza vaccinations.\n\n[Byline: Pam Jones]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Otago is a region of New Zealand in the south of the South Island; Central Otago is an informal name for the inland part of the Otago region https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Otago. A map of New Zealand showing the location of Otago can be found at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otago#/media/File:Position_of_Otago.png. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Webster County, Missouri, USA\nDate: Mon 22 May 2017, 5:35 PM\nSource: KY3 News [edited]\nhttp://www.ky3.com/content/news/whooping-cough-amish-seymour-423715413.html\n\n\nTwo babies are hospitalized from an outbreak of whooping cough in the Amish community in Webster County. County health officials now are trying to control the spread of the disease.\n\nThe whooping cough outbreak has been going on for at least a couple of weeks in the Amish community near Seymour, even leading to the hospitalization of 2 babies. A total of 6 cases are confirmed, while there are many more possible cases in the Amish community along Highway C.\n\n'The challenge came because you have to go to them; they don't really have the means to hear or see about it through the news, the media,' said Banks. The Webster County Health Unit used word of mouth and set up an immunization clinic at a country store last week. In 2 days, they vaccinated more than 300 adults and children. 'We're hoping that our actions and our control measures really counteracted against the spread of it. They told us what was going on,' said Banks.\n\nPharmacist Rebecca Kime at Downtown Drug in Seymour started hearing the signature cough about a week ago. 'Yep, we have; a lot of Purell, lot of Lysol wipe-downs,' said Kime. At Downtown Drug, the antibiotic used to treat whooping cough has been flying out the door. Just in the past week, they've handed out about 200 prescriptions for azithromycin. 'They also were treating all the children in the family, and sometimes you've got 13, 14 kids in a family,' said Kime. The favored herbal treatment has also sold out.\n\nSo far, no confirmed cases are outside the Amish community, and health officials have not even seen any cases in the Amish community along Highway A.\n\n[Byline: Linda Russell, Tim Leimkuhler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[The Amish settled in Webster County in 1968, acquiring many old rundown farms http://seymourmochamber.com/htm/amish.htm. They are engaged in farming, as well as construction and produce sales http://amishamerica.com/missouri-amish/. The Missouri Amish population is now North America's 7th-largest, with over 9000 Amish. The area near the town of Seymour in Webster County, with a population of about 1500 is the largest community of Amish in Missouri.\n\nAmish are not totally averse to childhood immunizations. In a survey of Amish families in Ohio in 2007, among the 359 respondents, '85 percent of Amish parents surveyed accept some immunizations' and 'only 14 percent of the parents reported that none of their children had received immunizations. As many as 85 percent of the parents who completely exempted their children from vaccines stated that the main reason they do not vaccinate their children is concern over adverse effects. Many parents indicated that they allow their children to receive only some vaccines because of their concern about the way certain vaccines are produced http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2011/06/23/peds.2009-2599?sso=1&sso_redirect_count=1&nfstatus=401&nftoken=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&nfstatusdescription=ERROR%3a+No+local+token.' - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Louisiana, USA\nDate: Thu 1 Jun 2017\nSource: KPLC TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kplctv.com/story/35563720/whats-going-around-whooping-cough\n\n\nA highly contagious respiratory disease known for its distinctive cough is what's going around this week. A recent handful of cases of whooping cough in local children is concerning in the medical community.\n\n'We're definitely seeing an increase in identified cases,' said Lake Charles Memorial Health System infection preventionist, Bridget Redlich.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Cairns, Queensland, Australia\nDate: Tue 23 may 2017, 3:00pm\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttp://www.cairnspost.com.au/news/cairns/parents-blame-school-for-not-warning-public-about-whooping-cough-outbreak/news-story/c339b6eb1fb23fef6738bab0054458ce\n\n\nParents of children who have contracted whooping cough are blaming authorities for not doing enough to warn the public about an outbreak of the highly infectious disease in a Cairns suburb.\n\nA total of 3 people have been confirmed with whooping cough at Gordonvale, including 2 students of Gordonvale State School, who became infected several weeks ago. The school, however, only advised its community about 1 of the cases in its latest newsletter yesterday [Mon 22 May 2017]. Both students, who are recovering at home, were vaccinated against the airborne bacterial disease at early ages.\n\nThere have been 45 cases of whooping cough or pertussis in the Cairns health district since the start of the year [2017], compared to a yearly average of 86 cases. Cairns Tropical Public Health Services director Dr Richard Gair said information about whooping cough had been distributed to the school and a letter provided for distribution to families.\n\nHowever, he said national guidelines for responding to a whooping cough case did not focus on a community-wide response, such as that relevant to dengue fever or the Zika virus, with the response instead targeting follow-up of 'close risk contacts'. A Department of Education and Training spokesman said the principal of Gordonvale State advised parents and carers yesterday about a confirmed case of whooping cough.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cairns, with a population of 147 993 residents, is a major city on the east coast of Far North Queensland in Australia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cairns. A map of Australia showing the location of Cairns can be found at: https://www.google.com/maps/place/Cairns+QLD,+Australia. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] South Australia, Australia\nDate: Tue 23 May 2017, 3:26 PM\nSource: Port Lincoln Times [edited]\nhttp://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/4682157/rise-in-local-whooping-cough-cases/\n\n\nRecent figures suggest a whooping cough epidemic could be on the way, with Port Lincoln doctors seeing several cases of the virus in babies and families.\n\nThere have already been 648 confirmed cases of whooping cough in South Australia in 2017, the highest year-to-date cases for more than 5 years. This time last year [2016] there were 452 cases, compared to just 168 cases in 2014.\n\nThe whooping cough vaccine wears off after 4 to 5 years, and those who are in contact with babies are especially encouraged to get their booster shot.\n\nLincoln Medical Centre general practitioner Dr Simon Lathlean said he\nencouraged anyone in contact with babies under 12 months of age to ensure their boosters were up to date.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Port Lincoln, with a population of 16 147 residents, is the largest city in the West Coast region, approximately 280 km west of the Adelaide in the Australian state of South Australia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Lincoln. A map of Australia showing the location of Port Lincoln can be found at: https://www.google.com/maps/place/Port+Lincoln+SA+5606,+Australia. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] Spain\nDate: Thu 1 June 2017\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 22, Issue 22 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22809\n\n\nA case-control study to assess the effectiveness of pertussis vaccination during pregnancy on newborns, Valencian community, Spain, 1 March 2015 to 29 February 2016.\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nBellido-Blasco J, Guiral-Rodrigo S, Miguez-Santiyan A, Salazar-Cifre A, Gonzalez-Moran F.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n'In the Valencian Community (Spain), the programme of maternal pertussis vaccination during pregnancy started in January 2015. The objective of this study was to estimate in this region the vaccine effectiveness (VE) in protecting newborns against laboratory-confirmed pertussis infection. A matched case-control study was undertaken in the period between [1 Mar 2015] and [29 Feb 2016]. A total of 22 cases and 66 controls (plus or less 15 days of age difference) were included in the study. Cases were non-vaccinated infants less than 3 months of age at disease onset testing positive for pertussis by real-time PCR. For every case 3 unvaccinated controls were selected. Odds ratios (OR) were calculated by multiple conditional logistic regression for association between maternal vaccination and infant pertussis. Other children in the household, as well as mother- and environmental covariates were taken into account. The VE was calculated as 1 minus OR. Mothers of 5 cases (23 percent) and of 41 controls (62 percent) were vaccinated during pregnancy. The adjusted VE was 90.9 percent (95 percent confidence interval (CI): 56.6 to 98.1). The only covariate in the final model was breastfeeding (protective effect). Our study provides evidence in favour of pertussis vaccination programmes for pregnant women in order to prevent whooping cough in infants aged less than 3 months.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Our study provides evidence in favour of pertussis vaccination programmes for pregnant women in order to prevent whooping cough in infants aged less than 3 months.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nSo far, no confirmed cases are outside the Amish community, and health officials have not even seen any cases in the Amish community along Highway A.\n\n[Byline: Linda Russell, Tim Leimkuhler]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Port Lincoln, with a population of 16 147 residents, is the largest city in the West Coast region, approximately 280 km west of the Adelaide in the Australian state of South Australia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Lincoln. USA (08): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4718641", "date": "2016-12-23 11:12:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Dec 2016\nSource: KRQE [edited]\nhttp://krqe.com/blog/2016/12/20/whooping-cough-outbreak-in-eddy-county/\n\n\nThe Department of Health has announced an outbreak of whooping cough in Eddy County.\n\n20 cases have been or are currently being investigated in Eddy County residents since 1 Nov [2016]. They include 10 school-aged children.\n\nWhooping cough is very contagious and can cause serious illness, especially in infants.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Trujillo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are pertussis (whooping cough) outbreaks occurring worldwide, associated with significant morbidity and mortality, especially in infants, variously attributed to increased virulence of outbreak strains, a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, a waning immune or ineffective immune response after vaccination with the current DTaP and Tdap vaccines, as well as decreased levels of vaccine utilization in some areas. A discussion of these issues can be found in prior ProMED-mail posts (e.g., Pertussis - USA (14) 20151110.3781837 and Pertussis - USA (02) 20130905.1923593).\n\nEddy County, with a population of 53 829 residents, is located in the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat and largest city is Carlsbad (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddy_County,_New_Mexico). Carlsbad Caverns National Park and the nuclear Waste Isolation Pilot Plant are located in this county. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are pertussis (whooping cough) outbreaks occurring worldwide, associated with significant morbidity and mortality, especially in infants, variously attributed to increased virulence of outbreak strains, a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, a waning immune or ineffective immune response after vaccination with the current DTaP and Tdap vaccines, as well as decreased levels of vaccine utilization in some areas. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Date: Tue 20 Dec 2016\nSource: KRQE [edited]\n PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eddy County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Carlsbad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4735420", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (01): (WI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4735420", "date": "2017-01-01 10:52:28", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (01): (WISCONSIN)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 30 Dec 2016 2:22 PM CST\nSource: WSAW [edited]\nhttp://www.wsaw.com/content/news/Vilas-Oneida-Co-release-newest-whooping-cough-numbers-408830535.html\n\n\nIn northern Wisconsin 2 counties have released new figures regarding the number of whooping cough cases.\n\nThe Oneida County and Vilas County health department reports collectively there are 39 confirmed cases, 29 probable, and 98 suspected cases of whooping cough.\n\nThe number of cases prompted the Rhinelander School District to extended its Christmas break by 3 days.\n\nAccording to a news release, Oneida County health officials reported a decrease in new identified cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are pertussis (whooping cough) outbreaks occurring worldwide, associated with significant morbidity and mortality, especially in infants, variously attributed to increased virulence of outbreak strains, a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, a waning immune or ineffective immune response after vaccination with the current DTaP and Tdap [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis] vaccines, as well as decreased levels of vaccine utilization in some areas. A discussion of these issues can be found in prior ProMED-mail posts (such as, Pertussis - USA (14) 20151110.3781837 and Pertussis - USA (02) 20130905.1923593).\n\nData from the Wisconsin DOH indicate that 2012 was an epidemic year, but subsequent years had much lower activity, including 2016 (https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/immunization/pert-report.pdf).\n\nThe state of Wisconsin can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/250. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/wisconsin-county-map.gif. Oneida County, with a population of almost 36 000 residents, and Vilas County, with a population of 21 430 residents, are located in the north-central region of the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneida_County,_Wisconsin and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilas_County,_Wisconsin). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are pertussis (whooping cough) outbreaks occurring worldwide, associated with significant morbidity and mortality, especially in infants, variously attributed to increased virulence of outbreak strains, a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, a waning immune or ineffective immune response after vaccination with the current DTaP and Tdap [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis] vaccines, as well as decreased levels of vaccine utilization in some areas. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The Oneida County and Vilas County health department reports collectively there are 39 confirmed cases, 29 probable, and 98 suspected cases of whooping cough. PERTUSSIS - USA (01): (WISCONSIN)\n*********************************\n Date: Fri 30 Dec 2016 2:22 PM CST\nSource: WSAW [edited]\nhttp://www.wsaw.com/content/news/Vilas-Oneida-Co-release-newest-whooping-cough-numbers-408830535.html \n\nThe state of Wisconsin can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/250.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-12-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vilas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Oneida County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oneida County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4902867", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (01): Viet Nam, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4902867", "date": "2017-03-15 15:53:36", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (01): VIETNAM, NEW ZEALAND\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Viet Nam (Northern Provinces, Hanoi)\n[2] New Zealand (Canterbury)\n[3] New Zealand (Bay of Plenty)\n\n******\n1] Viet Nam (Northern Provinces, Hanoi)\nDate: Mon 13 Mar 2017, 1:52 PM (GMT+7)\nSource: Saigon Giai Phong Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Health/2017/3/123523/\n\n\nThe number of kids with pertussis skyrockets in [the] North. The Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health said yesterday [Sun 12 Mar 2017] that since the beginning of the year [2017], 82 kids with pertussis had been reported; mostly from the northern provinces of Cao Bang, Hanoi, Hai Duong, Phu Tho, Ha Nam and the central province of Nghe An. Amongst localities, Hanoi has 21 cases with 1 death.\n\nIn the meantime, the National Children Hospital showed an upward trend of the disease in children. During the past 3 months, the hospital recorded 55 infection cases while it was 12 cases in the same period last year [2016] and it was 10 cases in 2015.\n\nThe Department also said that the cold weather in the North is conducive to the disease outbreaks. To make matters worse, many of them [the kids] had not been vaccinated.\n\n[Byline: Nguyen Quoc, translated by Uyen Phuonng]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Vietnam is divided into 58 provinces and 5 municipalities existing at the same level as provinces. A map of Vietnam can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152 and a map of Vietnam provinces can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Vietnam. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Canterbury)\nDate: Tue 14 Mar 2017, 3:48 PM\nSource: Stuff Health [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/national/health/90411986/whooping-cough-mini-epidemic-in-canterbury\n\nWhooping cough can seriously affect newborn babies. A 'mini epidemic' of whooping cough has afflicted Canterbury for the past 20 months. Health officials are calling for mothers and family members to immunise themselves as well as their children.\n\nBetween November 2016 and March 2017, 50 confirmed cases and 39 probable cases of whooping cough were reported to the Canterbury District Health Board. Canterbury Medical Officer of Health Dr Ramon Pink said the demographic of people afflicted was similar to a major epidemic, with the bulk of cases in people under the age of 15.\n\nThe last major whooping cough epidemic was in 2012, during which there were more than 100 cases reported in Canterbury in [a few] months. Pink said the situation was an increase above the 'endemic' \u00ad or normal \u00ad infection levels. 'Maybe what we we're seeing is an increase in the endemic level rather than a mini epidemic.' He said infant vaccination levels were very good in Canterbury, at 95 per cent for the last 15 months reported. 'Vaccination, with vaccine-preventable diseases, is still the most effective tool we have.'\n\nPink said the mini epidemic was not a major concern, but it was a reminder to healthcare providers to be vigilant. 'The fact that we have occasional clusters in different communities is not uncommon. And so we would address those as we usually would. We would just be more concerted in our effort to encourage timely vaccination. Which is what we have been doing.'\n\nHe said an area to work on was encouraging expecting mothers to get vaccinated between 28 weeks and 38 weeks of pregnancy. Pink said immunity to whooping cough wanes over time, so adults and teenagers might need another vaccination, particularly if they are going to be around children.\n\n'An adult who has whooping cough is pretty crook, but the real risk for the littlies, particularly down to 1 [year old], since their airways are really tiny.' People with a cold should avoid visiting young babies, he said. 'If you want to be sure, go to your GP and get vaccinated against whooping cough so that when you visit you're minimizing the risk to that newborn.' More information on whooping cough, and who should be immunised and when, is available on the Ministry of Health website.\n\n[Byline: Jamie Small]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Canterbury, with a population of 600 100 residents, is a region of New Zealand, located in the central-eastern South Island; Christchurch is the South Island's largest city with 65 percent of the region's population (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canterbury,_New_Zealand). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] New Zealand (Bay of Plenty)\nDate: Wed 8 Mar 2017, 5:00 PM\nSource: Bay of Plenty Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/bay-of-plenty-times/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503343&objectid=11814447\n\n\nIn the first 7 weeks of 2017 there have been 7 cases of whooping cough in the Bay of Plenty, 2 of which were babies. 'We're not off to a good start,' Toi Te Ora Public Health Service medical officer of health Dr Phil Shoemack, said.\n\nThe number of people with whooping cough increased across the Bay last year [2016] - up 61 from 2015. A total of 10 of these were babies, who were at most risk of complications, and 11 were young children aged from 1 to 4 years old. Already this year [2017] small children have been admitted to hospital with the disease. Babies under 1-year-old are at the most risk of serious complications from the illness such as pneumonia and brain damage.\n\nPregnant women could get a whooping cough booster vaccination free between 28 and 38 weeks of pregnancy. This was the time she could pass her immunity on to the baby, helping protect them until they were old enough to be vaccinated against whooping cough themselves as part of their free childhood immunisation at 6 weeks, 3 months and 5 months old.\n\nMr. Shoemack said as children have now gone back to school and preschool, it was a good time to check if family was up to date with immunisations. Immunisation coordinator Diane Newland said women should talk to their GP about the Boostrix vaccine and when the right time to have it. 'Staff should also be able to talk about immunisations for your baby and the importance of getting these on time.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Bay of Plenty is a region on the northern coast of New Zealand's North Island https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_of_Plenty. A map of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164 and a map of New Zealand's regions can be found at http://www.tourism.org.nz/regions.html. - Mod.ML]\n\n[There are pertussis (whooping cough) outbreaks occurring worldwide, associated with significant morbidity and mortality, especially in infants, variously attributed to increased virulence of outbreak strains, a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, a waning immune or ineffective immune response after vaccination with the current DTaP and Tdap [diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis] vaccines, as well as decreased levels of vaccine utilization in some areas.\n\nA discussion of these issues can be found in my colleague, Mod.LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts (such as Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935, Pertussis - USA (04) 20131229.2140560 and Pertussis - USA (02) 20130905.1923593).\n\nIn 2014 in the U.S., over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations of the vaccine. In the 'acellular' vaccine, the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nIn the U.S., children should get 5 doses of DTaP, 1 dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/dtap-tdap-td/hcp/recommendations.html). One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3167.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n ML]\n\n[There are pertussis (whooping cough) outbreaks occurring worldwide, associated with significant morbidity and mortality, especially in infants, variously attributed to increased virulence of outbreak strains, a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, a waning immune or ineffective immune response after vaccination with the current DTaP and Tdap [diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis] vaccines, as well as decreased levels of vaccine utilization in some areas. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Vietnam is divided into 58 provinces and 5 municipalities existing at the same level as provinces. The Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health said yesterday [Sun 12 Mar 2017] that since the beginning of the year [2017], 82 kids with pertussis had been reported; mostly from the northern provinces of Cao Bang, Hanoi, Hai Duong, Phu Tho, Ha Nam and the central province of Nghe An. {"archive_id": "5048581", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (04): Canada, USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5048581", "date": "2017-05-19 21:14:56", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (04): CANADA, USA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\nCanada\n---\n[1] Saskatchewan\nUSA\n---\n[2] Washington\n[3] New York\n[4] New York\n[5] Utah\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[1] Saskatchewan\nDate: Fri 5 May 2017 10:34 AM EDT\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttp://globalnews.ca/news/3429031/whooping-cough-outbreak-in-prince-albert-parkland-health-region/\n\n\nThe Prince Albert Parkland Health Region (PAPHR) [Saskatchewan] announced a whooping cough [pertussis] outbreak focused in its northwest portion on [Fri 5 May 2017].\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is a serious and highly contagious infection of the lungs and throat caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria.\n\nThe health region, Health Canada and surrounding First Nation communities [aboriginal peoples in Canada] are currently assessing and coordinating a response to the outbreak. 'Health Canada is working with First Nations communities to promote the voluntary childhood vaccination program which ensures that children are up to date with their routine vaccinations,' Dr Ibrahim Khan, regional medical health officer for Health Canada in Saskatchewan, said in a press release. 'Health Canada is working with and supporting the efforts of affected First Nation communities in providing enhanced immunization services for prenatal women in their third trimester.'\n\nPAPHR medical health officer Dr Khami Chokani is urging people to check their vaccination status. Health officials said young children who have not been immunized get sicker than older children and adults. 'Our immediate focus is to bring children and adults up-to-date with the pertussis vaccine,' Chokani said. 'It is also important for parents and other caregivers to check their immunization status. In order to help contain the virus, it is important for everyone who can to be immunized.'\n\nChokani added that if people are unsure about whether or not they are up to date with immunizations, they should contact their local public health office. According to PAPHR, people do not develop a permanent immunity to whooping cough and the disease may occur in those who have been vaccinated but symptoms are typically milder.\n\n[Byline: Thomas Piller]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4218.\n\nThe Prince Albert Parkland Regional Health Region, located in the center of the Canadian province of Saskatchewan, is one of 12 health regions in the province and is responsible for the delivery of health-care services for a population of 82 578 people, including 12 First Nations people, with a total on-reserve population of more than 9000 residents (http://paphr.ca/about-us); the largest community is the city of Prince Albert, with a population exceeding 44 000. A map showing the location of Prince Albert can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Prince+Albert+Parkland+Health+Region+Corporate+Office/@53.1986638,-105.8052457,13z/data. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[2] Washington\nDate: Mon 8 May 2017\nSource: Daily Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.dailysunnews.com/news/2017/may/08/granger-deals-reports-pertussis/\n\n\nThe local School District [Granger, Yakima County, Washington State] is dealing with an apparent outbreak of pertussis, or whooping cough. Yakima County health officials announced 4 confirmed cases in the district. The cases have appeared during the past 3 weeks, officials with the Yakima Health District said. The entire county had none in 2016. Granger School Superintendent Margarita Lopez did not return a message seeking comment as of press time.\n\n'This is why you need to get your immunization,' Grandview School District Nurse Skitch Stanton said. Stanton said there are no pertussis cases in the Grandview School District.\n\nThis sometimes happens in the spring,' she said of outbreaks. 'Pertussis is not so bad for adults or school age children. The problem is they can have a light case and they give it to a grandparent or the parent of a newborn baby. It's something to keep an eye on.'\n\nMabton School Superintendent Minerva Morales said her district has no cases to date. The same is true in Sunnyside schools, a district nurse, Becky Norem, said. The district is ready in the event of an outbreak, Sunnyside School District spokeswoman Jessica Morgan said. 'Doctor's orders are followed, which includes the student staying home from school until the medications have run their course,' Morgan said. And district officials work with the health department '... to identify people who came in close contact with the student and could potentially be affected,' Morgan said.\n\nYakima Health District officials said those who have the illness should remain isolated until a 5-day course of medication is complete.\n\nThe public is asked to call 509-249-6541 to report a suspected or confirmed case of pertussis.\n\n[Byline: John Fannin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Granger, with a population of 3246 residents, is a town in Yakima County, in the US state of Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granger,_Washington). Grandview, with a population of 10 862 residents, Sunnyside, with a population of 15 858 residents, and Mabton, with a population of 2286 residents, are also cities in Yakima County, Washington. A map showing the location of these cities can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mabton,+WA+98935. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] New York\nDate: Thu 11 May 2017 8:28 AM EDT\nSource: Times Union [edited]\nhttp://www.timesunion.com/allwcm/article/Bethlehem-schools-have-7-cases-of-whooping-cough-11136242.php\n\n\nTo date, 7 cases of pertussis -- commonly known as whooping cough, have been reported in Bethlehem [New York State] schools. There are 3 cases at the high school, 2 at the middle school and 1 each at Eagle and Slingerlands elementary schools, county spokeswoman Mary Rozak said. The outbreak is the 1st to occur statewide this year [2017], according to the state Health Department.\n\nOnly 4 of the Bethlehem cases have been confirmed by laboratory reports. 3 students have symptoms fitting the definition of pertussis and also had contact with students whose cases were laboratory-confirmed, according to a note to parents from Jody Monroe, superintendent of the Bethlehem Central School District.\n\nPertussis is highly contagious, and spreads through air droplets after an infected person sneezes or coughs. Infected people can spread the disease up to three weeks after they develop a cough from the illness. The illness is usually not serious, except for infants, said Dr Eric Schnakenberg of Community Care Family Medicine in Clifton Park. 'Typically, this is sort of a lingering cold, it will be kicking around for 6 weeks,' Schnakenberg said. Treatment is recommended, however, to keep the illness from spreading, he said. Serious complications include pneumonia, impaired brain function and even death, according to the state Health Department.\n\nMost schoolchildren in New York must be vaccinated for pertussis. The vaccine is effective, but wanes over time, requiring booster shots. Because the protection decreases over time, even people who have been vaccinated can catch pertussis. 'The immunity tends to wane, so at age 11 we recommend all the kids get a booster,' Schnakenberg said. Booster vaccinations are also recommended for anyone who expects to be in close contact with babies, he said, including pregnant women, child-care or health-care workers, or parents and grandparents of infants.\n\nThere have been no other reported cases of pertussis in the county this year [2017]. Last year [2016], there were 10 cases countywide, and in 2015, there were 5. Statewide, so far in 2017, there have been 119 cases of pertussis, compared to 220 cases at this time last year. There have been isolated clusters and sporadic cases around the state this year, but no outbreaks outside Bethlehem, according to the state Health Department. Schnakenberg said outbreaks are infrequent.\n\n'Since the pertussis vaccine has been available since 1990, there's been a dramatic decrease in whooping cough in this country,' he said. Pertussis does tend to spike every three to five years, however, according to state health officials. The last such increase was in 2012, when more than 3000 New Yorkers contracted the illness. More than 500 of those patients were in Suffolk County, according to state Health Department data. There were 58 cases in Albany County that year, and 168 in the 4-county Capital Region.\n\n[Byline: Claire Hughes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bethlehem, with a population of 33 656 residents, is a town in Albany County in the US state of New York. The town is just south of the city of Albany, the capital of New York State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bethlehem,_New_York). A map showing the location of Bethlehem can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Bethlehem,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York\nDate: Mon 15 May 2017\nSource: CNYCentral [edited]\nhttp://cnycentral.com/news/local/parents-warned-after-baldwinsville-district-confirms-whooping-cough-cases\n\n\nParents in the Baldwinsville School District have been warned to keep a close eye on their children's health after school officials confirmed there have been several diagnosed cases of pertussis, also known as whopping cough.\n\nThe superintendent said nearly all the students in the district are vaccinated as part of a requirement to attend 6th grade.\n\nThe district's custodial staff is now taking extra cleaning measures to disinfect all classrooms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Baldwinsville, with a population of 7378 residents, is a village in Onondaga County in the US state of New York; it is part of the Syracuse Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baldwinsville,_New_York). A map showing the location of Baldwinsville can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Baldwinsville,+NY+13027. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Utah\nDate: Tue 16 May 2017 12:18 PM MDT\nSource: The Salt Lake Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.sltrib.com/home/5297341-155/whooping-cough-outbreak-persists-at-charter\n\n\nSalt Lake County health officials hope summer break will run out the clock on a lingering outbreak of pertussis -- or whooping cough -- at the American International School of Utah [AISU].\n\nThe outbreak was reported last month, when roughly a dozen cases of pertussis led to 30 unvaccinated AISU students being excluded from classes, and the school closing one day early for its annual spring break [10-14 Apr 2017]. But the outbreak has since spread to include 32 confirmed or suspected cases of whooping cough, said Salt Lake County Health Department spokesman Nicholas Rupp, putting roughly 180 unvaccinated students at risk for infection.\n\nWhile symptomatic children have been encouraged to stay home, Rupp said unvaccinated students are no longer being 'excluded' -- or quarantined -- because classes are scheduled to end [2 Jun 2017]. 'Now it's more or less everywhere,' Rupp said. 'We've elected to not pursue those exclusions and just let the school year play out.'\n\nRupp said whooping cough is relatively common, with roughly 50 cases reported in Salt Lake County during 2016. The disease ebbs and flows on a multiyear cycle, he said, with the county reporting more than 60 confirmed or suspected cases so far this year. 'We're on the upswing,' Rupp said. 'AISU is certainly contributing to that increase.'\n\nUtah law requires that public school students be vaccinated, but allows parents to declare an exemption and opt out for any reason. The Salt Lake County Health Department recommends schools have an opt-out rate no higher than 5 percent to achieve 'herd immunity,' or the rate at which vaccination is so prevalent the spread of a disease is effectively halted.\n\nAt the American International School of Utah in Murray, the vaccination opt-out rate is 11 percent. Rupp said there is 'no doubt' the high number of unvaccinated children contributed to the spread of pertussis. 'We are struggling to control the outbreak because of that exemption rate,' he said. 'The lack of vaccination is a problem.'\n\nThe health department sent a letter to AISU staff and parents [Tue 16 May 2017], encouraging sick children be treated by medical providers and kept home. The letter also encouraged families to complete immunizations if they had not already done so. 'The most important message is that if your child is not vaccinated, not adequately immunized, please consider getting it done,' Rupp said.\n\nKelly Casaday, AISU's director of operations, said the school's attendance rates have returned to normal since last month's [April 2017] school closure, but the outbreak disrupted end-of-year events like testing, and a choir concert other schools were invited to participate in has been rescheduled. We're going to postpone that two weeks,' Casaday said. 'We don't want to put anybody else at risk.' He said students and staff have been told to assume any health issues are the result of whooping cough and to stay home from school. He also said several parents have indicated they will reconsider their vaccine exemptions as a result of the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Benjamin Wood]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The American International School of Utah is a 3-year-old public charter school for tuition-paying international and non- tuition-paying local students from grades K-12 in Murray, Utah. Murray, with a population of about 46 746 residents, is a city located Salt Lake County, about 8 miles [13 km] south of Salt Lake City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murray,_Utah). [1] Saskatchewan\nUSA\n---\n In this posting:\nCanada\n---\n \n\nKelly Casaday, AISU's director of operations, said the school's attendance rates have returned to normal since last month's [April 2017] school closure, but the outbreak disrupted end-of-year events like testing, and a choir concert other schools were invited to participate in has been rescheduled. \n\nThe outbreak was reported last month, when roughly a dozen cases of pertussis led to 30 unvaccinated AISU students being excluded from classes, and the school closing one day early for its annual spring break [10-14 Apr 2017]. \n\nWhile symptomatic children have been encouraged to stay home, Rupp said unvaccinated students are no longer being 'excluded' -- or quarantined -- because classes are scheduled to end [2 Jun 2017]. ' But the outbreak has since spread to include 32 confirmed or suspected cases of whooping cough, said Salt Lake County Health Department spokesman Nicholas Rupp, putting roughly 180 unvaccinated students at risk for infection. \n\n\nParents in the Baldwinsville School District have been warned to keep a close eye on their children's health after school officials confirmed there have been several diagnosed cases of pertussis, also known as whopping cough. \n\nRupp said whooping cough is relatively common, with roughly 50 cases reported in Salt Lake County during 2016. Date: Tue 16 May 2017 12:18 PM MDT\nSource: The Salt Lake Tribune [edited]\n \n\nYakima Health District officials said those who have the illness should remain isolated until a 5-day course of medication is complete. \n\n'Since the pertussis vaccine has been available since 1990, there's been a dramatic decrease in whooping cough in this country,' he said. Please see http://allafrica.com/stories/201510150328.html.\n\n--\nCourtney Kansler\niJET International\nWashington DC\nUSA\n<kanslerc@ijet.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Courtney Kansler for bringing this mistake to our attention. The report cited above, erroneously dated 2016, is likely the same as the one previously posted in 2015 in ProMED, archive no. 20151027.3746994. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56184.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n International\nWashington DC\nUSA\n<kanslerc@ijet.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Courtney Kansler for bringing this mistake to our attention. \n\n--\nCourtney Kansler\niJET [Re: ProMED-mail Pertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20161017.4566087]\n Date: Wed 19 Oct 2016\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "5017287", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (03): USA, Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5017287", "date": "2017-05-06 12:15:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Kansas, USA\nDate: Thu 27 Apr 2017 10:58 pm\nSource: Parsonssun.com [edited]\nhttp://www.parsonssun.com/news/article_015be532-2bc7-11e7-a026-dbbd7aa1e4fd.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Labette County has grown to 6, with 2 more suspected cases awaiting test results, so the Kansas Department of Health and Environment [KDHE] considers it an outbreak.\n\nAn outbreak is seeing more cases of a certain illness than health care professionals would on a normal day, so Public Health of Labette County administrator Debbi Baugher said one case of whooping cough, or pertussis, could be considered an outbreak. But with the potential for 8 cases in students, KDHE decided this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017] to declare an outbreak. Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.\n\nThe disease was 1st found in a high school student, but most of the recent victims are from middle-school age students at Meadow View Grade School. Baugher said a 4 month old infant [had been] admitted to Labette Health with pertussis. A family member who attends Labette County High School and had been exposed to the disease was in the presence of the infant. The infant was born with respiratory issues and was too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nTesting continues for suspected cases, but results have been slow to come back. Baugher said her department worked with KDHE, where cultures are tested, and arranged to reduce that delay for those who get the pertussis test at the hospital's lab. Baugher said the tests had been returning in 5 to 6 days. 'If they take a 5-day treatment they're already done with the treatment before we know what caused it,' Baugher said. Because of the outbreak, KDHE has agreed to test cultures immediately when the hospital lab calls ahead. 'As soon as they get it they test it, so we have a much shorter turn-around time. So we cut it about in half.'\n\nBaugher said as soon as the health department is able to connect the cases, KDHE will quit testing. At that point, if a patient presents at a doctor's office with symptoms, he or she is given a 5-day dose of antibiotic. 'Right now they still want to test because we don't quite have the connections,' Baugher said.\n\n[byline: Ray Nolting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Labette County, with a population of 21 607 residents, is located in the south eastern portion of the US state of Kansas; its most populous city is Parsons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labette_County,_Kansas). A map of the US can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky, USA\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017 7:27 PM EDT\nSource: WLWT [edited]\nhttp://www.wlwt.com/article/19-whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-grant-county-schools/9577025\n\n\nFor a 3rd time in 7 years, whooping cough is showing up in greater numbers than usual in Northern Kentucky. The disease has moved through several schools in Grant County this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017]. As the number of cases grows, so does concern. Those in charge of running Grant County schools are putting the word out to parents Friday night [28 April 2017] about pertussis.\n\nAs of mid-afternoon Friday [28 Apr 2017, presumably. - Mod.SH], there were 25 cases in Grant County, according to the Northern Kentucky Health Department. 'The vast majority are in Grant County schools,' said Emily Wherle, a spokeswoman for the health department. Most of the 19 cases in 4 of the 6 Grant County schools were concentrated in the high school.\n\nGrant County counted 5 cases of whooping cough during all of 2016. As of March 23 this year [2017], there were 5 times that number. There are 3800 students in the district.\n\nAs of [Fri 28 Apr 2017], the state health department had not labeled the increased instances of whooping cough an outbreak. The operative phrase was 'a spike in cases'. Howe said there is information on the school district's website. 'We'd like to see this wrapped up and out of our district and out of our community as soon as possible,' said Howe.\n\nFree vaccines are available for those who meet certain criteria. To learn whether you quality, call the Northern Kentucky Health Department at 859-363-2071.\n\n[byline: John London]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 24 662 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Kentucky; Grant County is included in the Cincinnati (Ohio)-Middletown (Ohio) Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_County,_Kentucky). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Wisconsin, USA\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017\nSource: Star Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.starjournalnow.com/2017/05/03/pertussis-in-the-northwoods-again/#_\n\n\nThe Oneida County Health Department (OCHD) has reported 4 lab-confirmed cases of pertussis at Three Lakes Elementary School. The OCHD is working with the Three Lakes School District, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and community health care providers to prevent the spread of pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nFor more information, call the OCHD at 715-369-6111.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oneida County, with a population of 35 998 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Wisconsin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneida_County,_Wisconsin). Three Lakes Elementary School is located in the town of Three Lakes, Wisconsin, which has a population of 2339 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Lakes,_Wisconsin). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Alabama, USA\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 3:12 pm EDT\nSource: WTVM [edited]\nhttp://www.wtvm.com/story/35345092/whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-at-chambers-county-schools\n\n\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health's Immunization Division is investigating an outbreak of 6 laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) at multiple schools in Chambers County.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Chambers County, with a population of 34 215 residents, is located in the east-central portion of the US state of Alabama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambers_County,_Alabama). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] New South Wales, Australia\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 8:49 AM\nSource: Northern Star [edited]\nhttps://www.northernstar.com.au/news/vaccinate-now-37-cases-of-whooping-cough-in-a-week/3173820/\n\n\nA local public health spokesperson said the recent spike in whooping cough cases on the Northern Rivers was a continuation of a worrying trend. This year [2017] 79 cases of whooping cough were confirmed during the month of April in the Northern NSW Local Health District, according to statistics from the NSW Department of Health. In 2016 this number was 77, in 2015 it was 8, just 3 in 2014 and 4 cases in 2013.\n\nFrom the figures the current spike was no surprise to the North Coast Public Health Unit, which anticipated a threat of the infection, acting director of public health, Greg Bell, said: 'Months April-May hold a real threat but last year [2016] cases dropped off as quickly as they rose,' Mr Bell said.\n\nThe North Coast Public Health Unit is asking parents to immunize their children against preventable diseases after a spike in cases of the potentially deadly whooping cough disease. Bell said there had been 37 whooping cough notifications on the North Coast in the past week [week of Sun 23 Apr 2017], more than double that in the previous week [week of Sun 16 Apr 2017].\n\nMr Bell said the North Coast experienced a similar spike in whooping cough cases leading into winter last year [2016]. He said persistent low vaccination levels in some parts of Northern NSW was worrying, given that free vaccination is available to all parents. Whooping cough vaccination is valuable in preventing severe infection in infants and toddlers, and if unvaccinated children are infected they are at high risk of severe disease. 'It must be remembered that prior to the NSW Government introducing free antenatal whooping cough vaccinations in 2015, 4 infants had died in the preceding 6 years,' Mr Bell said. 'All pregnant women are urged to have the free whooping cough vaccine during their 3rd trimester, preferably at 28 weeks, to provide optimal protection to their infants.'\n\nPositive health interventions, such as vaccination, in the 1st 5 years of a child's life are vitally important in laying the foundation for a healthy and fulfilling life.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Northern Rivers is one of 14 regions of the Australian state of New South Wales (NSW); it is located in the northern portion of NSW, on the border with the state of Queensland to the north and the Pacific Coast to the east; at its most northern point, Northern Rivers is 102 km (63 mi) south east of Brisbane, the Queensland capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rivers). Date: Thu 4 May 2017 8:49 AM\n Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-05-03 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-04-28 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brisbane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chambers County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Labette County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OCHD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio)-Middletown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oneida County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4638663", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (04): (NT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4638663", "date": "2016-11-18 16:05:31", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (04): (NORTHERN TERRITORY)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 15 Nov 2016\nSource: Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-15/whooping-cough-cases-double-in-the-northern-territory/8027570\n\n\nWhooping cough cases double in Northern Territory\n-------------------------------------------------\nThere has been a spike in whooping cough (pertussis) cases in the Top End, prompting the Northern Territory's Department of Health to extend its alert. Official figures show infection rates for the potentially fatal disease doubled since 2015, with 165 cases confirmed in the state since January 2016. Almost 90 percent of those infected have been in the Palmerston and Darwin areas.\n\nDr Rosalind Webby from the NT Centre for Disease Control said while the rise was not connected to a drop in immunization rates, Territorians were being urged to ensure their vaccinations were up-to-date. 'There hasn't been any decrease in immunization rates, we still have high immunization coverage in the Territory, and we know that's good, but we want to make sure people get it on time,' she said. 'But particularly because this is a new program, to make sure that pregnant women know that they can get a vaccine in their 3rd trimester.'\n\nThe last serious whooping cough outbreak occurred in the NT during 2011, with 383 cases confirmed that year.\n\nDr Webby said while whooping cough presented a serious risk to young children, free vaccinations available for parents, babies and carers were helping to reduce its impact. 'We're very lucky, we haven't yet had any infant deaths from whooping cough, but we want to keep it that way, that's why we are raising awareness, we want to make sure little ones really do not get sick,' she said. 'We worry particularly for the little children under 1 year of age, they are the ones that can get very unwell with whooping cough.' She said the lack of cases so far in infants aged under one was evidence the program was working, and pregnant women could be vaccinated during their 3rd trimester.\n\n'This can protect not only themselves, but also their baby,' Dr Webby said.\n\n[Byline: Carmen Brown]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up and down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/292.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up and down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nDr Webby said while whooping cough presented a serious risk to young children, free vaccinations available for parents, babies and carers were helping to reduce its impact. ' We're very lucky, we haven't yet had any infant deaths from whooping cough, but we want to keep it that way, that's why we are raising awareness, we want to make sure little ones really do not get sick,' she said. \n\nThe last serious whooping cough outbreak occurred in the NT during 2011, with 383 cases confirmed that year. http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-15/whooping-cough-cases-double-in-the-northern-territory/8027570\n\n\nWhooping cough cases double in Northern Territory\n PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (04): (NORTHERN TERRITORY)\n************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Palmerston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4971327", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (02): USA, maternal immunization", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4971327", "date": "2017-04-14 13:01:56", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (02): USA, MATERNAL IMMUNIZATION\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Maine (Yarmouth)\n[2] Utah (Murray)\n[3] Nebraska (Ralston)\n[4] Maternal pertussis immunization\n\n\n******\n[1] Maine (Yarmouth)\nDate: Fri 7 Apr 2017\nSource: WGME [edited]\nhttp://wgme.com/news/local/5-students-diagnosed-with-whooping-cough-in-yarmouth\n\n\nAccording to Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 5 students have been diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough, at schools in Yarmouth. The Maine CDC confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Yarmouth High School and one at Yarmouth Elementary School.\n\nWhooping cough is spread from person to person through coughing and sneezing. Whooping cough usually begins with the same symptoms of a common cold like a sore throat and runny nose. It often develops into a severe cough after a few weeks. The cough can last for several weeks or more, according to the Maine CDC.\n\nTo prevent the spread of pertussis, the Yarmouth School Department made the following recommendations: if you or your child has a severe cough, which may include coughing to the point of gagging, vomiting after coughing or difficulty breathing, or a prolonged cough lasting 2 weeks or longer, please keep your child home and contact your health care provider. If your provider suspects pertussis, they will obtain a specimen to be sent for pertussis testing.\n\nChildren and adults with severe cough, prolonged cough or confirmed pertussis will be started on antibiotics and will need to remain at home for five days while taking these antibiotics. Check with your medical provider to be sure you and your child are up to date on your pertussis vaccine.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Yarmouth, with a population of 8349 residents, is a town in Cumberland County, in the US state of Maine, located 12 miles [19.3 km] north of the state's largest city, Portland (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yarmouth,_Maine). A map showing the location of Yarmouth can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Yarmouth,+ME. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Utah (Murray)\nDate: Fri 7 Apr 2017 7:24 PM MDT\nSource: U.S. News & World Report, Associated (AP) report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/utah/articles/2017-04-07/whooping-cough-temporarily-closes-utah-charter-school\n\n\nOfficials have temporarily closed a charter school in Murray, Utah after more than a dozen cases of whooping cough were reported, about 30 unvaccinated students were quarantined and parents kept hundreds of other students home.\n\nThe Salt Lake Tribune reports (http://bit.ly/2oaRMbQ) the American International School of Utah, a public charter school, closed [on Fri 7 Apr 2017], 5 days after the 1st pertussis case was reported. School operations director Kelly Casaday said a weeklong spring break was already scheduled for next week. Classes will resume [17 Apr 2017].\n\nSalt Lake County Health Department spokesman Nicholas Rupp says about 89 per cent of the school's 1400 students are vaccinated. That's below the 92 to 95 per cent that health experts recommend to protect a community. State law allows parents to exempt children from immunizations for medical or religious reasons or a personal opposition to vaccination.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Murray, with a population of almost 50 000 residents, is a city situated in Salt Lake County in the US state of Utah (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murray,_Utah). A map showing the location of Murray, Utah can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Murray,+UT. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nebraska (Ralston)\nDate: Tue 11 Apr 2017\nSource: KETV [edited]\nhttp://www.ketv.com/article/four-cases-of-whooping-cough-confirmed-in-ralston-schools/9261651\n\n\n4 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in Ralston Public Schools [RPS], officials said. 2 cases of pertussis were diagnosed last week [week of 3 Apr 2017] at Wildewood Elementary School. One additional case was confirmed [Mon 10 Apr 2017] at Wildewood and another at Ralston High School.\n\nThe Douglas County Health Department is leading the investigation into the whooping cough cases and has issued a recommended response. According to Ralston Public Schools, the district has either met or exceeded those recommendations, which includes cleaning the affected classrooms. The health department has directly contacted some families and RPS has contacted remaining families in the two buildings that were affected.\n\nThe district released the following statement on [Mon 10 Apr 2017]: 'After communicating with the Douglas County Health Department, our staff immediately worked to meet or exceed their recommended response and share information with our families. We continue to monitor the situation. Student safety and well-being are always our top priorities.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ralston, with a population of almost 6000 residents, is a city in Douglas County, in the US state of Nebraska; Ralston is surrounded on 3 sides by Omaha, with a population of almost 500 000 residents, Nebraska's largest city and the county seat of Douglas County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralston,_Nebraska#Attractions). A map showing the location of Ralston can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ralston,+NE+68127. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Maternal pertussis immunization\nDate: Thu 13 Apr 2017\nSource: Eurosurveillance Edition 2017, 22(15) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22772\n\n\nref: Bento AI, King AA, Rohani P. Maternal pertussis immunisation: clinical gains and epidemiological legacy. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(15): pii=30510. doi: 10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2017.22.15.30510\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nThe increase in whooping cough (pertussis) incidence in many countries with high routine vaccination coverage is alarming, with incidence in the US reaching almost 50 000 reported cases per year, reflecting incidence levels not seen since the 1950s. While the potential explanations for this resurgence remain debated, we face an urgent need to protect newborns, especially during the time window between birth and the 1st routine vaccination dose. Maternal immunisation has been proposed as an effective strategy for protecting neonates, who are at higher risk of severe pertussis disease and mortality. However, if maternally derived antibodies adversely affect the immunogenicity of the routine schedule, through blunting effects, we may observe a gradual degradation of herd immunity. 'Wasted' vaccines would result in an accumulation of susceptible children in the population, specifically leading to an overall increase in incidence in older age groups. In this Perspective, we discuss potential long-term epidemiological effects of maternal immunisation, as determined by possible immune interference outcomes.\n\nConcluding remarks\n------------------\nMaternal pertussis immunisation is safe for both mother and infant [2,11] and is currently recommended in Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Portugal, the UK, and the US, in response to the rise in incidence [2,18]. Its principal aim is to reduce pertussis mortality and morbidity in neonates. There is good reason to stress the direct benefits of maternal immunisation to both mother and infant. However, its potential adverse effects on routine vaccination efficacy and the subsequent long-term epidemiological legacy remain the subject of debate [11,12,16,17,20-23].\n\nGiven these unknowns, mathematical transmission models can be instrumental in predicting the magnitude and time scale of potential effects of maternal antibody interference at the population level. Our recent modelling study [12] identified a trade-off between the direct protection of infants via maternal immunisation and the reduced indirect effects of herd immunity, leading to a gradual increase in incidence among older age cohorts.\n\nUltimately, quantifying the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of maternal immunisation requires a 2-pronged approach combining long-term clinical trials (such as the ongoing and recently finished studies in the UK, Canada, and the US [18]) with epidemiological and health economics modelling. Longitudinal clinical trials can resolve the immunological effects of MatAbs in response to routine vaccination. Furthermore, such research can shed light on the nature of any interference effect. Specifically, it is important to establish whether interference leads to an increase in vaccine failure, reduces the protective effects of the vaccine or affects the duration of protection [12,18]. By integrating information gleaned from clinical and immunological studies within epidemiological transmission models, the effectiveness of alternative strategies can be evaluated.\n\n[The full article, including the figure and references, is available at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Student safety and well-being are always our top priorities.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ralston, with a population of almost 6000 residents, is a city in Douglas County, in the US state of Nebraska; Ralston is surrounded on 3 sides by Omaha, with a population of almost 500 000 residents, Nebraska's largest city and the county seat of Douglas County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralston,_Nebraska#Attractions). \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Murray, with a population of almost 50 000 residents, is a city situated in Salt Lake County in the US state of Utah (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murray,_Utah). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [The full article, including the figure and references, is available at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org> \n\nTo prevent the spread of pertussis, the Yarmouth School Department made the following recommendations: if you or your child has a severe cough, which may include coughing to the point of gagging, vomiting after coughing or difficulty breathing, or a prolonged cough lasting 2 weeks or longer, please keep your child home and contact your health care provider.
