Date: Tue 11 Apr 2017\n Date: Thu 13 Apr 2017\n \n\n[Yarmouth, with a population of 8349 residents, is a town in Cumberland County, in the US state of Maine, located 12 miles [19.3 km] north of the state's largest city, Portland (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yarmouth,_Maine).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yarmouth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Omaha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ralston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Douglas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salt Lake County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cumberland County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Murray", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4706211", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (07): (CA) increased incidence, middle & high schools", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4706211", "date": "2016-12-18 00:13:37", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (07): (CALIFORNIA) INCREASED INCIDENCE, MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOLS\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 16 Dec 2016\nSource: Palo Alto Online [edited]\nhttp://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/2016/12/16/whooping-cough-hits-some-palo-alto-schools\n\n\nCases of whooping cough are affecting some Palo Alto [California] middle and high school students, prompting school officials to send students with any type of cough home and to the doctor for testing, a school district spokesman said this week.\n\nThe highly contagious disease, also called pertussis, has been confirmed in students at 3 schools: Jordan Middle School and Palo Alto and Gunn high schools. Students who have already been vaccinated have been confirmed with whooping cough, underlining the importance of receiving booster shots since the shot does not provide lifetime immunity.\n\nThe school district has worked closely with public health officials since October [2016], when the 1st cases were reported at 2 different schools, said Jorge Quintana, Palo Alto Unified's communications coordinator. Out of an abundance of caution, any student with a cough has been sent home with instructions to be tested by a physician. Students are not allowed back to school until they have tested negative for the disease or received appropriate antibiotics.\n\nThe local outbreak is marked by students who have already been vaccinated, according to the Santa Clara County Public Health Department. The vast majority of cases are part of outbreaks among vaccinated middle and high school students 'because immunity from the vaccines wanes rapidly, leading to cyclical increases in pertussis cases every few years,' county officials said in a 8 Dec [2016] advisory. Booster doses are needed throughout life.\n\nWhooping cough is marked by weeks of severe spasmodic coughing, vomiting and gasping for breath with a deep 'whooping' inhalation. Pertussis has 3 stages, which include with what is called a catarrhal stage of flu-like symptoms, sneezing and occasional cough, (but rarely a fever) lasting 1 to 2 weeks, according to the California Department of Public Health. The coughing gradually becomes more severe and the patient enters a 2nd, or paroxysmal, stage characterized by spasms of severe coughing and whooping.\n\nCoughing, whooping and vomiting decrease over time, but they may return with subsequent respiratory infections. This 3rd, or convalescent, stage typically lasts 6 to 10 weeks, according to the state public health department.\n\nThe disease is especially harmful to very young children, and deaths do occur in some cases. Infants less than a year old might have a shorter 1st stage, but they might gag, gasp or stop breathing, according to the public health department. Their face might also turn blue, purple or red. They might not have the noticeable cough or whoop, officials said.\n\nBecause pertussis is spread by coughing, Quintana said any report of a possible case is taken seriously. The district follows county health department protocol and has communicated the health risks to parents, sending letters to parents at the 3 schools about the outbreak and a more general message to parents of students at all other schools, he said.\n\nThe school district and public health department are currently working to address 'numerous' cases, but Quintana did not provide a specific number. Santa Clara County had 44 cases of suspected whooping cough between October and 6 Dec [2016]. As of 14 Dec [2016], 22 cases were confirmed, according to Santa Clara County Public Health Department officials. That number is not much higher than last year [2015] at this time, however, when 17 cases were confirmed, department spokeswoman Joy Alexiou said. But the number could rise once the probable and suspected cases are confirmed, she added.\n\nThe state health department recommends that infants start receiving the whooping cough vaccination series, or DTaP, as early as 6 weeks old. Even one dose of the vaccine may offer some protection against fatal whooping cough disease in infants, the department noted. Young children need 5 doses of vaccine by kindergarten. Students in 7th grade need to have a booster (Tdap), but adults should also receive a booster shot, especially if they are in contact with infants or are health care workers. Most adults have not yet received Tdap, the health department said.\n\nPregnant women should also receive the booster in their 3rd trimester at the earliest opportunity. Officials recommend the booster during each pregnancy, even when a woman has received the shot beforehand. The booster will help babies during the most vulnerable period after birth until they are old enough to receive the vaccine, officials said.\n\nThe latest information on whooping cough can be found on the California Department of Public Health webpage.\n\n[Byline: Sue Dremann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in a prior ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (07) 20160917.4495935.\n\nPalo Alto, with a population of 64 403, is one of the most expensive cities in the U. S. and its residents are among the most educated in the country, located in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, at the southern end of San Francisco Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palo_Alto,_California). A map showing the location of Palo Alto is available at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Palo+Alto,+CA/. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4249.]", "summary": "Source: Palo Alto Online [edited]\nhttp://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/2016/12/16/whooping-cough-hits-some-palo-alto-schools\n\n\nCases of whooping cough are affecting some Palo Alto [California] middle and high school students, prompting school officials to send students with any type of cough home and to the doctor for testing, a school district spokesman said this week. \n\nThe school district has worked closely with public health officials since October [2016], when the 1st cases were reported at 2 different schools, said Jorge Quintana, Palo Alto Unified's communications coordinator. The vast majority of cases are part of outbreaks among vaccinated middle and high school students 'because immunity from the vaccines wanes rapidly, leading to cyclical increases in pertussis cases every few years,' county officials said in a 8 Dec [2016] advisory. The district follows county health department protocol and has communicated the health risks to parents, sending letters to parents at the 3 schools about the outbreak and a more general message to parents of students at all other schools, he said. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe state health department recommends that infants start receiving the whooping cough vaccination series, or DTaP, as early as 6 weeks old. Out of an abundance of caution, any student with a cough has been sent home with instructions to be tested by a physician.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the U. S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palo Alto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palo Alto Online", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Clara County Public Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gunn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Clara County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4568827", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (02): (NU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4568827", "date": "2016-10-18 17:32:18", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (02): (NUNAVUT)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Oct 2016, 1:21 PM CT\nSource: CBC [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/whooping-cough-outbreak-nunavut-1.3808762\n\n\nNunavut's whooping cough (pertussis) outbreak has now spread throughout the territory, according to a public health advisory issued today 17 Oct 2016 by the territory's Department of Health. Earlier in October 2016, cases were confirmed in Igloolik. A total of 4 other communities in the Baffin region - Cape Dorset, Hall Beach, Pond Inlet and Iqaluit - had previously reported confirmed cases. The advisory says whooping cough is 'a serious and active health concern.'\n\nIqaluit pertussis cases now up to 29 and cases in Pond Inlet rose to 13.\n\nBabies who get whooping cough can become very sick. Officials are urging pregnant women in their last trimester and their families to get vaccinated at their local health centre to protect babies from being infected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis occurs in infants less than 6 months of age, especially neonates. Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension, are ominous signs for mortality.\n\nIn a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904, http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/265.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis occurs in infants less than 6 months of age, especially neonates. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. \n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/whooping-cough-outbreak-nunavut-1.3808762\n\n\nNunavut's whooping cough (pertussis) outbreak has now spread throughout the territory, according to a public health advisory issued today 17 Oct 2016 by the territory's Department of Health. PERTUSSIS - CANADA (02): (NUNAVUT)\n**********************************\n In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension, are ominous signs for mortality.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hall Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pond Inlet", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baffin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Igloolik", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4566087", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Sudan: (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4566087", "date": "2016-10-17 15:55:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN: (NORTH DARFUR)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Pertussis - Sudan: (ND) corr 20161019.4571016. The article below is from October 2015 and it was likely accidentally re-issued by AllAfrica.]\n\nDate: Mon 17 Oct 2016\nSource: allAfrica [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201610170205.html\n\n\nThe North Darfur Ministry of Health has reported that the outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality started in early September [2016]. As of 7 Oct 2016, 323 suspected cases were reported in the locality. The Health Ministry and the WHO are coordinating the response with partners to ensure that daily reporting, proper case management, and effective community mobilisation campaigns take place. A 3-month action plan has been prepared to deal with this outbreak.\n\nThe UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its weekly bulletin that the Health Ministry -with WHO support- sent an investigation team to the locality mid-September. The team collected 13 samples that were sent to the National Public Health laboratory for analysis, 4 of which tested positive for [the pertussis bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_].\n\nDoctors Without Borders/M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res-Spain (MSF-E) initiated case management and a community awareness-raising exercise has been conducted. Preparations are underway to conduct a vaccination campaign for children under 5 in the locality.\n\nPertussis can be prevented by immunization and is part of Sudan's national immunization program.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED reported on pertussis outbreaks in the same area in 2013 and 2015.\n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality of pertussis is in infants, especially those under 6 months of age where most of the mortality occurs in the developed world. The percent of people in North Sudan who are adequately immunized against pertussis is unclear.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with hypoxia-induced (low oxygen) seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED reported on pertussis outbreaks in the same area in 2013 and 2015. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod. \n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality of pertussis is in infants, especially those under 6 months of age where most of the mortality occurs in the developed world. The team collected 13 samples that were sent to the National Public Health laboratory for analysis, 4 of which tested positive for [the pertussis bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_]. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. The North Darfur Ministry of Health has reported that the outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality started in early September [2016]. \n\nThe UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its weekly bulletin that the Health Ministry -with WHO support- sent an investigation team to the locality mid-September.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-10-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4477542", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - UK: risk to infants", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4477542", "date": "2016-09-11 17:06:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - UK: RISK TO INFANTS\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Sep 2016\nSource: Gloucestershire Live [edited]\nhttp://www.gloucestershirelive.co.uk/it-s-a-real-threat-8203-whooping-cough-warning-to-pregnant-women-after-spike-in-cases/story-29693958-detail/story.html\n\n\nCases of highly infectious whooping cough [pertussis] have increased by 25 percent across the south region, posing a serious risk to babies and young infants. Yet despite the rise, thousands of women are still not being vaccinated, with 40 percent of pregnant women not taking the protection it offers to their newborn child. A regional campaign has been launched to raise awareness of the risks and promote uptake of the vaccine among pregnant women.\n\nWhooping cough \u00ad- known medically as pertussis -- is an infection which can create serious breathing difficulties, particularly in babies and young children. It can lead to major health complications such as brain damage and pneumonia and can be fatal. In the south region, there were 1141 cases of whooping cough in 2014, increasing by over 25 percent to 1432 in 2015. In 2012, 14 babies died in England and Wales following a whooping cough infection. Newborn and young babies are particularly vulnerable, but a highly effective vaccine is routinely available to pregnant women, who then pass the immunity to their unborn child, protecting the baby from birth until they are old enough to receive their childhood immunizations starting at around 2 months old [2 months in the USA - Mod.LL]. The vaccine is given at a GP practice or in maternity units at the point of the fetal abnormality scan, from 20 weeks of pregnancy. Ideally, it should be given before 32 weeks, but it can still be given right up to the point of labor, but with reduced effectiveness.\n\nThe national average coverage of eligible pregnant women is around 60%. But in the south, there is significant variation, as low as just 43% in Slough CCG area, highlighting areas where many women are not receiving the protection offered by the vaccine. During the winter influenza season, pregnant women should also receive the flu vaccination, which can be given at the same time as whooping cough.\n\nDr Nigel Acheson, Regional Medical Director, said: 'People often think of whooping cough as an illness from days gone by, but it is a real threat to babies and young children right now and can lead to pneumonia, brain damage and even death. The number of infections increased by 25 percent across the south region in 2015, but despite the risk, on average just 60% of women receive the vaccination, meaning many are putting their baby at risk. As we are also approaching the winter influenza season, I also urge pregnant women to receive their free influenza vaccination, which they can have at the same time as whooping cough. This way, they will protect themselves and their baby from both potentially fatal illnesses.'\n\n[Byline: Phil Norris]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures, usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Newborn and young babies are particularly vulnerable, but a highly effective vaccine is routinely available to pregnant women, who then pass the immunity to their unborn child, protecting the baby from birth until they are old enough to receive their childhood immunizations starting at around 2 months old Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. \n\n\nCases of highly infectious whooping cough [pertussis] have increased by 25 percent across the south region, posing a serious risk to babies and young infants. For the most recent data on pertussis in California, see the 27 Jun 2016 report at http://www.cdph.ca.gov/programs/immunize/pages/pertussissummaryreports.aspx.\n\n--\nKathleen Harriman, PhD, MPH, RN\nChief, Vaccine Preventable Diseases Epidemiology Section\nImmunization Branch\nCalifornia Department of Public Health\nRichmond, California 94804\nUSA\n<kathleen.harriman@cdph.ca.gov>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Harriman for alerting us to this mistake and regrets the error. The original posting has been corrected.\n\nThe following is extracted from the most recent report from the California Department of Public Health (27 Jun 2016) (http://www.cdph.ca.gov/programs/immunize/pages/pertussissummaryreports.aspx):\n\n608 cases with onset in 2016 were reported to CDPH for a state rate of 1.6 cases per 100 000 population. Due to reporting delays, the number of cases occurring January through June 2016 is expected to increase.\n- One death has been reported in an infant that was younger than 3 months of age at the time of disease onset.\n\n4705 cases with onset in 2015 were reported to CDPH for a state rate of 12.3 cases per 100 000 population.\n- 271 cases were hospitalized; 70 (26 percent) of these required intensive care\n- 179 (66 percent) of hospitalized patients were infants younger than 4 months of age.\n- Two deaths were reported: one was an infant that was younger than 3 weeks of age at the time of disease onset and one was an elderly woman who died of complications from many underlying health problems and for whom pertussis may have been a contributing cause.\n- Overall pertussis rates were highest for infants younger than 1 year of age and older children and adolescents and teens 14-17 years of age. Rates by race/ethnicity are highest for White and Hispanic infants younger than 6 months of age and White, non-Hispanic adolescents and teens aged 10-17 years of age.\n\n11 203 cases with onset in 2014 were reported to CDPH for a state rate of 29.3 cases per 100 000 population. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[re: ProMED-mail Pertussis - USA (04): (CA) increasing incidence 20160629.4315517]\n \n- 271 cases were hospitalized; 70 (26 percent) of these required intensive care\n- 179 (66 percent) of hospitalized patients were infants younger than 4 months of age. In just the last 2 weeks, over 800 cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, have been reported in the state. Already, almost 3500 cases have been reported this year [2016], which is more than all the cases in 2013.\n\nWhile the number of cases is alarming, officials have said that the sickness spikes every 3 to 5 years, and the last time it spiked was in 2010. That makes it very possible that the sickness is spiking this year [2016], which would result in such a large number of reported cases.\n\nWhooping cough is extremely contagious and is spread through the air. Infants and young children are most likely to get it, as adults have been vaccinated for the disease. However, even adults who have gotten vaccinated may still get the disease. 'Unlike some other vaccine-preventable diseases like measles, neither vaccination nor illness from pertussis offers lifetime immunity,' Dr Ron Chapman, director of the California Department of Public Health, said in a statement. 'However, vaccination is still the best defense against the potentially fatal diseases.'\n\nWhooping cough has a number of symptoms. The disease begins with mild symptoms, such as coughing, having a runny nose, sneezing, and other symptoms usually attributed to the common cold. After a week or 2, the symptoms can become worse, and may include a shortness of breath, vomiting, severe coughing attacks, and more. Although some of the symptoms are bad, the disease does not generally lead to death. If a patient does catch whooping cough, he or she is usually treated with antibiotics. The total length of the illness is about 6-8 weeks, although some of the worst symptoms will fade away before then.\n\n[Byline: Clinton Hesler]\n\n--\nCommunicate by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of pertussis, please see my colleague moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below.\n\nThe state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at < http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204>. A county map can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/california/california-county-map.html. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicate by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of pertussis, please see my colleague moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below. PERTUSSIS - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA) INCREASING INCIDENCE\n*******************************************************\n \n\nWhile the number of cases is alarming, officials have said that the sickness spikes every 3 to 5 years, and the last time it spiked was in 2010. The disease begins with mild symptoms, such as coughing, having a runny nose, sneezing, and other symptoms usually attributed to the common cold. In just the last 2 weeks, over 800 cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, have been reported in the state. \n\nWhooping cough has a number of symptoms. That makes it very possible that the sickness is spiking this year [2016], which would result in such a large number of reported cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4184540", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4184540", "date": "2016-04-26 12:35:36", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 April 2016\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/national/health/78861982/More-than-20-per-cent-of-whooping-cough-cases-in-Waikato\n\n\nMore than 20 per cent of whooping cough (pertussis) cases are occurring in the Waikato region, prompting doctors to urge parents to vaccinate their children against the preventable disease. New figures also show cases have doubled compared with this time in 2015, with specialists saying the country is due for another whooping cough outbreak.\n\nStarship Hospital paediatric specialists Dr Fiona Miles and Dr Anusha Ganeshalingham said outbreaks happen every 2 to 5 years. New Zealand's last outbreak of the disease was in 2011-2013. Ganeshalingham said the previous epidemic was the most serious recorded in the 25 year history of the Paediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU) at Starship Hospital. 'That outbreak was the worst our unit had seen since our unit was established in 1991. We had the same number of ICU admissions in that 2 year period as we had for the entire decade before that, and certainly the death rate was the worst it's ever been. We had 3 infant deaths, 2 were in our unit, and one was a little baby in another city, who was too sick for us to even retrieve.'\n\nThe call for vaccinations is being heard across the spectrum, with Waikato District Health Board staff leading the way with flu vaccines. Board chair Bob Simcock said prevention is the only way to go. 'It's really important to me to stay healthy and get through the winter as well as I can because of the roles I have to play,' Simcock said.\n\n[byline: Donna-Lee Biddle]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the significant morbidity and mortality from pertussis is in infants less than 12 months of age, especially less than 6 months of age. Protecting this cohort is done by immunization of the mother in her last trimester and immunizing those who will be around the infant.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 per cent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the commonest manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al. Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18):1897-904. Available at http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Donna-Lee Biddle]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the significant morbidity and mortality from pertussis is in infants less than 12 months of age, especially less than 6 months of age. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. \n\n\nMore than 20 per cent of whooping cough (pertussis) cases are occurring in the Waikato region, prompting doctors to urge parents to vaccinate their children against the preventable disease. \n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 per cent risk of death. \n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al. \n\nStarship Hospital paediatric specialists Dr Fiona Miles and Dr Anusha Ganeshalingham said outbreaks happen every 2 to 5 years. New figures also show cases have doubled compared with this time in 2015, with specialists saying the country is due for another whooping cough outbreak.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-04-19 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4202149", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (03): (CA) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4202149", "date": "2016-05-04 21:05:24", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (03): (CALIFORNIA) FATAL\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 May 2016\nSource: 23ABC News [edited]\nhttp://www.turnto23.com/news/local-news/kern-has-first-confirmed-whooping-cough-death-in-2016\n\n\nPertussis, better known as whooping cough, has claimed the life of a Kern County [California] infant less than 6 months of age, the Kern County Department of Public Health announced today [3 May 2016]. It is the 1st confirmed death from the disease in Kern County since 2009. 'This baby's death is a tragedy for the family and for our community,' said Matt Constantine, Director of Kern County Public Health Services Department.\n\nPertussis is cyclical with peaks in incidence every 3 to 5 years. In 2010, California experienced a pertussis epidemic with more than 9100 cases, including 376 in Kern County. Another epidemic with more than 11 000 cases in California and 166 cases in Kern County was seen in 2014. Last year [2015], there were 145 cases of pertussis reported in Kern County; 90 percent of those cases were children less than 18 years of age. Of the pediatric cases, 14 percent were in infants who were less than 6 months of age.\n\n'Immunizations are the 1st line of defense, especially to protect those who are not yet old enough to be vaccinated,' said Dr Claudia Jonah, Public Health Officer for Kern County Public Health Services Department. 'We strongly encourage pregnant women to get vaccinated as well as all those who will be in the household of children who are less than 12 months of age. Adults should keep current with their booster shots to reduce the spread of the disease, and all parents should vaccinate their children on time.'\n\nThe Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommends that all pregnant women receive a tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine during each pregnancy. While Tdap can be administered at any time during pregnancy, optimal timing is during the 3rd trimester, between 27 and 36 weeks.\n\nFor infants, pertussis vaccinations typically start at 2 months of age, but adequate protection doesn't occur until about 6 months of age. It is important that both children and adults are up-to-date on their immunizations. Booster shots for pertussis are critical because, unlike some other vaccine-preventable diseases, neither the pertussis disease nor vaccine confers lifelong immunity.\n\n'You know this is a situation where it's not like the parents didn't vaccinate their child. The child is too young to be vaccinated and so it's extremely important for all of the rest of us to be vaccinated so that we don't pass on infection to people who can't get their own,' said Dr Jonah.\n\nTo reduce the spread of pertussis, the California Department of Public Health recommends that:\n- Pregnant women receive a pertussis vaccine booster during 3rd third trimester of each pregnancy, even if they received it before.\n- Infants be vaccinated against pertussis as soon as possible. The 1st dose is recommended at 2 months of age. Young children need 5 doses of pertussis vaccine by kindergarten (ages 4-6 years).\n- California 7th grade students receive the pertussis vaccine booster as required.\n- Adults receive a pertussis vaccine booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers who may have contact with infants or pregnant women.\n\nThe symptoms of pertussis vary by age. For children, a typical case of pertussis starts with a cough and runny nose for one to 2 weeks. The cough then worsens and children may have rapid coughing spells that end with a whooping sound. Young infants may not have typical pertussis symptoms and may have no apparent cough. Parents may describe episodes in which the infant's face turns red or purple. For adults, pertussis may simply be a cough illness that persists for several weeks. Pertussis can be treated with antibiotics. If you think you may have pertussis, see your healthcare provider right away. Vaccinations are offered at Kern County Public Health Services as well as other locations throughout the county. For more information call 661-321-3000.\n\n[Byline: Alexis Lewis, Jessica Harrington]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of pertussis, please see my colleague moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below.\n\nThe state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8743. A county map can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/california/california-county-map.html. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n To reduce the spread of pertussis, the California Department of Public Health recommends that:\n- Pregnant women receive a pertussis vaccine booster during 3rd third trimester of each pregnancy, even if they received it before. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of pertussis, please see my colleague moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below. \n- Adults receive a pertussis vaccine booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers who may have contact with infants or pregnant women. Booster shots for pertussis are critical because, unlike some other vaccine-preventable diseases, neither the pertussis disease nor vaccine confers lifelong immunity. For infants, pertussis vaccinations typically start at 2 months of age, but adequate protection doesn't occur until about 6 months of age. \n\n\nPertussis, better known as whooping cough, has claimed the life of a Kern County [California] infant less than 6 months of age, the Kern County Department of Public Health announced today [3 May 2016]. Last year [2015], there were 145 cases of pertussis reported in Kern County; 90 percent of those cases were children less than 18 years of age. \n\nThe Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommends that all pregnant women receive a tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine during each pregnancy. \n- California 7th grade students receive the pertussis vaccine booster as required. [The city of Rochester, Minnesota is the Olmsted County seat and home to Mayo Medical School and the Mayo Clinic.]\n\nThe new recent cases bring Olmsted County's 2016 total to 173, which is by far the most in Minnesota and the highest local level since the 2012 outbreak. Hennepin County [where Minneapolis is located] had the 2nd highest annual total in the state with 62, according to the [30 Jun 2016] report from Minnesota Department of Health; a new state report is expected to be released next week.\n\nWhile more than half of the state has reported zero pertussis cases, Olmsted County has nearly matched Hennepin's total for 3 straight months, including 52 in May, 46 in June and 58 so far in July [2016].\n\n'Pertussis spreads through the air when a person who is contagious with pertussis coughs or sneezes and exposes others close[by],' said Pete Giesen, director of Olmsted County Public Health. 'Although the cough can last more than 100 days, a person is no longer spreading it after the 3rd week or after 5 days of taking antibiotics, which is why it is so important to follow the guidance to prevent further transmission.'\n\nThe local health department says that the pertussis outbreak continues to impact day cares, youth camps and sporting groups. After just 7 cases were counted between [11-17 Jul 2016], that number nearly tripled to dash hopes that the outbreak was subsiding.\n\nPertussis, which is also called whooping cough, mimics the common cold for about a week before symptoms worsen. Coughing often comes in uncontrollable fits that can cause vomiting and is often marked by a whooping-like noise. It's highly contagious and most commonly found in teenagers, but it's considered especially dangerous for infants and the elderly.\n\n[Byline: Brett Boese]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Oklahoma\nDate: Thu 28 Jul 2016\nSource: Tulsa World [edited]\nhttp://www.tulsaworld.com/news/health/oklahoma-sees-increase-in-whooping-cough-as-vaccination-rate-declines/article_1bc1e9cb-4099-56b3-a1db-035c1e609f1b.html\n\n\nOklahoma sees increase in whooping cough as vaccination rate declines. State health officials cite waning immunity and decisions to opt out of vaccinations.\n\nOklahoma has seen an increase this year [2016] in the occurrence of pertussis, or whooping cough, a highly contagious respiratory disease that can cause serious illness in children and adults. Since [1 Jan 2016], Oklahoma has seen 70 confirmed cases of pertussis, compared to 86 confirmed cases for all of 2015, according to the state Health Department. 'We don't know how the rest of the year is going to play out, and if we might end up with the same number of cases, but certainly going through the halfway point of the year so far, we have noted that we have seen more cases this year,' said Laurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist at the Oklahoma Department of Health.\n\nThe agency's investigations of recent cases have identified several case clusters across Oklahoma among household members and contacts within close-knit community groups, such as day cares and schools, Burnsed said.\n\n[Byline: Jaclyn Cosgrove]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks tend to occur in roughly 3- to 5-year cycles. We don't know how the rest of the year is going to play out, and if we might end up with the same number of cases, but certainly going through the halfway point of the year so far, we have noted that we have seen more cases this year,' said Laurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist at the Oklahoma Department of Health. USA (05): (MINNESOTA, OKLAHOMA) INCREASING INCIDENCE\n****************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-11-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2046-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-23 00:00:00", "2016-01-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MINNESOTA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hennepin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "olmste County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Olmsted County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rochester", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minneapolis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4495935", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4495935", "date": "2016-09-17 18:34:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Wisconsin (Jefferson County)\n[2] Virginia (Lynchburg)\n[3] New Jersey (Morris County)\n\n******\n[1] Wisconsin (Jefferson County)\nDate: Fri 16 Sep 2016\nSource: Channel 3000 [edited]\nhttp://www.channel3000.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-jefferson-county/41697284\n\n\nWhooping cough cases reported in Jefferson County [Wisconsin]\n-------------------------------------------------------------\n15 confirmed cases of whooping cough and 7 suspected cases have been found in Jefferson County in recent months, according to a news release from the Jefferson County Health Department. Health officials said the cases have been tracked since 1 May 2016, and they expect many other people might have been exposed.\n\n'At most, we had 37 contacts who were followed after contact, with one confirmed case. Another case had 14 contacts,' said Gail Scott, director of the health department. 'Usually, there are at least 3 to 5 contacts who need notification and possible treatment or isolation. It is never just the one confirmed patient who is affected by this illness.'\n\nHealth officials said vaccination is the best defense against whooping cough. Pertussis is a contagious bacterial disease affecting the respiratory tract and is spread by coughing and often through repeated face-to-face contact.\n\nAnyone with symptoms is asked to contact their healthcare provider about antimicrobial treatment that can shorten the time when they are contagious. Anyone with pertussis should be isolated from school, work or other activities until completing at least the 1st 5 days of the recommended antimicrobial therapy.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Lynchburg)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: News Advance [edited]\nhttp://www.newsadvance.com/news/local/update-whooping-cough-confirmed-at-e-c-glass-in-lynchburg/article_ff1796dc-7b5d-11e6-9497-a77239f4db3c.html\n\n\nA case of whooping cough has been confirmed at E.C. Glass High School\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nLynchburg City Schools [Virginia] circulated a letter to parents, guardians and staff on Monday, 12 Sep 2016, to confirm the diagnosis and provide details on the symptoms and treatment of whooping cough. Known clinically as pertussis, whooping cough is a common, vaccine-preventable disease.\n\nHaley Evans, epidemiologist for the Central Virginia Health District, said whooping cough is a persistent respiratory infection and can be contracted by those who are vaccinated against the illness. 'No vaccine is perfect; vaccinated people can still come down with pertussis,' Evans said. They typically will experience milder symptoms, she said, but still are contagious.\n\nPertussis has a debilitating effect, according to Evans. 'Anyone diagnosed with pertussis would be excluded from school, work, or daycare, until they have completed 5 days of antibiotics therapy,' she said. 'Anyone with a cough that has lasted more than 2 weeks, we would recommend that they see their primary care physician,' Evans said. 'People with pertussis will continue to cough for many weeks after they have been appropriately treated. They are no longer contagious, but we just can't stop the cough; the cough kind of has to run its course,' she explained. Evans added that unvaccinated children and adults are at the highest risk for pertussis, which she described as highly contagious.\n\nIn 2015, there were 334 reported cases of whooping cough in Virginia, according to the CDC 2015 Provisional Pertussis Surveillance Report, released in January 2016.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New Jersey (Morris County)\nDate: Tue 13 Sep 2016\nSource: NJ.com [edited]\nhttp://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2016/09/case_of_whooping_cough_confirmed_at_chatham_high_s.html\n\n\nA high school student was treated over the summer for a case of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, the district said in a notice to parents on Monday, 12 Sep 2016. The Madison Health Department informed the district on Monday, 12 Sep 2016, the student had tested positive for the disease and has since been treated, superintendent Michael LaSusa said Tuesday morning [13 Sep 2016]. The student, he said, has been in school since the beginning of the year.\n\n'No other student has been diagnosed and we are hopeful that this will be the only case,' LaSusa said, adding a notice was sent to parents 'in an effort to be forthcoming and transparent in the event another child develops symptoms.'\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the best way to protect against the disease is by vaccination. According to the state health department, about 9500 New Jersey school children skipped receiving vaccines for the 2015-16 school year. Under state law, children are permitted to opt out of receiving vaccinations for religious reasons.\n\n[byline: Justin Zaremba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The evolution of new clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which are less prevented by the current acellular vaccine, and the presence of an underimmunized cohort of individuals may play a role in the number of cases described here. It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _B. pertussis_ that can infect infants less than 1 year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, who are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting this susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 per cent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis was associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least 1 dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all-acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al. Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al. Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis. 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Justin Zaremba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< As compared to those who received at least 1 dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all-acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _B. pertussis_ that can infect infants less than 1 year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, who are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis was associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study. Source: Channel 3000 [edited]\nhttp://www.channel3000.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-jefferson-county/41697284\n\n\nWhooping cough cases reported in Jefferson County [Wisconsin]\n Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2016/09/case_of_whooping_cough_confirmed_at_chatham_high_s.html\n\n\nA high school student was treated over the summer for a case of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, the district said in a notice to parents on Monday, 12 Sep 2016. PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\n -------------------------------------------------------------\n15 confirmed cases of whooping cough and 7 suspected cases have been found in Jefferson County in recent months, according to a news release from the Jefferson County Health Department. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The evolution of new clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which are less prevented by the current acellular vaccine, and the presence of an underimmunized cohort of individuals may play a role in the number of cases described here. \nLynchburg City Schools [Virginia] circulated a letter to parents, guardians and staff on Monday, 12 Sep 2016, to confirm the diagnosis and provide details on the symptoms and treatment of whooping cough. In Oregon, a child was 30 per cent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. \n\n\nA case of whooping cough has been confirmed at E.C. Glass High School\n--------------------------------------------------------------------- In Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. During the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. In 2015, there were 334 reported cases of whooping cough in Virginia, according to the CDC 2015 Provisional Pertussis Surveillance Report, released in January 2016. \n\nHaley Evans, epidemiologist for the Central Virginia Health District, said whooping cough is a persistent respiratory infection and can be contracted by those who are vaccinated against the illness. ' \n\nHealth officials said vaccination is the best defense against whooping cough. [3] New Jersey (Morris County)\n\n******\n \n\n'No other student has been diagnosed and we are hopeful that this will be the only case,' LaSusa said, adding a notice was sent to parents 'in an effort to be forthcoming and transparent in the event another child develops symptoms.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-05-01 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-12 00:00:00", "2016-09-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2016-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Morris County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4135723", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (02): (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4135723", "date": "2016-04-03 18:45:14", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02): (NEW YORK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Apr 2016\nSource: WAMC [edited]\nhttp://wamc.org/post/winter-brought-high-number-pertussis-cases-dutchess#stream/0\n\n\nThe Dutchess County Department of Behavioral & Community Health in mid-February [20176] reported an increase in cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, particularly among adolescents, with more than 20 cases since [1 Jan 2016]. As Dutchess County's Director of Communicable Disease Control Linda Squires says, the number then continued to rise.\n\n'From between [1 Jan 2016] through the current date, we've had a total of 47 confirmed cases of pertussis but, fortunately, we are seeing a decline in the past 2 weeks, with only 5 cases reported since [15 Mar 2016],' says Squires. While the numbers of new cases have waned in the past few weeks, health experts say the recurrence of the disease, in general, is puzzling, and urge vaccination.\n\nAccording to the New York State Department of Health, pertussis is a serious lung infection caused by bacteria. It is also very contagious and causes coughing fits. 'Well, pertussis incidents sort of wax and wane over time and we do see clusters that are not really explainable,' says Squires. 'In 2011 we had 100 cases reported, but between 2012 and 2014 we've probably stayed under 20-30 cases each of those years, so it's variable.'\n\nDr Stuart Feinstein is an infectious disease specialist at Vassar Brothers Medical Center in Poughkeepsie and with Health Quest Medical Practice. 'It's just not something that seems to go away. It seems like every time they get it snuffed out, it's popping up somewhere,' says Dr Feinstein. 'It's been unusual.'\n\nSquires underscores the importance of vaccinating against pertussis. 'Vaccinations are extremely important in reducing the risk and the severity of pertussis,' says Squires. 'The recommendations begin at 2 months of age. And now there's Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccine, which is a booster for adolescents and adults, and is particularly recommended for those persons who are going to be around infants younger than 2 months, so that you could almost cocoon them against pertussis because they cannot be vaccinated themselves.'\n\nDr Feinstein agrees and says the fluctuation in annual cases defies easy explanation. 'I think it's very hard to say why the fluctuation in cases occurs. I know there is certainly an effort, a successful effort, to vaccinate, re-vaccinate adults, to give the Tdap vaccine, and to keep the children on tabs,' Dr Feinstein says. 'It's something that's never been totally wiped out. I think in the last 10 years, there's been waves of it back and forth.'\n\nMeanwhile, Squires says her department a few weeks ago sent an advisory to area health care providers to be on alert for screening and treatment of pertussis. She says the cases in Dutchess County were reported as far south as Beacon and as far north as the Rhinebeck/Red Hook area. Other whooping cough cases since the new year [2016] were seen in Orange and Sullivan Counties.\n\n[Byline: Allison Dunne]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of pertussis, please see my colleague moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below.\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1181. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif.\nDutchess, Orange, and Sullivan Counties are located in the mid-Hudson Region of the Hudson Valley and, with the Lower Hudson Region, is considered part of the Downstate New York region due to its geographical and cultural proximity to New York City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_Valley). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "From between [1 Jan 2016] through the current date, we've had a total of 47 confirmed cases of pertussis but, fortunately, we are seeing a decline in the past 2 weeks, with only 5 cases reported since [15 Mar 2016],' says Squires. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nThe Dutchess County Department of Behavioral & Community Health in mid-February [20176] reported an increase in cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, particularly among adolescents, with more than 20 cases since [1 Jan 2016]. And now there's Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccine, which is a booster for adolescents and adults, and is particularly recommended for those persons who are going to be around infants younger than 2 months, so that you could almost cocoon them against pertussis because they cannot be vaccinated themselves.' PERTUSSIS - USA (02): (NEW YORK)\n********************************\n \n\nDr Feinstein agrees and says the fluctuation in annual cases defies easy explanation. ' In 2011 we had 100 cases reported, but between 2012 and 2014 we've probably stayed under 20-30 cases each of those years, so it's variable.' She says the cases in Dutchess County were reported as far south as Beacon and as far north as the Rhinebeck/Red Hook area. While the numbers of new cases have waned in the past few weeks, health experts say the recurrence of the disease, in general, is puzzling, and urge vaccination. It was gathered that Maizare village where the 6 deaths occurred was the worst hit among the 6 villages affected by the outbreak of the 2 child killer diseases. Speaking to Daily Trust on phone, the Suletankarkar LGA Head of Department for Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), Mohammed Maisamari, confirmed the outbreak of the 2 diseases.\n\nHe said, 'Maizare is the only village amongst the villages that recorded the death of 6 children. So far 249 under-5 children have been treated as a result of contracting measles or whooping cough (pertussis) in 6 of the affected villages. In Maizare, 139 children have been treated, in Lula 24, in Dadin Duniya 26, Mallam Kadir 10, in Suletankarkar and Fulanin Danladi 25 children have been treated in each of the villages.'\n\nAmong other measures taken against the outbreak, which he said had since been brought under control, was to further educate the rural dwellers on the need for routine immunizations.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that much of the illnesses and deaths are related to measles, rather than pertussis, but this is not entirely clear.\n\nThe outbreak has been confirmed from EpiCore members communicating outside of the platform. Exact wording: 'Outbreak confirmed, and still ongoing. Measles outbreak also in Yobe, Jakuska LGA, over 100 cases.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2594.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: AllAfrica, Daily Trust report [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201603140413.html\n\n\nSix under-5 year old children have died following an outbreak of measles and whooping cough in Suletankarkar Local Government Area of Jigawa state [Nigeria], Daily Trust learned yesterday, 13 Mar 2016. So far 249 under-5 children have been treated as a result of contracting measles or whooping cough (pertussis) in 6 of the affected villages.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maizare", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4097729", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (03): (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4097729", "date": "2016-03-16 16:02:16", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sun 13 Mar 2016\nSource: Daily Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/inner-west/more-than-150-cases-of-whooping-cough-reported-in-sydney-by-march-2016/news-story/ab589bc9cb84b80e2e47430daa542144\n\n\nThere have already been more than 150 cases of whooping cough reported in Sydney in 2016, and the bulk of these have come from suburbs in the inner west.\n\nThe Director of Public Health from Sydney Local Health District, Dr Leena Gupta, said that so far in 2016, the local government areas with the highest number of incidences have been Canterbury (35), Marrickville (26), Ashfield (23) and Leichhardt (22).\n\nPrimary school students are the most likely to be affected by whooping cough (also known as pertussis), but anyone can contract it, and it can be life-threatening for infants (aged 6 months and under).\n\nWhooping cough usually begins like a cold with a blocked or runny nose, tiredness, mild fever and a cough. The cough gets worse, and severe bouts of uncontrollable coughing can develop. Coughing bouts can be followed by vomiting, choking or taking a big gasping breath which causes a whooping sound.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Herbertson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 Mar 2016\nSource: Daily Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/whooping-cough-rise-booster-at-18-months-to-help-repel-rise-of-potential-killer/news-story/1b4da2e47a0392d51266d860889a50fa\n\n\nThe NSW Vaccine Centre has begun sending the vaccine to doctors, and all children born after 1 Oct 2014 will be required to have an 18 month booster for pertussis from April 2016, on top of jabs at 2, 4 and 6 months.\n\nThere have been 2369 cases of whooping cough -- known medically as pertussis -- so far in 2016, compared with 1036 during the same period in 2015.\n\nThe extra vaccination has been added to the national immunization schedule because immunity wanes between the 1st trio of vaccinations and the next at 4 years old. There has been an increase in the number of 2-9-year-olds catching the disease. Most immunized children in that age group do not develop severe cases, but they can transmit the disease to babies with no or little immunity.\n\nAlmost all whooping cough deaths occur in babies too young to have received more than adequate doses of the vaccine, according to the federal government.\n\n'Parents are advised to ring the (medical) practice in advance to ensure that the vaccines have arrived,' NSW Health said. Meanwhile, there has been a shortage of the vaccine available for non-essential recipients, such as carers and grandparents. 'In regards to supplies for other groups, NSW Health has been advised by vaccine manufacturers that a small amount of whooping cough vaccine has been released into the private market, and the situation with regard to the overall private supply should improve within the next few months,' NSW Health said.\n\nVaccination rates are improving since a Sunday Telegraph campaign prompted the federal government to stop parents who refuse vaccinations claiming tax subsidies for childcare or family benefits.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Baker & Keely McDonough]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up and down nature of pertussis over years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up and down nature of pertussis over years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nThere have been 2369 cases of whooping cough -- known medically as pertussis -- so far in 2016, compared with 1036 during the same period in 2015. \n\nPrimary school students are the most likely to be affected by whooping cough (also known as pertussis), but anyone can contract it, and it can be life-threatening for infants (aged 6 months and under). In regards to supplies for other groups, NSW Health has been advised by vaccine manufacturers that a small amount of whooping cough vaccine has been released into the private market, and the situation with regard to the overall private supply should improve within the next few months,' NSW Health said. Canada: (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3930921", "date": "2016-01-12 23:13:49", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA: (ONTARIO)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 11 Jan 2016\nSource: Net News Ledger [edited]\nhttp://www.netnewsledger.com/2016/01/11/whooping-cough-reported-in-thunder-bay-district-health-unit/\n\n\nWith an increase in whooping cough (pertussis) cases reported in the city and district over the last 4 months, the Health Unit is urging that individuals ensure they are up to date with their immunization against this disease, particularly those individuals who are or will be around newborns and infants less than 6 months of age.\n\nThe Health Unit is aware of 10 cases of whooping cough that have been identified through laboratory testing, with additional cases in close household contacts. Five people have been hospitalized, 4 of whom were under 6 months of age. Although this is not considered an outbreak for our district, outbreaks have been reported in other areas of the country over the same time.\n\nNewborns and infants less than 6 months of age are particularly vulnerable to pertussis. They are more likely than any other age group to have serious disease and are more likely to require hospitalization. In rare cases, pertussis can result in death. Newborns and infants are also not yet protected by vaccination, as the infant series of immunizations occurs over the 1st 18 months of life.\n\nPregnant women can receive the vaccine after 26 weeks of pregnancy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis occurs in infants less than 6 months of age, especially neonates. Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension, are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis occurs in infants less than 6 months of age, especially neonates. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension, are ominous signs for mortality.
