Information provided by Hunter New England Health [local health district] shows there have been 271 cases of whooping cough, recorded in the region so far in 2016. There were 112 cases at the same time in 2015, and 50 at the start of March 2014.\n\nThe Newcastle Herald reported in February 2016 that supplies of the whooping cough booster had dried up in the middle of Hunter's worst outbreak of the disease in 5 years. Tim Llewellyn, pharmacist-in-charge at Kotara's Scott-Dibben Chemist, said they had received a shipment of the vaccine on [Mon 29 Feb 2016], but that supply had already been exhausted by [Thu 3 Mar 2016].\n\n'We received 20 of them, which was our back order from September 2015, and all of them have gone,' he said. 'We had quite a few names that we'd put down for them -- I know other pharmacies have been doing the same -- and every single last one has gone.' Mr Llewellyn said the shortage had caused some family friction, as many concerned parents were refusing to let anyone who had not had the booster visit their new babies.\n\n[Byline: Anita Beaumont]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen), usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis (particularly with white blood cell counts of 30 000 to 100 000) and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality.\n\nIn a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and represented a large proportion of infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nMaps of Australia can be seen at http://www.talenttraining.com.au/wp-content/uploads/image/Maps/Australia-Wine-Map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50247. The Hunter Region, also commonly known as the Hunter Valley, is a region of New South Wales, Australia. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and represented a large proportion of infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. VACCINE SHORTAGE\n**************************************************************\n Tim Llewellyn, pharmacist-in-charge at Kotara's Scott-Dibben Chemist, said they had received a shipment of the vaccine on [Mon 29 Feb 2016], but that supply had already been exhausted by [Thu 3 Mar 2016].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2050-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-02-29 00:00:00", "2015-09-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kotara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Hunter Region", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4018889", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Spain: (CM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4018889", "date": "2016-02-14 20:12:44", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SPAIN: (CASTILLA-LA MANCHA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 12 Feb 2016\nSource: 20 Minutos [in Spanish, trans. KS, edited]\nhttp://www.20minutos.es/noticia/2671733/0/sanidad-confirma-brote-familiar-tosferina-guadalajara-con-bebe-ingresado-hospital-madrid/\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health of Castilla-La Mancha, through the Director-General of Public Health, has confirmed a family-based outbreak of pertussis in the province of Guadalajara.\n\nThis outbreak affected the parents and 2 children. The parents are of Moroccan origin and unknown vaccination status. The son is 7 years old, born in Spain, and has had 5 doses of the pertussis vaccine. These 3 have not required hospitalization, the Ministry reported in a press release; however, a 3-week-old infant remains hospitalized and was transferred to the Infant Jesus Hospital in Madrid. Once there, he was taken to the '12 of October' Hospital, where he remains in the Intensive Care Unit.\n\nThe Ministry of Health stated that the known cases of pertussis in Castilla-La Mancha 'are not different from those registered in other years.' While in Spain, there is an incidence of 15.6 cases per 100 000 inhabitants; 'the incidence in Castilla-La Mancha is 6.8 per 100 000 inhabitants,' announced the regional government. They further explained that cases of pertussis in infants under 3 months old can be most serious, because the vaccine is given during the 2nd month of life and takes about 15 days to create defenses.\n\nThe strategy adopted in Castilla-La Mancha is to vaccinate pregnant women against pertussis in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy, concentrating on weeks 28 to 36, preferably between weeks 28 and 32. This action has been carried out since 9 Nov 2015 by primary care professionals after being agreed upon by experts in the field. In the case of a pertussis diagnosis, a pediatrician or family doctor recommends treatment with antimicrobials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000, and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nCastilla-La Mancha is a southwestern European region that was part of the Kingdom of Castile. Nowadays, it is established as an autonomous community of Spain. It can be found on a map of Spain at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castilla-La_Mancha#/media/File:Castilla-La_Mancha_in_Spain_(plus_Canarias).svg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20116.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. \n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. \n\nThe strategy adopted in Castilla-La Mancha is to vaccinate pregnant women against pertussis in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy, concentrating on weeks 28 to 36, preferably between weeks 28 and 32. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000, and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. They further explained that cases of pertussis in infants under 3 months old can be most serious, because the vaccine is given during the 2nd month of life and takes about 15 days to create defenses. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. \n\nThe Ministry of Health stated that the known cases of pertussis in Castilla-La Mancha 'are not different from those registered in other years.' While in Spain, there is an incidence of 15.6 cases per 100 000 inhabitants; 'the incidence in Castilla-La Mancha is 6.8 per 100 000 inhabitants,' announced the regional government. These 3 have not required hospitalization, the Ministry reported in a press release; however, a 3-week-old infant remains hospitalized and was transferred to the Infant Jesus Hospital in Madrid. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The son is 7 years old, born in Spain, and has had 5 doses of the pertussis vaccine. PERTUSSIS - SPAIN: (CASTILLA-LA MANCHA)\n \n\n--\n In the case of a pertussis diagnosis, a pediatrician or family doctor recommends treatment with antimicrobials. The Ministry of Health of Castilla-La Mancha, through the Director-General of Public Health, has confirmed a family-based outbreak of pertussis in the province of Guadalajara. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. \n\nThis outbreak affected the parents and 2 children. LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20116.] Date: Fri 12 Feb 2016\n KS, edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-11-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Kingdom of Castile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guadalajara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3926728", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia: (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3926728", "date": "2016-01-11 14:25:18", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA: (WESTERN AUSTRALIA)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 5 Jan 2016\nSource: Australian Broadcasting Corporation [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-05/wa-health-warns-whooping-cough-outbreak-imminent/7068350\n\n\nAn outbreak of the potentially deadly whooping cough (pertussis) disease may be imminent, West Australian health authorities have warned, as they urge pregnant women to get vaccinated. According to the WA Centre for Disease Control (CDC), the rate of weekly pertussis notifications steadily increased over 2015, which the department fears points to another outbreak being due.\n\nThe bacterial infection, which is passed on by sneezing and coughing, is always present in Western Australia but outbreaks occur in roughly 3- to 5-year cycles. There were 1784 cases in the state in 2015, up from 1753 in 2014. The last big spike in cases was in 2011, with 4005 recorded, up from 1446 in 2010.\n\nThe CDC has issued a warning that newborns will be particularly at risk, with more than 80 percent of deaths from the disease occurring in children less than 3 months of age.\n\nPregnant women are being urged to get vaccinated in their 3rd trimester, so antibodies can be transferred to the baby in utero to protect it in the first few months after birth. Babies cannot be fully vaccinated in the 1st few months.\n\nDr Paul Effler from the Department of Health's Communicable Disease Control Directorate said 80 percent of pertussis deaths occurred in infants under 3 months. 'What we want to do is get to the pregnant women, so they get vaccinated and they pass that protection to the baby in their body and when the child is born then they're protected when they are most vulnerable,' he said. 'We're not saying the sky is falling.\nWe're seeing increased whooping cough activity and we want to make sure parents are aware of it, so they can make sure their kids are protected and so that pregnant women get vaccinated to protect that baby when they're most vulnerable.'\n\nFollowing the death of a 1-month-old baby in March 2015 after contracting the disease, the Western Australian Government began offering free vaccinations to pregnant women. The death was the 1st since 2011, but in the 3 years before that, an infant died from the infection every year.\n\nAccording to the WA Department of Health, UK studies showed vaccinating women in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy can prevent more than 90 percent of infections among infants in the 1st few months of life.\n\n[Byline: Rebecca Trigger]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen), usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis (particularly with white blood cell counts of 30 000 to 100 000) and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality.\n\nIn a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and represented a large proportion of infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/289.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and represented a large proportion of infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. \n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. \n\nPregnant women are being urged to get vaccinated in their 3rd trimester, so antibodies can be transferred to the baby in utero to protect it in the first few months after birth. \n\nThe CDC has issued a warning that newborns will be particularly at risk, with more than 80 percent of deaths from the disease occurring in children less than 3 months of age. We're seeing increased whooping cough activity and we want to make sure parents are aware of it, so they can make sure their kids are protected and so that pregnant women get vaccinated to protect that baby when they're most vulnerable.' An outbreak of the potentially deadly whooping cough (pertussis) disease may be imminent, West Australian health authorities have warned, as they urge pregnant women to get vaccinated. Dr Paul Effler from the Department of Health's Communicable Disease Control Directorate said 80 percent of pertussis deaths occurred in infants under 3 months. ' According to the WA Department of Health, UK studies showed vaccinating women in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy can prevent more than 90 percent of infections among infants in the 1st few months of life.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1753-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-01-05 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1446-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1784-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3869310", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3869310", "date": "2015-12-17 11:01:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: Health Quality and Safety Commission New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/un-doctored/2015/december-2015/16/Immunisation-against-whooping-cough-crucial-in-pregnancy-new-report.aspx\n\n\nA new report discusses how rates of whooping cough can be reduced by immunizing women during pregnancy and improving education about the illness. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. 'All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,' says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n'GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.'\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]", "summary": "\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.' \n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week. The newborn died on 5 Dec 2015 in the intensive care unit of the center.\n\nThe Ministry of Health explained that the 1st dose of vaccine against whooping cough cannot be given until the baby is 2 months old and that infants under 4 months old are the most vulnerable group to the disease.\n\nThe baby's death happened the same day that the Ministry of Health started vaccinating women 36 weeks pregnant as well as those at more than 28 weeks at high risk.\n\nWhooping cough is a bacterial infection of the respiratory system caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, and its incidence has increased in recent years across the European region. Although vaccination does not guarantee 100 percent protection of vaccinated children, studies available to date support the strategy of vaccination against pertussis in pregnant women as the most effective measure to prevent disease in children under 3 months of age.\n\nExperts stressed the importance of vaccination in children aged 2, 4, 6 and 18 months old.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-12-05 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3843920", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (06): (SA, NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3843920", "date": "2015-12-06 15:00:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (06): (SOUTH AUSTRALIA, NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 1 Dec 2015\nSource: Adelaide Now [edited]\nhttp://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/vaccination-plea-whooping-cough-numbers-at-four-year-high-in-sa/story-fni6uo1m-1227630071228\n\n\nSouth Australia Health is urging parents to vaccinate their children against whooping cough as cases in South Australia reach a 4-year high.\n\nNew figures from SA Health reveal that the number of whooping cough cases are rising, up from a total of 505 cases in 2014 compared to 985 cases so far in 2015. In 2013, 820 people were reported to have whooping cough, and in 2012, 922 were struck with the disease. Numbers in SA peaked in 2010, when a whopping 7520 had the disease.\n\nWhooping cough is easily spread when an infected person talks, coughs or sneezes. SA Health public health physician and pediatrician Associate Professor Nicola Spurrier urged parents to vaccinate their children, who were most vulnerable to contracting the disease. 'There is a new booster vaccine recommended for pregnant women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy that provides protection for the mother and also for the baby when it is born.'\n\n[Byline: Katrina Stokes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 1 Dec 2015\nSource: The Daily Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/west/whooping-cough-outbreak-hits-mt-druitt-with-cases-up-450-per-cent-on-last-year/story-fngr8i5s-1227629543503\n\n\nParents are being warned to be on the lookout for symptoms of the potentially life-threatening whooping cough, as Blacktown Mt Druitt Hospital has recorded an increase of more than 450 per cent since this time in 2014.\n\nMore than 1200 cases of whooping cough were reported across western Sydney during 2015, with 200 cases reported in October 2015 alone. In 2014, only 400 cases were reported. This October 2015, more than 95 cases were reported in the Blacktown local government area, compared with just 21 cases in October 2014.\n\nWestern Sydney Local Health District Communicable diseases manager Dr Shopna Bag said cases of whooping cough had been consistently increasing. 'Western Sydney Local Health District has experienced a steady increase in pertussis (whooping cough) notifications since late 2014.'\n\nRegular immunization is recommended to prevent whooping cough, with all children receiving immunisation in high school; however, immunity fades over time, and booster shots are often needed for adults.\n\nDr Bag said the increase in cases in western Sydney could be put down to lack of immunization. 'Immunity [from] the whooping cough vaccination fades over time,' Dr Bag said. After 3 or 4 years, there are enough people in the community with low levels of immunity to allow an outbreak to occur.'\n\nPertussis is particularly dangerous for newborn babies, who may not show symptoms of a cough but may stop breathing and turn blue. To combat this risk to newborns, the NSW Government introduced the Antenatal Pertussis Vaccination program in April 2015. The program offers free vaccinations for all pregnant women in their 3rd trimester to protect children before they are born.\n\n[Byline: Jillian McKee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures, usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality.\n\nIn a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nNew figures from SA Health reveal that the number of whooping cough cases are rising, up from a total of 505 cases in 2014 compared to 985 cases so far in 2015. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. More than 1200 cases of whooping cough were reported across western Sydney during 2015, with 200 cases reported in October 2015 alone. \n\nRegular immunization is recommended to prevent whooping cough, with all children receiving immunisation in high school; however, immunity fades over time, and booster shots are often needed for adults. \n\nWestern Sydney Local Health District Communicable diseases manager Dr Shopna Bag said cases of whooping cough had been consistently increasing. ' \n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. \n\n[Byline: Katrina Stokes]\n\n--\n \n\n[Byline: Jillian McKee]\n\n--\n \n\n\nSouth Australia Health is urging parents to vaccinate their children against whooping cough as cases in South Australia reach a 4-year high. PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (06): (SOUTH AUSTRALIA, NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************************\n This October 2015, more than 95 cases were reported in the Blacktown local government area, compared with just 21 cases in October 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-10-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-10-25 00:00:00", "2015-04-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "7520-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Blacktown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3778426", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Sudan (02): (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3778426", "date": "2015-11-09 15:23:06", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN (02): (NORTH DARFUR)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2015\nSource: Dabanga Sudan [edited]\nhttps://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/whooping-cough-outbreak-in-north-darfur-s-el-sereif\n\n\nAs of 28 Oct 2015, 410 cases of whooping cough have been reported in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality, according to the Sudanese Ministry of Health (SMoH). The outbreak started in early September 2015 and has affected all age groups including infants, children and adults. No deaths have been reported so far, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest weekly bulletin.\n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). About half (193) of all cases have been reported in the El Hariga village where the outbreak started. The remaining cases are from 8 neighboring villages. The majority of cases are of people under 15 years of age.\n\nIn response, the SMoH, WHO, and health partners on the ground are implementing a 3-month action plan in the locality. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. Medecins Sans Frontieres Spain (MSF-Spain) has initiated case management and community awareness-raising activities.\n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. The rate of transmission seems to be decreasing, according to WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. At least 2 people died from the disease then. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. As of 28 Oct 2015, 410 cases of whooping cough have been reported in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality, according to the Sudanese Ministry of Health (SMoH). PERTUSSIS - SUDAN (02): (NORTH DARFUR)\n**************************************\n \n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. \n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-11-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SMoH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3927199", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (01)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3927199", "date": "2016-01-11 14:53:19", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (01)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Colorado (Prowers County)\n[2] California (Yolo County)\n[3] Ohio (Franklin County)\n[4] Minnesota (Olmsted County)\n[5] Wyoming (Teton County)\n\n*****\n[1] Colorado (Prowers County)\nDate: Mon 4 Jan 2016\nSource: Bent County Democrat [edited]\nhttp://www.bcdemocratonline.com/article/20160104/NEWS/151229895\n\n\nProwers County Public Health officials have received lab confirmation of pertussis in 2 Prowers County children, an 8-week old infant, and a 2 year old child, over the past 2 weeks.\n\nDue to the outbreak, Prowers County Public Health and Environment is advising parents to check their child's immunization record to ensure they are up to date with their vaccinations for pertussis. All adults are also advised to obtain the vaccination if they have not had the vaccination. Residents are advised to check with their health care provider or call the health department if they are uncertain about their vaccination status.\n\nProwers County Public Health and Environment will be offering clinic times to ensure that residents, including children and adults, who need vaccination can make an appointment to come in. These clinics are an ongoing effort to prevent the further spread of pertussis in Prowers County and possible spread to other counties and states. Children will not be denied due to inability to pay.\n\n'Vaccination is the safest and most effective tool against pertussis,' said Director of Public Health, Tammie Clark, RN, BSN. 'We are continuing to work with the healthcare providers and the community, to prevent the further spread of pertussis. Our work focuses on increasing vaccination rates, particularly in adults and adolescents, and preventing transmission to vulnerable populations, where the disease can have devastating results, such as pregnant women, infants, and those with weakened immune systems.\n\n'Pertussis is a vaccine-preventable disease that is also known as whooping cough, or the '100-day cough.' It is highly contagious and caused by a bacterial infection of the respiratory tract. People with suspected or confirmed diagnosis of pertussis should stay home from work, school, or childcare until they have been on antimicrobials for at least 5 days.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated if the mother of the 8-week-old infant diagnosed with pertussis had received pertussis immunization during the 2nd or 3rd trimester, which will dramatically decrease the incidence of this infection in such young infants, who represent the most vulnerable age group for morbidity and mortality.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures, usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis (particularly with white blood cell counts of 30 000 to 100 000) and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality.\n\nIn a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented [a larger proportion of] the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nA map of the counties of the western state of Colorado showing Prowers County in the southeastern part of the state can be found at:\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prowers_County,_Colorado#/media/File:Map_of_Colorado_highlighting_Prowers_County.svg - Mod.LL]\n\n*****\n[2] California (Yolo County)\nDate: Thu 24 Dec 2015\nSource: Davis Enteprise [edited]\nhttp://www.davisenterprise.com/local-news/yolos-pertussis-rate-still-high-but-new-law-could-change-that/\n\n\nYolo County's pertussis rate remains significantly higher than the rest of the state; only 1 county had a higher rate of whooping cough in 2015, but the county's health officer expects to see significant improvement when a new state law eliminating the personal-belief exemption for childhood vaccinations takes effect in January 2016.\n\n'The impact is going to be huge,' Dr. Ron Chapman said Tue, 22 Dec 2015. 'There will be an immediate effect.' Under the law signed by Gov. Jerry Brown in July 2015, all children will have to be vaccinated against a variety of infectious diseases before they enter school or day care, unless they have a medical exemption signed by a licensed physician. Children with personal-belief exemptions on file prior to 1 Jan 2016, will be able to stay in school, but will have to meet the requirements of the new law before advancing from preschool to elementary school (grades K-6) or from elementary school to secondary school (grades 7-12). All new students would be subject to the new law after 1 Jul 2016.\n\nSB 277 applies to public and private schools, including elementary and secondary schools, day-care centers and nursery schools.\nCountywide, private schools tended to have higher personal-belief exemption rates than public schools, and it was in those schools with high exemption rates where outbreaks of infectious diseases like pertussis were most likely to occur, Chapman said.\n\nStatewide, infants under the age of 1 and teens between the ages of 14 and 17 had the highest pertussis rates in 2015. Among residents of all ages, only Humboldt County had a higher incident rate than Yolo County. As of the end of November 2015, Yolo had documented 80 pertussis cases, for an incident rate of 38.8 per 100 000 residents. 'It's bad,' Chapman noted.\n\nThe reason why is not clear, he said, but Yolo is among a cluster of Northern California counties, the others being Marin, Sonoma and Napa, where pertussis rates have been higher than the rest of the state for the past 2 years. 'There seems to be a geographic area with higher rates,' Chapman said, 'but it's not totally clear why. I don't have an explanation.'\n\nThe good news is that cases of pertussis in Yolo County decreased from 147 in 2014 to 80 by the end of November 2015. However, given that the county historically had fewer than 5 cases annually, 'the rate is still high,' Chapman said. He expects the new state law not only will reduce the number of pertussis cases being seen locally but also other childhood infectious diseases like measles and chicken pox, and that's good news for those most vulnerable to infectious disease.\n\nNewborns, for example, cannot receive their 1st pertussis vaccine until they are 6 weeks old and remain particularly vulnerable to infection. Of the 176 pertussis cases that resulted in hospitalization in California in 2015, 70 percent (120) were infants under the age of 4 months.\n\n[Byline: Anne Ternus-Bellamy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[State laws such as the new California law can go a long way in decreasing the incidence of vaccine-preventable diseases ONLY if physicians do not sign medical exemptions on request of parents for children who truly do not have a real medical reason for the exemption.\n\nThe location of Yolo County in the state of California can be found on a map at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yolo_County,_California#/media/File:Map_of_California_highlighting_Yolo_County.svg. - Mod.LL]\n\n*****\n[3] Ohio (Franklin County)\nDate: Wed 23 Dec 2015\nSource: This Week News [edited]\nhttp://www.thisweeknews.com/content/stories/grandview/news/2015/12/22/whooping-cough-sweeps-through-schools.html\n\n\nWhooping cough sweeps through schools\n-----------\nGrandview Heights City School District officials are asking parents to help them contain a highly contagious disease. 21 cases of pertussis, also called whooping cough, have been reported in the district starting with the school year. Students at the high school and Edison Intermediate/Larson Middle School have been impacted. There have been no cases reported at Stevenson Elementary School.\n\n'It's an outbreak, not an epidemic,' school nurse Mary Mauro said. 'I do think it's interesting that we haven't had a case at the elementary school,' she said. 'Usually that is where you might expect to see it.' In a typical year, few if any cases are reported, Mauro said.\n\nThe cases have been spread throughout grade levels at the high school, with 2 seniors, 4 juniors, 3 sophomores and a freshman diagnosed.\nAt Edison/Larson, 7 8th-graders and 4 4th-grade students have come down with whooping cough.\n\nThe outbreak of the disease is not unique to Grandview, Superintendent Andy Culp said. 'We're just representative of what is happening statewide,' he said.\n\nPertussis is highly contagious and spread through the air by coughing and sneezing, Mauro said. The 1st case in Grandview was diagnosed in September 2015, Mauro added. 'It's 1 or maybe 2 or 3 cases identified in a week, then a couple weeks go by before we see another case,' she said.\n\nParents should make sure their children are up to date on immunizations, Mauro said. But the immunity from vaccinations decreases over time, and most of the Grandview students diagnosed with pertussis were up to date in their vaccines, she said.\n\n[Byline: Alan Froman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The evolution of new clones of _B. pertussis_, which are less prevented by the current acellular vaccine, and the presence of an underimmunized cohort of individuals may play a role in the number of cases described here. It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _B. pertussis_ that can infect infants less than 1 year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, who are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting this susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis was associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least 1 dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all-acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long.\n\nThe location of Franklin County in Ohio can be seen on a map at:\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_County,_Ohio#/media/File:Map_of_Ohio_highlighting_Franklin_County.svg. - Mod.LL]\n\n****\n[4] Minnesota (Olmsted County)\nDate: Tue 22 Dec 2015\nSource: Fox 9 [edited]\nhttp://www.fox9.com/home/59757849-story\n\n\n2015's Christmas Grinch in southern Minnesota appears to be coming in the form of whooping cough. Many schools and day care facilities in Rochester are seeing cases of the bacterial infection pop up. According to the Mayo Clinic, a new round of confirmed cases have been\nreported in Rochester.\n\nThe CDC recorded nearly 33 000 cases of whooping cough nationwide in 2014, a 15 percent increase from years past. Doctors say the whooping cough (also called pertussis) bacterium is endemic to Minnesota, which means it's going to be here every year, making vaccines that much more important.\n\n[Byline: Jack Highberger]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The location of Rochester in Olmsted County, Minnesota can be seen on a map at:\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rochester,_Minnesota#/media/File:Olmsted_County_Minnesota_Incorporated_and_Unincorporated_areas_Rochester_Highlighted.svg - Mod.LL]\n\n*****\n[5] Wyoming (Teton County)\nDate: Mon 21 Dec 2015\nSource: Jackson Hole Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.jhnewsandguide.com/news/health/whooping-cough-on-the-rise-in-teton-county/article_95682c8e-4001-5af9-bcb8-941b23cc3dc0.html\n\n\nAn 8th case of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, was recently reported in Teton County, adding to the spike seen in 2015. The county is home to about a 3rd of all reported cases across the state, according to health officials.\n\n'Vaccines are the most effective tool we have to protect against pertussis,' said Teton County Health Officer Dr. Travis Riddell. 'Therefore, it is important for all residents to get the recommended vaccinations to keep our community's immunity strong.'\n\nLocal cases have been found in vaccinated and unvaccinated children and adults, though the disease is most often associated with children. It can be a serious illness for young children and fatal for babies, according to the CDC.\n\n[Byline: Melissa Cassutt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Teton County in northwest Wyoming can be found on a map at:\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teton_County,_Wyoming#/media/File:Map_of_Wyoming_highlighting_Teton_County.svg - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The evolution of new clones of _B. pertussis_, which are less prevented by the current acellular vaccine, and the presence of an underimmunized cohort of individuals may play a role in the number of cases described here. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[State laws such as the new California law can go a long way in decreasing the incidence of vaccine-preventable diseases ONLY if physicians do not sign medical exemptions on request of parents for children who truly do not have a real medical reason for the exemption.
