As of the end of November 2015, Yolo had documented 80 pertussis cases, for an incident rate of 38.8 per 100 000 residents. ' \n\n\nAn 8th case of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, was recently reported in Teton County, adding to the spike seen in 2015. \n\n--\n [Byline: Anne Ternus-Bellamy]\n\n--\n [Byline: Alan Froman]\n\n--\n [Byline: Jack Highberger]\n\n--\n [Byline: Melissa Cassutt]\n\n--\n In Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. Source: Fox 9 [edited]\nhttp://www.fox9.com/home/59757849-story\n\n\n2015's Christmas Grinch in southern Minnesota appears to be coming in the form of whooping cough. \n\nReferences\n----------", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2016-01-01 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2021-07-12 00:00:00", "2016-01-04 00:00:00", "2015-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-08 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-09-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-01-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yolo County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prowers County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rochester", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sonoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Humboldt County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/yolo_county,_california#/media/file:map_of_california_highlighting_yolo_county.svg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Olmsted County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prowers_County,_Colorado#/media/File:Map_of_Colorado_highlighting_Prowers_County.svg - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Teton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yolo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3809154", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Spain (02): (AN) infant fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3809154", "date": "2015-11-25 15:06:20", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SPAIN (02): (ANDALUSIA) INFANT FATALITIES\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Nov 2015\nSource: La Razon [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.larazon.es/sociedad/muere-otro-bebe-de-dos-meses-por-tos-ferina-MA11224866#.Ttt1nKXnIKD7Da9\n\n\nThe Regional Government of Andalusia confirmed yesterday 17 Nov 2015, the death of a child less than 2 months old in the Virgen del Rocio hospital in Seville, in September 2015, making it 2 dead girls in less than 3 months of age, after the death of a newborn baby of 18 days recorded in late October 2015 in Malaga. In both cases the mother of the children had not been vaccinated. In view of this case, Andalusian authorities have planned to include the vaccine for all pregnant women starting on 1 Jan 2016.\n\nThe Community of Madrid will also begin vaccination in 2016. The [President of the Community of Madrid], Cristina Cifuentes, said that the decision responds to the recommendations of experts from the Vaccine Advisory Committee and indications agreed to by the Public Health Commission of the Interterritorial Council of the National Health Service, after assessing the nationwide increase in cases of whooping cough in recent years and the highest incidence in children younger than 1 year, an age group in which the disease can be severe.\n\nThe new vaccination strategy of the Community of Madrid includes pertussis vaccine for pregnant women in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy (between weeks 28 and 36). It is safe for pregnant women and protects the baby early in life until the immunization sequence for pertussis (combined with tetanus and diphtheria toxoids - Mod.LL] begins, with doses at 2, 4, 6, and 18 months of age. A booster is administered at 6 years of age. However, following the recommendations of experts, Madrid plans to adjust the calendar as a result of the worldwide shortage of vaccine and is expected to suspend temporarily the dose given at 6 years of age until the situation is resolved. The disease is far more deadly in infants than in children who have already received the initial doses.\n\nAccording to the National Epidemiology Center (NEC), until October 2015, the cumulative number of pertussis cases nationwide was 6816, almost triple compared to those recorded during the same period of the previous 5 years. Regional reports show data along the same lines. For example, in Aragon, in 2015 there has been a remarkable increase in the incidence (71 so far in 2015, against the 12 expected). If during the period between 2000 and 2006 an average of 1 death per year was recorded, between 2011 and 2014, the average annual deaths increased to 5.5, all young infants. So far in 2015, there have been 4 known deaths, according to the National Epidemiology Center.\n\nThe Spanish Society of Gynecology and Obstetrics (SEGO) already warned of the surge of cases a year ago after conducting a study of prevalence of the disease. It is for this reason that the recommendation to vaccinate all pregnant to avoid infection in newborns was established. 'There has been an increase in cases because there are women from other countries who have not been vaccinated or because there is a tendency not to vaccinate,' explains Jose Maria Lailla, professor of gynecology at the University of Barcelona.\n\nThere are 7 autonomous communities in Spain that recommend vaccination between weeks 27 and 36 of gestation (Catalonia, Asturias, Navarra, Valencia, Basque Country, Canary Islands, and Extremadura) after it was observed that in recent years, the incidence in Spain has increased to 325 cases per 100 000 in infants under 30 days old. The line followed by these regions is similar to that of other European countries, such as the UK, that follow the same recommendation\n\n[Byline: Rocio Ruiz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA newly released study now links an increased risk, albeit small, for the development of epilepsy in individuals who had a hospital-diagnosed case of pertussis:\n\nOlsen M, Thygesen SK, Ostergaard JR, et al: Hospital-Diagnosed Pertussis Infection in Children and Long-term Risk of Epilepsy.\nJAMA. 2015; 314(17): 1844-9. doi: 10.1001/jama.2015.13971.\n\nImportance:\nPertussis is associated with encephalopathy and seizures in infants. However, the risk of childhood epilepsy following pertussis is unknown.\n\nObjective:\nTo examine whether pertussis is associated with the long-term risk of epilepsy.\n\nDesign, setting, and measures:\nWe used individually linked data from population-based medical registries covering all Danish hospitals to identify a cohort of all patients with pertussis born between 1978 and 2011, followed up through 2011. We used the Civil Registration System to identify 10 individuals from the general population for each patient with pertussis, matched on sex and year of birth.\n\nExposures:\nInpatient or hospital-based outpatient diagnosis of pertussis.\n\nMain outcomes and measures:\nCumulative incidence and hazard ratio of time to hospital-based epilepsy diagnosis (pertussis cohort vs general population cohort), adjusted for birth year, sex, maternal history of epilepsy, presence of congenital malformations, and gestational age. Unique personal identifiers permitted unambiguous data linkage and complete follow-up for death, emigration, and hospital contacts.\n\nResults:\nWe identified 4700 patients with pertussis (48 percent male), of whom 90 developed epilepsy during the follow-up. The cumulative incidence of epilepsy at age 10 years was 1.7 percent (95 percent CI [confidence interval], 1.4-2.1) for patients with pertussis and 0.9 (95 percent CI, 0.8-1.0) for the matched comparison cohort. The corresponding adjusted overall hazard ratio was 1.7 (95 percent CI, 1.3-2.1).\n\nConclusions and relevance:\nIn Denmark, risk of epilepsy was increased in children with hospital-diagnosed pertussis infections compared with the general population; however, the absolute risk was low. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2376.]", "summary": "\n\nA newly released study now links an increased risk, albeit small, for the development of epilepsy in individuals who had a hospital-diagnosed case of pertussis:\n\nOlsen M, Thygesen SK, Ostergaard JR, et al: Hospital-Diagnosed Pertussis Infection in Children and Long-term Risk of Epilepsy.\n \n\nMain outcomes and measures:\nCumulative incidence and hazard ratio of time to hospital-based epilepsy diagnosis (pertussis cohort vs general population cohort), adjusted for birth year, sex, maternal history of epilepsy, presence of congenital malformations, and gestational age. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. The cumulative incidence of epilepsy at age 10 years was 1.7 percent (95 percent CI [confidence interval], 1.4-2.1) for patients with pertussis and 0.9 (95 percent CI, 0.8-1.0) for the matched comparison cohort. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. The Regional Government of Andalusia confirmed yesterday 17 Nov 2015, the death of a child less than 2 months old in the Virgen del Rocio hospital in Seville, in September 2015, making it 2 dead girls in less than 3 months of age, after the death of a newborn baby of 18 days recorded in late October 2015 in Malaga. \n\nThere are 7 autonomous communities in Spain that recommend vaccination between weeks 27 and 36 of gestation (Catalonia, Asturias, Navarra, Valencia, Basque Country, Canary Islands, and Extremadura) after it was observed that in recent years, the incidence in Spain has increased to 325 cases per 100 000 in infants under 30 days old. In Denmark, risk of epilepsy was increased in children with hospital-diagnosed pertussis infections compared with the general population; however, the absolute risk was low. The [President of the Community of Madrid], Cristina Cifuentes, said that the decision responds to the recommendations of experts from the Vaccine Advisory Committee and indications agreed to by the Public Health Commission of the Interterritorial Council of the National Health Service, after assessing the nationwide increase in cases of whooping cough in recent years and the highest incidence in children younger than 1 year, an age group in which the disease can be severe. \n\nThe new vaccination strategy of the Community of Madrid includes pertussis vaccine for pregnant women in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy (between weeks 28 and 36). \nTo examine whether pertussis is associated with the long-term risk of epilepsy. According to the National Epidemiology Center (NEC), until October 2015, the cumulative number of pertussis cases nationwide was 6816, almost triple compared to those recorded during the same period of the previous 5 years. We used individually linked data from population-based medical registries covering all Danish hospitals to identify a cohort of all patients with pertussis born between 1978 and 2011, followed up through 2011. Exposures:\nInpatient or hospital-based outpatient diagnosis of pertussis. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. If during the period between 2000 and 2006 an average of 1 death per year was recorded, between 2011 and 2014, the average annual deaths increased to 5.5, all young infants. \n\nThe Spanish Society of Gynecology and Obstetrics (SEGO) already warned of the surge of cases a year ago after conducting a study of prevalence of the disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-09-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1844-09-25 00:00:00", "6816-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2015-10-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aragon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asturias", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canary Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valencia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3796288", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3796288", "date": "2015-11-17 18:01:37", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (06)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Quebec\n[2] Canada\n\n******\n[1] Quebec\nDate: Tue 10 Nov 2015\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/whooping-cough-cases-triple-in-mauricie-and-central-quebec-1.3312071\n\n\nQuebec public health officials have confirmed that an outbreak of whooping cough -- or pertussis -\u00ad has led to 151 confirmed cases in the Mauricie-Central Quebec region. At the beginning of October 2015, there were about 40 cases. Since then, that number has tripled. Whooping cough is a highly contagious bacterial infection that affects the lungs and upper respiratory system, releasing toxins that cause inflammation and swelling.\n\nThe Mauricie-Central Quebec outbreak has mostly affected young children. Close to a dozen elementary schools, 2 high schools and at least 10 daycare centers in the region reported cases of whooping cough earlier this fall. The outbreak is already 4 times the annual average.\n\nBabies are at the highest risk of complications from pertussis, and they most often are infected by adult caregivers who might not realize they're infected. It takes 2 weeks to get the results of a test for pertussis, and because of that, public health authorities in the region have told doctors to advise patients to stay at home if whooping cough is suspected until they receive a firm diagnosis.\n\nIn Canada, between 1000 and 3000 people a year contract whooping cough, according to the Public Health Agency of Canada. Worldwide, the airborne bacterium that causes the illness affects 20 to 40 million people annually, killing some 400 000 people each year.\n\nThere is a vaccine for whooping cough which prevents the disease or, at least, leads to fewer complications. Quebec's Health Ministry recommends that all children be vaccinated with a 1st shot at 2 months. Children must receive 5 shots in all to be protected from the disease: at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months and 18 months, then a final booster between the age of 4 and 6. Teens receive a 6th dose of the vaccine in their 3rd year of high school. Adults need to get a one-time booster as well to be fully protected. The whooping cough booster is a combination vaccine, with diphtheria and tetanus. Once an adult receives the combination booster, they still need a further booster for diphtheria and tetanus once every 10 years.\n\n[Byline: Jae C. Hong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Canada\nDate: Thu 12 Nov 2015\nSource: Canadian Press [edited]\nhttps://blackburnnews.com/bri-lifestyle/2015/11/12/parts-of-canada-seeing-spikes-in-whooping-cough/\n\n\nSeveral provinces and at least one territory are experiencing outbreaks of pertussis, better known as whooping cough, and public health officials are encouraging Canadians of all ages to make sure their vaccinations are up to date. The bacterial infection, which often but not always causes a 'whoop' sound when breathing or coughing, is particularly dangerous for very young babies, say doctors. The disease can lead to hospitalization and, in rare cases, death.\n\nManitoba is dealing with an outbreak of pertussis in its southern region, where 44 of the province's 51 cases so far in 2015 have been reported. Most of those who developed the infection had not been inoculated against pertussis, which is included in a vaccine that typically also protects against diphtheria, tetanus and polio. Some provinces also include _Haemophilus influenzae_ type B vaccine (Hib) or hepatitis B vaccine in the shot.\n\n'You have outbreaks from time to time, but we're usually around 10 per year, so this is significant,' Dr. Michael Routledge, Manitoba's chief public health officer, said Thursday, 12 Nov 2015, from Winnipeg. Most of those who got sick were young children, but some teens and adults also contracted the infection, Routledge added. 'We're concerned this is happening in kids who are quite young, and they can have serious complications from it.' While the disease is endemic, or always present in the community to some extent, outbreaks tend to be cyclical, with a spike in cases every 2 to 5 years.\n\nNew Brunswick has also been dealing with a pertussis outbreak. The province has recorded 56 confirmed cases in 2015, all in the Greater Moncton area, including 4 new cases reported between 6 Nov 2015 and 12 Nov 2015 in residents aged 9 to 24, a spokesman said. The Northwest Territories has also had a jump in whooping cough cases in 2015.\n\nWhile Ontario has had some isolated outbreaks, Dr. Shelley Deeks said 2015 has 'not been a huge year' for pertussis, at least compared to some previous years. Deeks, medical director of immunization and vaccine-preventable diseases, said Public Health Ontario has received reports of about 500 cases to date, far below the peak of more than 1200 cases recorded in 2006. Deeks said: 'So adults should talk to their physicians and make sure they receive a dose of pertussis [vaccine],' she said, noting that the shot would typically also contain diphtheria and tetanus components. 'It's really important for their health, but the other thing we know is that parents and grandparents are an important source of pertussis for babies. And because the disease can be quite severe in infants, we want to make sure adults are protected for it so they don't pass it onto their children, especially newborns.'\n\nBritish Columbia is also seeing a bit of a jump in whooping cough in 2015, with double the number of cases reported in 2012, but half the case count in 2000, reflecting the cyclical nature of the infection, said Dr. Danuta Skowronski, an infectious disease expert at the BC Center for Disease Control. The highest proportion of cases in BC is among pre-teens aged 10 to 13, suggesting that waning immunity could be at play, as children that age would have had their most recent dose as 4 to 6 year olds, said Skowronski. While the goal of public health officials isn't to eradicate pertussis -- an impossible goal given its endemic nature -- it's not clear how more consistent protection can be achieved. Giving boosters more often would be like 'chasing a moving target,' Skowronski said. 'Do you add more doses? Or are we approaching the kind of program like we have with influenza ... where you have to give it annually or at least every few years?'\n\nBecause about 80 per cent of the serious outcomes due to whooping cough occur in babies under 3 months, Skowronski believes that's where the primary focus of immunization should be placed. 'It's most important that we get that 1st dose into children in a timely way, without delaying. Parents should be on that.' At the same time, drug companies may need to come up with a better vaccine that could be given sooner than 2 months old, offering earlier protection, she said. 'We're getting signals now of concern that we need to address, and especially if we are accumulating cohorts (groups) of children with waning immunity,' Skowronski said of the outbreaks. 'It's not scary monsters right now. But we want to look to the future and anticipate if this gets higher yet with the next cyclical peak. And what are the options that we might implement to try to mitigate that?'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the latest Public Health Agency of Canada's Update on Pertussis Vaccination in Pregnancy http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/naci-ccni/acs-dcc/2014/pvip-vcpg_0214-eng.php, last published in 2014, it is stated:\n\n'National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) does not recommend a universal program for vaccination of pregnant women given the current epidemiology in Canada.\n\n'In special circumstances, such as a regional outbreak situation, immunization with Tdap may be offered to pregnant women (26 weeks or more of gestation) irrespective of their immunization history.\n\n'Every effort should be made to administer one dose of pertussis containing vaccine in adulthood. Therefore, one dose of combined diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis containing vaccine (Tdap) can be offered to pregnant women (at 26 weeks of gestation or more) who have not been previously vaccinated against pertussis in adulthood.'\n\nIn the USA, however, the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6207a4.htm) states: 'In October 2011, in an effort to reduce the burden of pertussis in infants, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended that unvaccinated pregnant women receive a dose of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap). Vaccination of women with Tdap during pregnancy is expected to provide some protection to infants from pertussis until they are old enough to be vaccinated themselves. Tdap given to pregnant women will stimulate the development of maternal antipertussis antibodies, which will pass through the placenta, likely providing the newborn with protection against pertussis in early life, and will protect the mother from pertussis around the time of delivery, making her less likely to become infected and transmit pertussis to her infant. The 2011 Tdap recommendation did not call for vaccinating pregnant women previously vaccinated with Tdap. On 24 Oct 2012, ACIP voted to recommend use of Tdap during every pregnancy. This report summarizes data considered and conclusions made by ACIP and provides guidance for implementing its recommendations. These updated recommendations on use of Tdap in pregnant women aim to optimize strategies for preventing pertussis morbidity and mortality in infants.'\n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis occurs in infants less than 6 months of age, especially neonates. Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the latest Public Health Agency of Canada's Update on Pertussis Vaccination in Pregnancy http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/naci-ccni/acs-dcc/2014/pvip-vcpg_0214-eng.php, last published in 2014, it is stated:\n\n'National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) does not recommend a universal program for vaccination of pregnant women given the current epidemiology in Canada. \n\nIn the USA, however, the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6207a4.htm) states: 'In October 2011, in an effort to reduce the burden of pertussis in infants, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended that unvaccinated pregnant women receive a dose of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap). Tdap given to pregnant women will stimulate the development of maternal antipertussis antibodies, which will pass through the placenta, likely providing the newborn with protection against pertussis in early life, and will protect the mother from pertussis around the time of delivery, making her less likely to become infected and transmit pertussis to her infant. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/whooping-cough-cases-triple-in-mauricie-and-central-quebec-1.3312071\n\n\nQuebec public health officials have confirmed that an outbreak of whooping cough -- or pertussis -\u00ad has led to 151 confirmed cases in the Mauricie-Central Quebec region. Therefore, one dose of combined diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis containing vaccine (Tdap) can be offered to pregnant women (at 26 weeks of gestation or more) who have not been previously vaccinated against pertussis in adulthood.' \n\nBritish Columbia is also seeing a bit of a jump in whooping cough in 2015, with double the number of cases reported in 2012, but half the case count in 2000, reflecting the cyclical nature of the infection, said Dr. Danuta Skowronski, an infectious disease expert at the BC Center for Disease Control. It takes 2 weeks to get the results of a test for pertussis, and because of that, public health authorities in the region have told doctors to advise patients to stay at home if whooping cough is suspected until they receive a firm diagnosis.\n\n \n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. The province has recorded 56 confirmed cases in 2015, all in the Greater Moncton area, including 4 new cases reported between 6 Nov 2015 and 12 Nov 2015 in residents aged 9 to 24, a spokesman said. Deeks said: 'So adults should talk to their physicians and make sure they receive a dose of pertussis [vaccine],' she said, noting that the shot would typically also contain diphtheria and tetanus components. ' \n\nManitoba is dealing with an outbreak of pertussis in its southern region, where 44 of the province's 51 cases so far in 2015 have been reported. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Children must receive 5 shots in all to be protected from the disease: at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months and 18 months, then a final booster between the age of 4 and 6. \n\nWhile Ontario has had some isolated outbreaks, Dr. Shelley Deeks said 2015 has 'not been a huge year' for pertussis, at least compared to some previous years. \n\n'You have outbreaks from time to time, but we're usually around 10 per year, so this is significant,' Dr. Michael Routledge, Manitoba's chief public health officer, said Thursday, 12 Nov 2015, from Winnipeg. https://blackburnnews.com/bri-lifestyle/2015/11/12/parts-of-canada-seeing-spikes-in-whooping-cough/\n\n\nSeveral provinces and at least one territory are experiencing outbreaks of pertussis, better known as whooping cough, and public health officials are encouraging Canadians of all ages to make sure their vaccinations are up to date. \n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis occurs in infants less than 6 months of age, especially neonates. The highest proportion of cases in BC is among pre-teens aged 10 to 13, suggesting that waning immunity could be at play, as children that age would have had their most recent dose as 4 to 6 year olds, said Skowronski. \n\n'Every effort should be made to administer one dose of pertussis containing vaccine in adulthood. PERTUSSIS - CANADA (06)\n***********************\n While the goal of public health officials isn't to eradicate pertussis -- an impossible goal given its endemic nature -- it's not clear how more consistent protection can be achieved. \n\nBecause about 80 per cent of the serious outcomes due to whooping cough occur in babies under 3 months, Skowronski believes that's where the primary focus of immunization should be placed. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis b", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-10-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3746994", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Sudan: (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3746994", "date": "2015-10-27 13:32:52", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN: (NORTH DARFUR)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 14 Oct 2015\nSource: AllAfrica, Radio Dabanga [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201510150328.html\n\n\nThe State Ministry of Health in North Darfur has reported the outbreak of whooping cough (pertussis) in El Sareif Beni Hussein locality in early September 2015. As of 7 Oct 2015, 323 suspected cases of the contagious disease were reported in the locality.\n\nPreparations are underway to conduct a vaccination campaign for children under 5 in the locality, the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Sudan reported in its latest news bulletin. In mid-September 2015, the Health Ministry sent an investigation team to El Sareif Beni Hussein. The team collected 13 samples that were sent to the National Public Health laboratory for analysis, four of which tested positive for pertussis.\n\nA whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. At least 2 people died from the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the morbidity and mortality of pertussis is in infants, especially those under 6 months of age where most of the mortality occurs in the developed world. The percent of people in North Sudan who are adequately immunized against pertussis is unclear.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with hypoxia-induced (low oxygen) seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Sudan can be seen at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the morbidity and mortality of pertussis is in infants, especially those under 6 months of age where most of the mortality occurs in the developed world. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-11-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3780767", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3780767", "date": "2015-11-10 12:05:14", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (05)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Manitoba\n[2] Northwest Territories\n[3] New Brunswick\n\n******\n[1] Manitoba\nDate: Fri 6 Nov 2015\nSource: CJOB [edited]\nhttp://www.cjob.com/2015/11/06/98738/\n\n\nA Winkler [southern Manitoba] mom wants everyone to get vaccinated after her 4-month-old daughter was hospitalized. The infant had her 1st whooping cough vaccination at 2 months of age. A month later, she started to cough. 'It really just started with a cough here and then and then progressively got worse throughout the day.' The mother took her to the walk-in clinic. The doctor did a swab, and 2 days later, she was diagnosed.\n\nAnd she's not alone. Manitoba Health says the Southern Regional Health Authority [RHA] would typically see a handful of cases per year. But in 2015, there are more than 40 cases.\n\nWhooping cough (pertussis) is highly contagious disease that can cause severe coughing spells with a 'whoop' sound between as people try to take a big breath. The cough can last 6 to 12 weeks. It is most common among infants.\n\nDr Tim Hilderman, Manitoba's Medical Officer of Health for Vaccines, says in some cases it can be life-threatening. 'One of the most complications is a severe pneumonia that can result in hospitalization and, in rare cases, death.'\n\nThis infant had to be hospitalized. 'We went over to the Children's Hospital where they put her in isolation and then because she was not breathing. There are a few times where she would go blue. They put us into 24-hour monitoring and isolation, so we were in a plastic-wrapped room basically and they were all gowning up... It was pretty horrible for us,' she said. The infant was in the 'danger zone' for 2 days and was in the hospital for a week.\n\nHilderman says pertussis is cyclical -- there was a larger outbreak in Manitoba in 2012. But he says most of the patients they are seeing in the Southern RHA are not vaccinated. Others, like this infant, have had some of the vaccine. But immunity built up over time. So he says cases are more prevalent among infants less than 6 months, even those following the vaccine schedule, like this infant.\n\n'They haven't had enough vaccine and enough time to build up that immunity so this is where it become very important to have high levels of immunization in a community to prevent spread,' he said. 'I think what we're learning here is that the coverage rates that we have aren't high enough to prevent these kinds of clusters or outbreaks from occurring. It's very difficult for me to say whether or not that's a phenomenon that's due to the rate today or whether that's more of a phenomenon of the cyclical nature of the disease and the rates over time,' he said.\n\nHilderman says adults who haven't been vaccinated should get a booster shot. He says they also try to boost infant caregivers as well.\n\n[Byline: Kim Lawson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Northwest Territories\nDate: Tue 3 Nov 2015\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/range-lake-north-school-student-diagnosed-with-whooping-cough-1.3302740\n\n\nHealth officials are warning parents and guardians of children at Range Lake North School in Yellowknife [Northwest Territories, NT] that their child may have been exposed to a student with whooping cough. The school sent out a letter today [3 Nov 2015] about the bacterial infection, also called pertussis, which is transmitted though sneezing and coughing. Symptoms include a persistent cough, fever, runny nose, and sneezing.\n\nThe risk of serious and sometimes deadly complications is highest in babies and young children, especially those who have not been vaccinated. The Public Health Agency of Canada recommends adults be immunized against whooping cough if they are in regular contact with an infant.\n\nThe pertussis vaccine is part of the routine NT immunization schedule, but according to the health authority the protection from immunizations can start to wane or be less effective by age 9 or 10. The immunization schedule calls for booster vaccinations for tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis in Grade 9 and every 10 years for adults over 18.\n\nA similar letter was sent out to parents of students attending Yellowknife's William McDonald school in September 2015 after a child at that school was diagnosed with pertussis.\n\nAlberta Health Services declared a pertussis outbreak in northern Alberta in August 2015.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New Brunswick\nDate: Thu 29 Oct 2015\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/whooping-cough-outbreak-1.3293947\n\n\nDr Yves Lager, the medical officer of health in the eastern region, released the updated numbers on the whooping cough outbreak on Thursday morning, 29 Oct 2015. He said most of the whooping cough, or pertussis, cases are in the greater Moncton area [southeastern New Brunswick].\n\n'The profile of the cases we've seen in the last week remains really similar to what we've seen so far in this outbreak,' said Lager. 'Most cases have been in children and adolescents. Most cases for which we have vaccine information indicates that they are up to date with their pertussis vaccine.'\n\nLager said with this outbreak, public health has been closely monitoring its supply of the vaccines due to an increase in demand. 'We've received a large shipment on [Tue 27 Oct 2015], which will be more than enough to meet both our routine and outbreak needs,' said Lager. Approximately 12 000 doses of whooping cough vaccine were delivered in that shipment.\n\nWhile confirmed cases have been reported among people who have been vaccinated, Lager said that likely has to do with a decreased effectiveness. He said this can happen as people get closer to the time when they are due for their next pertussis booster immunization.\n\nLager said the number of confirmed cases in October 2015 is similar to the number of confirmed cases in September 2015.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the latest Public Health Agency of Canada's Update on Pertussis Vaccination in Pregnancy http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/naci-ccni/acs-dcc/2014/pvip-vcpg_0214-eng.php published in 2014, it is stated:\n\n'National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) does not recommend a universal program for vaccination of pregnant women given the current epidemiology in Canada.\n\nIn special circumstances, such as a regional outbreak situation, immunization with Tdap may be offered to pregnant women (26 weeks or more of gestation) irrespective of their immunization history.\n\nEvery effort should be made to administer one dose of pertussis containing vaccine in adulthood. Therefore, one dose of combined diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis containing vaccine (Tdap) can be offered to pregnant women (at 26 weeks of gestation or more) who have not been previously vaccinated against pertussis in adulthood.'\n\nIn the USA, however, the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6207a4.htm) states:\n'In October 2011, in an effort to reduce the burden of pertussis in infants, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended that unvaccinated pregnant women receive a dose of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap). Vaccination of women with Tdap during pregnancy is expected to provide some protection to infants from pertussis until they are old enough to be vaccinated themselves. Tdap given to pregnant women will stimulate the development of maternal antipertussis antibodies, which will pass through the placenta, likely providing the newborn with protection against pertussis in early life, and will protect the mother from pertussis around the time of delivery, making her less likely to become infected and transmit pertussis to her infant. The 2011 Tdap recommendation did not call for vaccinating pregnant women previously vaccinated with Tdap. On 24 Oct 2012, ACIP voted to recommend use of Tdap during every pregnancy. This report summarizes data considered and conclusions made by ACIP and provides guidance for implementing its recommendations. These updated recommendations on use of Tdap in pregnant women aim to optimize strategies for preventing pertussis morbidity and mortality in infants.'\n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis occurs in infants less than 6 months of age, especially neonates. Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA recent publication confirms that safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the latest Public Health Agency of Canada's Update on Pertussis Vaccination in Pregnancy http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/naci-ccni/acs-dcc/2014/pvip-vcpg_0214-eng.php published in 2014, it is stated:\n\n'National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) does not recommend a universal program for vaccination of pregnant women given the current epidemiology in Canada. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Tdap given to pregnant women will stimulate the development of maternal antipertussis antibodies, which will pass through the placenta, likely providing the newborn with protection against pertussis in early life, and will protect the mother from pertussis around the time of delivery, making her less likely to become infected and transmit pertussis to her infant. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n In October 2011, in an effort to reduce the burden of pertussis in infants, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended that unvaccinated pregnant women receive a dose of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap). Therefore, one dose of combined diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis containing vaccine (Tdap) can be offered to pregnant women (at 26 weeks of gestation or more) who have not been previously vaccinated against pertussis in adulthood.' \n\nA recent publication confirms that safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. Canada (04): (AB,SK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3653562", "date": "2015-09-18 09:32:14", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (04): (ALBERTA, SASKATCHEWAN)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Sep 2015\nSource: EnergeticCity.ca [edited]\nhttp://energeticcity.ca/article/news/2015/09/16/whooping-cough-outbreak-declared-in-northern-alberta-and-saskatchewan\n\n\nLocal Health authorities in northern Alberta and in parts of Saskatchewan have determined an outbreak of whooping cough is present in the areas.\n\nJonathon Dyck with Northern Health says they are seeing an expected seasonal increase of whooping cough in northern BC [British Columbia], and they recommend residents keep up to date for routine immunizations, as those that are immunized are much less likely to get them [vaccine preventable diseases].\n\nHe says immunization is important because 'herd immunity' can help keep those who aren't able to be immunized healthy. He urges anyone who can be immunized to do so.\n\nPeople who are under the age of 18 can get a whooping cough vaccine for free, and adults can pay a fee for one at a health unit.\n\nCheck out ImmunizeBC [http://immunizebc.ca] to get up to date information on diseases, vaccines, and schedules and to find an immunization clinic near you.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see the moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - Canada (03): (ON) update 20150726.3537081.\n\nA map of Canada showing the provinces can be found at http://members.shaw.ca/kcic1/mapmenu.html and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see the moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - Canada (03): (ON) update 20150726.3537081. PERTUSSIS - CANADA (04): (ALBERTA, SASKATCHEWAN)\n************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ALBERTA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3789050", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (15)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3789050", "date": "2015-11-13 17:26:21", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (15)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New York (western counties)\n[2] New Jersey (Ocean County)\n[3] Virginia (Albemarle County)\n[4] West Virginia\n\n*****\n[1] New York (western counties)\nDate: Wed 11 Nov 2015\nSource: WHEC [edited]\nhttp://www.whec.com/article/stories/s3960499.shtml\n\n\n7 cases of whooping cough have been reported in the Batavia school district so far in 2015. In Rochester, there has been a reported case of an elementary student with whooping cough. There have also been reported cases in Geneseo.\n\nThe Monroe county health department is asking parents be mindful that there was 1 case in a city. If your child develops a persisting cough and it's not getting better, they need to see a doctor.\n\nParents of children at the school on Webster Avenue in the city were sent a letter about the whooping cough cases. It reads in part, 'We are writing to inform you that the county health department has confirmed a case of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a student at our school.'\n\nIn Monroe County, we're told they're seeing more pertussis cases. County health representatives say there are between 50-100 cases a year now compared to 10 years ago, when there were only about 10-20 cases a year.\n\n[Byline: Rebecca Fath]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[2] New Jersey (Ocean County)\nDate: Wed 11 Nov 2015\nSource: Patch.com [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/new-jersey/brick/whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-ocean-county-report-0\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough has been reported in Ocean County, according to a media report. The Asbury Park Press is reporting that 3 cases of the respiratory disease were reported last week in Lakewood. Whooping cough, known formally as pertussis, is a highly contagious respiratory infection that causes violent coughing fits and a characteristic 'whooping' sound, according to the CDC. The bacterial infection can be deadly in infants.\n\nThe Press report said the Ocean County Health Department says the cases are centered in Lakewood's Orthodox Jewish communities and appear related to an outbreak of whooping cough in Brooklyn.\n\nThe health department is reaching out to members of local Orthodox communities and adults throughout Ocean County and urging Tdap vaccination for everyone who has contact with small children, the Press report said\n\n[Byline: Karen Wall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[3] Virginia (Albemarle County)\nDate: Thu 12 Nov 2015\nSource: NBC29 [edited]\nhttp://www.nbc29.com/story/30502641/case-of-whooping-cough-at-wahs\n\n\nWestern Albemarle High School has a confirmed case of whooping cough. Schools sent a note to parents Thursday, 12 Nov 2015, to inform them of the situation. Whooping cough, or pertussis, is spread through the air by coughing.\n\nThe note says casual contact in a classroom setting usually does not warrant routine preventative treatment. However, it does urge parents to take their children to a doctor if they cough for more than 2 weeks or it happens in fits and spasms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[4] West Virginia\nDate: Mon 9 Nov 2015\nSource: WTOV9 [edited]\nhttp://wtov9.com/news/local/whooping-cough-cases-up-in-west-virginia\n\n\nThere have been 52 confirmed cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, so far in 2015 in West Virginia, and health officials confirm 5 outbreaks of the disease. It's a disease that can be stopped [prevented] with a vaccine.\n\n'When an outbreak occurs, we move quickly to quash that because if not, we can have an entire day care, school or community affected very quickly,' Howard Gamble of the Wheeling-Ohio County Health Department said, 'When you have an outbreak announced concerning public health, you become a little more vigilant. We put out notices to hospitals and doctors that says be on the lookout for Pertussis. We're seeing it our area or different parts of the state. Now is the time to be [cognizant] of what's going on.'\n\nGamble says Ohio County is not 1 of the 5 counties, but 1 county in the Ohio Valley has been affected, so all 55 counties are on alert. The 5 counties have not been revealed by state administrators, but Gamble says it is a serious, but preventable, issue. Gamble added whooping cough was a big deal back in the 1920s, when more than 100 000 people contracted the disease and more than 500 died from it. He says as living conditions improved and access to health care was easier, the numbers dwindled.\n\n[Byline: Crissy Clutter]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The morbidity and mortality of pertussis in older children and adults is quite small compared with that in infants under 12 months of age, especially those under 6 months of age. In the wake of the increase in cases in older children and adolescents attributed to unimmunized children and in those with waning immunity attributed to the acellular vaccine (as compared with the classic whole-cell killed vaccine), immunization programs have targeted the concept of cocooning the newborn infant by immunization of those around the infant and immunizing the pregnant woman in the 2nd or 3rd trimester.\n\nA newly released study now links an increased risk, albeit small, for the development of epilepsy in individuals who had a hospital-diagnosed case of pertussis:\n\nOlsen M, Thygesen SK, Ostergaard JR, et al: Hospital-Diagnosed Pertussis Infection in Children and Long-term Risk of Epilepsy.\nJAMA. 2015 Nov 3;314(17):1844-9. doi: 10.1001/jama.2015.13971.\n\nIMPORTANCE:\nPertussis is associated with encephalopathy and seizures in infants. However, the risk of childhood epilepsy following pertussis is unknown.\n\nOBJECTIVE:\nTo examine whether pertussis is associated with the long-term risk of epilepsy.\n\nDESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS:\nWe used individually linked data from population-based medical registries covering all Danish hospitals to identify a cohort of all patients with pertussis born between 1978 and 2011, followed up through 2011. We used the Civil Registration System to identify 10 individuals from the general population for each patient with pertussis, matched on sex and year of birth.\n\nEXPOSURES:\nInpatient or hospital-based outpatient diagnosis of pertussis.\n\nMAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES:\nCumulative incidence and hazard ratio of time to hospital-based epilepsy diagnosis (pertussis cohort vs general population cohort), adjusted for birth year, sex, maternal history of epilepsy, presence of congenital malformations, and gestational age. Unique personal identifiers permitted unambiguous data linkage and complete follow-up for death, emigration, and hospital contacts.\n\nRESULTS:\nWe identified 4700 patients with pertussis (48 percent male), of whom 90 developed epilepsy during the follow-up. The cumulative incidence of epilepsy at age 10 years was 1.7 percent (95 percent CI, 1.4-2.1) for patients with pertussis and 0.9 (95 percent CI, 0.8-1.0) for the matched comparison cohort. The corresponding adjusted overall hazard ratio was 1.7 (95 percent CI, 1.3-2.1).\n\nCONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE:\nIn Denmark, risk of epilepsy was increased in children with hospital-diagnosed pertussis infections compared with the general population; however, the absolute risk was low. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nA newly released study now links an increased risk, albeit small, for the development of epilepsy in individuals who had a hospital-diagnosed case of pertussis:\n\nOlsen M, Thygesen SK, Ostergaard JR, et al: Hospital-Diagnosed Pertussis Infection in Children and Long-term Risk of Epilepsy.\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n \n\nMAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES:\nCumulative incidence and hazard ratio of time to hospital-based epilepsy diagnosis (pertussis cohort vs general population cohort), adjusted for birth year, sex, maternal history of epilepsy, presence of congenital malformations, and gestational age. PERTUSSIS - USA (15)\n********************\n In this update:\n[1] New York (western counties)\n \n\nThe health department is reaching out to members of local Orthodox communities and adults throughout Ocean County and urging Tdap vaccination for everyone who has contact with small children, the Press report said\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: Patch.com [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/new-jersey/brick/whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-ocean-county-report-0\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough has been reported in Ocean County, according to a media report. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The morbidity and mortality of pertussis in older children and adults is quite small compared with that in infants under 12 months of age, especially those under 6 months of age. \n\n'When an outbreak occurs, we move quickly to quash that because if not, we can have an entire day care, school or community affected very quickly,' Howard Gamble of the Wheeling-Ohio County Health Department said, 'When you have an outbreak announced concerning public health, you become a little more vigilant. \n\nParents of children at the school on Webster Avenue in the city were sent a letter about the whooping cough cases. \nTo examine whether pertussis is associated with the long-term risk of epilepsy. [Byline: Rebecca Fath]\n\n--\n [Byline: Karen Wall]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n [Byline: Crissy Clutter]\n\n--\n There have been 52 confirmed cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, so far in 2015 in West Virginia, and health officials confirm 5 outbreaks of the disease. [4] West Virginia\n\n*****\n \n\nDESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS:\n \n\nEXPOSURES:\n \n\nRESULTS:\n \n\nCONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE:\n The cumulative incidence of epilepsy at age 10 years was 1.7 percent (95 percent CI, 1.4-2.1) for patients with pertussis and 0.9 (95 percent CI, 0.8-1.0) for the matched comparison cohort.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ocean County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rochester", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wheeling", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Albemarle County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lakewood", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3781837", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (14)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3781837", "date": "2015-11-10 17:29:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (14)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] New Mexico (Curry County)\n[3] New York (Kings County)\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Mon 9 Nov 2015\nSource: WFAA [edited]\nhttp://www.wfaa.com/story/news/health/2015/11/09/two-plano-high-school-students-diagnosed-with-whooping-cough/75490264/\n\n\nTwo high school students have been diagnosed with perrtussis, also known as whooping cough, the Plano Health Department confirmed Mon 9 Nov 2015.\n\nAccording to the health department, both students go to Clark High School. School officials send a message to parents about one case last Fri 6 Nov 2015. The 2nd case was confirmed Mon 9 Nov 2015. Officials did not say what grade the infected students were in or release any other identifying information.\n\nNorth Texas had a major pertussis outbreak in 2013. The CDC predicts the protection provided from the pertussis vaccine may last a decade or less. Those in whom the vaccine is no longer effective can become infected and transmit the disease to others through respiratory droplets.\n\nPertussis, in its early stages, mimics the common cold. It is often not suspected or diagnosed until the more-severe symptoms appear. Symptoms can include fits of rapid, high-pitched coughs, vomiting, and exhaustion. Antimicrobials can shorten the amount of time a patient is contagious. In most cases, children under 1 year old are most severely affected. Infants can receive the 1st vaccination at 2 months of age, though it takes several doses to attain protection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plano is located mostly within Collin County but a small portion extends into Denton County. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap: Collin County, Texas: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4306]\n\n******\n[2] New Mexico (Curry County)\nDate: Sun 2 Nov 2015\nSource: Deming Headlight [edited]\nhttp://www.demingheadlight.com/story/news/2015/11/02/whooping-cough-cases-increase/75060900/\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today [2 Nov 2015] an increase in whooping cough (pertussis) cases in Curry County. 13 cases have been confirmed in Curry County residents in 2015, including 7 school-aged children and 2 infants who were hospitalized. The current rate of pertussis in Curry County is 25.5 cases per 100 000 compared to 7.6 per 100 000 for 2010 through 2014.\n\nStatewide, 149 probable and confirmed whooping cough cases have been reported in 2015, which is approximately half the number of cases reported at the same time in 2014.\n\n'Whooping cough is very contagious and can cause serious cough illness, especially in infants too young to be fully vaccinated,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'Getting vaccinated is the best way to prevent whooping cough. When you get your flu shot, talk to your doctor or pharmacist to make sure you are up to date on your Tdap vaccination.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap: Curry County, New Mexico: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1537]\n\n******\n[3] New York (Kings County)\nDate: Mon 19 Oct 2015\nSource: NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene [edited]\nhttp://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/home/home.shtml\n\n\nAn outbreak of pertussis is ongoing among the Orthodox Jewish communities in Crown Heights, Williamsburg, and Borough Park, Brooklyn. From October 2014 through October 2015, 109 cases of pertussis have been reported to the New York City (NYC) Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH), with an increase in cases over the past 4 months. The majority of cases (90 percent) are children aged less than 19 years (median age 4 years), of whom 52 percent were unvaccinated or not up to date with pertussis-containing vaccine. Infants aged less than 1 year account for 34 percent (n=37) of cases. Of the 37 mothers of infants with pertussis, only 3 (8 percent) received the recommended tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccination during their most recent pregnancy. Five infants were hospitalized, including 1 who had pneumonia.\n\nTo control the outbreak, we urge you to:\n1. Recall patients who are not up to date with DTaP and Tdap vaccines\n2. Vaccinate pregnant women with Tdap during every pregnancy\n3. Report suspect cases\n4. Follow droplet precautions\n5. Obtain optimal specimens for diagnostic testing\n6. Provide prompt antimicrobial treatment and/or post-exposure prophylaxis\n\nDelays in on-time initiation and completion of the pertussis-containing vaccine series remain problematic in the affected communities, facilitating ongoing transmission. Young infants are at greatest risk of severe pertussis infection and its complications. Recommended strategies to protect these infants include ensuring that the mother receives Tdap during her pregnancy and that the infant starts the vaccine series on time at 2 months of age. Subsequent doses should be given 4, 6 and 15-18 months and at 4-6 years of age. Pertussis-containing vaccines are required for children to attend child care, head start, pre-kindergarten and both private and public school programs. Providers caring for patients in the Orthodox Jewish communities should recall patients aged 2 months and older and who have not received recommended pertussis containing vaccines for immediate vaccination.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection that begins with nonspecific upper respiratory symptoms that last for 7-10 days, followed by onset of cough. The classic pertussis cough includes persistent paroxysms (coughing fits), an inspiratory 'whoop,' apnea, and/or post-tussive vomiting. Cough may last weeks to months if not treated early.\n\nPeople with prior history of disease or vaccination may have milder symptoms and lack classic features of disease, making diagnosis more difficult. Maintain a high level of suspicion of pertussis in all patients with a persistent cough. In infants, apnea can be a prominent feature and complications of pertussis include pneumonia, encephalitis, and death. In adults, complications of pertussis include post-tussive syncope and rib fracture, in addition to persistent cough.\n\nIndividuals are infectious for up to 3 weeks or until 5 days after the start of effective antimicrobial treatment. If pertussis is suspected based on clinical presentation or known exposure to a pertussis case, clinicians should collect a nasopharyngeal (NP) swab and send it to a commercial laboratory for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing. Provide treatment after collecting diagnostic specimens. Do not wait for the results. Waiting for results facilitates disease transmission. Specimens are most likely to be positive when patients have a clinically compatible illness and specimens are collected within the first 3 weeks of cough onset and before completion of antimicrobials.\n\nDOHMH does not recommend serologic testing for pertussis because standardized tests are not available, making the results of commercially available tests difficult to interpret. More information about pertussis diagnostics can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/clinical/downloads/diagnosis-pcr-bestpractices.pdf.\n\nAntimicrobial treatment can alleviate symptoms and reduce pertussis transmission if given early in the course of illness. Treatment should be provided to persons aged 1 year or older within 3 weeks of cough onset and to infants less than 1 year of age and pregnant women within 6 weeks of cough onset. Children receiving treatment must stay home and cannot attend child care or school until they have received 5 days of antimicrobials; similarly, adults should also stay home for the same time period. Treatment beyond this period is not thought to alter the duration of cough nor transmission to others and is not recommended. Physicians should prescribe either a macrolide or, for macrolide allergic patients, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.\n\nAntimicrobials should also be provided to close contacts (e.g. household members) of confirmed pertussis cases as post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) to prevent illness and transmission. The antibacterial and dosing for treatment and prophylaxis are the same. If pertussis is strongly suspected, then PEP should begin while awaiting laboratory confirmation. For details, see Table 4 at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5414.pdf.\n\nIn healthcare facilities, a dose of Tdap is routinely recommended for all healthcare personnel (HCP). HCPs should observe droplet precautions, such as wearing surgical masks, while evaluating suspect pertussis cases. Precautions should be observed regardless of the vaccination status of HCP. HCP with known unprotected exposure to pertussis and who are likely to expose pregnant women or neonates should receive PEP. Other HCP should either receive PEP or be monitored daily for 21 days after pertussis exposure and treated if pertussis symptoms develop. Clinicians should report all suspected cases of pertussis to DOHMH. Do not wait until laboratory confirmation to report. Early reporting allows DOHMH to investigate cases and assist the facility in identifying those who need post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent further infections. To report a suspected case, clinicians should call DOHMH at 866-692-3641.\n\n[Authors: Jennifer Rosen, MD Director, Epidemiology and Surveillance Bureau of Immunization and Jane R. Zucker, MD, MSc Assistant Commissioner Bureau of Immunization]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This latter post from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has an excellent discussion on issues of management and testing. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap: Kings County, New York: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/41759]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [Authors: Jennifer Rosen, MD Director, Epidemiology and Surveillance Bureau of Immunization and Jane R. Zucker, MD, MSc Assistant Commissioner Bureau of Immunization]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This latter post from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has an excellent discussion on issues of management and testing. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap: Curry County, New Mexico: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1537]\n\n******\n Treatment should be provided to persons aged 1 year or older within 3 weeks of cough onset and to infants less than 1 year of age and pregnant women within 6 weeks of cough onset. Provide prompt antimicrobial treatment and/or post-exposure prophylaxis\n\nDelays in on-time initiation and completion of the pertussis-containing vaccine series remain problematic in the affected communities, facilitating ongoing transmission. \n\nAntimicrobials should also be provided to close contacts (e.g. household members) of confirmed pertussis cases as post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) to prevent illness and transmission. The number of cases confirmed compared to just a year ago was way up, especially in northern Kentucky. Those cases were reported in both children and adults, but public health experts were especially concerned those infected will transmit the virus to babies.\n\nLocal 12 News got a report from the northern Kentucky Health Department that said compared to a year ago at the same time, there were 2 confirmed cases reported. In 2015 already in August, there were 9.\n\nThis was a big concern for those who were pregnant or taking care of young children. Local 12 News spent the day in the maternity ward at Saint Elizabeth Healthcare in Edgewood [Kentucky] to share more on what they want every new mom to know. Christina Rust, education specialist at Saint Elizabeth Healthcare, said, 'By immunizing the mother during her pregnancy she can pass those antibodies on to the baby.' Whooping cough is a respiratory infection which can cause serious complications. Pertussis is fatal in most cases for babies under 3 months of age. So those around [the newborn baby] must get the pertussis vaccine so whooping cough can't be transmitted to [the newborn] from someone else. 'That's called a cocoon. So we are making a cocoon of immunized moms, dads, uncles, aunts around the baby,' said Rust.\n\nAdults only need to have that vaccine once and it will protect them and those around them. A quick reminder for everyone as this starts to circulate and children go back to school; hand-washing is the best defense. Whooping cough is highly contagious. The initial symptoms of whooping cough are a lot like the common cold but if parents hear that 'hoop' sound they need to seek medical attention for them or anyone around them. Doctors are on high alert to diagnose this infection and are being asked to recommend the vaccine for anyone who has not had it between the ages of 10 and 60. The CDC recommended a booster vaccine called T-dap for children, at age 11 or 12. As well as for all adolescents and adults who did not receive the vaccine as a preteen. This vaccine helps to prevent whooping cough, as well as tetanus and diphtheria.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pertussis immunization recommendations given in the news report above are incomplete. The following is recommended by the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/recs-summary.htm):\n\nExpectant mothers should receive Tdap during EACH pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months, and 4 through 6 years of age. Tdap should be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should also receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]", "summary": "In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. \n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pertussis immunization recommendations given in the news report above are incomplete.
