Pertussis is fatal in most cases for babies under 3 months of age.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2015-09-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Edgewood", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENTUCKY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "INDIANA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3632579", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Spain", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3632579", "date": "2015-09-08 19:18:37", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SPAIN\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 7 Sep 2015\nSource: El Diario, Espana [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.eldiario.es/sociedad/tos-ferina-acelera-contagio-Espana_0_426958022.html\n\n\nWhooping cough or pertussis, a disease that sounds ancient but is still around, is accelerating the pace of contagion in Spain. The infection is growing.\n\nIn just 8 months in 2015, there were more cases recorded than in all of 2014. Additionally, in 32 weeks, the Carlos III Institute certified 4822 new cases; 1699 more are ill from this disease than in the 12 months of 2014, a jump of 54 percent without finishing this year.\n\nDoctors have spent months reporting people increasingly infected by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, which causes the disease. The rebound has been continuing since at least 2011. In 2011, by comparison, Carlos III Institute in late December had more than 800 cases. 'It is also true that now diagnostic capability is greater,' said officials.\n\nDr. Amos Garcia Rojas, president of the Spanish Vaccinology Association (AEV), said that 'the original vaccine for pertussis (whole cell) had a lot of power but had a high rate of side effects. The new generation vaccine (acellular) reduces this problem, but immune response is lower than with the other one.'\n\nThere is a worldwide shortage of pertussis vaccine production, and there may not be enough vaccine available to maintain immunization schedules.\n\nThe Spanish Medicines Agency (AEMPS) warned in May [2015] this year that the 'holders marketing vaccines containing the antigen against pertussis have been reporting supply problems because of difficulties in manufacturing.' The patent laboratories share the market (Sanofi Pasteur and GlaxoSmithKine), and cannot meet needs for vaccine.\n\nIn France, which has also suffered supply problems, it has been suggested that vaccinating pregnant women in the last trimester may be behind the lack of product sales. The vaccine is produced by biological processes, not chemical ones, which take time.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in the number of acellular pertussis vaccines given in a lifetime has expanded to one in adolescence and an additional Tdap in adulthood, as well as immunization during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy to assist in protecting infants less than 6 months of age, where much of the morbidity and mortality occurs, and may be straining the production capacity for the pertussis toxoids. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in the number of acellular pertussis vaccines given in a lifetime has expanded to one in adolescence and an additional Tdap in adulthood, as well as immunization during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy to assist in protecting infants less than 6 months of age, where much of the morbidity and mortality occurs, and may be straining the production capacity for the pertussis toxoids. \n\nThere is a worldwide shortage of pertussis vaccine production, and there may not be enough vaccine available to maintain immunization schedules. \n\nThe Spanish Medicines Agency (AEMPS) warned in May [2015] this year that the 'holders marketing vaccines containing the antigen against pertussis have been reporting supply problems because of difficulties in manufacturing.' \n\nDr. Amos Garcia Rojas, president of the Spanish Vaccinology Association (AEV), said that 'the original vaccine for pertussis (whole cell) had a lot of power but had a high rate of side effects. \n\nDoctors have spent months reporting people increasingly infected by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, which causes the disease. PERTUSSIS - SPAIN\n*****************\n Additionally, in 32 weeks, the Carlos III Institute certified 4822 new cases; 1699 more are ill from this disease than in the 12 months of 2014, a jump of 54 percent without finishing this year.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1699-03-25 00:00:00", "4822-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3606181", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3606181", "date": "2015-08-27 19:40:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (CANBERRA) NEW ZEALAND (SOUTH ISLAND)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Australia (Canberra)\n[2] New Zealand (South Island)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Canberra)\nDate: Wed 26 Aug 2015\nSource: The Canberra Times [edited]\nhttp://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/whooping-cough-cases-top-270-with-new-reports-at-hawker-primary-school-20150826-gj80jf.html\n\n\nMore than 270 Canberrans have been diagnosed with pertussis (whooping cough) this year [2015], with 3 cases reported at the Hawker Primary School this month [August 2015]. Parents at the northside school were alerted by management this week with whooping cough also reported at the Turner School and Orana Steiner School in both April and May of 2015.\n\nAn ACT [Australian Capital Territory] Health spokesman said an increase in notifications was recorded between March 2015 and May 2015, although new cases had declined since then. 'Schools are encouraged to distribute information and place notices in school newsletters if a case of whooping cough occurs in the school,' he said.\n\nAn ACT Education and Training spokesman said parents were required to notify schools as soon as they believed their child may have whooping cough. 'Schools must then notify the Chief Health Officer,' he said. 'Principals advise parents or carers of confirmed outbreaks at the school by newsletter or letter to parents or care deliverers.' The ACT Health spokesman said vaccination was the most effective way to avoid the whooping cough infection. 'However, immunity does fade over time and it is still possible to get whooping cough even if you have been vaccinated in the past,' he said.\n\nThe infection is cyclical in nature with the last outbreak in the ACT occurring in 2010-11.\n\n'Vaccination is recommended for all Australian children with the 1st dose of pertussis-containing vaccine given from 6 to 8 weeks of age, followed by doses at 4 and 6 months, a booster from 3-4 years of age, and a further booster at 12-17 years of age,' the health spokesman said. 'A booster dose of pertussis containing vaccine for 18-month-old children is to be added to the national immunisation program schedule later this year [2015].'\n\n[Byline: Henry Belot]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/294. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (South Island)\nDate: Sun 23 Aug 2015\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/national/health/71370118/whooping-cough-outbreak-continues-to-spread-through-south\n\n\nThe whooping cough outbreak in the south is continuing to spread. Over 200 people have reported having whooping cough in the last month, and the number is expected to rise. The outbreak is spreading across the South Island, after being centered in Central Otago. An increasing number of cases are being detected in Southland and further afield in Otago, including Dunedin.\n\nHistorically, a whooping cough outbreak happens once every 4 years -- with the last taking place in 2011/12. While the number of daily reports of patients believed to have whooping cough is declining, health officials expect the numbers to rise again in weeks to come.\n\nNaomi Gough, the public health physician for the Southern District Health Board, said the total number of notifications of whooping cough has been 200 over 4 weeks. Over the last week there had been less than 5 notifications per day of people having whooping cough. At the peak of the outbreak, it was about 15 people per day. A notification included suspected cases, and only about 1/3 of notifications have been confirmed as whooping cough. She said the difference between suspected and confirmed cases highlighted the fact it was a 'difficult disease to diagnose and doctors are being vigilant for possible cases'.\n\nIn about half of the cases, the patient had not been immunized against whooping cough, or their vaccinations were not up-to-date.\n\n[Byline: Ashleigh Stewart]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/23916. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nA recently published paper in PLoS Computational Biology suggests waning immunity from the acellular pertussis vaccine as the main reason for the dramatic increase in pertussis cases:\nGambhir M, Clark TA, Cauchemez S, et al: A change in vaccine efficacy and duration of protection explains recent rises in pertussis incidence in the United States. PLoS Comput Biol. 2015; 11(4): e1004138. doi: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004138; http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004138:\n\nAbstract\n--------\nOver the past 10 years, the incidence of pertussis in the USA has risen steadily, with 2012 seeing the highest case number since 1955. There has also been a shift over the same time period in the age group reporting the largest number of cases (aside from infants), from adolescents to 7-11 year olds. We use epidemiological modelling and a large case incidence dataset to explain the upsurge. We investigate several hypotheses for the upsurge in pertussis cases by fitting a suite of dynamic epidemiological models to incidence data from the National Notifiable Disease Surveillance System (NNDSS) between 1990-2009, as well as incidence data from a variety of sources from 1950-1989.\n\nWe find that:\n1. The best-fitting model is one in which vaccine efficacy and duration of protection of the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine is lower than that of the whole-cell (wP) vaccine, (efficacy of the 1st 3 doses 80 per cent [95 per cent CI (confidence interval): 78-82] versus 90 per cent [95 per cent CI: 87-94]);\n2. Increasing the rate at which disease is reported to NNDSS is not sufficient to explain the upsurge; and\n3. 2010-2012 disease incidence is predicted well.\n\nIn this study, we use all available USA surveillance data to:\n- fit a set of mathematical models and determine which best explains these data, and\n- determine the epidemiological and vaccine-related parameter values of this model.\n\nWe find evidence of a difference in efficacy and duration of protection between the 2 vaccine types, wP and aP (aP efficacy and duration lower than wP). Future refinement of the model presented here will allow for an exploration of alternative vaccination strategies such as different age-spacings, further booster doses, and cocooning.' - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The best-fitting model is one in which vaccine efficacy and duration of protection of the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine is lower than that of the whole-cell (wP) vaccine, (efficacy of the 1st 3 doses 80 per cent [95 per cent CI (confidence interval): 78-82] versus 90 per cent [95 per cent CI: 87-94]);\n2. All 4 patients were admitted to the Taaone hospital. 2 are from Bora Bora and 2 from Moorea. According to the health authorities, an active search for secondary cases was carried out for each of them and an antibiotic chemoprophylaxis was offered to the people who had been in contact with the 4 patients.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious infectious disease. Pertussis is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella_. It is an airborne disease. Symptoms include runny nose, fever, and cough.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, see moderator comments in prior ProMED-mail posts.\n\nFrench Polynesia is an overseas collectivity of the French Republic. It is composed of 118 dispersed islands and atolls, 67 of which are inhabited, stretching over an expanse of more than 2000 kilometers (1200 mi) in the South Pacific Ocean. It is divided into 5 groups of islands: The Society Islands archipelago composed of the Windward Islands and the Leeward Islands, the Tuamotu Archipelago, the Gambier Islands, the Marquesas Islands, and the Austral Islands (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Polynesia). Tahiti, which is located within the Society Islands, is the most populous island and the seat of the capital of the collectivity, Pape'ete, with a population of 133 627 inhabitants in 2012 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papeete).\n\nTaaone Hospital is in Pirae, a commune in the suburbs of Papeete (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirae). Bora Bora is an island in the Leeward group and Moorea is one of the Windward Islands, both parts of the Society Islands, (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bora_Bora and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo%27orea).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the islands in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/382. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, see moderator comments in prior ProMED-mail posts. PERTUSSIS - FRENCH POLYNESIA\n****************************\n \n\n\nSince the beginning of the year [2015], 4 people, including 3 babies younger than 3-month-old, have contracted pertussis in French Polynesia. \n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the islands in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/382. \n\n--\n According to the health authorities, an active search for secondary cases was carried out for each of them and an antibiotic chemoprophylaxis was offered to the people who had been in contact with the 4 patients.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the French Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Gambier Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Windward Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Marquesas Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Society Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Austral Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Leeward Islands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3537082", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (11): (KS) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537082", "date": "2015-07-26 20:07:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (KANSAS), UPDATE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 25 Jul 2015\nSource: The Hutchinson News [edited]\nhttp://www.hutchnews.com/news/local_state_news/whooping-cough-outbreak-won-t-give-up/article_be45552e-7d31-5647-b2e0-1f76fa58365f.html\n\n\nReno County's whooping cough outbreak continues, local health officials said, with the number of suspected pertussis cases now topping 70.\n\nThe persistent nature of the outbreak has health officials concerned that it won't be contained before school starts back up, creating fear of a potential 'micro-outbreak,' said Health Department Director Nick Baldetti. The last new case the agency began investigating was Friday [24 Jul 2015], Baldetti said. An outbreak is not considered contained until 2 full cycles of the disease -- a cycle is 21 days -- pass without a new case. At this point, that would be 4 Sep [2015].\n\n'I'm not confident to say we won't get any more,' Baldetti said. 'It seems we get one to 3 new cases a day. It just seems like it builds up. We don't have any for several days, and then we get 3 or 4.'\n\nWhooping cough is a contagious respiratory disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria. Initial symptoms include runny nose, sneezing and a mild cough, which may seem like a typical cold, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Usually, the cough slowly becomes more severe, and eventually the patient may experience bouts of rapid, violent coughing followed by the 'whooping' sound that gives the disease its common name when trying to take a breath. The disease can cause serious and sometimes life-threatening complications, permanent disability, and even death, especially in infants and young children.\n\nAs of Friday [24 Jul 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment listed Reno County with 41 confirmed or probable cases of pertussis, accounting for 20 percent of all cases in the state. That was up from 18 on Jun 29 [2015]. The state figures showed additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno -- Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick -- as well as in 2 other counties in the region.\n\nThe Reno County Health Department is actively working with area school districts to be prepared, 'but we can't put the onus on schools to get out in front of it. We hope to have (vaccination) clinics for Buhler, Haven and Nickerson [3 of the 7 Reno County school districts],' Baldetti said. '(USD) 308 [Unified School District 308, also called Hutchinson] has committed to not allow anyone to enroll without the vaccination or an acceptance form.'\n\nWhile the pertussis vaccine offers '90 percent protection' from the disease, new research shows antibodies decline in 2-5 years. That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The health department has at least 450 doses of vaccine and is offering the shots free.\n\n'It's really important for people to be proactive and be on guard for symptoms,' Baldetti said. 'Anyone suspected of being sick needs [to be] checked immediately. We cannot let cold symptoms be unchecked. It's too widespread now; it's better to be safe than sorry.' They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.\n\n'There's serious concern for a potential exponential spread through our schools,' Baldetti said. 'When they get back to school, it will be concentrated, so we want to focus on that group.' Active cases, however, range from infants to high school to adults 'and everywhere in between,' he said. 'We're not isolating our effort to elementary, middle or high school, but all levels of education, daycare providers, churches and businesses. This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,' he said. 'It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.'\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). A map of Kansas counties is available at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml.\n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_County,_Kansas#Education). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]", "summary": "In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). \n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) \n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). \n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhile the pertussis vaccine offers '90 percent protection' from the disease, new research shows antibodies decline in 2-5 years. As of Friday [24 Jul 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment listed Reno County with 41 confirmed or probable cases of pertussis, accounting for 20 percent of all cases in the state. \n\n\nReno County's whooping cough outbreak continues, local health officials said, with the number of suspected pertussis cases now topping 70. \n\nThe persistent nature of the outbreak has health officials concerned that it won't be contained before school starts back up, creating fear of a potential 'micro-outbreak,' said Health Department Director Nick Baldetti. \n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The state figures showed additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno -- Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick -- as well as in 2 other counties in the region. \n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\n \n\nWhooping cough is a contagious respiratory disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria. They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1965-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2070-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-06-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Reno County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nickerson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=kansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Midwestern United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3617491", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (12): (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3617491", "date": "2015-09-02 03:22:37", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (12): (ARIZONA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 1 Sep 2015\nSource: Eastern Arizona Courier [edited]\nhttp://www.eacourier.com/news/graham-keeping-close-eye-on-greenlee-pertussis-cases/article_43425666-4ded-11e5-9d14-93621c811cfc.html\n\n\nGraham County health officials said they're keeping watch on the number of pertussis cases in Greenlee County, in hopes of stopping an outbreak from occurring here. 'Our local health-care providers and schools are aware of the pertussis outbreak in Greenlee County and are taking proper measures to bring this occurrence to a close,' said Brian Douglas, Graham County Health director.\n\nThere are 8 confirmed cases of pertussis -- known as whooping cough -- in Greenlee County, with contact in Graham. In an e-mail, Douglas said pertussis 'is highly contagious, and one of the most commonly occurring vaccine-preventable diseases in the United States. People with pertussis usually spread the disease by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others, who then breathe in the pertussis bacteria. Many infants who get pertussis are infected by older siblings, parents, or other caregivers who might not even know they have the disease. Pertussis is most severe for infants. This is the age group we're most concerned about when it comes to this infection.'\n\nHe said pertussis occurs in a cyclical pattern, with the number of cases peaking every three to five years. He also said that even with the success of pertussis vaccines, people continue to get pertussis because no vaccine is guaranteed 100 percent effective.\n\nPertussis symptoms include: cold-like symptoms for the 1st one to 2 weeks with cough becoming more severe; after the initial few weeks, bursts of numerous, rapid coughs with difficulty in catching one's breath after the coughing episode; [and] possible vomiting from sticky mucus.\n\nTo reduce the risk of contracting pertussis, parents need to make sure everyone in the household is up to date with recommended pertussis vaccines (DTaP for infants/children and Tdap for adolescents/adults). Those planning on becoming pregnant or who are currently pregnant should talk to a doctor about getting the Tdap vaccine. To avoid spreading the disease to infants, make sure all people around the baby are vaccinated with Tdap, including siblings, grandparents, aunts, uncles, nannies, caregivers, child-care staff, etc. People with a cough illness or other communicable disease should always stay away from young infants.\n\nFor information regarding the signs and symptoms of pertussis, go to the CDC website at http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/ or contact the Graham County Health Department at 928-428-1962.\n\n[Byline: David Bell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to say the ages of the 8 pertussis cases in Greenlee County, Arizona, or their pertussis vaccination status.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months, and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old.\n\nAs of 31 Dec 2014, 28 660 cases of pertussis (with an incidence rate of 9.1 per 100 000) were reported in the US during 2014, which is an 18 percent increase, compared to provisional numbers that were reported at the same time in 2013 (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). The US state of Arizona had 464 cases with an incidence rate of 7.0 per 100 000 in 2014 (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf).\n\nThe state of Arizona can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9143. Greenlee County, where the 8 cases of confirmed pertussis resided, is the least populous county in Arizona with a population of 8437 in 2010; this county is located in the southeastern part of the US state of Arizona, on the border with the state of New Mexico (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenlee_County,_Arizona). Its economy is dominated by one of the largest copper mines in the world. Greenlee County is bordered to the west by Graham County, with a population of 37 220 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graham_County,_Arizona#Adjacent_counties). A map of Arizona counties can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/arizona-county-map.gif. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Because infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. \n\nPertussis symptoms include: cold-like symptoms for the 1st one to 2 weeks with cough becoming more severe; after the initial few weeks, bursts of numerous, rapid coughs with difficulty in catching one's breath after the coughing episode; [and] possible vomiting from sticky mucus.\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to say the ages of the 8 pertussis cases in Greenlee County, Arizona, or their pertussis vaccination status. ' Our local health-care providers and schools are aware of the pertussis outbreak in Greenlee County and are taking proper measures to bring this occurrence to a close,' said Brian Douglas, Graham County Health director.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2015-09-01 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "8437-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greenlee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Graham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Graham County Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Graham County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3446509", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3446509", "date": "2015-06-18 09:55:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (10): (KANSAS) FATAL, UPDATE\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Jun 2015\nSource: KSNW-TV [edited]\nhttp://ksn.com/2015/06/16/27-confirmed-cases-of-whooping-cough-in-2015-in-barton-county/\n\n\nThere have been 27 cases of whooping cough confirmed by the KDHE [Kansas Department of Health and Environment] in Barton County this year [2015]. The outbreak in Barton County started in December last year [2014] when an infant died from whooping cough. When more cases were confirmed, Barton County's Health Department held a free TDaP [DTaP] vaccination clinic and had over 1000 people immunized.\n\nWhooping cough can appear just like a cold or allergies when it first starts. 'It depends on if it's associated with a low-grade fever; pertussis does have just kind of like cold-like symptoms, viral-like symptoms in the beginning. If that progresses and doesn't go away you need to go see your provider,' said Debra Brockel a physician's assistant with Clara Barton Hospital.\n\nJust because it's summer doesn't mean that whooping cough will be less prevalent. 'Just because school isn't in session doesn't mean kids aren't in close proximity; they're at the pool; they're at camp, so that doesn't lessen the risk any,' said Brockel.\n\nImmunizations are the key to preventing whooping cough, but good hand-washing can help.\n\nSo far, there have been 143 total confirmed cases of whooping cough in the state this year [2015].\n\n[Byline: Molly Hadfield]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old.\n\nIn 2014, Kansas reported 357 cases (incidence rate 12.3 cases per 100 000 population); whereas the nationally the incidence rate was 9.1 per 100 000 (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf).\n\nFor a further discussion of pertussis, see the moderators' comments in prior ProMED-mail pertussis posts.\n\nKansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a US state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas).\nBarton County, with a population of 27 674 in 2010, is located in the middle of Kansas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barton_County,_Kansas).\nFor a map of Kansas showing the location of Barton County, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barton_County,_Kansas#/media/File:Map_of_Kansas_highlighting_Barton_County.svg. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In 2014, Kansas reported 357 cases (incidence rate 12.3 cases per 100 000 population); whereas the nationally the incidence rate was 9.1 per 100 000 (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). \n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. So far, there have been 143 total confirmed cases of whooping cough in the state this year [2015].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1965-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-06-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Midwestern United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TDaP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=kansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3537081", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (03): (ON) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537081", "date": "2015-07-26 20:09:02", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (03): (ONTARIO), UPDATE\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: Blackburn News [edited]\nhttp://blackburnnews.com/midwestern-ontario/midwestern-ontario-news/2015/07/24/whooping-cough-outbreak-plagues-huron-and-bruce-counties/\n\n\nLocal health units are trying to control an outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] in Bruce and Huron Counties [Ontario, Canada]. There are 39 cases in southern Bruce County, mainly in an under-immunized population. Huron County Health unit is also reporting a significant number of cases in the north part of the county.\n\nThe serious bacterial infection of the respiratory system is easily spread through coughing and sneezing. It starts with an irritating cough, which becomes more severe, and is often following by vomiting. It can last longer than 2 months. A characteristic crowing or high-pitched whoop may occur during the cough. Pregnant women and infants not fully immunized are at risk. Up-to-date immunizations can prevent infection. Complications may include pneumonia, seizures, brain damage, chronic lung damage and occasionally deaths in infants.\n\nPertussis is preventable through immunization. It is one of the 1st set of immunizations recommended for all babies. It is also included in the Ontario Immunization Of School Pupils Act. It is highly recommended that immunizations of all family members, including grandparents, be up-to-date for pertussis before arrival of a new baby into a family. Parents are asked to check their child's immunization status to ensure it is current. Routine childhood immunizations include the pertussis vaccine. Adults can receive one dose of pertussis containing vaccine along with tetanus and diphtheria.\n\nLocal hospital emergency departments, family physicians and nurse practitioners have been notified of this outbreak. The Grey Bruce Health Unit is continuing to hold assessment and immunization clinics to immunize families in the outbreak area and to ensure the follow-up of cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Huron County, with a population of 59 000 in 2011, is located in the Southwestern subregion of the Canadian province of Ontario, on the shore of Lake Huron (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huron_County,_Ontario). Bruce is an adjacent county is in Southwestern Ontario, north of Huron County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwestern_Ontario).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260.]", "summary": "In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). \n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). \n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. PERTUSSIS - CANADA (03): (ONTARIO), UPDATE\n******************************************\n Source: Blackburn News [edited]\nhttp://blackburnnews.com/midwestern-ontario/midwestern-ontario-news/2015/07/24/whooping-cough-outbreak-plagues-huron-and-bruce-counties/\n\n\nLocal health units are trying to control an outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] in Bruce and Huron Counties It is highly recommended that immunizations of all family members, including grandparents, be up-to-date for pertussis before arrival of a new baby into a family. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "1965-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bruce", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huron County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bruce County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Southwestern Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3347419", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (05): waning immunity, further comments", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3347419", "date": "2015-05-07 16:09:51", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (05): WANING IMMUNITY, FURTHER COMMENT\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 6 May 2015\nFrom: Frits R Mooi <frits.mooi@rivm.nl> [edited]\n\n\n[Ref: ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (04): waning immunity, comment 20150506.3344844]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn response to the suggestion by Dr Benjamin, 'to look at a hybrid immunization approach which utilizes acellular vaccine for the 1st 3 or even 4 doses (ages 2, 4, 6, and 15-18 months) to confer immunity while avoiding the adverse event more common in infancy, with a whole cell vaccine administered at 4-5 years of age, when the vaccine is better tolerated, thus conferring longer lasting immunity', I would like to refer to the excellent study by Sheridan and co-workers (1). These authors show that the 1st vaccine used to prime the infant immune system largely determines the efficacy of subsequent vaccinations. This study suggests that, in contrast to what Dr Benjamin suggests, for the 1st vaccination a WCV [whole-cell vaccine] should be used, or a vaccine (to be developed) which primes the immune system in a similar way as the WCV.\n\nAnother important intervention is, of course, maternal vaccination which has been shown to be safe and very effective in the UK (2, 3). Indeed, in the short term, this seems to me the only measure possible to protect infants too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nFinally, the resurgence of pertussis is probably multi-factorial, whereby the limited duration of immunity conferred by current vaccines is aggravated by pathogen adaptation (4).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Sheridan SL, Ware RS, Grimwood K, Lambert SB: Number and order of whole cell pertussis vaccines in infancy and disease protection. JAMA 2012; 308(5): 454-6 [available at http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1273011].\n2. Amirthalingam G, Andrews N, Campbell H, et al: Effectiveness of maternal pertussis vaccination in England: An observational study. Lancet 2014; 384(9953): 1521-8 [available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(14)60686-3/fulltext].\n3. Dabrera G, Amirthalingam G, Andrews N, et al: A case-control study to estimate the effectiveness of maternal pertussis vaccination in protecting newborn infants in England and Wales, 2012-2013. Clin Infect Dis 2015; 60(3): 333-7 [available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/lookup/pmid?view=long&pmid=25332078].\n4. Mooi FR, Van Der Maas NA, De Melker HE: Pertussis resurgence: Waning immunity and pathogen adaptation -- Two sides of the same coin. Epidemiol Infect 2014; 142(4): 685-94 [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23406868].\n\n--\nProf Dr Frits R Mooi\nCentre for Infectious Diseases Control\nNational Institute of Public Health and the Environment (RIVM)\nBilthoven\nThe Netherlands\n<frits.mooi@rivm.nl>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 6 May 2015\nFrom: James Cherry <JCherry@mednet.ucla.edu> [edited]\n\n\nGiving DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis] vaccine first and then DTwP [diphtheria, tetanus, and whole-cell pertussis] vaccine is not the solution because this leads to linked-epitope suppression (the recipient will never see the many other protective antigens that are in whole cell vaccines). The 2012 Sheridan paper in JAMA demonstrates this (see http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1273011). In addition, DTwP is less well tolerated with increasing age. There is no available licensed DTwP in the USA.\n\n--\nJames D Cherry, MD, MSc\nDistinguished Research Professor of Pediatrics\nDavid Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA\nLos Angeles, CA\nUSA\n<JCherry@mednet.ucla.edu>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Mooi and Cherry for their expert comments regarding pertussis immunization. I am honored to have 2 esteemed experts in the field directly comment on current pertussis vaccination and the role it has played in the upswing in _ Bordetella pertussis_ infections.\n\nThe Sheridan paper, a letter to the editor in JAMA (Sheridan SL, Ware RS, Grimwood K, Lambert SB: Number and order of whole cell pertussis vaccines in infancy and disease protection. JAMA 2012; 308(5): 454-6; available at http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1273011) is reproduced below:\n\nTo the Editor: Due to their lower rate of adverse events, acellular pertussis vaccines (diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis; DTaP) replaced whole cell vaccines (diphtheria-tetanus-whole cell pertussis; DTwP) in many developed countries during the 1990s. DTaP became available in Queensland, Australia, in 1996 and replaced DTwP for publicly funded primary course immunizations delivered at ages 2 months, 4 months, and 6 months in March 1999. This meant children born in 1998 could receive a primary course consisting of only DTwP, only DTaP, or a mixed schedule.\n\nSimilar to North America (1), Australia is experiencing a sustained pertussis epidemic (2) with the highest incidence rates in Queensland during 2011 in children aged 6 to 11 years. The recent changes in pertussis epidemiology may be related to the shift from DTwP to DTaP. To test this hypothesis, we compared pertussis reporting rates by primary course vaccination in the 1998 birth cohort.\n\nMethods\n-------\nReporting pertussis cases to the health department is mandatory in Queensland. For children born in 1998, we calculated pertussis reporting rates in both the preepidemic (1998-2008) and outbreak periods (2009-2011), by number and order of DTwP doses given before their first birthday. We linked data from the Queensland vaccination register (QVR) with case reports of pertussis. The QVR is not a population-based register so we could not construct a group of wholly unvaccinated children for comparison. Children were censored following initial reporting. We calculated average annual incidence rates, incidence rate differences, incidence rate ratios, and 95 percent confidence intervals using Stata version 12 (StataCorp). The Queensland Children's Health Services ethics committee approved the study.\n\nResults\n-------\nOf 58 233 children born in 1998 identified in the QVR, 40 694 (69.9 percent) received at least 3 doses of any pertussis-containing vaccine during the 1st year from a Queensland vaccine service provider and were included in the analysis. Overall, 267 1st pertussis cases were reported from this cohort between 1999 and 2011; 2 2nd reports were excluded.\n\nChildren who received a 3-dose DTaP primary course had higher rates of pertussis than those who received a 3-dose DTwP primary course in the preepidemic and outbreak periods (Table and Figure [available at the source URL above. - Mod.LL]). Among those who received mixed courses, rates in the current epidemic were highest for children receiving DTaP as their 1st dose. This pattern remained when looking at subgroups with 1 or 2 DTwP doses in the 1st year of life, although it did not reach statistical significance. Children who received a mixed course with DTwP as the initial dose had incidence rates that were between rates for the pure course DTwP and DTaP cohorts.\n\nComment\n-------\nInfant priming with DTwP was associated with a lower risk of subsequent pertussis than DTaP only primed children in this cohort. This difference persisted for more than a decade, being evident in preepidemic and outbreak periods. A primary course using even a moderately effective DTwP vaccine may be more protective than DTaP (3). In the preacellular era, Australia used a locally produced DTwP vaccine with very good to excellent effectiveness (4). Our findings suggest the most important factor, in this cohort, may be the initial vaccine received.\n\nIt is unlikely our findings during the current outbreak are the result of detection bias because this would require health care-seeking behavior, or the likelihood of laboratory testing or reporting, to be associated with the primary course received by children over a decade previously.\n\nPossible explanations for our findings could include antigenic shifts in circulating Bordetella pertussis strains (2) or the different immune responses from acellular and whole-cell priming (5). The lesser protection provided by DTaP, both as the initial vaccine or full primary course, may be due to linked epitope suppression, when the initial exposure locks in the immune response to certain epitopes and inhibits response to other linked epitopes on subsequent exposures (6).\n\nThe challenge for future pertussis vaccine development is to address the benefit-risk trade-off highlighted by our study, and to develop vaccines that induce long-lasting protection from the first dose, without the adverse events associated with DTwP use.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Witt MA, Katz PH, Witt DJ: Unexpected limited durability of immunity following acellular pertussis vaccination in preadolescents in a North American outbreak. Clin Infect Dis. 2012; 54(12): 1730-5 available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/54/12/1730.\n2. Octavia S, Sintchenko V, Gilbert GL, et al: Newly emerging clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ carrying prn2 and ptxP3 alleles implicated in Australian pertussis epidemic in 2008-2010. J Infect Dis. 2012; 205(8): 1220-4; available at http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/205/8/1220.\n3. Zhang L, Prietsch SOM, Axelsson I, Halperin SA: Acellular vaccines for preventing whooping cough in children. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2011; (1): CD001478; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21249646.\n4. Torvaldsen S, Simpson JM, McIntyre PB: Effectiveness of pertussis vaccination in New South Wales, Australia, 1996-1998. Eur J Epidemiol. 2003; 18(1): 63-9; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12705625.\n5. Mascart F, Hainaut M, Peltier A, et al: Modulation of the infant immune responses by the first pertussis vaccine administrations. Vaccine. 2007; 25(2): 391-8; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12705625.\n6. Cherry JD, Heininger U, Richards DM, et al: Antibody response patterns to Bordetella pertussis antigens in vaccinated (primed) and unvaccinated (unprimed) young children with pertussis. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2010; 17(5): 741-7; available at http://cdli.asm.org/content/17/5/741.full.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n JAMA 2012; 308(5): 454-6; available at http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1273011) is reproduced below:\n\nTo the Editor: Due to their lower rate of adverse events, acellular pertussis vaccines (diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis; DTaP) replaced whole cell vaccines (diphtheria-tetanus-whole cell pertussis; DTwP) in many developed countries during the 1990s. In response to the suggestion by Dr Benjamin, 'to look at a hybrid immunization approach which utilizes acellular vaccine for the 1st 3 or even 4 doses (ages 2, 4, 6, and 15-18 months) to confer immunity while avoiding the adverse event more common in infancy, with a whole cell vaccine administered at 4-5 years of age, when the vaccine is better tolerated, thus conferring longer lasting immunity', I would like to refer to the excellent study by Sheridan and co-workers (1). \n\nChildren who received a 3-dose DTaP primary course had higher rates of pertussis than those who received a 3-dose DTwP primary course in the preepidemic and outbreak periods (Table and Figure [available at the source URL above. \n\n\nGiving DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis] vaccine first and then DTwP [diphtheria, tetanus, and whole-cell pertussis] vaccine is not the solution because this leads to linked-epitope suppression (the recipient will never see the many other protective antigens that are in whole cell vaccines).
