The number of patients diagnosed with the contagious infection has also risen across the Black Country and Staffordshire [West Midlands].\n\nWhooping cough -- a bacterial infection of the lungs and airways -- affects all ages, but newborns and infants under 3 months of age are at highest risk of severe complications and death.\n\nDuring 2014 there were 135 cases in the West Midlands -- 39 of those were in the Black Country and Staffordshire. This is up by 42 per cent compared with 2013's figures when there were a total of 95 cases in the West Midlands.\n\nHealth chiefs have urged pregnant women to have a vaccination to protect themselves and their unborn babies against the risk of the infection, also known as pertussis. It protects the baby from developing whooping cough in the first few weeks of life as the mother passes immunity on to her unborn child, protecting the youngster until they receive their first vaccination at 2 months old. All pregnant women are offered vaccination against whooping cough when they are 28-38 weeks pregnant.\n\nIn 2014, the highest number of cases were diagnosed in Sandwell and Walsall with 12 patients in each borough suffering from the infection. This is compared with 4 cases and 6 cases respectively in 2013. The figure has also risen in Wolverhampton from 2 to 3 cases.\n\nBut the number of people being diagnosed fell in Dudley from 10 cases to 4, in Cannock from 3 to 2 and in Stafford from 4 to 2. The number of cases remained static in Wyre Forest with 2 reported in both 2013 and 2014.\n\nJyoti Atri, director of public health at Sandwell Council, said it was important to get vaccinated to prevent the risk of catching the infection, adding: 'Whooping cough is highly contagious and newborns are particularly vulnerable. It's vital that babies are protected from the day they are born - that's why the vaccine is being offered to all pregnant women. If you are pregnant, getting vaccinated is the best way you can protect your baby against whooping cough.'\n\nThe condition usually begins with a persistent dry and irritating cough that progresses to intense bouts of coughing. The gasping for breath after one of these coughing bouts causes a distinctive 'whooping' noise, which is how the infection gets its name. The coughing can last for around three months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, see moderators' comments in prior ProMED-mail pertussis posts.\n\nMaps of England can be seen at http://www.picturesofengland.com/images/mapofengland/regions-uk.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4481.\n\nThe Midlands is an area spanning central England, with a population of 9 439 516 (2001 census), but does not correspond to any current administrative area. Its largest city is Birmingham, and the greater part of the area is now administered as the Government Office Regions of the West Midlands and East Midlands (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Midlands). Wolverhampton (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolverhampton), Sandwell (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandwell), and Walsall (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walsall) are located in the West Midlands, surrounding the city of Birmingham. For a map of this area, see https://www.google.com/maps/@52.5323075,-2.0360236,13z. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhooping cough -- a bacterial infection of the lungs and airways -- affects all ages, but newborns and infants under 3 months of age are at highest risk of severe complications and death. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, see moderators' comments in prior ProMED-mail pertussis posts. \n\nJyoti Atri, director of public health at Sandwell Council, said it was important to get vaccinated to prevent the risk of catching the infection, adding: 'Whooping cough is highly contagious and newborns are particularly vulnerable. \n\nHealth chiefs have urged pregnant women to have a vaccination to protect themselves and their unborn babies against the risk of the infection, also known as pertussis. It protects the baby from developing whooping cough in the first few weeks of life as the mother passes immunity on to her unborn child, protecting the youngster until they receive their first vaccination at 2 months old. But the number of people being diagnosed fell in Dudley from 10 cases to 4, in Cannock from 3 to 2 and in Stafford from 4 to 2. All pregnant women are offered vaccination against whooping cough when they are 28-38 weeks pregnant. In 2014, the highest number of cases were diagnosed in Sandwell and Walsall with 12 patients in each borough suffering from the infection. \n\nThe condition usually begins with a persistent dry and irritating cough that progresses to intense bouts of coughing. The number of cases remained static in Wyre Forest with 2 reported in both 2013 and 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wolverhampton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dudley", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cannock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Birmingham", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3344844", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (04): waning immunity, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3344844", "date": "2015-05-06 10:47:49", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (04): WANING IMMUNITY, COMMENT\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 5 May 2015\nFrom: Robert Benjamin <robert.benjamin.md@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nThe epi analysis cited in PLoS (Gambhir M, Clark TA, Cauchemez S, et al: A change in vaccine efficacy and duration of protection explains recent rises in pertussis incidence in the United States. PLoS Comput Biol. 2015; 11(4): e1004138. doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004138 http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004138) comparing the efficacy and duration of both the whole cell and acellular vaccines mirrors what Australia, and we, here in California, have been experiencing. As a result, pertussis has once again approached endemicity. PAHO, the Pan American Health Organization, has I believe, advised countries which have not yet switched over to acellular pertussis vaccine not to do so, and to continue to utilize whole cell vaccines.\n\nThe reason given for our switching to acellular pertussis was the unacceptability of side effects in infants receiving whole cell... the trade-off now being both lower efficacy and shorter duration, with the preponderance of cases now emerging in high school populations.\n\nI would suggest that we look at a hybrid immunization approach which utilizes acellular vaccine for the 1st 3 or even 4 doses (ages 2, 4, 6, and 15-18 months) to confer immunity while avoiding the adverse event more common in infancy, with a whole cell vaccine administered at 4-5 years of age, when the vaccine is better tolerated, thus conferring longer lasting immunity, resulting in reducing the overall burden of pertussis in the community and hopefully, bringing us back from the current endemic state to only deal with sporadic cases. I put this forward as an option which I believe needs to be studied. While whole cell pertussis vaccine is no longer currently used in the USA, it was, and should still be licensed for use. It is still being manufactured and used in other countries and so should still be available.\n\nI suggest this because it is clear that simply increasing dosing frequency (that is, possible boosting at transition from middle school to high school) using a less effective acellular vaccine, leaves us complacently resigned to endemicity.\n\nUltimately, we need a new, re-engineered vaccine which addresses these issues, but this will take large amounts of resources and time, by far, to clear FDA approval.\n\n--\nRobert Benjamin, MD, MPH\n<robert.benjamin.md@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Benjamin for his comments. While the evolution of new clones of _B. pertussis_ and the presence of an under immunized cohort of individuals may play a role, it certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _B. pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, who are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting this susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nI would suggest that we look at a hybrid immunization approach which utilizes acellular vaccine for the 1st 3 or even 4 doses (ages 2, 4, 6, and 15-18 months) to confer immunity while avoiding the adverse event more common in infancy, with a whole cell vaccine administered at 4-5 years of age, when the vaccine is better tolerated, thus conferring longer lasting immunity, resulting in reducing the overall burden of pertussis in the community and hopefully, bringing us back from the current endemic state to only deal with sporadic cases. While the evolution of new clones of _B. pertussis_ and the presence of an under immunized cohort of individuals may play a role, it certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _B. pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, who are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. \n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study. \n\nThe reason given for our switching to acellular pertussis was the unacceptability of side effects in infants receiving whole cell... the trade-off now being both lower efficacy and shorter duration, with the preponderance of cases now emerging in high school populations. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. During the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. PAHO, the Pan American Health Organization, has I believe, advised countries which have not yet switched over to acellular pertussis vaccine not to do so, and to continue to utilize whole cell vaccines. \n\nI suggest this because it is clear that simply increasing dosing frequency (that is, possible boosting at transition from middle school to high school) using a less effective acellular vaccine, leaves us complacently resigned to endemicity. PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (04): WANING IMMUNITY, COMMENT\n****************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PLoS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3342572", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (03): (AC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3342572", "date": "2015-05-05 16:37:41", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Apr 2015\nSource: ABC (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-04-28/pertussis-whooping-cough-cases-in-act-double-last-years/6427590\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) has more than doubled in the last year. So far this year [2015], 115 cases of the illness have been reported to ACT Health, compared with 49 for the same period in 2014.\n\nACT chief health officer Dr Paul Kelly said whooping cough, or pertussis, was a serious respiratory infection that could be life-threatening for infants. 'In babies, the infection can sometimes lead to pneumonia and occasionally brain damage, and can be life threatening,' he said.\n\n'There has already been an increase in the number of pertussis notifications in the ACT so far in 2015. This has mainly been across the 0- to 14-year age group compared to the same time in 2014 (45 cases in 2015 to 13 cases in 2014). Especially children aged 10 to 12 (21 cases in 2015 compared to 3 cases in 2014).'\n\nBut Dr Kelly said it was usual for the number of cases to spike once every few years. 'The increased number of notifications is expected, as pertussis notifications tend to increase every few years, as they last did in 2010-11,' he said.\n\n'One of the issues with the vaccine is that it's very effective but it doesn't last as long as previous vaccines we've had.'\n\nDr Kelly said there were discussions with companies to develop a longer lasting vaccine. 'We need to improve the immunogenicity as it's called of the vaccine so that it can last longer,' he said. '[But] it is vital that parents ensure all their children are up to date with their scheduled vaccinations to minimise the risk of whooping cough circulating not only in their own families but in the wider community including schools.'\n\nFrom today, pregnant women in their 3rd trimester can access free whooping cough vaccinations. 'I encourage all pregnant women to ensure they are vaccinated in their 3rd trimester, ideally at 28 weeks or as soon as possible after, as it offers the best protection for babies until they have completed their primary immunisation for pertussis at six months of age,' Dr Kelly said.\n\n'Family members and other adults in close contact with young babies should also discuss the benefits of the vaccine.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[A recently published paper in PLoS Computational Biology suggests waning immunity from the acellular pertussis vaccine as the main reason for the dramatic increase in pertussis cases:\nGambhir M, Clark TA, Cauchemez S, et al: A change in vaccine efficacy and duration of protection explains recent rises in pertussis incidence in the United States. PLoS Comput Biol. 2015; 11(4): e1004138. doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004138 (http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004138):\n\nAbstract\n--------\nOver the past 10 years, the incidence of pertussis in the USA has risen steadily, with 2012 seeing the highest case number since 1955. There has also been a shift over the same time period in the age group reporting the largest number of cases (aside from infants), from adolescents to 7-11 year olds. We use epidemiological modelling and a large case incidence dataset to explain the upsurge. We investigate several hypotheses for the upsurge in pertussis cases by fitting a suite of dynamic epidemiological models to incidence data from the National Notifiable Disease Surveillance System (NNDSS) between 1990-2009, as well as incidence data from a variety of sources from 1950-1989.\n\nWe find that: the best-fitting model is one in which vaccine efficacy and duration of protection of the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine is lower than that of the whole-cell (wP) vaccine, (efficacy of the first 3 doses 80 per cent [95 per cent CI: 78-82] versus 90 per cent [95 per cent CI: 87-94]), increasing the rate at which disease is reported to NNDSS is not sufficient to explain the upsurge and 3) 2010-2012 disease incidence is predicted well. In this study, we use all available USA surveillance data to: 1) fit a set of mathematical models and determine which best explains these data and 2) determine the epidemiological and vaccine-related parameter values of this model. We find evidence of a difference in efficacy and duration of protection between the 2 vaccine types, wP and aP (aP efficacy and duration lower than wP). Future refinement of the model presented here will allow for an exploration of alternative vaccination strategies such as different age-spacings, further booster doses, and cocooning.'\n\nMaps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/290. The Australian Capital Territory (ACT) (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Capital_Territory) formerly, 'The Territory for the Seat of Government' and, later, the 'Federal Capital Territory' is a territory in the south east of Australia, enclaved within New South Wales. The only city and by far the most populous community is Canberra, the capital city of Australia. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nWe find that: the best-fitting model is one in which vaccine efficacy and duration of protection of the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine is lower than that of the whole-cell (wP) vaccine, (efficacy of the first 3 doses 80 per cent [95 per cent CI: 78-82] versus 90 per cent [95 per cent CI: 87-94]), increasing the rate at which disease is reported to NNDSS is not sufficient to explain the upsurge and 3) 2010-2012 disease incidence is predicted well. \n\n'Family members and other adults in close contact with young babies should also discuss the benefits of the vaccine.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [A recently published paper in PLoS Computational Biology suggests waning immunity from the acellular pertussis vaccine as the main reason for the dramatic increase in pertussis cases:\nGambhir M, Clark TA, Cauchemez S, et al: We investigate several hypotheses for the upsurge in pertussis cases by fitting a suite of dynamic epidemiological models to incidence data from the National Notifiable Disease Surveillance System (NNDSS) between 1990-2009, as well as incidence data from a variety of sources from 1950-1989. I encourage all pregnant women to ensure they are vaccinated in their 3rd trimester, ideally at 28 weeks or as soon as possible after, as it offers the best protection for babies until they have completed their primary immunisation for pertussis at six months of age,' Dr Kelly said. This has mainly been across the 0- to 14-year age group compared to the same time in 2014 (45 cases in 2015 to 13 cases in 2014). In this study, we use all available USA surveillance data to: 1) fit a set of mathematical models and determine which best explains these data and 2) determine the epidemiological and vaccine-related parameter values of this model. A change in vaccine efficacy and duration of protection explains recent rises in pertussis incidence in the United States. PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY)\n**********************************************************\n \n\n'There has already been an increase in the number of pertussis notifications in the ACT so far in 2015. Especially children aged 10 to 12 (21 cases in 2015 compared to 3 cases in 2014).'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-11-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/290", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "wp", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "wP", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3292931", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (02): (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3292931", "date": "2015-04-12 15:04:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (02): (ONTARIO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 8 Apr 2015\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/tara-hills-ottawa-mom-changes-anti-vaccination-stand-but-7-kids-still-get-sick-1.3025592\n\n\nAn Ottawa [Ontario, Canada] mother of 7 'defected' from the anti-vaccination movement, but then her youngest, a 10-month-old son, contracted whooping cough before she could get all of her children their shots.\n\nThe woman told CBC News that since all her children, aged 10 and under, were showing symptoms of the contagious disease, they have been advised to take antimicrobials and stay inside their Kanata home for 5 days. Her 1st 3 children were partially vaccinated, she said. But she decided to stop after the 4th was born because she was suspicious of the medical community. 'I just got scared. I got spooked. I thought, 'There's a lot of smoke, there must be fire.' We stopped vaccinating,' she said.\n\nThe mother said she had recently started rethinking her position on vaccinations. Before her youngest was diagnosed with whooping cough, she said, she met with her family doctor to put together a 'catch-up vaccination schedule' for her children. 'It's very sobering and it's very raw because we had just made a more fully informed decision about vaccinations. We had just defected from the anti-vaccination camp,' she said.\n\n'It was too late. It's so ironic and I'm not beating myself up for it. I just hope we can use this very painful experience to encourage other people like us to maybe re-examine the issue.'\n\nOttawa Public Health confirmed that there are 7 reported cases of whooping cough, also called pertussis, in Ottawa, including an infant. There are about 20 cases in Ottawa per year. 'The best way to protect children against pertussis is immunization,' Ottawa Public Health told CBC News in an email statement.\n\nThe mother decided to share her story in a parenting blog post called 'Learning the Hard Way: My Journey from #AntiVaxx to Science.' [http://thescientificparent.org/learning-the-hard-way-my-journey-from-antivaxx-to-science/\n\n'I am not looking forward to any gloating or shame as this 'defection' from the antivaxx camp goes public, but this isn't a popularity contest. Right now my family is living the consequences of misinformation and fear,' she wrote. 'I understand that families in our community may be mad at us for putting their kids at risk. I want them to know that we tried our best to protect our kids when we were afraid of vaccination and we are doing our best now, for everyone's sake, by getting them up to date.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fortunately, none, especially the youngest, of this mother's children developed complications from pertussis and perhaps others will learn from her experience.\n\nThe mother refers to the quote 'Where there's smoke, there must be fire,' but paraphrasing it, perhaps just as correctly is a quote attributed to John F Kennedy, 'Where there's smoke, there is usually a smoke-making machine.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9117.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n An Ottawa [Ontario, Canada] mother of 7 'defected' from the anti-vaccination movement, but then her youngest, a 10-month-old son, contracted whooping cough before she could get all of her children their shots. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fortunately, none, especially the youngest, of this mother's children developed complications from pertussis and perhaps others will learn from her experience. \n\nThe woman told CBC News that since all her children, aged 10 and under, were showing symptoms of the contagious disease, they have been advised to take antimicrobials and stay inside their Kanata home for 5 days. Before her youngest was diagnosed with whooping cough, she said, she met with her family doctor to put together a 'catch-up vaccination schedule' for her children. The mother refers to the quote 'Where there's smoke, there must be fire,' but paraphrasing it, perhaps just as correctly is a quote attributed to John F Kennedy, 'Where there's smoke, there is usually a smoke-making machine.' PERTUSSIS - CANADA (02): (ONTARIO)\n**********************************\n \n\nThe mother said she had recently started rethinking her position on vaccinations. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kanata", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3305675", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (08): (NC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3305675", "date": "2015-04-18 09:59:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: The Transylvania Times [edited]\nhttp://www.transylvaniatimes.com/story/2015/04/16/news/pertussis-cases-back-in-transylvania-county-transylvania-county-nc/22380.html\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating several cases of pertussis (whooping cough) that have occurred in Transylvania County [North Carolina] in recent months. 5 cases have been confirmed since January [2015].\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the mouth, nose, and throat. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. In late 2014, the county had 31 confirmed cases of pertussis and followed up with more than 450 individuals who had possibly been exposed to the disease.\n\nAll of the cases in 2015 have been in infants 7 months of age and younger, and 2 of these children have been hospitalized. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. After she developed a cough, she was tested for both RSV [respiratory syncytial virus] and pertussis at her pediatrician's office. 'She didn't really have a 'whoop' like you hear about,' [her mother] said, 'But you don't always have that at such a young age.' The RSV test was positive, so she was taken to Mission Children's Hospital in Asheville [North Carolina] to begin treatment. Then, the pertussis test results also came back positive. 'It was scary,' [her mother] said. 'She's 4 weeks old. She's little. There's not much you can do.'\n\nSuction helped to clear the mucus from [girl's] airways. She and the rest of her family were put on a course of antibiotics, which are used to control the symptoms and help prevent infected people from spreading the disease.\n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. 'It's miserable and awful, but when they say quarantine, you have to stay home,' [her mother] said.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of 'DTaP' [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of 'Tdap' should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n'It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,' said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. 'This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.'\n\n'These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,' Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should 'take it very seriously. Heed the warnings, the cautions, and keep them protected,' she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. The news report above fails to tell us if the 4-month-old child's mother received Tdap during her pregnancy, if those in close contact with the infant were also vaccinated, or who was the suspected source of the infant's infection.\n\nThe state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1159. Transylvania County, with a population of about 33 000 in 2010, is located in the southwestern region of state, on its southern border with the state of South Carolina (http://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina-county-map.gif). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of 'DTaP' [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months. \n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Because infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. \n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. \n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. \n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism. PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asheville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Transylvania County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3230176", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (06): (CA) infant fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3230176", "date": "2015-03-14 17:17:16", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06): (CALIFORNIA) INFANT FATALITY\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Mar 2015\nSource: Lodi News-Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.lodinews.com/news/article_691509ea-c3d9-11e4-9b64-bbc28dc835c9.html\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, has claimed the life of a 3-week-old infant in San Joaquin County, health officials announced Thursday, 5 Mar 2015. Of the 23 cases of pertussis reported in county residents in 2015. this is the first death. The infant did not reside in the north county area. In 2014, the county had 212 reported pertussis cases, an increase from 2013, when there were 27 cases in the county. The incidence of pertussis has been higher in south county communities, particularly Manteca and Tracy,\naccording to county health officials.\n\nThe California Department of Public Health reports that the state is currently experiencing a pertussis epidemic. Pertussis is cyclical and peaks every 3 to 5 years. In 2014, the latest state pertussis report shows 11 114 cases.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious illness that is spread from person to person, usually by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others. It can be serious at any age, but may be life-threatening for newborns and infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated. Since infants are at greatest risk for developing severe complications, health officials recommend pregnant women receive the pertussis vaccine during their 3rd trimester. Immunity is transferred from mother to fetus and can protect the baby until they are old enough for regular immunization.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 2nd infant death from pertussis reported from California in 2015. San Joaquin county is located in the Central Valley of the state, east of San Francisco and can be found on a map at http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Joaquin_County,_California#/media/File:California_county_map_(San_Joaquin_County_highlighted).svg.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA recent publication confirms that safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod. Pertussis disease, also known as whooping cough, has already infected more than 500 children in Maryland County in southern Liberia. The International Rescue Committee is supporting the local government in fighting what it calls an alarming outbreak of cases.\n\n'Pertussis is an example of a terrible disease that's preventable if children and babies are vaccinated,' said Nick Lobel-Weiss, an IRC health coordinator in Maryland County. 'We're working rapidly to get the message out to communities that parents need to get their kids to health facilities for treatment now. The people of Liberia have suffered enough. They don't need this.'\n\nThe IRC is already working closely with the county health team in the hardest hit areas of Maryland County, training and deploying teams of local volunteers to find children infected with whooping cough, assist parents in seeking treatment, and supporting campaigns to prevent further spread.\n\n[Byline: Veronica Mills]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The scope of this outbreak is not clear. Most pertussis-associated deaths are in quite young, unimmunized children who are in contact with older children or young adults with milder illness. Pertussis mortality can be minimized not only by immunization with trivalent vaccine against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis, but also by early antimicrobial intervention. Large populations of susceptible people in the developing world are the cause of large outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe IRC is already working closely with the county health team in the hardest hit areas of Maryland County, training and deploying teams of local volunteers to find children infected with whooping cough, assist parents in seeking treatment, and supporting campaigns to prevent further spread. \n\n'Pertussis is an example of a terrible disease that's preventable if children and babies are vaccinated,' said Nick Lobel-Weiss, an IRC health coordinator in Maryland County. Most pertussis-associated deaths are in quite young, unimmunized children who are in contact with older children or young adults with milder illness. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Pertussis disease, also known as whooping cough, has already infected more than 500 children in Maryland County in southern Liberia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liberia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3130174", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (02): (VI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3130174", "date": "2015-01-30 20:11:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): (VICTORIA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jan 2015\nSource: The Courier [edited]\nhttp://www.thecourier.com.au/story/2830210/whooping-cough-cases-up-by-700-in-ballarat/?cs=12\n\n\nPertussis (whooping cough) cases in Ballarat have skyrocketed in recent years, new figures show. Ballarat recorded 218 whooping cough cases in 2014, compared to 27 in 2013 and 38 in 2012, according to Department of Health figures. 9 whooping cough cases have already been recorded so far in 2015.\n\nGrampians Medicare Local immunization coordinator Breeanne Fratin said there were several reasons for the sudden spike, including family members no longer having whooping cough immunity, current vaccine protection wearing off, and anti-vaccination protesters not immunizing their children. She said a recent whooping cough study showed parents were the source of infection in more than 50 percent of cases due to their immunity fading over time.\n\n'You also need to make sure older children are fully immunized, with whooping cough boosters at 4 years and again in high school,' Ms Fratin said. She also urged grandparents and friends to make sure their needles were up to date, with the state government announcing a return of the free pertussis vaccine program that was axed in 2012.\n\n'Anti-vaccination protesters are also creating more opportunity for a pertussis outbreak and Grampians Medicare Local would encourage them to speak to their local provider if they have any concerns or questions,' Ms Fratin said.\n\nStatewide, there has been a 57.7 percent increase in whooping cough cases, rising from 2926 in 2013 to 4615 in 2014, with children less than one year old particularly vulnerable.\n\nState Health Minister Jill Hennessy said the government expected more than 80 000 Victorians to now be vaccinated annually. 'Whooping cough is highly contagious and, if parents aren't immunized, they could pass it on to their newborn baby,' Ms Hennessy said.\n\n[Byline: Fiona Henderson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[Research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) have been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be one of a number of factors causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. These changes may result in a need for modifications of the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4057. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[Research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) have been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be one of a number of factors causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'You also need to make sure older children are fully immunized, with whooping cough boosters at 4 years and again in high school,' Ms Fratin said. She said a recent whooping cough study showed parents were the source of infection in more than 50 percent of cases due to their immunity fading over time. Statewide, there has been a 57.7 percent increase in whooping cough cases, rising from 2926 in 2013 to 4615 in 2014, with children less than one year old particularly vulnerable. http://www.thecourier.com.au/story/2830210/whooping-cough-cases-up-by-700-in-ballarat/?cs=12\n\n\nPertussis (whooping cough) cases in Ballarat have skyrocketed in recent years, new figures show.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2015-01-20 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2926-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ballarat", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3229781", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (05): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3229781", "date": "2015-03-14 10:31:54", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (05): (OREGON)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 12 Mar 2015\nSource: Corvallis Gazette-Times [edited]\nhttp://www.gazettetimes.com/news/local/education/benton-county-confirms-pertussis-outbreak-at-local-schools/article_dee5142f-491b-55d0-afd4-56ac3c3ec04d.html\n\n\nBenton County [Oregon] Health Department officials said [Wed 11 Mar 2015] that Linus Pauling Middle School and Crescent Valley High School have new confirmed cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough. Bill Emminger, a manager of environmental health with the Benton County Health Department, said there also were confirmed cases in Philomath schools. Corvallis School District sent out alerts about the outbreak [Fri 6 Mar 2015].\n\nPertussis also broke out in Benton County schools in November [2014].\n\nEmminger said that the Health Department's main message on pertussis is that it is particularly dangerous to children who are less than a year old. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on its website that half of such infants require hospitalization if they contract pertussis. Of those hospitalized, 1 or 2 in 100 will die from it.\n\nAccording to Emminger, babies can begin to receive pertussis vaccinations at 2 months, but the health department also emphasizes protecting infants by having everyone who has contact with the babies vaccinated against pertussis.\n\nHe added that pertussis is distinctive because of the persistent 'whooping' cough it causes as patients struggle for air. He said people should stay home if [they] believe they have pertussis because it is highly contagious, and they should see a doctor.\n\nPeople with pertussis usually get a course of antibiotics and remain contagious for a week, Emminger said.\n\nSince October [2014], 37 cases of pertussis have been confirmed in Benton County. The most in a month was 13 in November [2014]. 8 confirmed cases were reported in February [2015]. The cases in Corvallis mostly have been at Corvallis High School and Crescent Valley High School. Of the people infected, 27 were ages 10 to 19; one was an infant.\n\nNo deaths have been reported.\n\n[Byline: Anthony Rimel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above does not say the percent of pertussis cases that were unimmunized. Although in some regions low immunization rates account for pertussis outbreaks, the California Department of Public Health said that low immunization rates could not account for the current pertussis outbreak in the state, because 90 per cent of those children infected in 2014 had been vaccinated against pertussis (see ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (29) 20141222.3044440); increased virulence and a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, attributed to genetic changes, as well as a waning immune response after vaccination may be other causes of the current outbreaks.\n\nIn the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc. Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.)\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccines.\n\nThe state of Oregon can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/26499. Benton County, with a population of 85 579 in 2010, is located in west central Oregon. Its county seat is the city of Corvallis, with a population of 54 462 in 2010. A map showing the location of Benton County can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Although in some regions low immunization rates account for pertussis outbreaks, the California Department of Public Health said that low immunization rates could not account for the current pertussis outbreak in the state, because 90 per cent of those children infected in 2014 had been vaccinated against pertussis (see ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (29) 20141222.3044440); increased virulence and a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, attributed to genetic changes, as well as a waning immune response after vaccination may be other causes of the current outbreaks. According to Emminger, babies can begin to receive pertussis vaccinations at 2 months, but the health department also emphasizes protecting infants by having everyone who has contact with the babies vaccinated against pertussis.\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above does not say the percent of pertussis cases that were unimmunized. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nBenton County [Oregon] Health Department officials said [Wed 11 Mar 2015] that Linus Pauling Middle School and Crescent Valley High School have new confirmed cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough. Because infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccines. \n\nPeople with pertussis usually get a course of antibiotics and remain contagious for a week, Emminger said. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.) \n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. PERTUSSIS - USA (05): (OREGON)\n******************************\n \n\nPertussis also broke out in Benton County schools in November [2014]. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Emminger said that the Health Department's main message on pertussis is that it is particularly dangerous to children who are less than a year old. Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philomath", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Benton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3320344", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (09)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3320344", "date": "2015-04-25 06:12:59", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (09)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Washington (Walla Walla County), Oregon (Umatilla County)\nDate: Wed 22 Apr 2015\nSource: East Oregonian [edited]\nhttp://www.eastoregonian.com/eo/local-news/20150422/weaker-vaccine-blamed-for-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nWhooping cough is spiking across the border in Walla Walla County. Public health directors in Walla Walla and Umatilla Counties explain the surge. Another pertussis epidemic is in full swing in Washington. Hardest hit is Walla Walla County, which has seen the highest rate of infection in the state.\n\nWalla Walla has 28 confirmed cases so far in 2015 with additional suspected cases boosting the number to about 55, said Walla Walla County public health director Harvey Crowder. The official rate is 47 per 100 000 persons.\n\nPublic health officials attribute the surge in pertussis, or whooping cough, to a weaker vaccine first used in 1997 to replace an earlier vaccine that triggered high fevers and seizures in some children. The current vaccine is safer, but protection seems to wane faster. In the mid-2000s, fully immunized people started coming down with whooping cough.\n\nCrowder said he wasn't surprised by the upsurge in 2015. 'For whatever reason the vaccine doesn't provide long-lived immunity,' Crowder said. 'We're going to see this again and again and again every 3-5 years until we get a vaccine that is longer-lived.' He said the majority of people coming down with whooping cough were fully vaccinated as children. 'Most of our cases have been adolescents and young adults,' he said.\n\nAcross the border in Oregon, Umatilla County has had only 2 confirmed cases, according to public health director Meghan DeBolt, and no current ones. 'There are no active pertussis cases in Umatilla County,' DeBolt said. 'We haven't seen a surge here.' That doesn't mean Umatilla County residents should feel invincible, however. Crowder and DeBolt urged people to get boosters, especially if they spend time around babies. Pregnant women should get vaccinated every time they get pregnant. Infants are particularly susceptible, they said.\n\nTo put the current outbreak in perspective, Washington saw epidemic numbers in 2012 with nearly 5000 whooping cough cases, dozens of hospitalizations and 1 infant death. So far, in 2015, 341 cases statewide have been reported. In 2014, at this time, there were 57 confirmed cases.\n\nOregon has seen 144 cases so far in 2015 after ending last year with 413.\n\n[byline: Kathy Aney]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Walla Walla county is in south eastern Washington State and shares a border with Umatilla county, Oregon. The location of Walla Walla county can be seen on a map at http://www.ofm.wa.gov/forecasting/images/clickable.gif. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Oregon (Deschutes County)\nDate: Tue 21 Apr 2015\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/Pertussis-cases-on-the-rise-in-Deschutes-County/32487026\n\n\nDeschutes County Health Services has identified over 20 cases of pertussis in the community since the start of 2015, after a 2014 that brought the highest count in 20 years, officials said on Tue 21 Apr 2015. All of the cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, have been investigated by Health Services Communicable Disease staff and close contacts have been notified.\n\nIn 2014, 60 cases of pertussis were reported in Deschutes County. This represented the highest number of annual cases reported in the last 2 decades, the department said. 'The best defense against pertussis is a well-immunized community,' the statement said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County is in central Oregon and be found at a map at http://pix.epodunk.com/locatorMaps/or/OR_15246.gif - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] Washington State (south western)\nDate: Fri 17 Apr 2015\nSource: TDN [edited]\nhttp://tdn.com/news/local/whooping-cough-cases-rise-statewide/article_0d07c603-9d89-5868-a9f8-c6604562a431.html\n\n\nConfirmed pertussis cases in 2015 by the numbers\n\u2022 Statewide: 319\n\u2022 Cowlitz: 7\n\u2022 Clark: 39\n\u2022 Lewis: 5\n\u2022 Pacific: 4\n\nWith 319 cases of whooping cough confirmed statewide this year, health officials are urging people to get vaccinated against the highly contagious disease. In Cowlitz County, 7 cases have been confirmed, matching the total number of cases for all of 2014. The most recent case was diagnosed at the end of March 2015.\n\n[byline: Lyxan Toledanes]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The overall state count is lower than the 1 above. These counties are in the south western corner of Washington State, as seen on a map at http://www.ofm.wa.gov/forecasting/images/clickable.gif - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[4] Pennsylvania (Montgomery County)\nDate: Thu 19 Apr 2015\nSource: Philly.com [edited]\nhttp://www.philly.com/philly/education/20150319_5_whooping_cough_cases_at_Montco_school.html\n\n\nAt least 5 students at Souderton Area High School have been diagnosed with pertussis, or whooping cough, prompting Montgomery County health officials to warn of an outbreak, the school district said in a statement this week.\n\nOf the 5 cases, 3 have been confirmed, superintendent Frank T Gallagher said Wed, 18 Apr 2015. 'Everyone's doing well,' he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Montgomery County is located in south eastern Pennsylvania not far from Philadelphia, and can be found on a map at http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Pennsylvania#/media/File:Map_of_Pennsylvania_highlighting_Montgomery_County.svg - Mod.LL]\n\n[A recently published paper in PLoS Computational Biology suggests waning immunity from the acellular pertussis vaccine as the main reason for the dramatic increase in pertussis cases: Gambhir M, Clark TA, Cauchemez S, et al. A change in vaccine efficacy and duration of protection explains recent rises in pertussis incidence in the United States. PLoS Comput Biol. 2015; 11(4): e1004138. doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004138:\n\nAbstract\n--------\nOver the past 10 years the incidence of pertussis in the USA has risen steadily, with 2012 seeing the highest case number since 1955. There has also been a shift over the same time period in the age group reporting the largest number of cases (aside from infants), from adolescents to 7-11 year olds. We use epidemiological modelling and a large case incidence dataset to explain the upsurge. We investigate several hypotheses for the upsurge in pertussis cases by fitting a suite of dynamic epidemiological models to incidence data from the National Notifiable Disease Surveillance System (NNDSS) between 1990-2009, as well as incidence data from a variety of sources from 1950-1989.\n\nWe find that: the best-fitting model is one in which vaccine efficacy and duration of protection of the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine is lower than that of the whole-cell (wP) vaccine, (efficacy of the first 3 doses 80 per cent [95 per cent CI: 78 - 82] versus 90 per cent [95 per cent CI: 87-94]), increasing the rate at which disease is reported to NNDSS is not sufficient to explain the upsurge and 3) 2010-2012 disease incidence is predicted well. In this study, we use all available USA surveillance data to: 1) fit a set of mathematical models and determine which best explains these data and 2) determine the epidemiological and vaccine-related parameter values of this model. We find evidence of a difference in efficacy and duration of protection between the 2 vaccine types, wP and aP (aP efficacy and duration lower than wP). Future refinement of the model presented here will allow for an exploration of alternative vaccination strategies such as different age-spacings, further booster doses, and cocooning. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Statewide: 319\n\u2022 Cowlitz: 7\n\u2022 Clark: 39\n\u2022 Lewis: 5\n\u2022 Pacific: 4\n\nWith 319 cases of whooping cough confirmed statewide this year, health officials are urging people to get vaccinated against the highly contagious disease. In Cowlitz County, 7 cases have been confirmed, matching the total number of cases for all of 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-04-21 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Umatilla county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Deschutes County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cowlitz County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montgomery County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Umatilla County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "wP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "wp", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3126015", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Pakistan: (BA) pediatric mortality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3126015", "date": "2015-01-28 21:04:28", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - PAKISTAN: (BALOCHISTAN) PEDIATRIC MORTALITY\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Dunya News [edited]\nhttp://video.dunyanews.tv/index.php/en/mustwatch/13479/Dera-Bugti:-Whooping-cough-claims-three-more-lives,-death-toll-rises-to-13#.VMZXNUeUf0c\n\n\nDeaths attributed to pertussis (whooping cough) mounted to 13 in a span of 16 days in Dera Bugti in Balochistan as 3 more children died on Mon 26 Jan 2015. As many as 11 deaths were confirmed in Peer Koh [Dera Bugti] while the deceased included a 1.5-year-old male, 4 male and 5 female 1-year-olds, and a 2-year old male.\n\nThe only healthcare worker working at the Basic Health Unit revealed that population of Peer Koh is estimated to be 20 000, and he can provide vaccination to only 5 percent of the population. Locals told Dunya News that the media is focused on the deaths in Tharparker (Sindh Province) alone and if due attention will not be given to the situation of whooping cough locally, significant human tragedies might arise.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[The scope of this outbreak is not clear. Most pertussis-associated deaths are in quite young, unimmunized children who are in contact with older children or young adults who have milder illness. Pertussis mortality can be minimized not only by immunization with trivalent vaccine against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis, but also by early antimicrobial intervention. Large populations of susceptible people in the developing world are the cause of large outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases.\n\nMaps of Pakistan can be seen at http://thumbs.dreamstime.com/z/pakistan-map-administrative-division-islamic-republic-31711340.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43801. Balochistan (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan) is the largest of Pakistan's 4 provinces in terms of area, constituting approximately 44 percent of the country's total land mass, and the smallest in terms of population, being home to less than 5 percent of the country's population. Balochistan province is bordered by Afghanistan to the north and north-west, Iran to the south-west, the Arabian Sea to the south, Punjab and Sindh to the east, and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Federally Administered Tribal Areas to the north-east. Quetta is the capital and largest city of Balochistan. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Balochistan (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan) is the largest of Pakistan's 4 provinces in terms of area, constituting approximately 44 percent of the country's total land mass, and the smallest in terms of population, being home to less than 5 percent of the country's population.
