Pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, has broken out at local schools several times this school year [2014-15]. A Benton County Health Department official said there have been close to 40 confirmed cases in the county between October 2014 and March 2015.\n\nPertussis is a vaccine-preventable illness that is particularly dangerous to infants. It is marked by coughing so vigorous that the afflicted person must struggle for breath, causing a whooping sound. Health officials emphasize that all people coming into contact with infants have a pertussis vaccination to reduce the risk of infecting the child.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Oregon can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/26499. Benton County, in the western part of the state, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif. - Mod. LL]\n\n*****\n[2] Pennsylvania (Delaware County)\nDate: Fri 10 Apr 2015\nSource: Delaware County Daily Times [edited]\nhttp://www.delcotimes.com/general-news/20150410/eight-cases-of-whooping-cough-confirmed-at-radnor-high-school\n\n\nParents in the Radnor Township School District are on the lookout for whooping cough symptoms in the wake of 8 confirmed cases at 2 schools. 'There have now been a total of 7 confirmed cases of pertussis at Radnor High School since [20 Mar 2015], in addition to one confirmed case at Radnor Middle School,' the district said in Friday [10 Apr 2015] statement.\n\nAccording to school officials, 6 of the 7 high school students stricken with the highly contagious respiratory disease had been vaccinated, 'Out of the entire Radnor High School student body, 7 students are currently exempt from vaccinations for medical or religious reasons,' the statement said. 'Radnor High School's nurse has called the parents of all of these students in order to discuss the importance of vaccination. Ultimately it's going to be their choice,' said district spokesman Michael Petitti.\n\nBefore pertussis vaccines became widely available in the 1940s, about 200 000 children got sick with it each year in the USA and about 9000 died as a result of the infection, according to the CDC website. Today, roughly 10 000 to 40 000 cases are reported each year that result in 10 to 20 deaths.\n\nThough there is no federal requirement, all 50 states have laws requiring certain vaccines for students, according to data compiled by the National Conference of State Legislatures through 3 Mar 2015. Every state except West Virginia and Mississippi grants religious exemptions for people who do not believe in immunizations, and 20 states, including Pennsylvania, allow philosophical exemptions for objections on personal, moral, or other grounds.\n\nUnofficial figures from the Pennsylvania Department of Health have Delaware County ranked 5th, behind Philadelphia, Allegheny, Bucks, and Montgomery counties, with 102 confirmed pertussis cases since 2013. The numbers from the state did not appear to account for the Radnor cases. Unlike Bucks, Chester, and Montgomery counties, Delaware County does not have its own health department.\n\n[Byline: Tim Logue]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Pennsylvania can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/pennsylvania-county-map.gif. Delaware County is adjacent to metropolitan Philadelphia in southern Pennsylvania. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania (York County)\nDate: Fri 27 Mar 2015\nSource: PennLive, The Patriot News [edited]\nhttp://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2015/03/whooping_cough_pertussis_pa.html\n\n\nHealth officials in York said Fri 27 Mar 2015, 3 students at a city school came down with whooping cough, and they are awaiting test results for several others who may have the illness, also called pertussis. The students attend St Patrick Catholic School.\n\nThe York City Bureau of Health said, 'Children with a cough thought to be pertussis should not go to school or other public activities until being evaluated by their doctor. A laboratory test can be ordered by the doctor and a prescription for an appropriate antibiotic given in order to clear the infection. In many cases, family members may also need to be treated since secondary infections within households are common.'\n\nChildren are typically vaccinated against pertussis through 5 doses of a vaccine known as DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis] in early childhood, and a booster shot at age 11 or 12. The vaccination is required to attend school in Pennsylvania.\n\nHere are the number of cases logged by the Pennsylvania Department of Health in recent years:\n\n2010: 979 cases\n2011: 742 cases\n2012: 1945 cases\n2013: 633\n2014: 691 confirmed or probable cases as of late December [2014].\n\n[Byline: David Wenner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[York County, Pennsylvania is in the southeastern part of the state and can be seen on a map at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/York_County,_Pennsylvania#/media/File:Map_of_Pennsylvania_highlighting_York_County.svg. - Mod.LL]\n\n*****\n[4] Utah (Summit County)\nDate: Wed 8 Apr 2015\nSource: Vaccine News Daily Reports [edited]\nhttp://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/333382-park-city-utah-sees-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nAs many as 63 cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, in children have been reported recently by Utah's Summit County Health Department. Pertussis, a highly contagious respiratory disease, has a 21-day incubation period.\n\n'We will be seeing cases for a while longer,' Summit County Health Department nursing director Carolyn Rose said in a telephone interview with Vaccine News Daily. 'We have 62 to 63 cases, but that changes daily.' To combat the spread of pertussis in its elementary schools, Park City School District officials and the health department have mandated that children who have not been vaccinated for pertussis stay home from school for 21 days or complete a course of antibiotics.\n\n'A lot of the cases are in that 3- to 5-year range, right before kids get boosters before they go into kindergarten,' Rose said.\n\nThe CDC says the best way to prevent pertussis is to get vaccinated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4389. Summit County, in north-central Utah, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/utah-county-map.gif. - Mod. LL]\n\n******\n[5] Guam\nDate: Fri 27 Mar 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/guam-reports-pertussis-outbreak-11-cases-reported-to-date-28327/\n\n\nHealth authorities on the Pacific Island of Guam say the pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak has reached 11 cases to date. This comes after the Department of Public Health and Social Services (DPHSS) received 3 additional laboratory confirmed cases of the vaccine-preventable disease in a 9 month old child, 3 year old child, and 41 year old adult. Investigation into the newest cases show no epidemiological linkage with each other or previous reported cases.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Guam is an organized, unincorporated territory of the United States in the western Pacific Ocean. A map of the island can be found at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/guam.gif.\n\nThere are likely a number of reasons for the upswing of pertussis in the USA and elsewhere, which include the well-recognized normal swings in incidence, the increase in the number of unvaccinated individuals whose parents chose not to vaccinate them, and waning immunity which has caused public health officials to advise boosters for all adults and especially pregnant women. However, research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) have been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail, reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. These changes may result in a need for modifications of the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nHere are the number of cases logged by the Pennsylvania Department of Health in recent years:\n\n2010: 979 cases\n2011: 742 cases\n2012: 1945 cases\n2013: 633\n2014: 691 confirmed or probable cases as of late December [2014]. According to school officials, 6 of the 7 high school students stricken with the highly contagious respiratory disease had been vaccinated, 'Out of the entire Radnor High School student body, 7 students are currently exempt from vaccinations for medical or religious reasons,' the statement said. ' LL]\n\n*****\n LL]\n\n******\n LL]\n\n*****\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1945-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bucks", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Summit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Benton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allegheny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/york_county,_pennsylvania#/media/file:map_of_pennsylvania_highlighting_york_county.svg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mississippi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3126014", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Brazil: (AC) indigenous people, infant mortality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3126014", "date": "2015-01-28 21:03:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL: (ACRE) INDIGENOUS PEOPLE, INFANT MORTALITY\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2015\nSource: A Gazeta do Acre [in Portuguese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://agazetadoacre.com/noticias/epidemia-de-coqueluche-matou-11-criancas-indigenas-em-2014-no-acre/\n\n\nFrom June to September 2014, 11 children of indigenous people of the Rio Breu area in Acre State, died with suspected pertussis. 9 of the children were from the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land called HuniKui, and 2 were of the Ashaninka people. One of the victims was 7 years of age, however, the majority were between 1 and 3 months of age.\n\nFor the communities to receive medical care, it is necessary to go by a motor canoe to the municipality of Marechal Thaumaturgo is necessary. The closest village, San Jose, can be 8 to 12 hours of additional travel when the level of the river is high, and the hard trip to the farthest town, Jacobina, takes 2 days. When the river is dry, the journey can take up to 4 days with some stretches traveled on foot, carrying the canoe. 2 children did not survive the long journey over the past year.\n\nAlthough the diagnosis of pertussis has not been confirmed, the symptoms are similar to those of the disease. The disease in older children and in adults was not so severe as it was in the young infants.\n\n[Byline: Isabela Gadelha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. In such remote areas, the degree, if any, of medical care and the availability of antimicrobials and vaccines are likely to be quite problematic.\n\nA recent publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904; http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10553. Acre (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acre_(state)) is located in the westernmost part of the Brazil, with a 2-hour time difference from Brasilia. It is bordered clockwise by Amazonas to the north and northeast, Rondonia to the east, the Bolivian department of Pando to the southeast, and the Peruvian regions of Madre de Dios, Ucayali, and Loreto to the south and west. It occupies an area of 152 581.4 sq km, being slightly smaller than Tunisia. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. Communicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. \n\nA recent publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. INDIGENOUS PEOPLE, INFANT MORTALITY\n**************************************************************\n From June to September 2014, 11 children of indigenous people of the Rio Breu area in Acre State, died with suspected pertussis. The closest village, San Jose, can be 8 to 12 hours of additional travel when the level of the river is high, and the hard trip to the farthest town, Jacobina, takes 2 days. [Byline: Isabela Gadelha]\n\n--\n Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-27 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Jose", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasilia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loreto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Acre State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rondonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3111598", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (03): (MD) health care worker presenteeism, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3111598", "date": "2015-01-23 13:22:20", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (03): (MARYLAND) HEALTH CARE WORKER PRESENTEEISM, 2014\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Jan 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(02): 45 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6402a3.htm?s_cid=mm6402a3_w\n\n\nInvestigation of contacts of a health care worker who worked while ill with pertussis -- Maryland, August-September 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Chu KM, Johnson LA]\n\nOn 5 Sep 2014, the public health department of a Maryland hospital was notified of a case of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in a staff health care worker (HCW). The HCW experienced onset of diarrhea and malaise (non-respiratory symptoms atypical of the catarrhal phase of pertussis) on 26 Aug 2014. By 2 Sep 2014, paroxysms of coughing led the HCW to consult a colleague, who ordered the PCR test, prescribed a 5-day course of azithromycin, and advised avoidance of patient care until treatment completion. Contrary to the hospital's infection control policy, neither the HCW nor the colleague reported the presumptive diagnosis of pertussis to the hospital's public health department. The HCW continued to work in the outpatient department until the positive PCR result was received on 5 Sep 2014, at which time the hospital's public health department was first notified. The hospital barred the HCW from further work at the hospital while ill, and, in collaboration with local and state public health counterparts, began a contact investigation and stratified patient and HCW contacts by level of exposure.\n\nThe HCW had received tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) in 2010 and reported an ill family member who had been exposed at school during a widespread outbreak of pertussis affecting the surrounding community in August [2014] (1). In all, 47 persons were identified as being exposed to the HCW, including 31 patients ranging in age from 7 days to 12 years (six of whom were too young to receive diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis vaccine [DTaP]) and 15 HCWs. Of these exposed persons, 22 were considered high-risk contacts (7 patients and 15 HCWs) because they were aged less than 12 months, or contacts who themselves have close contact with infants under 12 months, pregnant women, or persons with preexisting health conditions at risk for severe illness or complications from pertussis. All 22 high-risk contacts were assessed for symptoms and received postexposure prophylaxis according to established guidelines (2). Additionally, 6 HCW high-risk contacts (3 staff physicians, 2 residents, and a nurse) reported symptoms suggestive of pertussis and were excluded from work until completion of a course of antibiotics. No patient contacts reported symptoms. Nasopharyngeal swabs obtained from all symptomatic high-risk contacts were negative for pertussis by PCR. The remaining low-risk contacts, or their identified parents or guardians, were screened for symptoms, informed of the low-risk nature of the exposure, and provided education on the signs and symptoms of pertussis. All 47 persons identified as exposed were contacted by public health investigators.\n\nHCW presenteeism (that is, working while sick) can jeopardize the well-being of patients and coworkers (3). Because of the need to investigate and limit exposures, clinical activities in a facility can be disrupted when staff members are potentially exposed to transmissible disease. HCWs should not work while ill with a potentially contagious condition.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. St. George D: Whooping cough outbreak in Montgomery includes students at public, private schools. Washington Post; 2014. Available at http://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/whooping-cough-outbreak-in-montgomery-includes-students-at-seven-public-schools/2014/09/07/adb5c87c-34fb-11e4-9e92-0899b306bbea_story.html.\n2. CDC: Postexposure antimicrobial prophylaxis. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health and Human Services, CDC; 2013. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/pep.html.\n3. Widera E, Chang A, Chen HL: Presenteeism: a public health hazard. J Gen Intern Med 2010;25: 1244-1247; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2947637/.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In my experience, many health care workers are hesitant to use their sick days up for a variety of reasons. Coming to work ill with an infectious disease, presenteeism, whether it be pertussis or influenza or any other, puts our patients at risk. I have always favored the policy of putting such potentially infectious health care workers on 'leave' without requiring them to use sick days.\n\nPrimum non nocere (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primum_non_nocere) is a Latin phrase that means 'first, do no harm.' The phrase is sometimes recorded as primum nil nocere. Non-maleficence, which is derived from the maxim, is one of the principal precepts of bioethics that all healthcare students are taught in school and is a fundamental principle throughout the world. Another way to state it is that, 'given an existing problem, it may be better not to do something, or even to do nothing, than to risk causing more harm than good.' It reminds the health care provider that they must consider the possible harm that any intervention might do. It is invoked when debating the use of an intervention that carries an obvious risk of harm but a less certain chance of benefit. Non-maleficence is often contrasted with its corollary, beneficence. The origin of the phrase is uncertain. The Hippocratic Oath includes the promise 'to abstain from doing harm' but does not include the precise phrase. Perhaps the closest approximation in the Hippocratic Corpus is in Epidemics: 'The physician must ... have 2 special objects in view with regard to disease, namely, to do good or to do no harm.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/223.]", "summary": "Of these exposed persons, 22 were considered high-risk contacts (7 patients and 15 HCWs) because they were aged less than 12 months, or contacts who themselves have close contact with infants under 12 months, pregnant women, or persons with preexisting health conditions at risk for severe illness or complications from pertussis. [Authors: Chu KM, Johnson LA]\n\nOn 5 Sep 2014, the public health department of a Maryland hospital was notified of a case of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in a staff health care worker (HCW). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n PERTUSSIS - USA (03): (MARYLAND) HEALTH CARE WORKER PRESENTEEISM, 2014\n**********************************************************************\n \n\nThe HCW had received tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) in 2010 and reported an ill family member who had been exposed at school during a widespread outbreak of pertussis affecting the surrounding community in August [2014] (1). http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6402a3.htm?s_cid=mm6402a3_w\n\n\nInvestigation of contacts of a health care worker who worked while ill with pertussis -- Maryland, August-September 2014\n Additionally, 6 HCW high-risk contacts (3 staff physicians, 2 residents, and a nurse) reported symptoms suggestive of pertussis and were excluded from work until completion of a course of antibiotics. The remaining low-risk contacts, or their identified parents or guardians, were screened for symptoms, informed of the low-risk nature of the exposure, and provided education on the signs and symptoms of pertussis. The hospital barred the HCW from further work at the hospital while ill, and, in collaboration with local and state public health counterparts, began a contact investigation and stratified patient and HCW contacts by level of exposure. Contrary to the hospital's infection control policy, neither the HCW nor the colleague reported the presumptive diagnosis of pertussis to the hospital's public health department. The HCW continued to work in the outpatient department until the positive PCR result was received on 5 Sep 2014, at which time the hospital's public health department was first notified. In all, 47 persons were identified as being exposed to the HCW, including 31 patients ranging in age from 7 days to 12 years (six of whom were too young to receive diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis vaccine [DTaP]) and 15 HCWs. All 22 high-risk contacts were assessed for symptoms and received postexposure prophylaxis according to established guidelines (2). The zone's medical health officer says there is no way to know how long the outbreak will last. Digby Horne says there were 128 confirmed cases in 2014 and 1 case so far in 2015.\n\nThe outbreak was declared in early December 2014 after whooping cough spiked in late summer and October of 2014. Horne says people of all ages have been affected, but there aren't big clusters of infection in any one place. There was no update available on how many people have been hospitalized.\n\nPertussis also hit central Alberta in 2013 with 98 cases. In 2013, 'it seemed to be concentrated in a few areas. What we saw (in 2014) is it seemed to spread and will probably continue for a few more months.'\n\nInfants 6 months of age and younger are at greatest risk for serious complications, which include pneumonia, convulsions, brain damage and death.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2014, there have also been outbreaks of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection in British Columbia and Prince Edward Island. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/263.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Calgary Herald, Canadian Press report [edited]\nhttp://calgaryherald.com/health/family-child/whooping-cough-outbreak-slow-to-leave-central-alberta\n\n\nCases of whooping cough are still being diagnosed in central Alberta, the only health zone in the province experiencing an outbreak. \n\nThe outbreak was declared in early December 2014 after whooping cough spiked in late summer and October of 2014. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< PERTUSSIS - CANADA: (ALBERTA)\n*****************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-09 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3094365", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3094365", "date": "2015-01-15 16:46:55", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this post:\n[1] Victoria\n[2] Queensland, New South Wales\n\n******\n[1] Victoria\nDate: Sat 10 Jan 2015\nSource: Melbourne Herald Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/babies-most-at-risk-of-whooping-cough/story-fni0fit3-1227180816224\n\n\nWhooping cough cases shot up by more than 50 percent in the past year with an alarming increase in babies diagnosed with the potentially deadly infection. There were 4606 cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, between January 2014-2015. The largest increases were in children aged 10-14 and babies under 6 months. In a warning to clinicians and public health personnel, Chief Health Officer Rosemary Lester said infants of this age were also the most susceptible to the severe complications of pertussis. One in every 200 babies that contracts the infection will die.\n\nThe latest data from the [Victoria] Department of Health showed a 43 percent increase in whooping cough cases in patients aged 10-14 to 6 Jan 2015. There was also a 38 percent rise in babies aged under 6 months, increasing to 76 cases in 2014 from 55 in 2013.\n\n[Byline: Lucie Vandenberg]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Queensland, New South Wales\nDate: Sun 11 Jan 2015\nSource: The Courier-Mail [edited]\nhttp://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/queensland-records-the-nations-lowest-rate-of-whooping-cough-infections/story-fnn8dlfs-1227180764127\n\n\nFigures obtained from the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System show 1383 Queenslanders tested positive to the vaccine preventable bacterial disease in 2014, a rate of 29.7 cases per 100 000 people. The numbers were less than half those recorded in 2013 and 1/5th of those seen in 2012. They are the lowest for whooping cough in Queensland since 2004 when doctors reported 1034 cases -- 26.5 cases per 100 000 people. Queensland's 2014 figures were much lower than in New South Wales, which recorded 3023 cases, a rate of 40.8 cases per 100 000 population.\n\nQueensland Health's acting senior communicable diseases director Heidi Carroll said the drastically reduced numbers in the state were pleasing, but it was too early to say whether the fall was attributable to the statewide immunization strategy launched in 2014.\n\n'We are only 7 months into the implementation of the immunization strategy, which has set a target of 95 percent of all children being fully vaccinated,' Dr Carroll said. 'It is the only target of its kind in Australia.\n\n'Current figures show that we are hovering around the 91 percent mark for 1-year-olds, 93 percent for 2-year-olds and 92 percent for 5-year-olds.'\n\nDr Carroll said whooping cough was a highly contagious and very serious disease for babies and young children. 'By reducing the amount in the community, we are helping to minimize their exposure to the bacterium,' she said. 'However, while rates may have declined, we still have 1300 cases, too many for a virus that is entirely preventable through vaccination.'\n\n[Byline: Janelle Miles]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As shown in Australia as well as in the USA, the uptick of pertussis cases can be quite variable from state to state. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Current figures show that we are hovering around the 91 percent mark for 1-year-olds, 93 percent for 2-year-olds and 92 percent for 5-year-olds.' \n\nThe latest data from the [Victoria] Department of Health showed a 43 percent increase in whooping cough cases in patients aged 10-14 to 6 Jan 2015. \n\n[Byline: Janelle Miles]\n\n--\n Victoria\nDate: Sat 10 Jan 2015\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n\nWhooping cough cases shot up by more than 50 percent in the past year with an alarming increase in babies diagnosed with the potentially deadly infection. They are the lowest for whooping cough in Queensland since 2004 when doctors reported 1034 cases -- 26.5 cases per 100 000 people. PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA\n*********************\n \n\nQueensland Health's acting senior communicable diseases director Heidi Carroll said the drastically reduced numbers in the state were pleasing, but it was too early to say whether the fall was attributable to the statewide immunization strategy launched in 2014. There was also a 38 percent rise in babies aged under 6 months, increasing to 76 cases in 2014 from 55 in 2013.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1034-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-11 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-10 00:00:00", "2021-10-14 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1383-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3093551", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3093551", "date": "2015-01-15 15:46:21", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA: (CALIFORNIA) FATAL\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jan 2015\nSource: KCBX FM, Central Coast Public Radio [edited]\nhttp://kcbx.org/post/infant-becomes-santa-barbara-countys-first-recorded-death-whooping-cough\n\n\nCalifornia is in the middle of a whooping cough epidemic, the worst the state has seen in 70 years. The outbreak's latest fatality was a 25-day-old baby in Santa Barbara County. It's the county's 1st recorded death from the disease -- also called pertussis -- and only the 2nd death in California since the outbreak started last year [2014].\n\nDoctor Charity Thoman is with the Santa Barbara County Public Health Department and says deaths from the disease are preventable because there is a vaccine. She hopes in the wake of this tragic death that people will work to keep the disease from taking any more victims. 'I hope they use this information to make sure that they have their booster shot, to make sure that all their kids are up to date on their booster shots, and importantly for infants, to make sure that anyone coming into contact with an infant -- favorite uncle, baby sitter, nursery provider -- they all have their booster shots against pertussis,' said Thoman.\n\nSan Luis Obispo and Monterey Counties are not yet seeing record numbers, but total cases for this current outbreak far exceed those reported over the past few years.\n\n[Byline: Randol White]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2013 was the US's worst year for pertussis (whooping cough) in 6 decades, with more than 48 000 cases, including 18 deaths. In 2014, the number of reported cases nationwide dropped to about 20 000. However, as of 15 Dec 2014, the number of pertussis cases reported in California in 2014 (9935) was the highest number in 70 years. San Diego County is among the hardest hit. The cases included an infant who died (ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (29) 20141222.3044440).\n\nAlthough in some regions low immunization rates account for pertussis outbreaks, the California Department of Public Health said that low inoculation rates could not account for the current pertussis outbreak in the state, because 90 per cent of those children infected in 2014 had been vaccinated against pertussis; increased virulence and a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, attributed to genetic changes, as well as a waning immune response after vaccination may be other causes of the current outbreaks.\n\nIn the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). (Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D) and tetanus (T) toxoids and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.)\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccines.\n\nCalifornia of can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Although in some regions low immunization rates account for pertussis outbreaks, the California Department of Public Health said that low inoculation rates could not account for the current pertussis outbreak in the state, because 90 per cent of those children infected in 2014 had been vaccinated against pertussis; increased virulence and a mismatch between the vaccine strain and the current circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, attributed to genetic changes, as well as a waning immune response after vaccination may be other causes of the current outbreaks. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2013 was the US's worst year for pertussis (whooping cough) in 6 decades, with more than 48 000 cases, including 18 deaths. I hope they use this information to make sure that they have their booster shot, to make sure that all their kids are up to date on their booster shots, and importantly for infants, to make sure that anyone coming into contact with an infant -- favorite uncle, baby sitter, nursery provider -- they all have their booster shots against pertussis,' said Thoman. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However, as of 15 Dec 2014, the number of pertussis cases reported in California in 2014 (9935) was the highest number in 70 years. It's the county's 1st recorded death from the disease -- also called pertussis -- and only the 2nd death in California since the outbreak started last year [2014]. Because infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccines. \n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. \n\nSan Luis Obispo and Monterey Counties are not yet seeing record numbers, but total cases for this current outbreak far exceed those reported over the past few years. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.) The cases included an infant who died (ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (29) 20141222.3044440). (Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D) and tetanus (T) toxoids and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis. PERTUSSIS - USA: (CALIFORNIA) FATAL\n* [Byline: Randol White]\n\n--\n One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. \n\n\nCalifornia is in the middle of a whooping cough epidemic, the worst the state has seen in 70 years.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-13 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "9935-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Barbara County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Luis Obispo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3094367", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3094367", "date": "2015-01-16 13:13:23", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Indiana (Washington County)\n[2] Washington State (Walla Walla County)\n[3] Alaska\n[4] California\n[5] California (Santa Barbara County) infant fatality\n\n******\n[1] Indiana (Washington County)\nDate: Wed 14 Jan 2015\nSource: WDRB [edited]\nhttp://www.wdrb.com/story/27853773/health-officials-warn-against-whooping-cough-as-cases-appear-in-southern-indiana\n\n\nSeveral cases of whooping cough were detected in Washington County, Indiana earlier this week. The health department says 3 people, 2 juveniles and an adult, are being treated with antimicrobials for the disease. Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, can cause coughing fits which can lead to ongoing breathing issues and in some cases can also lead to pneumonia and seizures. Generally, it is milder in children and adults. However, health leaders say it can be very dangerous for infants.\n\n'It can easily spread,' says Peggy Scott with the Washington County Health Department, 'You need to protect those who can't get their vaccine or are too young to complete their vaccine.'\n\nOf the 3 cases in Washington County, 2 were students in school. One of those students is in elementary school in the Salem Community School District. Letters went home with parents of students in the district warning them that another student had tested positive.\n\n[Byline: Travis Ragsdale]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25803. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n*****\n[2] Washington State (Walla Walla County)\nDate: Tue 6 Jan 2015\nSource: Walla Walla Union-Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://t.union-bulletin.com/news/2015/jan/06/flu-pertussis-cases-climb-walla-walla-valley\n\n\nHealth officials today [6 Jan 2015] said Walla Walla County is experiencing a greatly increased number of cases of pertussis, best known as whooping cough. 'We're seeing pertussis in high school students. We've had a 5-month-old infant diagnosed, but we're now receiving a number of reports in adolescents,' he said. 'And that's particularly worrisome.'\n\nToday's pertussis immunization was developed to be safe for infants 'but the immunity is not particularly long-lived,' Crowder said. 'We're trying to find a better vaccine for adolescents and adults.'\n\n[Byline: Sheila Hagar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[3] Alaska\nDate: Sun 4 Jan 2015\nSource: News Miner [edited]\nhttp://www.newsminer.com/features/health/more-than-cases-of-whooping-cough-reported-in-in-alaska/article_55b07906-94b4-11e4-bab0-2f9260573e86.html\n\n\nBetween January and November 2014, Alaska had 130 reported cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, according to the Alaska Department of Health and Social Services. September 2014 had the highest number of incidences, 38, followed by October 2014, with 22.\n\nWhile a significant drop from the 356 cases reported in 2012, it was still significantly more than the 26 reported in 2011. Epidemiologist Louisa Castrodale said the large number of reported cases is likely a reflection of a growing baseline and increased screening.\n\nOf the 130 cases reported, 92 were from Interior Alaska. Castrodale said the large percentage of pertussis from the Interior is likely due to increased screening after a confirmed case.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Alaska can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 12 Jan 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/california-pertussis-cases-top-10000-for-2014/\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough, or pertussis, cases reported in the California epidemic in 2014 has eclipsed 10 000, and the counting is still ongoing. The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) reports the preliminary numbers to be 10 831 cases with onset in 2014.\n\nLos Angeles and San Diego have seen the most cases with nearly 2000 cases a piece reported.\n\nIn June 2014, health authorities declared pertussis and epidemic in the state. The last epidemic in California occurred in 2010 when the state experienced 9159 cases, the most in 6 decades; however, the overall incidence of pertussis has increased since the 1990s. In fact, pertussis incidence is higher than was reported in 2010 with a state rate of 28.35 cases per 100 000 population. Approximately 3.5 percent of all cases required hospitalization, with a quarter of them requiring intensive care treatment. 2 pediatric deaths were reported in 2014.\n\nOne reason for the increase is the use of acellular pertussis vaccines, which cause fewer reactions than the whole-cell vaccines that preceded them, but do not protect as long. Young infants are at greatest risk of hospitalization and death from pertussis, therefore pregnant women are encouraged to receive pertussis vaccine (Tdap) during the 3rd trimester of every pregnancy. Pertussis antibodies are transferred from vaccinated mothers to their infants and will help protect them until they are old enough to be vaccinated.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] California (Santa Barbara County) infant fatality\nDate: Wed 14 Jan 2015\nSource: Fox News, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.foxnews.com/health/2015/01/14/santa-barbara-county-infant-dies-from-whooping-cough/\n\n\nA newborn baby has died from whooping cough in Southern California, the 4th death since the beginning of 2014 as the state deals with an epidemic. The Santa Barbara County Public Health Department announced the death Tue 13 Jan 2015. It says the baby was 25 days old, caught the bacterial infection last year [2014] and died this month [January 2015].\n\nThe state Department of Public Health says 3 other infants died in 2014, including 2 who caught the illness in 2013. State health officials have recorded 10 831 cases that were contracted in 2014. It's the worst epidemic to hit the state in 7 decades. Authorities attribute the increase to better detection and to the use of new vaccines that have fewer side effects but also don't protect as long.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA recent publication confirms that safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904; http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Authorities attribute the increase to better detection and to the use of new vaccines that have fewer side effects but also don't protect as long.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: Walla Walla Union-Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://t.union-bulletin.com/news/2015/jan/06/flu-pertussis-cases-climb-walla-walla-valley\n\n\nHealth officials today [6 Jan 2015] said Walla Walla County is experiencing a greatly increased number of cases of pertussis, best known as whooping cough. PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, can cause coughing fits which can lead to ongoing breathing issues and in some cases can also lead to pneumonia and seizures. Young infants are at greatest risk of hospitalization and death from pertussis, therefore pregnant women are encouraged to receive pertussis vaccine (Tdap) during the 3rd trimester of every pregnancy.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-13 00:00:00", "2014-10-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-04 00:00:00", "2015-01-06 00:00:00", "2014-09-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-14 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-12 00:00:00", "2038-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Barbara County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3048988", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Brazil (04): (PI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3048988", "date": "2014-12-22 16:23:53", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL (04): (PIAUI)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: 180 Graus [in Portuguese, machine transl., edited]\nhttp://180graus.com/saude/aumentam-os-casos-de-coqueluche-no-piaui-de-3-para-176-casos-esse-ano\n\n\nIn 2 years, the occurrence of pertussis in Piaui State increased from 3 in 2012 to 176 in 2014. In 2014, there have been 2 deaths, 1 of which was in Teresina and the other in Esperantina, where there were a total of 3 babies with pertussis and 1 died. According to the director of health surveillance of the Municipal Foundation of Health (FMS), Amariles Borba, pertussis is on the rise due to low efficacy of immunization of the vaccine.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has been attempting to deploy the vaccine for the entire population, but 'there were difficulties in production to meet the demand of the Brazilian market,' says the director. Another problem, according to Amariles, is poor adherence to the vaccination schedule.\n\nThe only preventive vaccination was the pentavalent against tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis, _Haemophilus influenza_ and hepatitis B. It is intended for babies of 2, 4 and 6 months, but 70 per cent of the cases affect newborns in the 1st 3 months. For this reason, the Ministry of Health has chosen to distribute the vaccine in the public health network, which was previously done on the private network and has urged vaccination of mothers late in pregnancy.\n\n[byline: Jhone Sousa]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 4th state in Brazil about which ProMED-mail has posted reports of increases in pertussis in 2014. On ProMED-PORT, reports of outbreaks in 2 additional states have been posted.\n\nPiaui (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piau%C3%AD) has the shortest coastline of any of the non-landlocked Brazilian states at 66 km (41 miles), and the capital, Teresina, is the only state capital in the north east to be located inland. The reason for this is, unlike the rest of the area, Piaui was 1st colonized inland and slowly expanded towards the ocean, rather than the other way around. The location of Piaui in the South American country of Brazil can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Brazil_State_Piaui.svg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9666.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Jhone Sousa]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 4th state in Brazil about which ProMED-mail has posted reports of increases in pertussis in 2014. PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL (04): (PIAUI)\n********************************\n \n\nPiaui (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piau%C3%AD) has the shortest coastline of any of the non-landlocked Brazilian states at 66 km (41 miles), and the capital, Teresina, is the only state capital in the north east to be located inland. In 2014, there have been 2 deaths, 1 of which was in Teresina and the other in Esperantina, where there were a total of 3 babies with pertussis and 1 died.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis b", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Piaui State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ProMED - PORT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Esperantina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3058832", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (30)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3058832", "date": "2014-12-28 16:16:06", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (30)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[2] Nebraska (Lancaster County)\n[3] Pertussis toxin evolution\n\n******\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Tue 23 Dec 2014\nSource: Mlive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/12/grand_traverse_reports_81_whoo.html\n\n\nThe whooping cough outbreak in Grand Traverse County has reached 81 cases. Four babies younger than 12 months have been affected, the health department reported on Tue 22 Dec 2014.\n\nAn advisory [notice] from the health department regarding pertussis, also called whooping cough, encourages residents to take precautions with holiday travel and get-togethers to prevent the spread of disease. Children and adults are advised be up-to-date on vaccinations, including booster shots for pertussis. And people are urged to stay home if they are sick.\n\nThe pertussis outbreak has affected students at 22 schools in the county. The health department also reports 21 cases of parapertussis, an illness similar to pertussis.\n\nA hotline set up to answer questions from those who have been exposed to pertussis has received more than 3900 phone calls. 'Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority,' the advisory says. The health department 'urges all pregnant women to get vaccinated and parents to vaccinate infants as soon as possible.'\n\nInfants who are too young to be vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis. The health department says it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants to have up-to-date vaccines, an approach called cocooning. Mothers, fathers, siblings, grandparents, aunts, uncles and anyone who might be around an infant during the holidays should be vaccinated, said Wendy Trute, the Grand Traverse health officer.\n\n[byline: Sue Thoms]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grand Traverse County is located in the north west part of Michigan's Lower Peninsula http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan. The name Michigan is the French form of the Ojibwa word mishigamaa, meaning 'large water' or 'large lake.' Those living in the Upper Peninsula (or UP) are called 'Yoopers,' now an official word in the Merriam Webster Dictionary. The 2 peninsulas are connected by the famous Mackinaw Bridge, and those of us residing in the lower regions of the state are sometimes referred to by our northern neighbors as 'Trolls', as we live underneath the bridge.\n\nIn Grand Traverse County, there are a number of reasons why the local outbreak has occurred, including decreased efficacy of the current acellular vaccine (see below), the natural 3-5 year waves of the infection, and a substantial 'philosophical' objection rate among parents to the vaccine.\n\nIt should be noted that _Bordetella pertussis_'s cousin, _B. parapertussis_, causes a similar, although milder, illness to _B. pertussis_. There is, however, no cross-protection against parapertussis with the pertussis vaccine. Parapertussis does not produce the pertussis toxin. Co-infections with pertussis and parapertussis are not rare. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Nebraska (Lancaster County)\nDate: Fri 26 Dec 2014\nSource: KETV [edited]\nhttp://www.ketv.com/news/lincoln-health-officials-seeing-unprecedented-number-of-whooping-cough-cases/30415802\n\n\nLincoln-Lancaster County health officials have recorded 110 confirmed cases of whooping cough, and the number is growing.\n\nOn Tue 23 Dec 2014, one family in Lincoln learned that their 16-year-old son was one of those afflicted. 'The doctor said he's got pertussis or whooping cough,' the teenager's father said. That meant even though no one else in the family has it yet, it was home for the holidays. 'It is a terrible gift to give, so we don't want to give this to anybody,' the mother said. The family even left gifts they were going to take to relatives out on their porch. 'They didn't say, 'Hi,' or nothing. They picked it up and drove off,' the teenager said.\n\nNo one appreciates that more than health officials in Lincoln, faced with all the cases in 2014. 'It's the highest we had recorded. The last numbers even close to that were in 2005, and we had 87,' supervisor of the Communicable Disease Program Tim Timmons said.\n\nPertussis outbreaks are occurring all across the country. Health officials said the vaccination apparently wears off. Kids are supposed to get 4 doses of it by age 2, another when they enter grade school, and a booster shot in high school. 'The immunity doesn't seem to last as long, maybe 3-4 years,' Timmons said. That's why so many middle and high school students, like this teenager, seem to be getting the disease even when they had their shots.\n\n[byline: Andrew Ozaki]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nebraska (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebraska) gets its name from the archaic Otoe words 'ni brasge' meaning 'flat water', after the Platte River that flows through the state. It is located in the central USA. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] Pertussis toxin evolution\nDate: Fri 26 Dec 2014\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/health-30551093\n\n\nAnalysis of strains from 2012 shows the parts of the pertussis bacterium that the vaccine primes the immune system to recognize are changing. It may have 'serious consequences' in future outbreaks, UK researchers state in the Journal of Infectious Diseases. But experts stressed that the vaccine remains highly effective in protecting the most vulnerable young babies.\n\nRising figures prompted health officials to recommend vaccination of pregnant women so immunity could be passed to their newborns, a strategy that a recent study showed was working well. But there has been much debate among experts about whether the introduction of a new vaccine in 2004 has been a factor in rising rates of whooping cough.\n\nOne issue is that immunity from the newer acellular vaccine does not seem to last as long as the previous whole cell version, leaving teenagers and adults lacking protection. In the latest study, researchers analysed the genes coding for the proteins on the surface of the pertussis bacterium responsible for the UK outbreak. They found proteins being targeted by the vaccine were mutating at a faster rate than other surface proteins not included in the vaccine. Potentially, it means the bacteria are changing quickly to get around the immune system's defenses put in place with immunization.\n\nBut the researchers are still trying to work out what the changes mean in reality; for example, do the mutations boost the ability of the bacteria to cause infection. 'We wanted to look at strains from the UK to see if there was anything sudden that had occurred that had led to these really large outbreaks,' said study leader Dr Andrew Preston from the University of Bath. The 'million dollar question,' he said, was what, if anything, could be done to improve the vaccine, which is still the best defense we have, and prevent future outbreaks.\n\nOptions to consider include adding more or different proteins to the vaccine, adding novel adjuvants (chemicals which boost the immune response), or even revisiting the old-style whole cell vaccine, he said. 'Pertussis has a cyclical nature, and another big question is are we going to see another increase in late 2015?,' he added.\n\nProf Adam Finn, a paediatric immunology expert at the University of Bristol, said the importance, or not, of the subtle changes found in the study was, as yet, unclear. 'But the control of pertussis is a significant worry,' he added.\n\n[byline: Emma Wilkinson]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The publication mentioned is Sealey KL, Harris SR, Fry NK, et al. Genomic analysis of isolates from the UK 2012 pertussis outbreak reveals that vaccine antigen genes are unusually fast evolving. J Infect Dis. 8 Dec 2014. pii: jiu665. [Epub ahead of print].\n\nAbstract:\n'A major outbreak of whooping cough, or pertussis, occurred in 2012 in the UK, with nearly 10 000 laboratory-confirmed cases and 14 infant deaths attributed to pertussis. A worldwide resurgence of pertussis has been linked to switch to the use of acellular pertussis vaccines and the evolution of _B. pertussis_ away from vaccine-mediated immunity. We have conducted genomic analyses of multiple strains from the UK outbreak. We show that the UK outbreak was polyclonal in nature, caused by multiple distinct but closely related strains. Importantly, we demonstrate that acellular vaccine antigen encoding genes are evolving at higher rates than other surface protein encoding genes. This was true even prior to the introduction of pertussis vaccines but has become more pronounced since the introduction of the current acellular vaccines. The fast evolution of vaccine antigen genes has serious consequences for the ability of current vaccines to continue to control pertussis.'\n\nAnother recently published study (van Gent M, Heuvelman CJ, van der Heide HG, et al. Analysis of _Bordetella pertussis_ clinical isolates circulating in European countries during the period 1998-2012. Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2014 Dec 20. [Epub ahead of print] with Frits Mooi as the senior author has also addressed this issue:\n\nAbstract:\n'Despite more than 50 years of vaccination, pertussis is still an endemic disease, with regular epidemic outbreaks. With the exception of Poland, European countries have replaced whole-cell vaccines (WCVs) by acellular vaccines (ACVs) in the 1990s. Worldwide, antigenic divergence in vaccine antigens has been found between vaccine strains and circulating strains. In this work, 466 _Bordetella pertussis_ isolates collected in the period 1998-2012 from 13 European countries were characterized by multi-locus antigen sequence typing (MAST) of the pertussis toxin promoter (ptxP) and of the genes coding for proteins used in the ACVs: pertussis toxin (Ptx), pertactin (Prn), type 2 fimbriae (Fim2) and type 3 fimbriae (Fim3). Isolates were further characterised by fimbrial serotyping, multi-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA), and pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE). The results showed a very similar _B. pertussis_ population for 12 countries using ACVs, while Poland, which uses a WCV, was quite distinct, suggesting that ACVs and WCVs select for different _B. pertussis_ populations. This study forms a baseline for future studies on the effect of vaccination programs on _B. pertussis_ populations.'\n\nTo me, the evolutionary changes in current pertussis strains documented in the USA, Europe and Australia are playing a significant, but not at all the sole role in the upswing of pertussis throughout the world, and alteration of the current vaccine may be needed. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Andrew Ozaki]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nebraska (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebraska) gets its name from the archaic Otoe words 'ni brasge' meaning 'flat water', after the Platte River that flows through the state. \n\n[byline: Sue Thoms]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grand Traverse County is located in the north west part of Michigan's Lower Peninsula http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-12-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lancaster County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grand Traverse County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Traverse County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ojibwa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3039729", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - EU: 2012 increase", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3039729", "date": "2014-12-17 22:58:40", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - EU: 2012 INCREASE\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Dec 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-cases-up-significantly-in-the-eu-netherlands-and-uk-worst-hit-55315/\n\n\nThe number of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases in the European Union is up dramatically from 2011 to 2012, according to new data published in the Annual epidemiological report 2014 -- vaccine-preventable diseases, a European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) publication.\n\nIn 2012, the notification rate of pertussis cases was more than twice as high as in previous years. With 42 525 (38 840 confirmed) cases reported by 28 EU/EEA [European Union/European Economic Area] countries, the overall rate of confirmed cases in 2012 was 10.93 cases per 100 000 population, twice as high as in previous years. This compares to the 4 previous years -- in 2011 the EU saw 17 068 cases, in 2010 there were 14 337, and there were 18 164 and 19 741 cases recorded in 2009 and 2008, respectively.\n\nThe Netherlands reported the highest total number of cases (N=12 868), more than twice the number than in 2011, representing 30 percent of the total EU/EEA reported number of cases. The United Kingdom reported nearly 10 times more cases than in 2011 (1256 cases in 2011 to 11 993 cases in 2012), representing 28 percent of the total EU/EEA reported number of cases.\n\nIn addition to the 2 above countries, notable increases in the notification rate were observed in Denmark, Latvia, Czech Republic, Austria, Lithuania, Ireland, Poland and Portugal.\n\nThe ECDC says based on the data presented, pertussis is no longer solely a pediatric infection. Incidence is increasing in adolescents and adults and gives reasons for concern as these age groups are a source of transmission to infants too young to be vaccinated, especially because of mild and asymptomatic symptoms in adolescents and adults which are often not recognized as pertussis. As most severe cases and deaths occur in infants, policy makers need to reconsider regular pertussis booster vaccinations in adolescents and adults to reduce the overall incidence and indirectly protect susceptible infants.\n\nVaccine strategies should be revisited and consideration given to adolescent and adult boosters, as well as to vaccinations for healthcare workers and pregnant women, as these measures are essential for prevention, the health organization concludes.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11767.]", "summary": "The United Kingdom reported nearly 10 times more cases than in 2011 (1256 cases in 2011 to 11 993 cases in 2012), representing 28 percent of the total EU/EEA reported number of cases. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n This compares to the 4 previous years -- in 2011 the EU saw 17 068 cases, in 2010 there were 14 337, and there were 18 164 and 19 741 cases recorded in 2009 and 2008, respectively.
