Australia (02): cruise ship, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3032695", "date": "2014-12-14 21:18:19", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): CRUISE SHIP, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 12 Dec 2014\nSource: Cruise Law News [edited]\nhttp://www.cruiselawnews.com/2014/12/articles/disease-1/whooping-cough-outbreak-on-the-voyager-of-the-seas/\n\n\nThe operator of a fan 'Voyager of the Seas' Facebook page (not operated by the cruise line) posted the following:\n\n'If you were on the Voyager of the Seas relocation cruise from Singapore to Sydney, and you have a really bad cough, then I suggest you go see a doctor, as you may have whooping cough...'\n\nA large number of passengers have posted comments in response to this post. Many passengers on the cruise say that they are ill. Many people say that they are having their blood drawn and are seeing doctors to have their throats swabbed. Others say that it has been confirmed that they have been diagnosed with whooping cough.\n\nPassengers complain that they have heard nothing from Royal Caribbean. One person who heard back from the cruise line remarked: 'I've heard from RC, and they told me they are not compelled to notify all passengers...'\n\n[Byline: Jim Walker]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate information regarding what may be an outbreak of pertussis linked to a cruise ship that went from Singapore to Sydney. It would be very interesting to know the demographics of the travelers and their ages, which can help determine whether their past pertussis immunizations were from the better tolerated but with waning immunity acellular vaccine or from the older, more reactogenic but with longer lasting immunity whole cell killed _Bordetella pertussis_ vaccine. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate information regarding what may be an outbreak of pertussis linked to a cruise ship that went from Singapore to Sydney. The operator of a fan 'Voyager of the Seas' Facebook page (not operated by the cruise line) posted the following:\n\n'If you were on the Voyager of the Seas relocation cruise from Singapore to Sydney, and you have a really bad cough, then I suggest you go see a doctor, as you may have whooping cough...' PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): CRUISE SHIP, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************\n It would be very interesting to know the demographics of the travelers and their ages, which can help determine whether their past pertussis immunizations were from the better tolerated but with waning immunity acellular vaccine or from the older, more reactogenic but with longer lasting immunity whole cell killed _Bordetella pertussis_ vaccine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "RC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3027769", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (27): (MI) undervaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3027769", "date": "2014-12-11 16:22:40", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (27): (MICHIGAN) UNDERVACCINATION\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/index.ssf/2014/12/traverse_city_whooping_cough_o.html\n\n\nOver the past 6 weeks [late October to early December 2014], the Traverse City [Michigan] area has become an unnerving, real-life example of the consequences of undervaccination. Cases of whooping cough and measles have impacted hundreds of families, overwhelmed local doctors and public health officials, and put parents who don't vaccinate their children on the defensive.\n\n'Nobody likes to be the person who says, 'I told you so,'' but what's unfolding now is exactly the scenario feared by those worried about the region's low immunization numbers, said Dr. Bradley Goodwin, a Traverse City family physician who is president of the Grand Traverse County Medical Society. Grand Traverse County has one of Michigan's highest rates of schoolchildren opting out of vaccines -- twice the state average and 6 times the national rate for kindergartners in 2013-14. In some schools, the rate is even higher. That includes Grand Traverse Academy, the 1200-student charter school associated with the initial outbreak of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, an illness nicknamed 'the 100-day cough.'\n\nA teacher at Grand Traverse Academy was diagnosed with whooping cough on 16 Oct 2014. Once introduced into the school community, the disease took off. To date, a total of 151 confirmed and probable cases of whooping cough have been linked to the school. One reason the illness swept through the academy: A significant number of its students are unvaccinated. In 2013-14, 17 percent of Grand Traverse Academy kindergartners had parents who signed a waiver exempting their children from the required childhood immunizations. 'When you have (pertussis) spread so fast through a school community with high waiver rates, that's not coincidental,' Goodwin said.\n\nAlso fueling the outbreak: When the teacher was 1st diagnosed, students classified as 'close contacts' were told to take antimicrobials as a preventive measure, but not all followed the directive, said Wendy Trute, health director for the Grand Traverse County Health Department. Some parents didn't want to give antibiotics to children who don't seem sick. But whooping cough is contagious before symptoms appear. '2 families didn't get or take antimicrobials, and they account for 8 or 9 of the confirmed cases,' Trute said. 'People not following through (with medical directives) is one of the issues.'\n\nThe school had so many cases of whooping cough that school officials canceled the elementary fall carnival as well as 4 days of classes. While the school was shuttered, the 1200 students were told to stay at home in quarantine to prevent spreading the disease further.\n\nThat was the 2nd week of November 2014. Since then, whooping cough cases have been reported at 14 other school buildings across the region and new cases are still coming in, Trute said.\n\nTrute said about 1/3rd of the pertussis cases in the Traverse City area involve people who are vaccinated. Particularly vulnerable have been children around age 10 or 11, because the immunizations they received in infancy are wearing off and they haven't yet had a booster shot. It didn't help that the outbreak at Grand Traverse Academy started in the upper elementary grades, Trute said. Still, it's clear that unvaccinated children were those most at risk. A state epidemiologist ran the numbers for the Traverse City pertussis outbreak and calculated that children who aren't vaccinated have been 5 times more likely to come down with pertussis than those who have been immunized, Trute said.\n\nThe pertussis outbreak has become a hot-button issue in Traverse City, pitting parents who vaccinate their children against those who don't, said Beth Milligan, a reporter for The Ticker, a Traverse City news website. 'People on the pro-vaccination side are very angry at the anti-vaxers for exposing their children to disease,' Milligan said. Meanwhile, 'the anti-vaxers are latching onto the fact' that some fully vaccinated people are getting whooping cough, which they say proves their point that vaccinations are ineffective, Milligan added.\n\n'A lot of people who don't vaccinate don't see the need,' said Milligan, who wrote an in-depth story in September 2014 about the county's low vaccination rate. 'Many are families who are into holistic medicine,' and feel there are better ways to build the immune system and ward off disease.\n\nThe problem with that thinking, Goodwin said, is that unvaccinated people are much more likely to spread disease compared to those who are immunized, even if the unvaccinated people don't appear sick. 'I'm a big believer in better living through better living,' Goodwin said. 'But while your immune system is fighting off an illness, you can still be contagious and infect others, and those others may not be as healthy as you.'\n\nIf anything, Trute said, the fact the pertussis vaccine is not 100 percent effective is all the more reason to maintain high immunization rates, to prevent the disease from getting a foothold in the community. Her fear, she said, is that what's happening in 2014 will become a semi-regular event in Grand Traverse County.\n\n'It's also helping people to reconsider and re-evaluate their stance against vaccines,' Goodwin added. 'Most people are seeing now that there is a value to getting vaccines, and realizing their previous premise about going without being vaccinated was overzealous.'\n\nTrute agreed there has been a 'fair amount of conversation' in recent weeks about trying to reduce the number of schoolchildren with vaccination waivers. 'A lot of people are becoming vocal now because it's affecting them,' she said. 'I do think it's possible that once we get through this craziness, there will be a call to positive action.'\n\nSome educators are thinking the same way. Susan Wagner-Dameron, director of Grand Traverse Academy, said it is important to remain respectful of parents who choose not to vaccinate their children. But she is also thinking of hosting an immunization clinic at the school next year.\n\nMeanwhile, The Children's House, a Montessori school in Traverse City, which also had a student with whooping cough, has been educating parents on the value of vaccinations.\n\n'I don't think you're ever going to change the minds of some people,' Trute said. 'We're trying to affect people on the fence.' Milligan agreed that some opposed to vaccinations are 'digging in their heels,' but recent events are changing attitudes on vaccinations.\n\n'When you're faced with a highly contagious outbreak, it creates a lot of fear and that fear can be a useful catalyst,' Milligan said. 'Sometimes you need something scary to happen to realize the consequences of not vaccinating.'\n\n[Byline: Julie Mack]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In a previous posting on the outbreak of pertussis in Grand Traverse County, Michigan, particularly at the Grand Traverse Academy (Pertussis - USA (23), archive no. 20141116.2947034), I wrote, 'With a large jump in probable cases in a number that could represent more than 10 per cent or more of the students, it would be important to know the vaccination status of the school's students.'\n\nIt is now clear that undervaccination at the school (estimated at 17 percent) has played a large role in this outbreak of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection. The truths and untruths surrounding the anti-vaccine movement are complex and multifactorial. What is clear is that today's parents do not appreciate what these vaccine-preventable diseases have produced in their heydays, including pertussis's severe morbidity and mortality in infants less than 3 months of age, the deaths from encephalitis and pneumonia from measles and paralytic disease putting children in Drinker respirators (the 'iron lung') with poliomyelitis.\n\nBut the times and the distrusting mindset of parents are clearly different than in 1955. In the well-publicized Cutter incident in April 1955, more than 200 000 children in 5 Western and Midwestern USA states received a polio vaccine in which the process of inactivating the live virus proved to be defective (1). Within days there were reports of paralysis, and within a month the 1st mass vaccination program against polio had to be abandoned. Subsequent investigations revealed that the vaccine, manufactured by the California-based family firm of Cutter Laboratories, had caused 40 000 cases of polio, leaving 200 children with varying degrees of paralysis and killing 10. Although the vaccination against poliomyelitis took a hit, it was nothing compared to what would have happened to vaccine acceptance if it were to happen today.\n\n1. Nathanson N, Langmuir AD: The Cutter Incident. Poliomyelitis following formaldehyde-inactivation poliovirus vaccination in the United States in the spring of 1955. 1 Background. Am J Epidemiol 1963;78: 16-28\n2. Nathanson N, Langmuir AD: The Cutter incident. Poliomyelitis following formaldehyde-inactivated poliovirus vaccination in the United States during the Spring of 1955. II. Relationship of poliomyelitis to Cutter vaccine. Am J Epidemiol. 1995 Jul 15;142:109-40\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6537.]", "summary": "\n\nIf anything, Trute said, the fact the pertussis vaccine is not 100 percent effective is all the more reason to maintain high immunization rates, to prevent the disease from getting a foothold in the community. \n\nThe pertussis outbreak has become a hot-button issue in Traverse City, pitting parents who vaccinate their children against those who don't, said Beth Milligan, a reporter for The Ticker, a Traverse City news website. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In a previous posting on the outbreak of pertussis in Grand Traverse County, Michigan, particularly at the Grand Traverse Academy (Pertussis - USA (23), archive no. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'A lot of people who don't vaccinate don't see the need,' said Milligan, who wrote an in-depth story in September 2014 about the county's low vaccination rate. ' \n\nThe school had so many cases of whooping cough that school officials canceled the elementary fall carnival as well as 4 days of classes. \n\nAlso fueling the outbreak: When the teacher was 1st diagnosed, students classified as 'close contacts' were told to take antimicrobials as a preventive measure, but not all followed the directive, said Wendy Trute, health director for the Grand Traverse County Health Department. A state epidemiologist ran the numbers for the Traverse City pertussis outbreak and calculated that children who aren't vaccinated have been 5 times more likely to come down with pertussis than those who have been immunized, Trute said. \n\nTrute said about 1/3rd of the pertussis cases in the Traverse City area involve people who are vaccinated. What is clear is that today's parents do not appreciate what these vaccine-preventable diseases have produced in their heydays, including pertussis's severe morbidity and mortality in infants less than 3 months of age, the deaths from encephalitis and pneumonia from measles and paralytic disease putting children in Drinker respirators (the 'iron lung') with poliomyelitis. That includes Grand Traverse Academy, the 1200-student charter school associated with the initial outbreak of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, an illness nicknamed 'the 100-day cough.' Since then, whooping cough cases have been reported at 14 other school buildings across the region and new cases are still coming in, Trute said. The problem with that thinking, Goodwin said, is that unvaccinated people are much more likely to spread disease compared to those who are immunized, even if the unvaccinated people don't appear sick. ' \n\n'Nobody likes to be the person who says, 'I told you so,'' but what's unfolding now is exactly the scenario feared by those worried about the region's low immunization numbers, said Dr. Bradley Goodwin, a Traverse City family physician who is president of the Grand Traverse County Medical Society. \n\nIt is now clear that undervaccination at the school (estimated at 17 percent) has played a large role in this outbreak of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection. \n\n'When you're faced with a highly contagious outbreak, it creates a lot of fear and that fear can be a useful catalyst,' Milligan said. ' Cases of whooping cough and measles have impacted hundreds of families, overwhelmed local doctors and public health officials, and put parents who don't vaccinate their children on the defensive. People on the pro-vaccination side are very angry at the anti-vaxers for exposing their children to disease,' Milligan said. \n\n[Byline: Julie Mack]\n\n--\n Meanwhile, The Children's House, a Montessori school in Traverse City, which also had a student with whooping cough, has been educating parents on the value of vaccinations. \n\n'I don't think you're ever going to change the minds of some people,' Trute said. ' , I wrote, 'With a large jump in probable cases in a number that could represent more than 10 per cent or more of the students, it would be important to know the vaccination status of the school's students.' \n\nA teacher at Grand Traverse Academy was diagnosed with whooping cough on 16 Oct 2014. When you have (pertussis) spread so fast through a school community with high waiver rates, that's not coincidental,' Goodwin said. Meanwhile, 'the anti-vaxers are latching onto the fact' that some fully vaccinated people are getting whooping cough, which they say proves their point that vaccinations are ineffective, Milligan added.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis", "poliomyelitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1955-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Traverse City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Traverse County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3044440", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (29)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3044440", "date": "2014-12-22 16:29:28", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (29)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\n[3] Nebraska (Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties)\n[4] California\n[5] Ohio (Holmes County)\n[6] Texas\n[7] New Mexico (Valencia County)\n\n******\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/12/whooping_cough_outbreak_in_gra.html\n\n\nThe pertussis outbreak in Grand Traverse County [Michigan] has reached 70 confirmed cases, plus 14 cases of a similar disease, called parapertussis, according to the health department. Students at 19 schools in the county have been affected by the disease, also known as whooping cough. The county health department has received 3750 calls to the hotline set up to field questions from parents of children who may have been exposed to the illness.\n\nAs they announced the update on the outbreak on Thu 18 Dec 2014, health officials urged residents to get vaccinated in advance of holiday travel and get-togethers. 'Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority,' said Wendy Trute, the Grand Traverse health officer. 'We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated. We also urge parents to vaccinate infants as soon as possible.'\n\nA pertussis outbreak was reported in November 2014 at Grand Traverse Academy, a charter school. The number of confirmed cases linked to the school remains at 12, said Mike Lahey. He did not have numbers on the cases in the Traverse City Area Public School District.\n\n[byline: Sue Thoms]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It appears that a significant minority of students at Grand Traverse Academy were unvaccinated related to 'philosophical' objections of the parents. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Belgrade News [edited]\nhttp://www.belgrade-news.com/news/article_ac6e21ac-871d-11e4-9f73-ef7df241ce97.html\n\n\nAs of Thu 18 Dec 2014, 9 students in Three Forks Schools [Gallatin County, Montana] are confirmed to have whooping cough. 4 children in grades kindergarten through 5th have the respiratory illness and 5 in the middle and high school contracted it. A press release issued on the school's website on states, 'The school is a safe place for all stakeholders and unless your son or daughter has been diagnosed with pertussis, there is not any reason that they should not be in school.'\n\nWhooping cough is spread in much the same way as a regular cold virus, by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others who then breath in the bacteria. There is a pertussis vaccination, which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] says is the most effective tool in preventing the disease. But the vaccine is not 100 per cent effective.\n\nThree Forks School officials say the Gallatin City-County Health Department is working closely with the school staff to interview every person with a confirmed case of pertussis to identify close contacts. According to Gallatin City-County health officer Matt Kelley, there have been no other confirmed pertussis cases at other schools in the Gallatin Valley.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The vaccination status of the affected students is not stated. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] Nebraska (Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties)\nDate: Tue 16 Dec 2014\nSource: The Republic, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.therepublic.com/view/story/9a0752fa5c6841d5b249fa8064de1f5c/NE--Eastern-Nebraska-Illnesses\n\n\nAn eastern Nebraska health department is reporting several cases of whooping cough. The Fremont Tribune reports that Three Rivers Health Department in Fremont says at least 2 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in the district, which includes Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties.\n\nWhooping cough, or pertussis, is spread when infected people cough or sneeze. It starts like the common cold and can progress into violent coughing spells.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 15 Dec 2014\nSource: Oregon Live, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.oregonlive.com/health/index.ssf/2014/12/whooping_cough_epidemic_hits_c.html\n\n\nCalifornia officials are battling the worst whooping cough epidemic to hit the state in 7 decades as a recent rebound in cases raises questions about the effectiveness of the pertussis vaccine. Doctors emphasize that the inoculation has led to fewer deaths than in the past and in instances where people do get sick, their illnesses aren't as severe. But California officials say the limited protection of the vaccine introduced in the 1990s has led to the rise in cases. Research has shown it doesn't last as long as the one it replaced, and a new study suggests the vaccine may not prevent the spread of the disease. Whooping cough peaks every 3 to 5 years, and California's last epidemic was in 2010. But despite an aggressive public health campaign in response, the current outbreak is worse.\n\nA total of 9935 cases were reported to the California Department of Public Health from 1 Jan 2014 to 26 Nov 2014, the highest number in 70 years. The cases included an infant who died. Elementary, middle and high school outbreaks have occurred across the state. San Diego County is among the hardest hit areas with 1819 cases reported so far in 2014.\n\n'We'd have to go way back to the 1940s to find more cases,' said Dr Eric McDonald, medical director of the epidemiology and immunization branch for public health services in San Diego County. That's when whooping cough was common, causing hundreds of thousands of illnesses annually and thousands of deaths. But after a vaccine was introduced in the 1940s, cases dropped to fewer than 5000 a year. That vaccine was replaced in the 1990s because of side effects, which included pain and swelling from the shot and fever. The newer vaccine is part of routine childhood vaccinations as well as adult booster shots. [the older killed whole cell vaccine was thought to be too reactogenic in adults. - Mod.LL]\n\n2013 was the nation's worst year for whooping cough in 6 decades; health officials received reports of more than 48 000 cases, including 18 deaths. In 2014, the number of reported cases nationwide dropped to about 20 000.\n\nDr Gil Chavez, epidemiologist with the California Department of Public Health, does not believe low inoculation rates are the primary cause of the current epidemic: Of this year's [2014] pediatric cases that had information on the child's vaccination history, only 10 per cent of those infected in 2014 had not been vaccinated against pertussis. Chavez says the new vaccine's limitations and better tests have led to the increase in cases.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Ohio (Holmes County)\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Fox 8 Cleveland [edited]\nhttp://fox8.com/2014/12/18/whooping-cough-concerns-force-78-holmes-county-students-to-stay-home-from-school/\n\n\nThe East Holmes School District [Holmes County, Ohio] is telling 78 students from 2 elementary schools to stay at home after they might have been exposed to whooping cough, and have either not been vaccinated or their vaccinations are not complete. Holmes County Health Department director Dr DJ McFadden said 3 cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, have been confirmed in the county.\n\n'It does happen, but it doesn't happen as regularly as it is happening now. I mean, we are back to higher, as high of rates as we had before vaccinations in some parts of the country,' McFadden said.\n\nMcFadden made the recommendation to the school district to keep the kids home to try and limit the spread of the disease. 'They are well at this time and I certainly hope they are excluded for no good reason. There's about a week-long process to display symptoms so these children could be ill and we just don't know it yet so they are excluded as that precaution because if they are sick those symptoms will show up soon and they could be exposing other people at the same time,' said East Holmes superintendent Joe Edinger.\n\nEdinger said parents make decisions regarding the immunizations based on a number of good reasons. 'Maybe history with other children having reactions to the immunizations or for religious and cultural reasons and with that decision they accept the fact that when an outbreak occurs they will be asked to stay home,' Edinger said. Although the county has a large Amish population, Edinger said most of the kids who are being told to stay home are not Amish.\n\nThe timing means students will miss only about a week of classes before Christmas break. They will also miss their school's Christmas activities, but the school and the health district are not stopping them from attending family functions or other community events.\n\n[byline: Dave Nethers]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6] Texas\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: KTRE [edited]\nhttp://www.ktre.com/story/27669239/whooping-cough-moves-through-etx\n\n\nIt's a startling sound, especially if you're the parent of a small child. A deep cough with a 'whoop' sound is the sign of pertussis, also called whooping cough. It starts like a cold with a low fever and even a runny nose, but if left untreated, a lingering cough with the recognizable sound could lead to some serious health problems.\n\nThe number of pertussis cases is rising around the country, and has claimed 2 lives in Texas this year [2014]. More than 25 per cent of pertussis cases in children result in a hospital stay, according to health reports. Pediatrician Melanie Wick said adults or teenagers can be the culprits when it comes to spreading pertussis. 'We can get a cough that lasts for several weeks and we are the ones that expose those little children to pertussis,' wick said.\n\nWick said it's common to see more respiratory illnesses during the winter months when more people are indoors for longer times of the day. Some of the more serious complications of pertussis include pneumonia and apnea -- where one stops breathing for brief periods.\n\nWhile pertussis has been elevated to an epidemic status by health agencies in California, Wick said the number of patients she has seen with the illness here in East Texas in 2014 is about average. NetHealth, which surveyed 6 counties, said 94 cases of pertussis have been reported: Smith County accounted for 74 of those cases.\n\nIn Texas, just under 2200 cases have occurred in 2014 including 2 deaths. Nearly 50 percent of cases have been in children under the age of 7.\n\n[byline: Alex Osiadacz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[7] New Mexico (Valencia County)\nDate: Wed 17 Dec 2014\nSource: KRQE [edited]\nhttp://krqe.com/2014/12/17/school-district-warns-parents-of-whopping-cough/\n\n\nA New Mexico school district is warning parents about whooping cough. Los Lunas schools [Valencia County] sent emails to parents and even called them saying there have been several cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, in the area.\n\nHealth officials say whooping cough tends to hit in waves. In New Mexico in 2012, there were nearly 900 cases. In 2013 there were more than 600; so far in 2014 there were about 300.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in the number of cases of pertussis in the past few years in the USA is likely multifactorial, although in part due to the wave-like nature of the disease over years it is clear that the acellular vaccine, which is much better tolerated in children and can be given to adults, does not protect against _Bordetella pertussis_ as long. There is also some evidence that recent clonal strains have toxins that are less antigenic similar to the vaccine strain. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n[byline: Sue Thoms]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It appears that a significant minority of students at Grand Traverse Academy were unvaccinated related to 'philosophical' objections of the parents. Date: Thu 18 Dec 2014\n Date: Thu 18 Dec 2014\n \n\n\nAs of Thu 18 Dec 2014, 9 students in Three Forks Schools [Gallatin County, Montana] are confirmed to have whooping cough. http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/9a0752fa5c6841d5b249fa8064de1f5c/NE--Eastern-Nebraska-Illnesses\n\n\nAn eastern Nebraska health department is reporting several cases of whooping cough. Date: Fri 19 Dec 2014\n Date: Fri 19 Dec 2014\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-12-18 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-01 00:00:00", "2014-11-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fremont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holmes County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - USA (28)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3030234", "date": "2014-12-14 09:36:09", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (28)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Montana (Cascade County)\n[2] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\n[3] New York (Clinton County)\n[4] North Carolina (Buncombe County)\n\n******\n[1] Montana (Cascade County)\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2014\nSource: KRTV [edited]\nhttp://www.krtv.com/news/3rd-case-of-pertussis-confirmed-at-cmr-in-great-falls/\n\n\nThe City-County Health Department in Great Falls [Cascade County, Montana] says there are now 3 confirmed cases of pertussis, often called whooping cough, among students at C.M. Russell High School [CMR].\n\nSince 1 Jan 2014, there have been 423 cases of pertussis in Montana, with 16 of those cases in Cascade County. The Great Falls Public School District announced on Thursday, 11 Dec 2014, that 2 people at CMR had been diagnosed.\n\nCCHD health officer Tanya Houston said that they are conducting 'contact-tracing' in an attempt to find anyone who has come into contact with people that have been diagnosed. If these people have symptoms they will recommend that they contact their healthcare provider for testing and treatment. Contact-tracing is how they discovered the 3rd case of whooping cough at CMR.\n\n[Byline: Margaret DeMarco]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2014\nSource: WTAE [edited]\nhttp://www.wtae.com/health/allegheny-county-health-department-reports-growing-incidence-of-pertussis/30177816\n\n\nThe Allegheny County [Pennsylvania] Health Department today [11 Dec 2014] announced that a growing number of pertussis cases are being reported in the county. 'To prevent further transmission of the disease, we would like to remind residents of all ages, but especially school-age children, to follow proper cough etiquette and hand washing techniques. This includes coughing or sneezing into a tissue or sleeve and washing hands frequently with soap and water for 20 seconds,' said Health Director Dr. Karen Hacker.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New York (Clinton County)\nDate: Wed 3 Dec 2014\nSource: Press Republican [edited]\nhttp://www.pressrepublican.com/news/local_news/pertussis-confirmed-in-clinton-county-schools/article_b06299d8-148d-5200-9bd1-cfadcff10f47.html\n\n\nThe Clinton County [New York State] Health Department has confirmed that multiple area schools have recently been affected by pertussis. On Tuesday, 2 Dec 2014, the Plattsburgh City School District sent a letter informing parents that a small number of cases of the highly contagious disease had been confirmed in more than one district building. The district wished to make people aware of the potential for exposure in an effort to break the cycle of transmission, according to Health Department public-health nurse Karen Merrill.\n\n'Pertussis is also known as whooping cough, and that's because of the signature sound that is often heard when a person is coughing,' Merrill said. 'It's also known as the 100-day cough. And that's a long time to cough.'\n\n[Byline: Ashleigh Livingston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] North Carolina (Buncombe County)\nDate: Fri 12 Dec 2014\nSource: WYFF [edited]\nhttp://www.wyff4.com/news/Whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-in-WNC/30200514\n\n\nCases of pertussis are on the increase in Western North Carolina, with 19 cases reported in Buncombe County, according to Buncombe County Health and Human Services.\n\nBased on the CDC recommendations, Buncombe County Medical Director Dr. Jennifer Mullendore strongly recommends a one-time Tdap booster for preteens, teens and adults. It is also recommended that all women receive a Tdap booster in the 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, regardless of whether they were already immunized.\n\nPractice good health habits, like frequent hand-washing or using alcohol-based hand sanitizers and covering your nose and mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze, can help prevent the spread of pertussis and other illnesses.\n\n[Byline: Carla Field]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting this susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences:\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3520.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study. PERTUSSIS - USA (28)\n********************\n Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Source: WYFF [edited]\nhttp://www.wyff4.com/news/Whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-in-WNC/30200514\n\n\nCases of pertussis are on the increase in Western North Carolina, with 19 cases reported in Buncombe County, according to Buncombe County Health and Human Services. \n\n[Byline: Ashleigh Livingston]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. During the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. In Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. \n\n'Pertussis is also known as whooping cough, and that's because of the signature sound that is often heard when a person is coughing,' Merrill said. Russell High School \n\nReferences:\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-01 00:00:00", "2014-12-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cascade County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allegheny County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buncombe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clinton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City - USA (24)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\n[4] Idaho\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KTTC [edited]\nhttp://www.kttc.com/story/27422372/2014/11/18/zumbrota-mazeppa-schools-dealing-with-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] has affected the Zumbrota-Mazeppa Public Schools. At least 11 children in Zumbrota-Mazeppa Middle School and Zumbrota-Mazeppa High School [in Zumbrota, Goodhue County, Minnesota] are confirmed to have the infection. Additionally, 80 children stayed home sick from Zumbrota-Mazeppa schools on Tuesday, 18 Nov 2014, although not all of the cases are related to the outbreak. Doctors and health professionals in the Zumbrota area were still tracking the apparent outbreak of pertussis on Wednesday, 19 Nov 2014. State, county, and local officials compared notes on the outbreak in a conference call.\n\nMayo Clinic Dr. Elizabeth Cozine said she has been treating confirmed cases in her clinic in Zumbrota. She wants people to know that if you know for sure you have been exposed to pertussis, you should call your doctor. She said you might not need to come to the clinic to be treated.\n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. 'What I did learn about my daughter's pertussis is it acts like the common cold,' she said. 'You have no idea that it's anything more severe.'\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health has taken interest in the outbreak as well. A conference call between the Department of Health and the health departments of Goodhue and Wabasha counties is planned for Wednesday morning, 19 Nov 2014.\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health advises kids to get vaccinated so they can avoid whooping cough and for those suspected of having whooping cough to stay home from school.\n\n[Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 20 Nov 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/confirming_cases_of_whooping_c.html\n\n\nThe Grand Traverse County [Michigan] Health Department has confirmed 34 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, including 12 new cases this week. 27 of the confirmed cases are tied to 2 schools, Grand Traverse Academy, a K-12 charter school, and Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS). Health department officials say they are working closely with affected schools.\n\n'We continue to actively monitor this situation and make adjustments to make sure we have adequate staff,' said Mike Lahey, the emergency preparedness coordinator for the health department.\n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. The school of 1200 students reopened on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, after shutting down on 11 Nov 2014 because spread of the illness.\n\nThe health department says there are 166 probable cases linked to the charter school outbreak. Many more are being tested according to physician offices reports. This week Superintendent Susan Dameron, superintendent of Grand Traverse Academy, said all of the students at risk have taken the preventative antibiotic.\n\nThere are currently 15 confirmed cases at Traverse City Area Public Schools, up from 7 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, according to Christine Guitar, director of marketing and communications for TCAPS. 'We continue to work in close collaboration with the Grand Traverse County Health Department to identify possible cases and provide information about pertussis to families,' said Guitar, who said there are also confirmed cases in other school districts and in neighboring counties.\n\n'It is important that both children and adults are up-to-date on their immunization,' the health department reiterated in Thursday's [20 Nov 2014] update. 'Booster shots for pertussis are critical because, unlike some other vaccine-preventable diseases, neither the pertussis disease nor vaccine confers lifelong immunity.'\n\n[Byline: Monica Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: CapeCod.com [edited]\nhttp://www.capecod.com/newscenter/falmouth-students-whooping-cough/\n\n\nParents of students who attend Falmouth [Barnstable County, Massachusetts] schools have received written notification about a rash of cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Falmouth Schools Assistant Superintendent Nancy Taylor said that 17 students are currently out of school recuperating from the disease. Taylor said school administrators are in touch almost daily with state officials about the status of the situation at the schools.\n\nIn Massachusetts, pertussis is most common among people over 10 years old who have lost the protection they get from childhood vaccines, according to state health officials. All but one of the students who have pertussis were immunized, Taylor said. The treatment is to stay home on antimicrobials for 5 days before returning to school, she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Idaho\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KPVI [edited]\nhttp://www.kpvi.com/content/news/local/story/Idaho-Attributes-Increase-in-Pertussis-to-Low/M2FEtvj900SynGy_dNF1Tw.cspx\n\n\nHealth officials in Idaho are attributing the increase in pertussis due to the low vaccination rates in the state. The number of cases in Idaho doubled from January to August 2014 from the same periods in 2012 and 2013.\n\nAccording to the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare, of the 287 cases diagnosed through August 2014, one infant died.\n\nThere have been 31 cases of pertussis in the Pocatello and Idaho Falls area, with the highest number of cases being in Boise, Caldwell and Twin Falls.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The risk for acquiring pertussis is certainly higher in the unimmunized. Overall, however, waning immunity in those previously vaccinated with the acellular pertussis vaccine seems to be, in most states, the explanation for a rise of cases. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n We continue to work in close collaboration with the Grand Traverse County Health Department to identify possible cases and provide information about pertussis to families,' said Guitar, who said there are also confirmed cases in other school districts and in neighboring counties. ' In this update:\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. Source: KPVI [edited]\nhttp://www.kpvi.com/content/news/local/story/Idaho-Attributes-Increase-in-Pertussis-to-Low/M2FEtvj900SynGy_dNF1Tw.cspx\n\n\nHealth officials in Idaho are attributing the increase in pertussis due to the low vaccination rates in the state. \n\nThere have been 31 cases of pertussis in the Pocatello and Idaho Falls area, with the highest number of cases being in Boise, Caldwell and Twin Falls. \n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. ' \n\nThe health department says there are 166 probable cases linked to the charter school outbreak. [Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Goodhue County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Traverse City Area Public Schools", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barnstable County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zumbrota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3012191", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (25): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3012191", "date": "2014-12-05 21:11:41", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (25): (CALIFORNIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Dec 2014\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2013; 63(48); 1129-32 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6348a2.htm?s_cid=mm6348a2_e\n\n\nPertussis epidemic -- California, 2014\n--------------------------------------\nOn 13 Jun 2014, the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) declared that a pertussis epidemic was occurring in the state when reported incidence was more than 5 times greater than baseline levels. The incidence of pertussis in the USA is cyclical, with peaks every 3-5 years, as the number of susceptible persons in the population increases. The last pertussis epidemic in California occurred in 2010, when approximately 9000 cases were reported, including 808 hospitalizations and 10 infant deaths, for a statewide incidence of 24.6 cases per 100 000 population (1). During 1 Jan-26 Nov 2014, a total of 9935 cases of pertussis with onset in 2014 were reported to CDPH, for a statewide incidence of 26.0 cases per 100 000. CDPH is working closely with local health departments to prioritize public health activities, with the primary goal of preventing severe cases of pertussis, which typically occurs in infants. All prenatal care providers are being encouraged to provide tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) to pregnant women during each pregnancy, ideally at 27-36 weeks' gestation, as is recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) (4), or refer patients to an alternative provider, such as a pharmacy or local public health department, to receive Tdap.\n\nFor this analysis, case report forms with preliminary data on demographics, symptoms, clinical course, and exposures were completed by local and state health department investigators through patient interviews and medical record reviews and were available for 8562 (86 percent) cases. All cases met either the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists definition for confirmed pertussis, its definition for probable pertussis,* or the CDPH definition for suspected pertussis (2).\n\nDisease incidence in California among infants aged less than 12 months was 174.6 cases per 100 000 during 1 Jan-26 Nov 2014, and was significantly higher among Hispanic infants (rate ratio = 1.7; 95 percent confidence interval [CI] = 1.5-2.1) and lower among Asian/Pacific Islander infants (rate ratio = 0.4; CI = 0.3-0.6) than among white, non-Hispanic infants (Table 1 [for Tables, see source URL above. - Mod.LL]). Of 6790 cases with available data, 347 patients had been hospitalized, including 275 (79 percent) who were aged less than 12 months, of whom 214 (62 percent of those hospitalized) were aged less than 4 months. Among hospitalized infants aged less than 12 months with complete information, 33 percent required intensive care; few (24 percent) had received any doses of diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) (Table 2). One death was reported in an infant aged 5 weeks at the time of illness onset. 2 additional fatal cases in infants who became ill in 2013 were also reported in early 2014; both were aged less than 5 weeks at the time of illness onset, and 1 was hospitalized for more than a year before succumbing to pertussis-related complications.\n\nOf 211 (50 percent) infants aged less than 4 months whose mothers' Tdap immunization histories were available, only 35 (17 percent) had mothers who reported receiving Tdap at 27-36 weeks' gestation during their most recent pregnancy. Among mothers not vaccinated during pregnancy, 56 (36 percent) received Tdap within 7 days after delivery.\n\nDisease incidence was also high among older children and adolescents, peaking at 137.8 cases per 100 000 among adolescents aged 15 years (Figure [for Figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL]). Among the 2006 cases in adolescents aged 14-16 years, 5 patients (0.2 percent) were hospitalized; 4 were admitted for 2 days or less, and 1 was admitted for 5 days. Among the 83 percent of adolescent cases aged 14-16 years with known vaccination histories, only 2.2 percent reported never receiving any doses of pertussis-containing vaccine. Of those vaccinated adolescents with complete data, 87 percent had previously received the Tdap booster vaccine, and the median length of time since prior Tdap dose was 3 years (range = 0-7 years). Of the 1321 (66 percent) adolescents aged 14-16 years with known race and ethnicity, rates were highest among non-Hispanic white (166.2 cases per 100 000) adolescents and lower among Hispanic (64.2 per 100,000), Asian/Pacific Islander (43.9 per 100 000) and non-Hispanic black (23.7 per 100 000) adolescents.\n\n* Available at http://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/script/casedef.aspx?condyrid=950&datepub=1/1/2014%2012:00:00%20am.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nBecause infants aged less than 12 months have the greatest risk for hospitalization and death from pertussis, public health strategies have been prioritized towards preventing disease in this age group. During the 2010 pertussis epidemic in California, the main strategy used to protect infants was 'cocooning' (that is, vaccinating contacts of infants so they do not transmit pertussis to the infant). However, this strategy is difficult to implement, and even if all anticipated contacts could be immunized, infants could still be exposed to infected persons in the community.\n\nIn 2011, data became available demonstrating efficient transplacental transfer of antipertussis antibodies to the fetus, which might protect vulnerable infants until they are old enough to receive the primary DTaP series beginning at aged 2 months. In that year, ACIP recommended that pregnant women who had never received Tdap receive a dose after 20 weeks' gestation (3). In 2012, ACIP reviewed data indicating that antipertussis antibody concentrations declined substantially 1 year after vaccination; therefore, ACIP recommended that Tdap be administered during the third trimester of every pregnancy. Since the immune response to Tdap peaks about 2 weeks after administration and the majority of maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus at 36-40 weeks' gestation, Tdap is currently recommended at 27-36 weeks gestation to optimize antibody transfer and protection at birth (4,5). Preliminary data indicate that infants born to vaccinated mothers have a lower risk for pertussis early in life (6).\n\nVery few mothers of infants with pertussis had received Tdap during pregnancy; many more were vaccinated after delivery, which does not confer any direct protection to the infant and is no longer a preferred strategy. Recently published data indicate that Tdap vaccination coverage among pregnant women was only 19.5 percent in 2012 across California Vaccine Safety Datalink sites (7). Similarly, in a survey conducted at 100 birthing hospitals in California during October 2013, only 25 percent of new mothers reported receiving Tdap during pregnancy, whereas an additional 44 percent received Tdap in the hospital after delivery (CDPH, unpublished data, 2013). However, efforts to increase vaccine coverage have been successful among Northern California Kaiser patients, and in the third quarter of 2014, an estimated 84 percent of pregnant women received Tdap vaccine in their third trimester (T. Flanagan; Northern California Kaiser; personal communications; 26 Nov 2014).\n\nPrenatal care providers should vaccinate all pregnant patients with Tdap during the third trimester of each pregnancy, ideally at 27-36 weeks' gestation, as is recommended by ACIP (4). If Tdap cannot be administered on-site during routine prenatal care visits, CDPH encourages prenatal care providers to take the following steps: 1) provide the patient with a strong recommendation and patient-specific prescription for Tdap; 2) refer the patient to specific alternative sites for vaccine, such as pharmacies, primary care providers, or local health departments; and 3) assess Tdap status at follow-up visits to confirm and record receipt of vaccine. In addition, timely initiation of the primary DTaP infant series is essential for reducing severe disease in young infants. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, DTaP can be administered to infants at an accelerated schedule, with the first dose administered as early as age 6 weeks, when pertussis is prevalent in the community. Even 1 dose of DTaP might offer some protection against serious pertussis disease in infants (8).\n\nHispanic infants age less than 12 months have the highest and Asian/Pacific Islanders of all ages have the lowest rates of disease compared with other racial and ethnic groups. However, the Hispanic overrepresentation among infants disappeared by age 1 year, and disease incidence among older children and adolescents was highest among non-Hispanic whites, similar to trends reported previously in California (1). Nationally, since the 1990s, Hispanic infants have been noted to have higher rates of reported disease and pertussis-related deaths compared with non-Hispanic infants (8). The causes of these disparities are unknown, and data are needed to assess the contributing factors. Current hypotheses attribute the disparities to larger household size and/or cultural practices that increase the number of persons in contact with young infants.\n\nNotably, the peak age of disease incidence beyond infancy increased to age 14-16 years in 2014 compared with the peak among children aged 10 years during the 2010 pertussis epidemic (1). Children and teenagers born in the USA since 1997 have only received acellular pertussis vaccine, and the upper age of this cohort correlates with the peak age in incidence during both epidemic years. Data available since the 2010 epidemic indicate that immunity conferred by acellular vaccines, particularly when used for the primary series, wanes more rapidly than that conferred by older, whole-cell vaccines that were used in the United States from the 1940s to the 1990s. Because of vaccine safety concerns related to whole-cell pertussis vaccines, acellular pertussis vaccines were developed and recommended in 1992 for the 4th and 5th doses of the pertussis vaccine series and for all 5 doses in 1997. Acellular pertussis vaccines are less reactogenic than whole-cell vaccines, but the immunity conferred by them wanes more quickly. Most of the cases among adolescents aged 14-16 years were among those who had previously received Tdap 3 years or more earlier, suggesting that their illness was the result of waning immunity. It is likely that increased incidence will continue to be observed among this cohort in the absence of a new vaccine or more effective vaccination strategy. Although the highest burden of disease is currently being observed in adolescents aged 14-16 years, severe disease is uncommon at this age, and less than 0.5 percent of reported cases in this age group resulted in hospitalization. More data are needed to assess the potential benefit and timing of Tdap booster doses.\n\nCDPH is working with local public health departments as well as prenatal and pediatric health care providers, with the primary goal of encouraging vaccination of pregnant women and infants. In addition, CDPH is providing free Tdap to local health departments and community health centers to support vaccination of uninsured and underinsured pregnant women and is working to identify and mitigate barriers to Tdap vaccination for pregnant women. CDPH has been working closely with California local health departments to modify guidance for managing the high burden of disease in older children and teenagers, including school outbreaks of pertussis, by prioritizing follow-up of patients and contacts who are at higher risk for developing severe disease (9).\n\nAs long as currently available acellular pertussis vaccines are in use, it is likely that the 'new normal' will be higher disease incidence throughout pertussis cycles. The number of reported cases in 2014 has surpassed that of the 2010 epidemic and represents the most cases reported in California in nearly 70 years (1). However, it is important to put the current pertussis epidemic in historical perspective. In the immediate prevaccine era, there were approximately 157 reported cases of pertussis per 100 000 population in the USA, with 1.5 deaths per 1000 infants (10). Therefore, despite the limitations of currently available pertussis vaccines, they continue to have an important impact on pertussis. Strategies to prevent the most severe cases of pertussis, which occur primarily in young infants, should be prioritized.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Winter K, Harriman K, Zipprich J, et al: California pertussis epidemic, 2010. J Pediatr 2012; 161(6):1091-6 [Abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22819634]\n2.
