Available at http://www.cdph.ca.gov/healthinfo/discond/documents/cdph_pertussis_quicksheet.pdf.\n10. Cherry J, Brunnel P, Golden G: Report of the Task Force on Pertussis and Pertussis Immunization, 1988. Pediatrics 1988; 81(6): 933-84. [Abstract available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/81/6/933]\n\n[Reported by: Winter K, Glaser C, Watt J, Harriman K]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA recent publication confirms that safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nAbstract\n--------\nIn 2010, due to a pertussis outbreak and neonatal deaths, the California Department of Health recommended that the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) be administered during pregnancy. Tdap is now recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for all pregnant women, preferably between 27 and 36 weeks' gestation. Limited data exist on Tdap safety during pregnancy.\n\nObjective:\nTo evaluate whether maternal Tdap vaccination during pregnancy is associated with increased risks of adverse obstetric events or adverse birth outcomes.\n\nDesign and setting:\nRetrospective, observational cohort study using administrative health care databases from 2 California Vaccine Safety Datalink sites.\n\nParticipants and exposures:\nOf 123 494 women with singleton pregnancies ending in a live birth between 1 Jan 2010, and 15 Nov 2012, 26 229 (21 percent) received Tdap during pregnancy and 97 265 did not.\n\nMain outcomes and measures:\nRisks of small-for-gestational-age (SGA) births (less than 10th percentile), chorioamnionitis, preterm birth (less than 37 weeks' gestation), and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy were evaluated. Relative risk (RR) estimates were adjusted for site, receipt of another vaccine during pregnancy, and propensity to receive Tdap during pregnancy. Cox regression was used for preterm delivery, and Poisson regression for other outcomes.\n\nResults:\nVaccination was not associated with increased risks of adverse birth outcomes: crude estimates for preterm delivery were 6.3 percent of vaccinated and 7.8 percent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.03; 95 percent CI, 0.97-1.09); 8.4 percent of vaccinated and 8.3 percent of unvaccinated had an SGA birth (adjusted RR, 1.00; 95 percent CI, 0.96-1.06). Receipt of Tdap before 20 weeks was not associated with hypertensive disorder of pregnancy (adjusted RR, 1.09; 95 percent CI, 0.99-1.20); chorioamnionitis was diagnosed in 6.1 percent of vaccinated and 5.5 percent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.19; 95 percent CI, 1.13-1.26).\n\nConclusions and relevance:\nIn this cohort of women with singleton pregnancies that ended in live birth, receipt of Tdap during pregnancy was not associated with increased risk of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy or preterm or SGA birth, although a small but statistically significant increased risk of chorioamnionitis diagnosis was observed. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "\n\nDisease incidence in California among infants aged less than 12 months was 174.6 cases per 100 000 during 1 Jan-26 Nov 2014, and was significantly higher among Hispanic infants (rate ratio = 1.7; 95 percent confidence interval [CI] = 1.5-2.1) and lower among Asian/Pacific Islander infants (rate ratio = 0.4; CI = 0.3-0.6) than among white, non-Hispanic infants (Table 1 [for Tables, see source URL above. Vaccination was not associated with increased risks of adverse birth outcomes: crude estimates for preterm delivery were 6.3 percent of vaccinated and 7.8 percent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.03; 95 percent CI, 0.97-1.09); 8.4 percent of vaccinated and 8.3 percent of unvaccinated had an SGA birth (adjusted RR, 1.00; 95 percent CI, 0.96-1.06). Because of vaccine safety concerns related to whole-cell pertussis vaccines, acellular pertussis vaccines were developed and recommended in 1992 for the 4th and 5th doses of the pertussis vaccine series and for all 5 doses in 1997. Among hospitalized infants aged less than 12 months with complete information, 33 percent required intensive care; few (24 percent) had received any doses of diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) (Table 2). \n\nNotably, the peak age of disease incidence beyond infancy increased to age 14-16 years in 2014 compared with the peak among children aged 10 years during the 2010 pertussis epidemic (1). \n\nOf 211 (50 percent) infants aged less than 4 months whose mothers' Tdap immunization histories were available, only 35 (17 percent) had mothers who reported receiving Tdap at 27-36 weeks' gestation during their most recent pregnancy. Among the 83 percent of adolescent cases aged 14-16 years with known vaccination histories, only 2.2 percent reported never receiving any doses of pertussis-containing vaccine. 2 additional fatal cases in infants who became ill in 2013 were also reported in early 2014; both were aged less than 5 weeks at the time of illness onset, and 1 was hospitalized for more than a year before succumbing to pertussis-related complications. Receipt of Tdap before 20 weeks was not associated with hypertensive disorder of pregnancy (adjusted RR, 1.09; 95 percent CI, 0.99-1.20); chorioamnionitis was diagnosed in 6.1 percent of vaccinated and 5.5 percent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.19; 95 percent CI, 1.13-1.26). Of the 1321 (66 percent) adolescents aged 14-16 years with known race and ethnicity, rates were highest among non-Hispanic white (166.2 cases per 100 000) adolescents and lower among Hispanic (64.2 per 100,000), Asian/Pacific Islander (43.9 per 100 000) and non-Hispanic black (23.7 per 100 000) adolescents. In 2010, due to a pertussis outbreak and neonatal deaths, the California Department of Health recommended that the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) be administered during pregnancy. The last pertussis epidemic in California occurred in 2010, when approximately 9000 cases were reported, including 808 hospitalizations and 10 infant deaths, for a statewide incidence of 24.6 cases per 100 000 population (1). All prenatal care providers are being encouraged to provide tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) to pregnant women during each pregnancy, ideally at 27-36 weeks' gestation, as is recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) \n\nAs long as currently available acellular pertussis vaccines are in use, it is likely that the 'new normal' will be higher disease incidence throughout pertussis cycles. All cases met either the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists definition for confirmed pertussis, its definition for probable pertussis,* or the CDPH definition for suspected pertussis (2). Of 6790 cases with available data, 347 patients had been hospitalized, including 275 (79 percent) who were aged less than 12 months, of whom 214 (62 percent of those hospitalized) were aged less than 4 months. Although the highest burden of disease is currently being observed in adolescents aged 14-16 years, severe disease is uncommon at this age, and less than 0.5 percent of reported cases in this age group resulted in hospitalization. [Abstract available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/81/6/933]\n\n[Reported by: Winter K, Glaser C, Watt J, Harriman K]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< During 1 Jan-26 Nov 2014, a total of 9935 cases of pertussis with onset in 2014 were reported to CDPH, for a statewide incidence of 26.0 cases per 100 000. CDC: Updated recommendations for use of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) in pregnant women and persons who have or anticipate having close contact with an infant aged less than 12 months -- Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), 2011. \n\nA recent publication confirms that safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. Among the 2006 cases in adolescents aged 14-16 years, 5 patients (0.2 percent) were hospitalized; 4 were admitted for 2 days or less, and 1 was admitted for 5 days. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n If Tdap cannot be administered on-site during routine prenatal care visits, CDPH encourages prenatal care providers to take the following steps: 1) provide the patient with a strong recommendation and patient-specific prescription for Tdap; 2) refer the patient to specific alternative sites for vaccine, such as pharmacies, primary care providers, or local health departments; and 3) assess Because infants aged less than 12 months have the greatest risk for hospitalization and death from pertussis, public health strategies have been prioritized towards preventing disease in this age group. \n\nVery few mothers of infants with pertussis had received Tdap during pregnancy; many more were vaccinated after delivery, which does not confer any direct protection to the infant and is no longer a preferred strategy. CDPH is working closely with local health departments to prioritize public health activities, with the primary goal of preventing severe cases of pertussis, which typically occurs in infants. Similarly, in a survey conducted at 100 birthing hospitals in California during October 2013, only 25 percent of new mothers reported receiving Tdap during pregnancy, whereas an additional 44 percent received Tdap in the hospital after delivery (CDPH, unpublished data, 2013). \nOf 123 494 women with singleton pregnancies ending in a live birth between 1 Jan 2010, and 15 Nov 2012, 26 229 (21 percent) received Tdap during pregnancy and 97 265 did not. \n\nCDPH is working with local public health departments as well as prenatal and pediatric health care providers, with the primary goal of encouraging vaccination of pregnant women and infants. Children and teenagers born in the USA since 1997 have only received acellular pertussis vaccine, and the upper age of this cohort correlates with the peak age in incidence during both epidemic years. Nationally, since the 1990s, Hispanic infants have been noted to have higher rates of reported disease and pertussis-related deaths compared with non-Hispanic infants (8). CDPH has been working closely with California local health departments to modify guidance for managing the high burden of disease in older children and teenagers, including school outbreaks of pertussis, by prioritizing follow-up of patients and contacts who are at higher risk for developing severe disease (9). \n\nDisease incidence was also high among older children and adolescents, peaking at 137.8 cases per 100 000 among adolescents aged 15 years (Figure [for Figure, see source URL above - Mod. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2013; 63(48); 1129-32 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6348a2.htm?s_cid=mm6348a2_e\n\n\nPertussis epidemic -- California, 2014\n However, efforts to increase vaccine coverage have been successful among Northern California Kaiser patients, and in the third quarter of 2014, an estimated 84 percent of pregnant women received Tdap vaccine in their third trimester (T. Flanagan; Northern California Kaiser; personal communications; 26 Nov 2014). In the immediate prevaccine era, there were approximately 157 reported cases of pertussis per 100 000 population in the USA, with 1.5 deaths per 1000 infants (10). However, the Hispanic overrepresentation among infants disappeared by age 1 year, and disease incidence among older children and adolescents was highest among non-Hispanic whites, similar to trends reported previously in California (1). Of those vaccinated adolescents with complete data, 87 percent had previously received the Tdap booster vaccine, and the median length of time since prior Tdap dose was 3 years (range = 0-7 years). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Updated recommendations for use of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) in pregnant women-Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), 2012. The number of reported cases in 2014 has surpassed that of the 2010 epidemic and represents the most cases reported in California in nearly 70 years (1). During the 2010 pertussis epidemic in California, the main strategy used to protect infants was 'cocooning' (that is, vaccinating contacts of infants On 13 Jun 2014, the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) declared that a pertussis epidemic was occurring in the state when reported incidence was more than 5 times greater than baseline levels. In this cohort of women with singleton pregnancies that ended in live birth, receipt of Tdap during pregnancy was not associated with increased risk of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy or preterm or SGA birth, although a small but statistically significant increased risk of chorioamnionitis diagnosis was observed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1992-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-13 00:00:00", "8562-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2056-03-25 00:00:00", "1424-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1321-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-01 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-10-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quinello C", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2947034", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (23)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2947034", "date": "2014-11-16 18:06:06", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (23)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[2] California (Santa Barbara County): Commentary\n[3] Ohio (Hamilton County)\n[4] North Carolina (Chatham County)\n\n******\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Wed 12 Nov 2014\nSource: Mlive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/whooping_cough_outbreak_at_gra.html\n\n\nHealth department staff are warning students and teachers who are off this week amid a pertussis outbreak at Grand Traverse Academy to stay home as the number of those ill continues to grow. As of Wed 12 Nov 2014, there are 12 confirmed cases and 161 probable cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough. That is up from 10 confirmed and 83 probable cases 2 days ago.\n\nGrand Traverse Academy administrators chose to close for the week as the number of students and staff with the illness continued to grow. The academy, a K-12 charter school, is closed for all classes, extra-curricular activities and athletic events through Sun 16 Nov 2014 according to a notice posted on the school's website.\n\nArea physician offices, urgent care locations and clinics are bogged down handling the outbreak as Grand Traverse Health Department staff continue to urge any students and teachers to begin a course of preventative antimicrobials. A pertussis hotline designed to coordinate prescriptions has been staffed daily, and the health department staff has responded to more than 900 calls.\n\nStudents, staff members and their families are strongly urged to get the vaccine against pertussis. The CDC recommends vaccinating children in a 5-shot series beginning at 2 months. All children should receive an additional single dose at age 11 that provides additional protection. Adolescents and adults who have not received the vaccination in the past are urged to get a single dose to reduce their risk of contracting or spreading the sickness to others.\n\nEarlier this week, county health officer Wendy Trute shared her hope that those infected would not grow to include other community members. But because the academy's more than 1000 students come from beyond an area that would normally be restricted by district lines, it is very possible that would happen, she said.\n\n[byline: Heidi Fenton]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With a large jump in probable cases in a number that could represent more than 10 per cent or more of the students, it be important to know the vaccination status of the school's students. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] California (Santa Barbara County): commentary\nDate: Thu 6 Nov 2014\nSource: The Independent [edited]\nhttp://www.independent.com/news/2014/nov/06/whooping-cough-outbreak-public-health-perspective/\n\n\nWhile today's [6 Nov 2014] headlines in the media highlight the threat of Ebola, and our local health care community has appropriately been planning and preparing for months should this risk materialize, we have a real infectious disease danger already here in Santa Barbara County. 13 cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, have been identified just in the last few weeks. That makes almost 90 cases in our county so far in 2014, the most cases in one year since we have been collecting electronic reporting data, which goes back over 10 years.\n\nWe hope that the children affected fully recover, as whooping cough can cause serious illness. Of the almost 9000 cases statewide in 2014, over 300 resulted in hospitalizations, and there have been a handful of deaths. This is one of the largest epidemics of pertussis statewide in 60 years. What makes this particularly concerning is that whooping cough is largely a vaccine preventable disease.\n\nPertussis is often cyclical in nature, and there have been years of large outbreaks in the past. The vaccine isn't perfect as even those that had the vaccine can sometimes come down with mild symptoms. But a closer look at our current cases and contact tracing finds that almost all of the recent cases were linked to Waldorf School. That could be an unfortunate coincidence, as we always have some naturally occurring cases every year, but would it surprise anyone that this outbreak is occurring at a school where only 28 percent of the children are up-to-date on all of their vaccines?\n\nWhile Waldorf schoolchildren are particularly low in their vaccination rates, it would not be appropriate to assume this problem of unvaccinated children is isolated to that one school. In fact, many local schools fall below our target of having 90 per cent of children fully vaccinated. This is the level at which we generally have 'herd immunity', meaning that the number of vaccinated individuals in a group is sufficiently high enough to prevent an outbreak when someone comes down with the illness. (To find your school or child care center's immunization rates, go to http://www.sbcphd.org).\n\nWhy are there an increasing number of parents filing personal belief exemptions (PBEs) so their children do not need to comply with school vaccination requirements? There are many reasons. A small percentage have legitimate medical conditions or a documented history of adverse reactions that preclude them from safely receiving all of the vaccines. A few may have religious beliefs that do not approve of immunizations. Other parents are simply not adequately informed and still falsely believe there is a link between vaccines and autism: countless research studies have failed to find a causal association. Some believe that their children don't need to be vaccinated because almost everyone else is vaccinated. As mentioned previously, 'herd immunity' only holds when vaccination rates are typically above 90 per cent, and many of the schools where PBEs are common are well below this threshold. Some just don't like seeing their little ones getting all those shots (and I can relate as a parent of 3 young children myself; I still turn away when they get pricked).\n\nAnd yet others are part of a growing group of parents who are highly educated but still choose to file PBEs so their children do not need to get their vaccines upon school entry. For some of them, the miniscule risk, legitimate in their minds or not, is still not worth receiving immunizations because they would rather take the chance that their children catch the diseases naturally, hopefully have only mild symptoms, and develop their own immunity. There are even parties and play dates where parents intentionally expose their children to these vaccine preventable diseases in order for them to get infected and develop immunity.\n\nThe problem with these attitudes is that the diseases can be serious; these parents are rolling the dice that their children will not be one of the unfortunate cases that ends up in the hospital or worse. In addition, there is risk to the larger community. Even if one of these unvaccinated children contracts the illness and recovers fully, others around them -- pregnant women, infants too young to receive vaccines, children and adults with immunologic deficits or cancer -- may contract the disease and not be so fortunate.\n\nWhat can be done about this alarming trend? Several prominent area pediatricians are taking their own measures and have decided they will no longer accept unvaccinated children with PBEs into their medical practices. For them, the risk of vaccine preventable diseases coming in and sitting in their waiting rooms and possibly infecting other children is simply too great.\n\nPublic health professionals, the medical community, and schools also need to do a better job at education and outreach about the safety and efficacy of immunizations. After all, vaccines are one of the greatest public health successes in history. In the early 1900s, here in the USA, there were typically 500 000 cases of measles annually, with 8000 deaths. There were 20 000 cases and 1000 deaths from serious _Haemophilus influenzae_ b (Hib) illnesses, which cause meningitis and pneumonia in children under 5 years of age. There were 100 000 cases of pertussis and 5000 deaths. All of these diseases had been almost driven to zero at the start of the 21st century, and maybe that's why many current parents don't feel the immediate threat. But those very diseases are reemerging, and we need to increase awareness of this fact. We can work with the schools to help us with this effort. Local pediatricians need to be ready for these discussions with facts and may need some guidance on how to persuade reluctant parents. There is action at the state level to tighten up the PBE process to make it more difficult to exempt out of vaccines.\n\nEbola and other new infectious diseases like enterovirus D-68 are scary, and we need to prepare and find effective ways to control them, but there is no current vaccine to protect us against those threats. There is an immunization to prevent pertussis and many other communicable diseases. So, to the parents who choose not to vaccinate their children, I urge you to reconsider. This is not just for the health and well-being of your own children, but for the health of everyone around you, your friends, neighbors, and the community. It is the responsible thing to do.\n\n[byline: Takashi Wada]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Takashi Wada, MD, MPH, is director of the Santa Barbara County Public Health Department. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] Ohio (Hamilton County)\nDate: Tue 11 Nov 2014\nSource: Fox19 [edited]\nhttp://www.fox19.com/story/27356205/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-two-area-schools\n\n\nThe Cincinnati Health Department is reporting outbreaks of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, across the city including Elder High School and Cincinnati Hills Christian Academy. The outbreak at Elder began a month ago with one student and quickly spread to 20 students, but before things got out of hand, Principal Tom Otten says the Cincinnati Health Department was called in.\n\n'One of the students came to the school nurse,' Otten said. 'She realized what she was dealing with at the time, so she alerted the Cincinnati Health Department.' Otten, says the health department advised them to follow a strict protocol when a student or faculty member shows symptoms of pertussis. 'He goes to his physician and either gets a positive or negative. If it comes out negative, then he's allowed back in class. If it comes up positive that he's got whooping cough, then there's a mandatory 5 day antimicrobial treatment,' said Otten.\n\nDuring those 5 days, the student must stay home. Elder school nurse, Linda Giessler says pertussis is highly contagious. 'Pertussis spreads. It can start off like the common cold, you know, cough, sneezing, and because it's respiratory in nature, it's very contagious,' Giessler said.\n\nCustodian Jeff Hillgrove says he uses special wipes to sanitize the entire building because the disease stubbornly clings to surfaces. 'It actually will live on a surface for up to 7 days, so we've been doing this daily, trying to knock it out, get it out of the school building,' Hillgrove said.\n\nSimilar steps are being taken at Cincinnati Hills Christian Academy, which has reported 5 cases of whooping cough. They hope that at Elder the disease has run its course.\n\nAll 20 Elder students are healthy and back in class, but school officials are staying vigilant to make sure the outbreak doesn't spread.\n\n[byline: Gordon Graham]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] North Carolina (Chatham County)\nDate: Thu 14 Nov 2014\nSource: WNCN [edited]\nhttp://www.wncn.com/story/27375811/several-cases-of-whooping-cough-reported-in-chatham-co\n\n\nSeveral cases of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, have been reported in Chatham County, county health officials said on Thu 14 Nov 2014. In the last month, the Chatham County Public Health Department said it has been dealing with several cases of the respiratory disease.\n\nCounty health officials said a majority of those diagnosed with whooping cough have been adolescents; however, some of the cases are in children under 5 years old.\n\nThe health department is working with Chatham County Schools to identify the students who may have been exposed. The best protection against pertussis is vaccination.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The morbidity and mortality of pertussis in older children and adults is quite small compared with that in infants under 12 months of age, especially those under 6 months of age. In the wake of the increase in cases in older children and adolescents attributed to unimmunized children and in those with waning immunity attributed to the acellular vaccine (as compared with the classic whole cell killed vaccine), immunization programs have targeted the concept of cocooning the newborn infant by immunization of those around the infant and immunizing the pregnant woman in the 2nd or 3rd trimester.\n\nThe following recent publication seems to confirm the relative safety of prepartum pertussis immunization:\n\nKharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al. Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014;312: 1897-904.\n\nAbstract:\n'Importance: In 2010, due to a pertussis outbreak and neonatal deaths, the California Department of Health recommended that the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) be administered during pregnancy. Tdap is now recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for all pregnant women, preferably between 27 and 36 weeks' gestation. Limited data exist on Tdap safety during pregnancy.\n\n'Objective: To evaluate whether maternal Tdap vaccination during pregnancy is associated with increased risks of adverse obstetric events or adverse birth outcomes.\n\n'Design and setting: Retrospective, observational cohort study using administrative health care databases from 2 California Vaccine Safety Datalink sites.\n\n'Participants and exposures: Of 123 494 women with singleton pregnancies ending in a live birth between 1 Jan 2010 and 15 Nov 2012, 26 229 (21 per cent) received Tdap during pregnancy and 97 265 did not.\n\n'Main outcomes and measures: Risks of small-for-gestational-age (SGA) births (less than 10th percentile), chorioamnionitis, preterm birth (less than 37 weeks' gestation), and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy were evaluated. Relative risk (RR) estimates were adjusted for site, receipt of another vaccine during pregnancy, and propensity to receive Tdap during pregnancy. Cox regression was used for preterm delivery, and Poisson regression for other outcomes.\n\n'Results: Vaccination was not associated with increased risks of adverse birth outcomes: crude estimates for preterm delivery were 6.3 per cent of vaccinated and 7.8 per cent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.03; 95 per cent CI, 0.97-1.09); 8.4 per cent of vaccinated and 8.3 per cent of unvaccinated had an SGA birth (adjusted RR, 1.00; 95 per cent CI, 0.96-1.06). Receipt of Tdap before 20 weeks was not associated with hypertensive disorder of pregnancy (adjusted RR, 1.09; 95 per cent CI, 0.99-1.20); chorioamnionitis was diagnosed in 6.1 per cent of vaccinated and 5.5 per cent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.19; 95 per cent CI, 1.13-1.26).\n\n'Conclusion and relevance: In this cohort of women with singleton pregnancies that ended in live birth, receipt of Tdap during pregnancy was not associated with increased risk of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy or preterm or SGA birth, although a small but statistically significant increased risk of chorioamnionitis diagnosis was observed.' - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Heidi Fenton]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With a large jump in probable cases in a number that could represent more than 10 per cent or more of the students, it be important to know the vaccination status of the school's students. \n\n[byline: Takashi Wada]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Takashi Wada, MD, MPH, is director of the Santa Barbara County Public Health Department. \n\n'Results: Vaccination was not associated with increased risks of adverse birth outcomes: crude estimates for preterm delivery were 6.3 per cent of vaccinated and 7.8 per cent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.03; 95 per cent CI, 0.97-1.09); 8.4 per cent of vaccinated and 8.3 per cent of unvaccinated had an SGA birth (adjusted RR, 1.00; 95 per cent CI, 0.96-1.06). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Gordon Graham]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nCounty health officials said a majority of those diagnosed with whooping cough have been adolescents; however, some of the cases are in children under 5 years old. \n\n'Conclusion and relevance: In this cohort of women with singleton pregnancies that ended in live birth, receipt of Tdap during pregnancy was not associated with increased risk of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy or preterm or SGA birth, although a small but statistically significant increased risk of chorioamnionitis diagnosis was observed.' In the wake of the increase in cases in older children and adolescents attributed to unimmunized children and in those with waning immunity attributed to the acellular vaccine (as compared with the classic whole cell killed vaccine), immunization programs have targeted the concept of cocooning the newborn infant by immunization of those around the infant and immunizing the pregnant woman in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. Abstract:\n'Importance: In 2010, due to a pertussis outbreak and neonatal deaths, the California Department of Health recommended that the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) be administered during pregnancy. Receipt of Tdap before 20 weeks was not associated with hypertensive disorder of pregnancy (adjusted RR, 1.09; 95 per cent CI, 0.99-1.20); chorioamnionitis was diagnosed in 6.1 per cent of vaccinated and 5.5 per cent of unvaccinated women (adjusted RR, 1.19; 95 per cent CI, 1.13-1.26). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The morbidity and mortality of pertussis in older children and adults is quite small compared with that in infants under 12 months of age, especially those under 6 months of age. Source: Mlive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/whooping_cough_outbreak_at_gra.html\n\n\nHealth department staff are warning students and teachers who are off this week amid a pertussis outbreak at Grand Traverse Academy to stay home as the number of those ill continues to grow. \n\nThe following recent publication seems to confirm the relative safety of prepartum pertussis immunization:\n\nKharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al. \n\nWhy are there an increasing number of parents filing personal belief exemptions (PBEs) so their children do not need to comply with school vaccination requirements? Even if one of these unvaccinated children contracts the illness and recovers fully, others around them -- pregnant women, infants too young to receive vaccines, children and adults with immunologic deficits or cancer -- may contract the disease and not be so fortunate. \n\nAnd yet others are part of a growing group of parents who are highly educated but still choose to file PBEs so their children do not need to get their vaccines upon school entry. \n\n'Participants and exposures: Of 123 494 women with singleton pregnancies ending in a live birth between 1 Jan 2010 and 15 Nov 2012, 26 229 (21 per cent) received Tdap during pregnancy and 97 265 did not. \n\nArea physician offices, urgent care locations and clinics are bogged down handling the outbreak as Grand Traverse Health Department staff continue to urge any students and teachers to begin a course of preventative antimicrobials. \n\nWhile Waldorf schoolchildren are particularly low in their vaccination rates, it would not be appropriate to assume this problem of unvaccinated children is isolated to that one school. \n\n'Main outcomes and measures: Risks of small-for-gestational-age (SGA) births (less than 10th percentile), chorioamnionitis, preterm birth (less than 37 weeks' gestation), and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy were evaluated. Several cases of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, have been reported in Chatham County, county health officials said on Thu 14 Nov 2014. \n\n'Objective: To evaluate whether maternal Tdap vaccination during pregnancy is associated with increased risks of adverse obstetric events or adverse birth outcomes. PERTUSSIS - USA (23)\n********************\n \n\nSimilar steps are being taken at Cincinnati Hills Christian Academy, which has reported 5 cases of whooping cough. As of Wed 12 Nov 2014, there are 12 confirmed cases and 161 probable cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough. \n\nStudents, staff members and their families are strongly urged to get the vaccine against pertussis. \n\nPublic health professionals, the medical community, and schools also need to do a better job at education and outreach about the safety and efficacy of immunizations. LL]\n\n******\n LL]\n\n******\n http://www.fox19.com/story/27356205/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-two-area-schools\n\n\nThe Cincinnati Health Department is reporting outbreaks of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, across the city including Elder High School and Cincinnati Hills Christian Academy. \n\nGrand Traverse Academy administrators chose to close for the week as the number of students and staff with the illness continued to grow. There were 20 000 cases and 1000 deaths from serious _Haemophilus influenzae_ b (Hib) illnesses, which cause meningitis and pneumonia in children under 5 years of age. \n\nThe health department is working with Chatham County Schools to identify the students who may have been exposed. \n\nEarlier this week, county health officer Wendy Trute shared her hope that those infected would not grow to include other community members. \n\n'One of the students came to the school nurse,' Otten said. ' That makes almost 90 cases in our county so far in 2014, the most cases in one year since we have been collecting electronic reporting data, which goes back over 10 years.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chatham County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Barbara County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chatham County Schools", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hamilton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2922903", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (22)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2922903", "date": "2014-11-05 12:58:02", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (22)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Nevada (Elko County)\n[2] Illinois (Macoupin County)\n[3] New Jersey (Mercer County)\n\n******\n[1] Nevada (Elko County)\nDate: Thu 30 Oct 2014\nSource: Elko (NV) Daily Free Press [edited]\nhttp://elkodaily.com/news/pertussis-outbreak-in-elko-county/article_f30bc607-9aea-5462-b5cb-1d5cff469f70.html\n\n\nThe Division of Public and Behavioral Health has declared an outbreak of pertussis (whooping cough) in Elko County as of 20 Oct 2014. According to its data, Elko County has seen a rise in pertussis cases over recent years. As of Mon 27 Oct 2014, Elko County has had 14 cases of pertussis reported since July 2014. Controlling the spread of pertussis requires quick identification of cases and contacts prompt treatment of these individuals, and immunization of susceptible persons.\n\nPertussis spreads easily through the air when an infected person breathes, coughs, or sneezes. A person can spread the disease while he or she has cold-like symptoms and for at least 2 weeks after coughing starts. Vaccination of persons who are not up-to-date for pertussis provides long-term protection. Getting your child the vaccine helps protect them against whooping cough. It also protects other people who cannot get the vaccine, especially newborn babies, who can get very ill and can die from this infection. The division asks that you make sure your family's vaccinations are up-to-date. Older children and adults, including pregnant women, should get a pertussis booster shot called to protect themselves and infants near or around them. If you need the vaccine, contact your doctor. Early treatment of pertussis is very important. If treatment for pertussis is started early in the course of illness, during the 1st one to 2 weeks before coughing attacks occur, symptoms may be lessened.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Nevada can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35393. Elko County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/nevada-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Illinois (Macoupin County)\nDate: Wed 29 Oct 2014\nSource: KPLR, KTVI [summ., edited]\nhttp://kplr11.com/2014/10/29/cdc-monitoring-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-staunton-illinois/\n\n\nThe CDC is monitoring a disease outbreak in Staunton, [Macoupin County] Illinois. Cases of whooping cough appear to be spreading quickly. At last report, there were 24 confirmed cases of the illness in public and private schools in Staunton. The disease got its name from the sound babies make when they have pertussis or whooping cough. Classrooms are getting a deep cleaning.\n\nHealth officials said some people in the community are on edge after a toddler recently died [in Staunton]. They want everyone to know the child's death had nothing to do with whooping cough. If a student tests positive the youngster is given antimicrobial treatment and is out of class for 5 days.\n\n[Byline: Roche Madden]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Illinois can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42354. Macoupin County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/illinois-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] New Jersey (Mercer County)\nDate: Mon 27 Oct 2014\nSource: Planet Princeton [edited]\nhttp://planetprinceton.com/2014/10/27/another-case-of-whooping-cough-confirmed-in-princeton-public-schools/\n\n\nA 3rd elementary school student has been diagnosed with whooping cough in Princeton [Mercer County].\n\nA letter was sent home to parents of students at Community Park School today [27 Oct 2014] notifying them that a student attending the school has a confirmed case of whooping cough. Another student at the same school tested positive for whooping cough in late September [2014]. A student from Riverside Elementary School [Princeton] also tested positive for whooping cough.\n\nWhooping cough is a highly contagious bacterial disease of the nose, throat, and lungs that causes long bursts of coughing. It is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. Whooping cough can cause violent coughing fits as children choke and gasp for air while making a whooping sound. Adults and older children still get whooping cough, but they may not make the characteristic 'whooping' noise when coughing and are often not diagnosed.\n\nBabies need protection from whooping cough because this disease can make them very sick and is very contagious. People with whooping cough usually spread the disease by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others, who then breathe in the bacteria that cause the disease. Many babies who get whooping cough are infected by parents, older siblings, or other caregivers who might not even know they have the disease. When babies catch whooping cough, the symptoms can be very serious. Young babies could get pneumonia and many have trouble breathing. About half of babies younger than 1 year of age who get whooping cough end up in the hospital, and a few even die from the disease.\n\nBecause the disease can make babies so sick, and they can catch it from anyone around them, they need protection. If you are pregnant, you'll need the whooping cough vaccine in your 3rd trimester. Surround your baby with vaccinated family members and caregivers and make sure your baby gets all his doses of the whooping cough vaccine according to the CDC's recommended schedule.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of New Jersey can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8024. Mercer County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/new-jersey-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nIt certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting this susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. \n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. [3] New Jersey (Mercer County)\n\n******\n If you are pregnant, you'll need the whooping cough vaccine in your 3rd trimester. Getting your child the vaccine helps protect them against whooping cough. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elko County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Staunton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macoupin County ]", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macoupin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mercer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2864604", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (21): (CA) increasing incidence, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2864604", "date": "2014-10-15 10:20:28", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (21): (CALIFORNIA) INCREASING INCIDENCE, UPDATE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 Oct 2014\nSource: Record Searchlight [edited]\nhttp://www.redding.com/news/local-news/shasta-county-sees-fourfold-uptick-in-whooping-cough-cases_19207993\n\n\nKeeping up with a state-declared epidemic, Shasta County has had 4 times as many whooping cough cases, so far this year [2014], than it did during the same period of 2013. 'We're definitely having an upswing of whooping cough in Shasta County,' said Andrew Deckert, the county's public health officer.\n\nWhile the 28 cases reported so far this year [2014] are quadruple the 7 cases in 2013, and even further from the mere 2 cases the county saw in 2012, health officials weren't caught too off-guard because the disease is cyclical, meaning it tends to have a steep uptick every 3 to 5 years. For example, 2010 saw 32 cases in the same time period in Shasta County, Deckert said.\n\nIn Tehama County, there also has been a massive uptick this year [2014], with 38 reported cases to 2013's zero, according to CDPH data.\n\nDespite the cyclical nature of the illness, the sharp rise in cases is pushing local health officials to remind the public to get vaccinated for the airborne illness that's also known as pertussis. 'Having the disease is absolutely miserable, and I inspire you to get caught up and current on your Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] ... for your own preservation,' Lloyd Braemer, a pediatrician at Mercy Medical Center, said of the 2nd anti-whooping cough shot people are supposed to get after the DtaP shot as young children.\n\nThe vaccines, however, aren't required if parents object to them over philosophical or religious beliefs in California. So while the shot is technically considered mandatory for schoolchildren, it really isn't in California, since parents who object can use a 'personal belief exemption' form to avoid shots for their children. A full 10 percent of 7th-grade students and 8.56 percent of kindergarten students in Shasta County got a belief exemption in the last school year -- a rise from the year before, according to California Department of Public Health.\n\n'Personal belief exemptions definitely have an impact, not only on whooping cough, but other childhood diseases, as well,' said Valerie Lucero, executive director of the Tehama County Health Services Agency.\n\nIn addition to vaccines, there also are preventive antibiotics people can take up to 21 days after suspected exposure to the bacteria.\n\nThe incubation period for the bacterium that causes the illness is 5 to 21 days, Deckert said, after which people start showing general cold symptoms such as coughing and sneezing. But pertussis takes on a life of its own after a while, with the cough becoming so severe that it can induce vomiting or break patients' ribs and last for months.\n\nThe illness isn't just unpleasant -- it can be deadly, especially for infants, the youngest of whom can't be vaccinated, and is incredibly infectious ['contagious' is the appropriate descriptor here, rather than 'infectious'; see below] compared to more common ailments such as the flu. For example, Deckert said each person with the flu generally infects one to 2 other people, but every pertussis patient infects another 12 to 17 people. 'It's a huge difference -- much more infectious than the flu,' Deckert said.\n\nThe illness has hospitalized 288 people statewide, so far this year [2014], including 68 intensive-care stays, according to the California Department of Public Health. There also have been 3 deaths, so far in 2014, though 2 of those happened in children who contracted the illness in 2013. All told, 8278 people statewide have contracted the disease, so far this year, compared to 1249 in roughly the same period last year.\n\nBraemer said he hasn't seen many cases of whooping cough this year [2014]. 'I kept waiting for it. I haven't seen squat,' Braemer said. But, he said, it's also not the holiday season yet, when people traveling to more populous areas are likely to bring the illness back with them. 'I would think the travel time at Thanksgiving is going to be clinically relevant to rapidly spreading the pertussis disease, because we don't need to fly anywhere to get the heavy-hitters -- we just need to drive to the greater regions of California,' he said.\n\nFor information on [Shasta] county's shot clinics, call 530-225-5591. In Tehama County, call 530-527-6824. Whooping cough vaccines are recommended for everyone 6 weeks old and older, including pregnant women in their 3rd trimester, regardless of whether they were vaccinated earlier.\n\n[Byline: Alayna Shulman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'infectious' refers to the ability of an organism to cause disease, while 'contagious' refers to its ability to spread from person to person. Some organisms can be infectious without being contagious.\n\nThere were 7980 cases of pertussis in California reported statewide as of the 3rd week in September (2014), according to a news report posted recently by ProMED-mail (Pertussis - USA (19): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140921.2792202). There are now 8278 cases statewide so far this year, compared to 1249 in the same period last year (2013), according to the news report above.\n\nPertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383.\n\nIn the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). DTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis. (Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D) and tetanus (T) toxoids and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.)\n\nAntibiotic post exposure prophylaxis is used in all asymptomatic household contacts within 21 days of onset of cough in the index patient with pertussis and in persons within 21 days of exposure who are at high risk of developing severe pertussis and in persons who will have close contact with those at high risk of developing severe pertussis such as infants aged less than 12 months and women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy, immunocompromised persons, and patients with moderate to severe medically treated asthma (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/PEP.html). - Mod.ML\n\nThe state of can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. Shasta and Tehama counties in northern California can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nAntibiotic post exposure prophylaxis is used in all asymptomatic household contacts within 21 days of onset of cough in the index patient with pertussis and in persons within 21 days of exposure who are at high risk of developing severe pertussis and in persons who will have close contact with those at high risk of developing severe pertussis such as infants aged less than 12 months and women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy, immunocompromised persons, and patients with moderate to severe medically treated asthma (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/PEP.html). \n\nWhile the 28 cases reported so far this year [2014] are quadruple the 7 cases in 2013, and even further from the mere 2 cases the county saw in 2012, health officials weren't caught too off-guard because the disease is cyclical, meaning it tends to have a steep uptick every 3 to 5 years. \n\nThere were 7980 cases of pertussis in California reported statewide as of the 3rd week in September (2014), according to a news report posted recently by ProMED-mail (Pertussis - USA (19): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140921.2792202). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Having the disease is absolutely miserable, and I inspire you to get caught up and current on your Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] ... for your own preservation,' Lloyd Braemer, a pediatrician at Mercy Medical Center, said of the 2nd anti-whooping cough shot people are supposed to get after the DtaP shot as young children. \n\nThe illness has hospitalized 288 people statewide, so far this year [2014], including 68 intensive-care stays, according to the California Department of Public Health. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'infectious' refers to the ability of an organism to cause disease, while 'contagious' refers to its ability to spread from person to person. \n\nBraemer said he hasn't seen many cases of whooping cough this year [2014]. ' For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383. \n\n\nKeeping up with a state-declared epidemic, Shasta County has had 4 times as many whooping cough cases, so far this year [2014], than it did during the same period of 2013. There are now 8278 cases statewide so far this year, compared to 1249 in the same period last year (2013), according to the news report above. For example, Deckert said each person with the flu generally infects one to 2 other people, but every pertussis patient infects another 12 to 17 people. ' A full 10 percent of 7th-grade students and 8.56 percent of kindergarten students in Shasta County got a belief exemption in the last school year -- a rise from the year before, according to California Department of Public Health. \n\nThe illness isn't just unpleasant -- it can be deadly, especially for infants, the youngest of whom can't be vaccinated, and is incredibly infectious ['contagious' is the appropriate descriptor here, rather than 'infectious'; see below] compared to more common ailments such as the flu. All told, 8278 people statewide have contracted the disease, so far this year, compared to 1249 in roughly the same period last year. Despite the cyclical nature of the illness, the sharp rise in cases is pushing local health officials to remind the public to get vaccinated for the airborne illness that's also known as pertussis. ' \n\n'Personal belief exemptions definitely have an impact, not only on whooping cough, but other childhood diseases, as well,' said Valerie Lucero, executive director of the Tehama County Health Services Agency. I would think the travel time at Thanksgiving is going to be clinically relevant to rapidly spreading the pertussis disease, because we don't need to fly anywhere to get the heavy-hitters -- we just need to drive to the greater regions of California,' he said. The incubation period for the bacterium that causes the illness is 5 to 21 days, Deckert said, after which people start showing general cold symptoms such as coughing and sneezing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "7980-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1249-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "8278-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shasta County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tehama County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3024716", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (26)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3024716", "date": "2014-12-11 09:18:25", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (26)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New York (Erie County)\n[2] Virginia (southwest)\n[3] Utah (Salt Lake County)\n[4] Nebraska (Otoe County)\n[5] Michigan (Allegan County)\n[6] Michigan (Dickinson County)\n\n******\n[1] New York (Erie County)\nDate: Wed 10 Dec 2014\nSource: WGRZ [edited]\nhttp://www.wgrz.com/story/news/health/2014/12/09/pertussis-erie-county-november/20140395/\n\n\nErie County Health officials say they have had an 'uptick' of pertussis reports, specifically on Grand Island and in East Aurora. 13 cases have been reported to the county so far for the month of November 2014. December numbers have not been tallied yet. All, except one, have been school-age children.\n\nGrand Island Superintendent Dr Teresa Lawrence says they've had 10 cases of pertussis in the middle and high school. East Aurora is also dealing with several students with pertussis. Jerome Polakiewicz, Director of Pupil Services and Special Education say they have 8 confirmed cases, and 3 more probable cases. They have also sent a letter home to parents. The county says this is just a slight uptick and there was a more widespread outbreak in 2011 and 2012.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1851. Erie County in western New York can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (southwest)\nDate: Wed 10 Dec 2014\nSource: The News & Advance [edited]\nhttp://www.newsadvance.com/news/local/pertussis-cases-increasing-in-southwestern-virginia/article_68bc8884-8085-11e4-b9d8-d360dd5c2e53.html\n\n\nA wide swath of Central and Southside Virginia is seeing an increase in pertussis, or 'whooping cough'. 'We are seeing more than we would expect right now,' said Haley Philips, a Virginia Department of Health epidemiologist, this week. The increase is in the department's Southwestern region of Virginia, which encompasses an area that includes Alleghany, the Cumberland Plateau, Central Virginia, Mount Rogers, New River, Pittsylvania County/Danville, Lenowisco, Roanoke, and West Piedmont.\n\nPhilips would not identify the number of cases occurring either in Lynchburg or the Southwestern region, but according to Virginia Department of Health surveillance reports, 18 Virginians died as a result of pertussis in October [2014], the most recent month for which data is available. [It is unlikely that the figure quoted was for deaths from pertussis. - Mod.LL]\n\nNone of those cases occurred in the Central Virginia Health District, which includes Lynchburg and the counties of Appomattox, Amherst, Bedford, and Campbell. Philips said Tue, 9 Dec 2014, that 'pertussis is always a concern' for health departments. Pertussis is one of a number of diseases the health department continually monitors. Right now, Philips said, 'We certainly are paying attention.'\n\n[Byline: Amy Trent]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Virginia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/247. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/virginia-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Utah (Salt Lake County)\nDate: Thu 4 Dec 2014\nSource: The Salt Lake Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.sltrib.com/news/1908090-155/east-high-school-fighting-whooping-cough\n\n\nSeven East High School students were kept home from school on Thu 4 Dec 2014, while school officials and the Salt Lake County Health Department worked to contain an outbreak of whooping cough. The school also conducted on-site immunizations for roughly 30 students who had not yet received pertussis, or whooping cough, vaccinations, East High School Principal Paul Sagers said. 'We've personally called every student who has not been immunized,' Sagers said. 'We have basically told them that they need to be immunized.' The school's quick reaction to contain the cluster comes as whooping cough cases have declined in Utah, after a spike 2 years ago.\n\nThere have been 748 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Utah in 2014, according to Rebecca Ward, a health educator with the Utah Department of Health. That's down from 1132 at this time in 2013. In 2012, there were 1544 cases.\n\nUnlike the cold or flu, which peak during the winter season, pertussis circulates throughout the year, said Ward. Schools in Weber County and Sevier County were hit with outbreaks in February and May 2014. 'It's not as high as it has been and that's a good thing,' Ward said. 'We're probably not going to get to 1000 cases by the end of 2014.'\n\nSalt Lake County health officials were told of the 1st case of whooping cough 2 weeks ago, department spokeswoman Pamela Davenport said. As of Thu 4 Dec 2014, there were 6 confirmed cases, Davenport said, enough to classify as an outbreak under CDC guidelines.\n\n[Byline: Benjamin Wood]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4394. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/utah-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] Nebraska (Otoe County)\nDate: Fri 5 Dec 2014\nSource: KMA Land [edited]\nhttp://www.kmaland.com/news/pertussis-reported-in-nebraska-city-syracuse-schools/article_e78a6a24-7c9c-11e4-b09a-475e91448e11.html\n\n\nParents of 2 southeast Nebraska school districts are on alert regarding the whooping cough. Within the past week, students in the Nebraska City and Syracuse districts [Otoe County] have contracted pertussis. Nebraska City School Superintendent Dr Jeff Edwards tells KMA News reports were received from students at Nebraska City Middle School and Hayward Elementary School. Edwards says school officials worked with the Southeast District Health Department to inform students and parents about the illnesses.\n\n'Through the health department,' said Edwards, 'we received a letter from them, and then a fax sheet, that we mailed out to all of our parents in the middle school and at Hayward. Basically, that fact sheet talked about what parents should look for, what are some of the symptoms of the whooping cough, and if their child has not received immunization, how they can go about doing that.' Edwards says it's hard to tell how many students contracted whooping cough.\n\n'There's a lot of crud going around out there,' he said. 'Whether it's from the pertussis or whooping cough, or whether it's from the general flu, I would say our numbers (of absences) are typical for this time of year. Anytime you've got weekends where it's 60 deg F [15.5 deg C], and the next day, it's 20 [deg F/-6.6 deg C], wearing a jacket and not wearing a jacket, there's all kinds of different factors out there.'\n\n[Byline: Mike Peterson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Nebraska can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43100. Otoe County in south eastern Nebraska can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/nebraska-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Michigan (Allegan County)\nDate: Mon 8 Dec 2014\nSource: WOOD TV8 [edited]\nhttp://woodtv.com/2014/12/08/whooping-cough-outbreak-among-allegan-co-teens/\n\n\nAllegan County's medical director, Dr Richard Tooker, told 24 Hour News 8 he thinks 2014 may go down in history as the county's worst ever for whooping cough. 'I've been in public health since 1984 and I have never seen anything like this,' Tooker said.\n\nThere were 4 cases of whooping cough in Allegan County in 2011. Tooker said that was typical. In 2012, there were 27 cases. There were 25 case in 2013. There have already been 26 cases in 2014. 21 of those have happened since August. Most have affected Hamilton High School students, but there have also been cases reported involving middle school students.\n\nTooker said there are many more cases that his office expected, even though the number of cases has been on the rise for the last decade. The problem isn't that the children getting sick haven't received their pertussis vaccination. All of the Hamilton students who have been diagnosed with the illness have been properly vaccinated.\n\n'We recognize, in all likelihood, the vaccine doesn't produce long-term immunity like it used to,' Tooker said.\n\nThe CDC says the problem is nationwide. In 2012, there were 48 277 cases in the US -- the most since 1955. Whooping cough claimed 20 lives nationwide that year. Most of the deaths were of infants under the age of 3 months.\n\nThe Michigan Department of Community Health says there have been 1079 cases through 30 Nov 2014. In 2013, there were 766 in the same time period -- that's a 41 percent increase. There have been no whooping cough deaths in Allegan County. But there have been a few in the state in the last couple of years. Tooker said that is unacceptable. He said that even given waning efficacy, vaccination is still the best protection.\n\nTooker said he expects the CDC to begin convening expert panels to address the issue. He said that there currently seems to be no end in sight to the steady increase in the number of cases.\n\n[Byline: Steve Kelso and 24 Hour News 8 web staff]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Michigan can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/michigan-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[6] Michigan (Dickinson County)\nDate: Tue 9 Dec 2014\nSource: TV6 News [edited]\nhttp://www.uppermichiganssource.com/news/story.aspx?id=1133826\n\n\nWith 7 confirmed cases of pertussis in Dickinson County it is cause for concern. Students from the county's schools are missing classes because of the illness.\n\nThe Dickinson Iron County Health Department Director Joyce Ziegler, says that the best prevention is through vaccination. 'While we still may have some cases out there we don't probably have as many as we could potentially if people weren't vaccinated. So, vaccination is prevention. What that does is it protects the entire community.'\n\n[Byline: Blair Caldwell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4394.
