Date: Mon 8 Dec 2014\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1079-03-25 00:00:00", "1544-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1132-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2014-12-25 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Syracuse", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alleghany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/247", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Central Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erie County Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weber County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lynchburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erie County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allegan County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dickinson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otoe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Cumberland Plateau", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allegan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bedford", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Aurora", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salt Lake County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pittsylvania County / Danville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sevier County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2833302", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (20): (CO) increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2833302", "date": "2014-10-05 18:57:55", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (20): (COLORADO), INCREASING INCIDENCE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 3 Oct 2014\nSource: CBS Denver [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/10/03/whooping-cough-cases-rise-in-weld-county-impact-schools/\n\n\nHealth officials in Weld County [Colorado] say they've seen an increase in the number of cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, this year [2014]. County officials said they've encountered the same number of cases through early October 2014 that they saw throughout 2013. Weld County health officials have diagnosed 116 cases of pertussis this year. Students at 7 Windsor area schools are infected [Windsor, a town with a population of 18 644 in Larimer and Weld counties, is 59 miles (95 km) north of Denver, the Colorado State Capitol]. The health department notified administrators at each affected school.\n\n'Take this seriously. It is a cough, but it is a horrible cough. It will last for months. It can cause vomiting, incredible discomfort,' Eric Aakko with the county's health department said. Pertussis affects the respiratory system, causing stubborn and persistent coughing. It is very contagious and can be fatal. The best protection against pertussis is vaccination, although it does not provide life-long immunization.\n\nHealth officials said that for every diagnosed case of whooping cough, there are 9 or 10 that are not diagnosed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383.\n\nWeld County, with a population that was 252 825 in 2010, is one of the 64 counties of the U.S. state of Colorado and is located in northeast Colorado, on the state's northern border with the state of Wyoming [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weld_County,_Colorado]. A map of Colorado, showing the location of Weld County and the town of Windsor can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Weld+County,+CO/@41.4173904,-106.3747581,6z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x876c07da939b130b:0x79c8bbfa1c2ef9fa. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383. http://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/10/03/whooping-cough-cases-rise-in-weld-county-impact-schools/\n\n\nHealth officials in Weld County [Colorado] say they've seen an increase in the number of cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, this year [2014]. \n\nHealth officials said that for every diagnosed case of whooping cough, there are 9 or 10 that are not diagnosed. PERTUSSIS - USA (20): (COLORADO), INCREASING INCIDENCE\n******************************************************\n \n\nWeld County, with a population that was 252 825 in 2010, is one of the 64 counties of the U.S. state of Colorado and is located in northeast Colorado, on the state's northern border with the state of Wyoming [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weld_County,_Colorado].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2691608", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Netherlands: (OV) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2691608", "date": "2014-08-15 00:26:29", "main_text": "PERTUSSUS - NETHERLANDS: (OVERIJSSEL) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Aug 2014\nSource: NL Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nltimes.nl/2014/08/13/whooping-cough-cases-increasing-fast/\n\n\nIn Overijssel [province, Netherlands], 2 Municipal Healthcare Services (GGD) in the region of Twente have reported a rise in cases of whooping cough. Nurses are warning those vaccinated that their cough might not be a nasty cold after all, RTV Oost reports.\n\nThe GGD Twente speaks of a steep rise in the number of reports. In 2013, there were a total of 175 cases. Halfway through [2014], the numbers are already at 275.\n\nThe GGD in IJsselland is also seeing explosive numbers. Over the whole of last year [2013], there were just more than 100. In 2014, there have been 125 cases of whooping cough already.\n\nWhooping cough is caused by a bacterium [_Bordetella pertussis_], and is very contagious. People showing symptoms of whooping cough can transfer the sickness to others for up to 4 weeks.\n\nIn adults, the sickness resembles a nasty cold. Young children who have not yet been vaccinated are much more vulnerable to the sickness, however. Their sinuses can be blocked to the point of respiratory arrest. [This last sentence makes no sense. It may refer to apnea (respiratory arrest) that can occur following a paroxysm of coughing in very young children with pertussis, which has been attributed to 'failure of self-rescue breathing at the end of a paroxysm of coughing or to profound vagal stimulation even before a clinical cough episode' (http://www.jhasim.com/files/articlefiles/pdf/ASIM_Issue_5_5A_p444_449.pdf). - Mod.ML]\n\nThis outbreak of whooping cough has no clear cause. 'There just has to be a primary school with one sick parent or child, and it breaks out in the entire village,' infectious disease control nurse Judith Keizers of GGD Twente tells RTV Oost.\n\nKeizers wants to call attention to the fact that people who have been vaccinated are not necessarily immune to the sickness, and that it is not simply a harmless cough. 'For adults, whooping cough is only very irritating, [but] young children and infants can be seriously affected by this bacteria. By asking for attention, we hope to protect these children.'\n\n[Byline: Maxime Zech]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number 20140424.2426383.\n\nOverijssel is a province in the central-eastern part of the Netherlands (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overijssel). For a map of the Netherlands showing the location of Overijssel, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overijssel#mediaviewer/File:Overijssel_in_the_Netherlands.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21437.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n It may refer to apnea (respiratory arrest) that can occur following a paroxysm of coughing in very young children with pertussis, which has been attributed to 'failure of self-rescue breathing at the end of a paroxysm of coughing or to profound vagal stimulation even before a clinical cough episode' (http://www.jhasim.com/files/articlefiles/pdf/ASIM_Issue_5_5A_p444_449.pdf). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number 20140424.2426383. \n\n[Byline: Maxime Zech]\n\n--\n \n\nWhooping cough is caused by a bacterium [_Bordetella pertussis_], and is very contagious. ML]\n\nThis outbreak of whooping cough has no clear cause. ' For adults, whooping cough is only very irritating, [but] young children and infants can be seriously affected by this bacteria. Keizers wants to call attention to the fact that people who have been vaccinated are not necessarily immune to the sickness, and that it is not simply a harmless cough. ' PERTUSSUS - NETHERLANDS: (OVERIJSSEL) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n*********************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Overijssel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IJsselland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2792202", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (19): (CA) increasing incidence, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2792202", "date": "2014-09-21 20:37:16", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (19): (CALIFORNIA) INCREASING INCIDENCE, UPDATE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 21 Sep 2014\nSource: Petaluma 360 [edited]\nhttp://www.petaluma360.com/news/2825052-181/county-leads-state-in-whooping\n\n\nSonoma County [California]'s health officials [are worried about] the high incidence of pertussis, or whooping cough, among the school-age population. Building on a surge of 50 additional cases per week in the spring months, the county continues to lead the state by a wide margin in the rate of pertussis cases this year [2014].\n\nThe most recent report from the California Department of Public Health shows almost 7980 cases in the state, 684 of them in Sonoma County, leading to 5 hospitalizations but no deaths. While larger counties have had more cases, the incidence rate in Sonoma tops the list, over 137 cases per 100 000 persons. The next highest rates lag far behind, about 93/100 000 in Napa County, followed by 80 in Marin. Overall, the state rate is 20.9 per 100 000.\n\nThe geographical focus of the highest rates of pertussis does not escape Dr. Karen Holbrook, the deputy health officer for the county's Department of Health Services. 'That's how it spreads, person to person, and our populations between counties do intermix.'\n\nAs students returned to primary and secondary schools last month, they were faced with stricter requirements for immunizations against communicable diseases. Since 1962, California has required certain vaccinations for children starting kindergartens, including whooping cough. Additionally, now students entering 7th grade are required to have an up-to-date Tdap vaccination (which covers tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis). But a disturbing number of parents are pursuing the 'personal belief exemption' (PBE) option for their children, refusing some or all of the inoculations due, in many cases, to fears of vaccines and their perceived side effects.\n\n'I do have concerns about the rate of PBEs and the number of people not getting vaccinations -- it poses a risk to the individual and those around them,' said Holbrook. The side effects of refusing vaccination are themselves cause for concern, since the so-called 'herd immunity' theory holds that for a population at large to be resistant to wide-spread outbreaks of diseases like pertussis, at least 90 percent and preferably 95 percent or more should be immunized.\n\n'We are close to 90 percent overall, across Sonoma County,' said Dr. Holbrook. 'Do I want it to be better? Absolutely. But we also have pockets where it's not that. West County is an area where the proportion of kindergarteners that are up to date on all vaccines is lower. It's 67 percent in that area, but it varies by school between 23 percent and 91 percent.'\n\nPetaluma City Schools' elementary district overall had approximately 15 percent of parents sign PBE for the 2013-14 school year, for a vaccination rate around 85 percent, below the margin needed for herd immunity. While some schools boast 100 percent vaccination compliance, like St. Vincent de Paul Elementary, others have unusually low compliance. Only 35.7 percent of 7th graders at Live Oak Charter have received a Tdap immunization, a school where 2/3rds of parents have signed PBE.\n\nNumbers are only slightly better for the kindergarten immunization program, with vaccinations at Live Oak Charter under 44 percent and PBEs at 56 percent. Mary Collins Charter School has the next highest rate of PBEs among kindergarteners, at 25 percent. The figures cited are for the 2013-14 school year, according to the state's Shotsforschools.org website. Results for the current school year's [2014-15] immunization rates will not be available until October [2014] at the earliest, according to Petaluma public schools nurse Darian Chandler.\n\nBut she has reason to hope the numbers will improve this year [2014]. 'The law changed [1 Jan 2014], which no longer gives a parent the right to walk into school, register their child and sign an immunization waiver so their kid can start school,' she said, referring to AB 2109. 'Now they have to go to a medical provider with an appointment, sit down with the provider and go over the (risks of) lack of immunization in the hopes that the provider can convince the parent to start immunization.' That provider then must co-sign the PBE request to validate it.\n\nThe Tdap immunization now required for 7th-graders, and recommended for adults, was approved about 10 years ago as a replacement for the once-every-decade TD (tetanus-diphtheria) shots. 'Tdap' refers to tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis, the 'acellular' being a less potent form of immunization, but one with fewer side-effects.\n\nTdap shots are also recommended for pregnant women during their 3rd trimester with each pregnancy, as well as others who will be around newborns, such as parents and grandparents. This is because, Holbrook emphasizes, infants too young to be fully immunized are at highest risk for severe illness.\n\n'When we had grandchildren,' said Chandler, 'everyone in our family all went in and got a pertussis booster, even the great grandfather who was 90 years old.'\n\nThe recent PBS Nova program, 'Immunization -- Calling the Shots' that aired [10 Sep 2014] outlines the current issue and its historical context, not just for pertussis but measles, polio and other vaccine-preventable diseases as well. Chandler herself affirmed that of the people she has worked with in medicine, 'We all strongly support immunization because we've seen what happens. We've seen the infant that died of pertussis, and I've seen polio in the 50s and 60s.' She recalled caring for polio patients in iron lungs, and pointed out that polio has been all but wiped out in the US thanks to immunization.\n\nNow, she says, 'It shocks me when people do not immunize their children against polio.' And it's not just polio: 'In family practice pediatric care there are people that come in, they want the waiver signed, and there's no way to convince them that the immunizations are safe, much safer than they used to be. The risk of getting the disease outweighs any statistical risk of complications.'\n\nThe new requirement that parents consult with physicians about the risks of immunization should help increase immunization rates -- at least that's the purpose of AB 1209. But a law on its own cannot change people's behavior. Holbrook intends to focus on making this dialog productive in the near future by convening a task force to develop best practices for clinicians to work with vaccine-hesitant parents.\n\n'I don't want to vilify people choosing to exempt, I want to work with them,' said Holbrook. 'I want them to work with their providers to address their concerns and their fears. If it becomes an antagonistic relationship, then the listening shuts down.'\n\n[Byline: Christian Kallen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There were 6930 cases of pertussis in California reported statewide as of the 1st week in August (2014), according to a news report posted recently by ProMED-mail (Pertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140809.2675224). There are now almost 7980 cases in the state, 684 of them in Sonoma County, according to the news report above. Sonoma County has the highest incidence rate among the California counties, with over 137 cases per 100 000 persons. The overall incidence rate for the state is 20.9 per 100 000.\n\nPertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383.\n\nIn the US, DTaP, and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). DTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis. (Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D) and tetanus (T) toxoids and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case 'd' and 'p' denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The 'a' in DTaP and Tdap stands for 'acellular,' meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.) - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There were 6930 cases of pertussis in California reported statewide as of the 1st week in August (2014), according to a news report posted recently by ProMED-mail (Pertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140809.2675224). \n\nPetaluma City Schools' elementary district overall had approximately 15 percent of parents sign PBE for the 2013-14 school year, for a vaccination rate around 85 percent, below the margin needed for herd immunity. \n\nThe recent PBS Nova program, 'Immunization -- Calling the Shots' that aired [10 Sep 2014] outlines the current issue and its historical context, not just for pertussis but measles, polio and other vaccine-preventable diseases as well. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The side effects of refusing vaccination are themselves cause for concern, since the so-called 'herd immunity' theory holds that for a population at large to be resistant to wide-spread outbreaks of diseases like pertussis, at least 90 percent and preferably 95 percent or more should be immunized. The illness can turn deadly. It starts as a persistent cough and runny nose followed by weeks of rapid coughing fits. Pertussis is more common in the very young or very old, but if you're not protected, you're not immune.\n\n'Whooping cough is something that's prevented, and your child could die, your parent could die,' stated Dr Lila Schmidt.\n\nThe numbers are staggering -- record-breaking, in fact. There have been 1183 cases of pertussis or whooping cough in San Diego County so far this year [2014]. Last year, there was a total of 431 cases. Although the very contagious respiratory bacteria peaks every 3 to 4 years, this is shocking public health officials.\n\nSo what can you do to protect your family? Get vaccinated, says Dr Schmidt, especially if you're pregnant.\n\n'It's a series of 5 -- not just one and good to go. It's starts at a couple months old; by the time you are 5, you are finished with the series. Kids in the old days were okay, but now, a lot of parents opt out of vaccinations.'\n\nDr Schmidt says now is not the time to avoid having your child get shots as whooping coughs whip through the county. It's risk versus reward, she says. To prevent the spread of the bacteria, wash your hands with soap and hot water. Use hot towels to dry your hands, avoid hand sanitizers and those air-dry machines. If you are healthier, your chances of getting a disease -- even if you're exposed -- go down.\n\n'I would get vaccinated and do the basics mom taught you: wash your hands, get enough sleep, eat vegetables, drink water, and if someone is sick, stay away from them.'\n\nThey sound like simple reminders, but wash your hands before you eat, use your knuckle to call for the elevator, cough into your elbow. Just be smart so you don't get sick. If you have questions about getting immunized, go to http://sdiz.org.\n\n[Byline: Kristen Cusato]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of pertussis in San Diego County, California has increased by 288 cases since the last ProMED-mail report (Pertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332) less than 1 month ago.\n\nPertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. ML\n\nThe state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-08-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1183-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Diego", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2687562", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (17): (ID) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2687562", "date": "2014-08-13 18:38:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (17): (IDAHO), INCREASED INCIDENCE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Aug 2014\nSource: The Spokesman-Review [edited]\nhttp://www.spokesman.com/stories/2014/aug/13/in-brief-whooping-cough-nearly-doubles-in-idaho/\n\n\nNearly twice as many cases of whooping cough have been reported in Idaho so far this year [2014]. One infant has died from the highly contagious bacterial disease, also known as pertussis, the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare reported on Tuesday [12 Aug 2014].\n\nThrough July 2014, 241 cases were reported to public health officials, compared with 122 cases in the 1st 7 months of 2013. In the 5 North Idaho counties, 25 cases were reported through July 2014, compared to 24 last year [2013].\n\n'The best way to protect children and infants from pertussis is to get vaccinated so you are protected, and then you drastically reduce the risk of passing it on to extremely vulnerable infants,' said Mitch Scoggins, program manager for the Idaho Immunization Program.\n\nPertussis vaccines are available in many physicians' offices, local public health district offices and pharmacies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number: 20140424.2426383.\n\nIdaho is a state in the northwestern region of the United States (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho). A map of the US on which Idaho can be located is available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho#mediaviewer/File:Idaho_in_United_States.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number: 20140424.2426383. \n\nThrough July 2014, 241 cases were reported to public health officials, compared with 122 cases in the 1st 7 months of 2013. \n\n'The best way to protect children and infants from pertussis is to get vaccinated so you are protected, and then you drastically reduce the risk of passing it on to extremely vulnerable infants,' said Mitch Scoggins, program manager for the Idaho Immunization Program.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2675224", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2675224", "date": "2014-08-09 21:59:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (16): (CALIFORNIA), INCREASED INCIDENCE, UPDATE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Aug 2014\nSource: KPCC [edited]\nhttp://www.scpr.org/news/2014/08/08/45883/whooping-cough-number-of-new-cases-remains-high-in/\n\n\nThe California Department of Public Health is reporting 760 new cases of whooping cough for the 2-week period ending 4 Aug 2014.\n\nMore than 2/3rds of the new infections occurred in kids ages 7 to 16. But, health officials say, they're most concerned about infants who are too young to be vaccinated against the highly-contagious respiratory disease that's also known as 'pertussis.' More than 60 percent of those hospitalized with whooping cough in 2014 have been infants younger than 4 months of age.\n\nOfficials are urging women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy to get vaccinated, which then allows them to pass their immunity on to their newborns.\n\nParents are reminded to make sure their kids who are heading back to class get vaccinated, as whooping cough outbreaks have been reported at schools throughout California.\n\nStatewide, 6930 cases of whooping cough have been reported so far this year [2014].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There were over 5400 cases of pertussis in California in 2014 as of the last ProMED-mail update (ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332), compared to a total of 2372 cases in all of 2013. There are now 6930 cases reported statewide according to the news report above.\n\nPertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number: 20140424.2426383. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There were over 5400 cases of pertussis in California in 2014 as of the last ProMED-mail update (ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332), compared to a total of 2372 cases in all of 2013. PERTUSSIS - USA (16): (CALIFORNIA), INCREASED INCIDENCE, UPDATE\n***************************************************************\n \n\nParents are reminded to make sure their kids who are heading back to class get vaccinated, as whooping cough outbreaks have been reported at schools throughout California. The California Department of Public Health is reporting 760 new cases of whooping cough for the 2-week period ending 4 Aug 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2372-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "6930-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2670068", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (15): (MI) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2670068", "date": "2014-08-08 09:06:37", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (15): (MICHIGAN) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2014\nSource: WNDU.com, Michigan Department of Community Health report [edited]\nhttp://www.wndu.com/home/headlines/With-whooping-cough-cases-up-Michigan-urges-vaccinations-270172781.html\n\n\nAs Michigan continues to see new pertussis cases this year [2014], the Michigan Department of Community Health (MDCH) is reminding residents during National Immunization Awareness Month of the importance of being up to date on all vaccinations including pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nThrough the end of July [2014], Michigan has seen 546 cases, about 45 percent more than in the same period of 2013. Several other states, including Ohio, California, and Florida, are reporting similar increases.\n\n'Children are routinely recommended to receive a series of pertussis vaccine doses in infancy and early childhood,' said Dr Matthew Davis, chief medical executive of MDCH. 'Adolescents and adults should receive a booster dose of the vaccine. In addition, pregnant women should get a booster in the 3rd trimester of each pregnancy to help protect newborns, who are most vulnerable to the illness in the 1st few months of life.'\n\nPertussis is a respiratory infection caused by a bacterium that results in a prolonged illness. Severe coughing episodes are often accompanied by vomiting and difficulty breathing. In some cases, a characteristic 'whooping' noise is heard as the afflicted person tries to catch their breath.\n\nOnce extremely common, vaccines developed in the US starting in the mid-1940s and helped drive down the occurrence of pertussis. But in recent decades, pertussis has been making a comeback.\n\n'Part of the challenge,' Davis explained, 'is that immunity to pertussis wears off, so getting a booster vaccine dose later in life can help extend the protection. Our primary focus is on preventing the disease in babies -- they have smaller airways and less developed respiratory systems, which puts them at higher risk for severe cases as well as hospitalization and death from pertussis.'\n\nBabies get a 1st dose of the vaccine at 2 months of age, but they are not optimally protected until completing the series of several more doses over the next year and half. MDCH strongly recommends that adults or adolescents who will be around infants receive the recommended pertussis booster vaccine dose, and that all residents receive their vaccines on time.\n\nIf you are uncertain about whether you or your children have had all recommended vaccines and doses, speak with your doctor or contact your local health department. For more information about pertussis, or any recommended or required vaccine, visit http://www.michigan.gov/immunize.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383. 'We have the largest population, and control of the disease is being done. We recorded the notifications, which is not always done in other cities. A house to house check will be made by the healthcare teams to visit the homes in both rural and urban areas to assess the current vaccination status of children. Children who are not up to date will receive pertussis vaccination at the time of the visit.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It appears that more of the suspected cases are in children with inadequate immunization. In the USA, most analyses have found in the rising number of cases of pertussis that only 10-15 percent of the total are not immunized. Although not a great number of the total, their risk of acquiring pertussis is higher than those with presumed waning immunity.\n\nPernambuco is a state of Brazil, located in the Northeast region of the country. The state of Pernambuco also includes the archipelago Fernando de Noronha. To the north are the states of Paraiba and Ceara; to the west is Piaui; to the south are Alagoas and Bahia, and to the east is the Atlantic Ocean. A map of Brazil showing the state's location can be found at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pernambuco. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Children who are not up to date will receive pertussis vaccination at the time of the visit.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n< Through July 2014, the Secretariat of Health of Petrolina, in the inland area of Pernambuco, identified 46 suspected cases of pertussis, almost twice the number as last year (2013), in which the municipality recorded 25 cases. PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL (03): (PERNAMBUCO)\n*************************************\n In the USA, most analyses have found in the rising number of cases of pertussis that only 10-15 percent of the total are not immunized. A house to house check will be made by the healthcare teams to visit the homes in both rural and urban areas to assess the current vaccination status of children.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Petrolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alagoas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2623332", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2623332", "date": "2014-07-20 21:01:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA), INCREASED INCIDENCE, UPDATE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 19 Jul 2014\nSource: Insurance News Net [edited]\n<insurancenewsnet.com/oarticle/2014/07/19/pertussis-cases-reach-nearly-900-a-532417.html#.U8vDlahfn8B>\n\n\nPertussis (whooping cough) cases in San Diego County number nearly 900 for the year [2014], according to the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency; 9 new cases of the disease were confirmed this week in which the public may have been exposed. The locations are listed below.\n\n'The county and the state are experiencing an epidemic of pertussis,' said Wilma J. Wooten, M.D., M.P.H., County public health officer. 'Infants are at greatest risk for severe illness and death from pertussis, so we are urging parents to vaccinate their children and pregnant women to be vaccinated to protect their babies.'\n\nThere have been 895 confirmed cases of pertussis in 2014. There were only 120 cases reported at this same time last year [2013] and a total of 431 in [all of] 2013. Pertussis activity hit a record high in 2010 with 1179 cases.\n\nA typical case of pertussis starts with a cough and runny nose for one to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits that sometimes end with a whooping sound (http://www.whoopingcough.net/sound%20of%20whooping%20cough%20with%20much%20whooping.htm). Fever, if present, is usually mild. Antibiotics can lessen the severity of symptoms and prevent the spread of disease to others.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the following vaccination schedule: Young children need 5 doses of DTaP by kindergarten: at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months and 4 to 6 years; All students entering 7th grade need proof of a whooping cough booster immunization (Tdap). A Tdap booster is recommended for pregnant women during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got a booster before becoming pregnant. One dose of Tdap is recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent.\n\nParents can obtain the DTaP vaccine series and the Tdap booster shot for themselves and their children through their primary care physicians. Local retail pharmacies offer vaccinations for a fee, and anyone who is not covered by a medical insurance plan can get the shot from a County Public Health Center at minimal or no cost (http://www.sdcounty.ca.gov/hhsa/programs/phs/immunization_branch/immunizations_free_for_children_under_age_two.html).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 19 Jul 2014\nSource: Daily Democrat [edited]\n<ww.dailydemocrat.com/breakingnews/ci_26180864/number-yolo-county-whooping-cough-cases-doubled-past>\n\n\nIn the midst of a state-wide whooping cough epidemic, the number of Yolo County cases jumped from 37 to 80 in the past month. [Yolo County is a relatively rural agricultural region located in the Sacramento Valley immediately east of Napa County and is included in the Sacramento-Roseville-Arden-Arcade, CA Metropolitan Statistical Area (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yolo_County,_California#Adjacent_counties).]\n\n'We have already seen over 5400 cases of pertussis in California this year [2014] as compared to a total of 2372 cases in all of 2013,' said Constance Caldwell, Yolo County health officer. 'In Yolo County, we have seen nearly 80 cases so far in 2014, compared to 4 cases in all of 2013.' These cases represent ages from 6 weeks to 60 years old.\n\nHealth officials continue to be alarmed that the number of cases has soared since 1 Jan [2014], with the traditional peak month of July [2014]. As of 11 Jul 2014, the number of cases is now at 5393, more than double the 2532 reported for all of 2013, according to the state's Department of Public Health. As of 10 Jun 2014, there had been only 3458 reported cases, for an increase of 1935 in the past month.\n\nWhooping cough, or pertussis, is a bacterial illness which causes severe coughing fits that can last for weeks, according to Caldwell. It is spread easily by coughing on others and is most dangerous in young infants who can become severely ill very quickly and even die from it.\n\nPertussis is cyclical and peaks every 3 to 5 years. The last peak in California occurred in 2010, so it is likely another peak is underway, according to the California Department of Public Health.\n\nAlthough Yolo County cases shot up to 80 in the past month, Marin, Napa and Sonoma counties [counties just north of the city of San Francisco] have the highest whooping cough rates in the state, with 168, 124, and 589 cases, respectively.\n\n'The symptoms of pertussis vary by age,' Caldwell said. 'For children, a typical case of pertussis starts with a cough and runny nose for one to 2 weeks. The cough then worsens, and children may have rapid coughing spells that end with a whooping sound.'\n\nOverall whooping cough rates are highest for babies under one year old, followed by adolescents and teens from 10 to 17 years old, with the peak age at 15 years old, according to the California Department of Public Health.\n\n'Young infants may not have typical pertussis symptoms and may have no apparent cough,' Caldwell noted. 'Parents may describe episodes in which the infant's face turns red or purple.' For adults, pertussis may simply be a cough that persists for several weeks.\n\n'Prevention of the illness with the vaccine is the best course of action,' she said. 'However, immunity from pertussis is not life-long.'\n\nInfants too young to be fully immunized remain most vulnerable to severe and fatal cases of pertussis. Two infant deaths have been reported and 2/3rds of pertussis hospitalizations have been in children 4 months or younger. One of the deaths was a 2-month-old infant who was 5 weeks old at time of disease onset.\n\nThe Tdap vaccination for pregnant women is the best way to protect infants who are too young to be vaccinated. All pregnant women should be vaccinated with Tdap in the 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, regardless of previous Tdap vaccination. Pertussis antibodies are transferred from vaccinated mothers to their infants and will help protect them until they are old enough to be vaccinated. In addition, infants should be vaccinated as soon as possible. The 1st dose of pertussis vaccine can be given as early as 6 weeks of age.\n\n'Students entering 7th grade also receive a booster dose, as should health care workers and others working with infants and young children,' Caldwell said.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Dowling]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number: 20140424.2426383. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Source: Insurance News Net [edited]\n<insurancenewsnet.com/oarticle/2014/07/19/pertussis-cases-reach-nearly-900-a-532417.html#.U8vDlahfn8B>\n\n\nPertussis (whooping cough) cases in San Diego County number nearly 900 for the year [2014], according to the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency; 9 new cases of the disease were confirmed this week in which the public may have been exposed. According to data of the State Secretariat of Health, Sesab, between January and May 2014, 159 cases were reported, an increase of 25 percent from same period of 2013, when 127 cases were reported. A total of 300 cases were reported for the whole of 2013.\n\nThe municipality of Feira de Santana is the most affected. According to the WHO, pertussis is the 5th most common cause of death in children under 5 years of age of the diseases preventable by vaccines.\n\nIn 2013, there were confirmed cases in all age groups, but those less than one year old continued to be the most affected, Jacy Andrade, medical infectious disease specialist and director of the Specialized Service in Immunization and Infectious Diseases (SEMI), stated. She alerted adolescents and adults, who have been registering an increase in incidence, that they are transmitters of the bacterium to the small-children group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, 'cocooning' of the susceptible neonate has included immunization of close family contacts as well as the pregnant female. Almost all the significant morbidity and mortality of infection with _Bordetella pertussis_ occurs in infants less than 6 months of age.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea sometimes with hypoxia-induced seizures, usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000, and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000, and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. According to data of the State Secretariat of Health, Sesab, between January and May 2014, 159 cases were reported, an increase of 25 percent from same period of 2013, when 127 cases were reported. In 2013, there were confirmed cases in all age groups, but those less than one year old continued to be the most affected, Jacy Andrade, medical infectious disease specialist and director of the Specialized Service in Immunization and Infectious Diseases (SEMI), stated. According to the WHO, pertussis is the 5th most common cause of death in children under 5 years of age of the diseases preventable by vaccines. Almost all the significant morbidity and mortality of infection with _Bordetella pertussis_ occurs in infants less than 6 months of age. PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL (02): (BAHIA)\n \n\n--\n http://www.tribunadabahia.com.br/2014/06/28/coqueluche-cresce-25-na-bahia\n\n\nPertussis, a disease that can lead to death especially among newborns, is more frequent in Bahia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, 'cocooning' of the susceptible neonate has included immunization of close family contacts as well as the pregnant female. Symptoms can be substantially different, with periods of apnea sometimes with hypoxia-induced seizures, usually the most common manifestation of infection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2572898", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (12): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2572898", "date": "2014-06-29 14:19:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (12): (CALIFORNIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 Jun 2014\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-california-pertussis-epidemic-20140627-story.html\n\n\nCalifornia's pertussis epidemic has escalated, state health officials said Friday [27 Jun 2014], with 4558 cases reported in 2014 as of Tuesday, 24 Jun 2014, 1100 of those in the last 2 weeks. 'We are off to a really bad start in 2014,' said state epidemiologist Gil Chavez, of the California Department of Public Health, during a phone call with reporters on Friday.\n\nChavez delivered his comments as the state health department released a new report summarizing the latest data on this year's [2014] pertussis, or whooping cough, epidemic. Of this year's cases thus far, 3614, or 84 percent, have occurred in patients 18 or younger. Out of 142 illnesses that required hospitalization, 89, or 63 percent, were in infants 4 months old or younger.\n\nA total of 3 babies in the state have died from pertussis infections in 2014, Chavez said, though 2 of those will be attributed to 2013's case count because they initially became ill in 2013.\n\nBecause infants less than a year old are at the highest risk of hospitalization and death from pertussis, and because babies generally do not receive pertussis vaccinations until they're 8 weeks old, Chavez said that all pregnant women should receive a dose of the Tdap vaccine during their 3rd trimester.\n\n'Vaccination of pregnant women is the most important thing that can be done to protect infants,' he said, because the mothers' antibodies can get passed along to their newborns.\n\nBased on historical patterns, Chavez said, it is likely that disease activity will remain high throughout the summer. But he said it was too soon to know if this year [2014] would be worse than 2010, the last year pertussis peaked. That year, more than 9000 Californians were sickened with the disease.\n\n[Byline: Eryn Brown]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of pertussis over time tends to have upswing cycles every 3-5 years, but the case increases have been greater and more prolonged in the past several years. Utah is just one of a number of USA states including Washington and Wisconsin that have had substantial increase in the disease with, in addition, infant deaths related to cases transmitted by family members. Most up-to-date ACIP recommendations continue to increase vaccination recommendations to order to 'cocoon' the susceptible infant cohort. The most recent recommendations include re-vaccination for pregnant women in the 2nd or 3rd trimester for each pregnancy (1).\n\nIn addition to the Tartof paper (2), an additional recent publication, currently in press in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilizes a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences:\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013;62 (Suppl): 1-19.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis MKenyon C, etal: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013, doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al. Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013;56:1248-54.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. \n\nBecause infants less than a year old are at the highest risk of hospitalization and death from pertussis, and because babies generally do not receive pertussis vaccinations until they're 8 weeks old, Chavez said that all pregnant women should receive a dose of the Tdap vaccine during their 3rd trimester. In addition to the Tartof paper (2), an additional recent publication, currently in press in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilizes a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. The incidence rate is currently at 4.93 per 100 000 inhabitants, and the mortality rate at 9.6 percent.\n\nThe numbers are of concern to the Secretary of Health (SES). During all of 2013, 161 suspected cases of pertussis were reported in the city, 50 of them confirmed, and 2 deaths. The incidence rate was 7.95 per 100 000 inhabitants and the mortality rate was 4.0.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Brazil can be seen at http://www.zonu.com/brazil_maps/Brazil_States_Map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9502. Whooping cough, the common name for pertussis, is highly contagious. Those infected experience uncontrollable violent coughing that can make it hard to breathe.\n\nLocal media reports say the Mobile County Health Department has recorded 18 cases, 10 of which have been confirmed, between 25 May 2014 and 11 Jun 2014. Multiple other possible cases were being investigated. There were just 8 confirmed and probable cases in the county in 2013.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Alabama can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8322. Mobile County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/alabama-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] California (statewide)\nDate: Fri 13 Jun 2014\nSource: CBS Sacramento, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://sacramento.cbslocal.com/2014/06/13/california-reports-whooping-cough-epidemic-more-than-800-cases-over-past-2-weeks/\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in California is now at an epidemic level, state health officials said Fri 13 Jun 2014. More than 800 whooping cough cases were reported over the past 2 weeks, suggesting that the infection, which is also known as pertussis, is spreading rapidly, according to a statement by the California Department of Public Health.\n\nAs of 10 Jun 2014, there were 3458 reported cases -- more than in all of 2013. There have been 2 reported infant deaths.\n\nThe infection is cyclical and peaks every 3 to 5 years, officials said. The previous whooping cough peak was in 2010, when an epidemic struck 9159 people and killed 10 infants in the state. Infants are most susceptible to the disease so parents are encouraged to vaccinate their children as early as possible. Pregnant women are also encouraged to get vaccinated.\n\nThe disease has also raised national concerns. Although California is the only state to declare an epidemic, there has been a 24 percent increase of reported pertussis cases nationally from this time in 2013, according to the CDC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Ohio (Logan County)\nDate: Fri 6 Jun 2014\nSource: Springfield (OH) News-Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.limaohio.com/news/news/1407377/Bellefontaine-schools-see-pertussis-outbreak\n\n\nThe outbreak of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, started in April 2014 with 2 confirmed cases involving Bellefontaine Elementary School students. During May 2014, the district's number of confirmed pertussis cases jumped to 10. 'At first, they were in one part of Bellefontaine City Schools, and now it has spread to different grades,' Hoddinott said.\n\nThe school system sent out a letter and texts to parents alerting them about the outbreak. Hoddinott said it is not unusual for Bellefontaine to see 10 confirmed cases in a year, but the concern came because they were all so closely related. 'There are probably more cases that have not been diagnosed, but those (10 confirmed cases) are the ones who are sickest and have gone through a doctor and were tested,' he said.\n\nPhone calls to Champaign Health District officials for an update were not returned.\n\n[Byline: Brian Bondus]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12896. Logan County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/ohio-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\n[Issues remain regarding the efficacy of protection of the acellular vaccine. A manuscript in PNAS evaluated this in a nonhuman model: Warfel JM, Zimmerman LI, Merkel TJ: Acellular pertussis vaccines protect against disease but fail to prevent infection and transmission in a nonhuman primate model. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2013; 111(2): 787-92.\n\n'Significance\n-------------\nPertussis has reemerged as an important public health concern since current acellular pertussis vaccines (aP) replaced older whole-cell vaccines (wP). In this study, we show nonhuman primates vaccinated with aP were protected from severe symptoms but not infection and readily transmitted _Bordetella pertussis_ to contacts. Vaccination with wP and previous infection induced a more rapid clearance compared with naive and aP-vaccinated animals. While all groups possessed robust antibody responses, key differences in T-cell memory suggest that aP vaccination induces a suboptimal immune response that is unable to prevent infection. These data provide a plausible explanation for pertussis resurgence and suggest that attaining herd immunity will require the development of improved vaccination strategies that prevent _B. pertussis_ colonization and transmission.\n\nAbstract\n--------\nPertussis is a highly contagious respiratory illness caused by the bacterial pathogen _Bordetella pertussis_. Pertussis rates in the United States have been rising and reached a 50-year high of 42 000 cases in 2012. Although pertussis resurgence is not completely understood, we hypothesize that current acellular pertussis (aP) vaccines fail to prevent colonization and transmission. To test our hypothesis, infant baboons were vaccinated at 2, 4, and 6 months of age with aP or whole-cell pertussis (wP) vaccines and challenged with _B. pertussis_ at 7 months. Infection was followed by quantifying colonization in nasopharyngeal washes and monitoring leukocytosis and symptoms. Baboons vaccinated with aP were protected from severe pertussis-associated symptoms but not from colonization, did not clear the infection faster than naive animals, and readily transmitted _B. pertussis_ to unvaccinated contacts. Vaccination with wP induced a more rapid clearance compared with naive and aP-vaccinated animals. By comparison, previously infected animals were not colonized upon secondary infection. Although all vaccinated and previously infected animals had robust serum antibody responses, we found key differences in T-cell immunity. Previously infected animals and wP-vaccinated animals possess strong _B. pertussis_- specific T helper 17 (Th17) memory and Th1 memory, whereas aP vaccination induced a Th1/Th2 response instead. The observation that aP, which induces an immune response mismatched to that induced by natural infection, fails to prevent colonization or transmission provides a plausible explanation for the resurgence of pertussis and suggests that optimal control of pertussis will require the development of improved vaccines.'\n\nMore evidence continues to accumulate regarding issues revolving around the protective efficacy of the current acellular pertussis vaccines and the need for an improvement in the current product. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Alabama can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8322. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. \nPertussis has reemerged as an important public health concern since current acellular pertussis vaccines (aP) replaced older whole-cell vaccines (wP). The observation that aP, which induces an immune response mismatched to that induced by natural infection, fails to prevent colonization or transmission provides a plausible explanation for the resurgence of pertussis and suggests that optimal control of pertussis will require the development of improved vaccines.' Baboons vaccinated with aP were protected from severe pertussis-associated symptoms but not from colonization, did not clear the infection faster than naive animals, and readily transmitted _B. pertussis_ to unvaccinated contacts. \nPertussis is a highly contagious respiratory illness caused by the bacterial pathogen _Bordetella pertussis_. Source: Hattiesburg American, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.hattiesburgamerican.com/story/news/local/2014/06/13/whooping-cough-cases/10378765/\n\n\nHealth officials in Mobile say there's been an alarming recent rise in the number of whooping cough cases in the area. To test our hypothesis, infant baboons were vaccinated at 2, 4, and 6 months of age with aP or whole-cell pertussis (wP) vaccines and challenged with _B. pertussis_ at 7 months. These data provide a plausible explanation for pertussis resurgence and suggest that attaining herd immunity will require the development of improved vaccination strategies that prevent _B. pertussis_ colonization and transmission. More than 800 whooping cough cases were reported over the past 2 weeks, suggesting that the infection, which is also known as pertussis, is spreading rapidly, according to a statement by the California Department of Public Health. Although pertussis resurgence is not completely understood, we hypothesize that current acellular pertussis (aP) vaccines fail to prevent colonization and transmission.
