Previously infected animals and wP-vaccinated animals possess strong _B. pertussis_- specific T helper 17 (Th17) memory and Th1 memory, whereas aP vaccination induced a Th1/Th2 response instead. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12896.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-04-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-10 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Logan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mobile County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mobile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Springfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "wp", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bellefontaine City Schools", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PNAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "wP", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2559418", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (11)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2559418", "date": "2014-06-25 19:14:20", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Alabama (Mobile County)\n[2] Idaho\n[3] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\n[4] California (El Dorado County)\n[5] California (Napa County)\n[6] Texas (Tarrent County)\n[7] Virginia (Eastern Shore)\n\n******\n[1] Alabama (Mobile County)\nDate: Fri 20 Jun 2014\nSource: Al.com [edited]\nhttp://www.al.com/news/mobile/index.ssf/2014/06/whooping_cough_outbreak_not_sl.html\n\n\nSince alerting the public last week to a dramatic rise in the number of pertussis cases in the area, the Mobile County Health Department has reported more cases related to the outbreak according to media coordinator Casandra Andrews. Known as whooping cough, pertussis is a highly contagious respiratory disease marked by uncontrollable, violent coughing which often makes it hard to breathe.\n\nBetween 30 Apr 2014 and 20 Jun 2014, Mobile County recorded approximately 25 pertussis cases. In 2013, just 8 confirmed and probable cases were reported in Mobile County. Of the 25 cases reported so far in the most recent outbreak, 15 have been confirmed, health officials said. There are multiple ongoing investigations of other pertussis cases not included in the 25 reported so far, health officials said. There have been a total of 29 cases reported for all of 2014 in Mobile County.\n\nDr Paola Maurtua-Neumann, a pediatrician with the University of South Alabama Children's Medical Center, has diagnosed a majority of the cases so far. She urges residents to be aware of the disease and its consequences. Once a pertussis case has been confirmed, she said, all family members residing with the infected person should receive treatment with antibiotics regardless of previous immunizations.\n\n[Byline: Cassie Fambro]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Alabama can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8322. Mobile County in southwestern Alabama can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/alabama-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Idaho\nDate: Tue 17 Jun 2014\nSource: KBOI [edited]\nhttp://www.kboi2.com/news/local/Whooping-cough-pertussis-health-coughing-infants-babies-263562921.html\n\n\nIdaho is seeing a surge in the number of whooping cough cases reported in 2014. In 2013, the Gem State had 87 reported cases, and in 2012, we saw 76. But so far, we've seen 179 reports in 2014 and it's only June.\n\nThe Idaho Department of Health and Welfare says a large part of the problem could be that many people aren't staying up to date on their Tdap [combined tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccination. It's a shot most people get as a child, but booster shots are required to keep the vaccine active. When enough older children and adults neglect to get their boosters, whooping cough can begin spreading.\n\nNearly 1/3 of 2014's infections have been in newborns who are too young to get the vaccination and have a harder time fighting off the cough. 'Babies under 6 months, very often they're hospitalized,' said Sarah Correll, an epidemiologist at Central District Health Department in Boise. 'And when they're less than 4 months they definitely can die, so it is important that everyone in the home stay up to date on their vaccines and they protect the baby while it's trying to build up its immunity.'\n\nAccording to Health and Welfare, there has been one death due to whooping cough in Idaho in 2014, and it was a baby.\n\n[Byline: Jacqulyn Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Idaho can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\nDate: Wed 18 Jun 2014\nSource: Pittsburgh Tribune-Review [edited]\nhttp://triblive.com/news/healthnews/6300738-74/pertussis-cases-vaccine#axzz35T0GHSER\n\n\nAt least 50 people in Allegheny County have come down with whooping cough in 2014, putting the region on pace for one of its worst bouts in a decade with the respiratory disease. Most of the reported cases involve school-age children, all of whom recovered, according to county health officials. North Allegheny in McCandless was the most recent school district to confirm cases, announcing in June 2014 that 2 high school students contracted the bacterial ailment that doctors call pertussis.\n\n'It's probably going to be on the high side this year. Usually, we get 50 or less' cases, said Dr Kristen Mertz, a medical epidemiologist at the Allegheny County Health Department. Although the department hasn't listed any pertussis-linked deaths in 2014, the disease is blamed in at least 2 fatalities in California, where an epidemic led to more than 3450 cases since January 2014. Reported cases nationwide topped 24 000 in 2013, about half the tally from 2012 but up from 11 651 in 2003, according to the CDC.\n\nThe illnesses in 2012 marked one of the largest pertussis epidemics since the 1950s and could foreshadow worse outbreaks, said Dr Wilbert van Panhuis, an assistant professor of epidemiology at the University of Pittsburgh. 'It was almost as bad as it was before the vaccine was introduced,' said van Panhuis. Early pertussis shots went mainstream starting in the late 1940s.\n\n'You're seeing adults and teenagers getting pertussis because their vaccinations are not working well,' van Panhuis said. He said that trend, paired with some people's reluctance over vaccinations, might lead to more epidemics until pharmaceutical manufacturers introduce another pertussis vaccine. Preliminary state health data last month suggested as many as 177 confirmed pertussis cases in Pennsylvania since January 2014. The state recorded 633 cases in 2013, down from 1934 in 2012. Doctors said cyclical peaks in case volumes typically develop every 3 to 5 years.\n\nThe CDC is investigating the waning effectiveness of the current pertussis inoculation, given as part of so-called DTap [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine for children 2 months through 6 years of age] and Tdap vaccines. 'The message isn't that the vaccine is no good. It's still good. It's still effective,' Dr. Mertz said. 'Most kids are not getting the disease.'\n\n[Byline: Adam Smeltz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Pennsylvania can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3520. Allegheny County in southwestern Pennsylvania can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/pennsylvania-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California (El Dorado County)\nDate: Fri 20 Jun 2014\nSource: Tahoe Daily Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.tahoedailytribune.com/southshore/11895648-113/cases-pertussis-county-health\n\n\nHealth officials in El Dorado County and across California are seeing an uptick in pertussis cases and emphasizing the importance for children and adults to remain up to date on immunizations. 10 cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, have been reported in El Dorado County in 2014. That's more than twice the number of cases reported in 2013, County Health Officer Dr Alicia Paris-Pombo said.\n\n6 cases were reported in South Lake Tahoe and 4 cases were reported on the West Slope. None have been fatal.\n\nThe cyclical disease typically peaks every 3 to 5 years and the last peak occurred in 2010, when El Dorado County had 54 cases and California had more than 9400 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. A California county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] California (Napa County)\nDate: Fri 20 Jun 2014\nSource: Napa Valley Register [edited]\nhttp://napavalleyregister.com/news/local/st-helena-hospital-limits-visits-due-to-pertussis-spike/article_8f550f4a-b0d9-5c2c-a883-e6f786ed9f30.html\n\n\nSt Helena Hospital is curbing visits to its maternity section due to California's declaration of a whooping cough epidemic, the medical center announced Fri 20 Jun 2014. No visitors with coughing, runny nose, fever, or similar symptoms will be admitted to the family birthing center, according to Karen Phillips, infection prevention specialist at the hospital. In addition, children under 18 -- including siblings of newborns -- can enter only with proof of immunization for the bacterial disease, also called pertussis.\n\nThe restrictions at St Helena Hospital were issued following similar visiting curbs issued Tue 17 Jun 2014, at Queen of the Valley Medical Center in Napa.\n\nSince 1 Jan 2014, confirmed and suspected cases of pertussis in Napa County already are up 7-fold, to 91, from the number reported for all of 2013. Whooping cough reports in California have totaled more than 3400 in 2014, the most in 4 years, with 2 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6] Texas (Tarrant County)\nDate: Tue 17 Jun 2014\nSource: NBC DFW [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Pertussis-Cases-on-Track-to-Reach-Record-in-Tarrant-County-263385031.html\n\n\nAfter setting a record in 2013, officials with the Tarrant County Health Department are concerned the number of recorded pertussis cases could again set a record in 2014. Whooping cough, known to physicians as pertussis, has seen a resurgence in recent years.\n\nAs of 16 Jun 2014, there have been 174 reported cases of whooping cough in Tarrant County, roughly the same number of cases recorded by this time in 2013. Health officials believe that the number of cases could get higher once current possible cases are vetted.\n\nTarrant County is not the only region with a high number of whooping cough cases. The highly infectious bacterial disease, which can be spread by coughing, has reached epidemic levels in California, according to the California Health Department A record 700 cases were reported in 2013 in Tarrant County -- many of them were reported in infants.\n\n[Byline: Bianca Castro]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1259. 'We had the 1st case -- that was in an infant -- and it quickly swelled to 10, and now we have 15 active investigations,' said Dr David O Matson, director of the health district.\n\nIn comparison, only 3 cases of pertussis were diagnosed on the Eastern Shore in 2012 and one case was identified in 2013. Those recently diagnosed with pertussis on the Eastern Shore live from near the Maryland line in Accomack County to Cape Charles in Northampton County and range in age from 1 month to 50s, with the majority being infants. At least two have been hospitalized. There have been no deaths.\n\n[Byline: Carol Vaughn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Virginia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/247. ' Date: Fri 20 Jun 2014\n \n\n'You're seeing adults and teenagers getting pertussis because their vaccinations are not working well,' van Panhuis said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1976-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-17 00:00:00", "1934-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:50", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-20 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-01 00:00:00", "2014-06-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/247", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Accomack County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Napa County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mobile County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarrent County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarrant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allegheny County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McCandless", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Health District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northampton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Charles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Dorado County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2499851", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (08): (SD,CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2499851", "date": "2014-05-27 18:16:32", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (SOUTH DAKOTA, CALIFORNIA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] South Dakota\n[2] California (Sacramento County), nosocomial spread\n\n******\n[1] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 23 May 2014\nSource: Black Hills Pioneer [edited]\nhttp://www.bhpioneer.com/local_news/article_eac415a6-e290-11e3-9878-001a4bcf887a.html\n\n\nA 'disproportionate number of cases' of pertussis, or whooping cough, in the Black Hills has led officials at a Spearfish medical clinic to stop seeing children for routine well-baby visits.\n\nDr Angela Anderson, a pediatrician at Spearfish Regional Medical Clinic, said the clinic's staff have diagnosed 10 cases in the past 2 weeks through diagnostic culture and those numbers are expected to rise. 'We have been so inundated (with patients showing symptoms) we have cancelled routine well-baby visits,' she said. That reason is 2-fold -- to be able to care for those affected and to keep healthy children from being exposed from pertussis.\n\n'We have reorganized our clinic space and staff to handle the influx of patients,' she said. 'It has been this way for several weeks but increased in severity recently.' A diagnostic culture takes 10 days to 2 weeks to receive results. The results go to the state for confirmation. A quicker test, the respiratory DFA [direct fluorescent antibody] test, is done in 2 to 3 days. 'Many of the preliminary results are positive for pertussis. Cultures are pending on those,' she said.\n\nAnderson said patients who have been exposed and are showing symptoms are being tested and treated. Those who had had been exposed but are not yet showing symptoms are being tested and also treated due to the outbreak. 'In all cases, we evaluate the vaccine status for the patient and family members and vaccinate if indicated,' she said. 'Treatment is antibiotics. You have to be on antibiotics for 5 days before you aren't considered contagious.'\n\nThe increased number of cases in Spearfish prompted one childcare facility to close its doors until 2 Jun 2014. The board of directors at Children First, in Spearfish, held an emergency meeting where they voted to shut down for the rest of the school year.\n\nEarlier in May 2014, the South Dakota Department of Health released information stating that 23 children had tested positive for the disease. On Wed 21 May 2014, they released data showing 6 more positive cases throughout the state. This is the number confirmed after the local clinics and hospitals sent the positive test results.\n\n'For this time of year to have essentially 30 cases, that's not good for us,' said Dr Lon Kightlinger, South Dakota state epidemiologist. 'We're taking the opportunity to warn people that pertussis is circulating, especially in some of the Black Hills communities.'\n\nIn 2013 there were 66 cases reported statewide and 71 cases the year before. In 2010 and 2011 there were 32 and 37 cases reported in the state respectively. More cases are suspected this year [2014] but have yet to be confirmed by a lab diagnosis.\n\n[Byline: Mark Watson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] California (Sacramento County), nosocomial spread\nDate: Fri 23 May 2014\nSource: News10 [edited]\nhttp://www.news10.net/story/news/local/south-sacramento/2014/05/24/toddler-contracted-whooping-cough-at-hospital-mom-says/9531047/\n\n\nIt was just a normal trip to the hospital. The mother said her 18-month-old daughter had come down with a mild virus, so she took her to Kaiser Permanente in south Sacramento in mid-to-late April 2014. But, when the child got sicker and sicker, they went back to Kaiser on 12 May 2014. The toddler was coughing uncontrollably and sometimes had difficulty breathing. 'I took her there to get better not to get worse,' the mother said.\n\nTest results after that visit showed the child had pertussis, also known as whooping cough. 'It really scared me. I was at work when I found out,' the mother said. 'I broke down crying. It terrified me to death.' Then the mother discovered an employee at the hospital went to work with pertussis in April 2014 at the same time her daughter was there. She said she believes her little girl contracted the potentially deadly disease at the hospital.\n\nKaiser Permanente South Sacramento's Chief of Infectious Disease Dr John Belko released the following statement:\n'Regarding recent media reports about the ongoing pertussis outbreak in Sacramento County, Kaiser Permanente South Sacramento did recently confirm that an employee, who was vaccinated against the disease, tested positive for pertussis. The employee left work as soon as symptoms appeared and was diagnosed.\n\n'As a precaution Kaiser Permanente is contacting members and employees who may have been exposed to the employee as much as 3 weeks prior to the diagnosis because those infected with pertussis can carry the disease for some time before symptoms appear. Out of an abundance of caution, we are contacting members who may have been exposed between 22 Apr 2014 and 6 May 2014.\n\nAs of last week [week of 12 May 2014], the Sacramento County Health Department had 69 confirmed cases of whooping cough. In 2013, there were just 59 cases.\n\n[Byline: Thom Jensen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sacramento County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nNosocomial spread of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection probably occurs more commonly than is recognized and can be minimized but not eliminated by up-to-date immunization with Tdap [combined tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccines] of health care workers.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious respiratory infection, particularly in the household setting. Indeed, direct inoculation with as few as 140 organisms can cause disease in susceptible children. In a review, attack rates for unvaccinated children in the household setting ranged from 64 percent to 86 percent (average 76 percent) but was much lower (range 0-36 percent) in classroom contract studies. Clearly, transmission required repeated or prolonged exposure and/or close contact. Airborne transmission via respiratory droplets had been postulated but not clearly proven until 2012 when Merkel's laboratory (Warfel JM, Beren J, Merkel TJ: Airborne transmission of _Bordetella pertussis_. J Infect Dis 2012; 206(6): 902-6) demonstrated airborne transmission between infected and naive baboons.\n\nMuch of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _B. pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 percent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. MJ\n\nNosocomial spread of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection probably occurs more commonly than is recognized and can be minimized but not eliminated by up-to-date immunization with Tdap [combined tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccines] of health care workers. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243. \n\n'As a precaution Kaiser Permanente is contacting members and employees who may have been exposed to the employee as much as 3 weeks prior to the diagnosis because those infected with pertussis can carry the disease for some time before symptoms appear. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sacramento County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/california.shtml. \n\nDr Angela Anderson, a pediatrician at Spearfish Regional Medical Clinic, said the clinic's staff have diagnosed 10 cases in the past 2 weeks through diagnostic culture and those numbers are expected to rise. MJ]\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2014-04-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-06 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-12 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Black Hills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Black Hills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2493415", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada: (PE,BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2493415", "date": "2014-05-24 19:07:17", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA: (PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND, BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Prince Edward Island\nDate: Thu 22 May 2014\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/prince-edward-island/whooping-cough-outbreak-on-p-e-i-continues-to-spread-1.2650465\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak on PEI [Prince Edward Island Province], the 1st in nearly a decade, is growing in the western part of the province. Whooping cough, or pertussis, is a bacterial lung infection that poses a serious risk to babies. Adults can show much milder symptoms, which can help in its spread.\n\n'With those individuals they can actually have pertussis, have a mild cough and not know it, and then pass it on to vulnerable infants,' said Dr David Sabapathy, the province's deputy chief health officer. The outbreak started with 6 confirmed cases in February 2014. There are now 24. A total of 4 babies have been hospitalized.\n\nMost of the cases in this outbreak happened in Western PEI. Several of those afflicted were not immunized, he said, but should have been. 'It often will happen in pockets of people, in communities that are under-immunized with pertussis vaccine, so we encourage you to get your vaccine,' said Sabapathy.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED-mail/HealthMap interactive map showing Prince Edward Island is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/270.]\n\n******\n[2] British Columbia (Haida Gwaii)\nDate: Wed 21 May 2014\nSource: Haida Gwaii Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.haidagwaiiobserver.com/Article.aspx?id=27267\n\n\nOf the 22 confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) on the North Coast [of British Columbia Province], 20 of them are on the islands [Haida Gwaii], according to a Northern Health press release this week. That number is likely higher, however, as not every case gets swabbed and tested, said Jane Boutette, Northern Health's public health nursing manager for Prince Rupert and Haida Gwaii.\n\n'It's really scary,' said an expectant mother who is in her 3rd trimester of pregnancy and found out from her midwife that she had been exposed to pertussis. She was immediately prescribed antibiotics and said she is now just hoping the baby, which is due next week, will not be born until the 5-day cycle of antibiotics is over. 'It can be fatal for a newborn,' she said, and described herself upset and angry with the situation. 'I wish people were more aware of how this affects other people,' she said. 'It's your choice whether you immunize or not, but it's not all about you and your own little world.'\n\nMs Boutette said the people Northern Health worries about most are women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy and infants under one year old. 'We're asking anyone who has signs or symptoms to go to a clinic, get swabbed and notify Northern Health if they've been in contact with infants or a pregnant woman. We'll then contact them and we can offer prophylactic antibiotics. If you have a cough, try your best to isolate yourself,' she said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Haida Gwaii (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haida_Gwaii), literally 'Islands of the [Haida] People', informally but commonly known as the Queen Charlotte Islands and the Charlottes, is an archipelago on the north coast of British Columbia, Canada, populated mostly by Haida people. Haida Gwaii consists of 2 main islands: Graham Island in the north and Moresby Island in the south, along with about 150 smaller islands. - Mod.LL\n\nA ProMED-mail/HealthMap interactive map showing British Columbia is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/264.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Prince Edward Island\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n'With those individuals they can actually have pertussis, have a mild cough and not know it, and then pass it on to vulnerable infants,' said Dr David Sabapathy, the province's deputy chief health officer. PERTUSSIS - CANADA: (PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND, BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n********************************************************************************\n \n\nMs Boutette said the people Northern Health worries about most are women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy and infants under one year old. ' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Haida Gwaii (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haida_Gwaii), literally 'Islands of the [Haida] People', informally but commonly known as the Queen Charlotte Islands and the Charlottes, is an archipelago on the north coast of British Columbia, Canada, populated mostly by Haida people. Of the 22 confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) on the North Coast [of British Columbia Province], 20 of them are on the islands [Haida Gwaii], according to a Northern Health press release this week. It often will happen in pockets of people, in communities that are under-immunized with pertussis vaccine, so we encourage you to get your vaccine,' said Sabapathy. \n\n******\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED-mail/HealthMap interactive map showing Prince Edward Island is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/270.] It's really scary,' said an expectant mother who is in her 3rd trimester of pregnancy and found out from her midwife that she had been exposed to pertussis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-05-21 00:00:00", "2014-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Graham Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "british COLUMBIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2603059", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (13)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2603059", "date": "2014-07-13 16:52:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\n[3] California (Riverside County)\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\n[5] South Dakota\n\n******\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: KAPP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kapptv.com/article/2014/jul/08/pertussis-outbreak-among-migrant-farm-workers-near/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 3 laboratory confirmed cases and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n'We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,' states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, 'Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.' More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. 'These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,' Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. Nationally, according to the CDC, about 24 231 cases of pertussis were reported provisionally in the USA in 2013 and 48 277 in 2012.\n\nWhile a case is being investigated, Teule-Hekima said the VDH district offices will circulate letters within their specific jurisdictions, through places like schools and churches, to let people know it may be present without identifying the specific source due to privacy concerns.\n\n'Our whole point is to protect public health and make sure that people have the information they need,' she said.\n\n[Byline: Christine Sampson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Peninsula Health District serves Newport News, Poquoson, Williamsburg, James City County and York County in Virginia (http://www.vdh.state.va.us/lhd/peninsula/). For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or 'whooping cough,' at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n'We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,' said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. There was a total of 11 confirmed cases of whooping cough during the month of June 2014. Ten of the cases were among children ages 3 to 17, and one was an adult. In July 2014, 5 more suspected cases were discovered. The Health Department says all but one of the confirmed and suspected cases are from Brattleboro.\n\n'Anyone who has a persistent cough should be evaluated by his or her health care provider,' said Susan Schoenfeld, deputy state epidemiologist for infectious disease. 'People with suspected or confirmed pertussis should stay away from others until 5 days of antimicrobial therapy have been completed. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.'\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. http://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014. \n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. [Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. MPP]\n\n******\n MPP]\n\n******\n MPP]\n\n******\n MPP]\n\n******\n During the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. \n\n'We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. \n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "4558-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mattawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Custer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Butte", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Riverside County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Windham County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poquoson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ziebach County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "James City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quincy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brattleboro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vermont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lawrence County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "James City County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2513925", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (09): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2513925", "date": "2014-06-04 11:47:53", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (09): (CALIFORNIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 30 May 2014\nSource: The Sacramento (CA) Bee [edited]\nhttp://www.sacbee.com/2014/05/30/6445125/pertussis-continues-its-march.html\n\n\nPertussis is continuing to spread across California, public health officials said Friday [30 May 2014], with the number of whooping cough cases in Sacramento County so far in 2014 nearly doubling what the county confirmed for the entire year in 2013. Among 3 other counties in the capital region, only Yolo County is seeing a similarly dramatic increase, though the number of cases confirmed there is far lower.\n\nStatewide, the California Department of Public Health has counted 2649 pertussis -- or whooping cough -- cases from the start of 2014 through Tue 27 May 2014. In April alone, more than 800 people from Eureka to Escondido contracted the disease, said Dr Ron Chapman, the state's health officer. Infants are especially vulnerable to whooping cough, Chapman said, noting that before year's end, 'the number of pertussis cases is likely to continue to increase.'\n\nEveryone, particularly those who are around babies -- such as parents, care providers, and healthcare workers -- should get the pertussis immunization. It's especially important for women who are pregnant to receive a pertussis vaccine booster during their 3rd trimester so the shot's immune properties are transferred to their babies. Newborns are not old enough to receive whooping cough immunizations until 2 months of age, after which boosters are given at 4 months and 6 months.\n\nHealth officials in Sacramento County confirmed 137 cases so far, compared with 70 cases total in all of last year [2013]. In 2010, the worst year in recent memory, the county saw 175 cases. In Yolo County, 14 cases have been counted in 2014, up from 4 in 2013. El Dorado County has reported only 2 cases so far this year, compared with last year's total of 4. And Placer County has confirmed 37 cases, less than half of the 85 cases reported in 2013.\n\nSo far in 2014, 2 infants have died of pertussis in California, 1 in Placer County and the other in Riverside County. One of the babies contracted the disease last year.\n\n[Byline: Cynthia H Craft]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. A county can be seen at http://geology.com/state-map/maps/california-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. \n\n\nPertussis is continuing to spread across California, public health officials said Friday [30 May 2014], with the number of whooping cough cases in Sacramento County so far in 2014 nearly doubling what the county confirmed for the entire year in 2013. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study. \n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. In Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. Infants are especially vulnerable to whooping cough, Chapman said, noting that before year's end, 'the number of pertussis cases is likely to continue to increase.' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. El Dorado County has reported only 2 cases so far this year, compared with last year's total of 4. During the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. Statewide, the California Department of Public Health has counted 2649 pertussis -- or whooping cough -- cases from the start of 2014 through Tue 27 May 2014. Health officials in Sacramento County confirmed 137 cases so far, compared with 70 cases total in all of last year [2013]. \n\nSo far in 2014, 2 infants have died of pertussis in California, 1 in Placer County and the other in Riverside County. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year. \n\nEveryone, particularly those who are around babies -- such as parents, care providers, and healthcare workers -- should get the pertussis immunization.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2649-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Dorado County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Placer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yolo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Riverside County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2431379", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (05): (CA) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2431379", "date": "2014-04-26 10:14:35", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (05): (CALIFORNIA) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Insurancenewsnet.com [edited]\nhttp://insurancenewsnet.com/oarticle/2014/04/25/pertussis-cases-continue-to-soar-a-494613.html#.U1sNK8fO47B\n\n\nSan Diego County [California] issued the following news: 'We are seeing a level of pertussis activity that should cause concern for parents and caregivers,' said Wilma Wooten, MD, MPH, County public health officer. There were 10 new cases reported this week [week of 21 Apr 2014] in which others may have been exposed, bringing the total number of cases to 266 reported so far in 2014. There were 51 cases reported by this date in 2013 and a total of 430 that year [2014]. A high of 1179 cases was reported in 2010.\n\n'We are seeing a level of pertussis activity that should cause concern for parents and caregivers,' said Wilma Wooten, MD, MPH, County public health officer. 'We want everyone to receive the recommended vaccines so that they are protecting themselves as well as everyone around them.'\n\nA typical case of pertussis starts with a cough and runny nose for one to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits that sometimes end with a whooping sound (http://www.whoopingcough.net/sound%20of%20whooping%20cough%20with%20much%20whooping.htm). Fever, if present, is usually mild. Antibiotics can lessen the severity of symptoms and prevent the spread of disease to others.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the following vaccination schedule:\n- young children need 5 doses of DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine] by kindergarten: at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.\n- all students entering 7th grade need proof of a whooping cough booster immunization (Tdap).\n- a Tdap booster is recommended for pregnant women during their third trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got a booster before becoming pregnant.\n- one dose of Tdap is recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent.\n\n[In San Diego County] parents can obtain the DTaP vaccine series and the Tdap booster shot for themselves and their children through their primary care physicians. Local retail pharmacies offer vaccinations for a fee, and anyone who is not covered by a medical insurance plan can get the shot from a County Public Health Center at minimal or no cost (http://www.sdcounty.ca.gov/hhsa/programs/phs/immunization_branch/immunizations_free_for_children_under_age_two.html).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - North America (02): USA (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the following vaccination schedule:\n- young children need 5 doses of DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine] by kindergarten: at 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. PERTUSSIS - USA (05): (CALIFORNIA) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n********************************************************************\n \n\nA typical case of pertussis starts with a cough and runny nose for one to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits that sometimes end with a whooping sound (http://www.whoopingcough.net/sound%20of%20whooping%20cough%20with%20much%20whooping.htm). There were 10 new cases reported this week [week of 21 Apr 2014] in which others may have been exposed, bringing the total number of cases to 266 reported so far in 2014. \n\n'We are seeing a level of pertussis activity that should cause concern for parents and caregivers,' said Wilma Wooten, MD, MPH, County public health officer.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "1179-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2469830", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2469830", "date": "2014-05-14 14:41:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (07)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (Sacramento County)\n[2] California (Napa County)\n[3] California (Contra Costa County)\n[4] California (Placer County) infant fatality\n[5] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\n[6] South Carolina (Pickens County)\n\n******\n[1] California (Sacramento County)\nDate: Tue 13 May 2014\nSource: KCRA News [edited]\nhttp://www.kcra.com/news/pertussis-outbreak-reported-in-sacramento-county/25934928\n\n\nHealth officials said Sacramento County is experiencing an outbreak of pertussis, which causes a loud, gasping whooping cough. Sacramento County officials reported 69 confirmed cases in 2014. In 2013, about 59 cases were reported for the entire calendar year. 11 of the 69 are young children and many are teenagers, the health department said.\n\nSacramento County public health officer Dr Olivia Kasirye said it's not uncommon for parents not to know what their child is suffering from when it comes to whooping cough. 'If you have enough people immunized, you can stop it from spreading,' Kasirye said. 'It's spread through the air, through droplets -- usually, you have to be in pretty close contact with the person.'\n\nSchools and daycares are susceptible. What may appear to be a slight cough at first can get much worse. 'If it's a child, sometimes they go blue in the face,' Kasirye said. 'They might even start throwing up and they might have the characteristic whoop at the end of an episode (of) coughing.' Kasirye said it can be especially challenging to spot in babies who may only appear to have the sniffles.\n\n[Byline: Gamaliel Ortiz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] California (Napa County)\nDate: Fri 9 May 2014\nSource: CBS San Francisco and Bay City News Service [edited]\nhttp://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2014/05/09/cases-disease-whooping-cough-pertussis-on-rise-napa-county/\n\n\nCases of pertussis, a potentially deadly disease also known as whooping cough, are on the rise in Napa County in 2014, Napa County's top health official said. Napa County Public Health Officer Dr Karen Smith said 17 cases have been reported so far in 2013, 9 of them in the last 2 weeks. There were 13 pertussis cases in Napa County in all of 2013. All but 3 of this year's [2014], 17 reported cases have been in children of middle or high school age, Smith said.\n\nSmith urged women in their 3rd trimester of pregnancy to get vaccinated for pertussis to provide protection of the infant through transfer of antibodies from the mother before birth and by preventing the mother from passing a pertussis infection to the young infant after birth. Family members and childcare providers who have contact with the infant also should be vaccinated, health officials said.\n\nPertussis is cyclical and peaks every 3 to 5 years, health officials said. The last epidemic in California was in 2010 when there were 9100 cases statewide and 10 infant deaths.\n\nAll of Napa County's neighboring counties also are experiencing a high rate of pertussis, public health officials said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] California (Contra Costa County)\nDate: Fri 9 May 20143\nSource: KTVU [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvu.com/news/news/local/contra-costa-county-sees-spike-whooping-cough-case/nfscD/\n\n\nContra Costa County has seen a jump in the amount of whooping cough cases in 2014, with 9 cases of the disease found in a single school. In fact, in Martinez, all but 2 of the schools have seen confirmed cases. Morello Park Elementary was the school with 9 cases, the highest number in the county so far.\n\nThere have been 49 cases of whooping cough or pertussis, across the county. The 9 at Morello Park account for almost 20 percent of the county total.\n\n'So far we have had 4 babies hospitalized here in Contra Costa. Luckily, all are recovering,' said the county's communicable disease programs chief Erika Jenssen. 'But in 2010, when there was a big epidemic across California, 10 babies died throughout the state. And what we're really trying to do is protect the babies from pertussis.'\n\n[Byline: John Sasaki]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] California (Placer County) infant fatality\nDate: Wed 7 May 2014\nSource: The Sacramento Bee [edited]\nhttp://www.sacbee.com/2014/05/07/6386567/placer-county-infant-dies-of-whooping.html\n\n\nAn infant in Placer County has died of whooping cough, public health officials said Wed 7 May 2014. It was only the 2nd infant fatality from pertussis in 2014 in California -- the 1st being in Riverside County in Southern California. Public health officials do not disclose the identity of individuals who die of communicable diseases, but they did confirm that the infant was less than 6 months old, the most vulnerable age for succumbing to whooping cough.\n\n'It is a terrible tragedy for both the family and our community when a baby dies,' said Dr Robert Oldham, Placer County's public health officer. 'We can help prevent tragedies like these by vaccinating all pregnant women, ideally when they are between 27 and 36 weeks along in their pregnancies,' Oldham said.\n\n[Byline: Cynthia H Craft]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\nDate: Wed 14 May 2014\nSource: WPXI [edited]\nhttp://www.wpxi.com/news/news/local/11-cases-whooping-cough-confirmed-allderdice-high-/nfwSs/\n\n\nSo far 11 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed at Allderdice High School, Pittsburgh Public Schools spokeswoman Ebony Pugh said [Tue 13 May 2014]. Pugh said the 1st case was confirmed in April 2014.\n\nAfter the 1st case was confirmed, a letter was sent home to the parents of anyone in a classroom or team with the student or anyone not vaccinated. Pugh said a letter went out to all parents after the 4th case was confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Pennsylvania can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3520. Allegheny County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina (Pickens County)\nDate: Mon 12 May 2014\nSource: The Greenville News [edited]\nhttp://www.greenvilleonline.com/story/news/local/2014/05/12/whooping-cough-causes-concern-pickens-county/8987555/\n\n\nState health officials are asking health care providers to be on the watch for pertussis in Pickens County since there has been a spike in cases over the past few weeks. State health officials are asking health care providers to be on the watch for pertussis in Pickens County since there has been a spike in cases over the past few weeks.\n\nAt this time in 2013, there were 66 cases statewide. But of the 30 cases reported in the state so far in 2014, 13 have been in Pickens County, including 2 cases at West End Elementary and Forest Acres Elementary that were reported in March 2014, according to the state Department of Health and Environmental Control [DHEC].\n\nThere have been no cases in Greenville County and fewer than 4 cases each in Anderson and Spartanburg counties, DHEC reports. 'So far this year [2014], we've received reports of more pertussis cases from Pickens County compared to any other county in the state,' said Dr Riyadh Muhammad, a DHEC medical consultant and pediatrician. 'Through all of 2013,' she said, 'there were 9 cases reported in Pickens County.'\n\nThere were 24 231 cases of pertussis in 2013 nationwide, CDC reports. And DHEC reports 212 in South Carolina in 2013.\n\n[Byline: Liv Osby]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of South Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22966. Pickens County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/south-carolina.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "[Byline: Gamaliel Ortiz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.
