MJ\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-04-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Riverside County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Placer County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pickens County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Napa County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greenville County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Napa County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allegheny County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Costa County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Placer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kasirye", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Martinez", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spartanburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2426383", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2426383", "date": "2014-04-24 13:09:23", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04): (MONTANA, CALIFORNIA) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Montana\n[2] California\n\n******\n[1] Montana\nDate: Tue 22 Apr 2014\nSource: Beartooth NBC, Lewis & Clark Co. Health Dept report [edited]\nhttp://www.beartoothnbc.com/news/1677756191-7-cases-of-pertussis-confirmed-recently-in-helena-area.html\n\n\nThe Lewis and Clark City-County [Montana] Health Department announced Tuesday [22 Apr 2014] that 7 cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, have been identified in the Helena area in the past 2 weeks. Most of the confirmed cases have involved teenagers. The health department is contacting people who have been exposed to the disease in an effort to keep it from spreading.\n\nPertussis is a serious respiratory illness that can spread through close and prolonged person-to-person contact. People with pertussis can have symptoms ranging from runny nose and intermittent cough to severe uncontrollable coughing that can last for months. Pertussis is common in the United States, and there are frequent outbreaks, but it can cause serious illness and can even be life threatening, especially in infants.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend using antibiotics to treat those in close, prolonged contact with someone who is sick with pertussis. Antibiotics work best when given early in the course of the disease.\n\n'Another way to help protect our community is to get vaccinated,' said Karen Dobson Wandel, public health nurse supervisor at the health department. '5th and 6th graders who haven't had their pertussis booster yet should get it now. Adults, especially those who live and work with infants, should be sure they're up to date. Protection from the regular series of childhood shots wanes over time.'\n\nWomen also should be vaccinated during each pregnancy. The best time is during the 27th through 36th week, according to the CDC. Some of the protective antibodies in the vaccine will be passed to the infant, giving it short-term protection against pertussis until it's old enough to be vaccinated itself. [This statement is not exactly correct. The vaccine does not contain antibodies. Please see the moderator's comments below.]\n\nThe health department offers tetanus boosters that contain pertussis during regular walk-in immunization clinics Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 11 am to 4:30 pm at 1930 Ninth Ave. However, there will be no immunization clinic on Wed 23 Apr 2014 due to staff training.\n\nFor more information, contact your health-care provider or the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, 443-2584, or visit the CDC website at http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Montana can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18313. Helena is the state capital and seat of Lewis and Clark County. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] California\nDate: Tue 22 Apr 2014\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-whooping-cough-rise-long-beach-20140422,0,1316409.story#axzz2zj0eqQQB\n\n\nLong Beach [California] health officials are warning residents of a sharp increase in whooping cough cases in the city. Health officials say 42 cases have been reported since January [2014]. Although officials did not immediately have a breakdown for the cases reported in the same period last year, they said 15 cases were reported for all of 2013. 4 cases were reported in 2012.\n\nThis year [2014], most of the infected have been school-age children, officials said, adding that no deaths have been reported. 'A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,' said Dr Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSymptoms start with a cough, low-grade fever, and runny nose that will last up to 2 weeks, followed by rapid coughing fits that can sometimes last months. Typical symptoms in young infants may be more variable and severe, including intense coughing accompanied by a whooping sound and vomiting after coughing. Officials say complications, such as pneumonia and seizures, and in rare cases, death, can occur.\n\nAlthough most children receive 5 doses of pertussis vaccine before entering kindergarten, immunization wears off over time and booster shots are needed throughout life. Health officials are encouraging residents to contact their healthcare providers and immunize themselves and their families against the disease.\n\nThose who do not have a regular health provider or health insurance can dial 211 or the health department's immunization program at (562) 570-4516.\n\n[Byline: Ruben Vives]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of California can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/997. Long Beach, Los Angeles County, is located in Southern California. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis.\n\nThe incidence rate of pertussis among infants exceeds that of all other age groups, and the majority of deaths continue to occur among infants younger than 3 months of age. Because much of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis are in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, who are not as yet protected by active immunization, the CDC recommends 'cocooning,' a vaccination strategy that aims to protect infants from becoming infected with pertussis before the baby's whooping cough vaccinations start at 2 months of age, by vaccinating individuals, such as the mother and other caregivers, who would come into regular contact with the newborn infant.\n\nIn response to her pertussis vaccination, a pregnant woman will produce protective antibodies, which are passed transplacentally to her baby before birth. These antibodies provide the baby short-term protection against whooping cough in early life. Protective antibodies are at their highest about 2 weeks after getting the vaccine. So vaccination should be scheduled late in pregnancy, preferably during the 27th through 36th week, to give the baby the most protection when born and vaccination should be repeated with each pregnancy so high levels of protective antibodies are transferred to each of the babies.\n\nPregnant women should receive Tdap [combined tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccines, with a reduced dose of the diphtheria and pertussis vaccines], the type of pertussis vaccine for those 11 years and older, including pregnant women. Women who did not receive the vaccine during pregnancy should get it immediately after giving birth. Fathers, grandparents, and others 11 years and older who have close contact with the baby should also get a dose if they have not had the booster.\n\nDTaP is the type of pertussis vaccine used for children 2 months through 6 years of age. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years. Both the Tdap and DTaP vaccines combine protection against pertussis, tetanus and diphtheria (see http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/adults/rec-vac/pregnant/whooping-cough/get-vaccinated.html). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Because much of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis are in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, who are not as yet protected by active immunization, the CDC recommends 'cocooning,' a vaccination strategy that aims to protect infants from becoming infected with pertussis before the baby's whooping cough vaccinations start at 2 months of age, by vaccinating individuals, such as the mother and other caregivers, who would come into regular contact with the newborn infant. \n\nPregnant women should receive Tdap [combined tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccines, with a reduced dose of the diphtheria and pertussis vaccines], the type of pertussis vaccine for those 11 years and older, including pregnant women. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Montana can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18313. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of California can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/997. \n\nDTaP is the type of pertussis vaccine used for children 2 months through 6 years of age. \n\nThe health department offers tetanus boosters that contain pertussis during regular walk-in immunization clinics Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 11 am to 4:30 pm at 1930 Ninth Ave. The Lewis and Clark City-County [Montana] Health Department announced Tuesday [22 Apr 2014] that 7 cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, have been identified in the Helena area in the past 2 weeks. \n\nThose who do not have a regular health provider or health insurance can dial 211 or the health department's immunization program at (562) 570-4516. A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,' said Dr Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services. The incidence rate of pertussis among infants exceeds that of all other age groups, and the majority of deaths continue to occur among infants younger than 3 months of age. PERTUSSIS - USA (04): (MONTANA, CALIFORNIA) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n*****************************************************************************\n \n\nSymptoms start with a cough, low-grade fever, and runny nose that will last up to 2 weeks, followed by rapid coughing fits that can sometimes last months. \n\n'Another way to help protect our community is to get vaccinated,' said Karen Dobson Wandel, public health nurse supervisor at the health department. ' \n\nThis year [2014], most of the infected have been school-age children, officials said, adding that no deaths have been reported. ' \n\nPertussis is a serious respiratory illness that can spread through close and prolonged person-to-person contact. Although most children receive 5 doses of pertussis vaccine before entering kindergarten, immunization wears off over time and booster shots are needed throughout life. [2] California\n\n******\n Some of the protective antibodies in the vaccine will be passed to the infant, giving it short-term protection against pertussis until it's old enough to be vaccinated itself. So vaccination should be scheduled late in pregnancy, preferably during the 27th through 36th week, to give the baby the most protection when born and vaccination should be repeated with each pregnancy so high levels of protective antibodies are transferred to each of the babies. In response to her pertussis vaccination, a pregnant woman will produce protective antibodies, which are passed transplacentally to her baby before birth. People with pertussis can have symptoms ranging from runny nose and intermittent cough to severe uncontrollable coughing that can last for months. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years. In this posting:\n[1] Montana\n \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark City - County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2445291", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2445291", "date": "2014-05-03 17:44:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\n[4] Maine (York County)\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: KUSI News [edited]\nhttp://www.kusi.com/story/25389578/county-pertussis-cases-up-nearly-600-percent-over-last-year\n\n\nThere have been 298 pertussis cases reported in San Diego County [California] in 2014, nearly 6 times the 53 reported this time in 2013, the county Health and Human Services Agency reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n'Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,' said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. 'The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. 'A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,' said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called 'Tdap'). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. Now they're reporting 25 cases since the start of April 2014, and most of those cases are from students at Capital High School.\n\nThe school has been working in connection with the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department to identify those infected and figure out who may have come into contact. In most cases, students have been vaccinated already, according to Capital High nurse, Kathy Boutilier, RN. 'This is a vaccine that has a waning effectiveness. So, a number of variables that come into play as to why someone would get pertussis and why someone sitting next to them does not,' said Boutilier.\n\nMike Henderson, a public health nurse at the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, said that despite that, now is a perfect time for everyone to check their immunization status. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. In addition to high school-age kids, there is a pre-school-age child, and several adults who have been diagnosed with pertussis [in this outbreak].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: WMTW [edited]\nhttp://m.wmtw.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise/25740834\n\n\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Kennebunk [York County, Maine] and parents are on alert. A total of 6 cases have been reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. The superintendent sent an email to parents letting them know what's being done to keep kids at school, but it also talks about how prevention starts at home. 'We don't want to raise concern about issues that aren't significant. We don't want to create hysteria, but it is important to share when there are situations where there is a contagious disease that we want folks to be aware of,' said Superintendent Andrew Dolloff.\n\nThis week, a student at the Middle School of the Kennebunks contracted the disease, making it the 6th case district-wide and the 4th at the school. Each confirmed case means a mandatory 5 days away from the school to help stop the spread.\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Liepman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[CDC has the following recommendation: 'Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years.' http://www.cdc.gov/Vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm. in the UK, 'Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.' http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Whooping-cough/Pages/Introduction.aspx. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n http://www.kusi.com/story/25389578/county-pertussis-cases-up-nearly-600-percent-over-last-year\n\n\nThere have been 298 pertussis cases reported in San Diego County [California] in 2014, nearly 6 times the 53 reported this time in 2013, the county Health and Human Services Agency reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. in the UK, 'Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.' Spain: (VC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2329518", "date": "2014-03-12 20:41:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SPAIN: (VALENCIA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Mar 2014\nSource: Las Provincias [machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.lasprovincias.es/v/20140311/alicante/colegios-alicante-registran-brotes-20140311.html\n\n\nTwo schools in Alicante [province, Valencia] have notified the Department of Public Health at the Department of Health of school outbreaks of whooping cough (pertussis), a contagious disease, which has led to the diagnosis of 16 cases, although the evolution of none of the children affected is serious, as pointed out yesterday [10 Mar 2014] by the Department of Health.\n\nThe 1st of the outbreaks was recorded last week [week of 3 Mar 2014]. It has included 13 cases, according to what was reported to Public Health. This week [week of 10 Mar 2014] there is another school where the bacteria have also entered into the classroom, although there are only 3 cases.\n\nPediatricians pointed out that pertussis can be especially severe in the case of infants under 2 months old, since the 1st dose of the vaccine is not received by that date. They also stressed that Catalonia has decided to begin managing the doses in pregnant women. In January 2014, the Public Health Agency of Catalonia announced that it would begin the systematic vaccination of pregnant women. The recommendation is for pregnant women who are between week 27 and 36 of gestation to get vaccinated, with the goal of improving the protection of the newborn.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, 'cocooning' of the susceptible neonate has included immunization of close family contacts as well as the pregnant female. Almost all the significant morbidity and mortality of infection with _Bordetella pertussis_ occurs in infants less than 6 months of age.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea sometimes with hypoxia-induced seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000, and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Ogk.]\n\n.................................................jt/ll/je/mpp", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. \n\nPediatricians pointed out that pertussis can be especially severe in the case of infants under 2 months old, since the 1st dose of the vaccine is not received by that date. \n\n\nTwo schools in Alicante [province, Valencia] have notified the Department of Public Health at the Department of Health of school outbreaks of whooping cough (pertussis), a contagious disease, which has led to the diagnosis of 16 cases, although the evolution of none of the children affected is serious, as pointed out yesterday In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000, and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. Communicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n< Almost all the significant morbidity and mortality of infection with _Bordetella pertussis_ occurs in infants less than 6 months of age.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alicante", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2395621", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - North America", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2395621", "date": "2014-04-11 14:15:45", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NORTH AMERICA\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] USA (Georgia)\n[2] USA (California)\n[3] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] USA (Georgia)\nDate: Wed 9 Apr 2014\nSource: WCTV [edited]\nhttp://www.wctv.tv/news/floridanews/headlines/Public-Health-Investigating-Multi-County-Pertussis-Whooping-Cough-Outbreak-254428481.html\n\n\nSouthwest Georgia Public Health District is investigating clusters of pertussis, primarily associated with young children, in Colquitt, Mitchell and Thomas counties, Southwest Georgia Public Health District health director Dr Jacqueline Grant, said. Additional cases have also been confirmed in other counties. 'Pertussis, or whooping cough, is an infection caused by bacteria,' Grant said. 'It spreads easily through the air when an infected person breathes, coughs or sneezes.'\n\nPertussis can cause serious, even life-threatening, complications in babies and young children who are not fully vaccinated, Grant warned. 'More than half of infants younger than 12 months old who get pertussis require hospitalization,' she said. 'Since 2013, there have been 7 cases of infants with pertussis in our district; 4 of those were hospitalized, and 3, all under 2 months old, required intensive care outside of the area.'\n\nShe said the district epidemiologist and staff are working with area schools and child care facilities, which are especially prone to see clusters of whooping cough, to identify and manage cases of the disease and keep it from spreading.\n\n'We are asking contacts of patients with confirmed cases to get in touch with their healthcare providers,' said Southwest Georgia Public Health District epidemiologist Jacqueline Jenkins. 'Early recognition of cases, effective treatment and prophylaxis and vaccinations are vital to limiting the spread of pertussis.'\n\nGrant stressed that women should be vaccinated against pertussis with every pregnancy to protect their babies. 'The best time to receive the vaccine, known [as] Tdap, is between 27 and 36 weeks,' she said. 'If it isn't administered during pregnancy, it should be provided immediately after she gives birth. It should also be given to all of the baby's caregivers to provide a cocoon against pertussis infection.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (California)\nDate: Wed 9 Apr 2014\nSource: KPBS [edited]\nhttp://www.kpbs.org/news/2014/apr/09/san-diego-whooping-cough-cases-outpacing-2013-numb/\n\n\nThe rate of pertussis cases in San Diego County [California] continues to run far ahead of 2013, with 10 new diagnoses reported last week, the county Health and Human Services Agency announced on Wednesday [9 Apr 2014]. Nearly 200 cases of the disease that's also known as whooping cough have been logged so far in 2014, nearly halfway to the total for all of 2013, which was 430, according to the HHSA. By this time in 2013, 39 cases had been reported.\n\nTwo years after a KPBS/inewsource investigation posed serious questions about how well the whooping cough vaccine works, new research confirms the vaccine is failing at a higher rate than expected. 'A greater number of children are getting sick with pertussis in 2014, said Dr Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. 'Parents or guardians should make sure their children have received all the recommended doses of the pertussis vaccine.' She said it is also important that parents and other caregivers recognize symptoms immediately so that those sick with pertussis can get immediate treatment, and not spread the illness.\n\nInfants younger than one year old are especially vulnerable because they do not have the full 5-dose series of pertussis vaccinations.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Canada (Alberta)\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2014\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttp://calgary.ctvnews.ca/whooping-cough-outbreak-could-be-larger-than-expected-1.1766513\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] says 34 cases of whooping cough have been reported in southern Alberta since the beginning of 2014, and stress that there could be many more. One family in the community is urging parents to get their children immunized against pertussis after their 4 month old son became very sick.\n\nA Lethbridge family is urging families in the community to get their children vaccinated after their son is very ill and under quarantine with whooping cough. The mother said, 'Each [coughing fit] is really scary because it sounds like he's choking. It's day and night, so we take turns holding him through the night and switch off every attack.' The infant ended up contracting whooping cough from his parents after his dad caught a very bad cough shortly after he was born.\n\nThe parents both had their pertussis vaccinations 9 years ago. They hope that their story can encourage other parents to get their children vaccinated. 'Anyone who is pregnant or in that 5 to 10 year range needs to be getting it,' the mother says. 'Even if there's no outbreak. When you have an infant in the family, it's serious.'\n\n'Pertussis is really quite serious, especially in infants under the age of 6 months. This bacterium can intervene with their ability to breathe, and it can really lead to death,' said Dr Judy MacDonald from the AHS.\n\nThe last outbreak in the South Zone was in 2012 and claimed the life of one infant.\n\n[byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 per cent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea sometimes with hypoxia-induced seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n It should also be given to all of the baby's caregivers to provide a cocoon against pertussis infection.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Since 2013, there have been 7 cases of infants with pertussis in our district; 4 of those were hospitalized, and 3, all under 2 months old, required intensive care outside of the area.'\n\n This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm). In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. PERTUSSIS - NORTH AMERICA\n*************************\n Source: CTV News [edited]\nhttp://calgary.ctvnews.ca/whooping-cough-outbreak-could-be-larger-than-expected-1.1766513\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] says 34 cases of whooping cough have been reported in southern Alberta since the beginning of 2014, and stress that there could be many more. \n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 per cent risk of death. The rate of pertussis cases in San Diego County [California] continues to run far ahead of 2013, with 10 new diagnoses reported last week, the county Health and Human Services Agency announced on Wednesday [9 Apr 2014]. \n\nPertussis can cause serious, even life-threatening, complications in babies and young children who are not fully vaccinated, Grant warned. ' \n\n'Pertussis is really quite serious, especially in infants under the age of 6 months. \n\n\nSouthwest Georgia Public Health District is investigating clusters of pertussis, primarily associated with young children, in Colquitt, Mitchell and Thomas counties, Southwest Georgia Public Health District health director Dr Jacqueline Grant, said. In this posting:\n[1] USA (Georgia)\n She said the district epidemiologist and staff are working with area schools and child care facilities, which are especially prone to see clusters of whooping cough, to identify and manage cases of the disease and keep it from spreading. \n\nTwo years after a KPBS/inewsource investigation posed serious questions about how well the whooping cough vaccine works, new research confirms the vaccine is failing at a higher rate than expected. ' As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. A greater number of children are getting sick with pertussis in 2014, said Dr Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2368032", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2368032", "date": "2014-03-31 15:35:28", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (03)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] California (Tehama County)\n[3] Idaho (Canyon and Ada Counties)\n[4] Michigan (Antrim County)\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Fri 28 Mar 2014\nSource: NBC San Diego [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/Parents-Warned-of-Increase-in-SD-Whooping-Cough-Cases-252957271.html\n\n\nParents, among others, are being warned by county health officials of an increase in pertussis (whooping cough) cases compared to this time in 2013.\n\nOn Fri 28 Mar 2014, the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency reported 10 new cases of pertussis, where others in the county may have been exposed to the disease. This brings the total number of cases reported so far in 2014 to 154, a large increase compared to the only 33 reported cases during the same time in 2013. The 10 new cases affected children between the ages of 2 and 13 years old.\n\nHealth officials urged locals, especially children, to obtain recommended vaccines. 'We're seeing a very high level of pertussis activity throughout San Diego County,' Wilma Wooten, MD, MPH, County public health officer, said in a media release. 'Parents, caregivers and educators should be on the lookout for symptoms so those with pertussis get treatment so they don't infect others.' To help prevent pertussis, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that children receive doses of DTaP vaccine at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. Preteens and adults are encouraged to get a Tdap booster.\n\nBoth the DTaP vaccine series and the Tdap booster can be obtained for parents and their children from primary care physicians or local retail pharmacies. A total of 430 pertussis cases were reported in 2013, 165 in 2012 and a recent high of 1179 in 2010.\n\n[Byline: Joseph Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Tehama County)\nDate: Thu 27 Mar 2014\nSource: KRCR TV [edited]\nhttp://m.krcrtv.com/confirmed-whooping-cough-case-in-tehama-county/25204144\n\n\nTehama County Public Health revealed today [27 Mar 2014] that they've had a confirmed case of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, so they're reminding people to take precautions. They recommend that adults who have not had a vaccination get one. Infants are at higher risk and should be vaccinated at 2 months of age.\n\nPregnant women and also family members who are around infants should get vaccinated, since the bacterial disease is spread through talking, sneezing or coughing.\n\nLinda Rose, Tehama County Health supervising nurse, said it's also important to keep an eye out for symptoms.\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Montano]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Idaho (Canyon and Ada Counties)\nDate: Fri 28 Mar 2014\nSource: KTVB [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvb.com/news/health/Whooping-cases-spike-in-Ada-and-Canyon-Counties-252999821.html\n\n\nAda County is seeing the highest number of cases of whooping cough in several years. Whooping cough can be potentially deadly to infants. 'Right now, our numbers are about 4 times average, and they're continuing to grow,' said Central District Health Staff Epidemiologist Sarah Correll. 'We do realize that the number of cases we get reported to us is just a very small part of the actual cases in the community, so we're really just seeing the beginning.' Correll suspects not everyone who has whooping cough is getting treated or is being tested for the disease. There are 26 confirmed cases so far in Canyon County and 25 in Ada County.\n\n'It's not unusual to have a spike every 5 to 7 years, a little bit of whooping cough cycle, but what we do worry about is that the infants may be adversely affected because people aren't thinking whooping cough. And if an infant or a newborn baby is infected with whooping cough, that could be deadly,' said Correll. Most of the cases they have seen in Ada County have been kids between 5 and 18 years old, and they usually see the disease transmitted within the household.\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Zepelin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Michigan (Antrim County)\nDate:: Wed 26 Mar 2014\nSource: Petroskey News [edited]\nhttp://www.petoskeynews.com/charlevoix/news/local/whooping-cough-confirmed-in-antrim-county-child/article_0107468c-6919-5fc0-a7cc-8da68794c9af.html\n\n\nAuthorities recently confirmed pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, in an Antrim County student. The Health Department of Northwest Michigan mailed letters to parents in the affected school, to recommend students in that classroom be treated by their doctors with an antibiotic as a preventive measure. Letters also provided information about symptoms of the illness and vaccination recommendations.\n\nAccording to the health department, the infected student did not receive an up-to-date pertussis vaccination.\n\n'The best prevention is to ensure everyone in the family is vaccinated,' said Joshua Meyerson, medical director for the Health Department of Northwest Michigan. 'Make sure young children receive all 5 recommended doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine at 2, 4, 6 and 15 months of age, and again between 4 and 6 years of age. Starting at age 11, everyone should receive at least one Tdap booster dose, even if they have had a regular tetanus (Td) vaccine recently. Routine hand-washing is also helpful.'\n\nMeyerson warns that those who refuse vaccination put others at risk. 'Even if you aren't concerned about the threat of pertussis for yourself, you may be unknowingly spreading the illness to others, especially infants and young children, to whom it may be fatal,' he said.\n\nThe health department offers all necessary immunizations, including Tdap and DTaP vaccines, through its clinics in Bellaire, Mancelona, Charlevoix, Gaylord and Harbor Springs/Petoskey.\n\n[Byline: Rachel Brougham]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n To help prevent pertussis, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that children receive doses of DTaP vaccine at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [4] Michigan (Antrim County)\n\n******\n [Byline: Joseph Young]\n\n--\n [Byline: Stephanie Montano]\n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n [Byline: Stephanie Zepelin]\n\n--\n [Byline: Rachel Brougham]\n\n--\n \n\n\nParents, among others, are being warned by county health officials of an increase in pertussis (whooping cough) cases compared to this time in 2013. http://m.krcrtv.com/confirmed-whooping-cough-case-in-tehama-county/25204144\n\n\nTehama County Public Health revealed today [27 Mar 2014] that they've had a confirmed case of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, so they're reminding people to take precautions. On Fri 28 Mar 2014, the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency reported 10 new cases of pertussis, where others in the county may have been exposed to the disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1179-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bellaire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canyon County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Antrim County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mancelona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ada County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2315829", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2315829", "date": "2014-03-06 15:20:51", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Utah (Weber County)\n[2] Colorado (Weld County)\n[3] New York (Suffolk County)\n\n******\n[1] Utah (Weber County)\nDate: Fri 28 Feb 2014\nSource: KSTU, Fox 13 [edited]\nhttp://fox13now.com/2014/02/28/1-infant-hospitalized-as-officials-declare-pertussis-outbreak-at-schools-in-weber-co/\n\n\nHealth department officials in northern Utah are working with parents and teachers in several Weber County schools in order to contain an outbreak of pertussis, which is commonly known as whooping cough. According to a press release from the Weber-Morgan Health Department, an infant has been hospitalized due to pertussis and 5 more individuals are experiencing symptoms. The investigation involves family members and students at Wahlquist Junior High School, Plain City Elementary School, and Evergreen Montessori Academy.\n\nThe release states that an outbreak is defined as a period in which 2 or more cases present themselves in one school within 20 days. Amy Carter, who is a communicable disease nurse with the Weber-Morgan Health Department, said people should take precautionary measures. 'Pertussis is something we see all year long, not just during cold and flu season,' she stated in the press release. 'This reminds us that we all need to be diligent about getting vaccinated, frequent hand washing, covering your cough and staying home when you are ill.'\n\nCarter said they are concerned about those who are too young to be immunized. 'While the vaccines are very effective, we know there are some people who will not build full immunity,' Carter stated in the release. 'Our main goal is to protect infants who cannot be immunized and are most at-risk from severe complications and even death.'\n\nCarter said 'most' of the cases are recovering, and she said people 'should contact their medical provider if they are experiencing sneezing, a runny nose and other cold like symptoms especially if they have been exposed to someone who has had a lingering cough. Pertussis symptoms can last as long as 3 months if left untreated.' Those experiencing symptoms should remain home from school, work and other activities until they complete a 5-day course of antibiotics.\n\n[Byline: Mark Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2aBt. Weber County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/utah.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n*****\n[2] Colorado (Weld County)\nDate: Mon 3 Mar 2014\nSource: The Coloradoan [edited]\nhttp://www.coloradoan.com/viewart/20140303/WINDSORBEACON/303030054/Weld-County-health-officials-offer-tips-avoid-pertussis\n\n\nPertussis, also known as whooping cough, continues to infect residents. 'So far in 2014, we have 30 new cases of pertussis,' said Dr Mark Wallace, executive director of the Weld County Department of Public Health & Environment. In 2013, Weld had just more than 100 cases and typically averages only 4 cases per year.\n\nWallace stresses the following points:\n- 'Get vaccinated.' It is important to follow the recommended series of boosters for both adults and children, because the pertussis vaccine does not provide lifelong protection.\n- Pertussis can be treated. 'Get tested by a health care provider if a cough lasts longer than 2 weeks in order to receive the appropriate treatment.'\n- 'Always cover your cough and wash your hands.' The health department also recommends 'cocooning' vaccination efforts beyond just parents and siblings -- that is to encourage grandparents and caregivers to get vaccinated, in order to protect the infants and children they are caring for from pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/awAC. Weld County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/colorado.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] New York (Suffolk County)\nDate: Tue 25 Feb 2014\nSource: Riverhead local [edited]\nhttp://riverheadlocal.com/health/more-cases-of-pertussis-reported-in-riverhead\n\n\nNew cases of pertussis have been reported in the Riverhead Central School District, according to a notice published yesterday, 24 Feb 2014, on the school district's website. 'Please be advised that we continue to have new cases of pertussis in the Riverhead Central School District,' the notice said. 'The cases are not limited to 1 school.' The district did not disclose the number of cases or the school buildings affected.\n\nThe district published a similar notice 3 Dec 2013, referencing multiple cases of the illness in more than 1 building. On 13 Nov 2013, the district reported on case of pertussis in the high school.\n\nThere have been 2048 cases reported in the USA so far in 2014 -- 75 in NY, according to the CDC. There were 131 cases reported in NY in 2013.\n\n[Byline: Denise Civiletti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/9huu. Suffolk County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/new-york.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nSometimes referred to as the 'pertussis paradox', the rise in reported cases of pertussis in the USA and other parts of the developed world after switching to a more tolerable, less reactogenic vaccine that could be given to adults as well as children, is probably multifactorial in origin, but is not just a case of 'post hoc ergo propter hoc', if it occurred after, it must be due to. An example of false 'post hoc logic' is if one eats a cheeseburger and an hour later gets fever and diarrhea with a stool culture growing a salmonella then the cheeseburger was the vehicle. This is not true since the incubation period of salmonellosis is far greater than an hour. Perhaps the well recognized up and down swings of pertussis outbreaks and/or the increased sensitivity of physicians to the diagnosis with better availability of specific diagnostic testing are involved here.\n\nThe current acellular (aP) pertussis vaccine, however, has had a role to play in the reemergence of pertussis' pertinence. The following summaries 2 issues in this regard (from: Lutwick LI, Preis J: Pertussis: In: Emerging Infectious Diseases: Clinical Case Studies. Ergonul O, Can F, Akova M, Madoff L (eds), 2014, Elsevier, (in press)):\n\n'Clearly, the current formulation of the acellular pertussis vaccine is less potent than its whole cell ancestor. Whether measuring specific antibodies to proteins in the vaccine during the primary sequence (34) or assessing pertussis incidence after the sequence ends at age 5 (35), immunity to pertussis promptly waned. Indeed, pertussis incidence and risk ratios rose in the 3 study states (36) at high as 8.8 times and 3.9 times in Minnesota between year 1 and year 6 after completion of the sequence. Currently 3 antigen and 5 antigen component acellular pertussis vaccines are available in the USA. The 5 component vaccine had greater efficacy in a head-to-head comparison (36). Interestingly, the relative risk of pertussis was 8.57 times higher in those with a 5-dose aP schedule as compared to those who had received at least 1 dose of whole cell vaccine (37) while those with 6 doses of aP had a relative risk of 3.55 as compared to the 1 or more whole cell group. Whether changing the balance of antigens in the vaccine or adding different antigens is unclear. In a response to the waning immunity observed following the primary immunization sequence of the acellular pertussis vaccine, further immunizations were recommended first for adolescents and then for adults 19-64 years old and then to adults 65 years and older. Finally, in order to best 'cocoon' the as yet unborn baby, recommendations now exist for aP vaccination of the pregnant woman in the 2nd or 3rd trimester (38).\n\nEvolutional changes have been observed in _B. pertussis_ that may have had a role in the organism's ability to persist in a highly immunized population. Despite the genetically monomorphic nature of the pathogen without horizontal acquisition of new genes, Mooi and colleagues have observed strains carrying a mutation in the gene for the pertussis toxin gene promoter which mediates increased production that was associated with pertussis resurgence (39) and other genetic differences between surface proteins including pertussis toxin, pertactin, and fimbriae (40). Additionally, Lan's Australian group (41,42) have divided _B. pertussis_ isolates into six clusters based on single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). The reemergence of pertussis seemed to coincide with the emergence of SNP cluster 1 of strains carrying pertactin and pertussis toxin genes (prn2 and ptxP3) able to evade acellular pertussis vaccine-induced selective pressure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n35. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics. 2013 Apr; 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.full.pdf+html.\n36. Olin P, Rasmussen F, Gustafsson L, et al: Randomised controlled trial of two-component, three-component, and five-component acellular pertussis vaccines compared with whole-cell pertussis vaccine. Lancet. 1997 Nov 29; 350(9091): 1569-77; abstract available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(97)06508-2/fulltext.\n37. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, Truong ET, Witt DJ: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis. 2013 May; 56(9): 1248-54. doi: 10.1093/cid/cit046; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23487373\n38. CDC. Updated recommendations for use of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) in pregnant women - Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR 2013; 62(07): 131-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6207a4.htm.\n39. Mooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009; 15(8): 1206-13; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/15/8/08-1511_article.htm.\n40. Mooi FR: _Bordetella pertussis_ and vaccination: the persistence of a genetically monomorphic pathogen. Infect Genet Evol. 2010; 10(1): 36-49. doi: 10.1016/j.meegid.2009.10.007; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19879977.\n41. Lam C, Octavia S, Bahrame Z, et al: Selection and emergence of pertussis toxin promoter ptxP3 allele in the evolution of _Bordetella pertussis_. Infect Genet Evol. 2012; 12: 492-5. doi: 10.1016/j.meegid.2012.01.001; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22293463.\n42. Octavia S, Sintchenko V, Gilbert G, et al: Newly emerging clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ carrying prn2 and ptxP3 alleles implicated in Australia pertussis epidemic in 2008-2010. J Infect Dis. 2012; 205:1220-1224; J Infect Dis. 2012 Apr 15;205(8):1220-4. doi: 10.1093/infdis/jis178; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22416243.'\n\nTwo additional observations have been made following the writing of the piece above:\n- If pregnant women were not immunized: it is reasonable to immunize them in the immediate postpartum period prior to discharge (1) although this does not optimize the baby's protection since there is no transplacental transfer of maternal antibodies (Yeh S, Mink C, Kim M, et al: Effectiveness of hospital-based postpartum procedures on pertussis vaccination among postpartum women. Am J Obstet Gynecol 2014; 210: e1-6; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24096180).\n- Lam's group in Australia furthered their observations about pertactin-deficient pertussis isolates are not clonal, and have arose independently multiple times since 2008. This is consistent with vaccine pressure involved with the continued evolution of the organism (Lam C, Octavia S, Ricafort L, et al: Rapid increase in pertactin-deficient _Bordetella pertussis_ isolates, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(4); available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1478_article.htm. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Despite the genetically monomorphic nature of the pathogen without horizontal acquisition of new genes, Mooi and colleagues have observed strains carrying a mutation in the gene for the pertussis toxin gene promoter which mediates increased production that was associated with pertussis resurgence (39) and other genetic differences between surface proteins including pertussis toxin, pertactin, and fimbriae (40). The reemergence of pertussis seemed to coincide with the emergence of SNP cluster 1 of strains carrying pertactin and pertussis toxin genes (prn2 and ptxP3) able to evade acellular pertussis vaccine-induced selective pressure. The total number of suspected cases has reached 58, of which 2 were fatal. All identified cases are being treated.\n\nWHO provided technical and operational support to a rapid response team from the Epidemiology Department of the State Ministry of Health. The team is conducting an active search for cases. Coordination with the Expanded Programme on Immunisation is underway to revise the vaccination coverage in the area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The morbidity and mortality of pertussis is age-related. The major at-risk cohort are unimmunized infants less than 12 months, especially under 6 months.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1A1E. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\n Date: Sat 2 Nov 2013\n \n\nWHO provided technical and operational support to a rapid response team from the Epidemiology Department of the State Ministry of Health.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2140560", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2140560", "date": "2013-12-29 21:49:19", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] Illinois\n[3] Idaho (Bannock County)\n[4] Pennsylvania (Lancaster County)\n[5] Acellular vaccine non-protection issues\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Fri 27 Dec 2013\nSource: NBC San Diego [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/San-Diego-Cases-of-Pertussis-Whooping-Cough-Double-237339681.html\n\n\nThere has been a major increase in the number of cases of whooping cough across San Diego County in 2013, up double from 2012's count, according to the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency (HHSA). So far, 334 local cases of pertussis have been reported, including 12 new cases in local school districts. Compare that to 165 cases reported in San Diego County in 2012. According to the HHSA, the dozen new cases of whooping cough involved patients between the ages of 6 and 16. All but the one case involved patients with up-to-date immunizations.\n\nGiven the up-tick in pertussis cases, county public health officer Wilma Wooten, MD, MPH says it's important for locals to be up-to-date on their vaccines and booster shots. 'It's likely that activity levels will remain elevated in the region,' Wooten said.\n\nIn order to combat whooping cough, the CDC says children should get doses of the DtaP vaccine at the ages of 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. The CDC also recommends that preteens and adults get a Tdap booster shot. Individuals without medical insurance can get the shot from a County Public Health Center at no cost.\n\nNow, while cases of pertussis have doubled this year [2013], the HHSA says the current number of cases is much lower than the record-setting number reported in 2010. That year, a total of 1179 cases of whooping cough were reported across the county, 2 of which resulted in infant deaths. In 2011, the number declined substantially, with a total of 400 cases reported in San Diego County.\n\n[Byline: Monica Garskel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Illinois\nDate: Fri 27 Dec 2013\nSource: WICS [edited]\nhttp://www.wics.com/news/top-stories/stories/vid_14853.shtml\n\n\nAccording to the Illinois Department of Public Health, 2012 was the state's largest outbreak of whooping cough since 1950. Doctors admit cases have been growing because the bacterium has spread to unvaccinated adults. It's that time of year when coughs and sniffles return, but it's what the cough sounds like that doctors say is a cause for concern. Whooping cough isn't just for kids anymore.\n\n'Our older pertussis vaccines gave children a lot of side effects, local side effects, so they came out with a purified version. It's much safer, but the effect seems to wear off,' said Dr. Steven Bowers of Memorial Health System. That means many adults are susceptible to whooping cough, even if you had a vaccine years ago. For those who keep up to date on vaccinations, you may be covered.\n\nIn 2012, Illinois reported more than 2000 whooping cough cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Idaho (Bannock County)\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2013\nSource: Idaho State Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/state/idaho-schools-close-after-whooping-cough-reports/article_3ae5fbf4-14b6-5ab8-814e-2bbef347fc04.html\n\n\nSchools in eastern Idaho's Marsh Valley district have closed for the winter break 2 days early after several students were diagnosed with whooping cough.\n\nDistrict Superintendent Marvin Hansen told The Idaho State Journal (http://bit.ly/SxHTxs) that the health department notified the school this week that there were as many as 7 confirmed cases of pertussis, commonly called whooping cough, in the district. To keep the infectious illness from spreading, schools closed on 19 Dec 2013. Students will return to class on 6 Jan 2014.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Pennsylvania (Lancaster County)\nDate: Sat 21 Dec 2013\nSource: Lancaster Online [edited]\nhttp://lancasteronline.com/article/local/934371_4-whooping-cough-cases-in-Pequea-Valley-schools.html\n\n\nFor the 2nd time in a month, a Lancaster County school district is experiencing an outbreak of whooping cough.\n\nPequea Valley School District has 4 confirmed cases of the illness, explained a letter written to parents and guardians from Superintendent Erik Orndorff, who could not be reached for comment on Saturday [21 Dec 2013]. The district's website, http://www.pvsd.k12.pa.us, includes a notice on the outbreak as well.\n\nIn November 2013, Penn Manor School District had 3 cases of the infection. The CDC website said there were 1945 confirmed cases of pertussis in Pennsylvania last year [2012] and 48 277 nationwide.\n\n[Byline: Paula Wolf]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Acellular vaccine non-protection issues\nDate: Sun 2 Dec 2013\nSource: Medscape [edited]\nhttp://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/815247\n\n\nAcellular pertussis vaccines protected against disease but did not prevent infection and transmission, whereas whole-cell vaccines were more effective, according to findings from a primate model study published on 25 Nov 2013 in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.\n\n'There were 48 000 [pertussis] cases reported [in the USA] in 2012 despite high rates of vaccination,' Anthony S. Fauci, MD, director of the NIH's National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said in a news release. 'This resurgence suggests a need for research into the causes behind the increase in infections and improved ways to prevent the disease from spreading.' Factors underlying increased incidence of whooping cough may include diminished immunity from childhood pertussis vaccines, improved diagnostic testing, and increased reporting.\n\nFindings of the present study may help explain rising USA rates of whooping cough and response to vaccination following replacement of whole-cell vaccines by acellular vaccines in the 1990s. The former contain killed but complete _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria, whereas the latter use only selected portions of pertussis bacteria to stimulate the immune response. Despite concerns about adverse effects of whole-cell pertussis vaccines, they are still used in many other countries.\n\n'Pertussis rates in the USA have been rising,' write Jason M. Warfel from the Division of Bacterial, Parasitic and Allergenic Products, Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, FDA, and colleagues. 'Although pertussis resurgence is not completely understood, we hypothesize that current acellular pertussis vaccines fail to prevent colonization and transmission.'\n\nTo test this hypothesis, the investigators vaccinated infant baboons at 2, 4, and 6 months of age with acellular pertussis or whole-cell pertussis vaccines and challenged them with _B. pertussis_ at 7 months. For infected animals, the investigators quantified colonization in nasopharyngeal washes and monitored leukocytosis and symptoms. An unvaccinated control group contracted pertussis. Neither vaccinated group showed symptoms of pertussis, and both vaccinated groups had robust antibody responses.\n\nBaboons immunized with whole-cell vaccine were bacteria-free within 3 weeks, but bacterial nasal colonization was present for up to 6 weeks in baboons that received the acellular vaccine as well as in those that were not vaccinated. Of even greater concern was that the pertussis bacteria were transmitted from baboons that received acellular vaccine to unvaccinated baboons.\n\n'This study is critically important to understanding some of the reasons for the rising rates of pertussis and informing potential strategies to address this public health concern,' Karen Midthun, MD, director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, said in a news release. 'This research is a valuable contribution and brings us one step closer to understanding the problem. We are optimistic that more research on pertussis will lead to the identification of new and improved methods for preventing the disease.'\n\n'While all groups possessed robust antibody responses, key differences in T-cell memory suggest that [acellular pertussis] vaccination induces a suboptimal immune response that is unable to prevent infection,' the study authors write. 'These data provide a plausible explanation for pertussis resurgence and suggest that attaining herd immunity will require the development of improved vaccination strategies that prevent _B. pertussis_ colonization and transmission.'\n\n[Byline: Laurie Barclay]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manuscript discussed is Warfel JM, Zimmerman LI, Merkel TJ: Acellular pertussis vaccines protect against disease but fail to prevent infection and transmission in a nonhuman primate model. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA doi: 10.1073/pnas.1314688110:\n\n'Significance:\nPertussis has reemerged as an important public health concern since current acellular pertussis vaccines (aP) replaced older whole-cell vaccines (wP). In this study, we show nonhuman primates vaccinated with aP were protected from severe symptoms but not infection and readily transmitted _Bordetella pertussis_ to contacts. Vaccination with wP and previous infection induced a more rapid clearance compared with naive and aP-vaccinated animals. While all groups possessed robust antibody responses, key differences in T-cell memory suggest that aP vaccination induces a suboptimal immune response that is unable to prevent infection. These data provide a plausible explanation for pertussis resurgence and suggest that attaining herd immunity will require the development of improved vaccination strategies that prevent _B. pertussis_ colonization and transmission.\n\nAbstract:\nPertussis is a highly contagious respiratory illness caused by the bacterial pathogen _Bordetella pertussis_. Pertussis rates in the United States have been rising and reached a 50-year high of 42 000 cases in 2012. Although pertussis resurgence is not completely understood, we hypothesize that current acellular pertussis (aP) vaccines fail to prevent colonization and transmission. To test our hypothesis, infant baboons were vaccinated at 2, 4, and 6 months of age with aP or whole-cell pertussis (wP) vaccines and challenged with _B.. pertussis_ at 7 months. Infection was followed by quantifying colonization in nasopharyngeal washes and monitoring leukocytosis and symptoms. Baboons vaccinated with aP were protected from severe pertussis-associated symptoms but not from colonization, did not clear the infection faster than naive animals, and readily transmitted _B. pertussis_ to unvaccinated contacts. Vaccination with wP induced a more rapid clearance compared with naive and aP-vaccinated animals. By comparison, previously infected animals were not colonized upon secondary infection. Although all vaccinated and previously infected animals had robust serum antibody responses, we found key differences in T-cell immunity. Previously infected animals and wP-vaccinated animals possess strong _B. pertussis_- specific T helper 17 (Th17) memory and Th1 memory, whereas aP vaccination induced a Th1/Th2 response instead. The observation that aP, which induces an immune response mismatched to that induced by natural infection, fails to prevent colonization or transmission provides a plausible explanation for the resurgence of pertussis and suggests that optimal control of pertussis will require the development of improved vaccines.'\n\nMore evidence continues to accumulate regarding issues revolving around the protective efficacy of the current acellular pertussis vaccines and the need for an improvement in the current product. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "\n\nTo test this hypothesis, the investigators vaccinated infant baboons at 2, 4, and 6 months of age with acellular pertussis or whole-cell pertussis vaccines and challenged them with _B. pertussis_ at 7 months. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Medscape [edited]\nhttp://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/815247\n\n\nAcellular pertussis vaccines protected against disease but did not prevent infection and transmission, whereas whole-cell vaccines were more effective, according to findings from a primate model study published on 25 Nov 2013 in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n The observation that aP, which induces an immune response mismatched to that induced by natural infection, fails to prevent colonization or transmission provides a plausible explanation for the resurgence of pertussis and suggests that optimal control of pertussis will require the development of improved vaccines.' \n\n'While all groups possessed robust antibody responses, key differences in T-cell memory suggest that [acellular pertussis] vaccination induces a suboptimal immune response that is unable to prevent infection,' the study authors write. ' To test our hypothesis, infant baboons were vaccinated at 2, 4, and 6 months of age with aP or whole-cell pertussis (wP) vaccines and challenged with _B.. pertussis_ at 7 months. Pertussis has reemerged as an important public health concern since current acellular pertussis vaccines (aP) replaced older whole-cell vaccines (wP). Although pertussis resurgence is not completely understood, we hypothesize that current acellular pertussis vaccines fail to prevent colonization and transmission.' Baboons vaccinated with aP were protected from severe pertussis-associated symptoms but not from colonization, did not clear the infection faster than naive animals, and readily transmitted _B. pertussis_ to unvaccinated contacts. \n\nFindings of the present study may help explain rising USA rates of whooping cough and response to vaccination following replacement of whole-cell vaccines by acellular vaccines in the 1990s. \n\nDistrict Superintendent Marvin Hansen told The Idaho State Journal (http://bit.ly/SxHTxs) that the health department notified the school this week that there were as many as 7 confirmed cases of pertussis, commonly called whooping cough, in the district. In the following charts, I have contrasted WHO estimates of vaccine uptake in Afghanistan with those of bordering countries [1-3] http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Afghan-Vaccines.png.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA: Infectious Diseases of Afghanistan, 2012. 326 pages, 37 graphs, 1239 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-afghanistan/.\n2. Berger SA: Pertussis: Global Status, 2012. 340 pages, 506 graphs, 401 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/pertussis-global-status/.\n3.
