Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/pertussis-global-status/.\n3. \n\nReferences:\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2301877", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2301877", "date": "2014-03-01 16:10:14", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA\n***************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Virginia (Lynchburg)\n[2] Texas (Dallas County)\n[3] California (San Diego County)\n[4] California (Riverside County) fatal\n[5] Delaware (Kent County)\n\n******\n[1] Virginia (Lynchburg)\nDate: Mon 24 Feb 2014\nSource: WSET [edited]\nhttp://www.wset.com/story/24808757/whooping-cough-cases-increasing\n\n\nMore and more cases of whooping cough are turning up in the Lynchburg area. Just Monday morning, 24 Feb 2014, a local school put up a sign warning that a parent of a child that attends came down with the illness. The Lynchburg Health Department says they have seen an outbreak of pertussis, or whooping cough, since November 2013. There are cases in every age group from infants to the elderly, but officials say more often than not it is adults that spread the disease. 'We've had more cases than expected in this area,' said District\nEpidemiologist Haley Phillips Evans.\n\nHealth experts say it's not necessarily kids that spread the disease. 'Half of the kids that get whooping cough an adult brings them the illness,' said Dr Thomas Eppes.\n\n[Byline: Katie Brooke]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Virginia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/awei.\nLynchburg can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Texas\nDate: Wed 19 Feb 2014\nSource: Dallas (TX) News [edited]\nhttp://www.dallasnews.com/news/metro/20140219-whooping-cough-cases-soared-in-dallas-county-last-year.ece?nclick_check=1\n\n\nAny way you look at it, 2013 was a bad year for whooping cough. Dallas County counted the most cases of whooping cough, also called pertussis, in more than 2 decades with 404. Texas had to go back to the 1950s to find more cases than the 3908 confirmed last year [2013]. Its previous record was 5842 in 1959. But Tarrant County topped even that terrible distinction. Its 697 cases in 2013 beat the whooping cough record set there in 1940.\n\n'It was an awful year,' said Russell Jones, Tarrant County's chief epidemiologist. 'We had the most pertussis cases of every county in Texas.'\nOther counties reported high numbers including Denton County with 312 and Collin with 203.\n\nJones blamed the spike on the cyclical nature of pertussis. The respiratory disease reappears annually with a noticeable increase in cases every 3 to 5 years. 5 years ago, Tarrant recorded 312 pertussis cases, Jones said. The county's previous record was set almost a decade before a vaccine became available for the disease.\n\nTo stem a repeat in 2014, local officials hope to encourage residents to update their immunizations against the disease.\n\n[Byline: Sherry Jacobson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at < >. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/texas.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Wed 19 Feb 2014\nSource: San Diego 6 [edited]\nhttp://www.sandiego6.com/story/22-new-cases-of-pertussis-reported-in-san-diego-county-last-week-20140219\n\n\nAccording to the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency, 22 new cases of pertussis were reported in San Diego County last week [week of 10 Feb 2014], including 8 cases at locations where others may have been exposed to the disease.\n\nCases where others were exposed, include:\n- a 5-year-old at Adams Elementary School in the San Diego Unified School District;\n- a 7-year-old at Richland Elementary School in the San Marcos Unified School District;\n\u00b7 An 11-year-old at High Tech Middle School in San Diego Unified School District;\n- a 12-year-old at El Camino Creek Elementary School in the Encinitas Union School District;\n- a 12-year-old at Greenfield Middle School in the Cajon Valley Union School District;\n- a 14-year-old at High Tech High Media Arts charter school in the San Diego Unified School District;\n- a 16-year-old at La Jolla Country Day School;\n- an individual at Love to Dance studio in Carmel Valley\n\nThe number of cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, reported in the county now stands at 83 for the year [2014]. There were 430 cases reported in 2013, 165 in 2012, and 1179 cases in 2010.\n\n'We are continuing to see high levels of pertussis activity throughout the county,' said Wilma Wooten, MD, MPH, county public health officer. 'Being up-to-date on your vaccinations continues to be your best defense against the disease.'\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that children get doses of DTaP vaccine at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. Health officials also recommend that preteens and adults get a Tdap booster. Infants younger than 1-year-old are especially vulnerable because they cannot have the full five-dose series of pertussis vaccinations.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/3DHP.\nA county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California (Riverside County) fatal\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: My Desert [edited]\nhttp://www.mydesert.com/viewart/20140207/NEWS08/302070016/Two-month-old-Riverside-County-dies-from-whooping-cough\n\n\nA Riverside County infant died of complications related to whopping cough, in the 1st known fatal case in the state in 2014, health officials said Friday [7 Feb 2014]. According to the Riverside County Department of Public Health, the 2-month-old had not been vaccinated for whooping cough, also known as pertussis, nor had the infant's mother received a booster shot while she was pregnant. The child was not identified, though county health department Communicable Diseases Specialist Barbara Cole confirmed the infant was from the southwest county area.\n\n'This serves as a sad reminder that illnesses like whooping cough are still very much with us, and immunizations are the 1st line of defense,' said Dr Cameron Kaiser, public health officer for Riverside County.\n\n'We strongly encourage pregnant women to get vaccinated, all parents to vaccinate their children on time, and for adults to keep current with their booster shots to reduce the spread of the disease.'\n\nCalifornia Department of Public Health Director Dr Ron Chapman said pregnant mothers can get a pertussis booster by their 3rd trimester. 'Preventing deaths in infants by ensuring that all pregnant women get vaccinated is our primary goal in pertussis control,' Chapman said. When pregnant women are vaccinated, the immunity they develop against pertussis is passed to their infants and helps protect infants until they are old enough to be vaccinated themselves. Young infants are at the greatest risk of severe or fatal pertussis.'\n\nHealth officials noted that whooping cough cases had moderated since peaking in 2010, when 9100 cases and 10 deaths were reported in California. However, the number of infections began to surge again last summer, and 83 percent of those with symptoms were youths under 18 --12 percent of whom were infants less than 6 months old, according to the state.\n\nOfficials said children need 5 doses of pertussis vaccine before they reach kindergarten, while adults should be inoculated if they're in regular contact with toddlers or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Delaware (Kent County)\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: Delaware Online [edited]\nhttp://www.delawareonline.com/article/20140208/HEALTH/302080029/Whooping-cough-hits-Kent-County-Amish-community\n\n\nA total of 48 people living in an Amish community in western Kent County have been infected with whooping cough, a highly contagious bacterial illness that causes violent coughing and can be fatal in infants. 80 percent of the cases are in children age 10 and younger, said Dr Karyl Rattay, director of the Delaware Division of Public Health. 25 of the cases have occurred in infants through age 6, while 15 are ages 7 to 10. The rest are older youth or adults. So far, no cases have been identified outside the Amish community. Students from at least 3 schools have fallen ill. There have been no deaths or hospitalizations, and none of those sickened is seriously ill. 'It is the youngest that we are the most concerned with,' she said.\n\nIn Delaware, there were 57 cases in 2012 and 29 in 2011, according to DPH's communicable diseases statistics.\n\nRattay said DPH held an immunization clinic in the Amish community this past week with vaccinations available. The community has been supportive and helpful, with one of the elders opening their home as a meeting place for community education, antibiotics and vaccinations. 'Because of that, we believe we're going to be able to keep this well contained. They've been helping us with the investigation and ensuring that communications are reaching individuals, so we can get treatment and vaccines to individuals in the community,' Rattay said.\n\nIn 2004-2005, there was a bigger outbreak of pertussis in the Kent County Amish community, resulting in 345 identified cases, mostly among school-age children.\n\n[Byline: Jeff Montgomery, Kelly Bothum]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Delaware can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1kc*. Kent County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/delaware.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 percent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000 there were 11.8 percent with pneumonia, 1.4 percent with seizures, 0.2 percent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 percent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 percent, 8.6 percent, 0.7 percent, 0.1 percent, and less than 0.1 percent in infants 6-11 months of age http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea sometimes with hypoxia-induced seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nImmunization of the immediate family of the pregnant woman as well as of the woman herself are necessary to prevent needless deaths from infant pertussis. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "An 11-year-old at High Tech Middle School in San Diego Unified School District;\n- a 12-year-old at El Camino Creek Elementary School in the Encinitas Union School District;\n- a 12-year-old at Greenfield Middle School in the Cajon Valley Union School District;\n- a 14-year-old at High Tech High Media Arts charter school in the San Diego Unified School District;\n- a 16-year-old at La Jolla Country Day School;\n- an individual at Love to Dance studio in Carmel Valley\n\n \n\nCases where others were exposed, include:\n- a 5-year-old at Adams Elementary School in the San Diego Unified School District;\n- a 7-year-old at Richland Elementary School in the San Marcos Unified School District;\n\u00b7 A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Virginia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/awei. PERTUSSIS - USA\n**************", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1959-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1940-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "5842-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-24 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-11-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-10 00:00:00", "1179-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Denton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kent County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarrant County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarrant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego Unified School District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Riverside County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Collin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1477768", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Afghanistan: (BD), fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1477768", "date": "2013-01-01 23:31:15", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AFGHANISTAN: (BADAKHSHAN), FATALITIES\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 29 Dec 2012\nSource: PakTribune, Pakistan News Service [edited]\nhttp://paktribune.com/news/Whooping-cough-kills-12-children-256076.html\n\n\nThe provincial governor spokesman said 12 children suffering from whooping cough died in a snow-bound district in the northeastern province of Badakhshan.\n\nSpokesman Abdulmaroof Rasekh said the children were between the ages of 1 and 5 years old, and the deaths took place in Shoorian village bordering Tajikistan, located in Nasi Darwaz district of the province. He said local officials learned of the deaths last week. About 350 other children in the area are suffering from the whooping cough epidemic.\n\nThe village remains inaccessible from Afghanistan, so a health team was sent from Tajikistan 27 Dec 2012. The team is now treating the children and providing them nutritious food, Rasekh added.\n\nHeavy snow has blocked access to 12 districts in Badakhshan, and teams are unable to reach other areas with potential health emergencies. Officials have said they will call in the Afghan National Army for help if needed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The scope of this outbreak is not clear. Most pertussis-associated deaths are in quite young, unimmunized children who are in contact with older children or young adults with milder illness. Pertussis mortality can be minimized not only by immunization with trivalent vaccine against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis, but also by early antimicrobial intervention. Large populations of susceptible people in the developing world are the cause of large outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/4H4g.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The scope of this outbreak is not clear. \n\nSpokesman Abdulmaroof Rasekh said the children were between the ages of 1 and 5 years old, and the deaths took place in Shoorian village bordering Tajikistan, located in Nasi Darwaz district of the province. \n\n\nThe provincial governor spokesman said 12 children suffering from whooping cough died in a snow-bound district in the northeastern province of Badakhshan. Most pertussis-associated deaths are in quite young, unimmunized children who are in contact with older children or young adults with milder illness. Dec 2012\nSource: PakTribune, Pakistan News Service [edited]\nhttp://paktribune.com/news/Whooping-cough-kills-12-children-256076.html", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Badakhshan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1590032", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA: waning immunity", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1590032", "date": "2013-03-16 18:57:15", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA: WANING IMMUNITY\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Utah\n[2] Minnesota, Oregon\n\n******\n[1] Utah\nDate: Mon 4 Mar 2013\nSource: Davis County (UT) Clipper [edited]\nhttp://www.davisclipper.com/view/full_story/21844561/article-Adults-also-need--pertussis-vaccine?instance=secondary_stories_left_column\n\n\nPublic health officials have launched a media campaign to 'Stop Whooping Cough' that urges adults to get vaccinated against pertussis before being around an infant. The number of whooping cough cases in Utah jumped 142 percent between 2011 and 2012, health officials say. Concerns, especially for infants younger than one-year old who cannot be vaccinated, were the driving force. The state went from 618 reported cases in 2011 to 1497 in 2012.\n\n'By adults getting vaccinated, they are protecting themselves 1st,' said Davis County Health Department epidemiologist Brian Hatch. 'The other goal, perhaps more important, is to protect those who can't be vaccinated. During the 1st year of life, infants can't be [fully] vaccinated.'\n\nDavis County saw a 456 percent rise in whooping cough, or 139 cases over the year's time, 7 of them resulting in hospitalization, Hatch said.\n\nUtah is experiencing a dramatic increase in the number of pertussis cases. Utah's incidence rate is over 4 times the national average. More than half of infant pertussis cases must be hospitalized, according to a state Health Department press release. 83 percent of those infants were infected by a parent or other close family member. 90 percent of all pertussis deaths occur in infants.\n\nThe campaign is a collaboration by the Utah State Health Department and 9 of the 12 local health departments, including Davis. 'We're actively putting resources into the campaign,' Hatch said. 'We're actively doing everything we can to help control pertussis.'\n\nWhooping cough usually results in minor C but prolonged C illness in healthy adults, but it can be fatal in infants who are too young to be immunized against it.\n\n'So it's important that the adults and older children around an infant be adequately immunized by receiving a quick, easy, and relatively painless Tdap vaccine, according to the Health Department press release.\n\nThe campaign's website, StopWhoopingCough.org, helps visitors find a vaccination location near them. Those who get their Tdap vaccine from a participating health department clinic or at a Harmon's grocery store pharmacy will receive a free infant 'onsie' while supplies last.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[2] Minnesota, Oregon\nDate: Mon 11 Mar 2013\nSource: Daily Rx [edited]\nhttp://www.dailyrx.com/pertussis-vaccine-effectiveness-appears-wear-rates-increased-over-time\n\n\nVaccines save lives by preventing a person from getting a disease or dramatically lowering their risks for the disease. But vaccines are not perfect. Their protection can wear off. A recent study found more evidence that the vaccine for whooping cough is wearing off sooner than researchers expected.\n\nThe researchers in this study found that the risk of catching pertussis among fully vaccinated children in 2 states increased considerably over a 6 year period. The study, led by Sara Y. Tartof, PhD, MPH, of the CDC, aimed to understand how the risk of catching pertussis changed as time passed after children were vaccinated against it. The disease can be fatal to babies, especially those under 2 months old who have not received their 1st vaccine for it.\n\nThe researchers tracked children in Minnesota and Oregon who were born between 1998 and 2003 and had received all 5 shots for the DTaP. These shots start with an initial one at 2 months old, with 4 booster shots following throughout early childhood.\n\nThe study included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children.\n\nIn Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study.\n\nIn Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\n'This rise is likely attributable in part to waning immunity from DTaP vaccines,' the researchers wrote. Past studies in the last year have shown that the vaccine's effectiveness decreases over time more quickly than was expected.\n\nThis discovery of the decreasing effectiveness of the vaccine over time led the CDC's immunization policy group to recommend that pregnant women be vaccinated with the Tdap (the adult version of the DTaP) each time they are pregnant, even if they had the shot within the past 5 years.\n\nThe CDC group, called the Advisory Committee for Immunization Practices, hopes the extra shot during pregnancy will offer a bit of extra protection to the baby during its 1st year of life. The vaccine is still effective in the couple of years after it is given, and babies who receive the vaccine on time will be protected by it from whooping cough. Babies are at the highest risk from dying from the disease.\n\nThe study was published 11 Mar 2013 in the journal Pediatrics.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of pertussis over time tends to have upswing cycles every 3-5 years but the case increases have been greater and more prolonged in the past several years. Utah is just one of a number of USA states including Washington and Wisconsin that have had substantial increase in the disease with, in addition, infant deaths related to cases transmitted by family members. Most up-to-date ACIP recommendations continue to increase vaccination recommendations to order to 'cocoon' the susceptible infant cohort. The most recent recommendations include re-vaccination for pregnant women in the 2nd or 3rd trimester for each pregnancy (1).\n\nIn addition to the Tartlof paper (2), an additional recent publication, currently in press in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilizes a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, CA, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences:\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013;62 (Suppl): 1-19.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis MKenyon C, etal: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013, doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al. Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013 (in press).]", "summary": "As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study. In addition to the Tartlof paper (2), an additional recent publication, currently in press in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilizes a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, CA, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. The researchers in this study found that the risk of catching pertussis among fully vaccinated children in 2 states increased considerably over a 6 year period. \n\nThis discovery of the decreasing effectiveness of the vaccine over time led the CDC's immunization policy group to recommend that pregnant women be vaccinated with the Tdap (the adult version of the DTaP) each time they are pregnant, even if they had the shot within the past 5 years. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of pertussis over time tends to have upswing cycles every 3-5 years but the case increases have been greater and more prolonged in the past several years. In Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. During the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. \n\nDavis County saw a 456 percent rise in whooping cough, or 139 cases over the year's time, 7 of them resulting in hospitalization, Hatch said. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. The study, led by Sara Y. Tartof, PhD, MPH, of the CDC, aimed to understand how the risk of catching pertussis changed as time passed after children were vaccinated against it. Tartof SY, Lewis MKenyon C, etal: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013, doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928\n3. \n\n\nPublic health officials have launched a media campaign to 'Stop Whooping Cough' that urges adults to get vaccinated against pertussis before being around an infant. \n\nUtah is experiencing a dramatic increase in the number of pertussis cases. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year. So it's important that the adults and older children around an infant be adequately immunized by receiving a quick, easy, and relatively painless Tdap vaccine, according to the Health Department press release. \n\n'By adults getting vaccinated, they are protecting themselves 1st,' said Davis County Health Department epidemiologist Brian Hatch. ' By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. \n\nWhooping cough usually results in minor C but prolonged C illness in healthy adults, but it can be fatal in infants who are too young to be immunized against it. [2] Minnesota, Oregon\n\n******\n The vaccine is still effective in the couple of years after it is given, and babies who receive the vaccine on time will be protected by it from whooping cough. More than half of infant pertussis cases must be hospitalized, according to a state Health Department press release. In this posting:\n[1] Utah\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Davis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2135158", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2135158", "date": "2013-12-25 19:21:29", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (03)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas (Nueces County): fatality\n[2] Texas (statewide)\n[3] Wisconsin (Wood County)\n[4] Ohio (Clark County)\n[5] Colorado (Phillips County)\n[6] Pathogen evolution\n\n******\n[1] Texas (Nueces County): fatality\nDate: Thu 19 Dec 2013\nSource: Alice (TX) Echo-News Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.alicetx.com/recordstar/news/article_2cc1463c-a15f-5b73-b353-b5d9ffed96a6.html\n\n\nThe 1st death from pertussis in Nueces County [Texas] was reported by authorities on Wed 18 Dec 2013, just after a press conference held by the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Health District focused on the increase of pertussis cases in the Coastal Bend, and the urgent need of vaccination to prevent the illness. A Corpus Christi baby of 6 months succumbed to the illness after a lengthy battle, having been hospitalized since 28 Aug 2013. Looking back on their records, the Health District states that the baby's death was the 1st in Corpus Christi for 2013, and may have been the 1st area death in over a decade from pertussis, otherwise known as whooping cough.\n\nA report from the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Public Health District states that the level of pertussis cases in Nueces County has been on a recent rise, with 16 cases reported in the area in 2013; 11 of those cases requiring hospitalization. With all of that being said, the fact remains, pertussis is preventable. 'Pertussis is preventable through vaccine and it is of vital importance that anyone who is around a pregnant female receives their pertussis vaccine,' said Annette Rodriguez, MPH, Director of Public Health.\n\nDr Jaime Fergie, Pediatric Infectious Diseases, Driscoll Children's Hospital, further stressed this point, stating that the most important thing to prevent pertussis is for pregnant females to receive the vaccination in their 3rd trimester, and for all other relatives who will come into close proximity with the newborn to receive the vaccination [at least] 2 weeks before the baby is due.\n\nAccording to the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Public Health District, pertussis is an extremely serious respiratory infection, with the pertussis bacteria attacking the lungs and breathing tubes. It causes uncontrollable coughing.\n\nDr Fergie states that the whooping cough infects adults, and can cause many problems, but when a child under 2 (such as an infant who has not built up a tolerance or acquired the antibodies to fight against the infection) contracts the illness, it can be extremely harmful, or even deadly.\n\nThe death reported on Wed 18 Dec 2013 may be the 1st in 2013, but once again, there is a rising trend in cases. Remember to vaccinate early, in order to prevent more severe cases of pertussis.\n\n[Byline: Jimmy Willden]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2Jna. Nueces County and Corpus Christi in southern Texas can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/texas.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Texas (statewide)\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2013\nSource: Brownwood News, Brownwood/Brown County Health Department (BBCHD) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brownwoodnews.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14057\n\n\nPertussis, also known as whooping cough, is on a historic rise according to health officials. As of 16 Dec 2013, Texas has reported 3482 pertussis cases to the CDC for 2013 and has reported 3 deaths due to pertussis. Texas has not seen case numbers this high since 1959. Over the previous 3 weeks, there have been 3 cases of pertussis reported to the Brownwood/Brown County Health Department. The Brownwood/Brown County Health Department encourages the citizens of Brownwood and Brown County to check vaccination records and get vaccinated for this disease.\n\nPertussis is most harmful to young babies and can be deadly. It is very important that pregnant women and caregivers of babies maintain their Tdap [combined tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Cliff Karnes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Wisconsin (Wood County)\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2013\nSource: WSAU [edited]\nhttp://wsau.com/news/articles/2013/dec/20/health-officials-seeing-more-pertussis-cases-in-central-wisconsin/\n\n\nLocal health officials are continuing to see a number of cases of pertussis, or whooping cough. The Wood County Health Department is still seeing infections. Public health nurse Diane Rodd says they've had 31 cases of pertussis so far in 2013. 'Approximately 24 out of those 31 have occurred since 1 Nov 2013. So we are seeing an increase.'\n\nRodd says many of the people being infected are students who are nearly out of date with their shots. 'Because of that, the protection they got in kindergarten is starting to wane, and so they're a little more susceptible.' The early symptoms are much like catching a cold, but the mild cough progressively worsens to severe coughing spells. These coughing spells can include whooping and vomiting. Health officials say the illness can last nearly 6 weeks, and is contagious if left untreated. A course of antibiotics is available to help lessen the length of the disease, and Rodd says they need to do their job. 'We want to make sure people go through the entire cycle of antibiotics before going out into the public.'\n\n[Byline: Raymond Neupert]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Wisconsin can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/9BMx. Wood County in central Wisconsin can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] Ohio (Clark County)\nDate: Sun 8 Dec 2013\nSource: Springfield (OH) News Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.springfieldnewssun.com/news/news/local/clark-pertussis-cases-still-rising/ncDhn/\n\n\nThe outbreak of pertussis cases in Clark County follows a national trend that shows that whooping cough rates reached a 50-year high in 2012. Clark County has had a record 117 confirmed and suspected cases of pertussis since 1 Oct 2013, up from 98 before the Thanksgiving holiday [28 Nov 2013], Clark County Combined Health District Director Charles Patterson said. Patterson expressed frustration Friday [6 Dec 2013] after announcing the pertussis outbreak continued to climb in the area. 'There is some frustration because, if one family with the disease has extended family of 10 people, and each of them spread it to 5 or 10 people, it makes it difficult to stop,' Patterson said.\n\nIn 2013, Ohio has seen a 20 percent increase in reported pertussis cases, compared to 2012. As of 2 Nov 2013, there had been 901 cases reported in 2013, compared with 742 on the same date in 2012. Clark, Madison, Pickaway, Licking, Delaware, and Richland counties have the highest rates of the disease statewide, according to the Ohio Department of Health.\n\n[Byline: Tiffany Y Latta]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/9BMy. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/ohio.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Colorado (Phillips County)\nDate: Fri 6 Dec 2013\nSource: Fort Morgan (CO) Times [edited]\nhttp://www.fortmorgantimes.com/fort-morgan-local-news/ci_24669544/pertussis-infections-rise-northeast-colorado\n\n\nOver the past month the Northeast Colorado Health Department [NCHD] has received notification of 14 positive cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in Phillips County, according to a recent press release.\n\nThe majority of the positive cases are in school-aged children and even though the cases are concentrated in Phillips County at this time, case rates are high across the state. Health officials are urging individuals that have a cough, or have a family member that has a cough, that has lasted more than 14 days to see their healthcare provider, and to make sure family member vaccinations are up to date.\n\n'Pertussis has been circulating at epidemic levels in Colorado for the past couple of years so it's not surprising we're seeing increased cases in our area,' said Dr Tony Cappello, NCHD's public health director, in the release. 'While this infection can just be a nagging cough for some people, it can be very severe and even deadly for infants and others with compromised immune systems. This is not an illness you want to pass on to an infant that doesn't have the immunity to fight it off; whether it be your own grandchild, a neighbor's new baby, or your own newborn.\n\n'It can also be very hard to get rid of once it gets in a community,' continued Dr Cappello. 'Over the course of our case investigations in Phillips County we've had to touch base with several other school districts alerting them to probable exposures at school events. The best thing that people can do if they think they have pertussis is to visit their healthcare provider, stay home if they're ill, cover their cough, stay away from infants, wash their hands, and make sure they're up to date on vaccinations.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/9BMz. Phillips County in northeastern Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[6] Pathogen evolution\nDate: Mon 23 Dec 2013\nSource: Popular Science [edited]\nhttp://www.popsci.com/article/science/whooping-cough-has-evolved-response-its-vaccine\n\n\nThis is not your parents' pertussis. Over the last few years, this once-common childhood illness, also known as whooping cough, has evolved in response to its own vaccine, according to a new study from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe mutated pertussis is not more dangerous than the original, and vaccines against the illness are still effective. So the findings don't change researchers' and doctors' understanding of whooping cough as a public health problem. Instead, they're a glimpse into a fascinating natural phenomenon, and one that's happening as we speak. (Though this isn't the 1st time this has happened. Populations of pneumococcal illnesses changed after the introduction of its vaccine, prompting changes to the vaccine to deal with newly popular strains.) The whooping cough findings have kicked off research to determine whether this is related to the recent increase in whooping cough cases in the US.\n\nPaul Offit, chief of the division of infectious diseases at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, was not involved in the CDC study, but took part in a conference call about the study in which CDC researchers presented their results. He talked with Popular Science over the phone immediately after the call.\n\n'We discussed the data and what the data allow us to say and what they don't allow us to say,' he says. 'The data don't support the notion that the mutants are more virulent.' Babies who fall ill from un-mutated pertussis have the same symptoms as babies who fall ill from mutated pertussis, he says.\n\nThere's also no evidence yet that pertussis vaccines are less effective against the new strains, say all of the researchers Popular Science talked with, both in and outside of the CDC. Everyone recommended Americans continue to get vaccinated right on schedule. 'Currently, we know it's the best form of protection we have,' says Lucia Pawloski, the CDC scientist who led the new research. Kids who don't get vaccinated against pertussis are still 8 times as likely as vaccinated kids to get the disease, she adds.\n\nNevertheless, it's plausible whooping cough's changes do affect the vaccine's ability to protect. 'Yes, theoretically, there could be an issue, but we don't have any data to say that yet,' Pawloski says. The CDC is interested in answering this question and hopefully will have data to do so in 6 or 8 months, Offit says.\n\nSo what exactly is different about pertussis nowadays? Since 2010, Pawloski and her colleagues have recorded a sharp rise in the US in strains of the illness that don't make a protein called pertactin. Before 2010, researchers saw only one US pertussis infection, from 1994, in which the bacteria didn't make pertactin. By 2012, the majority of pertussis infections researchers studied were caused by non-pertactin-making pertussis. Pawloski and her team examined 1300 samples taken from whooping cough outbreaks between 1935 and 2012.\n\nPertussis bacteria make thousands of proteins, but pertactin happens to be one of the few included in many forms of the vaccine used in developed countries, including the US. 'We've created this selective pressure,' Offit says, by widely using vaccines with pertactin in them.\n\nWhen the proteins and other molecules in a vaccine enter your body through a shot, your immune system finds them, learns to recognize them, and develops defenses against them. Now, if you ever truly encounter that illness, your body will respond quickly to quash it. If the vaccine contains pertactin and the actual illness doesn't, that means your body is learning to recognize something that's useless to it when it encounters whooping cough.\n\nAll pertussis vaccines used in developed countries have one, 2, or 3 other pertussis molecules besides pertactin, so there's still stuff in there for your body to train on, even if pertactin is now useless. How much of a blow -- if any at all -- losing pertactin deals to vaccines that have other active molecules is still unclear. 'I think at this point it's hard to say exactly what it means for the vaccines' effectiveness,' says Nicola Klein, co-director of the Kaiser Permanente Vaccine Study Center in California. Klein was not involved in the CDC study.\n\nMeanwhile, pertussis vaccines often used in developing countries contain entire killed _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria, so they actually contain perhaps thousands of things the body is able to use to learn to recognize whooping cough. Those vaccines, which are cheaper to make, were discontinued in developed countries because they cause severe, if non-permanent, side effects, such as seizures in babies.\n\nCDC researchers now are looking into whether losing pertactin is related to another phenomenon associated with the increasing popularity of the newer whooping cough vaccines. Recent studies have found that even those kids who get all their recommended pertussis shots -- in the US administered as the DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis] shot -- are vulnerable again to whooping cough at about age 8 or 10. Researchers think the new vaccine is why the US saw more cases of whooping cough in 2012 than it has in any year since 1955. The older shot, with the killed bacteria, protected people for longer. Scientists are unsure what exactly made the tougher stuff longer-lasting, however.\n\nIs pertussis' evolution the answer? That's not certain yet. 'We couldn't say yes or no at this point whether pertactin had a role in the waning of immunity,' Pawloski says.\n\n[Byline: Francie Diep]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Palowski's paper, 'Prevalence and molecular characterization of pertactin-deficient _Bordetella pertussis_ in the US. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2013 Nov 20. [Epub ahead of print] can be found at http://www.asm.org/images/Communications/tips/2013/1213pertussis.pdf.\n\nThe number of cases of pertussis over time tends to have upswing cycles every 3-5 years but the case increases have been greater and more prolonged in the past several years. Utah is just one of a number of USA states including Washington and Wisconsin that have had substantial increase in the disease with, in addition, infant deaths related to cases transmitted by family members. Most up-to-date ACIP (Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices) recommendations continue to increase vaccination recommendations to order to 'cocoon' the susceptible infant cohort. The most recent recommendations include re-vaccination for pregnant women in the 2nd or 3rd trimester for each pregnancy (1).\n\nIn addition to the Tartlof paper (2), an additional recent publication, currently in press in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilizes a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/wk/mm62e0128.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis MKenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013; 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.full.pdf+html.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis. 2013 May; 56(9): 1248-54. doi: 10.1093/cid/cit046; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23487373.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n The best thing that people can do if they think they have pertussis is to visit their healthcare provider, stay home if they're ill, cover their cough, stay away from infants, wash their hands, and make sure they're up to date on vaccinations.'\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2Jna. \n\n\nThe 1st death from pertussis in Nueces County [Texas] was reported by authorities on Wed 18 Dec 2013, just after a press conference held by the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Health District focused on the increase of pertussis cases in the Coastal Bend, and the urgent need of vaccination to prevent the illness. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. As of 16 Dec 2013, Texas has reported 3482 pertussis cases to the CDC for 2013 and has reported 3 deaths due to pertussis. In addition to the Tartlof paper (2), an additional recent publication, currently in press in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilizes a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. Recent studies have found that even those kids who get all their recommended pertussis shots -- in the US administered as the DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis] shot -- are vulnerable again to whooping cough at about age 8 or 10. A report from the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Public Health District states that the level of pertussis cases in Nueces County has been on a recent rise, with 16 cases reported in the area in 2013; 11 of those cases requiring hospitalization. Meanwhile, pertussis vaccines often used in developing countries contain entire killed _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria, so they actually contain perhaps thousands of things the body is able to use to learn to recognize whooping cough. \n\nIn 2013, Ohio has seen a 20 percent increase in reported pertussis cases, compared to 2012. All pertussis vaccines used in developed countries have one, 2, or 3 other pertussis molecules besides pertactin, so there's still stuff in there for your body to train on, even if pertactin is now useless. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThere's also no evidence yet that pertussis vaccines are less effective against the new strains, say all of the researchers Popular Science talked with, both in and outside of the CDC. Public health nurse Diane Rodd says they've had 31 cases of pertussis so far in 2013. ' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Palowski's paper, 'Prevalence and molecular characterization of pertactin-deficient _Bordetella pertussis_ in the US. [6] Pathogen evolution\n\n******\n [Byline: Jimmy Willden]\n\n--\n [Byline: Cliff Karnes]\n\n--\n [Byline: Tiffany Y Latta]\n\n--\n \n\n\nPertussis, also known as whooping cough, is on a historic rise according to health officials. \n\nPertussis is most harmful to young babies and can be deadly. \n\nReferences\n---------- MJ]\n\n******\n Over the previous 3 weeks, there have been 3 cases of pertussis reported to the Brownwood/Brown County Health Department. MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n As of 2 Nov 2013, there had been 901 cases reported in 2013, compared with 742 on the same date in 2012. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/wk/mm62e0128.pdf.\n Researchers think the new vaccine is why the US saw more cases of whooping cough in 2012 than it has in any year since 1955. \n\nIs pertussis' evolution the answer? Date: Fri 6 Dec 2013\n Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013; 131(4): e1047-52.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1959-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Health District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Springfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County Combined", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nueces County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Licking", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phillips County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wood County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1923593", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1923593", "date": "2013-09-05 12:18:42", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Texas\n[2] New Mexico\n[3] Montana\n[4] North Carolina\n[5] Vaccine development\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Tue 3 Sep 2013\nSource: KENS 5, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.kens5.com/news/222217421.html\n\n\nTexas health officials say the number of people sick with whooping cough [pertussis] statewide is on track to reach the highest level in more than 50 years. The Texas Department of State Health Services on Tuesday, 3 Sep 2013, urged people to make sure they are vaccinated against the highly contagious disease that causes a severe cough.\n\nThere have been almost 2000 cases reported so far in 2013 with the annual total likely to surpass the recent high of 3358 cases in 2009. In 2013, 2 infants have died from whooping cough; both were too young to be vaccinated.\n\nThe infection spreads easily through the air when an infected person breathes, coughs or sneezes. While infants are most at risk, people of all ages can get whooping cough.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] New Mexico\nDate: Fri 30 Aug 2013\nSource: Los Alamos Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://www.ladailypost.com/content/more-300-cases-pertussis-reported-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health reported that 331 cases of pertussis (whooping cough) have been reported in New Mexico in 2013.\n\n'Pertussis is very contagious and can cause serious illness -- especially in infants too young to be fully vaccinated,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'Getting vaccinated is the best way to prevent pertussis. The Department of Health recommends that pregnant women and anyone who is going to be around a baby make sure they are up to date on their pertussis vaccination.'\n\nThe counties with the highest rate of pertussis in 2013 are Los Alamos, Taos and Santa Fe. Rates are used to describe disease activity of cases over a given period of time. Rates take into account the different population sizes of demographic groups or geographic areas so that meaningful comparisons can be made between groups and areas.\n\nIn 2012, 898 cases of pertussis were reported in New Mexico; 2 children died that year. No deaths have been reported in 2013, but 9 infants have been hospitalized.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Montana\nDate: Fri 30 Aug 2013\nSource: KPAX, Montana Television Network (MTN) report [edited]\nhttp://www.kpax.com/news/pertussis-reports-pour-in-from-around-mt/\n\n\nTowns and cities across Montana are still reporting cases of the whooping cough [pertussis]. During a health board meeting earlier in August 2013, it was revealed that 225 cases of pertussis were reported between June 2012 and May 2013. That's an average of nearly 19 cases a month -- and 25 more cases were reported in June 2013.\n\nData for the month of August [2013] was not made available in that report, but the Flathead City-County Health Department tells us they are still confirming cases of pertussis in the Flathead.\n\nThe Butte-Silver Bow Health Department is also dealing with an outbreak of whooping cough. Health officials say so far in 2013 there have been 27 cases of pertussis. In 2012, there were only 2.\n\nMeanwhile, Anaconda Deer Lodge County is also seeing a huge increase with 36 diagnosed cases already in 2013. In 2012, there was just one.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 28 Aug 2013\nSource: Healio [edited]\nhttp://www.healio.com/pediatrics/respiratory-infections/news/online/%7B7807cb8d-980c-4c34-899b-63cdd8554a2f%7D/pertussis-outbreak-continues-in-north-carolina\n\n\nAs of 14 Aug 2013, 326 cases of pertussis, including 50 cases in infants, have been identified by public health officials in North Carolina, according to a press release from the state Department of Health and Human Services.\n\n'State law requires that kindergartners and all rising 6th graders be up to date on pertussis vaccination before going to school,' Robin Cummings, MD, acting state health director, said in the press release. 'But as parents are getting their children ready to go to back to school, it is also good for parents to check on immunizations for the whole family. Any adults or older siblings, especially those who will be around newborns, should be vaccinated against pertussis.'\n\nHigh numbers of pertussis cases are being seen in Davidson, Forsyth and Rockingham counties, so the state Department of Health and Human Services authorized those counties' local health departments to provide the vaccine free to anyone, regardless of insurance status.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Vaccine development\nDate: Fri 30 Aug 2013\nSource: Family Practice News [edited]\nhttp://www.familypracticenews.com/news/child-adolescent-medicine/single-article/a-call-for-new-pertussis-vaccines/51384ddff61258ada488ac2e8bc0e23c.html\n\n\nDevelopment of a better pertussis vaccine has emerged as a pressing need in light of persuasive evidence of waning immunity to current vaccines. But can it be done? Can a new vaccine be created that provides enhanced efficacy and longer-lasting immunity without increasing reactogenicity? 'I think it can be done,' Dr. Myron J. Levin said at a conference on pediatric infectious diseases sponsored by the Children's Hospital Colorado.\n\nEvidence of waning immunity to the current 5-dose diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine has convinced some scientists that a better pertussis vaccine is needed. 'The question you might ask is, can we do a better job than nature? After all, pertussis infection doesn't cause lasting immunity, so could we do a better job than nature? I think so. And here's an example: We know that antibody is protective against HPV [human papillomavirus], and that the HPV vaccine gives a much stronger antibody response, often by 100-fold, than does natural infection with HPV,' observed Dr. Levin, who led development of the shingles vaccine.\n\nConvincing evidence of waning immunity to the current 5-dose diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine series completed before age 7 years in the USA comes from research conducted at the Kaiser Permanente Vaccine Study Center in Oakland, California. The investigators analyzed the large California pertussis outbreak of 2010. Their case-control study showed that the protection provided by the DTaP vaccine was short-lived, such that each year after completing the 5th dose the likelihood of developing PCR-proven pertussis climbed by an average of 42 percent (N. Engl. J. Med. 2012;367:1012-9). Thus, they calculated that if the initial effectiveness of DTaP was 90 percent, it would drop to a mere 42 percent 5 years after the 5th and final dose. In addition, there is a strong argument that the original estimate of the vaccine's efficacy of about 85 percent was inflated due to the case definition used. The efficacy rate after 5 years becomes disturbingly low if the actual efficacy rate was roughly 7 percent, as many now believe, noted Dr. Levin, professor of pediatrics and medicine at the University of Colorado, Denver.\n\nThe whole-cell pertussis vaccines were clearly more effective than the DTaP, which began replacing them in the early 1990s. In another Kaiser Permanente study that zeroed in on the transition period between the use of whole-cell pertussis vaccine and DTaP, patients who contracted PCR-confirmed pertussis did so an average of 14.7 years after receiving their last dose in the series if they received one or more doses of whole-cell vaccine compared with a mere 5.6 years after the last dose if they got the all-DTaP series.\n\nThe national switch to DTaP was carried out because the vaccine has fewer adverse effects than does the whole-cell pertussis vaccine. Components of whole-cell vaccines, including lipopolysaccharides and internal proteins, were important in signaling the innate immune system to shape a more robust response. Unfortunately, these whole-cell vaccine components also trigger unwanted reactogenic local and systemic effects.\n\n'Whenever a vaccine is cleaned up to decrease side effects, there is a great likelihood that the efficacy will be affected. This is almost certainly the case with acellular pertussis, and probably with the split-product flu vaccines as well. I would say we need to learn why the whole-cell pertussis vaccine was so effective -- which component was most important in directing the immune response -- and see if we can separate that from the side effects. This is a research issue,' said Dr. Levin.\n\nPossible ways to create a better DTaP vaccine might involve incorporating a detoxified lipopolysaccharide or adding additional adjuvants to increase the innate immune response to the pertussis antigen.\n\nVaccine development takes time. In the interim, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices of the CDC has taken steps to deal with the nation's worsening pertussis epidemic outbreak. Because the herd protection effect is probably low, a 'cocooning' strategy has been adopted. This involves targeted immunization of pregnant women and all close contacts of their babies during the 1st year of life, when pertussis has its highest morbidity and mortality. In addition, an adolescent dose of pertussis vaccine has been introduced. And consideration is being given to the possibility of universal once-per-decade booster doses in adults, but this has thus far been rejected as not being cost-effective.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Jancin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences:\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013;62 (Suppl): 1-19.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013, doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013;56:1248-1254. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In another Kaiser Permanente study that zeroed in on the transition period between the use of whole-cell pertussis vaccine and DTaP, patients who contracted PCR-confirmed pertussis did so an average of 14.7 years after receiving their last dose in the series if they received one or more doses of whole-cell vaccine compared with a mere 5.6 years after the last dose if they got the all-DTaP series. \n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine.
