Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< In this posting:\n[1] Texas\n In 2012, there was just one.\n\n--\n PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n Health officials say so far in 2013 there have been 27 cases of pertussis. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Bruce Jancin]\n\n--\n This involves targeted immunization of pregnant women and all close contacts of their babies during the 1st year of life, when pertussis has its highest morbidity and mortality.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-08-25 00:00:00", "2013-08-14 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2013-05-25 00:00:00", "2013-09-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Forsyth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lodge County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Davidson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oakland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Alamos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1400201", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Colombia: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1400201", "date": "2012-11-08 16:42:19", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - COLOMBIA: ALERT\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Nov 2012\nSource: Aporrea.org [in Spanish, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.aporrea.org/internacionales/n217707.html\n\n\nWhooping cough [pertussis], a highly contagious infectious disease that can be prevented with vaccination in children, resurfaced in Bogota and this year [2012] has already caused the deaths of 23 children younger than 5 years. The District Department of Health [SDS by its Spanish initials] confirmed that this number almost doubles the 14 fatal cases recorded in 2011. Most of the victims were younger than one year, according to SDS epidemiologist Patricia Arce.\n\nThe National Institute of Health [INS by its Spanish initials] in turn reported that between January and September 2012, 589 cases of pertussis were confirmed in Bogota, 21 percent of all cases diagnosed in the country. Bogota is 2nd to Antioquia, with the most confirmed cases, mostly in children under 5 years.\n\nThe concern of health authorities is that pertussis is easily transmitted by saliva droplets when you cough or sneeze.\n\nIn Bogota, most sick children were infected by their parents. 'Newborns are most susceptible to infection because their immune system still does not have enough defenses against disease,' explained Arce.\n\nSome health experts questioned the reemergence of pertussis, since a vaccine has been available for 50 years, and there are teams in the city which supposedly visit households to identify children requiring completion of their vaccination schedule. [But many were in children who were too young to be vaccinated. - Mod.JW].\n\nPertussis is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. It is transmitted by the respiratory route, has an incubation period of 6 to 20 days, and can last an average of 7 weeks or more. It begins with a catarrhal phase, and its characteristic symptom is persistent cough or wheezing with noise, which makes breathing difficult. In children, it can lead to breathing difficulties that last [for several] seconds, making them turn blue or purple and requiring urgent care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2012 has been a dramatic year for pertussis throughout most of the world. Although there is some evidence for genetic changes in the strains, it is clear that the less reactogenic acellular pertussis vaccine has a shorter length of protection than the older whole cell, killed vaccine.\n\nAs is reported in this posting, much of the morbidity and mortality with this infection is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, when they are not yet protected by active immunization. To protect this susceptible cohort, all care givers should have been given a TDap booster, and the pregnant mother should also be immunized in the 2nd or 3rd trimester to transplacentally provide maternal antibody. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.aporrea.org/internacionales/n217707.html\n\n\nWhooping cough [pertussis], a highly contagious infectious disease that can be prevented with vaccination in children, resurfaced in Bogota and this year [2012] has already caused the deaths of 23 children younger than 5 years. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2012 has been a dramatic year for pertussis throughout most of the world. \n\nThe National Institute of Health [INS by its Spanish initials] in turn reported that between January and September 2012, 589 cases of pertussis were confirmed in Bogota, 21 percent of all cases diagnosed in the country. Some health experts questioned the reemergence of pertussis, since a vaccine has been available for 50 years, and there are teams in the city which supposedly visit households to identify children requiring completion of their vaccination schedule. \n\nAs is reported in this posting, much of the morbidity and mortality with this infection is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, when they are not yet protected by active immunization. PERTUSSIS - COLOMBIA: ALERT\n***************************\n Although there is some evidence for genetic changes in the strains, it is clear that the less reactogenic acellular pertussis vaccine has a shorter length of protection than the older whole cell, killed vaccine. \n\n--\n In children, it can lead to breathing difficulties that last [for several] seconds, making them turn blue or purple and requiring urgent care.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bogota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1470809", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - UK (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1470809", "date": "2012-12-27 15:49:49", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - UK (04)\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 23 Dec 2012\nSource: The West Side Story [edited]\nhttp://www.thewestsidestory.net/2012/12/23/whooping-cough-outbreak-continues-in-uk/\n\n\nIn the United Kingdom, the largest outbreak in 20 years of whooping cough is taking place. However, experts announced that cases have fallen off slightly. In November 2012, new recorded cases dropped for the 1st time in the past 18 months, but medical experts have warned that whooping cough does generally die down during the winter months, and that could mean there still has not been a peak in the outbreak.\n\nFigures from the Health Protection Agency show 1080 new whooping cough cases in November 2012, compared to more than 1600 during October 2012. Thus far for the year [2012], there have been over 8800 cases of whopping cough, the highest in one year since the early 1990s.\n\nOverall, 14 babies have died from the disease because they were too young to be completely vaccinated, but no deaths were reported in November 2012. Other data show that hospital admissions for the disease in young children have increased steeply over the past month.\n\nIn August of 2011, 22 children younger than 5 years of age had to be admitted to a hospital in England for whopping cough. During August 2012, that number increased to 127 children being admitted for the disease to hospitals in England.\n\nIn the beginning of September 2012, an announcement was made by the Health Department that said pregnant women would be given whopping cough vaccinations to help protect their newborns, who usually do not have vaccinations against the disease until the age of 2 months.\n\n[Byline: Jamie Hacking]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis.\n\nProvisional data indicate that more than 39 000 cases of pertussis were reported to the United States CDC in 2012. The incidence rate of pertussis among infants exceeds that of all other age groups, and the majority of deaths continue to occur among infants younger than 3 months of age. Because much of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, who are not as yet protected by active immunization, the CDC recommends 'cocooning,' a vaccination strategy that aims to protect infants from becoming infected with pertussis by vaccinating individuals who would come into regular contact with the newborn infant. This includes booster immunization of any relatives involved with the infant's care and, most importantly, making sure that the pregnant mother has received Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine during the 2nd or 3rd trimester to provide transplacental protection if she has not been boosted in recent years (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks.html).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1lNY. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Because much of the morbidity and mortality from pertussis is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, who are not as yet protected by active immunization, the CDC recommends 'cocooning,' a vaccination strategy that aims to protect infants from becoming infected with pertussis by vaccinating individuals who would come into regular contact with the newborn infant. In November 2012, new recorded cases dropped for the 1st time in the past 18 months, but medical experts have warned that whooping cough does generally die down during the winter months, and that could mean there still has not been a peak in the outbreak. In the beginning of September 2012, an announcement was made by the Health Department that said pregnant women would be given whopping cough vaccinations to help protect their newborns, who usually do not have vaccinations against the disease until the age of 2 months. \n\nFigures from the Health Protection Agency show 1080 new whooping cough cases in November 2012, compared to more than 1600 during October 2012. The incidence rate of pertussis among infants exceeds that of all other age groups, and the majority of deaths continue to occur among infants younger than 3 months of age. \n\nProvisional data indicate that more than 39 000 cases of pertussis were reported to the United States CDC in 2012. This includes booster immunization of any relatives involved with the infant's care and, most importantly, making sure that the pregnant mother has received Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine during the 2nd or 3rd trimester to provide transplacental protection if she has not been boosted in recent years (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks.html). Thus far for the year [2012], there have been over 8800 cases of whopping cough, the highest in one year since the early 1990s.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-10-25 00:00:00", "2011-08-25 00:00:00", "2012-08-25 00:00:00", "2012-11-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1415845", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Colombia (02): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1415845", "date": "2012-11-19 15:56:15", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - COLOMBIA (02): FATAL\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 18 Nov 2012\nSource: Caracol Radio [in Spanish, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.caracol.com.co/noticias/bogota/cincuenta-menores-de-2-meses-de-nacidos-han-muerto-por-tos-ferina/20121118/nota/1797438.aspx\n\n\nSo far this year [2012], 50 children have died from whooping cough [pertussis], 23 of them in Bogota and 6 in Antioquia [department]. This is a highly contagious respiratory disease in children under 1 year of age in the country.\n\nDeputy Health Minister, Martha Ospina, who referred to the increase of the disease in the country said, 'We have an increase of pertussis in the country, foreseeable within expectations, because since 2010 we have the possibility of carrying out tests that help us determine whether children actually have this disease.'\n\nIn addition, the official said that the goal is to control the death rate from this disease.\n\n'So far this year [2012], 50 children have died from pertussis, of which 54 percent were children under 2 months of age. It is not that they don't have the necessary health measures, but that they were not old enough to participate in the vaccination schedule,' Ospina said.\n\nAccording to Ospina, a timely diagnosis and care at the health centers, coupled with basic hygiene recommendations, such as washing hands, contribute to the reduction of deaths from pertussis in children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The unfortunate death of a significant number of infants in Colombia underscores how important it is to cocoon vaccinate around the, as yet non-protected, infant. This includes booster immunization of any relatives involved with the infant's care and most importantly, making sure that the pregnant mother has received a Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccine) during the 2nd or 3rd trimester to provide transplacental protection if she had not been boosted in recent years. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nDeputy Health Minister, Martha Ospina, who referred to the increase of the disease in the country said, 'We have an increase of pertussis in the country, foreseeable within expectations, because since 2010 we have the possibility of carrying out tests that help us determine whether children actually have this disease.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The unfortunate death of a significant number of infants in Colombia underscores how important it is to cocoon vaccinate around the, as yet non-protected, infant. \n\n'So far this year [2012], 50 children have died from pertussis, of which 54 percent were children under 2 months of age. PERTUSSIS - COLOMBIA (02): FATAL\n********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bogota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ospina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colombia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1217585", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1217585", "date": "2012-07-27 14:01:16", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (06)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Country-wide\n[2] British Columbia\n\n******\n[1] Country-wide\nDate: Wed 25 Jul 2012\nSource: Democratic Underground [edited]\nhttp://www.democraticunderground.com/112720523\n\n\nPertussis is spreading in 4 provinces, infecting as many as 2000 people with a sometimes violent, uncontrollable cough and killing an infant in Alberta, as public-health authorities scramble to boost their vaccination programs.\n\nBritish Columbia's Fraser Valley, southern Alberta, parts of southwestern Ontario and New Brunswick are dealing with severe outbreaks of a disease that was once on the wane, pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, which can be especially deadly if contracted by infants. The USA, meanwhile, appears headed for its worst year for whooping cough in more than 5 decades, with more than 18 000 cases reported so far.\n\nAs health authorities on both sides of the border urge parents to get their children vaccinated, and start offering free vaccine clinics for adults, the outbreaks have fueled debate about the vaccine's effectiveness over time. The latest spread of the disease can be partially explained by parents who shun vaccinating their children. But health officials say a larger issue is at play: Children under 6 years need 5 doses of the whooping cough vaccine, with a booster in their teenage years. Routine vaccination efforts, however, have stopped by the time they reach adulthood.\n\n'We've got waned immunity,' said Doug Sider, Ontario's acting associate medical officer of health. 'We're great at emphasizing childhood vaccinations. We need to do a much better job at emphasizing adult vaccinations.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] British Columbia\nDate: Tue 24 Jul 2012\nSource: The Province [edited]\nhttp://www.theprovince.com/news/whooping%20cough%20outbreak%20slowing%20remains%20concern%20local%20officials/6982432/story.html\n\n\nAlmost 300 cases of pertussis have been reported among Fraser Valley residents in the past 9 months. The recent outbreak, part of the upward trend in pertussis infections in Canada and the USA in the past year, is slowing now but remains a concern for Fraser Health officials.\n\nOf the 295 probable and reported cases, 247 were confirmed as pertussis in laboratory tests since the outbreak's start in November 2011 through 7 Jul 2012, according to Fraser Health spokesman Roy Thorpe-Dorward.\n\n'The number is above the historical average,' he said on Tuesday [24 Jul 2012]. 'There is nothing that is alarming at the moment, but we are going to keep our eye on it.'\n\nB.C. is not the only region dealing with an outbreak this year [2012]. Pertussis has also been a problem in Alberta, Ontario and New Brunswick. The maritime province has seen 1024 reported cases so far in 2012, but no deaths. In Ontario, there have been 260 confirmed cases in 2012. One baby has died in Alberta, where there were 42 cases.\n\nFraser Health statistics show the spike in new cases hitting a high in February 2012 and tapering off significantly since then. In mid-June 2012, the health authority announced the outbreak was now 'decreasing but ongoing,' and noted reported cases 'have significantly tailed off over the past 6 weeks.'\n\nPertussis is most serious in infants under a year old. 'We've had a total of 8 cases in children under age one, which are the ones that are most serious and the ones we worry about the most, but we haven't had any fatalities,' Thorpe-Dorward said.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health has seen 156 confirmed cases in 2012 as of 4 Jul 2012, with 3 requiring hospitalization, but no deaths. There, the outbreak peaked in March 2012, with just 2 to 4 new cases reported per week now.\n\nAccording to Health Canada: 'Pertussis is the most frequently reported, vaccine-preventable disease in Canada.'\n\nThe Fraser Valley outbreak is clustered in Agassiz, Chilliwack, and Hope, where the outbreak began, and over half of all cases have been reported there. Others appeared in Langley, Surrey, Maple Ridge, White Rock, Abbotsford, Burnaby and Coquitlam. The disease has been most widespread among preschool children and their caregivers, according to Fraser Health statistics.\n\nTo date, there have been 52 probable reported cases among children aged one to 4, 43 cases among children aged 5 to 9, 3 cases among children aged 10 to 13, 22 cases among teens aged 14 to 18, 18 cases among youths aged 19 to 24, 62 cases among adults aged 25 to 44, 46 cases among older adults aged 45 to 64, and 11 cases among seniors aged 65 and over.\n\nThere are an estimated 30 to 50 million cases of pertussis globally each year and 300 000 deaths.\n\n[Byline: Elaine O'Connor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In this posting, the breakdown of age range does show some cases of pertussis in individuals over 65 years old. These are either people who were not immunized as children or who are waning in immunity for the old whole-cell killed vaccine. It would be interesting to know whether any of the cases in infants were spread from those who had received the old vaccine. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ALd.]", "summary": "To date, there have been 52 probable reported cases among children aged one to 4, 43 cases among children aged 5 to 9, 3 cases among children aged 10 to 13, 22 cases among teens aged 14 to 18, 18 cases among youths aged 19 to 24, 62 cases among adults aged 25 to 44, 46 cases among older adults aged 45 to 64, and 11 cases among seniors aged 65 and over. We need to do a much better job at emphasizing adult vaccinations.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOf the 295 probable and reported cases, 247 were confirmed as pertussis in laboratory tests since the outbreak's start in November 2011 through 7 Jul 2012, according to Fraser Health spokesman Roy Thorpe-Dorward. \n\nFraser Health statistics show the spike in new cases hitting a high in February 2012 and tapering off significantly since then. Vancouver Coastal Health has seen 156 confirmed cases in 2012 as of 4 Jul 2012, with 3 requiring hospitalization, but no deaths. \n\nAs health authorities on both sides of the border urge parents to get their children vaccinated, and start offering free vaccine clinics for adults, the outbreaks have fueled debate about the vaccine's effectiveness over time. \n\nThere are an estimated 30 to 50 million cases of pertussis globally each year and 300 000 deaths. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In this posting, the breakdown of age range does show some cases of pertussis in individuals over 65 years old. PERTUSSIS - CANADA (06)\n***********************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-11-25 00:00:00", "1024-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2065-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Abbotsford", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "White Rock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1196457", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - UK (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1196457", "date": "2012-07-10 17:18:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - UK (03)\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2012\nSource: Daily Mail [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-2171142/Should-parents-fear-whooping-cough-outbreak.html?ito=feeds-newsxml\n\n\nParents will have been concerned by the news last week [week of 2 Jul 2012] that pertussis (whooping cough) is on the rise. There's been a 10-fold increase in the number of cases so far in 2012 compared with the same period in 2010, according to the Health Protection Agency. Furthermore, this outbreak is greater than the last major outbreak, already in 2012 nearly 1800 adults and children have been affected, almost double the number in the whole of 2008 (when cases of the disease last rose sharply).\n\nWhat marks out today's whooping cough outbreak is that the current peak is lasting longer than normal. Worryingly, the outbreak is increasingly affecting young babies for whom the disease can prove deadly, 5 babies have died of it already in 2012.\n\nThe Health Protection Agency (HPA) believes the surge in cases may be partly due to an increased awareness among doctors who have been warned to look out for the disease, but says it could also be due to waning immunity because the effects of the vaccine reduce in time.\n\nIndeed, the rise in cases is occurring despite a good uptake of the vaccination in younger children, 96.3 percent of 2-year-olds have completed their vaccination course against pertussis.\n\n'Cases do increase every 3 to 4 years and this is the case the world over, it seems to be a characteristic of the disease,' says Dr Gayatri Amirthalingam, a consultant epidemiologist at the HPA. 'Our last major outbreak was in 2008 when we had 900 cases, so we were due another one.'\n\nBut what marks out today's pertussis outbreak is that the current peak is lasting longer than normal. 'Normally, the outbreaks of whooping cough are seasonal, peak in the autumn, and are over by the spring,' says Dr Amirthalingam.\n\nThe key to protect yourself is childhood vaccination. The vaccine is not really designed to protect older children or adults, but instead to prevent them from passing the illness to babies. While it can be an unpleasant illness for anyone, whooping cough in infants can be extremely serious, it is fatal for one in every 500 babies who develop it.\n\n[Byline: Lucy Elkins]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The UK, like many of the developed nations, is currently experiencing a significant jump in cases of pertussis resulting in severe illnesses and deaths in neonates. Immunizing pregnant women during the 2nd or 3rd trimester will booster anti-toxin antibodies that will be passively transferred to the fetus and should protect the infant until active immunization is finished.\n\nIt has been suggested (Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands - Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115 and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia - Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) that acellular pertussis vaccines have selected for less vaccine-protective strains. It may well be, however, that the acellular vaccine produces an immunity that more rapidly wanes than that of the old whole-cell-killed vaccine. More information is needed regarding these possibilities. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1lNY.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIt has been suggested (Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands - Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115 and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia - Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) that acellular pertussis vaccines have selected for less vaccine-protective strains. Furthermore, this outbreak is greater than the last major outbreak, already in 2012 nearly 1800 adults and children have been affected, almost double the number in the whole of 2008 (when cases of the disease last rose sharply). \n\nThe Health Protection Agency (HPA) believes the surge in cases may be partly due to an increased awareness among doctors who have been warned to look out for the disease, but says it could also be due to waning immunity because the effects of the vaccine reduce in time. \n\nWhat marks out today's whooping cough outbreak is that the current peak is lasting longer than normal. \n\nBut what marks out today's pertussis outbreak is that the current peak is lasting longer than normal. Indeed, the rise in cases is occurring despite a good uptake of the vaccination in younger children, 96.3 percent of 2-year-olds have completed their vaccination course against pertussis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1190855", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - New Zealand (03): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1190855", "date": "2012-07-06 13:01:52", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND (03): UPDATE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Jul 2012\nSource: Scoop Independent News, West Coast District Health press release [edited]\nhttp://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/GE1207/S00019/pertussis-whooping-cough-update.htm\n\n\nThe pertussis outbreak that was first detected on the West Coast in May 2011 is now being experienced in other areas of the country, including in Canterbury, Nelson-Marlborough, and parts of the North Island. The number of new cases on the West Coast has decreased from the peak in 2011 but is still higher than normal levels.\n\nBetween 1 May 2011 and 22 Jun 2012, there have been 497 notifications of suspected pertussis received by Community & Public Health's West Coast Office. To date, 328 people have been confirmed as having the disease. The difference between the number of notifications and the numbers of confirmed cases indicates that general practices are being vigilant when patients present with a cough of more than 2 weeks' duration. Children under the age of 10 years continue to have the highest rates of the disease.\n\nIn the winter school holidays there may be more Coasters traveling or visitors to the region so the risk of coming into contact with the disease, or it being 'imported' to the Coast is higher. People who are unwell should avoid going to sports events, concerts, or other large gatherings where there is a possibility that they may pass on their illness to others.\n\n'The best protection against pertussis is for babies and children to receive their childhood vaccinations on time,' says Dr Cheryl Brunton, West Coast medical officer of health.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear how many of the cases have occurred in the high risk group, infants under 6 months of age. The commonest complications of pertussis infection, especially in young infants, include apnea (stopping breathing), pneumonia, and weight loss secondary to feeding difficulties and post-coughing vomiting. Seizures and death also occur. Other complications include difficulty sleeping, pneumothorax, nose bleeds, subconjunctival hemorrhage, intracranial hematoma, rectal prolapse, urinary incontinence, and rib fracture. The overall complication rate of pertussis is 5-6 per cent, but among infants younger than 6 months, the complication rate can be 3-4 times that number.\n\nRecommendations on the use of 'cocooning' acellular pertussis vaccines have been developed in an attempt to expand protection in susceptibles to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not yet been adequately immunized. The now recommended use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nSusceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop', after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) has been highlighted in ProMED-mail. This phenomenon reflects antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. If so, these changes may result in a need for modifications to the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines, and without these modifications, selection and further spread of clones not as protected for by the vaccine will continue to increase. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) has been highlighted in ProMED-mail. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The overall complication rate of pertussis is 5-6 per cent, but among infants younger than 6 months, the complication rate can be 3-4 times that number. This phenomenon reflects antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND (03): UPDATE\n************************************\n \n\nSusceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop', after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. If so, these changes may result in a need for modifications to the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines, and without these modifications, selection and further spread of clones not as protected for by the vaccine will continue to increase. The commonest complications of pertussis infection, especially in young infants, include apnea (stopping breathing), pneumonia, and weight loss secondary to feeding difficulties and post-coughing vomiting.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canterbury", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1190876", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (11): (WA) hospital exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1190876", "date": "2012-07-06 13:06:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (WASHINGTON) HOSPITAL EXPOSURE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 July 2012\nSource: KOMO News [edited]\nhttp://www.komonews.com/news/local/Hospital-worker-exposes-hundreds-to-whooping-cough-161381365.html\n\n\nProvidence Hospital [Everett, Washington] officials say one of their own workers may have exposed hundreds of people to whooping cough, and now they're notifying employees and patients to get help immediately. Providence Regional Medical Center has been 'ground zero' for the treatment of pertussis, or whooping cough. But this week it became ground zero for a new potential outbreak.\n\nDr Ahmet Tural is the head of infectious disease at the hospital. He said a hospital employee went to the staff clinic last week [week of 25 Jun 2012] complaining of a nasty cough. He was sent home as a precaution, and on Mon 2 Jul 2012, his test results came back positive for whooping cough. 'He probably had it for about 2 weeks or slightly more, perhaps,' Tural said.\n\nThat means the employee had 2 weeks of direct contact with patients and fellow employees at the hospital. Officials believe at least 53 employees have been exposed to the illness, but that number could end up being more than 300 after factoring in patients and visitors.\n\nThe hospital has been proactive. 'If they had direct exposure, then we automatically require them to be put on antimicrobials,' said Providence official Teresa Wenta.\n\nThe worker in question thought he had been proactive, too. He was vaccinated against pertussis, but it wasn't effective. Tural said sometimes the vaccination just doesn't work. 'In 20, 25, 30 per cent of the cases it may not be fully protective,' he said.\n\n[byline: Jon Humbert]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Exposure and infection of hospital workers with pertussis can be the ultimate nightmare scenario since it can expose unprotected neonates, the major risk group, to the infection. Maternal immunization during the 2nd or 3rd trimester can protect the infant and is now part of 'cocooning' in many countries.\n\nThat the hospital employee had received a booster vaccine against pertussis brings up the selection of less vaccine-preventable clones. Research regarding acellular pertussis vaccination failures by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103), has been highlighted in ProMED-mail. This phenomenon reflects antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. If so, these changes may result in a need for modifications to the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines, and without these modifications, selection and further spread of clones not as protected for by the vaccine will continue to increase. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Washington State can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/2Ikc. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Research regarding acellular pertussis vaccination failures by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103), has been highlighted in ProMED-mail. \n\n[byline: Jon Humbert]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThat the hospital employee had received a booster vaccine against pertussis brings up the selection of less vaccine-preventable clones. PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (WASHINGTON) HOSPITAL EXPOSURE\n****************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Exposure and infection of hospital workers with pertussis can be the ultimate nightmare scenario since it can expose unprotected neonates, the major risk group, to the infection. This phenomenon reflects antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. If so, these changes may result in a need for modifications to the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines, and without these modifications, selection and further spread of clones not as protected for by the vaccine will continue to increase. \n\n\nProvidence Hospital [Everett, Washington] officials say one of their own workers may have exposed hundreds of people to whooping cough, and now they're notifying employees and patients to get help immediately. That means the employee had 2 weeks of direct contact with patients and fellow employees at the hospital.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1220263", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (13)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1220263", "date": "2012-07-30 14:32:43", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA-wide\n[2] North Dakota\n[3] New York\n[4] Maryland\n[5] Montana\n\n******\n[1] USA-wide\nDate: Thu 19 Jul 2012\nSource: ABC News [edited]\nhttp://abcnews.go.com/Health/pertussis-outbreak-worst-50-years/story?id=16814787\n\n\nReported cases of pertussis are at their highest level in 50 years, a top official with the CDC said Thursday, 19 Jul 2012, adding that outbreaks in several states should encourage all children and adults to get vaccinated.\n\nDr. Anne Schuchat, director of National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said doctors across the nation have reported more than 18 000 cases of pertussis so far in 2012. That is more than twice as many cases as there were at this time in 2011 and the 1st time since 1959 that so many cases have been reported by this time in the year.\n\nPertussis, or whooping cough, is a bacterial infection involving the respiratory tract that is easily spread by coughing and sneezing. It can start out like the common cold, but can be a very serious infection, particularly for infants under the age of one, who are too young to complete the full vaccination series.\n\nWhile some doctors say that part of the surge in reported cases can be credited to better diagnostic tests and increased awareness, the casualties thus far underscore a very real problem. Nine infants have died from pertussis so far in 2012 in the USA. The 13-to-14-year-old age group has been hit particularly hard. In Washington State, the number of cases this year [2012] has surpassed 3000, already more than 3 times as many as all of 2011. Washington state Secretary of Health Mary Selecky declared a statewide pertussis epidemic on 3 Apr 2012.\n\nThe vaccine for pertussis, known as DTaP, should be given to all children as a series at ages 2, 4, and 6 months, 15-18 months, and 4-6 years, according to the CDC. An additional booster, known as TDaP, is needed at age 11-12.\n\n'Unvaccinated kids are at 8 times higher risk for getting pertussis compared to kids who have been vaccinated,' said Schuchat. 'Vaccinated kids who do develop pertussis have a milder course. They're also less infectious than unvaccinated children.'\n\nHealth officials added that all adults who have not been vaccinated against pertussis should receive the TDaP vaccine, especially pregnant women and those who will have contact with babies. Pertussis outbreaks generally occur in peaks and waves. Even with vaccination, immunity tends to wane over time.\n\nAn estimated 84 percent of toddlers in the USA have received their complete course of vaccination. However, only 8 percent of adults are currently vaccinated. 'Our biggest work is to get adults immunized,' said Dr. Mark Sawyer, chairman of the CDC's pertussis work group and professor of pediatrics at UCSD. 'This is particularly relevant to pregnant women and new grandparents, who will have contact with infants.'\n\nWhat's unusual is the fact that so many 13- and 14-year-olds are falling ill with the infection. The CDC is looking into whether this could be attributed to a change implemented in 1997 that saw the vaccine used to immunize children change from a version that was taken off the market in the USA because of possible neurologic side effects.\n\nThe CDC is launching an investigation to find out what is contributing to the unusual features of this outbreak. Researchers are also looking at why the protection offered from the current vaccine is not complete.\n\nDr. Gregory Poland of the Mayo Clinic has had personal experience with pertussis, not only as a physician, but also as a father of a child who suffered through pertussis at the age of 13 despite being fully vaccinated. 'When I 1st heard my son cough, I knew he had pertussis,' Poland said. 'Even though I treated him immediately, the cough lasted for 100 days. He literally kept the family awake for months.'\n\nDr. Len Horovitz, an infectious disease specialist at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, is frustrated that despite the prevalence of media coverage, adults are not requesting the vaccine. 'How much relentless coverage and repetition of medical information [does it take] for the public to finally grasp an epidemic?' he asked. 'People aren't listening, aren't watching, or aren't paying attention.'\n\n[Byline: Dr. Laurie Handwerker]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]\n\n******\n[2] North Dakota\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2012\nSource: Grand Forks (ND) Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.grandforksherald.com/event/article/id/241764/group/homepage/\n\n\nNorth Dakota health officials also are seeing a spike in cases of whooping cough, said Abbi Pierce, immunization surveillance coordinator in the Division of Disease Control, North Dakota Department of Health. So far in 2012, North Dakota has more cases of whooping cough than were reported in all of 2011. As of 23 Jul 2012, the health department has received reports of 79 cases, already surpassing 2011's total of 70.\n\nNorth Dakota is in sync with the national trend of sharply escalating numbers of whooping cough cases that is causing serious concern among health care professionals.\n\n'Several states are reporting incredibly high numbers of cases this year [2012],' Pierce said. In North Dakota, 'we're experiencing higher levels of cases but nowhere near the levels they're seeing in Minnesota and Washington State,' she said.\n\nNorth Dakota's highest number of whooping cough cases, 757, was recorded in 2004, Pierce said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1m88.]\n\n*****\n[3] New York\nDate: 22 Jul 2012\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.therepublic.com/view/story/5f708205499f42468aa928c633fad1de/NY--Whooping-Cough-Schumer\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases has tripled in New York, and Sen. Charles Schumer is calling on health officials to provide free vaccinations.\n\nOn Sunday [22 Jul 2012], the senator urged the federal government to work with health officials in every state to make sure adults get vaccinated for free if they haven't been since age 18. He points out the cough is very contagious and especially dangerous if transmitted to young children.\n\nThis could be the worst year for whooping cough in this country in a half century, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. So far this year [2012], 1288 cases have been reported in New York state, 3 times the number from 2011. There have been 187 cases in New York City and 333 on Long Island.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1nEs.]\n\n******\n[4] Maryland\nDate: Sun 22 Jul 2012\nSource: Cecil County (MD) Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.cecildaily.com/news/local_news/article_ad08f7a6-d46c-11e1-9c05-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nMaryland health officials say it appears whooping cough is on the rise. Kurt Seetoo, senior epidemiologist with the Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, said in 2011 there were 123 cases of the disease. In 2012, from 1 Jan 2012 to 30 Jun 2012, there have already been 133,' Seetoo said of the preliminary numbers.\n\nSeetoo said anyone who has contact with an infant should get immunized to prevent transmitting whooping cough. Family members, including grandparents, should get the booster, known as TDaP.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1DmA]\n\n******\n[5] Montana\nDate: Thu 26 Jul 2012\nSource: Montana Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://www.dphhs.mt.gov/publichealth/immunization/documents/MontanaPertussisUpdate.pdf\n\n\nAccording to the DPHHS Communicable Disease Weekly Update (20 Jul 2012), so far in 2012, there have been 355 cases of pertussis in Montana, compared to 66 cases for the same period in 2011.\n\nWith school and athletics beginning soon, DPHHS is encouraging healthcare providers, schools, and sports teams to be aware of our continuing outbreak and consider the recommendations outlined on the attached information sheet.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Hector I. Ojeda-Martinez for contributing this post. - Mod.LL\n\nIn previous postings on pertussis, ProMED has highlighted research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) that has been reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. A recent in-press paper from the CDC (1) has also addressed these antigenic changes and also found the predominance of the fim3B allele but concluded that: 'The changes in vaccine composition and schedule were not the direct selection pressures that resulted in allele changes present in the current _B. pertussis_ population.'\n\nAnother recent paper from the CDC (2) discusses the apparent quicker wane in immunity against pertussis with the acellular vaccine and potential options, including an intranasal, live, attenuated _B. pertussis_ strain (3).\n\nReferences:\n1. Schmidtke AJ, Boney KO, Martin SW, et al: Population diversity among _Bordetella pertussis_ isolates, United States, 1935-2009. Emerg Infect Dis (in press); http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/8/12-0082_article.htm.\n2. Clark TA, Messonnier NE, Hadler SC: Pertussis control: time for something new? Trends Microbiol. 2012;20: 211-213.\n3. Feunou PF, Kammoun H, Debrie AS, Mielcarek N, Locht C: Long-term immunity against pertussis induced by a single nasal administration of live attenuated B. pertussis BPZE1. Vaccine. 2010;28: 7047-7053. - Mod.LL\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJm.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Family members, including grandparents, should get the booster, known as TDaP.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: Montana Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://www.dphhs.mt.gov/publichealth/immunization/documents/MontanaPertussisUpdate.pdf\n\n\nAccording to the DPHHS Communicable Disease Weekly Update (20 Jul 2012), so far in 2012, there have been 355 cases of pertussis in Montana, compared to 66 cases for the same period in 2011. Another recent paper from the CDC (2) discusses the apparent quicker wane in immunity against pertussis with the acellular vaccine and potential options, including an intranasal, live, attenuated _B. pertussis_ strain (3).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1288-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-01 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1959-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TDaP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hadler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Dakota 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cecil County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City and", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1188519", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Argentina (03): (MZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1188519", "date": "2012-07-03 13:25:57", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - ARGENTINA (03): (MENDOZA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Jul 2012\nSource: Diario Uno [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.diariouno.com.ar/edimpresa/2012/07/01/nota304019.html\n\n\nSo far this year [2012], 150 cases of pertussis (whooping cough) have been detected in the province of Mendoza, 71 of them confirmed by laboratory. These numbers are substantially higher than the 5 cases registered during the same period last year [2011]. The disease mainly affects children between 6 months and 1 year of age who are not [adequately] immunized, and in some cases can be life threatening.\n\nFor this reason, the province's Ministry of Health along with Central Vaccination insist on the importance of vaccination to prevent this disease, especially for pregnant women at 20 weeks of gestation and for children starting at 2 months of age, followed by subsequent doses as indicated by the official vaccination schedule.\n\n'Mendoza is also affected by the pertussis outbreak that exists globally and nationally, which in the epidemiological curve is in the red zone,' said the province's head of epidemiology, Adriana Koch.\n\nIn view of this situation, it is essential that pregnant women be vaccinated so that their children can develop antibodies through the placenta, because this respiratory disease, caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, can be transmitted to infants with no defenses when an adult or older sibling is infected.\n\nThe situation is explained in part, because not everyone completes the vaccination schedule properly resulting in the circulation of the bacteria. In addition, immunization wanes after 10 years and revaccination is necessary.\n\n'Whooping cough or pertussis is a respiratory disease very easily transmitted. It is important to note that because neither the natural infection nor the vaccine confer lifelong immunity, several doses of vaccine are required,' says Carla Vizzotti, head of the National Program for Control of Vaccine-Preventable Diseases (Pronacei) of the Ministry of Health.\n\nAt the same time she noted that 'while in adults and adolescents, pertussis is usually not a serious problem, these groups are the source of infection for infants under one year who have a high probability of developing severe complications and even death.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, as in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women to provide passive immunity is a further expansion of these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts small infants have, that the source for the infant is a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected by the current vaccines. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Argentina can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/2GmO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "At the same time she noted that 'while in adults and adolescents, pertussis is usually not a serious problem, these groups are the source of infection for infants under one year who have a high probability of developing severe complications and even death.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, as in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n For this reason, the province's Ministry of Health along with Central Vaccination insist on the importance of vaccination to prevent this disease, especially for pregnant women at 20 weeks of gestation and for children starting at 2 months of age, followed by subsequent doses as indicated by the official vaccination schedule. In view of this situation, it is essential that pregnant women be vaccinated so that their children can develop antibodies through the placenta, because this respiratory disease, caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, can be transmitted to infants with no defenses when an adult or older sibling is infected. \n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. \n\n'Mendoza is also affected by the pertussis outbreak that exists globally and nationally, which in the epidemiological curve is in the red zone,' said the province's head of epidemiology, Adriana Koch. PERTUSSIS - ARGENTINA (03): (MENDOZA)\n*************************************\n \n\n'Whooping cough or pertussis is a respiratory disease very easily transmitted. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected by the current vaccines.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mendoza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1170399", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (05): (ON), unimmunized cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1170399", "date": "2012-06-16 18:31:32", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (05): ONTARIO, UNIMMUNIZED CASES\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jun 2012\nSource: Owen Sound Sun-Times (ON) [edited]\nhttp://www.owensoundsuntimes.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=3585096\n\n\nAn infant and a young child living in southern Grey-Bruce are expected to make full recoveries from pertussis (whooping cough), a contagious bacterial respiratory illness, a Grey-Bruce Health Unit news release said Wed 13 Jun 2012.\n\nThe separate, lab-confirmed cases are not believed to be part of the outbreak in parts of southwestern Ontario, the health unit says. There are outbreaks in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph, Perth, Oxford, Elgin-St. Thomas, Haldimand-Norfolk and the Windsor-Essex areas. People in the households of the local kids involved and high-risk contacts have been offered preventative treatment with antibiotics.\n\nThe release was issued to remind people that immunization is the best protection against whooping cough or pertussis, health unit spokesman Drew Ferguson said.\n\nOne to 3 deaths from pertussis occur each year in Canada, usually in infants too young to have begun their immunization and in partially immunized infants. The Ontario outbreaks occurred among people who were not immunized, typically among Mennonites, Ferguson said. Locally though, the health unit has had success bringing immunization clinics to local Mennonites, he said.\n\n[Byline: Scott Dunn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unlike most if the outbreaks that have been posted on ProMED, it seems that much of the pertussis burden in Ontario, Canada has been occurring in a religious cohort in the province that had not been immunized. - Mod.LL\n\nOntario, Canada, can be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*Y3. - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unlike most if the outbreaks that have been posted on ProMED, it seems that much of the pertussis burden in Ontario, Canada has been occurring in a religious cohort in the province that had not been immunized. An infant and a young child living in southern Grey-Bruce are expected to make full recoveries from pertussis (whooping cough), a contagious bacterial respiratory illness, a Grey-Bruce Health Unit news release said Wed 13 Jun 2012. \n\nThe release was issued to remind people that immunization is the best protection against whooping cough or pertussis, health unit spokesman Drew Ferguson said. PERTUSSIS - CANADA (05): ONTARIO, UNIMMUNIZED CASES\n***************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wellington - Dufferin - Guelph", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1204697", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (12)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1204697", "date": "2012-07-18 13:53:51", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (12)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Oregon (Lake County)\n[2] Nevada (Clark County)\n[3] Washington State (Snohomish County)\n[4] Washington State (Yakima County)\n[5] New York (Steuben County)\n[6] Minnesota (Olmstead County)\n[7] Minnesota (Isanti County)\n[8] Kentucky (Madison & Estill Counties)\n\n******\n[1] Oregon (Lake County)\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2012\nSource: The Register-Guard [edited]\nhttp://www.registerguard.com/web/newslocalnews/28363316-41/health-county-cases-lane-pertussis.html.csp\n\n\nAs pertussis cases continue to climb in Oregon, Lane County health officials have decided it's time to sound the alarm with a town hall meeting. Pertussis is characterized by common cold symptoms that can evolve into severe, rapid coughing spells.\n\nThe infection is a growing concern for health officials in Oregon, who have seen a total of 458 reported cases through Friday, 6 Jul 2012, compared with just 147 by the same time in 2011. Infants younger than one account for 63 of those cases.\n\nOnly 10 of this year's [2012] cases have been reported in Lane County, but officials are concerned that the number could climb. Most of the local cases involve children; the mean age among the 10 cases is 8.\n\n'We are not ready,' Lane County Public Health Officer Patrick Luedtke said Monday [9 Jul 2012]. 'The No. 1 prevention method is vaccination, and our vaccination rates are not high enough.'\n\nAccording to Luedtke, roughly 20 percent of Lane County children age 2 or younger are not vaccinated, about 3500 individuals. Infants younger than 3 months are particularly vulnerable because they are too young to be vaccinated and have not developed enough to properly handle the coughing fits, thus making it much more important for adults to be vaccinated to avoid passing the infection to infants, Luedtke said.\n\n'Whooping cough kills babies, period,' Luedtke said. 'And some people don't know that.'\n\nAccording to state figures, Lane ranks the 3rd highest among Oregon counties with 8.5 percent of residents declining vaccination on religious or philosophical grounds, including those who have concerns about possible side effects of vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Patrick Malee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb.]\n\n******\n[2] Nevada (Clark County)\nDate: Wed 11 Jul 2012\nSource: 8 News Now [edited]\nhttp://www.8newsnow.com/story/18983109/health-district-reports-22-cases-of-pertussis\n\n\nThere have been 22 cases of pertussis reported in Clark County since the beginning of 2012, according to the Southern Nevada Health District. Seven of the cases were in children under the age of one. The health district is reminding parents, health care providers, and child care providers to receive the vaccine.\n\nChildren attending school in Clark County must be [fully] immunized before they can attend kindergarten and [again] prior to entering 7th grade.\n\n[Byline: Caroline Bleakley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1FX1.]\n\n******\n[3] Washington State (Snohomish County)\nDate: Fri 13 Jul 2012\nSource: Arlington (WA) Times [edited]\nhttp://www.arlingtontimes.com/news/162396306.html\n\n\nMore than 2000 new cases of pertussis, also known as 'whooping cough,' have been reported [in Washington State] since the state Secretary of Health declared an epidemic on 3 Apr 2012. The epidemic is up to 2883 reported cases and remains active, especially in Snohomish County, as state health officials urge vaccination and other disease prevention measures.\n\n'Infants are most at risk for very serious illness from whooping cough, and many are made sick by adults who don't know they're carrying the illness,' state Health Officer Dr. Maxine Hayes said. 'All teens and adults should get the Tdap shot. Even people who don't have close contact with babies can spread the illness to babies when they're in public.'\n\nAs of Friday, 6 Jul 2012, the Snohomish Health District had confirmed 408 cases of pertussis in Snohomish County since the start of 2012. 'This includes 6 hospitalizations, 5 of whom were infants,' said Suzanne Pate, public information officer for the Snohomish Health District, who noted that no infants in the county have died from pertussis in 2012, but one infant did die of it in August 2011.\n\nBabies younger than 2 months are not old enough to receive vaccinations and are at high risk for serious illnesses as a result. Statewide, there have been 173 reported cases of whooping cough among infants, 38 of whom were hospitalized.\n\nProtection provided by the childhood whooping cough vaccine series wears off over time, so teens and adults need a booster. People whose vaccine protection wears off may contract whooping cough themselves, but usually suffer from less severe symptoms and shorter illnesses and are less likely to spread the disease to others. Adults who aren't sure whether they've had the Tdap booster should check with their health care providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJo.]\n\n******\n[4] Washington State (Yakima County)\nDate: Thu 12 Jul 2012\nSource: KIMA-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kimatv.com/home/video/250-reported-cases-of-Whooping-Cough-in-Yakima-County-162295826.html\n\n\nThe Washington State Department of Health reports more than 2000 new cases [of whooping cough] since April 2012. Washington only saw a fraction of that in all of 2011. In Yakima, the local health district reports roughly 250 cases. There weren't even 5 cases in all of last year [2011].\n\nThe health district says the vaccines should help uninsured families. In all, 14 000 doses are being sent across the state.\n\n'Each county gets an allotment, and our providers are taking advantage of that, so that tells me they're using it,' said Yakima Health District Community Health Director Sheryl Di Pietro.\n\n[Byline: Michael Spears]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJo.]\n\n******\n[5] New York (Steuben County)\nDate: Thu 12 Jul 2012\nSource: Central NY [edited]\nhttp://centralny.ynn.com/content/top_stories/591338/whooping-cough-problem-in-steuben-county/\n\n\nOnly about halfway through July 2012, and so far in 2012, there have been nearly 50 cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, in Steuben County. That compares to just one all of 2011.\n\nCounty health officials say they aren't entirely sure why the outbreak has occurred but want people to be on the lookout for the signs and symptoms. In adults, whooping cough can appear as the common cold or sinus allergies but is much more serious if contracted by children. About half all of infants who get whooping cough end up in the hospital.\n\n[Byline: Bill Mich]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1nEs.]\n\n******\n[6] Minnesota (Olmstead County)\nDate: Fri 13 Jul 2012\nSource: My Fox 47 [edited]\nhttp://www.myfox47.com/story/18964061/pertussis-still-a-threat-in-olmsted-county\n\n\nPertussis continues to be a problem across Olmsted County. In fact, just in the 1st half of 2012, the county has had 5 times as many cases as in all of 2011.\n\nPertussis will typically peak every 3 to 5 years. While 2012 has been a peak year, it's unique in that the county is still seeing growing numbers of cases this far into summer.\n\n98 cases have been reported this year [2012] in Olmsted County, and the pattern is similar across Minnesota. According to Public Health, there's reason to believe many people are spreading the disease, and they don't even know they have it.\n\n'I do believe there are many people in the community that are unaware of the outbreak of pertussis but also about what the symptoms are,' said Linda Haeussinger of Olmsted County Public Health. 'The primary symptom of pertussis is coughing, and we cough for many reasons, bronchitis, pneumonia, allergies, etc.'\n\nFewer than 10 percent of adults across the country are vaccinated against the disease. That's currently considered the best method of prevention among health professionals.\n\n[Byline: Aubrey Helms]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1Cfy.]\n\n******\n[7] Minnesota (Isanti County)\nDate: Tue 11 Jul 2012\nSource: Isanti County News [edited]\nhttp://isanticountynews.com/2012/07/11/whooping-cough-is-making-rounds-again-in-isanti-county/\n\n\nPertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, is back as a distinct medical concern, with 14 cases in Isanti County since 1 May 2012, reported Public Health Director Kathy Minkler at the 5 Jul 2012 Isanti County Board meeting.\n\n'The biggest concern with pertussis is to protect infants in homes that have been infected, since they can have the most complications with the illness, which include seizures, inflammation of the brain and even death,' warned Minkler.\n\nShe said most of the Isanti County pertussis cases have been among middle school aged children, including 2 that were found in swimming classes. She added that Minnesota is 2nd to California in whooping cough cases in 2012. The bacterial disease, spread person to person through the air, goes in outbreak cycles between 7 to 10 years.\n\nMinkler added that there has been a drop in the pertussis immunization rate this year [2012], perhaps fueled by a fear from side effect reactions. But a new form of the Tdap vaccine was developed over the past 10 years which is showing fewer reactions, Minkler said.\n\n[Byline: Greg Hunt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1Cfy.]\n\n*****\n[8] Kentucky (Madison & Estill Counties)\nDate: Thu 12 Jul 2012\nSource: WTVQ [edited]\nhttp://www.wtvq.com/content/localnews/story/Whooping-Cough-Outbreak/QkovC9ZzxUm3brdC7gG9rQ.cspx\n\n\nThe USA is on course for a record year for pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough, and there are outbreaks being reported tonight in parts of our viewing area.\n\nMore than a dozen cases in recent weeks have been reported in Madison and Estill Counties, according to the respective health departments there.\n\n'We've never had this many cases over the last 5 years,' Judy Collins, Bluegrass Region Epidemiologist says. 'We're in the double digits now, so it's above and beyond what we would normally expect for this time of the year.'\n\n[Byline: Ellen Bryan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1zJq.\n\nIn previous postings on pertussis, ProMED has highlighted research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) that has been reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. A recent in-press paper from the CDC (1) has also addressed these antigenic changes and also found the predominance of the fim3B allele but concluded that: 'The changes in vaccine composition and schedule were not the direct selection pressures that resulted in allele changes present in the current _B. pertussis_ population.'\n\nAnother recent paper from the CDC (2) discusses the apparent quicker wane in immunity against pertussis with the acellular vaccine and potential options, including an intranasal, live, attenuated _B. pertussis_ strain (3).\n\nReferences:\n1. Schmidtke AJ, Boney KO, Martin SW, et al: Population diversity among _Bordetella pertussis_ isolates, United States, 1935-2009. Emerg Infect Dis (in press); http:wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/8/12-0082_article.htm.\n2. Clark TA, Messonnier NE, Hadler SC: Pertussis control: time for something new? Trends Microbiol. 2012;20: 211-213.\n3. Feunou PF, Kammoun H, Debrie AS, Mielcarek N, Locht C: Long-term immunity against pertussis induced by a single nasal administration of live attenuated B. pertussis BPZE1.
