Date: Thu 12 Jul 2012\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2883-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-08-25 00:00:00", "2012-07-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Isanti County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yakima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hadler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Steuben County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Olmstead County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lake County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lane County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Olmsted County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yakima County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arlington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Snohomish County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1161130", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis - UK (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1161130", "date": "2012-06-08 15:08:56", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - UK (02): BACKGROUND\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jun 2012\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail Pertussis - UK 20120607.1159983]\n-------------------------------------------------\nNotwithstanding increasing incidence during 2011 to 2012, the United Kingdom remains a paradigm for the success of pertussis vaccine. In the following graph, I've contrasted reported disease rates vs vaccine uptake: [1-3]:\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Pertus-UK.png.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Berger SA. Infectious diseases in the United Kingdom, 2012. 1029 pp, 797 graphs, 3290 references. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-the-united-kingdom/.\n3. Berger SA. Pertussis: global status, 2012. 340 pp, 506 graphs, 401 references. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/pertussis-global-status/.\n4. Gideon Graph Tool at http://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for his continuing contributions. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Tel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for his continuing contributions. - Mod. Source: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail Pertussis - UK 20120607.1159983]\n Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-the-united-kingdom/.\n3. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/pertussis-global-status/.\n4. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["3290-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1029-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1159983", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1159983", "date": "2012-06-07 14:58:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - UK\n**************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Jun 2012\nSource: Health Protection Agency. Health Protection Report 2012; 6(22) [edited]\nhttp://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/news/default.htm#prtsss\n\n\nConfirmed pertussis in England and Wales: update to end-April 2012\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nA national increase in laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis was observed after the 2nd quarter of 2011, predominantly in adolescents and adults. This increase continued into 2012 and extended into infants under 3 months who are at the highest risk of severe complications, hospitalisation, and death. A level 3 incident was declared in April 2012 to coordinate the response to the ongoing increased pertussis activity (1,2).\n\nPertussis is a cyclical disease with increases occurring every 3-4 years. The increase in 2011 has previously been reported (3), with the last peak occurring in 2008. During 2011, numbers of confirmed cases were high in age groups under 15 years, but in line with anticipated cyclical increases. The number of confirmed cases in the 15+ age group, however, exceeded expected levels; cases in this age group were nearly 50 per cent higher in 2011 than those in 2008. The data below update current pertussis activity to 30 Apr 2012.\n\nThe provisional total of confirmed cases of pertussis in 2012 in England and Wales to the end of April 2012 was 1080, compared with 248 in the same period in 2008 (table 1 [for tables, see source URL above. - Mod.LL]). High numbers of cases continue to be confirmed in individuals aged 15 years or older with 777 cases in this period in 2012, compared with 122 cases in 2008. Activity is also high in infants under 3 months with 100 cases in this period in 2012 compared with 49 cases in 2008. 5 pertussis-related deaths in infants were reported to 30 April 2012 and 3 to 30 Apr 2008.\n\nThis increase in reporting may, in part, be due to increased awareness among health professionals improving case ascertainment in older age groups. This is reflected by the increased demand for serology testing, which is the predominant method of confirmation in adolescents and adults who typically present with milder features late in the course of the illness. However, waning immunity following vaccination and/or natural infection is also likely to be an important contributory factor (4). The increase in pertussis activity has been observed across all regions in England with continuing reports of clusters in educational settings and incidents linked to health care settings. The highest numbers of confirmed cases in the first 4 months of 2012 have been in the South East and the South West regions (table 2 [see source URL above. - Mod.LL]).\n\nReferences/notes\n----------------\n1. A level 3 incident is the 3rd of 5 levels of alert under the HPA's Incident Reporting and Information System according to which public health threats are classified and information flow to the relevant outbreak control team is coordinated. A level 3 incident is defined as one where the public health impact is significant across regional boundaries or nationally.\n2. National increase in laboratory-confirmed pertussis cases in England and Wales. Health Protection Report 2012; 6(15): news.\n3. Laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis reported to the enhanced pertussis surveillance programme (England and Wales): annual report for 2011. Health Protection Report 2012; 6(8): immunisation.\n4. Campbell H, Amirthalingam G, Andrews N, et al. Accelerating control of pertussis in England and Wales. Emerg Infect Dis. 2012; 18: 38-47 [available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/1/11-0784_intro.htm].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in cases in the UK further underscores the research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103), which has been highlighted in ProMED-mail. This phenomenon reflects antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. If so, these changes may result in a need for modifications to the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines, and without these modifications, selection and further spread of clones not as protected for by the vaccine will continue to increase.\n\nIt would be useful to know if older individuals, immunized with the old, killed, whole cell vaccine, have the same level of 'break-through' as those immunized with the acellular toxoid vaccine. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1lNY.]", "summary": "\n\nThe provisional total of confirmed cases of pertussis in 2012 in England and Wales to the end of April 2012 was 1080, compared with 248 in the same period in 2008 (table 1 [for tables, see source URL above. High numbers of cases continue to be confirmed in individuals aged 15 years or older with 777 cases in this period in 2012, compared with 122 cases in 2008. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in cases in the UK further underscores the research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103), which has been highlighted in ProMED-mail. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Activity is also high in infants under 3 months with 100 cases in this period in 2012 compared with 49 cases in 2008. The number of confirmed cases in the 15+ age group, however, exceeded expected levels; cases in this age group were nearly 50 per cent higher in 2011 than those in 2008. Laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis reported to the enhanced pertussis surveillance programme (England and Wales): annual report for 2011. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A national increase in laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis was observed after the 2nd quarter of 2011, predominantly in adolescents and adults. http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/news/default.htm#prtsss\n\n\nConfirmed pertussis in England and Wales: update to end-April 2012\n This phenomenon reflects antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. 5 pertussis-related deaths in infants were reported to 30 April 2012 and 3 to 30 Apr 2008. The highest numbers of confirmed cases in the first 4 months of 2012 have been in the South East and the South West regions (table 2 [see source URL above. A level 3 incident was declared in April 2012 to coordinate the response to the ongoing increased pertussis activity (1,2). During 2011, numbers of confirmed cases were high in age groups under 15 years, but in line with anticipated cyclical increases. As of last Fri 25 May 2012, there were 274 confirmed or probable cases of the infection, according to Auckland Regional Public Health Service [ARPHS], up from 247 on 16 May 2012.\n\n'The outbreak is continuing. It's been with us since the beginning of 2012 and the number of cases is increasing every day,' said Dr William Rainger, medical officer of health at the ARPHS. 'Our response has been to actively follow up on cases to prevent the spread and to protect those most vulnerable.'\n\nRainger confirmed the newly notified cases are not linked to a Middlemore Hospital midwife who may have infected up to 170 people [the work 'may' here suggests that up to 170 people were exposed, rather than infected - Mod.LL]. The midwife who contracted the disease was immediately sent home to recover and may have been vaccinated. 'It is a sporadic outbreak, which means that it is being spread through the community,' he said.\n\nRainger said the ARPHS was gathering information on the areas in Auckland where the outbreak was continuing. 'Our response has been to actively follow up on cases to prevent the spread and to protect those vulnerable.'\n\n[Byline: Amy Maas]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The diagnosis of pertussis in a midwife could be a major issue since the neonates that the health care deliverer exposed are the exact group with the highest risk of morbidity and mortality from human infection with _Bordetella pertussis_. Ideally, the neonates should be immune since women in the 2nd or 3rd trimester of pregnancy can be safely vaccinated with the vaccine, giving birth to babies who are protected by transplacentally acquired antibody. Certainly all healthcare workers, especially those with contact with infants less than a year of age, should receive a pertussis vaccine in the form of dTap to further 'cocoon' the susceptible infants. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1VY-.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRainger confirmed the newly notified cases are not linked to a Middlemore Hospital midwife who may have infected up to 170 people [the work 'may' here suggests that up to 170 people were exposed, rather than infected - Mod. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The diagnosis of pertussis in a midwife could be a major issue since the neonates that the health care deliverer exposed are the exact group with the highest risk of morbidity and mortality from human infection with _Bordetella pertussis_. \n\n[Byline: Amy Maas]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n< As of last Fri 25 May 2012, there were 274 confirmed or probable cases of the infection, according to Auckland Regional Public Health Service [ARPHS], up from 247 on 16 May 2012.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-05-16 00:00:00", "2012-05-31 00:00:00", "2012-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1142647", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (04): (NB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1142647", "date": "2012-05-23 21:11:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (04): (NEW BRUNSWICK)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 23 May 2012\nFrom: Noortje Kunnen <Noortje.Kunnen@gnb.ca>\nNew Brunswick Department of Health [edited]\n\n\nSince January 2012, New Brunswick (NB) has been experiencing an outbreak of pertussis. As of 22 May 2012, 548 confirmed cases have been reported to Public Health which is a significant increase compared with recent non-outbreak years (the last provincial outbreak In New Brunswick was reported in 2004 with 300 cases).\n\nThe outbreak is concentrated largely in the urban and surrounding areas of Moncton and Saint John, which are located in Health Region 1 and Health Region 2 of New Brunswick respectively. Approximately 53 percent of the cases are residents of Health Region 1 and 18 percent of the cases are from Health Region 2. A map outlining the 7 Health Regions of the Province can be found at: http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/82-583-x/2010001/article/11222-eng.pdf. However, cases continue to be reported in other areas of the province.\n\nThe highest proportion of cases are in children aged 10-14 years (47 percent of the cases), followed by people aged 20 years and up (19 percent of the cases), children aged 5-9 years (16 percent of the cases); adolescents aged 15-19 years (8 percent of the cases); children aged 1-4 years (6 percent of the cases) and infants under 1 year of age (3 percent of the cases). The highest rate of disease is in the 10-14 year age group (637 per 100 000); followed by 5-9 year olds (242 per 100 000); less than one year old (227 per 100 000); 1-4 year olds (114 per 100 000); 15-19 (93 per 100 000); and 20+ (18 per 100 000).\n\nIn New Brunswick pertussis containing vaccines are provided as primary series at 2, 4, 6 months of age; a booster at 18 months of age and between 4 and 6 years of age. 2 doses of vaccine are recommended for adolescents and adults. Most of the cases in the 10-14 age group (68 percent) and 4-9 age group (59 percent) have been immunized with 5 doses of pertussis containing vaccine: the primary series; the booster and the dose at 4-6 years.\n\nThe New Brunswick Office of the Chief Medical Officer of Health together with Regional Health Authorities implemented measures to improve immunization coverage of individuals who were not immunized in the last 5 years and who are in close contact with infants under one year of age and pregnant women. Immunization of pregnant women or postpartum immunization of mothers is recommended. A school-based Tdap immunization program for students in grades 6, 7 and 8 in the most affected areas is starting imminently to prevent the continued rise of pertussis in school age children and to further interrupt the transmission to infants. Students in less affected areas will be offered immunization in the 2012-2013 school year.\n\nMore information regarding the Pertussis outbreak, advice to physicians and the public is available at the Office of the Chief Medical Officer of Health website: http://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/departments/ocmoh/cdc/content/whooping_cough.html\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNoortje Kunnen\nSenior Program Advisor\nCommunicable Disease Control Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Officer of Health\nDepartment of Health\nGovernment of New Brunswick, Canada\n<Noortje.Kunnen@gnb.ca>\n\n[Pro-MED sincerely thanks Noortje Kunnen from the New Brunswick Department of Health for this 1st-hand report of pertussis in New Brunswick. As seen in the statistics, those 20 years old or older had the lowest rate of disease. It would be interesting to divide this group further to assess if there is any evidence that those immunized with the older killed, whole cell vaccine had a lower rate than those immunized with the acellular toxoid vaccine. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1GBH.]", "summary": "\n\nThe highest proportion of cases are in children aged 10-14 years (47 percent of the cases), followed by people aged 20 years and up (19 percent of the cases), children aged 5-9 years (16 percent of the cases); adolescents aged 15-19 years (8 percent of the cases); children aged 1-4 years (6 percent of the cases) and infants under 1 year of age (3 percent of the cases). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As of 22 May 2012, 548 confirmed cases have been reported to Public Health which is a significant increase compared with recent non-outbreak years (the last provincial outbreak In New Brunswick was reported in 2004 with 300 cases).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-05-22 00:00:00", "2012-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moncton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Health", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1137183", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Argentina  (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1137183", "date": "2012-05-20 23:08:22", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - ARGENTINA (02)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 15 May 2012\nSource: La Voz [machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.lavoz.com.ar/ciudadanos/2012-crecieron-90-casos-tos-convulsa\n\n\nIn spite of the fact that there are vaccines to prevent whooping cough, the infection has become a re-emerging disease, which today is one of the major causes of morbidity and mortality in children. The main victims of this acute respiratory infection caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_ (whooping cough), are infants younger than 6 months, usually acquired from their parents or teenage siblings, or even a member of the health care team. In infants, pertussis can be a serious disease that can lead to severe complications or even death, unlike what happens in adults or older children. The reemergence of the whooping cough or pertussis can be observed in the numbers of cases in the country.\n\nUp until 30 April 2012 597 cases of pertussis were confirmed by laboratory testing. In the same period of 2011, there were 315 cases: [this is] 90 percent more. The data comes from the National Reference Laboratory for_Bordetella pertussis_ of Argentina.\n\nThe cases reported in that period were in turn 1028 in 2011 and 2399 in 2012, which means an increase of 133 percent, perhaps explained by the deepening of the epidemiological surveillance that would result in greater reporting of suspect cases.\n\nThe Ministry of Health of Argentina reported thatin 2011 the cases reported were more than expected, a situation similar to that recorded in other countries of the region, such as Chile, Uruguay, Cuba and the USA, which also had outbreaks of the disease. In 2012, the situation has not changed, warned this week the head of the National Program for Control of vaccine-preventable diseases, Carla Vizzotti, who pointed out that the figures 'indicate a level of suspect cases confirms that we are in an outbreak, as happened in 2011.'\n\n\n[Byline: Marcela Fernandez]\n\n--\nCoomunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA as in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women to provide passive immunity is a further expansion of these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts small infants have, that the source for the infant is a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected by the current vaccines.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yJb.\n- Mod. LL]", "summary": "[Byline: Marcela Fernandez]\n\n--\nCoomunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA as in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. The cases reported in that period were in turn 1028 in 2011 and 2399 in 2012, which means an increase of 133 percent, perhaps explained by the deepening of the epidemiological surveillance that would result in greater reporting of suspect cases. The main victims of this acute respiratory infection caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_ (whooping cough), are infants younger than 6 months, usually acquired from their parents or teenage siblings, or even a member of the health care team. In 2012, the situation has not changed, warned this week the head of the National Program for Control of vaccine-preventable diseases, Carla Vizzotti, who pointed out that the figures 'indicate a level of suspect cases confirms that we are in an outbreak, as happened in 2011.' PERTUSSIS - ARGENTINA (02)\n**************************\n The Ministry of Health of Argentina reported thatin 2011 the cases reported were more than expected, a situation similar to that recorded in other countries of the region, such as Chile, Uruguay, Cuba and the USA, which also had outbreaks of the disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2399-03-25 00:00:00", "1028-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-04-30 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1120666", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (03): (YT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1120666", "date": "2012-05-02 16:21:02", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (03): (YUKON)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 May 2012\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corp [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2012/04/30/north-whooping-cough-yukon.html\n\n\nYukoners are being asked to keep an eye out for pertussis (whooping cough) after 5 cases have been confirmed in the territory.\n\nThe acting chief medical officer of health, Dr. Sharon Lazeo, said all 5 cases link back to the Yukon Native Hockey Tournament, which took place in late March 2012. All those who are ill were either participants in the tournament or family members of participants. The outbreak is also directly linked to the current outbreak in British Columbia where there is a confirmed case.\n\n'We have begun contact tracing for all the individuals who may have come into contact with the Yukon case and the one case in BC,' said Lazeo in a release. Lazeo said parents should keep an eye out for signs of the illness in children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected with the current vaccines. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2iLq.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. PERTUSSIS - CANADA (03): (YUKON)\n********************************\n \n\n'We have begun contact tracing for all the individuals who may have come into contact with the Yukon case and the one case in BC,' said Lazeo in a release.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1122722", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Argentina", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1122722", "date": "2012-05-04 11:18:08", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - ARGENTINA\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2012\nSource: El Comercial [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG, edited]\nhttp://www.elcomercial.com.ar/index.php?option=com_telam&view=deauno&idnota=182838&Itemid=116\n\n\nThe Argentinean Minister of Health, after recognizing the increasing number of pertussis cases, urged the citizens to take preventive measures, particularly all pregnant women from 20 weeks gestation, who must have their vaccines administered, and he also indicated that every child must have his/her vaccination schedule completed. During 2011, the Laboratory Surveillance System (SIVILA, according to its Spanish initials) reported 1594 confirmed (pertussis) cases and 70 deaths in children less than one year old, and 91 percent of the total reported deaths occurred in children less than 4 years of age.\n\nIn 2011, notified cases were above the expected figures, and this situation was also observed in other countries in this region, such as the USA, Cuba, Chile, and Uruguay. These countries, together with Argentina, had pertussis outbreaks during 2011.\n\nFor the current year, 2012, data recorded in SIVILA up to the 16th epidemiological week (16-22 Apr 2012) indicates that there had been 2207 cases notified as compatible with pertussis, and 568 of them were reported to be positive for _Bordetella pertussis_.\n\nDr. Carla Vizotti, Head of the National Control Program for Immuno-Preventable Diseases, declared that 'this data indicates a number of suspected cases, confirming that we are still in the midst of an outbreak as it occurred in 2011.' The specialist pointed out that 'pertussis, also known as whooping cough, is a very contagious acute respiratory infection, and it is one of the main causes of morbidity and mortality in children.' She added: 'It is necessary to have boosters in vaccination, and we need to have a good vaccine coverage in order to stop the microorganism from circulating.'\n\nThe Argentinean Ministry of Health, alongside scientific societies who participate in the National Commission for Immunizations (CONIN, according to its Spanish initials), recommended in 2012 that a supplementary strategy -- purchasing and delivering vaccines to every province in the country -- should be developed, with the objective of immunizing 750 000 pregnant women during 2012. 'With this measure, we will protect infants from the time they are born until the time they acquire immunity through vaccination,' said Dr. Vizzotti.\n\nWith this reemergence of disease associated with _Bordetella pertussis_, reports from the WHO pointed out that there are 50 million pertussis cases per year all over the world, and the death rate is 350 000 persons per year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women to provide passive immunity is a further expansion of these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts small infants have, that the reservoir of the infant is a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected with the current vaccines. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yJb.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n For the current year, 2012, data recorded in SIVILA up to the 16th epidemiological week (16-22 Apr 2012) indicates that there had been 2207 cases notified as compatible with pertussis, and 568 of them were reported to be positive for _Bordetella pertussis_. During 2011, the Laboratory Surveillance System (SIVILA, according to its Spanish initials) reported 1594 confirmed (pertussis) cases and 70 deaths in children less than one year old, and 91 percent of the total reported deaths occurred in children less than 4 years of age. \n\nThe Argentinean Ministry of Health, alongside scientific societies who participate in the National Commission for Immunizations (CONIN, according to its Spanish initials), recommended in 2012 that a supplementary strategy -- purchasing and delivering vaccines to every province in the country -- should be developed, with the objective of immunizing 750 000 pregnant women during 2012. ' With this reemergence of disease associated with _Bordetella pertussis_, reports from the WHO pointed out that there are 50 million pertussis cases per year all over the world, and the death rate is 350 000 persons per year. The Argentinean Minister of Health, after recognizing the increasing number of pertussis cases, urged the citizens to take preventive measures, particularly all pregnant women from 20 weeks gestation, who must have their vaccines administered, and he also indicated that every child must have his/her vaccination schedule completed. \n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1594-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2207-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "sivila", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1105456", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (05): (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1105456", "date": "2012-04-18 20:50:57", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (05): WESTERN AUSTRALIA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Apr 2012\nSource: WA Today [edited]\nhttp://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/whooping-cough-cases-soar-across-wa-20120=416-1x3co.html\n\n\nWestern Australia [WA] has been in the grip of a pertussis (whooping cough) epidemic since the middle of 2011, and the number of cases continues to cause concerns for the health industry. It comes amid warnings that new strains of pertussis bacterium are evading the vaccine and entrenching a 4-year epidemic that could spread overseas.\n\nAccording to the Health Department's diseases register, 1505 cases have been recorded so far in 2012, 1000 more than at the same time in 2011, and almost 1400 more than in 2010.\n\nWA had a record number of notifications in 2011 with 4019 cases, double the amount recorded in 2004 when a whooping cough epidemic last hit the state. A Health Department spokesman said notifications peaked in November 2011 with 767 cases and remained very high in January 2012, with 721 cases. 'The number of new cases is now declining, but there is still significant pertussis transmission in the community,' the spokesman said.\n\nThe highest rates of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, are occurring in primary school aged children. 'Not only do these infections cause severe cough illnesses among the school children, but these students may also bring the infection home to a younger, more vulnerable, child, or newborn in the household,' the spokesman said.\n\nMore than 13 000 whooping cough cases were diagnosed across Australia in 2011, an all-time high.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDenis Green\n<legion@q-net.net.au>\n\n[Research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) have been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. These changes may result in a need for modifications of the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/21Bk.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nDenis Green\n<legion@q-net.net.au>\n\n[Research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) have been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWA had a record number of notifications in 2011 with 4019 cases, double the amount recorded in 2004 when a whooping cough epidemic last hit the state. http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/whooping-cough-cases-soar-across-wa-20120=416-1x3co.html\n\n\nWestern Australia [WA] has been in the grip of a pertussis (whooping cough) epidemic since the middle of 2011, and the number of cases continues to cause concerns for the health industry. A Health Department spokesman said notifications peaked in November 2011 with 767 cases and remained very high in January 2012, with 721 cases. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1505-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-11-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1161299", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (10)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1161299", "date": "2012-06-11 14:47:45", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (10)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington State (Island County)\n[2] Washington State (Grant County)\n[3] Washington State (Skagit County)\n[4] Montana (Flathead County)\n[5] Maine\n[6] Utah (Utah County)\n[7] Florida (Hillsborough County)\n[8] Wisconsin (Pierce County)\n[9] Iowa\n[10] Oregon\n[11] Kansas (Johnson County)\n[12] New York (Niagara County)\n\n******\n[1] Washington State (Island County)\nDate: Thu 7 Jun 2012\nSource: The Whidbey Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.whidbeyexaminer.com/main.asp?SectionID=1&SubSectionID=1&ArticleID=7833\n\n\nThis past week 3 more cases of pertussis were reported at Coupeville Elementary School, bringing the total to 10 students and an adult. Island County and school health officials say that more reports of cases of this contagious disease are possible at the 350 student school. The county health department reports at least 42 confirmed and probable cases of pertussis, also called whooping cough, on Whidbey and Camano islands as of 5 Jun 2012. 8 of the local students who contracted the disease had been vaccinated against pertussis, school nurse Tina Lewis said.\n\nIt is very likely most adults have not received the pertussis vaccine for adolescents and adults. Everyone over age 12 should have received at least one dose of the Tdap [or DTaP; tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis], said Island County health officer Roger Case. The immunization booster is required for school attendance for those over 11 years old. 'It is estimated that less than 10 per cent of the population has actually received the Tdap immunization,' Case said.\n\nBefore the development of the pertussis vaccine, the United States typically saw about 200 000 cases a year, she said. In 2010, 27 550 cases of whooping cough were reported across the nation, the highest number since 1959, she said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has found that immunization reduces the odds of contracting pertussis, especially for children. 'Children who never received any doses of DTaP vaccine face odds of having whooping cough at least 8 times higher than children who received all 5 doses of the vaccine,' Patti said.\n\n[byline: Elisabeth Murray]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washington State can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJo. A Washington county map can be seen at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Washington State (Grant County)\nDate: Thu 7 Jun 2012\nSource: NCW-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.ncwtv.com/thirteen-new-grant-county-whooping-cough-pertussis-cases-2828/\n\n\nTo help control the spread of disease, the Grant County Health District and several clinics are offering free Tdap vaccine for uninsured Grant County adults (or adults whose health insurance does not cover the cost of the vaccine) and have close contact with infants and young children. 'If you think you qualify for this program, first contact your health care provider,' states Carol Schimke, immunization coordinator and public health nurse. She adds, 'If you do not have a health care provider or your provider does not have the free Tdap vaccine, please contact us at the Moses Lake Office at 509-766-7960.'\n\nDue to the increasing number of whooping cough cases in Grant County and the State, contact your health care provider if you are coughing or are concerned that you may have been exposed to whooping cough. It is very important that you stay home and away from other people while waiting for test results or for 5 days while you are taking medication if your doctor tells you that you have whooping cough.\n\nWhooping cough 2012\n-------------------\nWashington State: 2092 cases compared to 164 cases in 2011 during the same time period.\nGrant County: 13 cases reported. Before the 2010-2011 outbreak, Grant County had an average of 2-4 cases a year.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Washington State (Skagit County)\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2012\nSource: KAPS radio [edited]\nhttp://www.kapsradio.com/kaps-radio-660am-news-headlines/skagit-county-has-the-highest-rate-of-pertussis/\n\n\nThe Washington State Department of Health says Skagit County now has 433 confirmed cases of whooping cough or pertussis, the most in state by a wide margin. In new numbers released yesterday, 5 Jun 2012, health officials say Skagit County also has the highest rate of pertussis per 100 000 residents at 363.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Montana (Flathead County)\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2012\nSource: West Shore News [edited]\nhttp://www.flatheadnewsgroup.com/westshorenews/article_8cefe6b4-aff0-11e1-bc9f-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nFlathead City-County Health Department officials have reported 3 more pertussis (whooping cough) cases, raising the county total to 56 and adding Somers Middle School to the list of affected school districts. The new cases included 2 children who were not given the recommended antibiotic treatment after the health department informed their families of their exposure.\n\nReferred to as prophylactic treatment, the antibiotic [azithromycin - Mod.LL] regimen usually takes 5 days and kills the bacteria that spread the highly communicable disease to others. 'Most disturbing is that one of the cases was not started on prophylaxis due to the health care provider not feeling it was necessary,' county health officer Joe Russell said. 'We follow the nationally recognized guidelines for identifying close contacts of known pertussis cases. Information regarding close contacts generally comes from the schools and the cases. When recommended intervention strategies are not followed, we can expect additional cases.'\n\nCommunity health director Jody White said, 'We are concerned with our infant population as they are too young to be immunized and don't have the naturally acquired abilities to fight the infection,' White said. 'Protecting infants is essential, as hospitalization rates can run higher than 50 per cent and there is a one per cent chance that a hospitalized infant will die.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2yIN. Flathead County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/montana.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Maine\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2012\nSource: Maine Sun Journal, Bangor Daily News report [edited]\nhttp://www.sunjournal.com/news/maine/0001/11/30/whooping-cough-spreads-maine-health-officials-urge/1206060\n\n\nAn infant recently arrived at Maine Medical Center [MMC] in Portland coughing and vomiting uncontrollably. The diagnosis was whooping cough, a highly contagious respiratory disease that's breaking out in pockets across Maine. Most of the 80 cases reported in a surge of whooping cough, or pertussis, in the state in 2012 have struck middle school-aged children. In 4 cases, children under 6 months old were sickened.\n\nThe baby at MMC was treated with antibiotics and recovered, said Leah Mallory, a pediatric hospitalist at MMC. For other babies, the unrelenting cough can prove life threatening, according to Dr Lawrence Losey, a pediatrician at Parkview Adventist Medical Center in Brunswick. 'They are coughing so hard and so long that they run out of oxygen and it can cause brain damage and seizures,' he said.\n\n'Just over 60 per cent of infant pertussis is gotten from a family member; half of those are from mom,' said Losey, who was recognized last month [May 2012] by the Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention for his work in childhood immunization. The danger pertussis poses to babies is one reason public health officials are pushing for better vaccination rates in Maine.\n\nCases of whooping cough are up significantly from 2011. So far in 2012, there have been 80 cases reported statewide, according to the Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention. During the same period in 2011, 49 cases were reported. The spike in pertussis first cropped up in northern Maine, followed by outbreaks at schools in Skowhegan and Scarborough. Most cases this year have been reported in Somerset, Cumberland, York, and Penobscot counties.\n\nMaine is among 20 states that allow parents to exempt their children from school-required immunizations based on philosophical objections. Without an exemption, kindergarten students in Maine must be vaccinated against pertussis, diphtheria, tetanus, measles, mumps, rubella, polio, and chickenpox. About 3.5 per cent of Maine students attended school in 2009-10 without a vaccination, with the majority of parents citing religious and philosophical objections. Some cited medical reasons. The exemption rate inched up from 3.33 per cent the previous year, but remained lower than a peak rate of more than 4 per cent in 2007-08. Parents who skip vaccines say they object to the number of shots and fear a link between immunization and autism, according to a 2008 report by the Muskie School of Public Service.\n\n[byline: Jackie Farwell]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maine can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1CfA. A Maine county map can be seen at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/maine.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[6] Utah (Utah County)\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2012\nSource: Daily Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/whooping-cough-cases-continue-to-rise-in-utah-county/article_a1febe87-378d-5bb6-b41e-1a4c39e3fed5.html\n\n\nThe Utah County Health Department is continuing to investigate new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, every week. In 2012, 96 cases have been reported throughout the county, which is more than the cases recorded in 2009 and 2010 combined.\n\nIn 2011, the health department reported 157 cases of whooping cough, the highest number of cases in Utah County in more than 5 years and Dr Joseph Miner, executive director of the Utah County Health Department, said the county is on track to pass that number in 2012.\n\n[byline: Paige Fieldsted]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2yIR. Utah County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/utah.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[7] Florida (Hillsborough County)\nDate: Sat 2 Jun 2012\nSource: The Ledger, Tampa Bay Times report [edited]\nhttp://www.theledger.com/article/20120602/NEWS/120609903/1374\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough in Hillsborough County has struck 10 schools, 9 public and 1 private. Now health officials worry that summer camps, outings, and family vacations may allow the illness, also known as pertussis, to spread even more widely. 'Kids will be fanning out to various churches, camps, and community centers, which increases the opportunity to spread pertussis and the number of people who will be exposed,' said Warren McDougle, epidemiology program manager for the Hillsborough County Health Department. 'The school year ending isn't necessarily going to bring us relief from this outbreak.'\n\nSo far in 2012, Hillsborough County has seen about 40 cases. In 2011, Hillsborough reported just 2 cases between January and June.\n\n[byline: Irene Maher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Florida can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2gcM. Hillsborough County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[8] Wisconsin (Pierce County)\nDate: Fri 1 Jun 2012\nSource: River Falls Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.riverfallsjournal.com/event/article/id/102197/\n\n\nThe River Falls School District sent notification to all parents in the district on Fri 1 Jun 2012, saying the Pierce County Health Department has confirmed 3 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, in students from 3 local schools: Rocky Branch Elementary, Meyer Middle, and the high school.\n\nThe message says, 'We are making all parent/guardians in the School District aware of this confirmation and also want to share information with you regarding this contagious disease and its symptoms.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wisconsin can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2yIQ. Pierce County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[9] Iowa\nDate: Thu 31 May 2012\nSource: Waterloo-Cedar Falls Courier [edited]\nhttp://wcfcourier.com/news/local/more-pertussis-cases-reported-in-county/article_f7e2cc33-a86d-586c-ab02-a4fb634b50c3.html\n\n\nPertussis, or whooping cough, continues to spread through the Cedar Valley and across the state. Black Hawk County has seen 13 cases in April and May [2012], according to Kaitlin Emrich, disease surveillance program manager with the county health department. 4 of those were reported at East High School and another 4 at Hoover Middle School. However, numbers have slowed down the past few weeks. 'I don't know if that's because schools are letting out (for the summer), and kids are outside,' Emrich said. 'It's less likely to spread in an outdoor environment.'\n\nCommunicable disease staff has been working closely with school nurses to track down infected persons and alert those with whom they've been in contact, she said. As additional people display symptoms, health officials follow up to make sure they are tested and receive treatment if necessary. They've also been educating health care providers.\n\nAccording to the IDPH [Iowa Department of Public Health], the past 5 years have seen an average of 91 cases of pertussis compared to 270 cases in 2012 as of 25 May 2012. That's a nearly 200 per cent increase, though no pertussis-related deaths have been reported to IDPH in 2012. Historically, pertussis has been cyclical, with increased activity observed every 3 to 5 years.\n\nAround north east Iowa in 2012, 33 investigations have been completed in Fayette County, 8 in Cerro Gordo, 3 in Buchanan, and 4 in Delaware. Polk County has logged 55 cases, and Scott, along the south eastern border with Illinois, has reported 64.\n\n[byline: Tina Hinz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Iowa can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1Cfz. An Iowa county map can be seen at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/iowa.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[10] Oregon\nDate: Thu 31 May 2012\nSource: Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/oregon-pertussis-cases-dramatically-higher-2012\n\n\nMuch of the country is experiencing increases in pertussis, or whooping cough so far this year [2012] and the Northwest of the country has been hit exceptionally hard.\n\nIn Oregon, health officials reported that as of 29 May 2012, there have been 294 reported pertussis cases. This number dwarfs the 112 cases reported during the same timeframe in 2011.\n\nThe Oregon Health Authority says the ages of 2012 pertussis cases range from 8 days to 58 years; the median age is 8 years. There have been 11 infants hospitalized; 10 are 3 months old or younger.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oregon can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[11] Kansas (Johnson County)\nDate: Mon 28 May 2012\nSource: KCUR [edited]\nhttp://www.kcur.org/post/johnson-county-works-contain-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nJohnson County, Kansas is in the midst of a whooping cough outbreak. It's not as bad as in Washington State, where they've declared an epidemic of the disease, also known as pertussis. But health workers and schools in the region have been taking extra steps to get a handle on the disease.\n\nNancy Tausz, a disease specialist with the county, says the outbreak surfaced in mid-April 2012. 'With that many cases come in, and continually, you know something other than just the norm is happening,' Tausz says. The county is now investigating more than 130 cases of the disease. Tausz says at first, it was concentrated in the southern part of the county. 'The ages we saw at the beginning were 5th grade and 6th grade,' Tausz says. 'And then started expanding from 5th grade to 8th grade.'\n\n[byline: Elana Gordon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2yIO. Johnson County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[12] New York (Niagara County)\nDate: Fri 8 Jun 2012\nSource: WGRZ [edited]\nhttp://www.wgrz.com/news/article/170808/1/Niagara-County-Report-Increase-in-Pertussis-Cases\n\n\nOfficials at the Niagara County Department of Health say several cases of pertussis have been reported recently in their county. They say 15 cases have been medically diagnosed since January 2012 to now, compared to 11 cases for the entire year in 2011.\n\nAffected individuals range in age from 65 years to 2 months, with a predominance of cases in school-age children. None of the sick had to be hospitalized and all received treatment at home.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[New York State can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2yIP. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Elisabeth Murray]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Jackie Farwell]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Paige Fieldsted]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Irene Maher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Tina Hinz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< and there is a one per cent chance that a hospitalized infant will die.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< In 2011, the health department reported 157 cases of whooping cough, the highest number of cases in Utah County in more than 5 years and Dr Joseph Miner, executive director of the Utah County Health Department, said the county is on track to pass that number in 2012. Source: NCW-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.ncwtv.com/thirteen-new-grant-county-whooping-cough-pertussis-cases-2828/\n\n\nTo help control the spread of disease, the Grant County Health District and several clinics are offering free Tdap vaccine for uninsured Grant County adults (or adults whose health insurance does not cover the cost of the vaccine) and have close contact with infants and young children. According to the IDPH [Iowa Department of Public Health], the past 5 years have seen an average of 91 cases of pertussis compared to 270 cases in 2012 as of 25 May 2012. \n\n\nFlathead City-County Health Department officials have reported 3 more pertussis (whooping cough) cases, raising the county total to 56 and adding Somers Middle School to the list of affected school districts. \n\nThe Oregon Health Authority says the ages of 2012 pertussis cases range from 8 days to 58 years; the median age is 8 years. In this update:\n[1] Washington State (Island County)\n -------------------\nWashington State: 2092 cases compared to 164 cases in 2011 during the same time period. The county health department reports at least 42 confirmed and probable cases of pertussis, also called whooping cough, on Whidbey and Camano islands as of 5 Jun 2012. Most of the 80 cases reported in a surge of whooping cough, or pertussis, in the state in 2012 have struck middle school-aged children. [3] Washington State (Skagit County)\n [3] Washington State (Skagit County)\n Source: Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/oregon-pertussis-cases-dramatically-higher-2012\n\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-31 00:00:00", "2007-08-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-29 00:00:00", "2012-01-25 00:00:00", "1959-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2064-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-10-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Flathead County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Skowhegan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buchanan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hillsborough County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Island County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/florida.shtml", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somerset", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Flathead City - Canada (02): (ON) unimmunized group", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1094957", "date": "2012-04-10 12:20:02", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA: (ONTARIO) UNIMMUNIZED GROUP\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Apr 2012\nSource: Guelph (ON) Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news/local/article/700524--whooping-cough-outbreak-among-mennonites\n\n\nA pertussis outbreak in the Low German-speaking Mennonite population of the region is proving challenging for public health officials to contain. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. 'They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,' Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Of the 82 confirmed cases within the district of the 7 health units, the median age of infection is 7 years.\n\nThe outbreak is occurring among members of the same religious community, who attend the same schools and churches.\n\n[Byline: Rob O'Flanagan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the ProMED-mail postings regarding pertussis have been related to outbreaks in immunized populations. When an outbreak occurs in a population that does not access vaccinations for religious reasons, the manifestations of the outbreak can be more severe and these individuals can serve as vehicles for transmission to others outside the religious community. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/29My.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n When an outbreak occurs in a population that does not access vaccinations for religious reasons, the manifestations of the outbreak can be more severe and these individuals can serve as vehicles for transmission to others outside the religious community. 'We're seeing more cases than we would normally expect this time of year,' said Ruth Marx, epidemiologist with the department. 'We're up past 100 confirmed cases.'\n\nThe Health Department is working with area school districts: D.C. Everest, Wausau, Mosinee, Marathon and Newman Catholic, to help prevent the spread of the illness. Letters have been sent to parents of students who are classmates of children with whooping cough. If children who came in contact with others who have pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, exhibit signs of cold symptoms, they should stay home and see a physician. People who are found to have whooping cough, and those who come in close contact with those who are ill, are prescribed a regimen of antibiotics.\n\nMost healthy teens and adults can recover from the illness, Marx said. But it's particularly dangerous to babies 6 months or younger or those who have compromised immune systems. 'It kills infants,' Marx said. 'Infants haven't received a full series of immunizations until they're 6 months old.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Montana (Ravalli County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2012\nSource: NBC Montana [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcmontana.com/news/30910437/detail.html\n\n\nRavalli County reported one more pertussis case Tuesday [17 Apr 2012]. That's a total of 15 confirmed whooping cough cases in the Bitterroot.\n\nThe latest case is another child. 14 children are now sick with pertussis. Only one adult has tested positive. Most of the cases are in Pinesdale. Some are in the Corvallis area.\n\n'The Corvallis school system is increasing surveillance,' said public health director Judy Griffin. 'The school nurse has been diligently talking with teachers and possible contacts.'\n\n[Byline: Kevin Maki]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina (multiple counties)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2012\nSource: MyFox 8 [edited]\nhttp://myfox8.com/2012/04/17/whooping-cough-outbreak-spreads-to-randolph-county/\n\n\nRandolph County has 15 cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, and health director Mimi Cooper said many of the cases are related to the 129 cases in Alamance County. 'We can connect those children to each other. They've spent time with each other during the period the children were incubating the disease,' Cooper said.\n\nGuilford County has had 5 cases of whooping cough in 2012. Cooper said those cases were also related to the Alamance outbreak, but the Guilford County Health Department could not confirm that.\n\nCooper said pertussis, which can be fatal in infants younger than 6 months, is that serious of an infliction. 'It's not intended to be punishing for the children or the school. We are trying to prevent children from dying,' Cooper said.\n\n[Byline: Mitch Carr]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Florida (Broward County)\nDate: Sat 14 Apr 2012\nSource: Local 10 [edited]\nhttp://www.local10.com/thats-life/health/Pertussis-identified-in-Broward-Co/-/1717022/10808020/-/lns7waz/-/\n\n\nFour cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, were identified in Broward County this week, health officials said. Since the beginning of 2012, several counties throughout the state have reported higher levels of pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized like the one described in the Colorado posting. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts 5-week-old infants have, that the reservoir of the infant was a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected, against which we are no longer as well protected with the current vaccines. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\n \n\n\nRandolph County has 15 cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, and health director Mimi Cooper said many of the cases are related to the 129 cases in Alamance County.
