' \n\nGuilford County has had 5 cases of whooping cough in 2012.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ravalli County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Randolph County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alamance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marathon County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broward County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pinesdale", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guilford County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1094968", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Chile (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1094968", "date": "2012-04-09 19:13:21", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CHILE (02): BACKGROUND\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: Gideon Online [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\nAlthough the incidence of pertussis in South America has remained low in recent years, disease rates in Chile remain slightly higher than those of neighboring countries [1-3]; see graph: http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/pertussis-chile.png\n\nSurprisingly, DPT vaccination uptake in Chile has continued to be comparatively high for over 2 decades; see graph: http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Chile-DPT.png.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA: Infectious Diseases of Chile, 2012. 383 pp, 90 graphs, 1546 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-chile.\n2. Berger SA: Pertussis: Global Status, 2012. 40 pp, 506 graphs, 401 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/pertussis-global-status/.\n3. Gideon graph tool at http://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center, Israel\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Berger for his continued contributions. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\n PERTUSSIS - CHILE (02): BACKGROUND\n**********************************\n Although the incidence of pertussis in South America has remained low in recent years, disease rates in Chile remain slightly higher than those of neighboring countries [1-3]; see graph: http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/pertussis-chile.png\n\n Tel Aviv Medical Center, Israel\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Berger for his continued contributions. - \n\nReferences:\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1546-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1122809", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (08)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1122809", "date": "2012-05-13 13:47:22", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Massachusetts (Hampden County) infant fatality\n[2] Idaho (Bannock County) infant fatality\n[3] Iowa (Howard County)\n[4] Iowa (Fayette County)\n[5] New York (Suffolk County)\n[6] Washington State (statewide)\n[7] Washington State (Grant County)\n[8] Montana (statewide)\n[9] Wisconsin (Dane County)\n[10] Arizona (Maricopa County), infant fatality\n\n*****\n[1] Massachusetts (Hampden County) infant fatality\nDate: Sun 27 Apr 2012\nSource: WBUR [edited]\nhttp://commonhealth.wbur.org/2012/04/death-from-pertussis\n\n\nA happy, healthy 6-week-old baby - got his 1st cold shortly after the new year. His mother had seen her share of sniffles (she has 2 older daughters, 8 and 5) and didn't think much of it. 'It was just a little cough and sneeze,' she said. 'I wasn't too worried.'\n\nBut a few days later, on 6 Jan 2012, his fever spiked to 104 degrees. So, in the middle of the night, the parents decided to take the baby to the emergency department at Baystate Children's Hospital in Springfield, Mass. near their home in Chicopee. He tested negative for flu and a common respiratory virus. By early morning, his fever was gone and the family was sent home. 3 weeks later he would be dead, a victim of pertussis, or whooping cough, a preventable but highly contagious bacterial disease that has been on the rise in recent decades.\n\nAt home, his breathing became slightly more labored; he'd been diagnosed with bronchiolitis, a swelling and buildup of mucus in the tiny air passages of the lungs, usually due to a viral infection. After another examination later in the week, a pediatrician prescribed albuterol to ease his symptoms.\n\nOn 16 Jan 2012, the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, the infant started spitting up more and his breathing worsened. This time he was admitted to Baystate's pediatric ICU, his mother said. A medical team assessed him; and an infectious disease doctor suggested he might have pertussis, though the diagnosis remained uncertain. Indeed, the family didn't get confirmation of his pertussis until after his death, when a test for the disease came back positive. 'I could have bet my whole life that it wasn't pertussis,' the mother said, recalling her reaction when the illness was 1st mentioned. 'He wasn't coughing like I would have imagined. And I didn't know any infant who ever had pertussis.'\n\nBut pertussis, or whooping cough, or 'the cough of 100 days' for its generally long duration, has been on the rise since the 1980s, according to the CDC. The disease is characterized by violent, uncontrollable coughing (including the characteristic 'whoop' sound) that can make it hard to breathe. But sometimes there is no 'whoop.' And infants with pertussis don't always cough, but may have apnea, a long pause in their breathing. The disease is most common in young children; babies under one are particularly vulnerable and face the greatest risk of death.\n\nIn 2010, there were 27 550 reported cases of pertussis nationally, the CDC says. That year, in California, 9143 cases of pertussis, including 10 infant deaths, were reported, the greatest number of cases in 63 years, according to the CDC. Vermont had a pertussis outbreak in 2011. And on 3 Apr 2012, Washington State officials declared a pertussis 'epidemic,' with over 1000 cases reported.\n\nThe CDC recommends pertussis vaccines for infants, adolescents and adults (most recently, pregnant women), summarized here:\n\nInfants and children are recommended a dose of DTaP (Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Acellular Pertussis) vaccine at 2, 4 and 6 months, 15 through 18 months, and 4 through 6 years of age. Everyone 11 years and older, including pregnant women, is recommended one dose of Tdap (combined Tetanus, Diphtheria and Acellular Pertussis) vaccine, preferably at 11-12 years of age. Pregnant women are recommended to receive a dose of Tdap vaccine, preferably during the 3rd trimester or late 2nd trimester (after 20 weeks gestation). By getting Tdap vaccine during pregnancy, maternal pertussis antibodies transfer to the newborn, likely providing protection against pertussis in early life, before the baby starts getting DTaP vaccines. Tdap will also protect the mother at time of delivery, making her less likely to transmit pertussis to her infant. A CDC spokesperson adds: 'Everyone needs Tdap vaccine as an adolescent/adult even if they were fully vaccinated with DTaP or DTP vaccine as a child.'\n\nWhat, exactly, is driving the increase in pertussis cases isn't totally clear. Experts speak of a convergence of factors, including waning immunity after vaccination, low vaccine compliance among adults (who had coverage rates of only 8.2 percent in 2010, according to the CDC) and a general perception that whooping cough isn't a dire condition. Another factor may be that pertussis is going undiagnosed in many cases - since not everyone 'whoops' - allowing for disease to spread. In addition (though the CDC disputes this) declining use of antibiotics by doctors wary of overuse and drug resistance may also be a cause. Some put the blame on parents who refuse to vaccinate their children. But officials at the CDC say it's more likely that declining protection in vaccinated people rather than vaccine refusal is contributing to the increase.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map showing the counties of Massachusetts, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/massachusetts.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[2] Idaho (Bannock County) infant fatality\nDate: Thu 3 May 2012\nSource: Local News 8 [edited]\nhttp://www.localnews8.com/news/31002886/detail.html\n\n\nAn infant from Pocatello died Thursday, from a once almost defeated disease now seeing a resurgence, pertussis. At 9 weeks old, this infant was too young to get a vaccine, but health professionals said if more people in the community made sure children got immunized, the baby likely wouldn't have caught this disease. The distinct wheezing noise a child infected with pertussis makes when gasping for breath in between fits of coughing, gave the disease its nickname, whooping cough.\n\n'Pertussis is a very contagious disease. It's a very debilitating, life-threatening disease also for little ones who can't fight it off,' Portneuf Medical Center Infection Preventionist Joyce Olson said. Olson said it is especially tragic when a child dies of a disease that has vaccines against it. 'It's very sad when any child that young, or any age, dies of pertussis, because it is a preventable one. It is a very sad situation,' Olson said.\n\nSoutheastern Idaho Public Health [SIPH] said if 90 percent of kids were vaccinated, the disease would be almost nonexistent. But many parents choose not to immunize their kids, some citing fears of a believed connection to autism. Those at SIPH said there's no significant danger from getting vaccinated. 'Vaccines are very, very safe. They are monitored so closely for any kind of adverse reaction, and the benefits of the vaccine, far, far, far and away outweigh any minimal risks,' SIPH District Director Maggie Mann said. It is a parents choice whether to immunize their kids, but those with SIPH said people should remember that one child not getting vaccinated means all children are more likely to get sick. 'While this is totally their call, whether or not to have their child vaccinated, it is critically important in protecting children against a variety of really serious childhood diseases,' Mann said.\n\nAccording to SIPH, in local communities 72 percent of children are immunized.\n\n[Byline: Jake Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Idaho showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/idaho.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[3] Iowa (Howard County)\nDate; Wed 2 May 2012\nSource: Cresco Times [edited]\nhttp://www.crescotimes.com/articles/2012/05/02/news/doc4fa167dc61c09477724134.txt\n\n\nIn information released from Iowa Department of Public Health, as of [19 Apr 2012], 92 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Iowa. This is an 83 percent increase over the 5-year average for the state. While cases are predominately occurring in eastern Iowa, scattered cases are being reported across the state. During outbreaks, local public health agencies interview cases (ensure appropriate isolation and treatment), identify those people who have been in close contact, and recommend prophylactic antibiotics to stop them from becoming ill and to stop further transmission.\n\nHoward County Public Health would like to inform the community that pertussis (whooping cough) is in Howard County. As of 27 Apr 2012, confirmed cases of pertussis have been found in Howard County. Howard County Public Health and local healthcare providers are working with affected individuals and close contacts. Local healthcare providers are aware of the situations. Iowa Department of Public Health does not recommend an entire class is treated for pertussis and/or school be canceled.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Iowa showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/iowa.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[4] Iowa (Fayette County)\nDate: Tue 1 May 2012\nSource: KWWL [edited]\nhttp://www.kwwl.com/story/18005010/north-fayette-schools-confirm-whooping-cough-cases\n\n\nThe North Fayette School District is confirming an outbreak of whooping cough. The district reports 15 to 20 school age children have come down with the illness within the last week. The district issued a letter to parents which states it is\nworking closely with Palmer Community Health and the Iowa Department of Health in dealing with the disease.\n\nStudents with confirmed cases of whooping cough are being isolated from the school population, by staying home from classes. Administrators say those students are also banned from all school activities until a whooping cough test comes back negative.\n\nClear Creek Amana Schools are also confirming an outbreak of whooping cough, but are not stating how many students are sick.\n\n[Byline: Kera Mashek]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Iowa showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/iowa.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[5] New York (Suffolk County)\nDate: Tue 1 May 2012\nSource: Patch. com [edited]\nhttp://hauppauge.patch.com/articles/district-confirms-whooping-cough-case-at-hauppauge-high-school\n\n\nAn individual from Hauppauge High School has been diagnosed with pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, according to a message posted on the district's website Monday, [30 Apr 2012]. A letter from Suffolk County Executive Steve Bellone and Suffolk County Department of Health Services does not identify the individual, or say if the individual was a student or faculty. Hauppauge parents were notified of the confirmed pertussis case by phone calls on Monday evening, according to district spokeswoman Trish Auerbach.\n\n[Byline: Sara Walsh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of New York State showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/new-york.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[6] Washington State (statewide)\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2012\nSource: Washington State Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://www.doh.wa.gov/cfh/Immunize/documents/pertupdate.pdf\n\n\n2012 year to date (YTD) confirmed and probable cases reported through [28 Apr 2012} (week 17)\n----------------------------\nThis update summarizes reports of pertussis in persons with 2012 onsets received by local health jurisdictions (LHJs) during weeks 1-17, made visible to Washington State Department of Health (DOH) - Communicable Disease Epidemiology, and containing sufficient information for a DOH case classification to have been assigned.\n\nThere have been a total of 1132 cases reported statewide through week 17, compared to 117 reported cases in 2011 during the same time period. Dates for the 2011/2012 comparison were based on LHJ notification date. 12 counties have reported no pertussis activity in 2012.\n\nAmong the 27 counties with pertussis activity, the number of pertussis cases reported in a given county so far in 2012 ranges from 1 to 234, and the rate of disease in a given county ranges from 1.1 to 196.1 per 100 000 persons year to date (see Table 1 [for tables see original URL - Mod. LL]). The median and mean county rates in counties reporting pertussis activity are 11.7 and 23.1 per 100 000 persons year to date, respectively.\n\nThe overall incidence rate year to date is 16.8 pertussis cases per 100 000 Washington residents and the rate of disease in infants under 1 year of age, 88.1 per 100 000, remains higher than rates in all other age groups (see Table 2). This equates to an annualized overall rate of pertussis in Washington residents of 51.4 per 100 000 persons with a rate in infants of 269.5 per 100 000 should this trend continue throughout 2012. 78 infants under 1 year of age were reported as having whooping cough and 20 of them were hospitalized. Of those hospitalized, 16 (80 percent) were very young (3 months of age or younger).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington State showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[7] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Wed 2 May 2012\nSource: NCW-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.ncwtv.com/two-pertussis-cases-with-exposures-at-ephrata-middle-school-and-high-school-1809/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 2 cases of whooping cough (pertussis) in Grant County residents who spent time at the Ephrata Middle School and High School while contagious 16-27 Apr 2012. No one has been hospitalized.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of disease, the Health Officer is recommending antibiotic treatment for all people who have come into close contact with whooping cough. GCHD recommends that all close contacts that have a cough be tested for pertussis. 'This is not a pertussis outbreak. However, we are working with the Ephrata School District to quickly notify students' parents/guardians and staff of their possible exposure to control the spread of this highly contagious disease,' states Shawta Sackett, Community Public Health Manager and Epidemiologist.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington State showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[8] Montana (statewide)\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2012\nSource: Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services [edited]\nhttp://www.dphhs.mt.gov/newsevents/newsreleases2012/april/pertussis.shtml\n\n\nThe Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services (DPHHS) reports that outbreaks of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, are being reported in several areas of Montana and is urging vaccines for all children and adults to help prevent the disease. Since January 2012, nearly 90 cases of pertussis have been reported statewide, compared to approximately 50 cases for the same period in 2011. Recent cases have been reported in Broadwater, Gallatin, Lewis and Clark, Ravalli, and Stillwater counties. Local and state public health officials are concerned that the number of reported cases will continue to increase unless people take action to protect themselves and others.\n\nWashington State has reported a large increase in reported pertussis, with nearly 800 cases reported over the last 4 months. Montana health officials do not want what is occurring in Washington State to happen here.\n\n'Most cases of pertussis are preventable,' said DPHHS Director Anna Whiting Sorrell. 'All parents and caregivers of children need to make sure their children are up to date on this and other vaccines. Anyone who cares for children should also be up to date on their vaccinations to prevent spreading pertussis.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Montana showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/montana.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[9] Wisconsin (Dane County)\nDate: Thu 26 Apr 2012\nSource: Maidson.com [edited]\nhttp://host.madison.com/ct/news/local/health_med_fit/whooping-cough-cases-take-huge-leap-in-dane-county-health/article_a82c021e-8ef8-11e1-93c2-001a4bcf887a.html\n\n\nPublic Health Madison & Dane County said in a news release on Wednesday, 25 Apr 2012, that more than 90 cases of whooping cough have been reported since 1 Mar 2012, and more cases are expected. For 2012, more than 160 cases have been reported.\n\n'These numbers are particularly alarming (because) they are much higher than the 2 or 3 cases per month we've seen the past several years,' said Amanda Kita-Yarbro, communicable disease epidemiologist for Public Health Madison & Dane County.\nMost of the cases are in school-aged children, especially in the 10 to 14 years old age group. The next hardest hit age group is among teens 15 to 19 years old, and the third hardest hit group is 5 to 9 year olds.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said pertussis is an endemic disease, meaning it's pretty common for outbreaks to occur on a regular basis at any time of the year in various parts of the country.\n\n[Byline: Bill Novak]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Wisconsin showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n*****\n[10] Arizona (Maricopa County), infant fatality\nDate: Thu 25 Apr 2012\nSource: AZ Central [edited]\nhttp://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2012/04/25/20120425phoenix-area-whooping-cough-death-1st-since-2009.html\n\n\nA Maricopa County infant died of whooping cough in April 2012, the 1st such death since 2009, the county Department of Public Health said. The baby was too young to be immunized and likely contracted the illness from an adult, health officials said. They urged residents to get vaccinated if they are in close contact with children younger than 12 months old.\n\nAbout 700 cases were reported in 2011, more than double the cases reported in 2009. Jeanene Fowler, county public-health spokeswoman, attributed the increase to more cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, and more testing being done by physicians.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Ye Hee Lee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[For a map of Arizona showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/arizona.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n\n[Research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) have been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. These changes may result in a need for modifications of the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines.\n\nCurrent recommendations for 'cocooning' infants against pertussis include dTap vaccinations of the pregnant woman after the 1st trimester as well of the father, aunts and uncles and grandparents. Given the aforementioned concerns regarding the acellular vaccine, it would be important to know if the reservoirs of pertussis at risk to infants are essentially those immunized with the acellular products rather than the original whole cell, killed _B. pertussis_ vaccine. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Anyone who cares for children should also be up to date on their vaccinations to prevent spreading pertussis.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe CDC recommends pertussis vaccines for infants, adolescents and adults (most recently, pregnant women), summarized here:\n\nInfants and children are recommended a dose of DTaP (Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Acellular Pertussis) vaccine at 2, 4 and 6 months, 15 through 18 months, and 4 through 6 years of age. Since January 2012, nearly 90 cases of pertussis have been reported statewide, compared to approximately 50 cases for the same period in 2011. \n\n'These numbers are particularly alarming (because) they are much higher than the 2 or 3 cases per month we've seen the past several years,' said Amanda Kita-Yarbro, communicable disease epidemiologist for Public Health Madison & Dane County. ' This update summarizes reports of pertussis in persons with 2012 onsets received by local health jurisdictions (LHJs) during weeks 1-17, made visible to Washington State Department of Health (DOH) - Communicable Disease Epidemiology, and containing sufficient information for a DOH case classification to have been assigned. \n\n--\n [Byline: Jake Taylor]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Kera Mashek]\n\n--\n [Byline: Sara Walsh]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Bill Novak]\n\n--\n [Byline: Michelle Ye Hee Lee]\n\n--\n Given the aforementioned concerns regarding the acellular vaccine, it would be important to know if the reservoirs of pertussis at risk to infants are essentially those immunized with the acellular products rather than the original whole cell, killed _B. pertussis_ vaccine. In information released from Iowa Department of Public Health, as of [19 Apr 2012], 92 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Iowa. \n\nWhat, exactly, is driving the increase in pertussis cases isn't totally clear. \n\nStudents with confirmed cases of whooping cough are being isolated from the school population, by staying home from classes. The district issued a letter to parents which states it is\nworking closely with Palmer Community Health and the Iowa Department of Health in dealing with the disease. And on 3 Apr 2012, Washington State officials declared a pertussis 'epidemic,' with over 1000 cases reported. By getting Tdap vaccine during pregnancy, maternal pertussis antibodies transfer to the newborn, likely providing protection against pertussis in early life, before the baby starts getting DTaP vaccines. 16:43:43", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (07)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update\n[1] Florida (Hillsborough County)\n[2] Wisconsin (Milwaukee County)\n[3] Texas (Bell, Waco-McLennan Counties)\n[4] Iowa (Polk County)\n[5] California (San Luis Obispo County)\n[6] Utah (Cache County)\n\n******\n[1] Florida (Hillsborough County)\nDate: Mon 23 Apr 2012\nSource: Tampa Bay Online, Tampa Tribune report [edited]\nhttp://www2.tbo.com/lifestyles/breaking-news/2012/apr/23/memeto1-whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-in-hillsb-ar-395475/\n\n\nLocal health officials think adults are unknowingly responsible for the latest outbreak of a severe childhood respiratory disease. A total of 35 cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, have been reported since 1 Jan 2012 in Hillsborough County. The 112 cases reported statewide so far indicate a possible spike not seen in several years, according to the Florida Department of Health.\n\nThe Hillsborough cases cropped up in the homes of 7 local families, said Warren McDougle, epidemiology program director at the Hillsborough County Health Department. In one case, an adult infected 6 children in the family who did not have vaccinations, he said. 'Pertussis has gotten in the adult population, and for them the experience is not unlike other respiratory illnesses where they cough and cough,' he said. 'It's not as severe as it is for children.'\n\nThis year-round illness is spreading beyond Florida. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also reports recent outbreaks in Montana, North Carolina, Texas, and Washington State. Cases could exceed the 27 550 reported in 2010, officials said.\n\n[byline: Mary Shedden]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Florida can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2gcM. Hillsborough County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Wisconsin (Milwaukee County)\nDate: Thu 19 Apr 2012\nSource: Fox 6 Now [edited]\nhttp://fox6now.com/2012/04/19/st-matthias-parish-school-has-17-whooping-cough-cases/\n\n\nSt Matthias Parish School in Milwaukee is dealing with a large cluster of pertussis (whooping cough) cases. The case count stands at 17 as of Thu 19 Apr 2012.\n\nPaul Biedrzycki with the Milwaukee County Health Department says pertussis is highly contagious and the antibiotics not only cure the students, but those most susceptible for contracting the illness or developing complications. Of the infants who contract whooping cough, 70 per cent are hospitalized. In February 2012, a baby less than a month old died from the illness. Biedrzycki says the best prevention is vaccination, although the vaccine is not a 100 per cent guarantee an individual will not contract the illness.\n\n'It's all about vaccinating the siblings who are generally school age, or the adults who provide care to infants and toddlers as soon as possible, to interrupt the chain of transmission within the household or community setting,' Biedrzycki said.\n\nIn 3 months there have been 55 cases of pertussis in Milwaukee (from January 2012 to March 2012). In all of 2011, there were 59 cases. Back in 2004, there were 1400 cases in Milwaukee.\n\n[byline: Beverly Taylor]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Milwaukee can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2gcN. Milwaukee County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Texas (Bell, Waco-McLennan Counties)\nDate: Thu 19 Apr 2012\nSource: KWTX [edited]\nhttp://www.kwtx.com/news/health/headlines/More_Area_Whooping_Cough_Cases_Reported__148184875.html\n\n\nAs of Thu 19 Apr 2012, there have been 58 confirmed and probable cases of pertussis (whooping cough) in Bell County, the Bell County Public Health District reported.\n\nMeanwhile the Waco-McLennan County Health Department was reporting 3 confirmed cases at Midway ISD schools, 3 isolated cases at various locations in the county, and a total of 19 cases in Robinson.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1mfK. Of the confirmed cases, 31 are students, said Rick Kozin, public information officer for the Polk County Department of Public Health. Only one of the pertussis cases was outside of Des Moines, but that case was in the Des Moines area. The 1st confirmed case was in mid-March [2012], he said.\n\nOne of the individuals who has a confirmed case of pertussis has been hospitalized. However, Kozin stressed that officials have not yet determined if that illness was what led to the need for hospitalization.\n\nKozin said the department did a vaccination clinic last week [week of 9 Apr 2012] at Des Moines Lincoln High School and administered 234 vaccinations. Of the confirmed cases, the majority have been in students, but the cases range from infant to middle-aged, he said.\n\nKozin said it's important for those experiencing symptoms to be checked out by a doctor.\n\n[byline: James Heggen]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Des Moines can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2gd1. The outbreak started a week ago when medical tests confirmed 2 5th grade students at North Park Elementary in North Logan had the disease.\n\nHealth officials said so far the outbreak is isolated to students at North Park Elementary. They said students who have not completed the proper series of vaccinations and booster shots against pertussis may be required to stay home by school officials.\n\n[byline: Dan Metcalf jr, Brian Carlson]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2gd2. Cache County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/utah.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized like the ones described in the Wisconsin and California reports. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts infants less than one month have, that the reservoir of the infant was a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop', after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected with the current vaccines. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Beverly Taylor]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Milwaukee can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2gcN. Date: Thu 19 Apr 2012\n Date: Thu 19 Apr 2012\n Date: Thu 19 Apr 2012\n Date: Thu 19 Apr 2012\n Date: Thu 19 Apr 2012\n Of the confirmed cases, the majority have been in students, but the cases range from infant to middle-aged, he said. \n\nHealth officials said so far the outbreak is isolated to students at North Park Elementary. Date: Mon 23 Apr 2012\n In 3 months there have been 55 cases of pertussis in Milwaukee (from January 2012 to March 2012).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-01-01 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-04-19 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Logan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/florida.shtml", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Luis Obispo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kozin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cache County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Milwaukee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polk County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Milwaukee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Des Moines", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bell County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hillsborough County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1090350", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1090350", "date": "2012-04-04 17:01:18", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CHILE: INCREASED MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Apr 2012\nSource: nacion.cl [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG, edited]\nhttp://www.lanacion.cl/tos-convulsiva-se-duplican-casos-y-ya-hay-5-guaguas-fallecidas/noticias/2012-04-02/184026.html\n\n\nThere has been an approximately 50 percent increase in the number of cases of whooping cough (pertussis) in Chile between 1 Jan 2012 and 24 Mar 2012, totaling 643 cases, compared to only 338 cases for the same period during 2011.\n\nAccording to data issued by the Chilean Ministry of Health, 43 percent of the cases correspond to children less than one year old (274 cases), and the incidence rate is 108.7 per 100 000 children less than 1 year old.\n\nThe [Santiago Metropolitan] and O' Higgins regions reported the most accentuated increase in the number of cases of whooping cough during the past few weeks. The most affected regions all over Chile are Antofagasta, Coquimbo, Valparaiso, Maule, Los Rios, and Los Lagos.\n\nBetween 1 Jan 2012 and 24 Mar 2012, 5 fatal cases in children have been reported, 1 in Antofagasta, 3 in Valparaiso, and 1 in Coquimbo. 4 of the deceased children were less than 2 months old and the other was a 4 month old baby. Whooping cough is a dangerous disease in children less than 6 months old. Nearly 7 newborns per year die because of this infection in Chile.\n\nLast January 2012, the Chilean Ministry of Health launched a vaccination campaign called in Spanish 'vacuna en capullo' (literally meaning 'cocoon vaccination') which consists in immunizing persons who have direct contact with newborns. Consequently, pregnant mothers, fathers, siblings more than 15 years old and health care personnel taking care of babies during their 1st months of life must be immunized. The objective is to prevent transmission of the infection to babies.\n\nMeanwhile, little children will still be immunized within the context of the Chilean National Vaccination Program.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Typically, the incubation period of pertussis ranges from 3-12 days. Pertussis (http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/967268-clinical) is a 6-week disease divided into catarrhal, paroxysmal, and convalescent stages, each lasting from 1-2 weeks. The 3 stages of disease progression are as follows:\n\nStage 1: the initial (catarrhal) phase is indistinguishable from common upper respiratory infections with nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and sneezing, variably accompanied by low-grade fever, tearing, and conjunctival suffusion. Pertussis is most infectious when patients are in the catarrhal phase, but pertussis may remain communicable for 3 or more weeks after the onset of cough.\n\nStage 2: patients in the 2nd (paroxysmal) phase present with paroxysms of intense coughing lasting up to several minutes. In older infants and toddlers, the paroxysms of coughing occasionally are followed by a loud whoop as inspired air goes through a still partially closed airway. Infants younger than 6 months do not have the characteristic whoop but may have apneic episodes and are at risk for exhaustion. Posttussive vomiting and turning red with coughing are common in affected children.\n\nStage 3: patients in the 3rd (convalescent) stage have a chronic cough, which may last for weeks.\n\nPertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/clinical/complications.html) can cause serious and potentially life-threatening complications in infants and young children who are not fully vaccinated.\n\nIn infants younger than 12 months of age who get pertussis, more than half must be hospitalized. Hospitalization is most common in infants younger than 6 months of age. Of those infants who are hospitalized with pertussis approximately:\n- 50 percent will have apnea\n- 20 percent get pneumonia\n- 1 percent will have seizures\n- 1 percent will die\n- 0.3 percent will have encephalopathy (as a result of hypoxia from coughing or possibly from toxin)\n\nOf those infants younger than 12 months of age who die:\n- Refractory pulmonary hypertension is a common, severe complication that contributes to death\n- Encephalopathy occurs in approximately 20 percent of cases\n- Other complications can include anorexia, dehydration, difficulty sleeping, epistaxis, hernias, otitis media, and urinary incontinence. More severe complications can include pneumothorax, rectal prolapse, and subdural hematomas. - Mod.LL]\n\n[Maps of Chile can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif and http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Of those infants who are hospitalized with pertussis approximately:\n- 50 percent will have apnea\n- 20 percent get pneumonia\n- 1 percent will have seizures\n- 1 percent will die\n- 0.3 percent will have encephalopathy (as a result of hypoxia from coughing or possibly from toxin) \n\nOf those infants younger than 12 months of age who die:\n- Refractory pulmonary hypertension is a common, severe complication that contributes to death\n- Encephalopathy occurs in approximately 20 percent of cases\n- Other complications can include anorexia, dehydration, difficulty sleeping, epistaxis, hernias, otitis media, and urinary incontinence. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nThere has been an approximately 50 percent increase in the number of cases of whooping cough (pertussis) in Chile between 1 Jan 2012 and 24 Mar 2012, totaling 643 cases, compared to only 338 cases for the same period during 2011. \n\nBetween 1 Jan 2012 and 24 Mar 2012, 5 fatal cases in children have been reported, 1 in Antofagasta, 3 in Valparaiso, and 1 in Coquimbo. According to data issued by the Chilean Ministry of Health, 43 percent of the cases correspond to children less than one year old (274 cases), and the incidence rate is 108.7 per 100 000 children less than 1 year old. The 3 stages of disease progression are as follows:\n\nStage 1: the initial (catarrhal) phase is indistinguishable from common upper respiratory infections with nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and sneezing, variably accompanied by low-grade fever, tearing, and conjunctival suffusion. \n\nPertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/clinical/complications.html) can cause serious and potentially life-threatening complications in infants and young children who are not fully vaccinated. Pertussis (http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/967268-clinical) is a 6-week disease divided into catarrhal, paroxysmal, and convalescent stages, each lasting from 1-2 weeks. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n< \n\nLast January 2012, the Chilean Ministry of Health launched a vaccination campaign called in Spanish 'vacuna en capullo' (literally meaning 'cocoon vaccination') which consists in immunizing persons who have direct contact with newborns. \n\nStage 2: patients in the 2nd (paroxysmal) phase present with paroxysms of intense coughing lasting up to several minutes. 4 of the deceased children were less than 2 months old and the other was a 4 month old baby.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Coquimbo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maule", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Lagos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Antofagasta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Rios", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1137174", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (09)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1137174", "date": "2012-05-22 20:51:09", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (09)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota (statewide)\n[2] Maine (statewide)\n[3] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\n[4] Montana (Flathead County)\n[5] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\n[6] Montana (Yellowstone County)\n[7] New Mexico (statewide) infant mortality\n[8] Iowa (Cerro Gordo County)\n[9] Washington (statewide)\n[10] Wisconsin (La Crosse County)\n[11] Illinois (Madison County)\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota (statewide)\nDate: Thu 17 May 2012\nSource: Minnesota Public Radio [edited]\nhttp://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2012/05/17/pertussis-whooping-cough/\n\n\nThe number of pertussis cases in Minnesota is surging, approaching 700 cases of the highly-contagious respiratory disease, according to the Minnesota Department of Health.\n\nThat's more than double the number of cases reported earlier this month [May 2012] and exceeds the total number of cases reported last year [2011].\n\nPertussis causes an uncontrollable, violent cough. The disease is often referred to as whooping cough because of the sound that many people make as they gasp for breath.\n\nIt's a scary and sometimes fatal disease. Infants are most at risk for severe complications including pneumonia, dehydration and seizures. Even adults can have a hard time recovering from the intense cough.\n\n'Sometimes they can cough so hard that they break ribs or break the blood vessels in their eyes,' said nurse practitioner Patsy Stinchfield, director of Infectious Disease Services at Children's Hospitals and Clinics of Minnesota.\n\n'They call it the 100-day cough. And it really is true that you can have these cough spasms for up to 100 days,' she said.\n\nPeople who have pertussis are usually infectious for the 1st 3 weeks of their illness. The disease spreads easily during this time, which is why outbreaks are often seen in clusters at the community level.\n\nMinnesota's outbreak is scattered across several counties including Hennepin and Ramsey Counties. Nearby Wright County, just west of the metro area, is also reporting a higher than usual number of cases, with 77 so far. Pertussis clusters are centered mainly in the eastern part of the county around St. Michael, Rockford, Delano and Monticello.\n\n'All of 2010, we had 97 cases for the entire year, and that was a record for us,' said Christine Austin-Roehler, health promotion coordinator for Wright County Public Health. 'If you look at the fact that we have 77 cases already and the year's not even half over with, it is a lot of cases.'\n\nMost children are vaccinated for pertussis before enrolling in school. But the vaccine starts to wear off by adolescence. A booster vaccine has been available for adolescents and adults since 2005, but many people don't get the booster.\n\nThe state has had good vaccination rates among adolescents who are due for the booster shot, said Claudia Miller, the vaccine-preventable disease surveillance supervisor for the Minnesota Department of Health. That's because they tend to see their health care providers regularly. But Miller suspects the vaccination rate could be better among adults.\n\n'We don't have a good way to measure our coverage in the adult population, but we're concerned that we're not seeing the coverage that would be necessary to turn this pertussis incidence around,' Miller said. 'This is a vaccine-preventable disease, and we really should not be seeing hundreds of cases each year if we have good immunization coverage.'\n\nPertussis is a bacterial infection and can be treated with antibiotics. However, the drugs don't do a lot to cure the symptoms, but mainly help reduce the amount of infectious particles a person can pass on to others.\n\n[Byline: Lorna Benson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Minnesota with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/minnesota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Maine (statewide)\nDate: Thu 17 May 2012\nSource: Portland (ME) Press Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.onlinesentinel.com/news/whooping-cough-on-risein-maine-across-nation_2012-05-17.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Maine is on the rise, mirroring a nationwide trend that health officials attribute in part to children and adults failing to get booster shots every 10 years. Health officials began noticing an increase in whooping cough -- pertussis -- cases in 2011, mainly in Maine's northern counties. This month, May 2012, an outbreak of 8 cases in children was reported in Skowhegan, and Scarborough school officials notified parents of 4 cases in the elementary and middle schools.\n\nThe Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention has confirmed 67 cases in 2012, up 34 percent from the 50 cases reported through 17 May 2011. Only 53 cases were reported for all of 2010.\n\nThe 67 cases in Maine so far in 2012 include 13 in Cumberland County, 10 in York County and 12 in Somerset County. In 2011, a total of 205 cases were reported in Maine, far exceeding the 53 reported cases in 2010 and the 10-year average of 82 cases per year.\n\n'People thought this disease was gone, and we know it's not,' Sears said. He said the most effective way to protect against whooping cough is vaccination. Most children get the initial vaccination, but only 60 percent to 70 percent receive the booster shot around age 11, he said.\n\nDr. Ali Kopelman of Saco PrimeCare Pediatrics said that in the past year, she has treated 10 children with pertussis, including 3 in the past 3 months. All of the patients were ages 4 to 10 and were up to date on vaccinations.\n\n[Byline: Gillian Graham]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Maine with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/maine.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania (Allegheny County)\nDate: Thu 17 May 2012\nSource: Patch.com [edited]\nhttp://plum-oakmont.patch.com/articles/county-health-department-reports-growing-incidence-of-whooping-cough\n\n\nThe Allegheny County Health Department announced this week that a growing number of pertussis cases are being reported in the county. There have been 46 confirmed or probable pertussis cases since the beginning of 2012, well above the average of 7 reported cases in that period over the past several years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Pennsylvania with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Montana (Flathead County)\nDate: Thu 17 May 2012\nSource: KCFW [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcmontana.com/news/31080535/detail.html\n\n\nFlathead County health officials are inundated with the onslaught of whooping cough tests. Six new cases have been confirmed in the county, bringing the total to 36. Four of those newly confirmed are in the same class as a child diagnosed on Tue 15 May 2012.\n\nCurrently, whooping cough is in 9 schools in the Flathead. County health officials say the labs are packed with cultures waiting to be tested. School administrators we spoke with had plenty of praise for the health department. 'The health department has been great. We spoke back and forth probably about 3 or 4 times yesterday [16 May 2012] with them, and they've been full of all kinds of helpful information,' said Dr. Ann Mincklers, superintendent of Helena Flats School. 'Their directions have been clear and straightforward. We really depend on them, but we've never been through anything like this before, so we appreciate all the help that they've given us.'\n\n[Byline: Rebecca Vogt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Montana with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/montana.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Thu 17 May 2012\nSource: Helenair [edited]\nhttp://helenair.com/news/local/four-new-whooping-cough-cases-found-in-county/article_13cbe2c8-9fe8-11e1-bebf-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nThere are 4 new Helena-area cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, bringing the total to 23 since the end of March 2012, which is significantly higher than 2011 when 11 cases were reported for the entire year.\n\nOfficials with the Lewis and Clark County Health Department say it's likely that additional cases have not been diagnosed and issued a news release asking people who are sick to stay home. The persistence of the outbreak has prompted county health officials to also urge all residents, adults and children, to make sure they're up to date on their pertussis vaccinations.\n\nPertussis is not uncommon, but there has been a spike in infections in 2012. Montana has seen 155 confirmed cases so far in 2011, compared to 54 at this time in 2011. The disease has been reported in 17 counties, according to the state Department of Public Health and Human Services.\n\n[Byline: Alana Listoe]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Montana with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/montana.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[6] Montana (Yellowstone County)\nDate: Wed 16 May 2012\nSource: Laurel Outlook [edited]\nhttp://www.laureloutlook.com/news/article_91b949f2-9f6e-11e1-ad44-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nSix confirmed cases of pertussis, or 'whooping cough,' in Yellowstone County have been reported to county health officials. Among them is a Laurel resident.\n\nThe Laurel High School (LHS) issued an Alert Now message to parents mid-morning on Fri 11 May 2012, stating: 'We have received confirmation from a high school student's family that there is a confirmed case of pertussis in their home. If you have a child with reduced immunities, we encourage you to take precautionary measures including contacting your medical care provider.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Montana with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/montana.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[7] New Mexico (statewide) infant mortality\nDate: Wed 16 May 2012\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.necn.com/05/16/12/NM-whoop-cough-cases-up-as-fewer-get-sho/landing_health.html?&apID=0b788266a3e6414fa858d16378d59b61\n\n\nThe number of children in New Mexico who were exempt from required vaccinations has tripled, as the number of cases of whooping cough reported in the state spiked in recent years, state health officials said.\n\nA recent state report shows the number of exemptions increased 3-fold since 1999 to nearly 3400. Meanwhile, the state's pertussis cases jumped from 85 in 2009 to 274 in 2011, according to state Department of Health data.\n\nNew Mexico law allows parents to exempt their children from required vaccinations by claiming a religious or personal belief that forbids vaccinations. The rate of such exemptions was 5.8 per 1000 children in 2011, up from 2 per 1000 in 1999.\n\nAbout 112 pertussis cases were reported in 2012 through 5 May 2012, according to the Albuquerque Journal.\n\nState health officials remain uncertain what role vaccine exemptions play in outbreaks of preventable diseases such as pertussis, said David Selvage, a state Department of Health epidemiologist. 'When you look at cases of pertussis, if you are in an area where there are increased numbers of vaccine exemptions, there's an increased chance that you're going to be in a pertussis cluster,' Selvage said. The vaccine 'is the best protection we have against pertussis, but it's probably somewhere in the neighborhood of 80-to-85 percent effective,' Selvage said.\n\nA 2-month-old baby in San Miguel County died in May 2012, making it the 1st pertussis-related death of a New Mexico infant since 2005. Infants 6 months and younger are most vulnerable to whooping cough because they have not received multiple doses of the vaccine, said Dr. Joan Baumbach, the state's medical epidemiologist. Health officials were uncertain how the infant was exposed to pertussis. The baby had received the 1st in a 4-dose series of childhood pertussis vaccinations, the agency said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of New Mexico with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/new-mexico.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[8] Iowa (Cerro Gordo County)\nDate: Wed 16 May 2012\nSource: KIMT [edited]\nhttp://www.kimt.com/content/localnews/story/More-Whooping-Cough-Cases-in-North-Iowa/tjlYifQxikmVe6VITXl-7Q.cspx\n\n\nMore cases of whooping cough are turning up in north Iowa. Health officials with Cerro Gordo county say they've looked into 9 cases of pertussis this past week. The Cerro Gordo County Department of Public Health is urging people to check their medical records to make sure they're up to date with the pertussis vaccinations.\n\n[Byline: Amy Fleming]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Iowa with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/iowa.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[9] Washington (statewide)\nDate: Mon 14 May 2012\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/other/news/may1412pertussis-br.html\n\n\nWashington State is battling its biggest pertussis outbreak in more than 3 decades, and cuts in local health department budgets are among the factors reported to be complicating the state's response to the epidemic.\n\nSeveral states have reported pertussis outbreaks in 2012, but Washington's outbreak appears to be the largest. So far this year [2012], 1284 cases have been reported, a nearly 10-fold increase from 2011, according to the most recent update from the Washington State Department of Health (WSDH). On 3 Apr 2012, the state's health secretary, Mary Selecky, announced that the disease had reached epidemic levels. Fueled by concerns about the risks to babies who are too young to be vaccinated, the WSDH urged state residents to verify their vaccination status and launched public service radio announcements.\n\nOn 3 May 2012, Washington Governor Chris Gregoire tapped emergency funds to help curb the pertussis epidemic, urged healthcare professionals to get vaccinated and to vaccinate their patients, and announced that the CDC was allowing the state to redirect some funds to buy 27 000 doses of pertussis vaccine for uninsured and underinsured adults.\n\nRising numbers of cases in Skagit County have placed a burden on the local medical system, and county health officials have asked doctors to stop testing, which can be costly and delay diagnosis and treatment, and instead to use empiric antibiotic treatment on patients with pertussis symptoms, the New York Times reported on 12 May 2012.\n\nHoward Leibrand, MD, health officer for Skagit County, told the Times that the public health department's staff is half the size it was in 2008, thanks to years of budget cutting. Skagit County officials estimate that only one in 5 cases is being reported, which could mean the number of pertussis cases is much higher than official counts indicate.\n\nIn an update on national pertussis activity yesterday [13 May 2012], ProMED-mail, the online reporting system of the International Society for Infectious Diseases, highlighted 10 media reports detailing infant deaths or outbreaks since the end of April 2012 from 8 different states. The infant deaths were reported from Massachusetts, Idaho, and Arizona. In addition, the New Mexico Department of Health on 7 May 2012 reported the pertussis death of a 2-month old baby, the state's 1st from the disease since 2005.\n\nBesides staffing issues, health departments working to slow pertussis outbreaks have 2 other notable challenges: under-immunization and signs that the vaccine may not provide protection for as long as previously thought. For example, a 2011 report from the CDC of vaccination coverage in kindergarteners during the 2009-10 school year found that the level of school vaccine exemptions varied by state, with Washington state having the nation's highest level. As a result, Washington legislators last year [2011] tightened vaccine exemption laws, which now require parents to show they have consulted a physician before opting out of immunizations for their children, the Times reported.\n\nHowever, Thomas Clark, MD, an epidemiologist with the CDC's meningitis and vaccine-preventable disease branch, told the Times that many people sickened in outbreaks in Washington and other states received their childhood vaccinations, but changes in the vaccine in the early 1990s to reduce side effects may have had an impact on how long immunity lasts.\n\nPertussis outbreaks, especially a 2010 one in California that sickened more than 9100 people and led to the deaths of 10 babies, have prompted actions from the CDC's vaccine advisors. Earlier in 2012, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) streamlined its pertussis vaccine recommendation for adults, advising that anyone over age 19 receive one dose of tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (Tdap) if they haven't received it already. In late 2010, ACIP also adjusted its pertussis vaccine recommendation to shore up a gap in protection in children ages 7 through 9 who haven't received all their recommended pertussis immunizations or whose status isn't known.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington State with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[10] Wisconsin (La Crosse County)\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nSource: La Crosse (WI) Tribune [edited]\nhttp://lacrossetribune.com/news/local/county-reports-spike-in-whooping-cough-cases/article_aac24a22-a101-11e1-b8f2-001a4bcf887a.html\n\n\nThe number whooping cough cases in Wisconsin are at levels not seen since 2004. In La Crosse County alone, there have been 33 confirmed cases, 17 in the past week.\n\n'We are concerned; we are watching,' said Traci Lien, a public health nurse for the La Crosse County Health Department. The state has 914 confirmed and 542 probable cases so far this year [2012], nearly matching the 1078 confirmed in 2012. La Crosse County gets about 8 cases in an average year.\n\n[Byline: Jessica Larsen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Wisconsin with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[11] Illinois (Madison County)\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nSource: Highland News-Democrat [edited]\nhttp://www.bnd.com/2012/05/18/2180254/another-five-cases-of-whooping.html\n\n\nWhile Madison County's 'spike' in pertussis cases has slowed, health officials are still concerned about the sudden increase in so-called 'whooping cough' cases. Another 5 cases of pertussis have been reported to the Madison County Health Department since the 1st 14 cases appeared almost overnight in late April 2012. That makes 19 cases in Madison County just in April and May of 2012, when there were only 16 in all of 2011.\n\n'We are not finding any common links between the cases,' Health Department spokeswoman Amy Yaeger said. 'They are not all at the same school, barbecue or birthday party.'\n\n[Byline: Elizabeth Donald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Illinois with counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/illinois.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[The current substantial increase in pertussis cases probably has multiple etiologies, including parental-signed exemptions to the vaccination, overall under-vaccination, and waning immunity of the vaccine protection. The currently used acellular pertussis vaccine, as compared to the previously used whole cell killed vaccine, is much less reactogenic in children and able to be given to adults. However, research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) has been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. If so, these changes may result in a need for modifications to the currently used acellular pertussis vaccines, and without these modifications, selection and further spread of clones not as protected for by the vaccine will continue to increase.\n\nThe following is a discussion regarding pertussis from the CDC web site: http://www.cdc.gov/Features/Pertussis/):\n\nPertussis (whooping cough) is a very contagious disease caused by a type of bacterium called _Bordetella pertussis_. Among vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is one of the most commonly occurring ones in the USA.\n\nPertussis vaccine protection\n----------------------------\nThere is high pertussis vaccine coverage for children nationwide. However, protection from the childhood vaccine decreases over time. Preteens, teens and adults need to be revaccinated, even if they were completely vaccinated as children.\n\nAlso, pertussis vaccines are very effective but not 100 percent effective. If pertussis is circulating in the community, there is still a chance that a fully vaccinated person can catch this very contagious disease. When you or your child develops a cold that includes a prolonged or severe cough, it may be pertussis. The best way to know is to contact your doctor.\n\nPertussis symptoms\n------------------\nPertussis can cause serious illness in infants, children and adults. The disease starts like the common cold, with runny nose or congestion, sneezing, and maybe mild cough or fever. But after 1-2 weeks, severe coughing can begin.\n\nUnlike the common cold, pertussis can become a series of coughing fits that continues for weeks. Pertussis can cause violent and rapid coughing, over and over, until the air is gone from the lungs and you are forced to inhale with a loud 'whooping' sound. In infants, the cough can be minimal or not even there.\n\nWhen the source of whooping cough was identified, mothers were responsible for 30-40 percent of infant infections. If you are pregnant and have not been previously vaccinated with Tdap (the whooping cough booster shot), talk with your doctor about getting one dose of Tdap, preferably during the 3rd trimester or late 2nd trimester, or immediately after delivery before leaving the hospital or birthing center with your newborn.\n\nDisease complications\n---------------------\nPertussis is most severe for babies; more than half of infants younger than one year of age who get the disease must be hospitalized. About one in 5 infants with pertussis get pneumonia (lung infection), and about one in 100 will have convulsions. In rare cases (one in 100), pertussis can be deadly, especially in infants.\n\nHow pertussis spreads\n---------------------\nPeople with pertussis usually spread the disease by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others, who then breathe in the pertussis bacteria. Many infants who get pertussis are infected by parents, older siblings, or other caregivers who might not even know they have the disease.\n\nPertussis trends\n----------------\nReported cases of pertussis vary from year to year and tend to peak every 3-5 years. In 2010, 27 550 cases of pertussis were reported in the USA, and many more cases go unreported. 27 deaths were reported, 25 of these deaths were in children younger than one year old. Since the 1980s, there has been an increase in the number of cases of pertussis, especially among teens (10-19 years of age) and babies younger than 6 months of age. In 2010, an increase in reported cases among 7-10 year olds was seen. This new trend reinforces the need for a routinely recommended booster dose of Tdap at age 11 or 12 years.\n\nPreventing pertussis\n--------------------\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is to get vaccinated. Parents can also help protect infants by keeping them away as much as possible from anyone who has cold symptoms or is coughing.\n\nVaccine recommendations\n-----------------------\nFor Infants and Children: In the USA, the recommended pertussis vaccine for children is called DTaP. This is a safe and effective combination vaccine that protects children against 3 diseases: diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. For maximum protection against pertussis, children need 5 DTaP shots. The 3 shots are given at 2, 4, and 6 months of age. The 4th shot is given at 15 through 18 months of age, and a 5th shot is given when a child enters school, at 4 through 6 years of age. If a 7-10 year old is not up-to-date with DTaP vaccines, a dose of Tdap should be given before the 11-12 year old check up.\n\nFor Preteens and Teens: Vaccine protection for pertussis, tetanus, and diphtheria can decrease with time. Preteens going to the doctor for their regular check-up at age 11 or 12 years should get a booster vaccine, called Tdap. Teens and young adults who didn't get a booster of Tdap as a preteen should get one dose when they visit their health care provider.\n\nFor Pregnant Women: Pregnant women who have not been previously vaccinated with Tdap should get one dose of Tdap during the 3rd trimester or late 2nd trimester, or immediately postpartum, before leaving the hospital or birthing center. By getting Tdap during pregnancy, maternal pertussis antibodies transfer to the newborn, likely providing protection against pertussis in early life, before the baby starts getting DTaP vaccines. Tdap will also protect the mother at time of delivery, making her less likely to transmit pertussis to her infant.\n\nFor Adults: Adults who didn't get Tdap as a preteen or teen should get one dose of Tdap. Getting vaccinated with Tdap at least 2 weeks before coming into close contact with an infant is especially important for families with, and caregivers of, new infants. Adults 65 years and older who have close contact with infants should also get a dose of Tdap if they never have before.\n\nThe easiest thing for adults to do is to get Tdap instead of their next regular tetanus booster as the Td shot that is recommended for adults every 10 years. The dose of Tdap can be given earlier than the 10-year mark, so it's a good idea for adults to talk to a health care provider about what's best for their specific situation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe following is a discussion regarding pertussis from the CDC web site: http://www.cdc.gov/Features/Pertussis/):\n\nPertussis (whooping cough) is a very contagious disease caused by a type of bacterium called _Bordetella pertussis_. However, research by both Dr Frits R Mooi from the Netherlands (Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115) and Dr Lyn Gilbert from Australia (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103) has been previously highlighted in ProMED-mail reflecting antigenic changes in circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ which may be causing the increased number of pertussis cases throughout the world. The number of pertussis cases in Minnesota is surging, approaching 700 cases of the highly-contagious respiratory disease, according to the Minnesota Department of Health. This month, May 2012, an outbreak of 8 cases in children was reported in Skowhegan, and Scarborough school officials notified parents of 4 cases in the elementary and middle schools. \n\nSeveral states have reported pertussis outbreaks in 2012, but Washington's outbreak appears to be the largest. If you have a child with reduced immunities, we encourage you to take precautionary measures including contacting your medical care provider.'\n\n--\n So far this year [2012], 1284 cases have been reported, a nearly 10-fold increase from 2011, according to the most recent update from the Washington State Department of Health (WSDH). The Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention has confirmed 67 cases in 2012, up 34 percent from the 50 cases reported through 17 May 2011. In this update:\n[1] Minnesota (statewide)\n The number of whooping cough cases in Maine is on the rise, mirroring a nationwide trend that health officials attribute in part to children and adults failing to get booster shots every 10 years. ------------------\nPertussis can cause serious illness in infants, children and adults. \n\nDisease complications\n Since the 1980s, there has been an increase in the number of cases of pertussis, especially among teens (10-19 years of age) and babies younger than 6 months of age. In 2010, 27 550 cases of pertussis were reported in the USA, and many more cases go unreported. [11] Illinois (Madison County)\n\n******\n [Byline: Lorna Benson]\n\n--\n [Byline: Gillian Graham]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Rebecca Vogt]\n\n--\n [Byline: Alana Listoe]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Amy Fleming]\n\n--\n [Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\n [Byline: Jessica Larsen]\n\n--\n Pertussis vaccine protection\n \n\n'We don't have a good way to measure our coverage in the adult population, but we're concerned that we're not seeing the coverage that would be necessary to turn this pertussis incidence around,' Miller said.
