USA (05)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Montana (Ravalli County)\n[2] Washington (Snohomish County)\n[3] Texas (Bell County)\n[4] Colorado (Boulder County)\n\n******\n[1] Montana (Ravalli County)\nDate: Tue 10 Apr 2012\nSource: Billings Gazette, Ravalli Republic report [edited]\nhttp://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/pinesdale-elementary-school-closed-by-whooping-cough/article_edcbbabb-c53e-5352-870a-a3f58ecd6ac8.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of pertussis (whooping cough) forced the closure of Pines Academy in Pinesdale on Mon 8 Apr 2012, and prompted the Ravalli County Public Health Department to issue a warning.\n\n'We have had 5 confirmed cases, which is definitely an outbreak,' said Ravalli County public health nurse Judy Griffin. 'And we are definitely expecting that number to go up in the next few days. It's a very serious disease. People die from it.'\n\nGriffin said all 5 of the people who tested positive live in the Pinesdale area northwest of Hamilton. Pines Academy is an elementary school there; school officials could not be reached for comment.\n\n'The school voluntarily made the decision to close all week this week [week of 9 Apr 2012],' Griffin said. 'People who might be sick need to get to the hospital, but otherwise stay at home and avoid contact if at all possible with other people and family members.'\n\nGriffin spent the day Mon 8 Apr 2012, on the phone with officials from all over Montana, some of whom are reporting similar outbreaks. 'Kalispell [Flathead County] had a case, Lewis and Clark County had a case, and there has been reports from all over the state,' she said. 'Washington State has had over 600 cases so far in 2012, so they are at an epidemic stage.'\n\n[Byline: David Erickson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/29NL. The counties mentioned are located in western Montana can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/montana.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n*****\n[2] Washington (Snohomish County)\nDate: Tue 9 Apr 2012\nSource: NWCN [edited]\nhttp://www.nwcn.com/home/?fId=146703005&fPath=/news/local&fDomain=10212\n\n\nIt's back to school for many spring breakers, but even before vacation, schools like Silver Lake Elementary in Everett saw 10 percent of its student body out sick.\n\nSnohomish County Health District officials can't say for sure what's behind the high number of absentees. They are tracking a health epidemic countywide: pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\n'It's a tremendously serious disease for us and we're definitely in a middle of an epidemic,' said Tim McDonald, Snohomish County Health District spokesman.\n\nWhooping cough has hit Marysville the hardest in Snohomish County; 69 cases have been reported so far in 2012, as well as 32 in Arlington, and 25 cases in Everett.\n\n'That's definitely the tip of the iceberg -- many more cases out there beyond the confirmed,' said McDonald.\n\nDuring this health epidemic, experts stress all teens and adults need to get the Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccine to prevent spreading it to the more susceptible infants and young children.\n\n[Byline: Teresa Yuan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/29NK. Snohomish County in north west Washington can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Texas (Bell County)\nDate: Tue 9 Apr 2012\nSource: KWTX [edited]\nhttp://www.kwtx.com/news/health/headlines/More_Than_20_Cases_Of_Whooping_Cough_Confirmed_Here_146687055.html\n\n\nThe Bell County Public Health District said Mon 8 Apr 2012, it has received 7 more confirmed cases of pertussis, raising the total number of confirmed cases in the county to 21. The health department said it also has more than 20 other probable cases.\n\nThe health department first issued an advisory on 8 Mar 2012 after 4 Bell County residents were diagnosed with pertussis, also referred to as whooping cough. 3 of those cases were identified at Lakewood Elementary School in Belton, and Kennedy-Powell and Cater Elementary Schools in Temple, officials said. The 4th case was diagnosed in a 9-week-old Bell County infant.\n\nThe health department said Mon 8 Apr 2012, 3 of the most recent cases are linked to an unnamed school in Killeen.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/29NM. Bell County in central Texas can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/texas.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n*****\n[4] Colorado (Boulder County)\nDate: Sat 6 Apr 2012\nSource: KDVR [edited]\nhttp://kdvr.com/2012/04/06/health-officials-boulder-has-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nA 7-week-old baby fought for her life after being diagnosed with pertussis. She is the most serious of 3 dozen cases diagnosed in 2012 in Boulder in what health officials are calling an outbreak.\n\nDoctors at Children's Hospital diagnosed her with pertussis, also called whooping cough. For 9 days, she was hooked up to oxygen inside an incubator constantly being monitored at the hospital's Neonatal Intensive Care Unit.\n\n'It was terrifying because we know that whooping cough can be fatal especially in such little babies. She was actually having such a hard time breathing, they had to help her breath and she stopped breathing a couple of times. So it was probably the worse thing I have ever went through,' the mother said.\n\nThe infant is one of 37 cases of whooping cough in Boulder County in 2012. 30 of those cases are children who are under the age of 18. Health officials are calling it an outbreak.\n\nThere were some folks who were not vaccinated or were not up to date in their vaccinations,' said Sophia Yager a nurse at Boulder County Public Health.\n\n[Byline: Sara Morris]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/29NN. Boulder County in north central Colorado can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/colorado.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized like the one described in the Colorado posting. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations. It is likely given the limited number of contacts 5-week-old infants have that the reservoir of the infant was a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected, against which we are no longer as well protected with the current vaccines. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[Byline: David Erickson]\n\n--\n \n\nThe health department said Mon 8 Apr 2012, 3 of the most recent cases are linked to an unnamed school in Killeen. \n\nThe health department first issued an advisory on 8 Mar 2012 after 4 Bell County residents were diagnosed with pertussis, also referred to as whooping cough. \n\n\nThe Bell County Public Health District said Mon 8 Apr 2012, it has received 7 more confirmed cases of pertussis, raising the total number of confirmed cases in the county to 21. \n\nWhooping cough has hit Marysville the hardest in Snohomish County; 69 cases have been reported so far in 2012, as well as 32 in Arlington, and 25 cases in Everett. \n\n'The school voluntarily made the decision to close all week this week [week of 9 Apr 2012],' Griffin said. Date: Tue 9 Apr 2012\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Everett", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hamilton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ravalli County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arlington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Snohomish County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bell County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/colorado.shtml", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ravalli Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Griffin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1078115", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1078115", "date": "2012-03-22 21:31:31", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (04): NEWLY EMERGING CLONES, DISCUSSION\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2012\nFrom: Dr. Frits Mooi [edited]\n<Frits.Mooi@rivm.nl>\n\n\nThe Australian study is important and it confirms European studies in which this strain has been linked to pertussis outbreaks. The strain is not 'new,' however, and was 1st identified in 2004 in the Netherlands (1). On the basis of a mutation in the pertussis toxin promoter region, we designated this strain the P3 strain (or lineage) and showed that it produced higher levels of pertussis toxin compared to the strains it replaced (2).\n\nThe emergence of P3 strains was found to be associated with increases in pertussis notifications in Finland and the Netherlands (2). We also found that the P3 strains have a global distribution and very likely evolved recently (3 and unpublished data). The association of P3 strains with pertussis outbreaks in various parts of the world underlines the importance of high vaccine coverage, especially with respect to infants and it also indicates that we need better pertussis vaccines (4, 5).\n\nReferences:\n1. Schouls LM, van der Heide HG, Vauterin L, Vauterin P, Mooi FR: Multiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis of Dutch _Bordetella pertussis_ strains reveals rapid genetic changes with clonal expansion during the late 1990s. J Bacteriol. 2004;186: 5496-5505.\n\n2. Mooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al:. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009;15: 1206-13.\n\n3. van Gent M, Bart MJ, van der Heide HG, et al: SNP-based typing: a useful tool to study _Bordetella pertussis_ populations. PLoS One 2011;6:e20340.\n\n4. Mooi FR, van Oirschot H, Heuvelman K, et al: Polymorphism in the _Bordetella pertussis_ virulence factors P69/pertactin and pertussis toxin in The Netherlands: temporal trends and evidence for vaccine-driven evolution. Infect Immun. 1998;66: 670-75.\n\n5. Mooi, FR: 2010. _Bordetella pertussis_ and vaccination: the persistence of a genetically monomorphic pathogen. Infect Genet Evol 20910;10: 36-49.\n\n--\nDr. Frits R Mooi\nDutch National Institute for Public Health and the Environment\n<Frits.Mooi@rivm.nl>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Mooi for his comments and wishes to recognize the seminal work from his group regarding this field. It is becoming more apparent that alterations in the pertussis vaccine and/or vaccination schedule may be necessary. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n On the basis of a mutation in the pertussis toxin promoter region, we designated this strain the P3 strain (or lineage) and showed that it produced higher levels of pertussis toxin compared to the strains it replaced (2). \n\n--\nDr. Frits R Mooi\nDutch National Institute for Public Health and the Environment\n<Frits.Mooi@rivm.nl>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Mooi for his comments and wishes to recognize the seminal work from his group regarding this field. The association of P3 strains with pertussis outbreaks in various parts of the world underlines the importance of high vaccine coverage, especially with respect to infants and it also indicates that we need better pertussis vaccines (4, 5). Mooi FR, van Oirschot H, Heuvelman K, et al: Polymorphism in the _Bordetella pertussis_ virulence factors P69/pertactin and pertussis toxin in The Netherlands: temporal trends and evidence for vaccine-driven evolution. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Schouls LM, van der Heide HG, Vauterin L, Vauterin P, Mooi FR: Multiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis of Dutch _Bordetella pertussis_ strains reveals rapid genetic changes with clonal expansion during the late 1990s. van Gent M, Bart MJ, van der Heide HG, et al: SNP-based typing: a useful tool to study _Bordetella pertussis_ populations. PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (04): NEWLY EMERGING CLONES, DISCUSSION\n*************************************************************\n \n\nThe emergence of P3 strains was found to be associated with increases in pertussis notifications in Finland and the Netherlands (2).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vauterin P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1076103", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1076103", "date": "2012-03-21 16:36:32", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): NEWLY EMERGING CLONES\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 Mar 2012\nSource: ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-03-21/whooping-cough-strain-27breaking-through-vaccines27/3902762/?site=newcastle\n\n\nA spike in whooping cough [pertussis] cases may have been caused by a new strain of the bacterium that is [more] resistant to existing vaccines, new research suggests. In 2011, the number of diagnosed whooping cough cases in Australia rose to 38 000, the highest since records began in 1991.\n\nA team of Australian scientists studied samples taken from patients in 4 states and found the new strain of the bacterium now accounts for 84 percent of whooping cough cases. Among the recent victims was a 5-week-old baby boy who died in an Adelaide hospital 18 months ago. Adults can get whooping cough as well.\n\nProfessor Lyn Gilbert, who is the director of the Centre for Infectious Diseases and Microbiology at Sydney's Westmead Hospital, says the strain is breaking through the protection of vaccines. 'What we suspect, although it's circumstantial evidence at this stage, is that one of the reasons that there has been a significant increase in Australia and many other countries in the last few years is that this strain is not affected as much by the vaccine as the older strains were,' she said. 'So that it's been able to break through the protection offered by the vaccines.'\n\nDoctor Jeremy McAnulty from New South Wales Health says that does not mean people should not be vaccinated. 'Before vaccinations against whooping cough it was a major killer, there were hundreds of deaths,' he said. He says even where the vaccine does not prevent the bacteria, it still reduces its severity.\n\n[Byline: Brendan Trembath]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Dr Gilbert and her colleagues have just published their findings (Octavia S, Sintchenko V, Gilbert GL, et al: Newly emerging clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ carrying prn2 and ptxP3 alleles implicated in Australian pertussis epidemic in 2008-2010. J Infect Dis 2012; 205: 1220-24; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22416243) suggesting that acellular pertussis vaccines seem to select for _B. pertussis_ clones carrying antigens that differ from those in the vaccine. It is not clear if these breakthroughs in immunization would have or will occur from use of the whole cell vaccine, which is still used in some countries. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z_*.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nA team of Australian scientists studied samples taken from patients in 4 states and found the new strain of the bacterium now accounts for 84 percent of whooping cough cases. \n\n\nA spike in whooping cough [pertussis] cases may have been caused by a new strain of the bacterium that is [more] resistant to existing vaccines, new research suggests. J Infect Dis 2012; 205: 1220-24; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22416243) suggesting that acellular pertussis vaccines seem to select for _B. pertussis_ clones carrying antigens that differ from those in the vaccine. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Dr Gilbert and her colleagues have just published their findings (Octavia S, Sintchenko V, Gilbert GL, et al: Newly emerging clones of _Bordetella pertussis_ carrying prn2 and ptxP3 alleles implicated in Australian pertussis epidemic in 2008-2010. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nProfessor Lyn Gilbert, who is the director of the Centre for Infectious Diseases and Microbiology at Sydney's Westmead Hospital, says the strain is breaking through the protection of vaccines. What we suspect, although it's circumstantial evidence at this stage, is that one of the reasons that there has been a significant increase in Australia and many other countries in the last few years is that this strain is not affected as much by the vaccine as the older strains were,' she said. Source: ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\n **\n He says even where the vaccine does not prevent the bacteria, it still reduces its severity. Adults can get whooping cough as well.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1071497", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (02): (QL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1071497", "date": "2012-03-16 17:39:48", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): (QUEENSLAND)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 14 Mar 2012\nSource: Gold Coast.com [edited]\nhttp://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2012/03/14/399211_gold-coast-news.html\n\n\nThe [Australian] Gold Coast is under threat from deadly whooping cough with a dramatic rise in the number of cases reported in 2012. As of 13 Feb 2012, Queensland Health reported 876 cases of whooping cough (medical name pertussis) across the state since the beginning of 2012, that was almost 200 more cases than the average reported during the same period between 2007 and 2011.\n\nGold Coast Population Health Unit physician Doctor Don Staines, based at Robina Hospital, said 15 to 20 cases of the highly contagious disease were reported to him each week. Dr Staines said he was not surprised by the recent outbreaks. 'We've been in a significant pertussis event for 3 years, which basically says there have been increased cases across the community,' he said. He added that the Coast community needed to be extra wary of the disease as [pertussis] immunizations did not necessarily last as long as other, more common vaccines.\n\n[Byline: Sophia Lazarides]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear how many of the cases have occurred in the high risk group, infants under 6 months of age. The commonest complications of pertussis infection, especially in young infants, include apnea [stopping breathing], pneumonia, and weight loss secondary to feeding difficulties and post-coughing vomiting. Seizures and death also occur. Other complications include difficulty sleeping, pneumothorax, nose bleeds, subconjunctival hemorrhage, intracranial hematoma, rectal prolapse, urinary incontinence, and rib fracture. The overall complication rate of pertussis is 5-6 per cent, but among infants younger than 6 months, the complication rate can be 3-4 times that number.\n\nRecommendations on the use of 'cocooning' acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA have been developed in an attempt to expand protection in susceptibles to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not yet been adequately immunized. The now recommended use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nSusceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but other issues may be at work. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As of 13 Feb 2012, Queensland Health reported 876 cases of whooping cough (medical name pertussis) across the state since the beginning of 2012, that was almost 200 more cases than the average reported during the same period between 2007 and 2011. The overall complication rate of pertussis is 5-6 per cent, but among infants younger than 6 months, the complication rate can be 3-4 times that number. \n\nSusceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n The commonest complications of pertussis infection, especially in young infants, include apnea [stopping breathing], pneumonia, and weight loss secondary to feeding difficulties and post-coughing vomiting. Dr. Amy Person, health officer for Benton and Franklin counties, said most of the reported Tri-City cases have been schoolchildren or people around them. A small outbreak was reported in some Kennewick schools in February, and Person said she has heard some recent reports of pertussis in Pasco schools.\n\nPerson said the increased number of cases in Benton and Franklin counties isn't abnormal, particularly as nearby counties were reporting outbreaks in late 2010.\n\nGrant County experienced 57 cases, including one infant death, during a 16-month outbreak that started in late 2010. included one infant death. In the previous five years, Grant County reported one to four cases per year.\n\nBenton County was seeing very few cases during Grant County's outbreak, but now is seeing activity while Grant County has had no reported cases in 2012.\n\n'I think it ended up just being our time,' Person said. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full paper is available at http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Illinois (McHenry county)\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n[byline: Kaitlyn Piccoli]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< From the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. [2] Wisconsin (Chippewa county)\n Date: Fri 9 Mar 2012\n Date: Fri 9 Mar 2012\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-01-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2011-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McHenry County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1076102", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1076102", "date": "2012-03-22 21:29:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (03)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas (Bell County)\n[2] North Carolina (Orange County)\n[3] Pennsylvania (Chester County)\n[4] Washington (Kittitas County)\n[5] Washington (Jefferson County)\n[6] New York (Tompkins County)\n\n*****\n[1] Texas (Bell County)\nDate: Mon 19 Mar 2012\nSource: KXXV [edited]\nhttp://www.kxxv.com/story/17193198/whooping-cough-becoming-a-growing-concern-in-bell-county\n\n\nMore cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in the Bell County area. As of Monday, 19 Mar 2012, there are 14 confirmed cases in both Belton and Temple, with 8 probable cases that have yet to be confirmed. The health department is expecting more cases to surface. While the cases are, for the most part, not connected, it is still vital to recognize symptoms early.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*XX - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n*****\n[2] North Carolina (Orange County)\nDate: Mon 19 Mar 2012\nSource: Chapelboro [edited]\nhttp://www.chapelboro.com/Whooping-Cough-Confirmed-at-Carrboro-Elementary/12586474\n\n\n'We have had 2 cases in the same grade level that have been confirmed,' says Community Health Services Supervisor Judy Butler.\n\nLast November 2011, WCHL reported that a kindergartner in the Chapel Hill-Carrboro school system had developed the disease. That student was also at Carrboro elementary.\n\nButler says school system parents should take a few basic precautions. 'Have your child fully vaccinated and to be alert for symptoms in your child and if they do have symptoms, consult your physician.' says Butler. 'Keep the child away from infants, pregnant women, and people are immunocompromised in particular. If whooping cough is strongly suspected, they need to stay away from everyone.'\n\nOn average, Orange County sees about 3 cases of whooping cough per year. But Butler says those numbers have been going up in recent years.\n\n'2008-2009 was a big year; there were 29 cases. Then in 2010, 2; 2011 we had 3 and we've had more in 2012,' says Butler. 'Alamance [County] is also having a significant outbreak.'\n\nAlthough the pertussis vaccine isn't 100 percent effective, Butler says those who have been immunized tend to have milder cases if they do develop the disease. All North Carolina children are required by law to receive a vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Anne Brenner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*XY - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n*****\n[3] Pennsylvania (Chester County)\nDate: Mon 19 Mar 2012\nSource: Patch.com [edited]\nhttp://malvern.patch.com/articles/pertussis-case-confirmed-at-general-wayne-elementary-school\n\n\nGreat Valley School District alerted parents Monday morning, 19 Mar 2012, that a student at General Wayne Elementary School was diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nThe new case is the 7th confirmed case of pertussis in the Great Valley School District. There have been 4 in Great Valley High School, 1 in Great Valley Middle School, 1 in Kathryn D. Markley Elementary School and the latest in General Wayne.\n\nAccording to Betsy Walls, director of Personal Health Services in the Chester County Department of Health, 'What we're seeing nationally is that [for] people who have the vaccine and have received age-appropriate dosing, there's a point where protection seems to be waning and people become susceptible to pertussis.'\n\nA policy change was recently enacted to mandate that all students entering seventh grade have the vaccine, according to Walls.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*XZ - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n*****\n[4] Washington (Kittitas County)\nDate: Fri 16 Mar 2012\nSource: KNDO [edited]\nhttp://www.kndo.com/story/17179334/more-cases-of-pertussis-in-kittitas-county\n\n\n2 more cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, have been confirmed in Kittitas County. In all of 2011, there was only 1 person in Jefferson County to be stricken with what is more commonly known as whooping cough. The person hospitalized spent one night under observation.\n\n'We really want to make sure infants are protected,' Jefferson County Public Health supervisor Julia Danskin said on Tuesday, 13 Mar 2012. 'We've seen grandparents come through wanting to be immunized. So I think we have increased awareness a lot.'\n\n80 percent of the people who contracted pertussis this year have not been fully immunized, Danskin said. But there is no specific school or community that is being hit more than another, she said.\n\nAges of those diagnosed with pertussis range from a 6-month-old child to a 14-year-old and 3 adults, whose ages were not available.\n\n[Byline: Allison Arthur]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*X- - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n*****\n[6] New York (Tompkins County)\nDate: Wed 14 Mar 2012\nSource: The Ithaca Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.theithacajournal.com/article/20120314/NEWS01/203140327/Tompkins-Health-Department-targets-whooping-cough-through-prevention-education?odyssey=tab%7Ctopnews%7Ctext%7CFRONTPAGE\n\n\nWith a recent increase in whooping cough cases, the Tompkins County Health Department is focusing efforts to educate the public to contain the disease. 'There are more cases than we saw in all of 2011,' Tompkins County Public Health Director Frank Kruppa said Tuesday, 13 Mar 2012.\n\nAs of 13 Mar 2011, there were 15 pertussis cases recorded in 2012, 2 more than in all of 2011. The disease normally occurs more frequently in the winter, although cases can happen any time of year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*X* - CopyEd.EJP\n\nThis manuscript (Witt MA, Katz PH, Witt DJ: Unexpectedly limited durability of immunity following acellular pertussis vaccination in pre-adolescents in a North American outbreak. Clin Infect Dis. (2012) doi: 10.1093/cid/cis287) is one of the 1st detailed analyses of a recent North American pertussis outbreak found widespread disease among fully vaccinated older children. Starting approximately 3 years after prior vaccine dose, attack rates markedly increased, suggesting inadequate protection or durability from the acellular vaccine.\n\n'Abstract\n---------\nBackground: Despite widespread childhood vaccination against _Bordetella pertussis_, disease remains prevalent. It has been suggested that acellular vaccine may be less effective than previously believed. During a large outbreak, we examined the incidence of pertussis and effectiveness of vaccination in a well-vaccinated, well-defined community.\n\n'Methods: Our center provides care to 135 000 patients, 40 percent of the population of Marin County, CA. 171 patients with a positive Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test for _B. pertussis_ from 1 Mar 2010 to 31 Oct 2010 were identified. Electronic medical records were reviewed for demographics and vaccination status.\n\n'Results: We identified 171 cases of clinical pertussis; 132 in pediatric patients. There was a notable increase in cases in patients aged 8-12. The rate of testing peaked in infants, but remained relatively constant until age 12. The rate of positive tests was low for ages zero to 6, and increased in preadolescents, peaking at age 12. Vaccination rates of PCR positive preadolescents were approximately equal to that of controls. Vaccine effectiveness was 41 percent, 24 percent, 79 percent, for ages 2-7, 8-12, 13-18, respectively.\n\n'Conclusions: Our data suggests that the current schedule of acellular pertussis vaccine doses is insufficient to prevent outbreaks of pertussis. We noted a markedly increased rate of disease from age 8 through 12, proportionate to the interval since the last scheduled vaccine. Stable rates of testing ruled out selection bias. The possibility of earlier or more numerous booster doses of acellular pertussis vaccine either as part of routine immunization or for outbreak control should be entertained.'\n\nThis paper along with further observations regarding shifting of the antigenicity of the recent clones of _B. pertussis_ (Pertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones Archive Number: 20120321.1076103) further underscore the need for potential revisions in the vaccine and vaccine schedule for pertussis prevention. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*XY - CopyEd. Source: Patch.com [edited]\nhttp://malvern.patch.com/articles/pertussis-case-confirmed-at-general-wayne-elementary-school\n\n\nGreat Valley School District alerted parents Monday morning, 19 Mar 2012, that a student at General Wayne Elementary School was diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Director of Communicable Disease Control Dr Paul Armstrong said notifications in Western Australia peaked at 704 cases for the month of November 2011, and although there now appeared to be some decrease, whooping cough activity in the community remained high.\n\n'WA's last whooping cough epidemic was in 2004, and we have been overdue for a big year, which typically occurs every 3-4 years,' Dr Armstrong said. 'The increase in WA is consistent with whooping cough activity in other states in recent years.\n\n'Whooping cough affects people of all ages, but the rise in infections is particularly concerning for children under 6 months of age, in whom infection can be very severe and even life threatening.' There have been 4 deaths associated with whooping cough in babies in the past 4 years in WA.\n\n[Byline: Linda Campbell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear how many of the cases in 2011 have occurred in the high risk group, infants under 6 months of age. The commonest complications of pertussis infection, especially in young infants, include apnea, pneumonia, and weight loss secondary to feeding difficulties and post-coughing vomiting. Seizures and death also occur. Other complications include difficulty sleeping, pneumothorax, nose bleeds, subconjunctival hemorrhage, intracranial hematoma, rectal prolapse, urinary incontinence, and rib fracture. The overall complication rate of pertussis is 5-6 per cent, but among infants younger than 6 months, the complication rate can be 3-4 times that number.\n\nRecommendations on the use of 'cocooning' acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA have been developed in an attempt to expand protection in susceptibles to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized. The now recommended use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but other issues may be at work. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1DDQ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: IEWY News [edited]\nhttp: //www.iewy.com/39153-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise.html\n\n\nThe Department of Health [of Western Australia] is encouraging parents of young children to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure their families' vaccinations are up-to-date. \n\n'Whooping cough affects people of all ages, but the rise in infections is particularly concerning for children under 6 months of age, in whom infection can be very severe and even life threatening.' \n\n'WA's last whooping cough epidemic was in 2004, and we have been overdue for a big year, which typically occurs every 3-4 years,' Dr Armstrong said. ' \n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop,' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. In\na normal period 800 cases at most are recorded, a number that has been\nlargely exceeded.\n\nTo address this alarming situation, which so far in 2011 has resulted\nin the deaths of 11 infants in the Bio-Bio Region, the Ministry of\nHealth announced a novel vaccination campaign focused on controlling\nthis disease.\n\nUndersecretary Diaz explained to Radio Cooperativa the new 'cocoon\nvaccine' strategy, which consists in vaccinating pregnant mothers and\npeople older than 12 years of age whose families include newborn\ninfants. The reason, according to Diaz, is that 'the vaccine confers\nprotective immunity for approximately 10 years, therefore, young\npeople and adults are likely to contract the disease and spread it to\ninfants younger than 6 months of age, who are at the greatest risk.'\n\nSo far, 11 deaths have been recorded, 6 of them in the Bio-Bio Region\nalone. 'Children younger than 6 months of age are at risk of a very\nserious disease, respiratory distress, and death,' said the official.\n\nThe cocoon vaccination campaign will begin in Bio-Bio and seeks to\naddress the 209 per cent increase in cases of whooping cough compared\nto those reported in 2010. '(Last year) to date we had 794 cases,\ntherefore there is an almost 3-fold increase in the numbers of\nprevious years (...) While the National Immunization Program\npermanently vaccinates children against pertussis, this immunity is\nacquired after 1 year of age, therefore during the period between\nbirth and the 1st year there is risk of infection,' said Diaz.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear how many of the 2000+ cases in 2011 have occurred in\nthe high risk group, infants under 6 months of age. The commonest\ncomplications of pertussis infection, especially in young infants\ninclude apnea, pneumonia, and weight loss secondary to feeding\ndifficulties and post-coughing vomiting. Seizures and death also\noccur. Other complications include difficulty sleeping, pneumothorax,\nnose bleeds, subconjunctival hemorrhage, intracranial hematoma, rectal\nprolapse, urinary incontinence, and rib fracture. The now\nrecommended use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these\nrecommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to\npertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical\n'whoop' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be\nincreasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the\ncause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\n>From moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post (Pertussis - USA:\n(MN) 20100514.1573):\n\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults\nare generally attributed to waning immunity without considering\npotential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed\nout in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (02):\n(SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which show that\noutbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in the _B.\npertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more virulent\n(P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible\nfor the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have emerged\nworldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in\ninfectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population.\nThis is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. There have been more than 140 suspected or confirmed cases of the illness since early December 2011, according to the Fraser Health Authority.\n\nHotspots for the outbreak include the Hope, Chilliwack and Agassiz areas, but officials said it has also spread to other communities.\n\nWith this in mind, anyone traveling into the region might want to double check what their pre-existing medical travel insurance covers, just in case the worst happens.\n\nThe authority said the genuine number of cases is likely to be considerably higher because of those that are yet to be reported.\n\nChief Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Van Buynder has said the best way to safeguard against whooping cough is to get vaccinated, especially for people who have contact with children. Dr Buynder has called for adults who had the vaccination as a child to book a booster shot and parents to make sure their children are also vaccinated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 23 Feb 2012\nSource: Tri-City News [edited]\nhttp://www.tricitynews.com/news/140235883.html\n\n\nA spreading outbreak of whooping cough has prompted Fraser Health to extend its vaccination campaign across the region. More than 150 people are believed to have contracted pertussis, a highly contagious bacterial infection that causes adults to cough for months but can be deadly to babies.\n\nMedical health officer Dr. Elizabeth Brodkin said efforts to combat the illness had focused on Chilliwack and Hope [British Columbia, Canada], where the outbreak began but said the vaccine is now being made available to doctors and pharmacists across the region. 'More and more, we are seeing cases outside of Fraser East,' she said.\n\nWhooping cough cases are appearing in Burnaby, New Westminster, Langley and Maple Ridge [British Columbia, Canada], Brodkin said.\n\n'We didn't want to wait until we were seeing huge numbers of cases and a very aggressive spread,' she added. 'We saw enough cases that we became concerned and decided it was time to act.'\n\nAdults and youth in contact with young children who have not had the pertussis vaccine in the last 5 years are urged to get vaccinated. The goal is to immunize adults, for whom pertussis is more of an irritant, so they don't act as carriers infecting infants, who are most at risk and are hospitalized in more than half of cases.\n\nThree children have already been hospitalized due to the outbreak, including a 2-week-old baby that ended up in intensive care for 5 weeks. All 3 have recovered. Most infants infected get it from parents or close family members.\n\nCalifornia had a huge outbreak in 2009 that claimed the lives of 10 children; 5 more died in Saskatchewan in 2010, and 2 more children died in 2011 just across the border in Washington State, where authorities are still battling an outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Jeff Nagel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some researchers noted that: 'Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and young adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than seen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT. Report of the task force on pertussis and pertussis immunization - 1988. Pediatrics 1988; 81(June Suppl): 955). The duration of protection has varied in several studies, depending on the epidemiological setting, that is, prevalence of natural disease as well as the vaccine product used. A study in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last dose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years. Breakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.' - Mod.LL]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of British Columbia, Canada can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1ALd. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ALd.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some researchers noted that: 'Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and young adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than seen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT. \n\nCalifornia had a huge outbreak in 2009 that claimed the lives of 10 children; 5 more died in Saskatchewan in 2010, and 2 more children died in 2011 just across the border in Washington State, where authorities are still battling an outbreak. \n\nMedical health officer Dr. Elizabeth Brodkin said efforts to combat the illness had focused on Chilliwack and Hope [British Columbia, Canada], where the outbreak began but said the vaccine is now being made available to doctors and pharmacists across the region. ' \n\nChief Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Van Buynder has said the best way to safeguard against whooping cough is to get vaccinated, especially for people who have contact with children. \n\nAdults and youth in contact with young children who have not had the pertussis vaccine in the last 5 years are urged to get vaccinated. \n\nThree children have already been hospitalized due to the outbreak, including a 2-week-old baby that ended up in intensive care for 5 weeks. Nelson Marlborough\nDistrict Health Board says the outbreak in the top of the south, with\nsimilar outbreaks in West Coast and Hawke's Bay, may develop into a\nnationwide epidemic similar to 2004-2005.\n\nMedical Officer of Health for Nelson Marlborough District Dr Jill\nSherwood said so far in October 2011, it had 27 cases with a further\n16 still under investigation. In September 2011, Nelson had 40 cases\nof whooping cough. She said this disease was especially serious for\nbabies who have not yet been immunized.\n\nDr Sherwood advised parents to keep young babies away from anyone with\na cough. Adults and older children with coughs might have unrecognised\nwhooping cough and are often the source of infection for babies. 'See\nyour GP quickly if you are concerned about your health or the health\nof your child, as antibiotics prescribed early in the illness could\ndecrease the seriousness of the symptoms,' she said.\n\nWhooping cough is a preventable disease. 'If babies and young children\nare immunized, they can reduce their chance of this serious and\nsometimes life-threatening illness,' Dr Sherwood said. Babies are not\nprotected until they have received their 3 initial vaccinations, due\nat 6 weeks, 3 months and 5 months [2, 4 and 6 months in the USA -\nMod.LL]. The vaccination is free and available from GPs or practice\nnurses.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated in the posting what ages were affected by\n_Bordetella pertussis_ in this outbreak and whether any of the cases\nwere in infants or individuals who were not immunized. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Babies are not\nprotected until they have received their 3 initial vaccinations, due\nat 6 weeks, 3 months and 5 months [2, 4 and 6 months in the USA -\nMod.LL]. There are ongoing reports of the\nhighly contagious respiratory infection, which can be life\nthreatening, running rampant in the Miriam Vale and Agnes Water\ncommunities and further afield.\n\nThere have been 65 notifications of whooping cough recorded in\nGladstone in 2010. This is an alarming increase on the 11\nnotifications recorded for the same period in 2009. This dramatic\nrise in reported cases has prompted a plea by local medical officials\nfor residents to get [re-]immunized against this infection, which is\ncapable of causing serious health complications in babies under 6\nmonths of age.\n\nSpeaking with The Observer yesterday [19 Oct 2010], a local medical\npractitioner said his practice alone had recorded 14 cases in the\npast 4 months and a total of 18 for 2010. The medical practitioner\nsaid it was an alarming number, particularly considering a number of\nbabies had become ill.\n\n'It's a bit of an epidemic which has been going on for some time\nnow,' the medical practitioner said.\n\nCaused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_, whooping cough can\naffect babies, infants, adolescents, and adults. For adolescents and\nadults the infection may cause an irritating, persistent cough, which\ncan last up to 8 weeks. However, for babies and young children the\ninfection can be life threatening, particularly for those not fully\nprotected by vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Kelli Downey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains.\nAs pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which\nshow that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in\nthe _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more\nvirulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly)\nresponsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have\nemerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in\ninfectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen\npopulation. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full\npaper is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm>. - Mod.LL]\n\n[Gladstone can be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap of Australia at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0d-Y>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 20 Oct 2010\n This dramatic\nrise in reported cases has prompted a plea by local medical officials\nfor residents to get [re-]immunized against this infection, which is\ncapable of causing serious health complications in babies under 6\nmonths of age. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which\nshow that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in\nthe _B. pertussis_ population. There are ongoing reports of the\nhighly contagious respiratory infection, which can be life\nthreatening, running rampant in the Miriam Vale and Agnes Water\ncommunities and further afield. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. Speaking with The Observer yesterday [19 Oct 2010], a local medical\npractitioner said his practice alone had recorded 14 cases in the\npast 4 months and a total of 18 for 2010. Mooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. LL]\n\n[Gladstone can be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap of Australia at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0d-Y>. Most recently, we have shown that more\nvirulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly)\nresponsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1055492", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1055492", "date": "2012-02-29 10:42:29", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA\n***************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] North Carolina (Alamance county)\n[2] Missouri (Springfield, Greene county)\n[3] Pennsylvania (Chester county)\n[4] Iowa (Scott county)\n[5] Washington (King county)\n\n******\n[1] North Carolina (Alamance county)\nDate: Sat 25 Feb 2012\nSource: Times-News [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.thetimesnews.com/articles/pertussis-52838-department-outbreak.html\n\n\nThe Alamance County Health Department announced Thursday, 23 Feb 2012, that it has lifted restrictions on who can receive the Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccine. The pertussis medication, which is usually 35 dollars, is now free for a limited time, and the department will be holding a communitywide vaccination clinic in March 2012.\n\nThe decision follows a countywide pertussis outbreak that has 82 confirmed, probable, suspected, or epidemiologically linked cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, since the middle of December 2011.\n\n'Epi-link' cases refer to pertussis cases in which the disease develops in a person who had been in close contact with someone who had a lab-confirmed case. 'Probable' defines a case of pertussis in which the patient has not been in close contact with a lab-confirmed case but has exhibited symptoms for 2 or more weeks, said Communicable Disease Program Coordinator Ayo White.\n\nTo date, said White, there have been 15 lab-confirmed, 31 epi-linked, 3 probable, and 3 suspect cases in Alamance County. 'These are the numbers up to this point,' and are expected to change quickly, she said. White acknowledged that 82 is a high number of pertussis cases and said, 'This is more than usual.'\n\nMedical Director Dr Kathleen Shapley-Quinn said, 'In the 10 years I've worked here, I've never had an outbreak (in Alamance County).'\n\nThe outbreak is a big one, hitting 5 elementary schools, 4 middle schools, 2 day cares, and 3 other individuals in the county.\n\nThe 12 schools with confirmed cases of pertussis are: Broadview Middle School, Turrentine Middle School, and Eastlawn Elementary School in Burlington; Western Alamance Middle School in Elon; B. Everett Jordan Elementary School, South Graham Elementary School, Alexander Wilson Elementary School, and Graham Middle School in Graham; Audrey W Garrett Elementary School, Hawfields Middle School, and Woodlawn Middle School in Mebane; and Haw River Elementary School in Haw River.\n\nThe health department has been administering azithromycin, an antimicrobial, to confirmed cases and Shapley-Quinn said the department has taken a targeted approach when giving the antibiotic to suspect cases. She said those at the highest risk take precedence, such as those children who have been in close proximity to confirmed cases and have poor immune systems.\n\nHealth officials are concentrating their efforts on immunizing as many people as possible, especially those at higher risk. Immunization Program Coordinator Christie Sykes said infants less than 12 months, immunocompromised individuals, and pregnant women are considered high risk.\n\n[Byline: Molly McGowan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1Q7S. Alamance County in north central North Carolina can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Missouri (Springfield, Greene county)\nDate: Tue 28 Feb 2012\nSource: News-Leader [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.news-leader.com/article/20120228/NEWS01/302280038\n\n\nThe Springfield-Greene County Health Department said Mon 27 Feb 2012, that it is seeing an increase in cases of whooping cough. In a news release, the health department said it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough in recent weeks. 3 of the cases were infants less than a year old; the other was an adult.\n\n'While the number of cases is not especially large, any such spike is notable because of the highly contagious nature of the disease,' the release said. 'The situation is compounded by an alarming lack of immunizations among infants in these recent cases.'\n\nInfants and young children are at the highest risk of life-threatening consequences. More than half of infants younger than one year of age who get the disease must be hospitalized. Of those infants who are hospitalized for pertussis, about one in 5 will get pneumonia and about one in 100 will die, according to the CDC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1UtN. Springfield in Greene County, south west Missouri, can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/missouri.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania (Chester county)\nDate: Mon 27 Feb 2012\nSource: CBS News [summ., edited]\nhttp://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2012/02/27/a-chesco-school-vaccinates-adults-after-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nThere has been a confirmed outbreak of whooping cough at a Chester County public school. Valley Forge Elementary School has had 2 confirmed cases of pertussis, and that is enough to constitute an 'outbreak,' according to Betsy Walls, bureau director for personal health services at the Chester County Health Department.\n\n'All of the kids were protected (vaccinated),' she tells KYW Newsradio, 'but that's because of their age and school requirements. It was the faculty that didn't have it -- in adults it's not a required vaccine. And so that what was we were doing there on Friday [4 Feb 2012]. We thought we would have some students, but we had all adults (needing to be vaccinated).' One of those diagnosed with the ailment is a student, the other is not.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Durham]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Pennsylvania can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1UtM. Chester County in south eastern Pennsylvania can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] Iowa (Scott county)\nDate: Mon 27 Feb 2012\nSource: The Associated Press (AP) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.news8000.com/news/Eastern-Iowa-officials-warn-of-whooping-cough/-/326/9137536/-/5hcfuu/-/\n\n\nThe Scott County Health Department in eastern Iowa is sending out an alert that there are more whooping cough cases in area schools. Davenport television station KWQC reports that 10 cases were reported last week [week of 20 Feb 2012] alone.\n\nIowa has seen a jump in whooping cough cases in recent years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Iowa can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1UtO. Scott County in eastern Iowa can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/iowa.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Washington (King county)\nDate: Fri 24 Feb 2012\nSource: Vashon-Maury Island Beachcomber [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.vashonbeachcomber.com/news/140016423.html\n\n\nTo date, 6 students on Vashon [Island] have confirmed cases of whooping cough, prompting King County health officials to issue a letter urging parents and teachers to be on alert for the highly contagious disease. The public health agency, in a letter to all parents and staff at Vashon's 3 public schools, says adults should pay attention to cold symptoms among children, noting they could be the 1st signs of pertussis, or whooping cough.\n\nThose adults who have contact with babies or young children, considered the most vulnerable to severe infection from the disease, should take extra precautions to ensure they don't get the illness, the letter adds. Babies, according to the letter, signed by Eileen Benoliel, a public health nurse in the Communicable Disease Epidemiology & Immunization Program at Public Health, Seattle & King County, can die from pertussis.\n\nThe letter was issued late Fri 25 Feb 2012, after officials learned there are 4 confirmed cases of pertussis at the Vashon School District and 2 confirmed cases of the disease in school-age children who attend a private school on Vashon. School officials believe there's a linkage to those cases, or 'evidence of contagion,' as Sarah Day, Vashon's school nurse, put it, which led to the county's letter.\n\nAccording to recently tabulated numbers, 33 percent of the students in the Vashon school district have not been fully vaccinated against whooping cough. What's more, according to health officials, the immunization is not highly effective or long-lasting. Health officials believe the pertussis vaccine is only 59 to 89 percent effective in preventing the disease.\n\nAccording to the state Department of Health, there were 728 cases of pertussis in Washington from 1 Jan to 17 Dec 2011. This compares with 529 cases in the same period in 2010. 86 infants under one had the illness and 29 were hospitalized, including 23 who were under 3 months. 2 infants died. In King County, there were 98 confirmed cases in 2011, according to James Apa, the communications manager for county health department.\n\nVashon School District currently has 75 students who don't have either a record of their immunizations or a signed waiver on file, Soltman said. Next week [week of 27 Feb 2012], he said, the district will issue letters to the parents or guardians of those students, telling them that they have 30 days to submit documentation of immunization or a waiver to the district. Those students whose families don't comply, he said, won't be allowed to attend public school.\n\n'In light of the concerns from the county health department,' Soltman said, 'we need to get Vashon's schools in compliance with the state's immunization laws.'\n\n[Byline: Leslie Brown]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1hcI. King County in west central Washington can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts of continue to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical 'whoop' after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n----------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full paper is available at http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1UtM, http://healthmap.org/r/1UtN, http://healthmap.org/r/1Q7S, http://healthmap.org/r/1UtO, http://healthmap.org/r/1hcI.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The letter was issued late Fri 25 Feb 2012, after officials learned there are 4 confirmed cases of pertussis at the Vashon School District and 2 confirmed cases of the disease in school-age children who attend a private school on Vashon.
