MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-02-04 00:00:00", "2012-02-20 00:00:00", "2012-02-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vashon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Springfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "King County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alamance county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greene county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alamance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scott County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chester county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greene County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chester County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scott county", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "453730", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, fatal - USA: (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=453730", "date": "2010-06-26 13:00:10", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, FATAL - USA: (CALIFORNIA)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Jun 2010\nSource: CBS2 [edited]\n<http://cbs2.com/local/Whooping.Cough.Epidemic.2.1768290.html>\n\n\nWhooping cough is now an epidemic in California, and is on pace to\nbreak a 50-year record for infections for the year. As of 15 Jun\n2010, California had 910 recorded cases of the highly contagious\ndisease, and 5 babies -- all under 3 months of age -- have died from\nthe disease this year.\n\n'Children should be vaccinated against the disease and parents,\nfamily members and caregivers of infants need a booster shot,'\nCalifornia Department of Public Health director Dr. Mark Horton said\nWednesday [23 Jun 2010].\n\nThis year's surge in cases of whooping cough, also known as\npertussis, is a 4-fold increase from the same period last year, when\n219 cases were recorded. At least 600 additional cases are under\ninvestigation by local health departments. Officials fear that with\nthe number of known and suspected cases at 1510, the state is on\ntrack to beat 1958's record 3847 cases; midway through that year,\n1200 cases had been reported.\n\nNationally, 23 weeks into 2010, there were 4656 cases of whooping\ncough, compared with 6017 cases in the same period in 2009, according\nto the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe declaration of epidemic is made after a significant increase in\nthe number of illnesses to a broad swath of the state's population,\nsaid state health department spokesman Ken August.\n\nHealth officials say whooping cough is cyclical and tends to peak\nevery 2 to 5 years. A typical case starts with a cough and runny nose\nfor one to 2 weeks, followed by weeks or months of rapid coughing\nfits that sometimes end with a whooping sound. Fever is rare.\n\nUnimmunized or incompletely immunized babies are particularly\nvulnerable. A total of 3 vaccines are administered for whooping\ncough, from 2 to 6 months of age. Neither vaccine nor surviving the\nillness provides lifetime immunity.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promed.isid.harvard.edu>\n\n[An older vaccine called DTP (an acronym for a triple vaccine used to\nimmunize against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis) has been\nreplaced by DTaP, a safer version in which the pertussis component is acellular\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/vis/downloads/vis-dtap.pdf>). DTP\nis no longer used in the United States. Children should get 5 doses\nof DTaP vaccine, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and\n15-18 months, and 4-6 years of age. DTaP is not licensed for\nadolescents, adults, or children 7 years of age and older. A single\ndose of another vaccine called Tdap, which is similar to DTaP, is\nrecommended for people 11 through 64 years of age in place of their\nnext Td booster (recommended to be given every 10 years). Td,\nprotects against tetanus and diphtheria, but not pertussis.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis -\nUSA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains.\nAs pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which\nshow that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in\nthe _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more\nvirulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly)\nresponsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have\nemerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in\ninfectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen\npopulation. This is even true for pertussis.\n\n'Reference\n----------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full\npaper is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm>.'\n\nThe state of California can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01vt>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promed.isid.harvard.edu>\n\n[An older vaccine called DTP (an acronym for a triple vaccine used to\nimmunize against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis) has been\nreplaced by DTaP, a safer version in which the pertussis component is acellular\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/vis/downloads/vis-dtap.pdf>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Jun 2010\n From the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis -\nUSA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which\nshow that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in\nthe _B. pertussis_ population. As of 15 Jun\n2010, California had 910 recorded cases of the highly contagious\ndisease, and 5 babies -- all under 3 months of age -- have died from\nthe disease this year. Officials fear that with\nthe number of known and suspected cases at 1510, the state is on\ntrack to beat 1958's record 3847 cases; midway through that year,\n1200 cases had been reported. ----------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. A single\ndose of another vaccine called Tdap, which is similar to DTaP, is\nrecommended for people 11 through 64 years of age in place of their\nnext Td booster (recommended to be given every 10 years). \n\nThis year's surge in cases of whooping cough, also known as\npertussis, is a 4-fold increase from the same period last year, when\n219 cases were recorded. Nationally, 23 weeks into 2010, there were 4656 cases of whooping\ncough, compared with 6017 cases in the same period in 2009, according\nto the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Children should get 5 doses\nof DTaP vaccine, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and\n15-18 months, and 4-6 years of age. A typical case starts with a cough and runny nose\nfor one to 2 weeks, followed by weeks or months of rapid coughing\nfits that sometimes end with a whooping sound. \n\n'Children should be vaccinated against the disease and parents,\nfamily members and caregivers of infants need a booster shot,'\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["4656-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1510-03-25 00:00:00", "1958-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-06-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "417410", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Congo DR: (KO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=417410", "date": "2010-04-28 15:00:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CONGO DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO: (KASAI ORIENTAL)\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 22 Apr 2010\nSource: Radio Okapi [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\n<http://radiookapi.net/actualite/2010/04/22/pres-de-80-cas-de-coqueluche-dans-le-sankuru/>\n\n\nThe health zones of Onema Ototo and Vangakete [in Sankuru] are\naffected by pertussis. In total, 74 cases have already been\nregistered. Among the victims, many are children of 1 to 3 years. The\nlack of vaccination or the use of expired vaccines are the cause of\nthe disease, according to the provincial Minister of Health.\n\nThe resurgence of these cases are causing concern at the highest\nlevel of the health authorities in the province of Kasai Oriental\nbecause whooping cough [pertussis] is a disease eradicated from the DRC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since it seems clear that the eradication of pertussis even from the\nindustrialized world is quite difficult, it is not likely that _B.\npertussis_ had been eradicated from DRC. - Mod.LL]\n\nA map showing the provinces of the Democratic Republic of Congo can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/01eu>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 22 Apr 2010\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since it seems clear that the eradication of pertussis even from the\nindustrialized world is quite difficult, it is not likely that _B.\npertussis_ had been eradicated from DRC. The resurgence of these cases are causing concern at the highest\nlevel of the health authorities in the province of Kasai Oriental\nbecause whooping cough [pertussis] is a disease eradicated from the DRC. The\nlack of vaccination or the use of expired vaccines are the cause of\nthe disease, according to the provincial Minister of Health. Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< LL]\n\nA map showing the provinces of the Democratic Republic of Congo can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Sankuru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "473074", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=473074", "date": "2010-07-22 14:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] California\n[2] Michigan\n[3] Georgia\n\n******\n[1] California\nDate: Thu 15 Jul 2010\nSource: Google News, Agencia EFE report [in Spanish trans. Corr.SB edited]\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/epa/article/ALeqM5g8vdn-gXwY03IVU3cM34NLFVB5bQ>\n\n\nAn epidemic of pertussis in California has had a particularly serious\neffect in Hispanic children, as the 5 children who have died from the\ndisease in 2010 were Latino babies, less than 3 months old.\n\nThe Department of Public Health in California (CDPH) has launched a\nSpanish-language ad campaign to warn the Latino community about the\nimportance of vaccinating infants at 2, 4, and 6 months of age, with\na booster between 15 and 18 months of age and another between 4 and 6\nyears.\n\n'Whooping cough is a highly contagious disease,' warned Dr Mark\nHorton, director of CDPH in a statement. 'Babies who are not\nvaccinated or who have not completed the series of recommended\nvaccines are particularly vulnerable. The disease in this age group\noften results in hospitalization and can be fatal.'\n\nFor the 1st half of 2010, state health authorities reported 1337\ncases of pertussis in the state, a rate 3.4 cases per 100 000\ninhabitants, representing an increase of 500 percent over the same\nperiod in 2009.\n\nCDPH statistics show that the highest incidence of pertussis in\ninfants under 6 months of age occurs among Hispanics at a rate of\n94.2 cases per 100 000, more than double that of African Americans.\n\n'Studies have shown that half of children with whooping cough are\ninfected by their parents, particularly their mothers,' states the\nCDPH instructive about its prevention. 'Therefore, vaccination of\nparents and caregivers against whooping cough before or just after\nthe birth of the child is the most important way to protect babies.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00aj>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Michigan\nDate: Tue 13 Jul 2010\nSource: Michigan Public Radio [edited]\n<http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/michigan/news.newsmain/article/1/0/1674931/Michigan.News/Whooping.Cough.On.The.Rise.In.Michigan>\n\n\nMore people are getting pertussis in Michigan and across the nation.\nThe disease, better known as whooping cough, because of the intense\ncough that children with the disease often exhibit.\n\nFatima Mamou is an epidemiologist with Genesee County Health\nDepartment. She says pertussis is most often transmitted by adults,\nwho get the illness, but pass it off as a bad cough. 'If they have\npertussis they can give it to an infant,' she says, 'And infants less\nthan age 1 are too young to be fully protected by the vaccine and\nthey can get pertussis and severe complications that can even result\nin death.'\n\nThere have been more than 600 cases of pertussis in Michigan so far\nin 2010. That is compared to only 278 in 2009.\n\n[Byline: Tracy Samilton]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Michigan can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01bN>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Georgia\nDate: Mon 19 Jul 2010\nSource: The Examiner, Associated Press (AP) report, information from\nWALB-TV [edited]\n<http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/breaking/whooping-cough-cases-confirmed-in-ga-98794624.html>\n\n\nSome Georgia health officials are warning parents to vaccinate\nchildren after cases of whooping cough have increased in Georgia.\n\nAuthorities tell WALB that 46 cases of the transmissible disease,\nalso called pertussis, have been confirmed in Georgia.\n\nHealth officials are looking into cases of other possible cases in\nTift, Turner, and Grady counties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Georgia can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00u5>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains.\nAs pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (see ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): 'There are now many studies\nwhich show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with\nchanges in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have\nshown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe\nto be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The\nP3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of\nsudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the\npathogen population. This is even true for pertussis. (1)'\n\nAs a reminder, the 5 dose primary series for\ndiphtheria/tetanus/acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine in children is\nrecommended (2) at ages 2, 4, 6, 15-18 months, and 4-6 years. A\nbooster of Tdap (lower dose of diphtheria and pertussis immunogens)\nis then recommended (2) between ages 11-12 or before age 18 if not\ngiven. Additionally, a single dose of Tdap is now recommended in\nadults (3) to be given to replace a dose of the every-10 year Td\nbooster for adults aged less than 65 years who have not previously\nreceived a dose of Tdap. This dose is particularly important in\nadults (pediatric health care workers, new parents, and grandparents)\nwho are likely to be in contact with young children of the age\nprecluding them from being adequately protected from pertussis. These\ninfants are the cohort group with the highest morbidity and mortality\nfrom pertussis.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Mooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. Full paper\navailable at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm>.\n2. CDC: Recommended Immunization Schedules for Persons Aged 0-18\nYears - United States, 2007. MMWR 2007; 55: Q1-Q4, available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5551a7.htm>.\n3. CDC: Recommended Adult Immunization Schedule - United States,\nOctober 2007-September 2008. MMWR 2007; 56: Q1-Q4, available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5641-Immunizationa1.htm>.\n- Mod. LL]\n\n[In response to the ongoing epidemic, California has expanded their\nrecommendations for acellular pertussis vaccines,\n<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/Pertussis.aspx>\nnow recommending the use of Tdap whenever tetanus toxoid is\nrecommended including in those over 65, and for all women of\nchildbearing age. DTap is recommended for those 6 months to 6 years\nof age. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "LL]\n\n[In response to the ongoing epidemic, California has expanded their\nrecommendations for acellular pertussis vaccines,\n<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/Pertussis.aspx>\nnow recommending the use of Tdap whenever tetanus toxoid is\nrecommended including in those over 65, and for all women of\nchildbearing age. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this posting:\n \n\nThe Department of Public Health in California (CDPH) has launched a\nSpanish-language ad campaign to warn the Latino community about the\nimportance of vaccinating infants at 2, 4, and 6 months of age, with\na booster between 15 and 18 months of age and another between 4 and 6\nyears. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (see ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): 'There are now many studies\nwhich show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with\nchanges in the _B. pertussis_ population. For the 1st half of 2010, state health authorities reported 1337\ncases of pertussis in the state, a rate 3.4 cases per 100 000\ninhabitants, representing an increase of 500 percent over the same\nperiod in 2009. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< References\n----------\n1. Full paper\navailable at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm>. \n\nAuthorities tell WALB that 46 cases of the transmissible disease,\nalso called pertussis, have been confirmed in Georgia. \n\nThere have been more than 600 cases of pertussis in Michigan so far\nin 2010. \n\nHealth officials are looking into cases of other possible cases in\nTift, Turner, and Grady counties.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2065-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1337-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "453763", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - New Zealand: (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=453763", "date": "2010-06-26 15:00:04", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND: (CANTERBURY)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Jun 2010\nSource: The Marlborough Express [edited]\n<http://www.stuff.co.nz/marlborough-express/news/3844090/Outbreak-of-whooping-cough-hits-Kaikoura>\n\n\nKaikoura has been hit by a whooping cough epidemic, with 15 cases\nconfirmed by the Kaikoura Medical Centre since the beginning of April\n[2010]. Centre practice manager Wendy Campbell said the outbreak was\nunder control with no new cases reported for 2 weeks.\n\nOne of the confirmed cases was a baby under one. Babies were\nespecially vulnerable to the disease, which could be deadly, Mrs\nCampbell said. 'It is more than likely there are more undiagnosed\ncases in the community,' she said.\n\nKaikoura Medical Centre doctor Andrea Judd said these kinds of\nepidemics were more likely when parents did not have their children\nimmunised. She was concerned whooping cough might become more\nprevalent. Dr Judd praised early childhood centres and schools for\nbeing aware of the epidemic and working to control the outbreak.\n\nNelson Marlborough District Health Board medical officer of health\nJill Sherwood said health practices were legally required to report\nsuspected cases of whooping cough, also called pertussis. One\nprobable case of whooping cough in Marlborough had been reported to\nthe public health service this year. 'We know that many people with\npertussis may not attend their GP,' Dr Sherwood said. However,\nnotified cases were a good guide as to whether whooping cough was on the rise.\n\nCanterbury medical officer of health Ramon Pink said babies should be\nvaccinated and kept away from anyone with whooping cough.\n\n[Byline: Ljana Sligo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kaikoura is a town on the east coast of the South Island of New\nZealand, with a population is 2172 in 2006\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaikoura>). It is the governmental\nseat of the territorial authority of the Kaikoura District, which is\na part of the Canterbury Region. The Canterbury, Nelson and\nMarlborough regions of New Zealand are located in the northeast of\nthe South Island (for a map of the regions of New Zealand see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_New_Zealand#Current_regions>).\n\nFor pertussis immunization, an older vaccine called DTP (an acronym\nfor a triple vaccine used to immunize against diphtheria, tetanus,\nand pertussis) has been replaced by DTaP, a safer version in which\nthe pertussis component is acellular\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/vis/downloads/vis-dtap.pdf>). DTP\nis no longer used in the United States. Children should get 5 doses\nof DTaP vaccine, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and\n15-18 months, and 4-6 years of age. DTaP is not licensed for\nadolescents, adults, or children 7 years of age and older. A single\ndose of another vaccine called Tdap, which is similar to DTaP, is\nrecommended for people 11 through 64 years of age in place of their\nnext Td booster (recommended to be given every 10 years). Td,\nprotects against tetanus and diphtheria, but not pertussis.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis -\nUSA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains.\nAs pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which\nshow that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in\nthe _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more\nvirulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly)\nresponsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have\nemerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in\ninfectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen\npopulation. This is even true for pertussis.\n\n'Reference:\n-----------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full\npaper is available at <http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm>.'\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00c3>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Jun 2010\n For pertussis immunization, an older vaccine called DTP (an acronym\nfor a triple vaccine used to immunize against diphtheria, tetanus,\nand pertussis) has been replaced by DTaP, a safer version in which\nthe pertussis component is acellular\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/vis/downloads/vis-dtap.pdf>). From the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis -\nUSA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n'Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which\nshow that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in\nthe _B. pertussis_ population. -----------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. A single\ndose of another vaccine called Tdap, which is similar to DTaP, is\nrecommended for people 11 through 64 years of age in place of their\nnext Td booster (recommended to be given every 10 years). Source: The Marlborough Express [edited]\n<http://www.stuff.co.nz/marlborough-express/news/3844090/Outbreak-of-whooping-cough-hits-Kaikoura>\n\n\nKaikoura has been hit by a whooping cough epidemic, with 15 cases\nconfirmed by the Kaikoura Medical Centre since the beginning of April\n The Canterbury, Nelson and\nMarlborough regions of New Zealand are located in the northeast of\nthe South Island (for a map of the regions of New Zealand see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_New_Zealand#Current_regions>). ' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kaikoura is a town on the east coast of the South Island of New\nZealand, with a population is 2172 in 2006\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaikoura>). Most recently, we have shown that more\nvirulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly)\nresponsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in\ninfectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen\npopulation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2172-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canterbury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marlborough", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kaikoura", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANTERBURY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "475118", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=475118", "date": "2010-07-25 18:00:04", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (03)\n******************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Idaho\n[2] Ohio\n[3] California\n[4] California (July 2010 immunization recommendations)\n\n******\n[1] Idaho\nDate: Thu 22 Jul 2010\nSource: Oregon Public Broadcasting [edited]\n<http://news.opb.org/article/9519-north-idaho-suffers-through-whooping-cough-outbreak/>\n\n\nWhooping cough is hitting Idaho hard. 77 cases of pertussis have been\nreported, about twice the average. Cynthia Taggart from the Panhandle\nHealth District says there's no particular reason for the outbreak.\nShe says the illness tends to go in cycles. She says the best way to\nprevent the disease is through immunization.\n\nChildren get a series of shots through infancy. But Taggart says kids\nbecome more vulnerable as they age.\n\nCynthia Taggart: 'Kids 11 and 12 need their booster. They need to be\nrevaccinated, even kids who have been vaccinated for pertussis. But\nit wears off over time. And, you know, a lot of parents aren't aware\nof that.' Health officials like Taggart also encourage adults who\nhave contact with children to get a special pertussis booster.\n\n[Byline: Doug Nadvornick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthmap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ohio\nDate: Sat 24 Jul 2010\nSource: Buckeye Lake Beacon [edited]\n<http://www.buckeyelakebeacon.net/news/2010-07-24/News/Fairfield_Medical_sees_increase_in_Pertussis_cases.html>\n\n\nOver the last several months, Fairfield Medical Center's Infection\nControl Department has observed an increase in the number of\npertussis cases (also known as whooping cough) in the community. As\nof July 2010, there have been 36 cases detected through the\nlaboratory at Fairfield Medical Center. Donna Hedges, Fairfield\nMedical Center Infection Control Practitioner, said, 'We have\nmaintained open communication with the Fairfield County Department of\nHealth, and they are actively monitoring and following up on all\nreported cases.'\n\n'Compared to 2009, this is a significant increase in numbers. In\n2009, the hospital detected 24 cases for the entire year, and, of\ncourse, we are concerned, since we are only half way through this\nyear. In fact, this is very troubling to us; during the summer, we\ndon't normally see these high numbers,' noted Dr. Andrew Murry,\nInfectious Disease Physician at Fairfield Medical Center.\n\nDue to this rise in the number of cases, for the upcoming 2010-2011\nschool year, Ohio law for immunizations needed to enter school has\nbeen changed. New this year [2010], a booster dose of the Tdap\nvaccine (providing protection against Tetanus, Diphtheria, and\nPertussis) is required for all students entering the 7th grade. The\nOhio Department of Health recently made this revision to the\nimmunization requirements for school attendance.\n\nDr. Murry commented: 'We strongly urge parents to plan ahead and meet\nthis requirement as soon as possible. There are many opportunities to\nreceive this vaccination for the overall safety and well being of\nchildren in our community.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] California\nDate: Fri 23 Jul 2010\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504763_162-20011458-10391704.html>\n\n\nThe state recorded about 1500 cases through 13 Jul 2010, a 5-fold\nincrease over the same period in 2009. Six infants have died in the\nrecent outbreak. Yesterday, 22 Jul 2010, officials in Calaveras\nCounty near Sacramento announced 3 new cases of the sometimes-deadly\nillness.\n\nWhooping cough (also known as pertussis) is a highly contagious\nbacterial infection that attacks the respiratory system. The\ninfection is preventable by vaccination, which is why Calaveras\nCounty Health Officer Dr. Dean Kelaita urged people, especially\nexpectant mothers and those with infants in their households, to get\nimmunized, according to the Record Net newspaper.\n\nStill, 5 of the 6 infants who died in California were under 3 months\nold, which is too young for immunization.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[4] California (July 2010 immunization recommendations)\nDate: July 2010\nSource: California Department of Public Health (CDPH) [edited]\n<http://eziz.org/PDF/CDPH%20Pertussis%20Immunization%20Policy%20July%202010.pdf>\n\n\nCDPH recommends that all patients indicated for immunization against\ntetanus, diphtheria or pertussis be immunized with:\n\n- DTaP if aged 6 weeks through 6 years; or\n- Tdap if aged 7 years and older.\n\nThe only reasons not to provide Tdap are documentation of a prior\ndose or a valid contraindication. Health care facilities and\nproviders should institute policies to achieve these recommendations.\n\nCDPH recommends that all patients without documentation of full\nimmunization against pertussis be fully immunized at the earliest\nopportunity, particularly:\n\n- Women of childbearing age: CDPH recommends that all women of\nchildbearing age be vaccinated with Tdap, preferably before\npregnancy, but otherwise during or after pregnancy, although\npregnancy is not a contraindication to vaccination (1,4). The\nAmerican Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that unvaccinated\npregnant adolescents be given the same consideration for Tdap\nvaccination as non-pregnant adolescents (1). The Advisory Committee\non Immunization Practices (ACIP) prefers Tdap vaccination in the\nimmediate postpartum period (4). AAP, ACIP, and the American College\nof Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommend that, when given\nduring pregnancy, it is preferable to administer Tdap during the 2nd\nor 3rd trimester to minimize the coincidental association of Tdap\nvaccination with adverse outcomes, which occur most often during the\n1st trimester (1,2,4,6).\n\n- Other close contacts of infants: CDPH recommends that birth\nhospitals and other immunizers provide Tdap to all close contacts of\ninfants without documentation of Tdap vaccination, especially parents\nand childcare providers. Contacts should be immunized before mother\nand baby are discharged after birth, regardless of when the contacts\nreceived any prior doses of Td.\n\n- Health care personnel: CDPH recommends that all health care\npersonnel, particularly those who have direct contact with infants\nand pregnant women, be immunized with Tdap to protect their patients\nand themselves. Effective 1 Sep 2010, the Cal/OSHA Aerosol\nTransmissible Disease Standard requires all hospitals, outpatient\nmedical facilities, and other employers covered by the standard to\noffer Tdap immunization to their employees who may be exposed to\npertussis. Employees who decline to be vaccinated must sign a\ndeclination form.\n\n- Patients with wounds: CDPH recommends that providers administer\nTdap (instead of Td or TT) whenever tetanus toxoid is indicated for\nwound management in patients 7 years of age and older.\n\nWhen the risk of contracting pertussis is elevated, as at present,\nACIP and AAP recommendations permit any interval between doses of Td\nand Tdap. In contrast to the grave potential risks of susceptible\npersons becoming infected and transmitting pertussis to vulnerable\ninfants, the most common adverse reaction to tetanus or diphtheria\nvaccines is a local reaction at the injection site, which may be more\nlikely after an increased number of prior doses (9); however, recent\nstudies and reports suggest that doses of Tdap given after previous\nTd or DTaP are well tolerated at intervals as brief as 1-18 months\n(3,7,8). An undocumented history of immunization with Tdap or Td is\nnot a valid reason to avoid or delay administration of Tdap.\n\nThe only contraindications to immunization with Tdap, both rare, are:\n- a documented history of anaphylaxis after receipt of Tdap, DTaP or\ntheir ingredients; or\n- encephalopathy occurring within 7 days after immunization against\npertussis that was not due to another identifiable cause (5,6).\n\nUse beyond licensed age groups is permitted by law:\n- 7-9 Years: CDPH recommends administration of Tdap to children 7\nthrough 9 years of age whenever vaccination against tetanus,\ndiphtheria, or pertussis is indicated. Existing data suggest that the\nuse of Tdap at these ages is safe (7, 10); in Canada, Tdap is\nlicensed for persons 4 years of age and older.\n\n- 65+ Years: CDPH recommends administration of Tdap to persons 65\nyears of age and older. Local and systemic events after Tdap\nvaccination have been reported less frequently in adults less than 65\nyears than in adolescents (5,11). Published data on the safety and\nvaccine efficacy of Tdap in persons 65 years and older are limited.\nEven if the immunogenicity of Tdap is found to decline with age, any\nadditional protection provided could help to limit transmission and\nprotect the vulnerable.\n\nUse of Tdap beyond licensed age groups may or may not be covered by\nprivate insurers.\n\nPertussis (whooping cough) is highly contagious and is spread by\ninhalation of respiratory droplets or aerosols. A high level of\ncommunity immunity is needed to reduce the incidence of pertussis,\nbut immunity from immunization or disease wanes over time. Most\nchildren vaccinated for pertussis before kindergarten are susceptible\nagain by early adolescence.\n\nTdap immunization rates in adolescents and adults are currently low.\nAs a result, pertussis continues to circulate widely, resulting in\nthe hospitalization and death of young infants who are too young for\nroutine immunization with DTaP. As of 15 Jul 2010, there have been 5\nreported 2010 infant deaths due to pertussis in California. Close\ncontacts, most often mothers, are the most common known source of\npertussis in infants (12). Thus, vaccinating household contacts,\nhealth care personnel, and child care workers against pertussis is\nrecommended at least 2 weeks before their contact with young infants\n(5,6). Increasing community immunity through widespread immunization\nwill also decrease the chances that vulnerable infants will be\nexposed to pertussis. Immunization will also prevent debilitating\ncases of pertussis in older children, adolescents, and adults.\n\n1. American Academy of Pediatrics. Pertussis. In: Pickering LK, Baker\nCJ, Kimberlin DW, Long SS, eds. Red Book: 2009 Report of the\nCommittee on Infectious Diseases. 28th ed. Elk Grove, IL: American\nAcademy of Pediatrics; 2009:514.\n<http://aapredbook.aappublications.org/>.\n\n2. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. ACOG\nCommittee Opinion No. 438. Update on immunization and pregnancy:\ntetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccination. Obstet Gynecol\n2006;114: 398-400.\n\n3. Beytout J, et al: Safety of Tdap-IPV given one month after Td-IPV\nbooster in health young adults: a placebo-controlled trial. Hum\nVaccines 2009;5: 315-321.\n\n4. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Prevention of\nPertussis, Tetanus, and Diphtheria Among Pregnant and Postpartum\nWomen and Their Infants. MMWR 2008; 57 (No.RR-4): 1-52.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5704.pdf>.\n\n5. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Preventing Tetanus,\nDiphtheria, and Pertussis Among Adults. MMWR 2006; 55 (No.RR-17):\n1-33. <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5517.pdf>.\n\n6. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Preventing Tetanus,\nDiphtheria, and Pertussis Among Adolescents. MMWR 2006; 55 (No.RR-3):\n1-43. <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5503.pdf>.\n\n7. Halperin SA et al: How soon after a prior tetanus-diphtheria\nvaccination can one give adult formulation\ntetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccine? Pediatr Infect Dis J\n2006;25: 195-200.\n\n8. Iskander J: Immunization Safety Office Surveillance Updates, ACIP\nMeeting, February 2007.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/recs/acip/downloads/min-archive/min-feb07.pdf>.\n\n9. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, Offit PA. Vaccines. 5th ed.\nPhiladelphia, PA: Saunders, 2008:149, 823.\n\n10. Scheifele DW, et al. A modified vaccine reduces the rate of large\ninjection site reaction to the preschool booster dose of\ndiphtheriatetanus- acellular pertussis vaccine. Pediatr Infect Dis J\n2005;24: 1059-1066.\n\n11. Vaccines and Related Biological Products Safety (VRBPS)\nCommittee, FDA Clinical Briefing Document of Tetanus Toxoid, Reduced\nDiphtheria Toxoid, and Acellular Pertussis Vaccine, Adsorbed (Tdap,\nADACEL?) Aventis Pasteur, Limited. 15 Mar 2005.\n<http://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/05/briefing/2005-4097B1_4a.pdf>.\n\n12. Wendelboe AM et al: Transmission of Bordetella pertussis to young\ninfants. Pediatr Infect Dis J 2007;26: 293-299.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The enhanced recommendation of the use of Tdap is overdue for its\nuse in limiting the outbreaks of pertussis around the country. One\nmight also suggest that, for both health care workers and day care\nworkers involved in the care of not yet fully immunized infants,\nimmunization should be mandatory. Given the New York State experience\nwith health care workers, especially nurses, refusing mandatory\nepidemic H1N1 vaccination, this may be difficult to enforce. Supreme\nCourt precedence, however, going back to 1905 (Jacobson v. State of\nMassachusetts\n<http://biotech.law.lsu.edu/cases/vaccines/Jacobson_v_Massachusetts.htm>)\ngives states the power to require vaccinations. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "In contrast to the grave potential risks of susceptible\npersons becoming infected and transmitting pertussis to vulnerable\ninfants, the most common adverse reaction to tetanus or diphtheria\nvaccines is a local reaction at the injection site, which may be more\nlikely after an increased number of prior doses (9); however, recent\nstudies and reports suggest that doses of Tdap given after previous\n \n\nCDPH recommends that all patients without documentation of full\nimmunization against pertussis be fully immunized at the earliest\nopportunity, particularly:\n\n- Women of childbearing age: CDPH recommends that all women of\nchildbearing age be vaccinated with Tdap, preferably before\npregnancy, but otherwise during or after pregnancy, although\npregnancy is not a contraindication to vaccination (1,4). PERTUSSIS - USA (03)\n******************\n The\nAmerican Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that unvaccinated\npregnant adolescents be given the same consideration for Tdap Cynthia Taggart from the Panhandle\nHealth District says there's no particular reason for the outbreak.\n [1] Idaho\n[2] Ohio\n In fact, this is very troubling to us; during the summer, we\ndon't normally see these high numbers,' noted Dr. Andrew Murry,\nInfectious Disease Physician at Fairfield Medical Center. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Elk Grove, IL: American\nAcademy of Pediatrics; 2009:514.\n \n\n- 65+ Years: CDPH recommends administration of Tdap to persons 65\nyears of age and older. \n\nStill, 5 of the 6 infants who died in California were under 3 months\nold, which is too young for immunization.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-09-01 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2057-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-02-25 00:00:00", "2043-01-25 00:00:00", "2033-01-25 00:00:00", "2055-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1905-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2052-01-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halperin SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "427505", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA: (MN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=427505", "date": "2010-05-14 12:00:04", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 May 2010\nSource: KSTP-TV [edited]\n<http://kstp.com/news/stories/S1554995.shtml?cat=1>\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough in Wright County has schools and public\nhealth officials taking measures to contain the disease. Health\nofficials have confirmed 46 cases of the contagious disease in the\nMaple Lake area. Most of the cases were diagnosed in students from\nMaple Lake Elementary and St Timothy's Catholic School.\n\nOfficials said they are working to identify students with whooping\ncough, or pertussis, and get them out of the classroom. School\nofficials have sent letters home to parents of children who are in\nclass with students who have been diagnosed.\n\nPertussis cases tend to come in waves. The last wave in Minnesota\npeaked in 2005 with more than 1500 confirmed cases. In 2009,\nMinnesota reported more than 1000 cases.\n\nThere is a vaccine, but it loses its effectiveness over time. Health\nofficials believe that is why they're seeing more cases among 5th and\n6th graders who received the vaccine before they entered kindergarten.\n\nHealth officials say people with pertussis should stay home until\nthey have completed 5 days of antimicrobial treatment.\n\n[Byline: Tim Sherno, Becky Nahm]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains.\nAs pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): 'There are now many studies\nwhich show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with\nchanges in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have\nshown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe\nto be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The\nP3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of\nsudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the\npathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13.'\nThe full paper is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm>. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01hD>.\nWright County can be located on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_County,_Minnesota>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 May 2010\n As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis -\nAustralia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): 'There are now many studies\nwhich show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with\nchanges in the _B. pertussis_ population. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and\nadults are generally attributed to waning immunity without\nconsidering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. Mooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al: _Bordetella pertussis_\nstrains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis\nresurgence. Health\nofficials believe that is why they're seeing more cases among 5th and\n6th graders who received the vaccine before they entered kindergarten. LL]\n\n[The state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01hD>. Health\nofficials have confirmed 46 cases of the contagious disease in the\nMaple Lake area. School\nofficials have sent letters home to parents of children who are in\nclass with students who have been diagnosed. Most recently, we have\nshown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe\nto be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. Any discussion on the causes of\nsudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the\npathogen population. Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\nHealth officials say people with pertussis should stay home until\nthey have completed 5 days of antimicrobial treatment.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wright County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "508182", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=508182", "date": "2010-08-27 16:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington state\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Michigan\n[4] California\n[5] Missouri\n\n*****\n[1] Washington state\nDate: Thu 26 Aug 2010\nSource: The Wenatchee World [edited]\n<http://www.wenatcheeworld.com/news/2010/aug/26/grant-county-baby-dies-from-whooping-cough/>\n\n\nA Grant County baby has died from whooping cough [pertussis] and\nanother is recovering from the highly contagious bacterial disease,\nGrant County health officials say.\n\nThe infant died Tuesday night, 24 Aug 2010, at Children's Hospital\nand Medical Center in Seattle, Washington, according to Theresa\nFuller, public information officer for the Grant County Health\nDistrict. The other child is recovering at home. There appears to be\nno connection between the cases, she said.\n\nHealth officials are working with health-care providers of children\nand adults who may have been exposed to the sick children, Fuller\nsaid. In some cases, those people may need antibiotics.\n\nAccording to the CDC, 8000 to 25 000 cases of pertussis, are reported\neach year in the USA.\n\nDuring the last decade, pertussis has re-emerged as one of the most\npressing public health issues due to increasing numbers of cases and\nlower vaccination rates, Fuller said.\n\nRecently, multiple outbreaks of pertussis have been investigated in\nthe USA, including cases in California and Idaho, said Jeff Ketchel,\nhealth district administrator. From 2005 to 2009, Washington state\nhad 2636 cases of whooping cough. During this same time period, Grant\nCounty had 17 cases.\n\nAbout 1 in 20 infants with pertussis get pneumonia, said Dr Alexander\nBrzezny, Grant County health officer. About 1 in 100 infants will\nhave convulsions. In rare cases, pertussis can be deadly, especially\nin infants under 1 year old. Nearly all infants with pertussis get\nthe infection from an infected adult.\n\n[Byline: Dee Riggs]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County can be seen on the map of Washington state at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania\nDate: Wed 25 Aug 2010\nSource: VaccineNewsDaily.com, Philly.com report [edited]\n<http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/214853-philadelphia-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise>\n\n\nA rise in reported cases of pertussis in causing concern in the\ngreater Philadelphia area, health officials say. The suburban\ncounties of southeastern Pennsylvania have witnessed increased\noccurrences of the infection, which can be fatal in infants,\nPhilly.com reports. Delaware County saw the largest increase in\ncases, jumping from 5 cases to 44 within a 3 month period.\n\nThe 2nd highest increase in whooping cough cases was in Montgomery\nCounty, Philly.com reports, where 39 new cases were tallied between\nApril and June 2010, compared to 8 new cases in the 3 months preceding.\n\n[Byline: Malik Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Pennsylvania at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Michigan\nDate: Tue 24 Aug 2010\nSource: Gaylord Herald Times [edited]\n<http://www.gaylordheraldtimes.com/articles/2010/08/24/news/local_news/doc4c740c3a8f597802151863.txt>\n\n\nAccording to a report from Dr Joshua Meyerson, the medical director\nof the Health Department of Northwest Michigan, 25 cases of pertussis\nhave been discovered in the 4 counties, Antrim, Charlevoix, Emmet,\nand Otsego, served by Northwest. The outbreak is 5 times the typical\nnumber. There have been cases so far in Otsego County in 2010, a\nchild and an adult.\n\nMeyerson states that 10-15 percent of children have not been\nvaccinated. 'In some ways these vaccinations are victims of the\ninitial success of the vaccine,' said Jane Sundmacher, public\ninformation officer of Northwest. 'Before the vaccine was introduced\nin the 1940s, pertussis was the major cause of serious illness and\ndeath in infants and young children.'\n\nThe alarm being sounded about the outbreak is particularly important\nin Michigan. California and Michigan lead the country in the\npercentage of children not vaccinated. California has suffered 10\ndeaths and Michigan one.\n\n'Be really careful about who's around an infant,' Sundmacher said. 'A\nreally common report we hear is that an adult has a cough, but\ndoesn't feel that sick, and ends up passing pertussis on to a baby or\nyoung child. Even if an infant has started the series of shots\nusually given at 2, 4, and 6 months, if they haven't completed the\nseries, their parents and anyone else who cares for them should get\nimmunized. Booster shots are available for ages 7 to 64.'\n\nWendy Phillips, public information officer of Northeast Health\nDepartment, reports there have been no identified cases of pertussis\nin 2010 in Montmorency County. There are, however, 2 cases in both\nAlpena and Cheboygan, and the 2 in Otsego suggests it's only a matter\nof time before it spreads to Montmorency.\n\n[Byline: Lorene Parshall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Michigan at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 16 Aug 2010\nSource: The Bakersfield Californian, Kern County Department of Public\nHealth Services (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1415296021/Number-of-whooping-cough-cases-up-to-227>\n\n\nAn additional 17 cases of whooping cough were reported last week\n[week of 9 Aug 2010] in Kern County, bringing the total to 227 for\n2010, according to the Kern County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe monthly rate of cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis,\nin Kern County has been going up and up in 2010, though no deaths\nhave been reported. The weekly rate has, since 23 May 2010, ranged\nfrom 5 between 30 May and 5 Jun 2010 to 33 between 27 Jun and 3 Jul\n2010, according to Public Health. Of the 227 Kern cases, 182 were\nreported in Bakersfield.\n\nThe reason for the uptick is unclear but it's happening across the\nstate so health officials are just trying to get the word out about\nthe need for vaccination, said Denise Smith, Public Health's\nassistant director of disease control.\n\nOfficials have said the incidence of whooping cough is cyclical. In\nKern there were 6 reported cases in all of 2009 and 8 in 2008,\naccording to Public Health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kern County can be seen on the map of California at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Missouri\nDate: Sun 22 Aug 2010\nSource: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/article_fd578e9f-0af5-55f9-85b1-4ee13e39a699.html>\n\n\nMissouri has reported 82 confirmed cases of pertussis in the last\nmonth. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster. Source: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/article_fd578e9f-0af5-55f9-85b1-4ee13e39a699.html>\n\n\nMissouri has reported 82 confirmed cases of pertussis in the last\nmonth.
