' Source: The Bakersfield Californian, Kern County Department of Public\nHealth Services (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1415296021/Number-of-whooping-cough-cases-up-to-227>\n\n\n PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\n[Byline: Malik Wilson]\n\n--\n Delaware County saw the largest increase in\ncases, jumping from 5 cases to 44 within a 3 month period. A rise in reported cases of pertussis in causing concern in the\ngreater Philadelphia area, health officials say. According to the CDC, 8000 to 25 000 cases of pertussis, are reported\neach year in the USA.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-05-23 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1976-03-25 00:00:00", "1010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:30", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2636-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Theresa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brzezny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montmorency County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otsego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "327513", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis - Australia (02): (SA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=327513", "date": "2009-11-08 18:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 7 Nov 2009\nFrom: Frits Mooi <Frits.Mooi@rivm.nl>\n\n\nIn response to the outbreak of pertussis in Australia (Pertussis -\nAustralia: (SA) 20091107.3842), the moderator discusses the duration of\nvaccine-induced immunity. Whenever outbreaks of pertussis occur, this\nsubject is rightfully brought up, but whether limited public resources\nshould be used for more and more boosters is another matter. Perhaps we\nneed better vaccines.\n\nSurprisingly, the pathogen is generally left out of the picture. There are\nnow many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often\nassociated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we\nhave shown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe\nto be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3\nstrains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden\nupsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen\npopulation. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference:\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. Bordetella pertussis strains with\nincreased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg\nInfect Dis 2009; 15: 1206-13.\n\n--\nProf Dr Frits R Mooi\nNetherlands Centre for Infectious Diseases Control\nNatl Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM)\nBilthoven, Netherlands\n<frits.mooi@rivm.nl>\n\n[Indeed, it is important to keep the pathogen per se in perspective as\nProfessor Mooi suggests. This moderator thanks Professor Mooi for pointing\nout this recent publication from his group in the Netherlands. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 7 Nov 2009\n Infect Dis 2009; 15: 1206-13.\n\n--\nProf Dr Frits R Mooi\nNetherlands Centre for Infectious Diseases Control\nNatl Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM)\n In response to the outbreak of pertussis in Australia (Pertussis -\nAustralia: (SA) 20091107.3842), the moderator discusses the duration of\nvaccine-induced immunity. There are\nnow many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often\nassociated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Whenever outbreaks of pertussis occur, this\nsubject is rightfully brought up, but whether limited public resources\nshould be used for more and more boosters is another matter. Any discussion on the causes of sudden\nupsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen\npopulation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "928148", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=928148", "date": "2011-10-29 20:52:17", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA\n***************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Illinois\n[2] Kansas\n[3] New York\n[4] Newest CDC recommendation\n\n*****\n[1] Illinois\nDate: Fri 28 Oct 2011\nSource: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-10-28/news/chi-mchenry-county-whooping-cough-cases-hit-29-more-unconfirmed-20111028_1_whooping-cough-cases-highly-contagious-bacterial-infection-students\n\n\nWhooping cough cases in McHenry County, Illinois, are showing no signs\nof slowing down after 31 students at 6 different schools have now been\ndiagnosed with the contagious bacterial infection.\n\n28 of those afflicted with the illness, also known as pertussis, come\nfrom northwest suburban Cary. The majority of confirmed cases, 24, are\nat Cary-Grove High School.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Illinois is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1nEq - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n*****\n[2] Kansas\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2011\nSource: Kansas City Star [edited]\nhttp://www.kansascity.com/2011/10/27/3233258/lawrence-reports-6-cases-of-whooping.html\n\n\nHealth officials here are dealing with an outbreak of whooping cough.\nDouglas County, Kansas, officials have recorded a half-dozen cases of\nthe illness in Lawrence during the past month. 4 of the cases involved\nchildren who had not been vaccinated for whooping cough, also known as\npertussis.\n\nThe bacterial illness is contagious and spreads by coughing or\nsneezing in close contact with others. A pertussis outbreak in March\n[2011] affected 7 Lawrence children, most of them unvaccinated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Kansas is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1nEr - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n*****\n[3] New York\nDate: Tue 25 Oct 2011\nSource: My Fox News [edited]\nhttp://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/news/whooping-cough-cases-triple-in-suffolk-county-20111025-lgf\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough (pertussis) cases in Long Island's\nSuffolk County has tripled in 2011. There have been 179 reported cases\nin 2011 as compared to 2010's 54.\n\nThe disease is contagious. It is known for uncontrollable, violent\ncoughing which often makes it hard to breathe. After fits of many\ncoughs, someone with pertussis often needs to take deep breathes which\nresult in a 'whooping' sound.\n\nPertussis most commonly affects infants and young children and can be\nfatal. The Suffolk County Health Department says that since 2011 is\nnot over, the number of whooping cough cases is expected to rise\nfurther.\n\n[Byline: Luke Funk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Long Island, New York, is\navailable at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1nEt - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n*****\n[4] Newest CDC recommendations\nDate: Fri 21 Oct 2011\nSource: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2011;60: 1424-1426 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6041a4.htm?s_cid=mm6041a4_w\n\n\nCompared with older children and adults, infants aged less than 12\nmonths have substantially higher rates of pertussis and the largest\nburden of pertussis-related deaths. Since 2004, a mean of 3055 infant\npertussis cases with more than 19 deaths has been reported each year\nthrough the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (CDC,\nunpublished data, 2011). The majority of pertussis cases,\nhospitalizations, and deaths occur in infants aged 2 months or\nyounger, who are too young to be vaccinated; therefore, other\nstrategies are required for prevention of pertussis in this age\ngroup.\n\nSince 2005, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)\nhas recommended tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid and\nacellular pertussis (Tdap) booster vaccines to unvaccinated postpartum\nmothers and other family members of newborn infants to protect infants\nfrom pertussis, a strategy referred to as cocooning (1). Over the past\n5 years, cocooning programs have proven difficult to implement widely\n(2,3). Cocooning programs might achieve moderate vaccination coverage\namong postpartum mothers but have had limited success in vaccinating\nfathers or other family members. On 22 Jun 2011, ACIP made\nrecommendations for use of Tdap in unvaccinated pregnant women and\nupdated recommendations on cocooning and special situations. This\nreport summarizes data considered and conclusions made by ACIP and\nprovides guidance for implementing its recommendations.\n\nACIP recommends a single Tdap dose for persons aged 11 through 18\nyears who have completed the recommended childhood diphtheria and\ntetanus toxoids and pertussis/diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and\nacellular pertussis (DTP/DTaP) vaccination series and for adults aged\n19 through 64 years who have not previously received Tdap (1,4). ACIP\nalso recommends that adults aged 65 years and older receive a single\ndose of Tdap if they have or anticipate having close contact with an\ninfant aged <12 months and previously have not received Tdap (5). 2\nTdap vaccines are available in the United States. Adacel (Sanofi\nPasteur) is licensed for use in persons aged 11 through 64 years.\nBoostrix (GlaxoSmithKline Biologicals) is licensed for use in persons\naged 10 years or older (6).\n\nThe ACIP Pertussis Vaccines Work Group reviewed unpublished Tdap\nsafety data from pregnancy registries and the Vaccine Adverse Event\nReporting System (VAERS) and published studies on use of Tdap in\npregnant women. The Work Group also considered the epidemiology of\npertussis in infants and provider and program feedback, and then\npresented policy options for consideration to ACIP. These updated\nrecommendations on use of Tdap in pregnant women are consistent with\nthe goal of reducing the burden of pertussis in infants.\n\nSafety of Tdap in Pregnant Women\n--------------------------------\nIn prelicensure evaluations, the safety of administering a booster\ndose of Tdap to pregnant women was not studied. Because information on\nuse of Tdap in pregnant women was lacking, both manufacturers of Tdap\nestablished pregnancy registries to collect information and pregnancy\noutcomes from pregnant women vaccinated with Tdap. Data on the safety\nof administering Tdap to pregnant women are now available. ACIP\nreviewed published and unpublished data from VAERS, Sanofi Pasteur\n(Adacel) and GlaxoSmithKline (Boostrix) pregnancy registries, and\nsmall studies (7,8). ACIP concluded that available data from these\nstudies did not suggest any elevated frequency or unusual patterns of\nadverse events in pregnant women who received Tdap and that the few\nserious adverse events reported were unlikely to have been caused by\nthe vaccine. Both tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) and tetanus\ntoxoid vaccines have been used extensively in pregnant women worldwide\nto prevent neonatal tetanus. Tetanus- and diphtheria-toxoid containing\nvaccines administered during pregnancy have not been shown to be\nteratogenic (9,10). From a safety perspective, ACIP concluded that\nadministration of Tdap after 20 weeks' gestation is preferred to\nminimize the risk for any low-frequency adverse event and the\npossibility that any spurious association might appear causative.\n\nTransplacental Maternal Antibodies\n----------------------------------\nFor infants, transplacentally transferred maternal antibodies might\nprovide protection against pertussis in early life and before\nbeginning the primary DTaP series. Several studies provide evidence\nsupporting the existence of efficient transplacental transfer of\npertussis antibodies (7,11,12). Cord blood from newborn infants whose\nmothers received Tdap during pregnancy or before pregnancy had higher\nconcentrations of pertussis antibodies when compared with cord blood\nfrom newborn infants of unvaccinated mothers (7,11). The half-life of\ntransferred maternal pertussis antibodies is approximately 6 weeks\n(12). The effectiveness of maternal antipertussis antibodies in\npreventing infant pertussis is not yet known, but pertussis-specific\nantibodies likely confer protection and modify the severity of\npertussis illness (13,14). In addition, a woman vaccinated with Tdap\nduring pregnancy likely will be protected at time of delivery, and\ntherefore less likely to transmit pertussis to her infant. After\nreceipt of Tdap, boosted pertussis-specific antibody levels peak after\nseveral weeks, followed by a decline over several months (15,16). To\noptimize the concentration of maternal antibodies transferred to the\nfetus, ACIP concluded that unvaccinated pregnant women should receive\nTdap, preferably in the 3rd or late 2nd (after 20 weeks gestation)\ntrimester.\n\nInterference with Infant Immune Response to Primary DTaP Vaccination\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nSeveral studies have suggested that maternal pertussis antibodies can\ninhibit active pertussis-specific antibody production after\nadministration of DTaP vaccine to infants of mothers vaccinated with\nTdap during pregnancy, referred to as blunting (12,17). Because\ncorrelates of protection are not fully understood, the clinical\nimportance of blunting of an infant's immune response is not clear.\nEvidence suggests that any blunting would be short-lived because\ncirculating maternal antibodies decline rapidly (12,18). Circulating\nmaternal pertussis antibodies might reduce an infant's risk for\npertussis in the 1st few months of life but slightly increase risk for\ndisease because of a blunted immune response after receipt of primary\nDTaP doses. The benefit would be to reduce the risk for disease and\ndeath in infants aged less than 3 months, but the trade-off might be\nto increase the occurrence of pertussis in older infants; however,\nthis group experiences a substantially lower burden of\nhospitalizations and mortality (National Notifiable Diseases\nSurveillance System, CDC, unpublished data, 2011).\n\nCurrently, 2 clinical trials are being conducted to measure the immune\nresponse of infants receiving DTaP immunization at ages 2, 4, and 6\nmonths whose mothers received Tdap during the 3rd trimester of\npregnancy (19,20). These trials also are designed to evaluate safety\nand immunogenicity of Tdap during pregnancy, but are not sufficiently\npowered to assess disease endpoints. Analysis of interim data from one\ntrial (19, unpublished data) measured infant antibody to pertussis\nantigens in a blinded fashion for 2 groups: infants whose mothers\nreceived Tdap and infants whose mothers received Td. The 1st group had\nelevated antipertussis antibody levels compared with the 2nd at birth\nand before dose 1, which might be the result of passive antibody\ntransfer, but had lower antipertussis antibody levels after dose 3. In\nboth groups, antipertussis antibody levels were comparable before\ndoses 2 and 3. Although the 1st group had lower antipertussis antibody\nlevels after dose 3, the evidence of sufficient immune response to\nDTaP doses compared with the 2nd group was reassuring. ACIP concluded\nthat the interim data are consistent with previously published\nliterature suggesting a short duration of blunting of the infant\nresponse, and that the potential benefit of protection from maternal\nantibodies in newborn infants outweighs the potential risk for\nshifting disease burden to later in infancy.\n\nCocooning\n---------\nCocooning is defined as the strategy of vaccinating pregnant women\nimmediately postpartum and all other close contacts of infants aged\nless than 12 months with Tdap to reduce the risk for transmission of\npertussis to infants. Cocooning has been recommended by ACIP since\n2005. Cocooning programs have achieved moderate postpartum coverage\namong mothers but have had limited success in vaccinating fathers or\nother family members (3) (CDC, unpublished data, 2011). Programmatic\nchallenges make implementation of cocooning programs complex and also\nimpede program expansion and sustainability (2). The effectiveness of\nvaccinating postpartum mothers and close contacts to protect infants\nfrom pertussis is not yet known, but the delay in antibody response\namong those vaccinated with Tdap after an infant's birth might result\nin insufficient protection to infants during the 1st weeks of life\n(21). ACIP concluded that cocooning alone is an insufficient strategy\nto prevent pertussis morbidity and mortality in newborn infants.\nRegardless, ACIP concluded that cocooning likely provides indirect\nprotection to infants and firmly supports vaccination with Tdap for\nunvaccinated persons who anticipate close contact with an infant.\n\nDecision and Cost Effectiveness Analysis\n----------------------------------------\nA decision analysis and cost effectiveness model was developed to\nassess the impact and cost effectiveness of maternal Tdap vaccination\nduring pregnancy compared with immediately postpartum. The model\nshowed that Tdap vaccination during pregnancy would prevent more\ninfant cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared with the\npostpartum dose for 2 reasons: 1) vaccination during pregnancy\nbenefits the mother and infant by providing earlier protection to the\nmother, thereby protecting the infant at birth; and 2) vaccination\nduring late pregnancy maximizes transfer of maternal antibodies to the\ninfant, likely providing direct protection to the infant for a period\nafter birth. Model results were most sensitive to efficacy of maternal\nantibodies and risk for disease as a result of blunting; however, a\nsensitivity analysis in which infants were assumed to have as little\nas 20 percent efficacy of maternal antibodies and a 60 percent\nincrease in risk for disease as a result of blunting found that\nmaternal vaccination during pregnancy was more cost effective and\nprevented a greater proportion of infant cases and deaths than\npostpartum maternal vaccination (22).\n\nGuidance for Use\n----------------\nMaternal vaccination. ACIP recommends that women's health-care\npersonnel implement a Tdap vaccination program for pregnant women who\npreviously have not received Tdap. Health-care personnel should\nadminister Tdap during pregnancy, preferably during the 3rd or late\n2nd trimester (after 20 weeks' gestation). If not administered during\npregnancy, Tdap should be administered immediately postpartum.\n\nCocooning. ACIP recommends that adolescents and adults (e.g., parents,\nsiblings, grandparents, child-care providers, and health-care\npersonnel) who have or anticipate having close contact with an infant\naged less than 12 months should receive a single dose of Tdap to\nprotect against pertussis if they have not previously received Tdap.\nIdeally, these adolescents and adults should receive Tdap at least 2\nweeks before beginning close contact with the infant.\n\nSpecial Situations\n------------------\nPregnant women due for tetanus booster. If a tetanus and diphtheria\nbooster vaccination is indicated during pregnancy for a woman who has\npreviously not received Tdap (i.e., more than 10 years since previous\nTd), then Tdap should be administered during pregnancy, preferably\nduring the 3rd or late 2nd trimester (after 20 weeks' gestation).\n\nWound management for pregnant women. As part of standard wound\nmanagement care to prevent tetanus, a tetanus toxoid-containing\nvaccine might be recommended for wound management in a pregnant woman\nif 5 years or more have elapsed since last receiving Td. If a tetanus\nbooster is indicated for a pregnant woman who previously has not\nreceived Tdap, Tdap should be administered.\n\nPregnant women with unknown or incomplete tetanus vaccination. To\nensure protection against maternal and neonatal tetanus, pregnant\nwomen who have never been vaccinated against tetanus should receive 3\nvaccinations containing tetanus and reduced diphtheria toxoids. The\nrecommended schedule is 0, 4 weeks, and 6 to 12 months. Tdap should\nreplace 1 dose of Td, preferably during the 3rd or late 2nd trimester\n(after 20 weeks' gestation) of pregnancy.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. PERTUSSIS - USA\n***************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nACIP recommends a single Tdap dose for persons aged 11 through 18\nyears who have completed the recommended childhood diphtheria and\ntetanus toxoids and pertussis/diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and\nacellular pertussis (DTP/DTaP) vaccination series and for adults aged\n19 through 64 years who have not previously received Tdap (1,4). Since 2005, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)\nhas recommended tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid and\nacellular pertussis (Tdap) booster vaccines to unvaccinated postpartum\nmothers and other family members of newborn infants to protect infants\nfrom pertussis, a strategy referred to as cocooning (1). Circulating\nmaternal pertussis antibodies might reduce an infant's risk for\npertussis in the 1st few months of life but slightly increase risk for\ndisease because of a blunted immune response after receipt of primary\nDTaP doses. The majority of pertussis cases,\nhospitalizations, and deaths occur in infants aged 2 months or\nyounger, who are too young to be vaccinated; therefore, other\nstrategies are required for prevention of pertussis in this age\ngroup. If a tetanus and diphtheria\nbooster vaccination is indicated during pregnancy for a woman who has\npreviously not received Tdap (i.e., more than 10 years since previous\nTd), then Tdap should be administered during pregnancy, preferably\nduring the 3rd or late 2nd trimester (after 20 weeks' gestation). ACIP concluded that available data from these\nstudies did not suggest any elevated frequency or unusual patterns of\nadverse events in pregnant women who received Tdap and that the few\nserious adverse events reported were unlikely to have been caused by\nthe vaccine. Source: Kansas City Star [edited]\nhttp://www.kansascity.com/2011/10/27/3233258/lawrence-reports-6-cases-of-whooping.html\n\n\nHealth officials here are dealing with an outbreak of whooping cough.\n This\nreport summarizes data considered and conclusions made by ACIP and\nprovides guidance for implementing its recommendations. Date: Tue 25 Oct 2011\nSource: My Fox News [edited]\nhttp://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/news/whooping-cough-cases-triple-in-suffolk-county-20111025-lgf ACIP\nreviewed published and unpublished data from VAERS, Sanofi Pasteur\n Most recently, we have shown that more virulent\n(P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible\nfor the outbreak in the Netherlands. The full paper\nis available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-13 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2054-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-06-22 00:00:00", "2023-10-20 20:11:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kirkland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McHenry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Douglas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Island 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halperin SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas City Star", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Suffolk County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "326798", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia: (SA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=326798", "date": "2009-11-07 04:00:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA: (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2009\nSource: Adelaide Now [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,26306408-5006301,00.html>\n\n\nSouth Australia is experiencing its worst whooping cough [pertussis]\noutbreak on record and babies are the main victims of the potentially fatal\nand highly infectious disease. Babies are most vulnerable as they are too\nyoung to be [fully] immunized, and rely upon 'herd immunity', the high\nimmunisation of those around them.\n\nSA Health has received almost 3500 reports in 2009, compared with 859 at\nthe same time in 2008 and 318 in 2007. National statistics show the rate in\nSouth Australia is twice as high as the national average. A 4 week old NSW\nbaby who died in March 2009 was the 1st fatality from the disease in a\ndecade. Since then it is understood 2 other children have died.\n\nSA Health Communicable Disease Control branch director Dr Ann Koehler said\nnationally there had been a 'big wave' of infections. She said SA had the\nhighest rate, although it was not clear why. Dr Koehler said more cases\nwere being diagnosed as people were tested for swine flu. She said SA had\nrecorded the highest number of notifications since records started being\nkept in 1991, and warned that people needed to be vigilant about\nvaccinations to protect vulnerable children.\n\n'The highest rates of infection we're seeing are children who are too young\nto be vaccinated,' Dr Koehler said. 'With children, brain damage can be a\nreally serious complication. While they're trying to cough, they stop\nbreathing. Little children also get hernias and might need surgery to fix\nthat.'\n\nAbout 95 per cent of SA children are immunized, but Dr Koehler said SA\nHealth was concerned about some people's resistance to or complacency about\nvaccinating children. She warned homeopathic 'vaccines' did not work.\n'That's wasting your money ... you're putting yourself, your children and\nother people's children at risk,' she said.\n\n[byline: Tory Shepard]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some\nresearchers noted that 'Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and\nyoung adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than\nseen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT.\nReport of the task force on pertussis and pertussis immunization - 1988.\nPediatrics 1988; 81(June Suppl): 955). The duration of protection has\nvaried in several studies, depending on the epidemiological setting; that\nis, prevalence of natural disease as well as the vaccine product used. A\nstudy in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last\ndose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years.\nBreakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.'\n\nBecause of these and similar findings, it is now recommended to reimmunize\nteenagers and give adults between 19 and 64 year old a TdaP [tetanus, low\ndose diphtheria, acellular pertussis] booster substituted for one of the\nevery 10 year Td vaccines [detailed adult immunisation practices vary\nworldwide. - Mod.SH]. - Mod.LL\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for South Australia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00N_> - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Tory Shepard]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some\nresearchers noted that 'Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and\nyoung adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than\nseen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2009\n She said SA had\nrecorded the highest number of notifications since records started being\nkept in 1991, and warned that people needed to be vigilant about\nvaccinations to protect vulnerable children. \n\nBecause of these and similar findings, it is now recommended to reimmunize\nteenagers and give adults between 19 and 64 year old a TdaP [tetanus, low\ndose diphtheria, acellular pertussis] booster substituted for one of the\n Source: Adelaide Now [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,26306408-5006301,00.html>\n\n\nSouth Australia is experiencing its worst whooping cough [pertussis]\noutbreak on record and babies are the main victims of the potentially fatal\nand highly infectious disease. \n\nAbout 95 per cent of SA children are immunized, but Dr Koehler said SA\nHealth was concerned about some people's resistance to or complacency about\nvaccinating children. A\nstudy in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last\ndose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years. A 4 week old NSW\nbaby who died in March 2009 was the 1st fatality from the disease in a\ndecade. The duration of protection has\nvaried in several studies, depending on the epidemiological setting; that\nis, prevalence of natural disease as well as the vaccine product used. Babies are most vulnerable as they are too\nyoung to be [fully] immunized, and rely upon 'herd immunity', the high\nimmunisation of those around them.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "TdaP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Karzon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36287", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36287", "date": "2007-11-11 15:00:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL DISTRICT - USA (02): (WISCONSIN)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Nov 2007\nSource: WSAW [edited]\n<http://www.wsaw.com/home/headlines/11111811.html>\n\n\nClark County school officials say an outbreak of pertussis, commonly\ncalled whooping cough, has more than 1/3rd of Greenwood Junior High\nand High School students staying home today [8 Nov 2007]. County\nHealth Officials say 32 cases have now been confirmed, and the school\ndistrict is fighting to contain the disease.\n\nGreenwood High School officials say when an outbreak of illness in\nthe school was recently diagnosed as whooping cough, they asked for\nguidance from the health department. 'Our county health officials are\nscreening students, encouraging them, sometimes demanding they go in\nand be tested to make sure they're not a carrier for us,' says High\nSchool Principal Jim Haines.\n\nThe health department has set up a station inside the high school.\nThey say the cough is very contagious for those in close quarters,\neven for those who have had the vaccination. In fact, county health\nofficials say every student that has been diagnosed with pertussis\nhas had a vaccination for the disease.\n\nBut despite the high number of cases, Haines says they're following\nthe recommendation of the Health Department to keep the school open.\n'It really makes a great deal of sense that they need to be able to\nhave contact with these people,' said Haines. 'If we were to close\nthe school for a week, or 2 weeks, or 3 weeks, we have no guarantee\nthat someone wouldn't come in and infect the whole group again.'\n\nBut Health and School Officials say that in order to protect the rest\nof the community, it's important that anyone who has been in contact\nwith the disease stays home during treatment. Those receiving\ntreatment are asked not to return to school or work until they have\nreceived at least 5 days of antibiotics.\n\n[Byline: Mikel Lauber]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 2nd outbreak of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection\nreported within one week, both in junior and senior high school\nstudents. It is among this age group that immunity to the infection\nbegins to wane and is the reason pertussis vaccine boosters are now\nrecommended for 11-12 year olds as well as once in adulthood. Usually\na relatively mild disease in this age group resulting in a chronic\ncough, infection in this age group can function as a reservoir to\ninfect infants, who have a substantial morbidity and mortality from pertussis.\n\nClark County is located in central Wisconsin and can be seen on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clark_County,_Wisconsin>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Nov 2007\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 2nd outbreak of _Bordetella pertussis_ infection\nreported within one week, both in junior and senior high school\nstudents. Usually\na relatively mild disease in this age group resulting in a chronic\ncough, infection in this age group can function as a reservoir to\ninfect infants, who have a substantial morbidity and mortality from pertussis. Our county health officials are\nscreening students, encouraging them, sometimes demanding they go in\nand be tested to make sure they're not a carrier for us,' says High\nSchool Principal Jim Haines. Clark County school officials say an outbreak of pertussis, commonly\ncalled whooping cough, has more than 1/3rd of Greenwood Junior High\nand High School students staying home today [8 Nov 2007]. Greenwood High School officials say when an outbreak of illness in\nthe school was recently diagnosed as whooping cough, they asked for\nguidance from the health department. ' \n\nBut Health and School Officials say that in order to protect the rest\nof the community, it's important that anyone who has been in contact\nwith the disease stays home during treatment. It is among this age group that immunity to the infection\nbegins to wane and is the reason pertussis vaccine boosters are now\nrecommended for 11-12 year olds as well as once in adulthood.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "277501", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=277501", "date": "2009-08-25 22:00:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ATYPICAL CASES - USA: (COLORADO), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 23 Aug 2009\nSource: Durango (CO) Herald [edited]\n<http://durangoherald.com/sections/News/2009/08/23/Scientists_probe_pertussis_cases/>\n\n\nExperts from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) are\nin Durango looking for clues as to why an unusually large percentage\nof the pertussis cases reported in Colorado in 2009 occurred in La\nPlata County.\n\n'It warrants investigation because of the wide spectrum of symptoms\natypical of pertussis,' Dr. Sema Mandal said during an interview at\nthe San Juan Basin Health Department.\n\nIt's not unusual for the CDC to investigate unusual trends such as\nthe extraordinarily high number of pertussis cases, but they do so\nonly at the invitation of state and local health authorities, said\nMatt Griffith, a CDC epidemiologist. A CDC team visited the Four\nCorners in 1993 during a hanta virus outbreak and more recently sent\na team to New York to help with investigation into H1N1 (swine) flu,\nGriffith said. Experience has taught the CDC that it's important to\nget detailed histories of illnesses and not to rule out anything,\nMandal said.\n\n'In this situation, with a mix of classical and nonclassical\nsymptoms, diagnosis can be a challenge,' Mandal said.\n\nSneezing, a runny nose, a fever and cough typically herald the onset\nof pertussis. A regimen in which children are vaccinated at 2, 4 and\n6 months of age, then between 15 and 18 months and finally between 4\nand 6 years of age confers protection that is 85 to 95 percent\neffective. Protection diminishes with time, and even fully vaccinated\nchildren can get the disease. Children ages 11 and older and adults\nalso should be vaccinated against pertussis.\n\nIn many of the La Plata County cases in which children and adults\ntested positive for pertussis, the symptoms were mild or not\naccompanied by the telltale whooping, which lends the disease its\npopular name. Given the absence of the wracking cough and the fact\nthat pertussis is hard to diagnose, the CDC team is looking for other\nbugs that could cause illness, Mandal said. Pertussis is caused by a\nbacterium.\n\n'It's too early to speculate what could account for the high number\nof pertussis cases here,' said Mandal, who added that the team had\narrived only a week earlier. She, Griffith and Pam Cassiday a\nmicrobiologist, were invited to investigate the pertussis cases by\nthe Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment. They will\nspend about 3 weeks in Durango.\n\nThe investigators, who are interviewing people who were treated for\npertussis, are particularly interested in learning what symptoms they\nhad. They also have contacted 3 or 4 local health-care facilities to\nask that their patients with new cough-related illnesses take part in\nthe investigation. Participation is voluntary.\n\nParticipants fill out a questionnaire that asks about their symptoms,\ntreatment and vaccination history. Also, they are asked for a blood\nsample and a nasal swab, which are sent to the CDC laboratory for\ntesting. 'People have been incredibly supportive,' Griffith said. 'It\ntakes about 5 minutes to complete the questionnaire.'\n\n[Byline: Dale Rodebaugh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is well known that _B. pertussis_ infection in previously\nimmunized adolescents and young adults rarely presents with the\ntypical cough paroxysm ending with a whoop, the prolonged\ninspiration. Rather, this cohort generally has a persistent cough for\nseveral weeks and can be responsible for transmission to infants who\nare not yet fully immunized. It is this group of susceptible infants\nthat represents most of the severe morbidity and mortality of the\ninfection.\n\nIt is not stated how the diagnosis was made, clinically, by culture,\nthrough serology and/or using PCR technology. Each technique has its\ndrawbacks. As an example, Dr. David Fisman from Toronto reported\ncases of a pertussis-like illness which may have been due to _B.\nholmesii_. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 23 Aug 2009\n Source: Durango (CO) Herald [edited]\n<http://durangoherald.com/sections/News/2009/08/23/Scientists_probe_pertussis_cases/>\n\n\nExperts from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) are\nin Durango looking for clues as to why an unusually large percentage\nof the pertussis cases reported in Colorado in 2009 occurred in La\nPlata County. \n\nIt's not unusual for the CDC to investigate unusual trends such as\nthe extraordinarily high number of pertussis cases, but they do so\nonly at the invitation of state and local health authorities, said\nMatt Griffith, a CDC epidemiologist. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is well known that _B. pertussis_ infection in previously\nimmunized adolescents and young adults rarely presents with the\ntypical cough paroxysm ending with a whoop, the prolonged\ninspiration. In many of the La Plata County cases in which children and adults\ntested positive for pertussis, the symptoms were mild or not\naccompanied by the telltale whooping, which lends the disease its\npopular name. A regimen in which children are vaccinated at 2, 4 and\n6 months of age, then between 15 and 18 months and finally between 4\nand 6 years of age confers protection that is 85 to 95 percent\neffective. A CDC team visited the Four\nCorners in 1993 during a hanta virus outbreak and more recently sent\na team to New York to help with investigation into H1N1 (swine) flu,\n \n\n'It warrants investigation because of the wide spectrum of symptoms\natypical of pertussis,' Dr. Sema Mandal said during an interview at\nthe San Juan Basin Health Department. It's too early to speculate what could account for the high number\nof pertussis cases here,' said Mandal, who added that the team had\narrived only a week earlier. Given the absence of the wracking cough and the fact\nthat pertussis is hard to diagnose, the CDC team is looking for other\nbugs that could cause illness, Mandal said. They also have contacted 3 or 4 local health-care facilities to\nask that their patients with new cough-related illnesses take part in\nthe investigation. As an example, Dr. David Fisman from Toronto reported\ncases of a pertussis-like illness which may have been due to _B.\nholmesii_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "H1N1", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "125863", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=125863", "date": "2008-11-07 16:00:35", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOLCHILDREN - USA: (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 Nov 2008\nSource: KELOLAND-TV (SD) [edited]\n<http://www.keloland.com/healthbeat/newsdetail6387.cfm?Id=0,76006>\n\n\nHealth officials say 17 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in\neastern South Dakota and are tied to Madison Elementary in Huron, where 10\nof the cases have been reported. Another 7 cases were reported in Lake\nPreston. Health officials say the cases involve children appropriately\nvaccinated for their ages, though they note that youngsters are not fully\nimmunized until 4 to 6 years of age, and they emphasized the need for\nbooster shots due to the fact that immunity wanes over time.\n\n[byline: Kelli Grant]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The ages of the affected children are not stated [Madison Elementary in\nHuron serves pre-kindergarten to 5th grade. - Mod.SH]. Immunity to the\ninfection begins to wane in adolescence and is the reason pertussis vaccine\nboosters are now recommended for 11-12 year olds as well as once in\nadulthood. Usually a relatively mild disease in this age group resulting in\na chronic cough, infection in this age group can function as a reservoir to\ninfect not yet adequately immunized infants, who have a substantial\nmorbidity and mortality from pertussis.\n\nHuron is in Beadle County in east-central South Dakota, which is in the\nnorth-central USA. The town and county can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huron,_South_Dakota>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the USA is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 Nov 2008\n Health officials say the cases involve children appropriately\nvaccinated for their ages, though they note that youngsters are not fully\nimmunized until 4 to 6 years of age, and they emphasized the need for\nbooster shots due to the fact that immunity wanes over time. Usually a relatively mild disease in this age group resulting in\na chronic cough, infection in this age group can function as a reservoir to\ninfect not yet adequately immunized infants, who have a substantial\nmorbidity and mortality from pertussis. Immunity to the\ninfection begins to wane in adolescence and is the reason pertussis vaccine\nboosters are now recommended for 11-12 year olds as well as once in\nadulthood. \n\n[byline: Kelli Grant]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Beadle County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Huron", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209639", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02): corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209639", "date": "2007-07-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "BORDETELLA HOLMESII, PERTUSSIS-LIKE ILLNESS - CANADA (ONTARIO) (02): CORRECTION\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Feb 2007\nFrom: David N. Fisman, MD <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nAdditional names of individuals contributing to the information\nposted in ProMED-mail posting Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like\nillness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261 are:\nDr. Fran Jamieson <frances.jamieson@ontario.ca>\nPatrick Tang (head technologist in respiratory pathogens and\nlegionella) <patrick.tang@ontario.ca>\nShirley Brown (manager, bacteriology) <shirley.brown@ontario.ca>\n--\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Additional names of individuals contributing to the information\nposted in ProMED-mail posting Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like\nillness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261 are:\nDr. Fran Jamieson <frances.jamieson@ontario.ca>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-02-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "171373", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Undiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=171373", "date": "2009-04-04 19:00:53", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED RESPIRATORY DEATHS - NICARAGUA: (JINOTEGA), PERTUSSIS\nSUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 4 Apr 2009\nSource: La Prensa [in Spanish, trans. Mod.MPP, edited]\n<http://www.laprensa.com.ni/archivo/2009/abril/04/noticias/nacionales/320734.shtml>\n\n\nMinistry of Health investigates an outbreak of whooping cough in Jinotega\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAn epidemic of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough may be\nresponsible for the deaths of at least 4 children with 70 others\naffected in the Amak area, on the Bocay River in Jinotega, according\nto a warning by Jose Luis Rodriguez, pastor of the Council of\nPro-Denominational Alliance Churches (CEPAD).\n\nWhooping cough (or pertussis is a contagious bacterial disease that\ncauses a violent and sometimes difficult to control cough that can\nlead to difficulty in breathing, and it can lead to incapacitation or\ndeath of those affected, particularly in young children.\n\nThrough a press release, CEPAD reported that Pastor Rodriguez\nreceived the news from Maria Cornejo, one of the health promoters in\nthe area [health promoters are community health workers. - Mod.MPP]\n\nShe added that on 25 Mar [2009] another 7 children were suspected of\nbeing infected. The children are from the Amalakuwas community,\nlocated about 8 hours by pipante [a motorized dugout canoe] from the\nKarawah community on the same Bocay river.\n\nBocas de Wina, 36 km [approx. 22 mi] from Ayapal, is another place\nwhere tens of children were reported with symptoms of whooping cough\naccording to CEPAD.\n\nThe main cause of the outbreak, according to the health promoter, is\nthat parents do not come to vaccinate their children when they\nconduct vaccination days. [In remote, difficult to access regions,\nvaccination activities are often conducted on special vaccination\ndays, either once a week or once a month, or other frequencies\ndepending upon the size of the target population. Maintenance of the\ncold chain, keeping vaccines within required temperature ranges so\nthey maintain their potency, is a challenge, as well as the logistics\nof bringing supplies and trained personnel into these regions. - Mod.MPP]\n\nThe Ministry of Health (MINSA) via Dr Edmundo Sanchez, director of\nthe Department of Disease Surveillance, confirmed the existence of\ntens of children with symptoms of a cold (catarrhal disease),\nespecially cough, in the Jinotega area. However, he said they cannot\nensure what the disease is [the diagnosis], until they have taken\nsamples from cases and perform a variety of different tests on the specimens.\n\nAccording to Sanchez, a medical team from MINSA traveled to the\naffected area and they expect to have news on what is really\nhappening there. 'For now, we cannot say what disease is affecting\nthe population, the children, but we do not think that it is an\noutbreak of whooping cough, because this zone has a good immunization\ncoverage, surpassing 85 per cent. When we know what is going on we\nwill [provide more information], it is not our policy to hide what is\nhappening,' said Dr Sanchez.\n\n[Byline: Roberto Perez Solis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Even with more widespread immunization, outbreaks of pertussis in\nyoung infants (who represent the cohort with most of the severe\nmorbidity and mortality in this disease) can occur since vaccine\nimmunity wanes and can produce adolescents and young adults who,\nmanifesting infection as a chronic cough, transmit _Bordetella\npertussis_ to infants. Reimmunization of this older group may be able\nto prevent serious pertussis in infants not old enough to be fully immunized.\n\nMore information on the results of investigations of this outbreak\nwould be appreciated.\n\nThe Department (State) of Jinotega is located in northwestern\nNicaragua and can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinotega_Department>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nicaragua is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008u>. - Mods.LL/MPP]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Even with more widespread immunization, outbreaks of pertussis in\nyoung infants (who represent the cohort with most of the severe\nmorbidity and mortality in this disease) can occur since vaccine\nimmunity wanes and can produce adolescents and young adults who,\nmanifesting infection as a chronic cough, transmit _Bordetella\npertussis_ to infants. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 4 Apr 2009\n An epidemic of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough may be\nresponsible for the deaths of at least 4 children with 70 others\naffected in the Amak area, on the Bocay River in Jinotega, according\nto a warning by Jose Luis Rodriguez, pastor of the Council of\nPro-Denominational Alliance Churches (CEPAD). \n\nWhooping cough (or pertussis is a contagious bacterial disease that\ncauses a violent and sometimes difficult to control cough that can\nlead to difficulty in breathing, and it can lead to incapacitation or\ndeath of those affected, particularly in young children. \n\nThe Ministry of Health (MINSA) via Dr Edmundo Sanchez, director of\nthe Department of Disease Surveillance, confirmed the existence of\ntens of children with symptoms of a cold (catarrhal disease),\nespecially cough, in the Jinotega area. For now, we cannot say what disease is affecting\nthe population, the children, but we do not think that it is an\noutbreak of whooping cough, because this zone has a good immunization\ncoverage, surpassing 85 per cent. [In remote, difficult to access regions,\nvaccination activities are often conducted on special vaccination\ndays, either once a week or once a month, or other frequencies\ndepending upon the size of the target population. \n\nThe main cause of the outbreak, according to the health promoter, is\nthat parents do not come to vaccinate their children when they\nconduct vaccination days. 22 mi] from Ayapal, is another place\nwhere tens of children were reported with symptoms of whooping cough\naccording to CEPAD. Through a press release, CEPAD reported that Pastor Rodriguez\nreceived the news from Maria Cornejo, one of the health promoters in\nthe area [health promoters are community health workers. The children are from the Amalakuwas community,\nlocated about 8 hours by pipante [a motorized dugout canoe] from the\nKarawah community on the same Bocay river. According to Sanchez, a medical team from MINSA traveled to the\naffected area and they expect to have news on what is really\nhappening there. ' However, he said they cannot\nensure what the disease is [the diagnosis], until they have taken\nsamples from cases and perform a variety of different tests on the specimens. When we know what is going on we\nwill [provide more information], it is not our policy to hide what is\nhappening,' said Dr Sanchez.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "La Prensa", "country": "Guatemala"}, {"location": "Sanchez", "country": "Dominican Republic"}, {"location": "Nicaragua", "country": "Nicaragua"}, {"location": "Amalakuwas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jinotega", "country": "Nicaragua"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17539", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17539", "date": "2007-07-14 11:00:03", "main_text": "BORDETELLA HOLMESII, PERTUSSIS-LIKE ILLNESS - CANADA (ONTARIO) (02)\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 13 Jul 2007\nFrom: David Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>, Tracey Clatworthy\n<tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\n\nRe: Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nWe appreciate ProMED-mail's posting of our initial report, and also\nappreciate the Moderator's (Dr. Levison's) interesting questions and comments.\nWith respect to the question of whether our isolation of _B.\nholmesii_ is related to the presence or absence of cephalexin in\nculture or transport media, we think this unlikely. Indeed, all 5\nisolates initially identified at the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory grew on Regan-Lowe charcoal agar with 20 ug/ml cephalexin,\nand we have been able to grow all 6 isolates (a 6th isolate was\nforwarded to us for reference identification) in the presence of up\nto 40 ug/ml cephalexin. As such, our experience differs from that\ndescribed in Massachusetts (reference: Mazengia E, et al, J Clin\nMicro 2000; 38(6): 2330-3).\n\nThe Moderator notes that Toronto has seen a marked increase in\npertussis rates since 2005, though the fact that most cases are IS481\nPCR-positive but culture negative, and clinically quite mild (no\npertussis-related hospitalizations noted at the region's major\nchildren's hospital) suggests that increased sensitivity of\nlaboratory methods may have led to the identification of individuals\nwith relatively mild infection and low organism burden. Nonetheless,\nof 1340 specimens that tested positive for pertussis between January\n2005 and March 2007, 104 (7.8 percent) were culture positive for _B.\npertussis_. In contrast, only 5 _B. holmesii_ isolates were\nidentified during the same period. As such, we think it unlikely that\n_B. holmesii_ is a major contributor to increased local pertussis\nrates. We recently presented a laboratory-based assessment of\npertussis epidemiology in the Greater Toronto Area at the meeting of\nthe Pediatric Academic Societies meeting; the abstract can be accessed at\n<http://www.pas-meeting.org/2007Toronto/Abstracts/LB%20Sessions%2007.pdf>.\n--\nDavid N. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. The _B. pertussis_ assay that targets insertion sequence\nIS481 has been found to cross-react with isolates of _B. holmesii_\n(see Reischl U, et al, J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1963-6). Indeed,\nFisman and Jamieson reported that 4 of the actual nasopharyngeal\nspecimens that were culture-positive for _B. holmesii_ gave a\npositive result by the PCR assay for IS481 (see ProMED-mail\n_Bordetella holmesii_, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n20070711.2215). However, the prevalence of _B. holmesii_ in the upper\nrespiratory tract of healthy individuals and its clinical\nsignificance in patients with cough remain to be evaluated. In the\nmeantime, since the PCR assay for IS461 is not specific for _B.\npertussis_, other diagnostic tests would seem to be necessary. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "The Moderator notes that Toronto has seen a marked increase in\npertussis rates since 2005, though the fact that most cases are IS481\nPCR-positive but culture negative, and clinically quite mild (no\npertussis-related hospitalizations noted at the region's major\nchildren's hospital) suggests that increased sensitivity of\nlaboratory methods may have led to the identification of individuals\nwith relatively mild infection and low organism burden. Indeed, all 5\nisolates initially identified at the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory grew on Regan-Lowe charcoal agar with 20 ug/ml cephalexin,\nand we have been able to grow all 6 isolates (a 6th isolate was\nforwarded to us for reference identification) in the presence of up\nto 40 ug/ml cephalexin. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Indeed,\nFisman and Jamieson reported that 4 of the actual nasopharyngeal\nspecimens that were culture-positive for _B. holmesii_ gave a\npositive result by the PCR assay for IS481 (see ProMED-mail\n_ Nonetheless,\nof 1340 specimens that tested positive for pertussis between January\n2005 and March 2007, 104 (7.8 percent) were culture positive for _B.\npertussis_. We recently presented a laboratory-based assessment of\npertussis epidemiology in the Greater Toronto Area at the meeting of\nthe Pediatric Academic Societies meeting; the abstract can be accessed at\n<http://www.pas-meeting.org/2007Toronto/Abstracts/LB%20Sessions%2007.pdf>. The _B. pertussis_ assay that targets insertion sequence\nIS481 has been found to cross-react with isolates of _B. holmesii_\n(see Reischl U, et al, J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1963-6). As such, we think it unlikely that\n_B. holmesii_ is a major contributor to increased local pertussis\nrates. With respect to the question of whether our isolation of _B.\nholmesii_ is related to the presence or absence of cephalexin in\nculture or transport media, we think this unlikely. From: David Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>, Tracey Clatworthy\n<tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\n\nRe: Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1340-03-25 00:00:00", "1963-06-25 00:00:00", "2330-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Regan - Lowe", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "35548", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, school district - USA: (OH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=35548", "date": "2007-11-06 13:00:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL DISTRICT - USA: (OHIO)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 5 Nov 2007\nSource: WBNW-10TV (Ohio) [edited]\n<http://www.10tv.com/?sec=news&story=sites/10tv/content/pool/200711/1239409135.html>\n\n\nThe Columbus Health Department on Mon 5 Nov 2007 confirmed that 46\nstudents in the Worthington City School district have been diagnosed\nwith whooping cough. The outbreak started in early October 2007 and\nadditional students were being tested for the disease, 10TV's Kurt\nLudlow reported.\n\nIn October 2007, the Columbus Health Department confirmed that 5\nstudents at Worthington Kilbourne High School were diagnosed with\nwhooping cough. The school district confirmed more cases late last\nweek. At least one student at Thomas Worthington High School was\ndiagnosed with whooping cough, 10TV News reported.\n\nColumbus public health commissioner Dr Teresa Long said vaccines are\nextremely important in thwarting the spread of whooping cough.\n'Please, do not wait. Do not wait to get your children vaccinated,'\nLong said. 'A vaccine now is very important because we want to\nprotect going into the Thanksgiving holiday [22 Nov 2007]. There will\nbe more families gathering and we do not want to see the spread of\nthis outbreak any further.'\n\nHealth officials said parents should also check immunization records\nto ensure that children have had the appropriate vaccines. The\nbooster shot is usually available through a family physician.\n\nLong said Worthington students who have not had the booster shot\nshould do so immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whether culture or polymerase chain reaction assays were used to\ndiagnose _Bordetella pertussis_ in this outbreak is not stated. The\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) publication on\ncontrolling pertussis outbreaks (1) is an excellent reference on not\nonly diagnosis and treatment, but also epidemiology and control\nmeasures in a variety of settings including those of household,\nchildcare, school, and health care environments.\n\nAs a reminder, the 5 dose primary series for\ndiphtheria/tetanus/acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine in children is\nrecommended (2) at ages 2, 4, 6, 15-18 months, and 4-6 years. A\nbooster of Tdap (lower dose of diphtheria and pertussis immunogens)\nis then recommended (2) between ages 11-12 or before age 18 if not\ngiven. Additionally, a single dose of Tdap is now recommended in\nadults (3) to be given to replace a dose of the every-10 year Td\nbooster for adults aged less than 65 years who have not previously\nreceived a dose of Tdap. This dose is particularly important in\nadults (pediatric health care workers, new parents, and grandparents)\nwho are likely to be in contact with young children of the age\nprecluding them from being adequately protected from pertussis. These\ninfants are the cohort group with the highest morbidity and mortality\nfrom pertussis.\n\nReferences:\n1. CDC: Guidelines for the Control of Pertussis Outbreaks, CDC,\nAtlanta, GA, 2000 (amended 2005, 2006), available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pertussis-guide/guide.htm>.\n\n2. CDC: Recommended Immunization Schedules for Persons Aged 0-18\nYears -- United States, 2007. MMWR 2007; 55: Q1-Q4, available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5551a7.htm>.\n\n3. CDC: Recommended Adult Immunization Schedule -- United States,\nOctober 2007-September 2008. MMWR 2007; 56: Q1-Q4, available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5641-Immunizationa1.htm>.\n\nWorthington is a northern suburb of Columbus, Ohio in Franklin\nCounty. It can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worthington,_Ohio>. - Mod.LL\nThe Midwestern state of Ohio can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 5 Nov 2007\n The\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) publication on\ncontrolling pertussis outbreaks (1) is an excellent reference on not\nonly diagnosis and treatment, but also epidemiology and control\nmeasures in a variety of settings including those of household,\nchildcare, school, and health care environments. Additionally, a single dose of Tdap is now recommended in\nadults (3) to be given to replace a dose of the every-10 year Td\nbooster for adults aged less than 65 years who have not previously\nreceived a dose of Tdap. This dose is particularly important in\nadults (pediatric health care workers, new parents, and grandparents)\nwho are likely to be in contact with young children of the age\nprecluding them from being adequately protected from pertussis. A\nbooster of Tdap (lower dose of diphtheria and pertussis immunogens)\nis then recommended (2) between ages 11-12 or before age 18 if not\ngiven. \n\nAs a reminder, the 5 dose primary series for\ndiphtheria/tetanus/acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine in children is\nrecommended (2) at ages 2, 4, 6, 15-18 months, and 4-6 years. The Columbus Health Department on Mon 5 Nov 2007 confirmed that 46\nstudents in the Worthington City School district have been diagnosed\nwith whooping cough. In October 2007, the Columbus Health Department confirmed that 5\nstudents at Worthington Kilbourne High School were diagnosed with\nwhooping cough. The outbreak started in early October 2007 and\nadditional students were being tested for the disease, 10TV's Kurt\nLudlow reported. CDC: Guidelines for the Control of Pertussis Outbreaks, CDC,\nAtlanta, GA, 2000 (amended 2005, 2006), available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pertussis-guide/guide.htm>. These\ninfants are the cohort group with the highest morbidity and mortality\nfrom pertussis. PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL DISTRICT - USA: (OHIO)\n****************************************\n The Midwestern state of Ohio can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-10-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Columbus", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin \n County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17048", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17048", "date": "2007-07-11 22:00:03", "main_text": "BORDETELLA HOLMESII, PERTUSSIS-LIKE ILLNESS - CANADA (ONTARIO)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2007\nFrom: David Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>, Frances Jamieson\n<frances.jamieson@ontario.ca>\n\nDrs. David Fisman and Frances Jamieson report:\n'Between January and May 2007, the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory (CPHL) has identified 5 isolates of _Bordetella holmesii_\nin individuals being tested for pertussis. An additional isolate had\nbeen identified in August 2005. The CPHL performs parallel culture\nand real-time PCR [polymerase chain reaction] (using the IS481\ntarget) on all specimens submitted for pertussis testing, and also\nserves as a reference laboratory for regional public health\nlaboratories. Colonies suspicious for _Bordetella_ spp. are\nsubcultured for purity, and then definitively identified through\ndirect fluorescent antibody (DFA) and serum agglutination (for _B.\npertussis_ and _B. parapertussis_). Isolates that do not react with\nDFA and agglutination reagents are identified by cellular fatty acid\n(CFA) analysis (Sherlock, MIDI Inc, Newark, DE), and biochemical\nprofile. Isolates are also tested by real-time PCR for the presence\nof IS481 and IS1001.\nOf 6 isolates, 5 were from individuals in the Greater Toronto Area\n(GTA), Canada's largest metropolitan area with a population of\napproximately 5.5 million people in 2006. The 6th isolate was from an\nindividual in the a health region approximately 70 miles (about 113\nkm) northwest of Toronto. In addition to being culture-positive and\nphenotypically identified as _B. holmesii_, 4 nasopharyngeal swab\nspecimens tested positive by PCR for IS481. PCR using the IS481\ntarget will detect _B. holmesii_, as this organism also contains the\nIS481 insertion sequence.\nThere were 3 male and 3 female source patients. All were adolescents\n(age range 11 to 17) at the time of presentation. As such, this group\nmay have received primary vaccination against pertussis with a whole\ncell vaccine that is believed to have been poorly immunogenic. Most\npertussis test specimens received by the laboratory are obtained from\nsource patients under 10 years; for example, from January 2005 to the\npresent the lab received 4008 pertussis specimens from children under\n10, and only 615 for those aged 10 to 19. The P-value for all 6 _B.\nholmesii_ isolates having come from the latter group is smaller than\n0.001, and the lower bound confidence limit for the relative risk is\n7.2 (the RR itself is undefined, as no isolates came from children under 10).\nPrimary care providers who submitted the specimens were contacted.\nAll 6 individuals presented with cough illness. Duration of cough\nprior to presentation was 3 days to 2 weeks. Cough was described as\n'slightly productive' or 'wet' in 2 individuals, and dry in others.\nFour individuals had a history of paroxysmal cough or coughing 'until\nchest was sore'. No post-tussive vomiting, no whoop, and no fever\nwere reported in any of the 6. All 6 are reported to have had normal\nphysical examinations; 2 individuals had chest radiographs, both of\nwhich were normal. It was volunteered that 2 of the cases (both in\nthe GTA) had history of 'pertussis exposure' (at school or summer\ncamp). Macrolide therapy was given to 5 of the 6 (3 received\nclarithromycin; 2 received azithromycin).\nIt is possible that _B. holmesii_ is a true cause of pertussis-like\nillness, and interestingly, the link between B. holmesii and teens\nhas been seen in Massachusetts as well. A dispatch in Emerging\nInfectious Diseases described this microorganism as being isolated\nprimarily from adolescents with cough (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/Ncidod/eid/vol5no3/yih.htm>).\n_B. holmesii_ has also caused bacteremia in asplenic individuals (see\nShepard CW et al., Clin Infect Dis 2004; 38: 799-804).\nOur identification of this microorganism has been possible due to our\nlaboratory's ongoing performance of both PCR and culture on submitted\nspecimens. We would be very interested in 'comparing notes' with\ncolleagues in other jurisdictions in terms of their experience with\nthis microorganism, and their thoughts related to whether or not _B.\nholmesii_ is a true pathogen. We thank ProMED-mail in advance for\nconsideration of posting this description, and we hope that this\nstimulates discussion on ProMED-mail. We would also be delighted to\nhear from colleagues directly, via e-mail.\n--\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nFrances Jamieson, MD FRCP(C)\nMedical Microbiologist,\nClinical and Environmental Microbiology,\nOntario Central Public Health Laboratory\n<frances.jamieson@ontario.ca>\n[In the winter of 2005-6, Toronto experienced an outbreak of\npertussis (see ProMED-mail Pertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431),\nmainly in children under 4 years of age. The immunization status of\nthe cases was not specified in this report, but most of the cases\nwere noted to have only mild symptoms. Whether any of the cases were\ndue to _B. holmesii_ is not known. _B. holmesii_ was formerly\ndesignated as nonoxidizer group 2 by the CDC (US Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention), and 1st described in 1995. This organism was\ninitially described as causing sepsis in severely compromised\npatients. However, Yih et al ( see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/Ncidod/eid/vol5no3/yih.htm>) reported this\norganism caused a pertussis-like illness, mainly in adolescents and\nyoung adults in Massachusetts in 1995-8. The Massachusetts State\nLaboratory found that cephalexin, the antibiotic commonly\nincorporated into Bordet-Gengou and charcoal agar for the recovery of\n_Bordetella_ spp. from respiratory specimens, is inhibitory for\ngrowth of _B. holmesii_. The authors thought that this explained why\n_B. holmesii_ was not isolated previously from respiratory specimens\nin patients suspected of having pertussis (see Mazengia E, Silva EA,\nPeppe JA, et al J Clin Microbiol 2000; 38:2330-3). Perhaps Drs.\nFisman and Jamieson could comment whether this explanation was\ninvolved in the Toronto experience. - Mod.ML]\n[The province of Ontario, in the east-central part of Canada, can be\nlocated on the map at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/Ncidod/eid/vol5no3/yih.htm>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Most\npertussis test specimens received by the laboratory are obtained from\nsource patients under 10 years; for example, from January 2005 to the\npresent the lab received 4008 pertussis specimens from children under\n10, and only 615 for those aged 10 to 19. The CPHL performs parallel culture\nand real-time PCR [polymerase chain reaction] (using the IS481\ntarget) on all specimens submitted for pertussis testing, and also\nserves as a reference laboratory for regional public health\nlaboratories. Medical Microbiologist,\nClinical and Environmental Microbiology,\nOntario Central Public Health Laboratory\n<frances.jamieson@ontario.ca>\n The authors thought that this explained why\n_B. holmesii_ was not isolated previously from respiratory specimens\nin patients suspected of having pertussis (see Mazengia E, Silva EA,\nPeppe JA, et al J Clin Microbiol 2000; 38:2330-3). David Fisman and Frances Jamieson report:\n'Between January and May 2007, the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory (CPHL) has identified 5 isolates of _Bordetella holmesii_\nin individuals being tested for pertussis. The P-value for all 6 _B.\nholmesii_ isolates having come from the latter group is smaller than\n0.001, and the lower bound confidence limit for the relative risk is\n7.2 (the RR itself is undefined, as no isolates came from children under 10). However, Yih et al ( see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/Ncidod/eid/vol5no3/yih.htm>) reported this\norganism caused a pertussis-like illness, mainly in adolescents and\nyoung adults in Massachusetts in 1995-8. Colonies suspicious for _Bordetella_ spp. are\nsubcultured for purity, and then definitively identified through\ndirect fluorescent antibody (DFA) and serum agglutination (for _B.\npertussis_ and _B. parapertussis_). We would be very interested in 'comparing notes' with\ncolleagues in other jurisdictions in terms of their experience with\nthis microorganism, and their thoughts related to whether or not _B.\nholmesii_ is a true pathogen.
