The Massachusetts State\nLaboratory found that cephalexin, the antibiotic commonly\nincorporated into Bordet-Gengou and charcoal agar for the recovery of\n_Bordetella_ spp. Scientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\n [In the winter of 2005-6, Toronto experienced an outbreak of\npertussis (see ProMED-mail Pertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431),\nmainly in children under 4 years of age. It is possible that _B. holmesii_ is a true cause of pertussis-like\nillness, and interestingly, the link between B. holmesii and teens\nhas been seen in Massachusetts as well. In addition to being culture-positive and\nphenotypically identified as _B. holmesii_, 4 nasopharyngeal swab\nspecimens tested positive by PCR for IS481. \n_B. holmesii_ has also caused bacteremia in asplenic individuals (see\nShepard CW et al., Clin Infect Dis 2004; 38: 799-804). Of 6 isolates, 5 were from individuals in the Greater Toronto Area\n(GTA), Canada's largest metropolitan area with a population of\napproximately 5.5 million people in 2006. All 6 are reported to have had normal\nphysical examinations; 2 individuals had chest radiographs, both of\nwhich were normal. B. holmesii_ was formerly\ndesignated as nonoxidizer group 2 by the CDC (US Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention), and 1st described in 1995.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-01-25 00:00:00", "2005-08-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Newark", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "23581", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (MS): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=23581", "date": "2007-08-19 23:03:59", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (MISSISSIPPI): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 16 Aug 2007\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.wmcstations.com/Global/story.asp?S=6942106>\n\nMore than 80 whooping cough cases have been reported in Mississippi,\nwith most of them clustered in Neshoba, Leake, Lauderdale, Attala,\nNewton, and Winston counties.\nInterim state health officer Doctor Ed Thompson said he has asked the\nCDC in Atlanta for help. Thompson said CDC epidemiologists have\nplenty of expertise in containing such outbreaks. Health officials\nare providing booster vaccines for pertussis, commonly known as whopping cough.\nThompson said the outbreak flared rather quickly, as reemerging\ndiseases often do. The focus now is on containing it. Doctor Bret\nBoes of Riley Hospital in Meridian said children are immunized for\nwhooping cough before entering school.\nThe most obvious symptom of whooping cough is intense coughing\nspells. Experts say there will normally be 4 to 5 coughs at a time,\nfollowed by a deep breath [the whoop - Mod.LL]. Other symptoms are\nrunny nose, severe upper respiratory congestion and low grade fever.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The diagnostic criteria used for the cases here are not stated. Just\nas important, the ages of the cases are not stated to assess whether\nthe infections are in the un-immunized, due to failure of the vaccine\nin older children, waning of immunity in young adults or a combination.\nThe most recent CDC statement regarding adult immunization (CDC:\nRecommended Adult Immunization Schedule --- United States, October\n2006--September 2007 MMWR 2006;55; Q1-Q4)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5540-Immunizationa1.htm>\nstates this about the tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis vaccine in adults:\n'Adults with uncertain histories of a complete primary vaccination\nseries with diphtheria and tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines should\nbegin or complete a primary vaccination series. A primary series for\nadults is 3 doses; administer the 1st 2 doses at least 4 weeks apart\nand the 3rd dose 6-12 months after the 2nd.\nAdminister a booster dose to adults who have completed a primary\nseries and if the last vaccination was received greater 10 years\npreviously. Tdap or tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine may be used;\nTdap should replace a single dose of Td for adults aged less than 65\nyears who have not previously received a dose of Tdap (either in the\nprimary series, as a booster, or for wound management).\nOnly one of 2 Tdap products (Adacel [Sanofi Pasteur, Swiftwater,\nPennsylvania]) is licensed for use in adults. If the person is\npregnant and received the last Td vaccination greater than 10 years\npreviously, administer Td during the 2nd or 3rd trimester; if the\nperson received the last Td vaccination in less than 10 years,\nadminister Tdap during the immediate postpartum period. A one-time\nadministration of one dose of Tdap with an interval as short as 2\nyears from a previous Td vaccination is recommended for postpartum\nwomen, close contacts of infants aged <12 months, and all health-care\nworkers with direct patient contact. In certain situations, Td can be\ndeferred during pregnancy and Tdap substituted in the immediate\npostpartum period, or Tdap can be given instead of Td to a pregnant\nwoman after an informed discussion with the woman.' - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Recommended Adult Immunization Schedule --- United States, October\n2006--September 2007 MMWR 2006;55; Q1-Q4)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5540-Immunizationa1.htm>\nstates this about the tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis vaccine in adults:\n'Adults with uncertain histories of a complete primary vaccination\nseries with diphtheria and tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines should\nbegin or complete a primary vaccination series. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n If the person is\npregnant and received the last Td vaccination greater than 10 years\npreviously, administer Td during the 2nd or 3rd trimester; if the\nperson received the last Td vaccination in less than 10 years,\nadminister Tdap during the immediate postpartum period. A one-time\nadministration of one dose of Tdap with an interval as short as 2\nyears from a previous Td vaccination is recommended for postpartum\nwomen, close contacts of infants aged <12 months, and all health-care\nworkers with direct patient contact. Tdap or tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine may be used;\nTdap should replace a single dose of Td for adults aged less than 65\nyears who have not previously received a dose of Tdap (either in the\nprimary series, as a booster, or for wound management). Just\nas important, the ages of the cases are not stated to assess whether\nthe infections are in the un-immunized, due to failure of the vaccine\nin older children, waning of immunity in young adults or a combination. In certain situations, Td can be\ndeferred during pregnancy and Tdap substituted in the immediate\npostpartum period, or Tdap can be given instead of Td to a pregnant\nwoman after an informed discussion with the woman.' - Mod. Source: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.wmcstations.com/Global/story.asp?S=6942106>\n\nMore than 80 whooping cough cases have been reported in Mississippi,\nwith most of them clustered in Neshoba, Leake, Lauderdale, Attala,\nNewton, and Winston counties. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n Administer a booster dose to adults who have completed a primary\nseries and if the last vaccination was received greater 10 years\npreviously.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Newton", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leake", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Winston", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mississippi", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Attala", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Meridian", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "tdap", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6195", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA)(03): correct dx?", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6195", "date": "2006-12-28 00:00:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, HOSPITAL EMPLOYEES - USA (MASSACHUSETTS) (03): CORRECT DIAGNOSIS?\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 26 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/yourlife/health/diseases/articles/2006/12/26/coughing_cases_mystify_specialists/>\n\nIt seemed straightforward enough at first: A 19-month-old boy being\ntreated at Children's Hospital Boston had classic symptoms of\nwhooping cough, and a laboratory test confirmed he had the disease.\nThen, from late September through early November 2006, 3 dozen\nhospital employees in wards where the child had been treated also\ndeveloped coughs and other symptoms suggesting that they too were\nstricken with the disease. And, just as for the toddler, initial\ntesting confirmed they carried the bacterium.\nBut now, more than 3 months after the child fell ill, disease\ninvestigators are no longer certain that the respiratory illnesses\nthat struck workers and another patient at Children's Hospital were\ncaused by whooping cough, also known as pertussis. Additional\ntesting, using approaches different from the 1st round, could find\nlittle evidence of the highly contagious germ.\nStill, no one can say for sure what made the workers sick -- they all\nrecovered -- and disease specialists can't definitively rule out\npertussis as the cause.\nThe cluster of illnesses is proving so intriguing that federal\ndisease sleuths and even a lab in Canada have joined specialists from\nBoston and the state who are trying to crack the mystery.\nThe episode at Children's Hospital is a cautionary tale about the\nlimits of science, particularly the ability of laboratories to\nproduce absolute, unimpeachable results when disease strikes.\n'People think laboratory tests are 100 percent accurate: If they're\npositive, they're positive; if they're negative, they're negative,'\nsaid David Warshauer, a top official at the Wisconsin State\nLaboratory of Hygiene, which oversaw testing during a pertussis\noutbreak in 2003 and 2004 that spawned more than 5000 cases. 'But\nthat's not the case with any laboratory test. And when you're looking\nfor an infectious agent like pertussis, there's a lot of variables.'\nThe mystery began 18 Sep 2006, when a toddler came down with symptoms\nof whooping cough, typically heralded by a runny nose, sneezing,\nslight fever, and mild cough. The disease can develop far more severe\nmanifestations, most notably spasmodic coughing that can last for\nmonths, and be ferocious enough to shatter ribs.\nWhile symptoms can provide strong clues about whether a patient has\nthe disease, laboratory tests provide far more robust proof,\nespecially for pertussis, with early symptoms similar to the common\ncold. To collect a specimen for testing, a cotton swab-like probe is\nthreaded through the nose and into the back of the throat\n[nasopharyngeal culture. - Mod.LL]. 'People generally don't like it\nmuch when you do that,' said Dr. Alfred DeMaria, director of\ncommunicable disease control for the state. 'But you can't get to\nthat area through the mouth.'\nThe sample is then used 2 ways. One is a laboratory classic called\nculturing: Material from the patient is placed in a dish with a\ngrowth medium that will allow the bacterium to reproduce if it's\npresent. The other approach is more modern: polymerase chain\nreaction, or PCR, involves looking for the genetic fingerprint of the\ndisease. PCR has emerged in the past decade as a favorite testing\ntechnology in state labs across the nation, including the\nMassachusetts State Laboratory Institute in Jamaica Plain, in large\npart because it's easier and faster than culturing. It was that lab\nthat tested most of the samples collected from Children's Hospital,\ninitially using PCR. There were hundreds of tests performed, and 38\n-- 2 patients and 36 healthcare workers -- came back positive for pertussis.\n'Children's [Hospital], much like the local health department, really\nrelies on laboratory tests to guide us on what the diagnosis is,\nespecially illnesses that can look like a lot of different things,'\nsaid Dr. Anita Barry, top disease tracker at the Boston Public Health\nCommission. 'Having accurate test results early on, particularly when\nthey're consistent with the clinical symptoms, really launches us\ninto control steps.' And that is what happened at Children's\nHospital, with measures designed to hem in the bacterium and prevent\nit from colonizing more victims.\n'You think you know what's going on,' said Dr. Manisha Patel, a\ndisease investigator at the CDC, 'and you want to make sure it\ndoesn't spread to the most vulnerable patients in the hospital.' But\neven as those steps appeared to be reining in the outbreak, something\ncurious began happening at the state lab.\nSpecialists rarely rely on a single testing method to confirm a\ndiagnosis if multiple methods exist. So state lab workers, in\naddition to performing PCR testing, proceeded with the laborious task\nof culturing samples. They also tested blood samples from the\nhospital workers. The results of those additional tests: They were\nalmost uniformly negative for pertussis, DeMaria said.\n'What was going through my head at the time was what might explain\nthis?' Barry said. 'Is there some type of problem with one of the\ntests? Could it be something closely related to pertussis?'\nSamples were sent to the CDC in the quest for answers. Researchers in\nAtlanta performed a more elaborate, 2-tier PCR test. 'The results\nwere inconclusive,' said Dr. Amanda Cohn, a medical epidemiologist\nfor the federal agency.\nIt turned out that one part of the PCR test suggested the presence of\nthe pertussis bacterium, while the other part didn't. The state lab,\nwhich initially performed just one phase of the PCR test, decided to\nconduct the 2nd phase and, like the federal lab, came back with\nnegative results on that 2nd phase.\n'One of our group's highest priorities at [CDC] is working out better\nlaboratory diagnostics for pertussis,' Cohn said. 'The laboratory\ndiagnostics for pertussis are difficult. It's a priority for us to\nfind reliable, rapid, standardized testing for pertussis.'\nThe federal agency and Massachusetts health authorities continue to\nwork with Children's Hospital to ascertain what made the 36 adults\nand 2 children ill. There are competing theories, ranging from a cold\nvirus to a bacterial relative of pertussis to the virus that causes\nthe condition commonly known as walking pneumonia. It's unlikely that\nthe causes of all the respiratory illnesses will ever be fully known.\n'What I can say is that whatever it was, it went away,' Barry said.\n'And that's the good news.'\n[Byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Polymerase chain reaction relies on amplification of a specific DNA\nsegment analogous to a primer used to anneal it to. If the particular\nstrain involved here was not analogous to one of the primers used,\nthen the PCR may not be positive. It is unclear, indeed, whether the\ncluster was or was not pertussis.\nDespite this, clusters of pertussis do occur in adults, and\nvaccination of hospital employees, especially those with pediatric\npatient contact, does occur, and vaccination of such cohorts with the\nacellular pertussis vaccine seems more than reasonable. The following\nis from the initial posting of this thread:\n'The most recent CDC statement regarding adult immunization (CDC:\nRecommended Adult Immunization Schedule --- United States, October\n2006 - September 2007 MMWR 2006;55; Q1-Q4\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5540-Immunizationa1.htm>)\nstates this about the tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis vaccine in adults:\n'Adults with uncertain histories of a complete primary vaccination\nseries with diphtheria and tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines should\nbegin or complete a primary vaccination series. A primary series for\nadults is 3 doses; administer the 1st 2 doses at least 4 weeks apart\nand the 3rd dose 6-12 months after the 2nd.\n'Administer a booster dose to adults who have completed a primary\nseries and if the last vaccination was received more than 10 years\npreviously. Tdap or tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine may be used;\nTdap should replace a single dose of Td for adults aged less than 65\nyears who have not previously received a dose of Tdap (either in the\nprimary series, as a booster, or for wound management).\n'Only one of 2 Tdap products (Adacel [Sanofi Pasteur, Swiftwater,\nPennsylvania]) is licensed for use in adults. If the person is\npregnant and received the last Td vaccination greater than 10 years\npreviously, administer Td during the 2nd or 3rd trimester; if the\nperson received the last Td vaccination in less than 10 years,\nadminister Tdap during the immediate postpartum period. A onetime\nadministration of one dose of Tdap with an interval as short as 2\nyears from a previous Td vaccination is recommended for postpartum\nwomen, close contacts of infants aged <12 months, and all health-care\nworkers with direct patient contact. In certain situations, Td can be\ndeferred during pregnancy and Tdap substituted in the immediate\npostpartum period, or Tdap can be given instead of Td to a pregnant\nwoman after an informed discussion with the woman.'\n'Immunization of adolescents and adults with an acellular pertussis\nvaccine booster as part of an adult tetanus/diphtheria vaccination\nhas been recommended for more than a year. It is unclear how much\nadherence to this recommendation is occurring. With an increased risk\nof both acquiring pertussis and spreading it to susceptible infants,\nwould it not be reasonable to require a Tdap booster for each\nhospital employee to assure immunity? Similar requirements are in\nplace for other childhood diseases, such as measles and rubella.'\nA similar article was submitted by Brent Barrett. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The following\nis from the initial posting of this thread:\n'The most recent CDC statement regarding adult immunization (CDC:\nRecommended Adult Immunization Schedule --- United States, October\n2006 - September 2007 MMWR 2006;55; Q1-Q4\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5540-Immunizationa1.htm>)\n >\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/yourlife/health/diseases/articles/2006/12/26/coughing_cases_mystify_specialists/>\n\nIt seemed straightforward enough at first: A 19-month-old boy being\ntreated at Children's Hospital Boston had classic symptoms of\nwhooping cough, and a laboratory test confirmed he had the disease.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n People think laboratory tests are 100 percent accurate: If they're\npositive, they're positive; if they're negative, they're negative,'\nsaid David Warshauer, a top official at the Wisconsin State\nLaboratory of Hygiene, which oversaw testing during a pertussis\noutbreak in 2003 and 2004 that spawned more than 5000 cases. ' Children's [Hospital], much like the local health department, really\nrelies on laboratory tests to guide us on what the diagnosis is,\nespecially illnesses that can look like a lot of different things,'\nsaid Dr. Anita Barry, top disease tracker at the Boston Public Health\nCommission. ' If the person is\npregnant and received the last Td vaccination greater than 10 years\npreviously, administer Td during the 2nd or 3rd trimester; if the\nperson received the last Td vaccination in less than 10 years,\nadminister Tdap during the immediate postpartum period. A onetime\nadministration of one dose of Tdap with an interval as short as 2\nyears from a previous Td vaccination is recommended for postpartum\nwomen, close contacts of infants aged <12 months, and all health-care\nworkers with direct patient contact. states this about the tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis vaccine in adults:\n'Adults with uncertain histories of a complete primary vaccination\nseries with diphtheria and tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines should\nbegin or complete a primary vaccination series. Despite this, clusters of pertussis do occur in adults, and\nvaccination of hospital employees, especially those with pediatric\npatient contact, does occur, and vaccination of such cohorts with the\nacellular pertussis vaccine seems more than reasonable. While symptoms can provide strong clues about whether a patient has\nthe disease, laboratory tests provide far more robust proof,\nespecially for pertussis, with early symptoms similar to the common\ncold. But now, more than 3 months after the child fell ill, disease\ninvestigators are no longer certain that the respiratory illnesses\nthat struck workers and another patient at Children's Hospital were\ncaused by whooping cough, also known as pertussis. The state lab,\nwhich initially performed just one phase of the PCR test, decided to\nconduct the 2nd phase and, like the federal lab, came back with\nnegative results on that 2nd phase. Tdap or tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine may be used;\nTdap should replace a single dose of Td for adults aged less than 65\nyears who have not previously received a dose of Tdap (either in the\nprimary series, as a booster, or for wound management). \n'Immunization of adolescents and adults with an acellular pertussis\nvaccine booster as part of an adult tetanus/diphtheria vaccination\nhas been recommended for more than a year. Then, from late September through early November 2006, 3 dozen\nhospital employees in wards where the child had been treated also\ndeveloped coughs and other symptoms suggesting that they too were\nstricken with the disease. PCR has emerged in the past decade as a favorite testing\ntechnology in state labs across the nation, including the\nMassachusetts State Laboratory Institute in Jamaica Plain, in large\npart because it's easier and faster than culturing. With an increased risk\nof both acquiring pertussis and spreading it to susceptible infants,\nwould it not be reasonable to require a Tdap booster for each\nhospital employee to assure immunity? One is a laboratory classic called\nculturing: Material from the patient is placed in a dish with a\ngrowth medium that will allow the bacterium to reproduce if it's\npresent. In certain situations, Td can be\ndeferred during pregnancy and Tdap substituted in the immediate\npostpartum period, or Tdap can be given instead of Td to a pregnant\nwoman after an informed discussion with the woman.' [Byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< A primary series for\nadults is 3 doses; administer the 1st 2 doses at least 4 weeks apart\nand the 3rd dose 6-12 months after the 2nd. Still, no one can say for sure what made the workers sick -- they all\nrecovered -- and disease specialists can't definitively rule out\npertussis as the cause. Administer a booster dose to adults who have completed a primary\nseries and if the last vaccination was received more than 10 years\npreviously. The cluster of illnesses is proving so intriguing that federal\ndisease sleuths and even a lab in Canada have joined specialists from\nBoston and the state who are trying to crack the mystery. The mystery began 18 Sep 2006, when a toddler came down with symptoms\nof whooping cough, typically heralded by a runny nose, sneezing,\nslight fever, and mild cough. The federal agency and Massachusetts health authorities continue to\nwork with Children's Hospital to ascertain what made the 36 adults\nand 2 children ill. There are competing theories, ranging from a cold\nvirus to a bacterial relative of pertussis to the virus that causes\nthe condition commonly known as walking pneumonia. You think you know what's going on,' said Dr. Manisha Patel, a\ndisease investigator at the CDC, 'and you want to make sure it\ndoesn't spread to the most vulnerable patients in the hospital.' People generally don't like it\nmuch when you do that,' said Dr. Alfred DeMaria, director of\ncommunicable disease control for the state. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-01-02 00:00:00", "2006-09-25 00:00:00", "2006-09-18 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jamaica Plain", "country": "Jamaica"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4229", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4229", "date": "2006-11-02 00:00:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, HOSPITAL EMPLOYEES - USA (MASSACHUSETTS)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 2 Nov 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2006/11/02/whooping_cough_outbreak_strikes_16_at_childrens/>\n\nAt least 1 young patient and 15 staff members at Children's Hospital\nBoston have been diagnosed with whooping cough [pertussis? - Mod.LL],\nthe hospital and public health authorities reported yesterday, 1 Nov\n2006, marking the 2nd time in 2 months that a Massachusetts hospital\nhas faced an outbreak of the infectious disease.\nSixty other staff members at Children's have symptoms of the\nbacterial illness and are undergoing blood tests to determine whether\nthey have the condition, said Dr. Anita Barry, from the Boston Public\nHealth Commission. Those workers were sent home until they can finish\na 5-day course of the antibiotic azithromycin, said Dr. Thomas\nSandora, an epidemiologist at Children's.\nLetters have been sent to the parents of about 1000 patients who may\nhave come into contact with potentially infectious staff members,\nproviding information about the disease and directions on what to do\nif symptoms appear, Sandora said.\n'Many of those patients probably weren't exposed, but we're taking a\nvery cautious approach,' Sandora said.\nIt appeared last night that Children's did not follow the law in\nalerting local health authorities about the outbreak, which began in\nSeptember 2006, in a timely fashion. State law requires that\nsuspected cases of many infectious diseases, including whooping\ncough, be reported to the local board of health within 24 hours of\nbeing identified, a measure designed to contain dangerous outbreaks.\nHospital and city investigators said they believe the outbreak began\nafter a 19-month-old boy was admitted to the hospital 21 Sep 2006\nwith a fever, cough, and wheezing. Initially, the child was\ndiagnosed with a disease called respiratory syncytial virus, but\nbecause of worsening symptoms, he was sent to intensive care and\nsubsequently diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as\npertussis. From that case, the outbreak radiated outward, infecting\nnurses, clinical assistants, and administrative staff members,\nSandora said. The toddler has recovered and none of the hospital\nworkers became seriously ill, he added.\nAt St. Vincent Hospital in Worcester (MA), an outbreak in September\n2006 infected 30 staff members. Officials said they believe a\ngastrointestinal surgeon who is a military reservist contracted the\ndisease while on duty and unknowingly carried it into the hospital.\nDr. Katrina Kretsinger, medical epidemiologist at the CDC, said one\nCanadian study had shown that healthcare workers are 1.7 times more\nlikely than the general public to suffer from whooping cough, an\nincrease attributed to their contact with infected\npatients. Hospital-based outbreaks, she said, 'are fairly common,\nand they're quite disruptive when they do occur because of the risk\nof transmitting pertussis to vulnerable patients in the hospital.'\nWhooping cough is a highly infectious bacterial disease transmitted\nby coughing and sneezing. Typically, the disease arrives with\nsymptoms similar to those of the common cold. 'But then,' Barry said,\n'patients move into the coughing phase, with spasms of coughing.'\nAt its worst, a rattling, rib-cracking cough can linger for months\nand cause patients to lose sleep and weight. Studies have shown that\n62 percent of adults with pertussis are still coughing 3 months after\nsymptoms appear.\nWhile symptoms can be persistent, the disease rarely kills adults.\nBut it can be deadly in children under 6 months for 2 pivotal\nreasons: they have yet to receive a full course of vaccines against\nthe disease, and their immature immune systems may not be sufficient\nto respond to the infection.\nThe number of infants dying from the disease, while still small, has\nbeen increasing in recent years, Kretsinger said, with 54 deaths\nbetween 1980 and 1989, but 92 deaths in the first half of this decade.\nChildren today routinely get a series of 5 vaccinations against\npertussis. The vaccine's effectiveness wanes within 5-10 years,\nleaving recipients vulnerable to infection. In 2005, US health\nregulators approved the 1st pertussis booster shot for adults and\nadolescents, a lower dose than what is given to infants and, thus,\nless likely to cause adverse effects.\n'If we could just get that shot into everybody, we wouldn't be having\nthese problems,' said Dr. Alfred DeMaria, the state's director of\ncommunicable disease control.\n[Byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\nBrent Barrett\nMicrobiologist\nIndianapolis, IN\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[The most recent CDC statement regarding adult immunization (CDC:\nRecommended Adult Immunization Schedule --- United States, October\n2006--September 2007 MMWR 2006;55; Q1-Q4)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5540-Immunizationa1.htm>\nstates this about the tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis vaccine in adults:\n'Adults with uncertain histories of a complete primary\nvaccination series with diphtheria and tetanus toxoid-containing\nvaccines should begin or complete a primary vaccination series. A\nprimary series for adults is 3 doses; administer the first 2 doses at\nleast 4 weeks apart and the third dose 6-12 months after the second.\nAdminister a booster dose to adults who have completed a primary\nseries and if the last vaccination was received greater 10 years\npreviously. Tdap or tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine may be used;\nTdap should replace a single dose of Td for adults aged less than 65\nyears who have not previously received a dose of Tdap (either in the\nprimary series, as a booster, or for wound management).\nOnly 1 of 2 Tdap products (Adacel [Sanofi Pasteur, Swiftwater,\nPennsylvania]) is licensed for use in adults. If the person is\npregnant and received the last Td vaccination greater than 10 years\npreviously, administer Td during the second or third trimester; if\nthe person received the last Td vaccination in less than 10 years,\nadminister Tdap during the immediate postpartum period. A 1 time\nadministration of 1 dose of Tdap with an interval as short as 2 years\nfrom a previous Td vaccination is recommended for postpartum women,\nclose contacts of infants aged <12 months, and all health-care\nworkers with direct patient contact. In certain situations, Td can be\ndeferred during pregnancy and Tdap substituted in the immediate\npostpartum period, or Tdap can be given instead of Td to a pregnant\nwoman after an informed discussion with the woman.'\nImmunization of adolescents and adults with an acellular pertussis\nvaccine booster as part of an adult tetanus/diphtheria vaccination\nhas been recommended for more than a year. It is unclear how much\nadherence to this recommendation is occurring. With an increased\nrisk of both acquiring pertussis and spreading it to susceptible\ninfants, would it not be reasonable to require a Tdap booster for\neach hospital employee to assure immunity? Similar requirements are\nin place for other childhood diseases such as measles and rubella. -\nMods.LL/MPP]", "summary": "Recommended Adult Immunization Schedule --- United States, October\n2006--September 2007 MMWR 2006;55; Q1-Q4)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5540-Immunizationa1.htm>\nstates this about the tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis vaccine in adults:\n'Adults with uncertain histories of a complete primary\nvaccination series with diphtheria and tetanus toxoid-containing\nvaccines should begin or complete a primary vaccination series. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A 1 time\nadministration of 1 dose of Tdap with an interval as short as 2 years\nfrom a previous Td vaccination is recommended for postpartum women,\nclose contacts of infants aged <12 months, and all health-care\nworkers with direct patient contact. If the person is\npregnant and received the last Td vaccination greater than 10 years\npreviously, administer Td during the second or third trimester; if\nthe person received the last Td vaccination in less than 10 years,\nadminister Tdap during the immediate postpartum period. Initially, the child was\ndiagnosed with a disease called respiratory syncytial virus, but\nbecause of worsening symptoms, he was sent to intensive care and\nsubsequently diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as\npertussis. Brent Barrett\nMicrobiologist\nIndianapolis, IN\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n LL],\nthe hospital and public health authorities reported yesterday, 1 Nov\n2006, marking the 2nd time in 2 months that a Massachusetts hospital\nhas faced an outbreak of the infectious disease. Tdap or tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine may be used;\nTdap should replace a single dose of Td for adults aged less than 65\nyears who have not previously received a dose of Tdap (either in the\nprimary series, as a booster, or for wound management). Letters have been sent to the parents of about 1000 patients who may\nhave come into contact with potentially infectious staff members,\nproviding information about the disease and directions on what to do\nif symptoms appear, Sandora said. In 2005, US health\nregulators approved the 1st pertussis booster shot for adults and\nadolescents, a lower dose than what is given to infants and, thus,\nless likely to cause adverse effects. Sixty other staff members at Children's have symptoms of the\nbacterial illness and are undergoing blood tests to determine whether\nthey have the condition, said Dr. Anita Barry, from the Boston Public\nHealth Commission. State law requires that\nsuspected cases of many infectious diseases, including whooping\ncough, be reported to the local board of health within 24 hours of\nbeing identified, a measure designed to contain dangerous outbreaks. Canadian study had shown that healthcare workers are 1.7 times more\nlikely than the general public to suffer from whooping cough, an\nincrease attributed to their contact with infected\npatients. But it can be deadly in children under 6 months for 2 pivotal\nreasons: they have yet to receive a full course of vaccines against\nthe disease, and their immature immune systems may not be sufficient\nto respond to the infection. With an increased\nrisk of both acquiring pertussis and spreading it to susceptible\ninfants, would it not be reasonable to require a Tdap booster for\neach hospital employee to assure immunity? In certain situations, Td can be\ndeferred during pregnancy and Tdap substituted in the immediate\npostpartum period, or Tdap can be given instead of Td to a pregnant\nwoman after an informed discussion with the woman.' Administer a booster dose to adults who have completed a primary\nseries and if the last vaccination was received greater 10 years\npreviously. Hospital and city investigators said they believe the outbreak began\nafter a 19-month-old boy was admitted to the hospital 21 Sep 2006\nwith a fever, cough, and wheezing. A\nprimary series for adults is 3 doses; administer the first 2 doses at\nleast 4 weeks apart and the third dose 6-12 months after the second. Hospital-based outbreaks, she said, 'are fairly common,\nand they're quite disruptive when they do occur because of the risk\nof transmitting pertussis to vulnerable patients in the hospital.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-21 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indianapolis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4444", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4444", "date": "2006-11-09 00:00:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, HOSPITAL EMPLOYEES - USA (MASSACHUSETTS)(02)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 8 Nov 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2006/11/08/8_more_childrens_workers_diagnosed_with_whooping_cough/>\n\n8 more staff members at Children's Hospital Boston have tested\npositive for whooping cough, bringing to 33 the number of workers\ninfected, city health authorities reported yesterday, 7 Nov 2006.\nThe outbreak at Children's Hospital is the largest in recent memory\nat a Boston healthcare facility, said Dr. Anita Barry, Boston's\ndirector of communicable disease control. With the latest\nconfirmatory lab results, the Children's outbreak has now eclipsed a\ncluster of cases in September 2006 at St. Vincent Hospital in\nWorcester [MA], where 30 staff members were diagnosed with the highly\ninfectious bacterial disease, also known as pertussis.\nAccording to the state Department of Public Health, 15 to 35\nhealthcare workers statewide come down with the disease during a typical year.\nDisease investigators have said they believe whooping cough was\ncarried into Children's Hospital by a 19-month-old patient. They\ncontinue to investigate whether a 3-year-old girl who has the illness\ncontracted it at the hospital or before she arrived there.\nBarry said the 8 additional cases reported yesterday do not reflect\nrecent infections. Instead, she said, most of those staff members\nbegan displaying symptoms in mid-October 2006. So far, no hospital\nworkers or patients have faced life-threatening complications as a\nresult of the outbreak.\nMichelle Davis, a Children's spokeswoman, said the hospital is\ncontinuing to encourage staff members who show any signs of the\ndisease, which in its earliest phase mimics the common cold, to come\nforward. Workers with symptoms are sent home for 5 days and told to\ntake antibiotics before they can return to their jobs. Yesterday, 138\nstaff members were still furloughed.\n'It's certainly putting pressure on the system, but we're meeting the\nneeds' of patients, Davis said.\n[Byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\nBrent Barrett\nIndianapolis, IN\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[A confirmative diagnosis of pertussis is not necessarily rapid,\nthereby the delay in more cases being reported. This large cluster\nunderscores, in my mind, the need for consideration of mandatory\nacellular pertussis booster immunization of hospital employees,\nespecially those involved with small children who are not fully\nimmunized and who are at risk for the complications of infection with\n_Bordetella pertussis_. ProMED thanks Brent Barrett for this post. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "With the latest\nconfirmatory lab results, the Children's outbreak has now eclipsed a\ncluster of cases in September 2006 at St. Vincent Hospital in\nWorcester [MA], where 30 staff members were diagnosed with the highly\ninfectious bacterial disease, also known as pertussis.\n This large cluster\nunderscores, in my mind, the need for consideration of mandatory\nacellular pertussis booster immunization of hospital employees,\nespecially those involved with small children who are not fully\nimmunized and who are at risk for the complications of infection with\n_ A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2006/11/08/8_more_childrens_workers_diagnosed_with_whooping_cough/>\n\n8 more staff members at Children's Hospital Boston have tested\npositive for whooping cough, bringing to 33 the number of workers\ninfected, city health authorities reported yesterday, 7 Nov 2006. Michelle Davis, a Children's spokeswoman, said the hospital is\ncontinuing to encourage staff members who show any signs of the\ndisease, which in its earliest phase mimics the common cold, to come\nforward. So far, no hospital\nworkers or patients have faced life-threatening complications as a\nresult of the outbreak.\n Brent Barrett\nIndianapolis, IN\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n The outbreak at Children's Hospital is the largest in recent memory\nat a Boston healthcare facility, said Dr. Anita Barry, Boston's\ndirector of communicable disease control. They\ncontinue to investigate whether a 3-year-old girl who has the illness\ncontracted it at the hospital or before she arrived there.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-11-07 00:00:00", "2006-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boston", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209266", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209266", "date": "2006-02-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (ONTARIO)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 9 Feb 2006\nFrom: Nita Madhav <nmadhav@alum.emory.edu>\nSource: National Post, Canada [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/story.html?id=c4c90c57-d55a-4804-87ad-4f7de422ff03&k=31870>\n\nToronto is in the grip of the worst whooping cough outbreak to hit\nthe city in at least a dozen years, public health authorities\nconfirmed yesterday, 8 Feb 2006.\n'We're seeing about a 5-fold increase in the number of cases being\nreported to us,' said Rita Shahin, a doctor with Toronto Public\nHealth.\nToronto has recorded 164 cases of the highly contagious disease since\n1 Nov 2005, nearly as many as it logged in all of 2003, 2004 and the\nrest of 2005 combined. 31 cases were reported in 2003, 88 in 2004 and\n62 in the first 10 months of 2005.\nOf the past 12 years, only 1994 saw more than 164 cases of whooping\ncough. There were 172 cases that year -- 8 more in 12 months than\nToronto has logged in 3 months this winter.\nMost of those diagnosed have been children under the age of 4, making\nthe mini-epidemic a tough challenge for city daycares. 'Dealing with\nthis has been a full-time job since we got back from the holidays,'\nsaid preschool supervisor Georgia Bowen. The supervisor at the\nCreative Preschool of East Toronto on St. Matthews Road said that in\nher 27 years in the daycare business, she had never seen an outbreak\nof whooping cough like the one that has torn through her Riverdale\npreschool this winter.\nSince Dec 2005, 9 children have tested positive for the respiratory\nillness; as of 25 Jan 2006 all 104 of her tiny charges were either on\nantibiotics to prevent the spread of the disease or, if their parents\nobjected to that, barred from the preschool for 21 days.\nMiriam Mifshud of Ms. Miriam's Nursery School and Play Centre on\nDanforth Avenue also said she was 'absolutely stunned' by the 7 cases\ndiagnosed at her daycare this winter. 'In 3 or 4 decades of\nteaching, I just haven't seen this,' she said. At both Creative\nPreschool and Ms. Miriam's, every child had been vaccinated.\nDr. Shahin said it is difficult to pinpoint what caused the unusual\nspike in pertussis, commonly called the whooping cough because of the\nhigh-pitched wheezing noise sufferers make at the end of its\ncharacteristic prolonged coughing fits.\n'A lot of the infectious diseases tend to peak certain years and then\ngo back down again, and we don't really know what the cause is,' said\nDr. Shahin. 'Sometimes it may be that the vaccine might be a little\nless effective.'\nDr. Shahin said the public health authority is reviewing all 164\ncases to determine if all those afflicted had received the full 5\ndoses of the whooping cough vaccine, 4 of which should be given\nbefore a child is 18 months old. 'Maybe some of them weren't\nimmunized completely,' Dr. Shahin said. The outbreak appears to be\nlimited to Toronto.\n'We're aware of the Toronto outbreak, but we haven't heard of any\nothers elsewhere in Canada,' said Michael Tansey, a spokesman for the\nPublic Health Agency of Canada.\nOf the 164 Torontonians diagnosed in the past 3 months, 44 were\nchildren younger than 1, 90 were children between the ages of 1 and\n4, and the rest were older than 4. While cases have popped up all\nover the city, there is a large concentration in its eastern and\nsouthern portions.\nMost of the children infected in Toronto have displayed only mild\nsymptoms akin to a cough or cold, Dr. Shahin said. Still, for\naffected parents, the outbreak has caused concern and headaches.\n[Byline: Kelly Patrick]\n--\nNita Madhav, MSPH\nResearch Analyst\nAIR Worldwide\nBoston, MA, USA\n<nmadhav@alum.emory.edu>\n[The reason for this impressive cluster of cases of pertussis in\nOntario is as yet unclear, but at least some of the cases occurred in\nfully immunized children. It is not stated in the posting what the\nrange of symptoms were and how many of the cases were diagnosed\nsolely on culture with no or little illness. Indeed, the effect of\nimmunization on the overall carriage rate of _Bordetella pertussis_\nin the population (<http://www.who.int/vaccines/en/pertussis.shtml>)\nmay be summarized as 'the possible effect of the respective vaccines\non pharyngeal colonization of _B. pertussis_ and on mild pertussis\namong adolescents and adults needs to be better established.'\nIf the affected cohort as a whole had been adequately immunized, it\nis possible that a strain of the organism has developed that may be\nescaping the vaccine-induced immunity, but no clear data support this\nsupposition.\nHowever, it is clear that immunity to pertussis wanes with time.\nThis is true in both the older whole cell killed vaccine and the\nnewer acellular toxoid product (which is less reactogenic but no more\nimmunogenic). Susceptibility increases during adolescent years with\nthe production of infectious cases with 'non-whoop' pertussis\nmanifesting as a chronic cough.\nTo deal with infected adolescents functioning as a reservoir to\nunimmunized children, the following are the newest recommendations\nfor the expanded use of pertussis vaccine in adolescents in the USA\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5451-Immunizationa1.htm>:\n'A new tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular\npertussis vaccine for adolescents (Tdap adolescent preparation [a\nsmall letter is used for diphtheria and pertussis in this product,\nsince the amount of antigen is lower than the pediatric formulation -\nMod.LL]) was approved by the USA FDA on 5 May 2005, for use in the\nUSA. Tdap is recommended for adolescents aged 11-12 years who have\ncompleted the recommended childhood diphtheria and tetanus toxoids\nand pertussis/diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and acellular pertusis\n(DTP/DTaP) vaccination series and have not received a tetanus and\ndiphtheria toxoids (Td) booster dose. Adolescents aged 13 -18 years\nwho missed the age 11-12-year Td/Tdap booster dose should also\nreceive a single dose of Tdap if they have completed the recommended\nchildhood DTP/DTaP vaccination series. Subsequent Td boosters are\nrecommended every 10 years. In the future, acellular pertussis\nimmunization may be used in adults as well.'\nIn assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children,\nsome researchers noted that 'Reported cases and outbreaks in older\nchildren and young adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced\nprotection than seen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA,\nGolden GA., Karzon, DT: Report of the Task Force on Pertussis and\nPertussis Immunization - 1988, Pediatrics, 1988; 81 (June Suppl):\n955). The duration of protection has varied in several studies,\ndepending on the epidemiological setting, i.e., prevalence of natural\ndisease as well as the vaccine product used. A study in Michigan\nshowed an efficacy of 80 percent 3 years after the last dose, 50\npercent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years.\nBreakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.'\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "To deal with infected adolescents functioning as a reservoir to\nunimmunized children, the following are the newest recommendations\nfor the expanded use of pertussis vaccine in adolescents in the USA\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5451-Immunizationa1.htm>:\n'A new tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular\npertussis vaccine for adolescents (Tdap adolescent preparation [a\nsmall letter is used for diphtheria and pertussis in this product,\nsince the amount of antigen is lower than the pediatric formulation - In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children,\nsome researchers noted that 'Reported cases and outbreaks in older\nchildren and young adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced\nprotection than seen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA,\nGolden GA., Karzon, DT: Report of the Task Force on Pertussis and\nPertussis Immunization - 1988, Pediatrics, 1988; 81 (June Suppl):\n955). Indeed, the effect of\nimmunization on the overall carriage rate of _Bordetella pertussis_\nin the population (<http://www.who.int/vaccines/en/pertussis.shtml>)\nmay be summarized as 'the possible effect of the respective vaccines\non pharyngeal colonization of _B. pertussis_ and on mild pertussis\namong adolescents and adults needs to be better established.' The supervisor at the\nCreative Preschool of East Toronto on St. Matthews Road said that in\nher 27 years in the daycare business, she had never seen an outbreak\nof whooping cough like the one that has torn through her Riverdale\npreschool this winter.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nDr. Shahin said the public health authority is reviewing all 164\ncases to determine if all those afflicted had received the full 5\ndoses of the whooping cough vaccine, 4 of which should be given\nbefore a child is 18 months old. ' Research Analyst\nAIR Worldwide\nBoston, MA, USA\n<nmadhav@alum.emory.edu>\n Tdap is recommended for adolescents aged 11-12 years who have\ncompleted the recommended childhood diphtheria and tetanus toxoids\nand pertussis/diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and acellular pertusis\n Adolescents aged 13 -18 years\nwho missed the age 11-12-year Td/Tdap booster dose should also\nreceive a single dose of Tdap if they have completed the recommended\nchildhood DTP/DTaP vaccination series. Dr. Shahin said it is difficult to pinpoint what caused the unusual\nspike in pertussis, commonly called the whooping cough because of the\nhigh-pitched wheezing noise sufferers make at the end of its\ncharacteristic prolonged coughing fits. Source: National Post, Canada [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/story.html?id=c4c90c57-d55a-4804-87ad-4f7de422ff03&k=31870>\n\nToronto is in the grip of the worst whooping cough outbreak to hit\nthe city in at least a dozen years, public health authorities\nconfirmed yesterday, 8 Feb 2006. Since Dec 2005, 9 children have tested positive for the respiratory\nillness; as of 25 Jan 2006 all 104 of her tiny charges were either on\nantibiotics to prevent the spread of the disease or, if their parents\nobjected to that, barred from the preschool for 21 days. \n'A lot of the infectious diseases tend to peak certain years and then\ngo back down again, and we don't really know what the cause is,' said\nDr. Shahin. ' If the affected cohort as a whole had been adequately immunized, it\nis possible that a strain of the organism has developed that may be\nescaping the vaccine-induced immunity, but no clear data support this\nsupposition. [Byline: Kelly Patrick]\n--\nNita Madhav, MSPH\n A study in Michigan\nshowed an efficacy of 80 percent 3 years after the last dose, 50\npercent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-12-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-02-09 00:00:00", "2005-05-05 00:00:00", "2006-01-25 00:00:00", "2006-02-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Karzon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207242", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207242", "date": "2005-01-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, FATAL - AFGHANISTAN (DAYKUNDI)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 24 Jan 2005\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez <ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: Yahoo News & AFP [edited]\n<http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/afp/20050124/hl_afp/afghanistanunhealth_050124164903>\n\nDoctors airlifted to help sick Afghan children\n----------------------------------------------\nA group of Afghan and UN doctors flew into central Afghanistan to offer\nhelp after 25 children died of whooping cough [pertussis - Mod.LL],\ngovernment and USA military officials said.\nThe 10 doctors, equipped with antimicrobial agents for 2000 people and\nvaccinations for 2500, were taken by a USA military helicopter to the Gizab\ndistrict of Daykundi province, some 300 kilometers (188 miles) south of Kabul.\nAll roads to the district in Afghanistan's remote central highlands have\nbeen blocked by heavy snow, and reports of the deaths reached the capital\nlast week.\n'25 children died of whooping cough in Gizab in the course of the past\nweek,' Afghan health minister Sayed Mohammed Amin Fatemi said on Sun, 23\nJan 2005.\nUSA military spokesman Major Mark McCann said they flew down the team from\nthe Afghan health ministry and the WHO in a USA-led coalition aircraft.\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that can cause weeks of severe\ncoughing. Every year it kills more than 300 000 children around the world,\naccording to WHO figures, but patients can be treated with antimicrobial\nagents.\nAfghanistan's child mortality rate is one of the world's highest, the WHO\nsays. More than 250 out of 1000 children die before the age of 5 in\nAfghanistan, while in France it is 5 out of 1000.\nThere were outbreaks of whooping cough, measles and some other epidemic\ndiseases in northeastern and southern provinces of Afghanistan in 2004 and\n2003.\n--\nAlfonso Rodriguez, M.D.\n<ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\n[The scope of this outbreak is not clear. Most pertussis-associated deaths\nare in quite young, unimmunized children who are in contact with older\nchildren or young adults with milder illness. Pertussis mortality can be\nminimized not only by immunization with trivalent vaccine against tetanus,\ndiphtheria, and pertussis, but also by early antimicrobial intervention.\nLarge populations of susceptible people in the developing world is the\ncause of large outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n'25 children died of whooping cough in Gizab in the course of the past\nweek,' Afghan health minister Sayed Mohammed Amin Fatemi said on Sun, 23\n \nAlfonso Rodriguez, M.D.\n<ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\n Most pertussis-associated deaths\nare in quite young, unimmunized children who are in contact with older\nchildren or young adults with milder illness. The 10 doctors, equipped with antimicrobial agents for 2000 people and\nvaccinations for 2500, were taken by a USA military helicopter to the Gizab\ndistrict of Daykundi province, some 300 kilometers (188 miles) south of Kabul. Every year it kills more than 300 000 children around the world,\naccording to WHO figures, but patients can be treated with antimicrobial\nagents. Pertussis mortality can be\nminimized not only by immunization with trivalent vaccine against tetanus,\ndiphtheria, and pertussis, but also by early antimicrobial intervention. All roads to the district in Afghanistan's remote central highlands have\nbeen blocked by heavy snow, and reports of the deaths reached the capital\nlast week. There were outbreaks of whooping cough, measles and some other epidemic\ndiseases in northeastern and southern provinces of Afghanistan in 2004 and\n2003. Source: Yahoo News & AFP [edited]\n<http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/afp/20050124/hl_afp/afghanistanunhealth_050124164903>\n\nDoctors airlifted to help sick Afghan children\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-01-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "Afghanistan"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Kabul", "country": "Afghanistan"}, {"location": "Sun", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1722", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1722", "date": "2006-06-12 00:00:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - PAPUA NEW GUINEA (EAST SEPIK)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 9 Jun 2006\nFrom: Akira Goto <dolphin@mail.ne.jp>\nSource: The National.com [edited]\n<http://www.thenational.com.pg/060906/nation4.htm>\n\nThe outbreak of whooping cough in East Sepik province is stretching the\nlimited resources of a medical team sent to the affected areas, and there\nare fears that the situation is on the verge of getting out of control.\nAccording to the latest reports, the situation is worsening by the day, as\nit sweeps through the Sepik plains into Angoram district.\nThe National reported last Wed 7 Jun 2006 that 16 children have already\ndied, and the toll is expected to rise further. Four new cases had been\ndetected at Pagwi station, while the medical team sent to help has just\nabout exhausted every available resource to prevent further spread, and the\ndeath toll rising.\nThe work load on the whooping cough team has now been compounded, the\nhelicopter hired to ferry health workers and drugs into inaccessible areas\nof central Sepik having been pulled back by the management of Niugini\nHelicopters until payments are made.\nAn emergency provincial health task force meeting was held in Wewak to\ndecide the best methods of tackling the cough epidemic. They resolved to\nimmunize every child in the Sepik plains against the disease.\nHealth Minister Sir Peter Barter has ordered the Health Department to send\na team to investigate the situation. 'The provincial team has been in the\narea for the past few weeks immunizing children and are attempting to curb\nthe spread of the disease.' Sir Peter said the situation seemed under\ncontrol, although 'we are anxious to ensure it does not spread.'\nA health extension officer in East Sepik said they had immunization\nprograms in place, but 'how can one access long stretches of savannah\ngrassland with tons of vaccines, especially on foot.'\n[Byline: Reuben Kalaung]\n--\nAkira Goto\n<dolphin@mail.ne.jp>\n[Whooping cough (pertussis) causes a classical paroxysmal coughing period\nduring a single expiration preceding a 'whoop' (a massive inspiration, with\nair forced against a partially narrowing glottis), especially suggestive in\nan un-immunized population. Most deaths seem to occur in young (especially\nless than one year of age) unvaccinated children.\nProMED thanks Dr. Goto for pointing us to this pertussis outbreak. A map of\nPapua New Guinea showing the location of East Sepik province can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/papua.pdf>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The work load on the whooping cough team has now been compounded, the\nhelicopter hired to ferry health workers and drugs into inaccessible areas\nof central Sepik having been pulled back by the management of Niugini\nHelicopters until payments are made.\n Source: The National.com [edited]\n<http://www.thenational.com.pg/060906/nation4.htm>\n\nThe outbreak of whooping cough in East Sepik province is stretching the\nlimited resources of a medical team sent to the affected areas, and there\nare fears that the situation is on the verge of getting out of control. [Whooping cough (pertussis) causes a classical paroxysmal coughing period\nduring a single expiration preceding a 'whoop' (a massive inspiration, with\nair forced against a partially narrowing glottis), especially suggestive in\nan un-immunized population. Four new cases had been\ndetected at Pagwi station, while the medical team sent to help has just\nabout exhausted every available resource to prevent further spread, and the\ndeath toll rising. A health extension officer in East Sepik said they had immunization\nprograms in place, but 'how can one access long stretches of savannah\ngrassland with tons of vaccines, especially on foot.' The provincial team has been in the\narea for the past few weeks immunizing children and are attempting to curb\nthe spread of the disease.' PERTUSSIS - PAPUA NEW GUINEA (EAST SEPIK)\n*******************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "Sepik", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "East Sepik", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "Angoram", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208068", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, adult vaccine - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208068", "date": "2005-06-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADULT VACCINE - USA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 10 Jun 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA.gov [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2005/ANS01361.html>\n\nFDA approves a new vaccine to help protect adults against pertussis\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe FDA today, 10 Jun 2005, approved a new vaccine for a single booster\nimmunization against pertussis (whooping cough), in combination with\ntetanus and diphtheria, for adolescents and adults 11-64 years of age. The\nvaccine will be marketed as Adacel by Aventis Pasteur Limited located in\nToronto, Canada. It is the 1st vaccine approved as a pertussis booster for\nadults. Vaccines for prevention of tetanus and diphtheria (Td vaccine) in\nadolescents and adults have been available for many years.\nThe vaccine is a Tetanus Toxoid (T), Reduced Diphtheria Toxoid (d) and\nAcellular Pertussis Vaccine (ap), Adsorbed. It contains the same components\nas DTaP vaccine indicated for infants and children, but the diphtheria\ntoxoid and one of the pertussis components are in reduced quantities.\nRecently, FDA approved a similar vaccine called Boostrix, manufactured by\nGlaxoSmithKline, for use in adolescents 10-18 years of age.\nPertussis is a highly communicable and potentially serious illness in\nadolescents and adults, and can cause prolonged cough and missed days at\nschool and work. In young infants, pertussis is more frequently severe and\ncan be fatal, particularly in those too young to be fully vaccinated. Since\n1980, the rates of reported pertussis cases have been increasing in\nadolescents and adults, as well as in young infants. Adolescents and\nadults have been implicated as the source of pertussis infection for\nsusceptible young infants, and other family members.\nThe ability of this vaccine to protect against pertussis was assessed by\ncomparing the antibody responses of adolescents and adults who received it\nwith the antibody responses of infants who had received the pediatric\nvaccine in a clinical trial. The antibody responses of the adolescents and\nadults who received a single dose of this vaccine were at least as good as\nthose observed in the infants following 3 doses of the pediatric vaccine.\nFor diphtheria and tetanus, the antibody responses following this vaccine\nwere comparable to those following immunization with a USA-licensed Td vaccine.\nIn clinical trials, the safety of this vaccine was compared to a\nUSA-licensed Td vaccine. Among adolescent recipients of this vaccine,\ninjection site pain and low-grade fever were observed more frequently than\namong those who received Td vaccine. Rates of adverse reactions were\nsimilar in adults receiving this vaccine or receiving Td vaccine.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun, Jun 12, 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Utica Observer-Dispatch [edited]\n<http://www.uticaod.com/archive/2005/06/12/news/30899.html>\n\nWhooping cough worries\n----------------------\nWith 8 cases of whooping cough diagnosed in Oneida County [NY] schools,\nparents are learning 1st-hand that immunizations against the disease may\nnot be enough to prevent onset of the illness. Concerned parents are\nlikely to hear a troubling message about immunization: officials emphasize\nthat vaccines given according to recommended guidelines are the most\neffective line of defense against contracting communicable illnesses. But\nofficials caution that the vaccine against whooping cough, also known as\npertussis, may not be 100 percent effective because its effectiveness\ndeclines with [the vaccinee's] age.\n'The current vaccine is effective and does protect for a certain amount of\ntime, up to the age of 7,' said Patrice Bogan, director of clinical\nservices for the Oneida County Health Department. 'But we know it wears off\nand the situation here proves this.'\nAccording to the state Health Department, there have been 241 cases of\nwhooping cough in Upstate New York in 2005. Whooping cough, an infectious\ndisease that causes coughing in rapid succession, has affected 14 Oneida\nCounty residents, including 8 students, jarring many parents who already\nhad their children immunized against the illness.\nBogan points to future vaccines as offering more assurance: Boostrix for\nadolescents, and Adacel for age 11-64, currently are being developed and\nshould be available within a month. Bogan is excited about targeting middle\nschool students with the new medicine.\n'We are eagerly awaiting the new vaccines,' she said.\n[Byline: Marshand Boone and Beth Seltzer]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon, 13 Jun 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org.\nSource: GazetteExtra.com [edited]\n<http://www.gazetteextra.com/whoopingcough061305.asp>\n\nWisconsin led nation in whooping cough cases in 2004\n---------------------------------------------------\nPublic health officials say better monitoring of whooping cough could be\nwhy Wisconsin had the most reports of whooping cough in 2004. The state\nhad 4048 whooping cough cases in 2004, according to the CDC. New York was\n2nd with 2059. Many states had just single- or double-digit figures.\nDan Hopfensperger, director of the Madison-based Wisconsin Immunization\nProgram, said the state is examining the way it identifies and investigates\ncases and is comparing notes with other states. He suspects other states\naren't as aggressive about diagnosing whooping cough, which would skew\nstatistics.\n'As far as discrepancies in the numbers, I don't know that our population\nis any more susceptible than the rest of the country. I think it's a lot to\ndo with case identification and case follow-up,' he said. 'If you look at\nour immunization levels as a whole in the state, we compare very favorably\nwith the rest of the country.'\nHopfensperger also said whooping cough is a cyclical disease, meaning [case\nnumbers increase and decrease] every 2 to 3 years.\nDr. Matt Hall, a Marshfield Clinic infectious disease specialist,\nattributed the state's influx of cases to new testing and more\ntesting. Wisconsin introduced a new molecular test in the last few years\nthat 'probably doubles the number of cases you can find,' Hall said. Other\nstates may not have the test yet, he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[With this approval, we may see a clear difference in the number of cases\nof pertussis once boosters in adolescents and adults come into use. How\nlong the booster in adults will protect for remains unclear. Only time\nwill tell whether the standard every-10-year booster in adults will be a\nTdap vaccine. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Whooping cough, an infectious\ndisease that causes coughing in rapid succession, has affected 14 Oneida\nCounty residents, including 8 students, jarring many parents who already\nhad their children immunized against the illness.\n The ability of this vaccine to protect against pertussis was assessed by\ncomparing the antibody responses of adolescents and adults who received it\nwith the antibody responses of infants who had received the pediatric\nvaccine in a clinical trial.
