DPT3)\n1974 / 36 767\n1975 / 37 135\n1976 / 46 605\n1977 / 82 265\n1978 / 107 979\n1979 / 98 931\n1980 / 28 631 / (1 percent)\n 1998 / 169 / (70 percent)\n1999 / 51 / (79 percent)\n2000 / 80 / (65 percent)\n2001 / 645 / (71 percent)\n--\nDr. Steve Berger\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n 1993 / 264 / (51 percent)\n1994 / 127 / (77 percent)\n1995 / 1496 / (72 percent)\n1996 / 133 / (79 percent)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1974-03-25 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1986-03-25 00:00:00", "1981-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1975-03-25 00:00:00", "1979-03-25 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00", "1976-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204691", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204691", "date": "2003-10-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN (EQUATORIA): CONFIRMED (03)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 8 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AllAfrica.com [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200310080169.html>\n\nWhooping Cough Death Toll Rises\n----------------------------\nA total of 175 children have died of a whooping cough outbreak in Kimatong\nBudi county, Equatoria state, according to NGO sources. 2 of the deaths\noccurred on Tue, 7 Oct 2003. Almost 1000 suspected cases have been\nobserved to date, with over 560 this week alone, Ed Walker of Tearfund told\nIRIN. He said 860 cases had been confirmed, with most of them under 5 years\nof age.\nA mass treatment and prevention campaign is being carried out in several\nlocations around the villages of Chawa, Kimatong, Thurunge, and Kali, with\nfamilies being treated once a member has become infected. So far 82 of\nthose infected have also tested positive for malaria, said Medair, another\nNGO.\nThere has been no NGO presence in the area for 5 years, and there is only\none health facility in operation -- with limited medicines. There are no\nlaboratory facilities. With chronic malaria (and ongoing rains bringing\nfurther mosquitoes), the almost total lack of healthcare, and no\nvaccinations, children were very likely to become infected, warned Els\nStamm, programme coordinator for Medair. Medair and Tearfund are jointly\ncarrying out treatment and health education programmes in the area.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The method of pertussis confirmation is not stated, and often whooping\ncough is a clinical diagnosis. Not surprisingly, many of the children have\nmalaria infection as well. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n With chronic malaria (and ongoing rains bringing\nfurther mosquitoes), the almost total lack of healthcare, and no\nvaccinations, children were very likely to become infected, warned Els\n A mass treatment and prevention campaign is being carried out in several\nlocations around the villages of Chawa, Kimatong, Thurunge, and Kali, with\nfamilies being treated once a member has become infected. Medair and Tearfund are jointly\ncarrying out treatment and health education programmes in the area.\n Almost 1000 suspected cases have been\nobserved to date, with over 560 this week alone, Ed Walker of Tearfund told\nIRIN. Source: AllAfrica.com [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200310080169.html>\n\nWhooping Cough Death Toll Rises\n --\nProMED-mail\n< PERTUSSIS - SUDAN (EQUATORIA): CONFIRMED (03)\n*********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chawa", "country": "Malawi"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Budi county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kimatong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207842", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207842", "date": "2005-05-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADOLESCENT VACCINE - USA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 3 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA.gov [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2005/ANS01354.html>\n\nCombination vaccine approved to protect adolescents against whooping cough\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today, 3 May 2005,\napproved the 1st combination vaccine that provides a booster immunization\nagainst pertussis (whooping cough) in combination with tetanus and\ndiphtheria for adolescents. The vaccine will be marketed as Boostrix by\nGlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Philadelphia, PA.\nPertussis is a highly communicable disease of the respiratory tract that\ncan be especially serious for infants under 1 year old, and may even be\nfatal. Pertussis can cause spells of coughing and choking that make\nbreathing difficult. The disease is generally less severe in adolescents,\nbut it is thought that they might transmit the disease to susceptible\ninfants and other family members. In the last 20 years, rates of pertussis\ninfection have been increasing in very young infants who have not received\nall their immunizations and in adolescents and adults.\nBoostrix is a tetanus toxoid (T), reduced diphtheria toxoid (d) and\nacellular pertussis vaccine (ap), adsorbed. Although booster vaccines for\nadolescents containing T and d are currently licensed and marketed for use\nin this age group, none contains a pertussis component. Boostrix has the\nsame components as Infanrix, a DTaP vaccine for infants and young children,\nbut in reduced quantities. Boostrix is indicated for use as a single\nbooster dose to adolescents 10-18 years of age.\nThe efficacy of the vaccine was measured by looking at the immune response\nto the vaccine, as measured by antibody concentrations. The response to the\nT and d components was at least as good as the response to a licensed Td\nvaccine. Boostrix also induced an antibody response to the pertussis\ncomponent of the vaccine. The response to the pertussis component was\ncompared to the response induced by a 3-dose series of Infanrix given to\ninfants in a previous study. The response of adolescents to Boostrix was\nconsidered adequate. It is not known how long immunity to pertussis will\nlast. Adolescents who received Boostrix experienced pain, redness, and\nswelling at the injection site. The frequency of redness and swelling after\nBoostrix was similar to what is expected following the administration of a\nTd vaccine. However, pain reactions at the injection site were more\nfrequent with those who received Boostrix. Other side effects included\nheadaches, fever and fatigue for a short period of time after the injection.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 10 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n-------------------------------\nThere have been 58 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Travis County\nschools in 2005. 100 more are suspected. 'In 2004, we had 300 cases\nreported in to us in the whole year, and we've already had more than 50\npercent of that number reported to us, just in the last 6 weeks,' Dr Adolfo\nValadez, of the Travis County Health Department, said.\nWhooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. The coughing can become so severe it can close off [airways],\nespecially tiny ones. But doctors say those shots wear off when kids get a\nlittle older. The greatest danger is when school-age kids catch what looks\nlike a cold and bring it home to their baby brother or sister. 'When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,' Valadez said.\nA 6 week old baby died in 2003 from whooping cough.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 6 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource Fort Madison Daily Democrat (IA) [edited]\n<http://www.dailydem.com/articles/2005/05/06/news/news1.txt>\n\nArea whooping cough numbers climb\n----------------------------------\nIt's been determined to be an outbreak, with 17 confirmed cases of whooping\ncough in Lee County since mid-April 2005. Of the 17 cases, 16 are in the\nCentral Lee Community School District.\nCentral Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families.\nReighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels.\nThis isn't the 1st time that whooping cough has hit the area. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system.\nA release of information concerning the outbreak from the Lee County Health\nDepartment did not indicate that there were incidents of whooping cough in\nFort Madison this time. Schilling said whooping cough has been in Iowa\nsince last summer [2004] but usually shows up in the fall. 'But it can\noccur at any time,' Schilling said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although ProMED-mail does not cover pertussis regularly, regular outbreaks\nof the disease have continued to occur in the USA and elsewhere despite\naggressive universal childhood immunization programs. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. This product, DTaP, has been used in the pediatric\nvaccination sequence for some time. As noted above, the Tdap variation is\nnow approved in adolescents and contains lower amounts of both diphtheria\nand pertussis components than the pediatric vaccine. Vaccination in\nadolescence should prolong immunity, but an additional booster will\nprobably be needed later in life. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today, 3 May 2005,\napproved the 1st combination vaccine that provides a booster immunization\nagainst pertussis (whooping cough) in combination with tetanus and\ndiphtheria for adolescents. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. Central Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families. Reighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels. The response to the pertussis component was\ncompared to the response induced by a 3-dose series of Infanrix given to\ninfants in a previous study. Although booster vaccines for\nadolescents containing T and d are currently licensed and marketed for use\nin this age group, none contains a pertussis component. Whooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. Source: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n In the last 20 years, rates of pertussis\ninfection have been increasing in very young infants who have not received\nall their immunizations and in adolescents and adults. When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,' Valadez said. The response to the\nT and d components was at least as good as the response to a licensed Td\nvaccine. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Pertussis is a highly communicable disease of the respiratory tract that\ncan be especially serious for infants under 1 year old, and may even be\nfatal. PERTUSSIS, ADOLESCENT VACCINE - USA\n***********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-05-06 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206609", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (multistate)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206609", "date": "2004-09-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (MULTISTATE)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Illinois\nDate: Mon, 20 Sep 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Chicago Sun-Times [edited]\n<http://www.suntimes.com/output/health/20whoop.html>\n\nWhooping cough cases on upswing\n-------------------------------\nThere's been a significant rise in the number of cases of whooping cough in\nthe Chicago area in 2004, public health administrators said on 20 Sep 2004,\nurging people to use precautions to help stem the spread of the contagious\ndisease. The outbreak has been concentrated in children 10 to 15 years old,\nages when immunity from the childhood vaccine wanes. While Chicago has\nconfirmed an increase in whooping cough cases in 2004 compared with\nprevious years, the biggest jump in numbers appears to be happening in\nsuburban Cook and the collar [surrounding - Mod.LL] counties. McHenry\nCounty, for example, averages about 8 cases annually. In 2004, it's already\nup to 143.\nHealth officials couldn't explain what's driving the increase. 'Part of it\nmay be increased surveillance,' said Dr Julie Morita, medical director of\nthe Chicago Department of Public Health's immunization program.\nAlso known as pertussis, whooping cough is a bacterial infection that\nspread easily through coughing or sneezing. It's called whooping cough\nbecause those who get it -- especially children -- sometimes make a\n'whooping' sound when inhaling. The first symptoms usually appear about a\nweek after someone is exposed. They can mimic the symptoms of a cold: runny\nnose, sneezing, a low fever and a mild cough. Whooping cough symptoms can\nprogress, though, to severe coughing fits, particularly at night, and\ncoughing attacks are sometimes followed by vomiting.\nThe potentially fatal disease tends to be most serious in infants and\npeople who have compromised immune systems. The last whooping cough death\nin Illinois was that of a 2 month old baby in 2001.\nEach child should get the pertussis vaccine at 2, 4, 6, and 15 months,\nfollowed by a booster between ages 4 and 6 years, experts say. The vaccine\nisn't recommended for anyone over 7, but a booster shot for older people is\nin development and could be available in a year, said Dr Eric Whitaker,\ndirector of the Illinois Department of Public Health.\nHe urged parents to get their children vaccinated and to practice 'plain\nold good hygiene,' including frequent handwashing and covering your mouth\nand nose while coughing or sneezing. People exposed to someone with\npertussis should see a doctor and begin antibiotic treatment immediately.\n[byline: Lori Rackl]\n******\n[2] New York\nDate: Wed, 22 Sep 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Newsday.com [edited]\n<http://www.newsday.com/news/local/wire/ny-bc-ny--whoopingcough0922sep22,0,6987317.story?coll=ny-ap-regional-wire>\n\nWhooping cough on the rise in New York\n--------------------------------------\nAfter several years under the public health radar, whooping cough is making\na comeback in New York. The number of New Yorkers affected by the highly\ncontagious respiratory illness passed the 1000 mark for the 2nd straight\nyear, prompting health officials to step up efforts to stave off the disease.\nEarlier in 2004, the state Health Department posted a bulletin to community\nhealth departments and health care providers about the recent trend. A\nsimilar alert was sent in Jun 2004 to directors and nurses at summer camps,\nwhere whooping cough outbreaks are not uncommon since children live\ntogether in tight quarters and often have direct contact with one another,\nmaking the disease easier to spread.\nNow with the fall school year underway, the focus is shifting to school\nnurses and teachers to be on the alert. New York is among 7 states that\ncurrently do not require school-age children to be vaccinated against\nwhooping cough, although most received the shot as infants as part of a\ncombination vaccine. Starting in 2005, babies born after 1 Jan would be\nrequired to be vaccinated against whooping cough before they enter school\nor day care, under a new law.\n'We are taking some unusual and strong measures here to try to deal with\nthis problem,' said Dr Gus Birkhead, the director of the Center for\nCommunity Health at the state Health Department. So far in 2004, there were\n1448 confirmed cases of whooping cough, up from 388 in 2000. The average is\n300 cases annually.\nHealth experts say a number of factors may be responsible for the spike in\nwhooping cough cases in recent years, a trend that is mirrored nationwide,\nalthough they have been unable to pinpoint an exact cause. In 2003, 229\npeople, in the newborn to age 14 category, were hospitalized with\npertussis. Hospitalization data for 2004 were incomplete.\n'Public health officials are somewhat exasperated by not being able to get\nthis quickly under control,' said Dr Lloyd Novick, the commissioner of the\nOnondaga County Health Department in central New York, whose county is\nconsidered a whooping cough hotspot. Onondaga County, which includes the\ncity of Syracuse, normally has 10 cases of pertussis annually. So far this\nyear, the county is leading the state with the highest number of cases at\n128, according to state Health Department figures.\nHistorically, the incidence of whooping cough has fluctuated, peaking every\n3 to 5 years, and health officials say it's possible that the past 2 years\nare part of the natural peak cycle. Health officials also point out there's\nincreased awareness in the medical community and doctors now have more\nadvanced technology to detect the disease than in previous years.\nThe federal government is debating whether it should allow booster shots\nagainst the cough, since protection begins to drop 5 to 10 years after the\nlast shot.\n[byline: Alicia Chang]\n******\n[3] Kansas\nDate: Thu, 23 Sep 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org> Source: Johnson County Sun [edited]\n<http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=12984252&BRD=1459&PAG=461>\n\nWhooping cough is cyclical in Kansas\n------------------------------------\nThe upsurge in whooping cough or pertussis cases in Kansas in 2004,\nparticularly in the northeast part of the state, may be cyclical, said\nSharon Watson, spokeswoman for the Kansas Department of Health and Environment.\nThe department said that, from May through Sep 2004, there were 31\nconfirmed cases reported in the state, compared with an average of 9 cases\nin the previous 3 years for the same months.\nIn Johnson County, there have been 8 confirmed cases since 1 May 2004. In\n2003, 10 cases total were reported, said Nancy Tausz, director of disease\ncontainment for the county health department. No cases have been reported\nin the Shawnee Mission School District, according to Debbie Sokoloff,\nhealth services and safety resource specialist. 'I do not know of any\ncases,' she said Wed, 22 Sep 2004. Loralee Baker, director of community\nrelations for the Olathe School District, said the district had reported 1\nsuspected case of whooping cough to the Johnson County Health Department\nbut that it had not been confirmed.\n'It seems to go in cycles,' Watson said. 'In 1999, we had an upsurge in\ncases with a total of 49. Children either don't have the vaccinations at\nall or haven't completed them. This leads to some adults getting pertussis\nfrom children.' More than half of the 31 (Kansas) cases involved children\nunder age 5, Watson said. 'In the cases reported since May 2004, a number\nof children were not vaccinated or had not completed the vaccinations they\nneeded to be protected.'\nA majority of the Kansas cases so far in 2004 have been reported by 6 north\neast Kansas counties, including Douglas, Franklin, Leavenworth, Johnson,\nMiami and Wyandotte, according to Watson. KDHE hopes that, by reporting the\nincreasing incidence of the disease this year, parents will be encouraged\nto check their children's records and complete their vaccinations if they\nhave not already done so.\n[byline: Elaine Bessier]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Even in developed countries such as the USA, pertussis clusters continue\nto occur. The demographics of the cases in such clusters are nonvaccination\nof children, incomplete vaccination of children, primary vaccine failure,\nwaning immunity in adolescence and adults, improved reporting of cases, or,\nmost likely, a combination of factors. The change in DTP vaccine (which\ncontained killed, whole-cell pertussis organisms and was quite reactogenic)\nto DTaP (which contains several toxoids of _Bordetella pertussis_) has\ndecreased the reactogenicity but does not appear to greatly increase\nimmunogenicity. In addition to a higher percentage of infants receiving a\nfull primary series of vaccination against pertussis, the addition of aP to\nthe Td booster (which should be given to adults every decade) can assist in\ndiminishing cases. Unlike the whole-cell product, acellular pertussis\nvaccine is well-tolerated in adults. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A\nsimilar alert was sent in Jun 2004 to directors and nurses at summer camps,\nwhere whooping cough outbreaks are not uncommon since children live\ntogether in tight quarters and often have direct contact with one another,\nmaking the disease easier to spread. The change in DTP vaccine (which\ncontained killed, whole-cell pertussis organisms and was quite reactogenic)\nto DTaP (which contains several toxoids of _Bordetella pertussis_) has\ndecreased the reactogenicity but does not appear to greatly increase\nimmunogenicity. There's been a significant rise in the number of cases of whooping cough in\nthe Chicago area in 2004, public health administrators said on 20 Sep 2004,\nurging people to use precautions to help stem the spread of the contagious\ndisease. The department said that, from May through Sep 2004, there were 31\nconfirmed cases reported in the state, compared with an average of 9 cases\nin the previous 3 years for the same months.\n While Chicago has\nconfirmed an increase in whooping cough cases in 2004 compared with\nprevious years, the biggest jump in numbers appears to be happening in\nsuburban Cook and the collar [surrounding - Mod. The demographics of the cases in such clusters are nonvaccination\nof children, incomplete vaccination of children, primary vaccine failure,\nwaning immunity in adolescence and adults, improved reporting of cases, or,\nmost likely, a combination of factors. Loralee Baker, director of community\nrelations for the Olathe School District, said the district had reported 1\nsuspected case of whooping cough to the Johnson County Health Department\nbut that it had not been confirmed. Public health officials are somewhat exasperated by not being able to get\nthis quickly under control,' said Dr Lloyd Novick, the commissioner of the\nOnondaga County Health Department in central New York, whose county is\nconsidered a whooping cough hotspot. New York is among 7 states that\ncurrently do not require school-age children to be vaccinated against\nwhooping cough, although most received the shot as infants as part of a\ncombination vaccine. In addition to a higher percentage of infants receiving a\nfull primary series of vaccination against pertussis, the addition of aP to\nthe Td booster (which should be given to adults every decade) can assist in\ndiminishing cases. The vaccine\nisn't recommended for anyone over 7, but a booster shot for older people is\nin development and could be available in a year, said Dr Eric Whitaker,\ndirector of the Illinois Department of Public Health. The federal government is debating whether it should allow booster shots\nagainst the cough, since protection begins to drop 5 to 10 years after the\nlast shot.\n KDHE hopes that, by reporting the\nincreasing incidence of the disease this year, parents will be encouraged\nto check their children's records and complete their vaccinations if they\nhave not already done so. ' Source: Johnson County Sun [edited]\n<http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=12984252&BRD=1459&PAG=461>\n\nWhooping cough is cyclical in Kansas\n Source: NY Newsday.com [edited]\n<http://www.newsday.com/news/local/wire/ny-bc-ny--whoopingcough0922sep22,0,6987317.story?coll=ny-ap-regional-wire>\n\nWhooping cough on the rise in New York\n Health officials also point out there's\nincreased awareness in the medical community and doctors now have more\nadvanced technology to detect the disease than in previous years.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-01 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-06-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-20 00:00:00", "2004-09-23 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Onondaga County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syracuse", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Miami", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McHenry \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyandotte", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204663", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204663", "date": "2003-10-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN (EQUATORIA): SUSPECTED\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 3 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN (Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN), part of the\nUN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)) 3 Oct 2003\n[edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=36985&SelectRegion=East_Africa&SelectCountry=SUDAN>\n\nSudan: Suspected whooping cough outbreak in Equatoria\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nOver 100 children, mostly under age 5, have died from a suspected outbreak\nof whooping cough in Kimatong Budi county, Equatoria state, according to\nthe NGO, Medair.\nIn the space of 4 weeks from 20 Aug until 22 Sep 2003, 126 children had\ndied in the villages of Chawa, Kimatong, Thurunge, and Kali, said Els Stam,\nProgramme Coordinator for Medair.\nWith no NGO presence in the area for 5 years, only one health facility with\nlimited medicines, and no laboratory facilities, it had been impossible to\nestablish the precise causes of death, but whooping cough was suspected,\nshe said. Of the 312 apparent cases observed by a Medair team from 22\nuntil 25 Sep 2003, half of them also had enlarged livers and spleen, she said.\nA Medair team returned to Kimatong Budi country on Thu, 2 Oct 2003 and\nplans to split into 2 teams, based in Chawa and Kimatong, to treat people\nand give them preventative medicine. A doctor, a number of nurses, and a\nlaboratory technician will be located in each place.\nWithout vaccinations in the region, chronic malaria (and ongoing rains\nbringing further mosquitoes), plus the almost total lack of health care,\nchildren were very likely to become infected, she warned.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Nothing objective is stated here regarding the illness to suggest or\nrefute the diagnosis of pertussis. The classical paroxysmal coughing\nperiod during a single expiration preceding a 'whoop' (massive inspiration\nwith air forced against a partially narrowing glottis) would be highly\nsuggestive in an unimmunized population as described here. Most deaths\nseem to occur in young (especially less than 1 year of age) unvaccinated\nchildren.\nThe presence of hepatosplenomegaly is probably multifactorial, not related\nto the presumed pertussis. Factors relevant in these cases are most likely\nmalaria infection and malnutrition. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 3 Oct 2003\n With no NGO presence in the area for 5 years, only one health facility with\nlimited medicines, and no laboratory facilities, it had been impossible to\nestablish the precise causes of death, but whooping cough was suspected,\nshe said. Over 100 children, mostly under age 5, have died from a suspected outbreak\nof whooping cough in Kimatong Budi county, Equatoria state, according to\nthe NGO, Medair.\n 3 Oct 2003\n[edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=36985&SelectRegion=East_Africa&SelectCountry=SUDAN>\n\nSudan: Suspected whooping cough outbreak in Equatoria\n The classical paroxysmal coughing\nperiod during a single expiration preceding a 'whoop' (massive inspiration\nwith air forced against a partially narrowing glottis) would be highly\nsuggestive in an unimmunized population as described here. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Without vaccinations in the region, chronic malaria (and ongoing rains\nbringing further mosquitoes), plus the almost total lack of health care,\nchildren were very likely to become infected, she warned. In the space of 4 weeks from 20 Aug until 22 Sep 2003, 126 children had\ndied in the villages of Chawa, Kimatong, Thurunge, and Kali, said Els Stam,\nProgramme Coordinator for Medair.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["malaria", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-09-22 00:00:00", "2003-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kimatong Budi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kimatong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203175", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02):chemoprophylaxis", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203175", "date": "2003-01-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADULTS - USA (ILLINOIS) (02):CHEMOPROPHYLAXIS\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 06:43:12 +0000\nFrom: Badri Badrinath <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nUK guidelines on erythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to\npertussis have been published recently.\nDodhia H, Crowcroft NS, Bramley JC, Miller E: UK guidelines for use of\nerythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to pertussis. J Pub Health\nMed 2002;24:200-206\nAbstract from:<http://pubmed.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/3/200>\nPertussis is well controlled in the UK as a result of an effective\nvaccination program. Nevertheless, the disease has not been eliminated, and\ncases still occur in the most vulnerable group of young infants.\nErythromycin chemoprophylaxis has been advocated for use in contacts to\nprevent secondary cases, but the evidence for its use is weak. These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.\nIf a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. The aim is to protect those at greatest risk from\npertussis by offering chemoprophylaxis to them, to all their household\ncontacts who are unimmunized, and to contacts who are 5 years or older if\nthey did not receive a preschool pertussis booster (not given to those born\nbefore 1996 in the United Kingdom). There is no evidence of any benefit\nfrom chemoprophylaxis given more than 21 days from the date of onset of the\nprimary case. Unimmunized or partially immunized cases and contacts should\ncomplete their course of vaccine.\nI thought this might be of interest to ProMED-mail Readers.\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 06:43:12 +0000\n The aim is to protect those at greatest risk from\npertussis by offering chemoprophylaxis to them, to all their household\ncontacts who are unimmunized, and to contacts who are 5 years or older if\nthey did not receive a preschool pertussis booster (not given to those born\nbefore 1996 in the United Kingdom). If a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. [These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. --\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\n These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. There is no evidence of any benefit\nfrom chemoprophylaxis given more than 21 days from the date of onset of the\nprimary case. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-01-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204167", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (South Carolina)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204167", "date": "2003-07-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (SOUTH CAROLINA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 15 Jul 2003\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@virgin.net>\nSource: TheState.com (SC) Online, AP [edited]\n<http://www.thestate.com/mld/thestate/6310342.htm>\n\nState investigating whooping cough outbreak\n-------------------------------------------\nState health officials have reported more than 40 confirmed cases of\nwhooping cough after an outbreak was first seen in Georgetown County 3\nmonths ago. The state Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC)\nsaid on Tuesday that there are 15 more probable cases of whooping cough, or\npertussis. Over 300 people who have come in close contact with the patients\nhave begun taking antibiotics as a preventive measure.\nThose 300 people include school and day care workers as well as household\nmembers who have come in contact with a coughing patient, said Dr Robert\nBall, an infectious disease consultant and epidemiologist at DHEC's\nWaccamaw and Trident public health districts. Hugging, kissing, and sharing\ncups, utensils, and food can also spread the highly contagious disease of\nthe respiratory system.\nBall urged parents to make sure children are up-to-date on required\nvaccinations, particularly for whooping cough. 'The patients are in\ntreatment, and there have been no complications,' he said. 'While the\nnumber of actual cases and those under preventive treatment are high, we\nfeel the actions of everyone involved have reduced the chances of more\ninfections and serious illness, especially in the elderly or very young.'\nThose most at risk are children younger than 12 months who may not be\nvaccinated. Shots are recommended at 2, 4, and 6 months and at 12 to 18\nmonths with a booster after age 4 but before entering school. Severe cases\n[may suffer] pneumonia, seizures, brain damage and even death. From 6 to 21\ndays after exposure, patients suffer a runny nose and cough. That may\nprogress to whooping, a coughing spasm that ends in a prolonged,\nhigh-pitched intake of breath.\nWhooping cough is caused by bacteria [_Bordetella pertussis_] found in the\nmouth, nose and throat of an infected person. Ball said it's usual to see\noutbreaks of pertussis throughout the country each year, but it's unclear\nwhere the disease originated this year. The first cases of the outbreak in\nGeorgetown were seen in early May 2003 and continued into July. Related\ncases have been found in Horry, Williamsburg and Charleston counties, but\nGeorgetown has had more than 30 confirmed cases. South Carolina had just 48\npertussis cases in 2002. Greenville County had the most with 8, while\nCharleston and Berkeley counties each had 5.\n[byline: Jacob Jordan]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The age distribution of cases is not stated in this news report but the\ninclusion of school and daycare workers implies that young children are\namong the cases. Small outbreaks of pertussis are not uncommon and may\noccur in unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated children (including those\nless than 1 year old who have not yet completed immunization) and older\nchildren and adults in whom vaccine immunity has waned. Pertussis can be\ntroubling and debilitating (presenting as prolonged cough) but is rarely\nfatal in this older group. Some apparent outbreaks occur when surveillance\nand detection are enhanced. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Small outbreaks of pertussis are not uncommon and may\noccur in unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated children (including those\nless than 1 year old who have not yet completed immunization) and older\nchildren and adults in whom vaccine immunity has waned. Those 300 people include school and day care workers as well as household\nmembers who have come in contact with a coughing patient, said Dr Robert\nBall, an infectious disease consultant and epidemiologist at DHEC's\n While the\nnumber of actual cases and those under preventive treatment are high, we\nfeel the actions of everyone involved have reduced the chances of more\ninfections and serious illness, especially in the elderly or very young.' [byline: Jacob Jordan]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< [The age distribution of cases is not stated in this news report but the\ninclusion of school and daycare workers implies that young children are\namong the cases. The state Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC)\nsaid on Tuesday that there are 15 more probable cases of whooping cough, or\npertussis. Related\ncases have been found in Horry, Williamsburg and Charleston counties, but\nGeorgetown has had more than 30 confirmed cases. Ball said it's usual to see\noutbreaks of pertussis throughout the country each year, but it's unclear\nwhere the disease originated this year. Pertussis can be\ntroubling and debilitating (presenting as prolonged cough) but is rarely\nfatal in this older group. Source: TheState.com (SC) Online, AP [edited]\n<http://www.thestate.com/mld/thestate/6310342.htm>\n\nState investigating whooping cough outbreak\n-------------------------------------------", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greenville County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Charleston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgetown County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204029", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (WA, NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204029", "date": "2003-06-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (WASHINGTON, NEW YORK)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n*****\n[1] Washington\nDate: 23 June 2003\nFrom: ProMED <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News Tribune (Tacoma, WA) (edited)\n<http://www.tribnet.com/news/health_science/story/3332815p-3363474c.html>\nSpike seen in county whooping cough cases\n--------------------------------------------\nReported cases of whooping cough are on the rise in Pierce County,\nquadrupling to an average of 12.3 a month in the past 8 months. The\nspike, health officials say, puts the county and the state on track\nto surpass last year's reported cases of whooping cough, also known\nas pertussis. Pierce County had 68 reported cases as of the end of\nMay, the last month for which the health department has complete\ndata. Last year, the county had 84 cases and the state 575.\n'We don't know where people are getting it, which tells me that it's in the\ncommunity, not in a particular setting' such as a school or hospital, said\nMonica Raymond, an epidemiologist with the Tacoma/Pierce County Health\nDepartment.\nOther counties are reporting increases from recent years. That's\nprompting renewed efforts to shed light on the disease and vaccinate\nchildren who are particularly susceptible.\nIn Pierce County, an average of 2.9 people each month were diagnosed\nwith the infectious disease from Nov 1998 through Sep 2002. From Oct\n2002 to May 2003, the monthly average rose to 12.3, according to the\nhealth department. King County has recorded 113 cases of whooping\ncough, compared with 155 in 2002 and 39 in 2001.\nThis year, as many as 600 cases of whooping cough may be reported statewide.\nThat would exceed last year's 575 cases and far outstrip the 184 reported in\n2001. The worst recent year was in 1996, when 830 cases were reported. The\nlowest recent year was in 1993, with fewer than 100 cases.\nPart of the problem, heath officials say, is that parents are not\nhaving their children vaccinated for the disease. Health officials\nrecommend children get four shots before age 2 to build up\nimmunization to whooping cough. Most children get the first 3, but\nthe number drops to about 80 percent for the fourth shot, said Cindy\nGleason, a health educator with the state Department of Health\nimmunization program.\n'The real danger with pertussis is that it tends to be very severe in\nsmall kids, particularly those under 6 months of age,' said Marcia\nPatrick, a registered nurse for MultiCare Health Systems, which\nincludes Mary Bridge, Tacoma General and Allenmore hospitals.\nThough children are most susceptible to whooping cough, health\nofficials note adults can be afflicted as well. Last year, several\nstaff members at Mary Bridge's Children's Hospital and Health Center\nand its sister facility, Tacoma General Hospital, caught pertussis.\nThe hospitals treated nearly 1,000 workers with antibiotics to make\nsure the disease didn't spread to patients.\n[Byline: Sheila B. Lalwani]\n-----\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2] New York\nDate: 19 June 2003\nFrom: ProMED <promed@promedmaio.org>\nSource: Times Union (Albany, NY)\n<http://www.timesunion.com>\nOfficials warn of pertussis outbreak\n------------------------------------\nAlbany County reports 19 cases of the contagious illness that is also\nknown as whooping cough. County health officials issued an alert\nabout a pertussis outbreak Wed, Jun 18 after 19 cases of the\ncontagious illness have been reported this year, many in recent weeks.\n----\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Even in developed countries such as the USA, pertussis clusters continue to\noccur. The demographics of the cases are not given in the posting to assess\nwhether the reasons behind the clusters were nonvaccination of children,\nincomplete vaccination of children, primary vaccine failure, waning immunity in\nadolescence and adults, improved reporting of cases, or, most likely,\na combination of factors. The change in DTP (which contained killed,\nwhole cell pertussis organisms and was quite reactogenic) to DTaP\n(which contains several toxoids of _B. pertussis_) has decreased the\nreactogenicity but does not appear to greatly increase\nimmunogenicity. The addition of aP to the Td booster (which should\nbe given to adults every decade) can assist in diminishing cases.\nUnlike the whole cell product, acellular pertussis vaccine is well\ntolerated in adults. - Mod. LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n*****\n The demographics of the cases are not given in the posting to assess\nwhether the reasons behind the clusters were nonvaccination of children,\nincomplete vaccination of children, primary vaccine failure, waning immunity in\nadolescence and adults, improved reporting of cases, or, most likely,\na combination of factors. The\nspike, health officials say, puts the county and the state on track\nto surpass last year's reported cases of whooping cough, also known\nas pertussis. We don't know where people are getting it, which tells me that it's in the\ncommunity, not in a particular setting' such as a school or hospital, said\nMonica Raymond, an epidemiologist with the Tacoma/Pierce County Health\nDepartment. That's\nprompting renewed efforts to shed light on the disease and vaccinate\nchildren who are particularly susceptible.\n --------------------------------------------\nReported cases of whooping cough are on the rise in Pierce County,\nquadrupling to an average of 12.3 a month in the past 8 months. \nAlbany County reports 19 cases of the contagious illness that is also\nknown as whooping cough. Health officials\nrecommend children get four shots before age 2 to build up\nimmunization to whooping cough. Last year, several\nstaff members at Mary Bridge's Children's Hospital and Health Center\nand its sister facility, Tacoma General Hospital, caught pertussis.
