USA (WASHINGTON, NEW YORK)\n**************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-06-23 00:00:00", "2003-05-25 00:00:00", "2068-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-06-19 00:00:00", "2002-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Albany County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "King County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pierce County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201996", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis, school outbreak - UK (England) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201996", "date": "2002-06-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND) (05)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[We are reopening this thread to post the official findings of the\ninvestigation of this outbreak as prior reports on cases and epidemiology\nwere weighted towards the lay press reports. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Thu, 13 June 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDR Weekly [edited]\n<http://www.phls.org.uk/publications/CDR%20Weekly/pages/news.html#pertussis>\n\nAn outbreak of pertussis at a school in Leicestershire\n---------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of pertussis has occurred at a primary school in the Vale of\nBelvoir in north Leicestershire, on the boundaries with Nottinghamshire and\nLincolnshire. The outbreak was recognised on 23 May 2002, the first case\nhaving developed symptoms on 25 Mar 2002.\nThe Head Teacher of the school had first reported concerns that children at\nthe school had whooping cough at the beginning of May, and contacted the\nLeicestershire Health Protection Team again on 15 May 2002. When contacted,\nlocal general practitioners (GPs) reported that they did not think that\nthey were seeing children with pertussis. [Certainly, the diagnosis of\npertussis may be difficult, but earlier diagnosis may have minimized the\noutbreak - Mod.LL] A further report on 22 May 2002 that nearly half of the\npupils were coughing prompted a visit to the school by the Health\nProtection Team on 23 May 2002. At the visit, children were observed to\nhave paroxysmal cough typical of whooping cough.\nThe school is in a small village. It has 86 full-time pupils aged between 5\nand 10 years, 21 part-time pupils aged under 5 years, and 16 teaching and\nother staff members. Children aged 5 and under are taught in a mobile\nclassroom. Other children are taught in 2 classrooms in the main school\nbuilding: children in years one and 2 (aged between 5 and 7) in one\nclassroom and years 3, 4, and 5 (aged between 7 and 10) in the other classroom.\nAfter consultation with the PHLS Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre\nand the Respiratory and Systemic Infection Laboratory at CPHL, initial\naction was agreed that included: (1) information about the outbreak and\npertussis to be sent to parents of all children at the school; (2)\ninformation about the outbreak and whooping cough to be sent to all local\nGP practices with advice on the immediate management of suspected cases;\n(3) a symptom questionnaire to be administered to all children and staff in\nthe school; (4) rapid confirmation of disease to be attempted by obtaining\npernasal swabs for _Bordetella pertussis_ PCR from those with early coryzal\nsymptoms, and blood for serological evidence of recent _B. pertussis_ in\nthose with a 2-week history of typical paroxysmal cough (>100 EU/mL of _B.\npertussis_ IgG is suggestive of recent infection, in the absence of recent\nimmunization).\nA 7-day course of erythromycin was initially offered to all children and\nstaff at the school because so many appeared to have early coryzal\nsymptoms. Chemoprophylaxis with erythromycin was offered to vulnerable\nhousehold contacts of cases. NHS Direct was briefed to enable them to\nhandle enquiries from parents, and pediatricians in local NHS Trusts were\ninformed of the outbreak. An outbreak control team first met on 27 May 2002.\nInformation from the questionnaires suggested a continuing outbreak. The\nfirst child became unwell before the Easter holiday break and returned to\nschool on 8 Apr 2002. A household contact of this child became unwell a\nweek later followed by several more within the next fortnight. The epidemic\ncurve demonstrated the continuing progression of the outbreak. There was a\ntotal of 23 confirmed and probable cases, including 7 members of staff.\nWithin 24 hours of receipt of the samples, 6 cases were microbiologically\nconfirmed by RSIL-CPHL, using culture, PCR, or serology, and 17 were\nprobable cases (cough for more than 2 weeks) including 7 members of staff.\nPupils and staff throughout the school were affected, but most cases were\naged 5 to 7 years. Childhood vaccine uptake in the area is very high, and\nonly 1 child was identified who had not received a primary course of\npertussis vaccine. Few children were young enough to have benefited from\nthe addition of acellular pertussis to the preschool booster in November 2001.\nThe further measures to investigate and control the outbreak were agreed\nare as follows, taking into account factors such as the known widespread\nintolerance to erythromycin: (1) Active case finding by providing\ninformation and raising awareness through primary care, local schools, and\nNHS Direct. (2) Active treatment of suspected cases, including anyone with\ncoryzal symptoms and direct epidemiological links to the outbreak. (3)\nSentinel microbiological surveillance in selected practices in the Vale of\nBelvoir, with pernasal swabs for _B. pertussis_ culture from patients\npresenting with coryzal symptoms and serological testing for pertussis\ntoxin IgG from patients with cough of more than 2 weeks duration. (4)\nStrain typing of _B. pertussis_ isolates obtained to determine whether the\nstrain was similar to other circulating strains. (5) Given the likely\nintolerance to erythromycin among those offered treatment, azithromycin for\n6 days (dosage as per British National Formulary) should be the treatment\nof choice in order to ensure compliance. (6) All children in the school\nwould be offered a DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis) booster\ninjection, as would other vulnerable children in the area ie those under\nthe age of 4 months who would not be fully immunized, and other children\nwith immune deficiencies or lung conditions such as cystic fibrosis for\nwhom whooping cough would potentially be a life-threatening illness.\nThe outbreak control team met again on 7 Jun 2002 to review the management\nof the outbreak. It appeared that the outbreak at the school had been\nbrought under control. Active case finding and sentinel surveillance had\nidentified a small number of additional cases in the local community, but\nno evidence consistent with a widespread community outbreak. It was agreed\nthat no further control measures were necessary. A further questionnaire\nwill be administered to parents of all children at the school to document\nthe true extent of the outbreak. The 80 children who had been given an\nadditional DTaP booster were asked to complete symptom diaries that will be\nanalyzed to determine the extent of adverse reactions that can sometimes\noccur when children receive more DT than in the routine schedule (there is\nno available monovalent pertussis vaccine).\nThe strain of _B. pertussis_ has been identified by RSIL-CPHL as serotype\n1,3 and appears similar to other strains circulating in England and Wales.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The description of the circumstances of this pertussis outbreak\nunderscores how difficult control of this infection can be in a school even\nwith what seems to be adherence to immunization schedules and how important\nearly suspicion and diagnosis remain. In total, 16 of 86 students were\nthought to have been infected (18 percent of the student body - if no\nsibling non-student cases were included) and 7 of 16 staff (44 percent).\nThe active surveillance, aggressive diagnosis methodologies, and\nappropriate therapeutic interventions brought the epidemic to an end - Mod.LL]\n[The epidemic curve of this outbreak is available on the PHLS website link\ngiven above. The delayed identification of this outbreak is noteworthy as\nthe date of onset of the index case was 25 Mar 2002 while the outbreak was\nofficially identified on 23 May 2002, 8 weeks later. In an earlier comment\nthe vaccine efficacy was estimated to be at 74 percent. According to the\ninformation given above, the apparent vaccine efficacy in this outbreak was\nbetween 82 and 84 percent (86 full-time students and 12 part-time\nstudents), well within the range of expected vaccine efficacy for 3 doses\nof the whole cell vaccine, albeit the true efficacy will not be known as\nother control measures were implemented. The occurrence of cases in staff\nmembers is consistent with current concerns on the contribution of adults\nto pertussis circulation. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "After consultation with the PHLS Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre\nand the Respiratory and Systemic Infection Laboratory at CPHL, initial\naction was agreed that included: (1) information about the outbreak and\npertussis to be sent to parents of all children at the school; (2)\ninformation about the outbreak and whooping cough to be sent to all local\nGP practices with advice on the immediate management of suspected cases;\n(3) a symptom questionnaire to be administered to all children and staff in\nthe school; (4) rapid confirmation of disease to be attempted by obtaining\npernasal swabs for _Bordetella pertussis_ PCR from those with early coryzal\nsymptoms, and blood for serological evidence of recent _B. pertussis_ in\nthose with a 2-week history of typical paroxysmal cough (>100 EU/mL of _B.\npertussis_ IgG is suggestive of recent infection, in the absence of recent\nimmunization). (6) All children in the school\nwould be offered a DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis) booster\ninjection, as would other vulnerable children in the area ie those under\nthe age of 4 months who would not be fully immunized, and other children\nwith immune deficiencies or lung conditions such as cystic fibrosis for\nwhom whooping cough would potentially be a life-threatening illness. According to the\ninformation given above, the apparent vaccine efficacy in this outbreak was\nbetween 82 and 84 percent (86 full-time students and 12 part-time\nstudents), well within the range of expected vaccine efficacy for 3 doses\nof the whole cell vaccine, albeit the true efficacy will not be known as\nother control measures were implemented. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The 80 children who had been given an\nadditional DTaP booster were asked to complete symptom diaries that will be\nanalyzed to determine the extent of adverse reactions that can sometimes\noccur when children receive more DT than in the routine schedule (there is\nno available monovalent pertussis vaccine). The further measures to investigate and control the outbreak were agreed\nare as follows, taking into account factors such as the known widespread\nintolerance to erythromycin: (1) Active case finding by providing\ninformation and raising awareness through primary care, local schools, and\nNHS Direct. Sentinel microbiological surveillance in selected practices in the Vale of\nBelvoir, with pernasal swabs for _B. pertussis_ culture from patients\npresenting with coryzal symptoms and serological testing for pertussis\ntoxin IgG from patients with cough of more than 2 weeks duration. [The description of the circumstances of this pertussis outbreak\nunderscores how difficult control of this infection can be in a school even\nwith what seems to be adherence to immunization schedules and how important\nearly suspicion and diagnosis remain. Given the likely\nintolerance to erythromycin among those offered treatment, azithromycin for\n6 days (dosage as per British National Formulary) should be the treatment\nof choice in order to ensure compliance. Other children are taught in 2 classrooms in the main school\nbuilding: children in years one and 2 (aged between 5 and 7) in one\nclassroom and years 3, 4, and 5 (aged between 7 and 10) in the other classroom. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n The delayed identification of this outbreak is noteworthy as\nthe date of onset of the index case was 25 Mar 2002 while the outbreak was\nofficially identified on 23 May 2002, 8 weeks later. The Head Teacher of the school had first reported concerns that children at\nthe school had whooping cough at the beginning of May, and contacted the\nLeicestershire Health Protection Team again on 15 May 2002. Within 24 hours of receipt of the samples, 6 cases were microbiologically\nconfirmed by RSIL-CPHL, using culture, PCR, or serology, and 17 were\nprobable cases (cough for more than 2 weeks) including 7 members of staff. A 7-day course of erythromycin was initially offered to all children and\nstaff at the school because so many appeared to have early coryzal\nsymptoms. It has 86 full-time pupils aged between 5\nand 10 years, 21 part-time pupils aged under 5 years, and 16 teaching and\nother staff members. Active case finding and sentinel surveillance had\nidentified a small number of additional cases in the local community, but\nno evidence consistent with a widespread community outbreak. A further questionnaire\nwill be administered to parents of all children at the school to document\nthe true extent of the outbreak. An outbreak of pertussis has occurred at a primary school in the Vale of\nBelvoir in north Leicestershire, on the boundaries with Nottinghamshire and\nLincolnshire. In total, 16 of 86 students were\nthought to have been infected (18 percent of the student body - if no\nsibling non-student cases were included) and 7 of 16 staff (44 percent). Source: CDR Weekly [edited]\n<http://www.phls.org.uk/publications/CDR%20Weekly/pages/news.html#pertussis>\n\nAn outbreak of pertussis at a school in Leicestershire\n PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND) (05)\n**********************************************\n A further report on 22 May 2002 that nearly half of the\npupils were coughing prompted a visit to the school by the Health\nProtection Team on 23 May 2002.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2002-06-07 00:00:00", "2002-04-08 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2002-05-22 00:00:00", "2002-05-23 00:00:00", "2002-05-15 00:00:00", "2002-06-13 00:00:00", "2001-11-25 00:00:00", "2002-05-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202600", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis - USA (Texas) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202600", "date": "2002-09-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (TEXAS) (02)\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 14:14:07 +0000\nFrom: Badri Badrinath <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nIn the recent posting on pertussis in USA the moderator commented that\n'immunization of adults with the acellular pertussis vaccine, reasonably\nwell tolerated in this group (unlike the old killed whole cell product),\nmay be the answer'. The following 2 trials also show that aP is safe and\nimmunogenic in adults.\nChristie CD, Garrison KM, Kiely L, et al: A trial of acellular pertussis\nvaccine in hospital workers during the Cincinnati pertussis epidemic of\n1993. Clin Infect Dis 2001;33:997-1003\nHalperin SA, Smith B, Russell M, Hasselback P, et al: An adult formulation\nof a 5-component acellular pertussis vaccine combined with diphtheria and\ntetanus toxoids is safe and immunogenic in adolescents and adults. Vaccine\n2000;18:1312-9\nHowever according to Weingart et al (Weingart CL, Keitel WA, Edwards KM,\nWeiss AA: Characterization of bactericidal immune responses following\nvaccination with acellular pertussis vaccines in adults. Infect Immun\n2000;68:7175-9) booster immunization of adults with acellular pertussis\nvaccines was not found to increase bactericidal activity over\npreimmunization levels. Identifying ways to promote bactericidal immune\nresponses might improve the efficacy of acellular pertussis vaccines.\nThe following 2 recent editorials also address relevant issues:\nCrowcroft NS, Britto J: Whooping cough a continuing problem. BMJ\n2002;324:1537-1538 -\n'Policy makers need more information about the natural history of pertussis\nin adolescents and adults to determine the potential benefits from booster\nvaccination in these groups irrespective of any possible benefit to infants\nthrough reducing transmission.\nRobbins JB, Schneersonn R, Trollfors B: Pertussis in developed countries.\nLancet 2002;360:657. -\n'Pertussis in children is at all-time lows and immunisation rates at\nall-time highs with aP vaccines. More susceptible adults, due to lower\nvaccination rates in the 1980s, and increased awareness and better\ndiagnostic methods account for the increase in pertussis. DTaP should\nreplace DT in adults to eliminate pertussis from the entire\npopulation.'\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journal/vol360/iss9334/full/llan.360.9334.editorial_and_review.22323.1>\n\n--\nDr. P. Badrinath\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>", "summary": "BMJ\n2002;324:1537-1538 -\n'Policy makers need more information about the natural history of pertussis\nin adolescents and adults to determine the potential benefits from booster\nvaccination in these groups irrespective of any possible benefit to infants\nthrough reducing transmission. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 14:14:07 +0000\n Clin Infect Dis 2001;33:997-1003\nHalperin SA, Smith B, Russell M, Hasselback P, et al: An adult formulation\nof a 5-component acellular pertussis vaccine combined with diphtheria and\ntetanus toxoids is safe and immunogenic in adolescents and adults. Infect Immun\n2000;68:7175-9) booster immunization of adults with acellular pertussis\nvaccines was not found to increase bactericidal activity over\npreimmunization levels. the moderator commented that\n'immunization of adults with the acellular pertussis vaccine, reasonably\nwell tolerated in this group (unlike the old killed whole cell product),\nmay be the answer'. DTaP should\nreplace DT in adults to eliminate pertussis from the entire\npopulation.'\n <http://www.thelancet.com/journal/vol360/iss9334/full/llan.360.9334.editorial_and_review.22323.1>\n\n--\nDr. P. Badrinath\nSt.Clement's Hospital\n (Weingart CL, Keitel WA, Edwards KM,\nWeiss AA: Characterization of bactericidal immune responses following\nvaccination with acellular pertussis vaccines in adults. A trial of acellular pertussis\nvaccine in hospital workers during the Cincinnati pertussis epidemic of\n1993. More susceptible adults, due to lower\nvaccination rates in the 1980s, and increased awareness and better\ndiagnostic methods account for the increase in pertussis. -\n'Pertussis in children is at all-time lows and immunisation rates at\nall-time highs with aP vaccines. Identifying ways to promote bactericidal immune\nresponses might improve the efficacy of acellular pertussis vaccines. The following 2 trials also show that aP is safe and\nimmunogenic in adults. \nRobbins JB, Schneersonn R, Trollfors B: Pertussis in developed countries.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-09-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halperin SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201965", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis, school outbreak - UK (England) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201965", "date": "2002-06-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND) (03)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 10 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: GP 2002; 10 June: 8 [edited]\n\nFall in immunity led to outbreak of pertussis\n---------------------------------------------\nWaning immunity from primary immunisation is to blame for last\nmonth's pertussis outbreak, which affected a quarter of the children\nat a village school in Leicestershire, communicable disease\nspecialists have said.\nPrimary vaccination uptake among the 87 children at Stathern Village\nSchool was high, and only one child who contracted whooping cough had\nnot been vaccinated.\nBut Gerry Bryant, public health specialist at Leicestershire Health\nAuthority told GP [General Practitioner] that by the age of 5 the\nprotection offered by primary vaccination can decline by 50 percent.\n'The age booster was introduced in November [2001] because we\nanticipated the increase in pertussis,' she said.\nAll children attending Stathern primary school have now been given\nthe school entry DTPa [diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis\nvaccine] booster.\nThe vaccine is only licensed for children up to 7 because of\npotential side effects of the diphtheria component. The Public Health\nLaboratory Service (PHLS) is monitoring side effects.\n'If they are not too bad, we might consider introducing catch-ups in\nthe future,' said Dr Mary Ramsay, an immunologist [sic, actually an\nepidemiologist - Mod.SH] at the PHLS. She warned a peak in the 4-year\npertussis cycle was due this year.\n[Byline: Prisca Middlemiss]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given past concerns, whether entirely well-founded or not, about\nwhole cell pertussis vaccine use by older children or adults, the use\nof the acellular pertussis vaccine in this cohort has been still an\nissue. It appears, as in this UK school outbreak, that waning\nimmunity is a significant issue that needs to be addressed. It\nappears that the acellular vaccine is safe and immunogenic in adults\n(1,2), and boosters of the vaccine have been felt to have potential\nbenefits in the problem of waning immunity even in adults (3).\n1. Turnbull FM, Health TC, Jalaludin BB, et al: A randomized trial of\ntwo acellular pertussis vaccines (dTpa and pa) and a licensed\ndiphtheria-tentanus vaccine (Td) in adults. Vaccine 2000;19:628-36.\n2. Christie CD, Garrison KM, Kiely L, et al: A trial of acellular\npertussis vaccine in hospital workers during the Cincinnati pertussis\nepidemic of 1993. Clin Infect Dis 2001; 33:997-1003.\n3. Beard SM, Finn A: Do we need to boost pertussis immunization\nwithin the existing UK vaccination schedule? J Pub Health Med 2000;\n22:349-56.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nWaning immunity from primary immunisation is to blame for last\nmonth's pertussis outbreak, which affected a quarter of the children\nat a village school in Leicestershire, communicable disease\nspecialists have said. [Given past concerns, whether entirely well-founded or not, about\nwhole cell pertussis vaccine use by older children or adults, the use\nof the acellular pertussis vaccine in this cohort has been still an\nissue. It\nappears that the acellular vaccine is safe and immunogenic in adults\n(1,2), and boosters of the vaccine have been felt to have potential\nbenefits in the problem of waning immunity even in adults (3). \nPrimary vaccination uptake among the 87 children at Stathern Village\nSchool was high, and only one child who contracted whooping cough had\nnot been vaccinated. [Byline: Prisca Middlemiss]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< All children attending Stathern primary school have now been given\nthe school entry DTPa [diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis\nvaccine] booster. Christie CD, Garrison KM, Kiely L, et al: A trial of acellular\npertussis vaccine in hospital workers during the Cincinnati pertussis\nepidemic of 1993. A randomized trial of\ntwo acellular pertussis vaccines (dTpa and pa) and a licensed\ndiphtheria-tentanus vaccine (Td) in adults. PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND) (03)\n**********************************************\n She warned a peak in the 4-year\npertussis cycle was due this year.\n But Gerry Bryant, public health specialist at Leicestershire Health\nAuthority told GP [General Practitioner] that by the age of 5 the\nprotection offered by primary vaccination can decline by 50 percent.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-10 00:00:00", "2002-06-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203150", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, adults - USA (Illinois)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203150", "date": "2003-01-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADULTS - USA (ILLINOIS)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 9 Jan 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Morbidity & Mortality Weekly Report 10 Jan 2003 / 52(01):1-4\n[edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5201a1.htm>\n\nPertussis Outbreak Among Adults at an Oil Refinery --- Illinois,\nAugust-October 2002\n------------------------\nOn 16 Sep 2002, the Crawford County Health Department (CCHD) reported to\nthe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) 4 cases of cough illness\namong workers at an oil refinery (total worker population: 750) in Crawford\nCounty, Illinois. On 14 Aug 2002, a worker aged 39 years reported to the\nplant's health unit with a cough lasting 14 days. On the same day, the\nworker's supervisor aged 50 years visited the health unit for a paroxysmal\ncough of 3 days' duration and an incident of cough syncope. Both patients\nwere referred to private health-care providers; blood samples from both\npatients had serologic test results suggestive of recent _Bordetella\npertussis_ infection, and CCHD was contacted. On 18 Sep 2002 IDPH and CCHD\ninitiated active surveillance and case investigations. This report\nsummarizes the results of that investigation, which found that during 1\nAug-9 Oct 2002 pertussis was diagnosed in 15 (10 percent) of 150 oil\nrefinery workers from 2 separate operations (n=95) and maintenance (n=55)\ncomplexes, who were linked by contact with the ill supervisor. Through\nenhanced case finding, 24 cases of pertussis, 21 (88 percent) of which\noccurred in adults aged >20 years, were identified in this outbreak,\nunderscoring the need to recognize this highly infectious disease in adults\nand to improve national diagnostic and preventive strategies.\nA clinical case was defined as an acute cough illness lasting >2 weeks in a\nperson with 1) at least one of the following: paroxysms of coughing,\ninspiratory 'whoop,' or post-tussive vomiting, without other apparent cause\nor 2) >14 days of cough in a person in an outbreak setting. A confirmed\ncase was defined as a cough illness of any duration in a person with\nisolation by culture of _B. pertussis_ or a case that met the clinical case\ndefinition and was confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for _B.\npertussis_ DNA or by epidemiologic linkage to a laboratory-confirmed case.\nA probable case met the clinical case definition, was not\nlaboratory-confirmed, and was not linked by direct contact with a\nlaboratory-confirmed case. At the oil refinery, any worker reporting a\ncough illness to the health unit was referred to the local community\nhospital for evaluation for pertussis and interviewed by CCHD or IDPH staff\nto establish onset of illness, symptoms, area of work and work schedules,\nand information on all close contacts. Community cases were identified\nthrough standard IDPH case report forms submitted by health-care providers\nto CCHD for suspected cases of pertussis and then reviewed by the IDPH\nimmunization section to determine if the case definition was met.\nAs of 13 Dec 2002, a total of 17 cases of pertussis have been associated\nwith the oil refinery: 4 confirmed cases (including one culture-positive\ncase, one PCR-positive case, and 2 epidemiologically linked cases) and 13\nprobable cases; 10 patients were males. A pulsed-field gel electrophoresis\n(PFGE) DNA fingerprint from the _B. pertussis_ isolate from the\nculture-confirmed case (illness onset date: 10 Sep 2002) was PFGE profile\n13. The median age of patients was 40 years (range: 16-53 years). 6\npatients worked in the same work unit. 8 of 14 patients tested by a\nprivate diagnostic laboratory had serologic testing results (anti-_B.\npertussis_ IgA, IgM, or IgG enzyme immunoassay) suggestive of recent _B.\npertussis_ infection. In addition to the 17 patients identified from the\noil refinery, 7 patients in the community who were unrelated\nepidemiologically to the oil refinery also were identified as having\nprobable cases of pertussis; 4 were males with a median age of 24 years\n(range: 5-33 years). All 24 patients received treatment with macrolide\nantibiotics and were encouraged to be tested for pertussis by PCR and\nnasopharyngeal culture. On 19 Sep 2002, with the cooperation of the oil\nrefinery management, 150 close work contacts of the 17 patients at the oil\nrefinery plant were prescribed azithromycin prophylaxis at a dose schedule\nof 500 mg for the first day, followed by 250 mg daily for the next 4 days.\nOther than a meeting lasting approximately 5 minutes conducted indoors each\nmorning, daily work assignments at the plant are performed outdoors.\nHowever, workers may congregate in an indoor dining area reserved for lunch.\nNo cases of pertussis at the oil refinery have been reported since 9 Oct\n2002. School officials and health-care providers within the community have\nbeen given guidelines on pertussis case recognition, reporting, and\nprophylaxis measures. IDPH and the local health department continue to\nperform ongoing case ascertainment.\nEditorial Note:\nAmong the diseases for which universal childhood vaccination is recommended\nin the United States, only pertussis has increased in incidence in the\nUnited States during the preceding 20 years, from 1730 cases in 1980 to\n8296 cases provisionally reported in 2002 (1; CDC, unpublished data, 2002).\nThe outbreak described in this report reflects the changing demographics of\npertussis in the United States, with reported incidence rates in adults\nincreasing 400 percent during 1990-2001 (2; CDC, unpublished data, 2002).\nAdults and adolescents might be a reservoir for _B. pertussis_ in the\ncommunity, because immunity from childhood vaccination declines beginning\n5-15 years after the last pertussis vaccine dose (3). Despite increasing\nrecognition of pertussis as a disease affecting older children and adults,\npertussis often is overlooked in the differential diagnosis of cough\nillness in this population (4). Pertussis can be highly infectious during\nthe 3 weeks after illness onset, and infection can spread to exposed\ninfants, who have the highest rates for complications and death (5). In\nthis outbreak, pertussis was not considered initially in the index\npatient's 14-day cough illness until the patient's supervisor reported to\nthe oil refinery health unit concurrently with cough syncope, triggering\nreferral of both patients to the local community hospital for evaluation\nfor pertussis. Emblematic in this outbreak was the protracted duration of\ncough symptoms in the first patient, followed by a comprehensive public\nhealth response once several close contacts became infected and, late in\nthe outbreak, _B. pertussis_ was cultured successfully from an oil refinery\nworker; isolation of _B. pertussis_ from an adult is uncommon.\nIn Illinois, 46 of 191 cases (24 percent) of reported pertussis in 2001\noccurred in adults aged >20 years (incidence rate: 0.5 per 100 000\npopulation), a proportion similar to that of cases in the United States\namong this age group (1). Persons aged 10-19 years comprised 18 percent of\nall cases in 2001 in Illinois. Waning vaccine-induced immunity probably\naccounts for susceptibility to _B. pertussis_ infection in both adults and\nadolescents (3,6). Since the 1980s, the reported incidence rates in\nadolescents and adults in the United States have increased as a result of\nchanges in reporting, a true increase in incidence, or both (1,2). In 1995,\nthe case definition for pertussis was expanded to include PCR-positive\ntests and epidemiologic linking of pertussis cases as confirmation\ncriteria. In addition, a possible increase in awareness of pertussis in\nolder age groups within the medical community during the 1990s might have\ncontributed to increased diagnosis rates in this population (7).\nAdults with pertussis can have mild symptoms and might not seek medical\ncare, and clinicians might not consider pertussis as a cause of illness\n(8). Although the fastidious _B. pertussis_ bacterium often cannot be\nisolated, to confirm diagnosis in symptomatic adults, health-care providers\nshould obtain a nasopharyngeal aspirate or swab for _B. pertussis_ culture\nwithin 2 weeks of cough onset. In this outbreak, serologic testing for\ndiagnosis of recent _B. pertussis_ infection was performed in the majority\nof cases. No serologic assay for a single convalescent sera is currently\napproved or recommended for serodiagnosis of pertussis. Because adults\nmight report to health-care providers late in the disease course, a\nstandardized and valid serologic test is needed to diagnose recent _B.\npertussis_ infection in adults (9).\nAs one of several state health departments with enhanced pertussis\nsurveillance systems, IDPH analyzes _B. pertussis_ isolates from cases by\nPFGE. The single isolate in this outbreak indicated PFGE profile 13, the\nmost frequently identified pattern from _B. pertussis_ isolates in the\nUnited States. Identification of pertussis DNA fingerprints by PFGE might\nallow health officials to track disease transmission and associated outbreaks.\nA 14-day course of erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic with substantial in\nvitro and in vivo activity against _B. pertussis_, is the recommended\nantimicrobial for treatment of patients with pertussis and for prophylaxis\nof close contacts. Treatment and prophylaxis are most effective when\nerythromycin is administered to patients within 3 weeks of illness onset\nand to close contacts within 3 weeks of cough onset in the primary case\n(9). During an outbreak, repeated exposure to pertussis might warrant\nrepeated courses of erythromycin. If erythromycin is poorly tolerated\nbecause of gastrointestinal side effects, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can\nbe prescribed; azithromycin and clarithromycin might be effective\nalternatives in the eradication of _B. pertussis_ in symptomatic patients\n(9,10). However, effectiveness of azithromycin or clarithromycin as\nprophylaxis for asymptomatic close contacts in an outbreak setting is not\nwell documented.\nOutbreaks of pertussis in adults are controlled through prompt treatment of\npatients and antimicrobial prophylaxis for close contacts. Acellular\npertussis vaccines are licensed in the United States for infants and\nchildren aged 6 weeks-6 years (i.e., before the seventh birthday). These\nvaccines might have a future role in the prevention of disease and control\nof outbreaks in older age groups (4,5,7).\nReferences\n1. CDC. Pertussis---United States, 1997--2000. MMWR 2002;51:73--6.\n2. Guris D, Strebel PM, Bardenheier B, et al. Changing epidemiology of\npertussis in the United States: increasing reported incidence among\nadolescents and adults, 1990--1996. Clin Infect Dis 1999;28:1230.\n3. Jenkinson D. Duration of effectiveness of pertussis vaccine: evidence\nfrom a 10-year community study. Br J Med 1988;296:612--4.\n4. Keitel WA, Edwards KM. Pertussis in adolescents and adults: time to\nreimmunize? Semin Respir Infect 1995;10:51--7.\n5. CDC. Pertussis deaths---United States, 2000. MMWR 2002;51:616--9.\n6. Mortimer EA Jr. Pertussis vaccine. In: Plotkin SA, Mortimer EA Jr, eds.\nVaccines. Philadelphia, Pennsylvania: WB Saunders, 1988:74--97.\n7. Yih WK, Lett SM, des Vignes FN, Carrison KM, Sipe PL, Marchant CD. The\nincreasing incidence of pertussis in Massachusetts adolescents and adults,\n1989--1998. J Infect Dis 2000;182:1409--16.\n8. Dworkin MS, Shoemaker P. Pertussis in adults. Ann Int Med 1998;128:1047.\n9. CDC. Guidelines for the control of pertussis outbreaks. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nip/publications/pertussis/guide.htm>.\n10. Halperin SA, Langley JM, Boucher FD, Smith B. Azithromycin is as\neffective as and better tolerated than erythromycin estolate for the\ntreatment of pertussis. [Abstract]. Presented at the 40th Annual Meeting of\nInfectious Diseases Society of America. Chicago, Illinois: Infectious\nDiseases Society of America, October 24--27, 2002; A169.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given the changing epidemiology of pertussis in the USA, one wonders if\nand when the acellular pertussis vaccine, may become part of the\nonce-a-decade routine booster for tetanus-diphtheria (Td) to become TdaP.\n-Mods.LL/MPP]", "summary": "In\nthis outbreak, pertussis was not considered initially in the index\npatient's 14-day cough illness until the patient's supervisor reported to\nthe oil refinery health unit concurrently with cough syncope, triggering\nreferral of both patients to the local community hospital for evaluation\nfor pertussis. A confirmed\ncase was defined as a cough illness of any duration in a person with\nisolation by culture of _B. pertussis_ or a case that met the clinical case\ndefinition and was confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for _B.\npertussis_ DNA or by epidemiologic linkage to a laboratory-confirmed case. Emblematic in this outbreak was the protracted duration of\ncough symptoms in the first patient, followed by a comprehensive public\nhealth response once several close contacts became infected and, late in\nthe outbreak, _B. pertussis_ was cultured successfully from an oil refinery\nworker; isolation of _B. pertussis_ from an adult is uncommon. In addition to the 17 patients identified from the\noil refinery, 7 patients in the community who were unrelated\nepidemiologically to the oil refinery also were identified as having\nprobable cases of pertussis; 4 were males with a median age of 24 years\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 9 Jan 2003\n At the oil refinery, any worker reporting a\ncough illness to the health unit was referred to the local community\nhospital for evaluation for pertussis and interviewed by CCHD or IDPH staff\nto establish onset of illness, symptoms, area of work and work schedules,\nand information on all close contacts. Through\nenhanced case finding, 24 cases of pertussis, 21 (88 percent) of which\noccurred in adults aged >20 years, were identified in this outbreak,\nunderscoring the need to recognize this highly infectious disease in adults\nand to improve national diagnostic and preventive strategies. This report\nsummarizes the results of that investigation, which found that during 1\nAug-9 Oct 2002 pertussis was diagnosed in 15 (10 percent) of 150 oil\nrefinery workers from 2 separate operations (n=95) and maintenance (n=55)\ncomplexes, who were linked by contact with the ill supervisor. Source: CDC Morbidity & Mortality Weekly Report 10 Jan 2003 / 52(01):1-4\n[edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5201a1.htm>\n\nPertussis Outbreak Among Adults at an Oil Refinery --- Illinois,\nAugust-October 2002\n If erythromycin is poorly tolerated\nbecause of gastrointestinal side effects, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can\nbe prescribed; azithromycin and clarithromycin might be effective\nalternatives in the eradication of _B. pertussis_ in symptomatic patients\n(9,10). As of 13 Dec 2002, a total of 17 cases of pertussis have been associated\nwith the oil refinery: 4 confirmed cases (including one culture-positive\ncase, one PCR-positive case, and 2 epidemiologically linked cases) and 13\nprobable cases; 10 patients were males. Although the fastidious _B. pertussis_ bacterium often cannot be\nisolated, to confirm diagnosis in symptomatic adults, health-care providers\nshould obtain a nasopharyngeal aspirate or swab for _B. pertussis_ culture\nwithin 2 weeks of cough onset. Community cases were identified\nthrough standard IDPH case report forms submitted by health-care providers\nto CCHD for suspected cases of pertussis and then reviewed by the IDPH\nimmunization section to determine if the case definition was met. Despite increasing\nrecognition of pertussis as a disease affecting older children and adults,\npertussis often is overlooked in the differential diagnosis of cough\nillness in this population (4). In Illinois, 46 of 191 cases (24 percent) of reported pertussis in 2001\noccurred in adults aged >20 years (incidence rate: 0.5 per 100 000\npopulation), a proportion similar to that of cases in the United States\namong this age group (1). A 14-day course of erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic with substantial in\nvitro and in vivo activity against _B. pertussis_, is the recommended\nantimicrobial for treatment of patients with pertussis and for prophylaxis\nof close contacts. Among the diseases for which universal childhood vaccination is recommended\nin the United States, only pertussis has increased in incidence in the\nUnited States during the preceding 20 years, from 1730 cases in 1980 to\n8296 cases provisionally reported in 2002 (1; CDC, unpublished data, 2002). 8 of 14 patients tested by a\nprivate diagnostic laboratory had serologic testing results (anti-_B.\npertussis_ IgA, IgM, or IgG enzyme immunoassay) suggestive of recent _B.\npertussis_ infection. In 1995,\nthe case definition for pertussis was expanded to include PCR-positive\ntests and epidemiologic linking of pertussis cases as confirmation\ncriteria. Because adults\nmight report to health-care providers late in the disease course, a\nstandardized and valid serologic test is needed to diagnose recent _B.\npertussis_ infection in adults (9). On 19 Sep 2002, with the cooperation of the oil\nrefinery management, 150 close work contacts of the 17 patients at the oil\nrefinery plant were prescribed azithromycin prophylaxis at a dose schedule\nof 500 mg for the first day, followed by 250 mg daily for the next 4 days. On 16 Sep 2002, the Crawford County Health Department (CCHD) reported to\nthe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) 4 cases of cough illness\namong workers at an oil refinery (total worker population: 750) in Crawford\nCounty, Illinois. Both patients\nwere referred to private health-care providers; blood samples from both\npatients had serologic test results suggestive of recent _Bordetella\npertussis_ infection, and CCHD was contacted. A pulsed-field gel electrophoresis\n(PFGE) DNA fingerprint from the _B. pertussis_ isolate from the\nculture-confirmed case (illness onset date: 10 Sep 2002) was PFGE profile\n13. Treatment and prophylaxis are most effective when\nerythromycin is administered to patients within 3 weeks of illness onset\nand to close contacts within 3 weeks of cough onset in the primary case\n(9). A clinical case was defined as an acute cough illness lasting >2 weeks in a\nperson with 1) at least one of the following: paroxysms of coughing,\ninspiratory 'whoop,' or post-tussive vomiting, without other apparent cause\nor 2) >14 days of cough in a person in an outbreak setting. [Given the changing epidemiology of pertussis in the USA, one wonders if\nand when the acellular pertussis vaccine, may become part of the\nonce-a-decade routine booster for tetanus-diphtheria (Td) to become TdaP.\n-Mods. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Adults and adolescents might be a reservoir for _B. pertussis_ in the\ncommunity, because immunity from childhood vaccination declines beginning\n5-15 years after the last pertussis vaccine dose (3). Adults with pertussis can have mild symptoms and might not seek medical\ncare, and clinicians might not consider pertussis as a cause of illness\n As one of several state health departments with enhanced pertussis\nsurveillance systems, IDPH analyzes _B. pertussis_ isolates from cases by\nPFGE. The outbreak described in this report reflects the changing demographics of\npertussis in the United States, with reported incidence rates in adults\nincreasing 400 percent during 1990-2001 (2; CDC, unpublished data, 2002). School officials and health-care providers within the community have\nbeen given guidelines on pertussis case recognition, reporting, and\nprophylaxis measures. Pertussis can be highly infectious during\nthe 3 weeks after illness onset, and infection can spread to exposed\ninfants, who have the highest rates for complications and death (5). In this outbreak, serologic testing for\ndiagnosis of recent _B. pertussis_ infection was performed in the majority\nof cases. Changing epidemiology of\npertussis in the United States: increasing reported incidence among\nadolescents and adults, 1990--1996. In addition, a possible increase in awareness of pertussis in\nolder age groups within the medical community during the 1990s might have\ncontributed to increased diagnosis rates in this population (7). A probable case met the clinical case definition, was not\nlaboratory-confirmed, and was not linked by direct contact with a\nlaboratory-confirmed case.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-09-18 00:00:00", "1730-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-01-10 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-09-10 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-12-13 00:00:00", "2027-10-24 20:02:00", "2003-01-09 00:00:00", "2002-08-14 00:00:00", "2002-09-16 00:00:00", "2002-09-19 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halperin SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202594", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (Texas)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202594", "date": "2002-09-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (TEXAS)\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 10:16:39 -0700 (PDT)\nFrom: H.Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>\nSource: HoustonChronicle.com [edited]\n<http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/story.hts/health/1587476>\n\nHealth officials fight outbreak of pertussis\n-------------------------------------\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Texas, and health officials in\nComal County are trying to stem an outbreak in which 5 children have\nrecently come down with the disease and 5 others may have it.\n'We've taken a real aggressive stance to try to keep it from getting out of\ncontrol,' said Comal County health nurse Karon Preiss. She said\ninformation has been sent home with schoolchildren, and doctors have been\nasked to be on the lookout for symptoms.\nSince January 2001, 9 children in Texas have died of the disease. A total\nof 615 cases were reported in Texas that year, the most since 1968. This\nyear, 766 cases already have been reported.\nThe number of reported cases is unusually high, according to David Bastis,\na program director in the immunization division of the Texas Department of\nHealth. 'Usually we see no deaths or one death,' he said.\n[Byline: Roger Croteau]\n--\nH.Larry Penning\n<hlpenning@yahoo.com>\n[The number of cases and deaths in this continuing outbreak of pertussis is\nquite noteworthy. It would be very informative to know the age and\nimmunization status of pertussis cases, particularly of the fatalities, as\nwell as the entire cohort of cases. Generally, 2 different circumstances\nare noted: children who were never adequately immunized against pertussis\nand those (often older children or adolescents) in whom the immunity of the\nprimary series they had received has waned. In both circumstances, it is\ncommon that adults with more atypical pertussis represent the reservoir to\ninfect the children. In addition to reaching 100 percent childhood\nimmunization, immunization of adults with the acellular pertussis vaccine,\nreasonably well tolerated in this group (unlike the old killed whole cell\nproduct), may be the answer.\nThis reference with abstract is an example of one study from Australia that\ndemonstrated the utility of the product in adults:\nTurnbull FM, Heath TC, Jalaludin BB, et al:A randomized trial of two\nacellular pertussis vaccines (dTpa and pa) and a licensed\ndiphtheria-tetanus vaccine (Td) in adults. Vaccine 2000; 19:628-36\nAbstract: A single blinded randomized controlled trial to compare the\nreactogenicity and immunogenicity of adult formulated dTpa and monovalent\npa vaccines with a licensed Td vaccine. 548 healthy adults aged 19-70 years\nreceived a single injection of dTpa or separate injections of pa or Td\n(with the alternate vaccine 1 month later). Local and systemic reactions\nwere monitored for 15 days after each vaccination. Serum antibody levels\nwere measured immediately prior to and 1 month after vaccination. Antibody\nlevels were measured 12 months after vaccination in 100 subjects. There was\nno difference in the total frequency of symptoms and signs between subjects\nreceiving any of the three vaccines. There was a significantly lower\nincidence of local reactions following pa (60 percent) than dTpa (80\npercent, P=0.002) or Td (93 percent, P=0.0008). The incidence of clinically\nsignificant (Grade 2 or 3) swelling (> or =20 mm) was higher for Td (20\npercent, P=0.002) than for dTpa (11 percent) or for pa (2 percent),\nhowever, there were no other significant differences in the incidence of\nGrade 2 or 3 reactions between the vaccines. A high anti-pertussis\nseroconversion rate (>97 percent) against all the studied pertussis\nantigens was seen 1 month after vaccination with dTpa and pa. A total of 96\nand 99 percent of subjects receiving dTpa and Td, respectively, had\nanti-diphtheria titres > or =0.01 IU/ml, and all but one subject had\nanti-tetanus titres > or =0.1 IU/ml after 1 month. Twelve months after\nvaccination the majority (90-100 percent) of the subjects were still\nseropositive for each antigen and although GMTs had decreased they were\nsubstantially higher than pre-vaccination levels. The dTpa vaccine was well\ntolerated and capable of eliciting an immune response against all the\nantigens in a broad spectrum of the adult population and could potentially\nreplace Td for routine boosters in adults. - Mod.LL]\n[Information on the age distribution and vaccination histories of the\nreported cases of pertussis in Texas was not available on the Texas State\nDepartment of Health webpages on\npertussis. <http://www.tdh.state.tx.us/immunize/pertussis.htm> There is\nmention that 30 percent of the reported cases in 2002 were in children less\nthan 1 year of age. There was a report available online that suggested\nthat several of the fatal cases were below one month of age and that the\nindex case in these households was probably an adult. More information on\nthe epidemiology of this increase in pertussis cases in Texas would be\nappreciated from official sources. One does wonder if the shortage of\nvaccine experienced in the earlier part of this year may have contributed\nto this outbreak. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 10:16:39 -0700 (PDT)\n The incidence of clinically\nsignificant (Grade 2 or 3) swelling (> or =20 mm) was higher for Td (20\npercent, P=0.002) than for dTpa (11 percent) or for pa (2 percent),\nhowever, there were no other significant differences in the incidence of\nGrade 2 or 3 reactions between the vaccines. This reference with abstract is an example of one study from Australia that\ndemonstrated the utility of the product in adults:\nTurnbull FM, Heath TC, Jalaludin BB, et al:A randomized trial of two\nacellular pertussis vaccines (dTpa and pa) and a licensed\ndiphtheria-tetanus vaccine (Td) in adults. [Byline: Roger Croteau]\n--\nH.Larry Penning\n<hlpenning@yahoo.com>\n In addition to reaching 100 percent childhood\nimmunization, immunization of adults with the acellular pertussis vaccine,\nreasonably well tolerated in this group (unlike the old killed whole cell\nproduct), may be the answer. [Information on the age distribution and vaccination histories of the\nreported cases of pertussis in Texas was not available on the Texas State\nDepartment of Health webpages on\npertussis.
