A total of 96\nand 99 percent of subjects receiving dTpa and Td, respectively, had\nanti-diphtheria titres > or =0.01 IU/ml, and all but one subject had\nanti-tetanus titres > or \nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Texas, and health officials in\nComal County are trying to stem an outbreak in which 5 children have\nrecently come down with the disease and 5 others may have it. The dTpa vaccine was well\ntolerated and capable of eliciting an immune response against all the\nantigens in a broad spectrum of the adult population and could potentially\nreplace Td for routine boosters in adults. A high anti-pertussis\nseroconversion rate (>97 percent) against all the studied pertussis\nantigens was seen 1 month after vaccination with dTpa and pa. There was a significantly lower\nincidence of local reactions following pa (60 percent) than dTpa (80\npercent, P=0.002) or Td (93 percent, P=0.0008). There is\nmention that 30 percent of the reported cases in 2002 were in children less\nthan 1 year of age. It would be very informative to know the age and\nimmunization status of pertussis cases, particularly of the fatalities, as\nwell as the entire cohort of cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "1968-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-01-25 00:00:00", "2002-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Comal County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201968", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis, school outbreak - UK (England) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201968", "date": "2002-06-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND) (04)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 12 Jun 2002\nFrom: Marjorie P. Pollack, MD <pollack@promedmail.org>\nAssociate Editor\nEpidemiology & Surveillance Moderator\nProMED-mail\n\nFor those of our readers not familiar with immunization program\nissues and discussions (not wanting to use the word 'controversy' in\nthis case), I thought it was important to elaborate a bit further on\nsome of the issues pertaining to pertussis vaccination and this\ncurrent outbreak in the UK.\nAs mentioned in prior postings on the changing epidemiology of\npertussis, the issue of waning immunity as a contributing factor for\ncontinuation of transmission of the disease is very much a topic of\ndiscussion and study, given the concerns about vaccination against\npertussis in older age groups (1,2). With the release of the\nacellular vaccine, studies are now showing the safety of\nadministration of this vaccine in older age groups. Other studies\nare being directed towards addressing the probable need to implement\npertussis boosters in older age groups (3).\nWhile waning immunity has been documented, there are conflicting\nreports in the literature of the duration of immunity following\nprimary immunization schedules. Many of these studies have measured\npertussis antibody levels by number of years following last pertussis\ndose (either primary series or after booster doses). One questions\nwhy we have not seen more outbreaks of pertussis in school-aged\nchildren in the developing world, where primary immunization with 3\ndoses of vaccine is the norm for the majority of the population.\n(One may argue that there probably is a significant problem, but\ndiagnosis of the disease in older children is less frequent, and\ntherefore reporting via disease surveillance systems is suboptimal to\nidentify this problem.)\nA note of caution on the interpretation of studies measuring duration\nof immunity. A 1997 Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices\nreport on the use of the acellular pertussis vaccine stated: 'It\nshould be mentioned that findings of efficacy studies have not\ndemonstrated a direct correlation between antibody responses and\nprotection against pertussis disease. However, antibody studies are\nuseful to compare immune responses elicited by a single vaccine under\ndifferent conditions or in different studies. Thus, efficacy studies\nare required to measure clinical protection conferred by each\npertussis vaccine.'\nWith respect to the outbreak in England, according to the newswire\nreports, only one of 87 students was not vaccinated. Assuming that\nthe unvaccinated child was one of the 23 reported cases, the\nestimated vaccine efficacy in this outbreak would be 74 percent,\nsomewhat decreased from a reported vaccine efficacy of approximately\n80 percent following 3 doses of the whole-cell vaccine.\nIn a recent MMWR article on the trends in pertussis in the USA, the\nauthors noted that the pertussis incidence continues to increase in\ninfants too young to receive 3 doses of pertussis-containing vaccine\nand in adolescents and adults (4). There was also reference to an\nobserved vaccine efficacy of 77-90 percent previously estimated using\nthe screening method (surveillance data) for whole-cell vaccine\nduring 1992--1994, comparing it to an observed vaccine efficacy of 88\npercent in 1998/1999. This observed efficacy range for the\nwhole-cell pertussis vaccine is not far off from the estimated\nvaccine efficacy in this current outbreak.\nOf additional mention is a study on an outbreak in the Netherlands in\n1996, which noted a probable decrease in vaccine efficacy among the\n1- to 4-year-old population. (The term 'probable' is being used, as\nthere was the question of possible increased reporting of cases that\nwas never fully resolved.) In this case, it was postulated that\nthere may have been changes in the pertussis organism in circulation\n(8,9).\nHence, one might question the actual etiology of this current\noutbreak of pertussis in a highly immunized population. Is it a\nwarning that a primary series of 3 doses of pertussis vaccine can\nresult in a vaccine efficacy that is too low to impact on disease\ntransmission? Is it a wake-up call for the need to further adjust\nimmunization schedules so that all children in primary schools in the\nUK receive at least 4 doses of pertussis vaccine (3 doses DPT, and 1\nbooster DaPT), thus highlighting the need for catchup boosters for\nchildren attending school prior to the addition of the school entry\ndose in the office immunization schedule in the UK? Or could we be\ndetecting the presence of a changing organism, as postulated in the\nDutch experience?\nLest we fall victim to becoming a listserve on immunization\npractices, this thread is now cut. - Mod.MPP\n1. Blennow M, Granstrom M., Long term serologic follow-up after\npertussis immunization. Pediatr Infect Dis J 1990 Jan;9(1):21-6\n2. Esposito S, Agliardi T, Giammanco A, Faldella G, Cascio A, Bosis\nS, Friscia O, Clerici M, Principi N. Long-term pertussis-specific\nimmunity after primary vaccination with a combined diphtheria,\ntetanus, tricomponent acellular pertussis, and hepatitis B vaccine in\ncomparison with that after natural infection. Infect Immun 2001\nJul;69(7):4516-20\n3. Hewlett EL. Pertussis in adults: possible use of booster doses\nfor control. Tokai J Exp Clin Med 1988;13 Suppl:125-8\n4. Pertussis--United States, 1997-2000. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep\n2002 Feb 1;51(4):73-6\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm>\n5. Pertussis Vaccination: Use of Acellular Pertussis Vaccines Among\nInfants and Young Children Recommendations of the Advisory Committee\non Immunization Practices (ACIP) MMWR 28 Mar 1997 / 46(RR-7);1-25\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00048610.htm>\n6. Khetsuriani N, Bisgard K, Prevots DR, Brennan M, Wharton M, Pandya\nS, Poppe A, Flora K, Dameron G, Quinlisk P. Pertussis outbreak in\nan elementary school with high vaccination coverage. Pediatr Infect\nDis J 2001 Dec;20(12):1108-12\n8. Mooi FR, van Loo IH, King AJ. Adaptation of Bordetella pertussis\nto vaccination: a cause for its reemergence? Emerg Infect Dis\n2001;7(3 Suppl):526-8\n9. de Melker HE, Conyn-van Spaendonck MAE, R\u00fcmke HC, van Wijngaarden\nJK, Mooi FR, Schellekens JFP. Pertussis in the Netherlands: an\nOutbreak Despite High Levels of Immunization with Whole-Cell Vaccine.\n1997: EID 3:2\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol3no2/melker.htm>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "From: Marjorie P. Pollack, MD <pollack@promedmail.org>\nAssociate Editor\nEpidemiology & Surveillance Moderator\nProMED-mail\n\nFor those of our readers not familiar with immunization program\nissues and discussions (not wanting to use the word 'controversy' in\nthis case), I thought it was important to elaborate a bit further on\nsome of the issues pertaining to pertussis vaccination and this\ncurrent outbreak in the UK. Is it a wake-up call for the need to further adjust\nimmunization schedules so that all children in primary schools in the\nUK receive at least 4 doses of pertussis vaccine (3 doses DPT, and 1\nbooster DaPT), thus highlighting the need for catchup boosters for\nchildren attending school prior to the addition of the school entry\ndose in the office immunization schedule in the UK? Assuming that\nthe unvaccinated child was one of the 23 reported cases, the\nestimated vaccine efficacy in this outbreak would be 74 percent,\nsomewhat decreased from a reported vaccine efficacy of approximately\n80 percent following 3 doses of the whole-cell vaccine. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A 1997 Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices\nreport on the use of the acellular pertussis vaccine stated: 'It\nshould be mentioned that findings of efficacy studies have not\ndemonstrated a direct correlation between antibody responses and\nprotection against pertussis disease. There was also reference to an\nobserved vaccine efficacy of 77-90 percent previously estimated using\nthe screening method (surveillance data) for whole-cell vaccine\nduring 1992--1994, comparing it to an observed vaccine efficacy of 88\npercent in 1998/1999. Esposito S, Agliardi T, Giammanco A, Faldella G, Cascio A, Bosis\nS, Friscia O, Clerici M, Principi N. Long-term pertussis-specific\nimmunity after primary vaccination with a combined diphtheria,\ntetanus, tricomponent acellular pertussis, and hepatitis B vaccine in\ncomparison with that after natural infection. As mentioned in prior postings on the changing epidemiology of\npertussis, the issue of waning immunity as a contributing factor for\ncontinuation of transmission of the disease is very much a topic of\ndiscussion and study, given the concerns about vaccination against\npertussis in older age groups (1,2). One questions\nwhy we have not seen more outbreaks of pertussis in school-aged\nchildren in the developing world, where primary immunization with 3\ndoses of vaccine is the norm for the majority of the population.\n In a recent MMWR article on the trends in pertussis in the USA, the\nauthors noted that the pertussis incidence continues to increase in\ninfants too young to receive 3 doses of pertussis-containing vaccine\nand in adolescents and adults (4). Is it a\nwarning that a primary series of 3 doses of pertussis vaccine can\nresult in a vaccine efficacy that is too low to impact on disease\ntransmission? This observed efficacy range for the\nwhole-cell pertussis vaccine is not far off from the estimated\nvaccine efficacy in this current outbreak.\n (One may argue that there probably is a significant problem, but\ndiagnosis of the disease in older children is less frequent, and\ntherefore reporting via disease surveillance systems is suboptimal to\nidentify this problem.) Or could we be\ndetecting the presence of a changing organism, as postulated in the\nDutch experience?\n MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep\n2002 Feb 1;51(4):73-6\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm>\n5. Many of these studies have measured\npertussis antibody levels by number of years following last pertussis\ndose (either primary series or after booster doses). Thus, efficacy studies\nare required to measure clinical protection conferred by each\npertussis vaccine.' With the release of the\nacellular vaccine, studies are now showing the safety of\nadministration of this vaccine in older age groups. Other studies\nare being directed towards addressing the probable need to implement\npertussis boosters in older age groups (3).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis b", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-06-12 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201898", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis, school outbreak - UK (England) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201898", "date": "2002-05-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND) (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thurs, 30 May 2002 09:46:27 -0500\nFrom: Brad Walsh <epibeemie@hotmail.com>\n\nre: school pertussis outbreak in the UK\n---------------------------------------\nThis public health outbreak response creates an opportunity for a natural\nexperiment in the sensitivity of the culture for _B. pertussis_ bacteria.\nThe culture is said to be notoriously inaccurate in routine clinical use.\nSometimes the poor results are blamed on less-than-ideal handling/shipping\nconditions, or on the (presumed) fastidiousness of the organism. In this\nsetting, where we can assume a high proportion of actual infections, the\nnumber of culture positives achieved will be interesting. I hope we hear\nfrom public health authorities what the aggregate test results are. In some\npediatric settings in the US, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are\nbeing used instead of cultures. One pediatric hospital in Fort Worth, Texas\nhas switched over to PCR entirely. The jury is still out on whether these\nare more sensitive and specific, although I have heard the Fort Worth\nhospital is happy with the change.\n--\nBrad Walsh\nParkland Health & Hospital System\nDallas, Texas, USA\n<epibeemie@hotmail.com>\n[Although culture of _B. pertussis_ on specific media has been considered\nto be the gold standard for diagnosis, its sensitivity is limited,\nparticularly if the patient has received antimicrobial therapy. In\naddition, even if positive, the results take 5 to 7 days, as this Gram\nnegative bacillus is slow-growing. Dr Walsh points out that PCR can be a\nmore rapid and more sensitive alternative to diagnosis.\nAs an example, using TaqMan PCR technology, a recent report from the\nProvincial Laboratory in Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada (1) found the\nfollowing in comparing PCR and culture:\nParameter / PCR (percentage) / culture (percentage)\nSensitivity / 100 / 11.6\nSpecificity / 97.4 / 100\nPositive predictive value / 87.6 / 100\nNegative predictive value / 100 / 85.7\nAverage time for positive test / 2.3 days / 5.1 days\nThat PCR can be useful in diagnosis of pertussis even while on treatment\nwas shown by Edelman, et al. (2): PCR was positive for as long as 7 days\nafter therapy was begun and the culture was no longer positive. This\ntechnology, especially with the use of multiple primers, may speed the\ndiagnosis and therefore the control of this infection.\n1. Chan EL, Antonishyn N, McDonald R, et al. The use of TaqMan PCR assay\nfor detection of Bordetella pertussis infection from clinical specimens.\nArch Pathol Lab Med 2002; 126: 173-6.\n2. Edelman K, Nikkari S, Ruuskanen O, et al. Detection of Bordetella\npertussis by polymerase chain reaction and culture in the nasopharynx of\nerythromycin-treated infants with pertussis. Pediatr Infect Dis J 1996; 15:\n54-7. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nBrad Walsh\nParkland Health & Hospital System\nDallas, Texas, USA\n<epibeemie@hotmail.com>\n Sensitivity / 100 / 11.6\nSpecificity / 97.4 / 100\nPositive predictive value / 87.6 / 100\nNegative predictive value / 100 / 85.7\n As an example, using TaqMan PCR technology, a recent report from the\nProvincial Laboratory in Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada (1) found the\nfollowing in comparing PCR and culture:\nParameter / PCR (percentage) / culture (percentage)\n [Although culture of _B. pertussis_ on specific media has been considered\nto be the gold standard for diagnosis, its sensitivity is limited,\nparticularly if the patient has received antimicrobial therapy. Detection of Bordetella\npertussis by polymerase chain reaction and culture in the nasopharynx of\nerythromycin-treated infants with pertussis. In\naddition, even if positive, the results take 5 to 7 days, as this Gram\nnegative bacillus is slow-growing. In this\nsetting, where we can assume a high proportion of actual infections, the\nnumber of culture positives achieved will be interesting. This\ntechnology, especially with the use of multiple primers, may speed the\ndiagnosis and therefore the control of this infection. In some\npediatric settings in the US, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are\nbeing used instead of cultures. PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND) (02)\n**********************************************\n The jury is still out on whether these\nare more sensitive and specific, although I have heard the Fort Worth\nhospital is happy with the change.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-05-30 00:00:00", "2054-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Worth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Regina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201894", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, school outbreak - UK (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201894", "date": "2002-05-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 May 2002, 1350 GMT\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/uk/england/newsid_2014000/2014708.stm>\n\nWhooping cough at a primary school in Leicestershire\n----------------------------------------------------\nA primary school in Leicestershire [in the East Midlands of England. -\nMod.SH] has reported an outbreak of whooping cough. The disease has been\ncontracted by 23 pupils at Stathern School in the Vale of Belvoir. Several\nother children also have the early symptoms of infection. All the pupils\nand staff at the school are being given antimicrobials and a full\nimmunization program is being carried out.\nThe outbreak first came to light last week and officials from\nLeicestershire Health Authority were sent in to investigate. Dr Philip\nMonk, consultant in communicable disease control, said: 'Within the school\nthere are currently a total of 23 confirmed and probable cases of whooping\ncough. In addition a number of children have early symptoms which are\nsuggestive of the disease.'\n'We visited the school last Thursday (23 May 2002) to carry out tests and\ngave all the children and teachers antimicrobial treatment to control the\nspread of the disease. In addition, all the children at Stathern Primary\nSchool have been given a booster vaccination against whooping cough to\nfurther protect them.'\nAuthorities also report that the entire school is being cultured for\n_Bordetella pertussis_.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Reports of clusters of pertussis continue to occur in various parts of the\ndeveloped world. The age of the affected students is not stated but,\nassuming adherence to standard immunization protocols [94 per cent of\nchildren aged 2 years in England and Wales have received three doses of\npertussis vaccine. -Mod.SH], it is likely that the cluster is related to\nwaning immunity from primary immunization. No mention is made of cases in\nadults with household contact to the students either as a primary or\nsecondary case. Immunization of contacts with the acellular pertussis\nvaccine should be effective in this outbreak, but it is likely that\nclusters such as this one will continue until boosters of the vaccine are\nnot in short supply and given routinely every 10 years with adult Td toxoid\nvaccine. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Immunization of contacts with the acellular pertussis\nvaccine should be effective in this outbreak, but it is likely that\nclusters such as this one will continue until boosters of the vaccine are\nnot in short supply and given routinely every 10 years with adult Td toxoid\nvaccine. - Mod. The age of the affected students is not stated but,\nassuming adherence to standard immunization protocols [94 per cent of\nchildren aged 2 years in England and Wales have received three doses of\npertussis vaccine. We visited the school last Thursday (23 May 2002) to carry out tests and\ngave all the children and teachers antimicrobial treatment to control the\nspread of the disease. In addition, all the children at Stathern Primary\nSchool have been given a booster vaccination against whooping cough to\nfurther protect them.' Source: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/uk/england/newsid_2014000/2014708.stm>\n\nWhooping cough at a primary school in Leicestershire\n All the pupils\nand staff at the school are being given antimicrobials and a full\nimmunization program is being carried out. No mention is made of cases in\nadults with household contact to the students either as a primary or\nsecondary case. PERTUSSIS, SCHOOL OUTBREAK - UK (ENGLAND)\n*****************************************\n --\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-05-29 00:00:00", "1350-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-05-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belvoir", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201743", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, neurological complications - RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201743", "date": "2002-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, NEUROLOGICAL COMPLICATIONS - RFI\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 6 May 2002\nFrom: Joyce Oliver <joliver@mail.mcg.edu>\n\nI would appreciate comments from anyone with experience involving\nunusual complications from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection. I am\nparticularly interested in information regarding neurological\ncomplications. We have a patient who is currently on a respirator\nwith encephalitis that thus far has tested negative for all of the\nusual culprits, i.e. Herpes, arboviruses, rabies, etc. The patient\nhad a week or 2 of a 'sinus infection' which then turned into\nvomiting for an additional week, and then evolved into 'mental status\nchanges.'\nShe is a 32-year-old kindergarten teacher with no additional history\nthat is remarkable. The only laboratory result that has been of\ninterest is an extremely high titer (serum) of IgM antibody to _B.\npertussis_ from a commercial laboratory. The original whole-cell _B.\npertussis_ vaccine was notorious for causing neurological\nconsequences, and I have had a difficult time finding information\nregarding the mechanism for this neurological association!\nApparently the organism itself has, on rare occasions, been\nassociated with encephalitis as a consequence of some of the toxins\nthat are produced. We have had other cases of encephalitis in which\nthe etiology has remained elusive. Historically, we have not\nroutinely tested these encephalitis cases for _Bordetella pertussis_.\nAdditional information which may be of interest, is that the patient\nhas tested negative for _B. pertussis_ by nasal aspirate PCR and has\nbeen negative on various cultures. The organism, from my\nunderstanding, remains within the confines of the respiratory tract,\nand patients generally do not become bacteremic. Failure to culture,\nor identify with PCR does not exclusively rule out infection,\nespecially when the testing is done well into the course of illness.\nAny and all comments regarding the association of _B. pertussis_ with\nneurological disease, and with the mechanism for neurological\ncomplications from vaccination, would be much appreciated.\n--\nJoyce Oliver, MT(ASCP),SI\nClinical Immunology Supervisor\nMedical College of Georgia, Health Inc.\nAugusta, GA 30912\ne-mail: <joliver@mail.mcg.edu>\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate reader comments on the neurological\ncomplications of pertussis, especially in adults. Although most of\nthe recent literature in this area deals with potential neurological\nevents associated with pertussis vaccination, it is clear that CNS\nabnormalities are not rare in younger children infected with\npertussis. In one report in children under 12 months of age in the\n1980s who were hospitalized with pertussis, 3 percent had seizures\nand 0.9 percent had an encephalopathy (ref 1). The mechanism of CNS\ndisease in pertussis is undefined, but among possibilities (ref. 2)\ninclude CNS hemorrhage from increased intracranial pressure during\ncough paroxysms, hypoxia during paroxysms, vascular occlusion due to\nleukocyte or platelet 'activation', a direct effect of a pertussis on\nthe CNS, and inflammation of the CNS enhanced by the adjuvant effect\nof a pertussis toxin.\nEncephalopathy from pertussis has been described in an adult who had\ncough paroxysms (see Ref. 3). His symptoms were seizures, brief loss\nof consciousness, and confusion. Of interest, this patient's\ndiagnosis was confirmed by serological tests, as in the Ms. Oliver\npresents. Usually, the antibody testing is used for serosurveys, not\nindividual diagnoses. The case outlined in the current posting also\ndid not seem to have the cough paroxysms seen in most of the CNS\ncomplications of pertussis, ruling out the first 2 causes suggested\nabove.\n1. Farzio KM, Cochi SL, Zell ER, et al: Epidemiological features of\npertussis in the United States, 1980-1989. Clin Infect Dis 1992; 14:\n708-19.\n2. Hewlett EL: Bordetella pertussis and the central nervous system.\nIn: Infections of the Central Nervous System. Scheld WM, Whitley RJ,\nDurack DT (eds.). Raven Press, NY, 1991, pp 625-53.\n3. Halperin SA, Marrie TJ: Pertussis encephalopathy in an adult: case\nreport and review. Rev Infect Dis 1991; 13: 1043-47.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "2)\ninclude CNS hemorrhage from increased intracranial pressure during\ncough paroxysms, hypoxia during paroxysms, vascular occlusion due to\nleukocyte or platelet 'activation', a direct effect of a pertussis on\nthe CNS, and inflammation of the CNS enhanced by the adjuvant effect\nof a pertussis toxin. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although most of\nthe recent literature in this area deals with potential neurological\nevents associated with pertussis vaccination, it is clear that CNS\nabnormalities are not rare in younger children infected with\npertussis. The original whole-cell _B.\npertussis_ vaccine was notorious for causing neurological\nconsequences, and I have had a difficult time finding information\nregarding the mechanism for this neurological association!\n The case outlined in the current posting also\ndid not seem to have the cough paroxysms seen in most of the CNS\ncomplications of pertussis, ruling out the first 2 causes suggested\nabove. The patient\nhad a week or 2 of a 'sinus infection' which then turned into\nvomiting for an additional week, and then evolved into 'mental status\nchanges.' Failure to culture,\nor identify with PCR does not exclusively rule out infection,\nespecially when the testing is done well into the course of illness.\n Any and all comments regarding the association of _B. pertussis_ with\nneurological disease, and with the mechanism for neurological\ncomplications from vaccination, would be much appreciated. In one report in children under 12 months of age in the\n1980s who were hospitalized with pertussis, 3 percent had seizures\nand 0.9 percent had an encephalopathy (ref 1). Additional information which may be of interest, is that the patient\nhas tested negative for _B. pertussis_ by nasal aspirate PCR and has\nbeen negative on various cultures. The only laboratory result that has been of\ninterest is an extremely high titer (serum) of IgM antibody to _B.\npertussis_ from a commercial laboratory. PERTUSSIS, NEUROLOGICAL COMPLICATIONS - RFI\n******************************************\n We have a patient who is currently on a respirator\nwith encephalitis that thus far has tested negative for all of the\nusual culprits, i.e. Herpes, arboviruses, rabies, etc. I am\nparticularly interested in information regarding neurological\ncomplications. Apparently the organism itself has, on rare occasions, been\nassociated with encephalitis as a consequence of some of the toxins\nthat are produced.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis", "rabies"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-05-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cochi SL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halperin SA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201764", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA ex Russia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201764", "date": "2002-05-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA EX RUSSIA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 May 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR 51(18);394-5 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5118a3.htm>\n\nPublic Health Dispatch: Pertussis in an Infant Adopted from Russia -- May\n2002\n------------------------------------------------------\nOn 2 May 2002, the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services\nnotified CDC about an infant aged 10 months adopted from Russia who had\nculture-confirmed pertussis diagnosed. On 8 Apr 2002, the adoptive parents\npicked him up in the orphan ward at hospital A in Bryansk and noticed that\nthe child had upper respiratory congestion and cough. The adoptive parents\nreported that the infant had not received any vaccinations and that another\ninfant living in the same room in hospital A had a severe cough. The\nadopted infant subsequently was examined by a local physician, who\ndiagnosed his condition as a 'cold,' and the infant was taken to the U.S.\nEmbassy in Moscow, where the parents were interviewed for an immigrant visa\nfor the child.\nOn 24 Apr 2002, the infant and his parents traveled from Moscow to Raleigh,\nNorth Carolina, through New York on commercial airline flights. On 26 Apr\n2002, the infant was seen as an outpatient at a local clinic; a culture of\na nasopharyngeal swab confirmed infection with _Bordetella pertussis_. The\ninfant improved after treatment with clarithromycin and was administered\nthe first dose of diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and acellular pertussis\nvaccine (DTaP). The parents were placed on azithromycin for prophylaxis.\nCDC is collaborating with the U.S. Embassy, adoption agencies, visa\napplicant medical clinics in Moscow, and the airline to identify and notify\npersons who might have been exposed to the infant during his communicable\nperiod. The airline is working to identify those passengers who might have\nbeen exposed to the infant during his flights to North Carolina. CDC is\ncollaborating with state health departments, who are notifying and ensuring\nappropriate chemoprophylaxis and vaccination for exposed passengers in\ntheir jurisdiction.\nHealth-care providers and public health officials are advised to consider\npertussis when evaluating or notified of a person with an acute illness\ncharacterized by cough with paroxysms, whoop, or post-tussive gagging or\nvomiting. Following are CDC guidelines on the management of patients with\npertussis and their contacts:\nFor symptomatic patients, test by culture of nasopharyngeal aspirate or\nswab; a nasopharyngeal Dacron swab should be used. Swabs or aspirate should\nbe placed in Regan Lowe transport media if direct inoculation of selective\nmedia is not possible.\nFor hospitalized patients, respiratory isolation (droplet precautions) is\nrecommended for at least the first 5 days of antimicrobial treatment.\nFor symptomatic patients, the treatment of choice for pertussis is\nerythromycin for 14 days. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxozole is an alternative\nantibiotic. Limited clinical data suggest that newer macrolides, such as\nazithromycin for 5-7 days or clarithromycin for 14 days, might be as\neffective as erythromycin in the treatment of pertussis and are\nalternatives for patients who cannot tolerate erythromycin.\nFor exposed persons, chemoprophylaxis is recommended to limit secondary\ntransmission. Exposure is defined as having face-to-face contact, having\ndirect contact with respiratory, oral, or nasal secretions, or being in the\nsame room with a coughing pertussis case-patient. The recommended\nchemoprophylaxis regimen is erythromycin for 14 days. Alternative therapies\nare the same as for symptomatic patients.\nPertussis vaccination should be initiated or continued according to the\nrecommended schedule for exposed children aged under 7 years who are\nundervaccinated or who have received fewer than 4 DTaP doses. Exposed\nchildren may receive DTaP dose 2 or 3 if 4 weeks have elapsed after dose 1\nor 2, respectively. Children may receive DTaP dose 4 as early as age 12\nmonths, and preferably 6 months after dose 3. Children should be\nadministered DTaP dose 5 unless a dose was given within the last 3 years or\nthey are aged over 7 years.\nAdditional information about pertussis is available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nip/publications/pertussis/guide.htm>\nReported by: see Source URL.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The occurrence of pertussis in an unvaccinated child is not unusual in\nmany parts of the world. This event serves as a reminder to all of us of\nthe continued importance of pertussis as a childhood disease in areas of\nthe world where childhood immunization coverages are not at adequate levels\nto affect transmission. This case also begs the question of whether\nchildhood vaccinations should be part of pre-adoptive recommendations,\nespecially for children coming from countries where childhood vaccination\nlevels are lower. Given the huge effort involved in tracing this child's\ncontacts en route from Russia to the USA/NC, one wonders if this might have\nbeen somewhat prevented by a vaccination requirement similar to the school\nentry requirements all states currently have. Granted the vaccine does not\nhave 100 percent efficacy and therefore there is no guarantee that\npertussis in this child specifically could have been prevented (just trying\nto preempt some reader comments here), but it still seems like a reasonable\ntopic of discussion. (Why do I think I'm now opening myself up to a\nbarrage of emails in response to this?) - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 May 2002\n The\nadopted infant subsequently was examined by a local physician, who\ndiagnosed his condition as a 'cold,' and the infant was taken to the U.S.\nEmbassy in Moscow, where the parents were interviewed for an immigrant visa\nfor the child. \nHealth-care providers and public health officials are advised to consider\npertussis when evaluating or notified of a person with an acute illness\ncharacterized by cough with paroxysms, whoop, or post-tussive gagging or\nvomiting. Granted the vaccine does not\nhave 100 percent efficacy and therefore there is no guarantee that\npertussis in this child specifically could have been prevented (just trying\nto preempt some reader comments here), but it still seems like a reasonable\ntopic of discussion. Limited clinical data suggest that newer macrolides, such as\nazithromycin for 5-7 days or clarithromycin for 14 days, might be as\neffective as erythromycin in the treatment of pertussis and are\nalternatives for patients who cannot tolerate erythromycin. This event serves as a reminder to all of us of\nthe continued importance of pertussis as a childhood disease in areas of\nthe world where childhood immunization coverages are not at adequate levels\nto affect transmission. CDC is collaborating with the U.S. Embassy, adoption agencies, visa\napplicant medical clinics in Moscow, and the airline to identify and notify\npersons who might have been exposed to the infant during his communicable\nperiod. This case also begs the question of whether\nchildhood vaccinations should be part of pre-adoptive recommendations,\nespecially for children coming from countries where childhood vaccination\nlevels are lower. Given the huge effort involved in tracing this child's\ncontacts en route from Russia to the USA/NC, one wonders if this might have\nbeen somewhat prevented by a vaccination requirement similar to the school\nentry requirements all states currently have. CDC is\ncollaborating with state health departments, who are notifying and ensuring\nappropriate chemoprophylaxis and vaccination for exposed passengers in\ntheir jurisdiction. Swabs or aspirate should\nbe placed in Regan Lowe transport media if direct inoculation of selective\nmedia is not possible.\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n On 2 May 2002, the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services\nnotified CDC about an infant aged 10 months adopted from Russia who had\nculture-confirmed pertussis diagnosed. Pertussis vaccination should be initiated or continued according to the\nrecommended schedule for exposed children aged under 7 years who are\nundervaccinated or who have received fewer than 4 DTaP doses. On 26 Apr\n2002, the infant was seen as an outpatient at a local clinic; a culture of\na nasopharyngeal swab confirmed infection with _Bordetella pertussis_. The adoptive parents\nreported that the infant had not received any vaccinations and that another\ninfant living in the same room in hospital A had a severe cough.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-05-25 00:00:00", "2002-05-02 00:00:00", "2002-05-10 00:00:00", "2002-04-24 00:00:00", "2002-04-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bryansk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Regan Lowe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201738", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, worldwide increase, change in epi. (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201738", "date": "2002-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, WORLDWIDE INCREASE, CHANGE IN EPIDEMIOLOGY (02)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2201742", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, worldwide increase, change in epi. (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201742", "date": "2002-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, WORLDWIDE INCREASE, CHANGE IN EPIDEMIOLOGY (03)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 6 May 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource:Herald Sun (Australia) [edited]\n\n\nBabies Facing Disease Threat\n--------------------------------------\nA new report from the Australian Pediatric Surveillance Unit warns\nthat adults are unknowingly exposing their newborn infants to\nwhooping cough, because they are unaware that as adults, they can\nstill contract the disease. Over the past 2 years, 9 infants have\ndied from whooping cough in Australia, and the report found that over\nhalf of all reported cases are researchers are calling for greater\nuse of adult booster shots.\nDr. Peter McIntyre, deputy director of the National Center for\nImmunization Research, noted that adults should be aware that they,\ntoo, can become infected with pertussis, adding that 'anyone who is\nthinking about getting pregnant or who has just had a baby should\nthink seriously about having a booster.'\n[Byline: Evonne Barry]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 May 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Vancouver Province [edited]\n\n\nWhooping Cough Spreads\n------------------------------\nHealth officials in British Columbia, Canada, last week declared an\nepidemic of pertussis in Fraser Valley. There have been 29 cases\nalready this year (2002), and last year there were 86 confirmed cases\nof the disease -- up significantly from the 20 cases recorded in\n2000. In the past 2 months, there have only been 2 cases recorded in\nVancouver, where the immunization rate for children is over 90\npercent; however, most of the Valley cases are in Chilliwack and\nAgassiz, where the immunization rate for toddlers is just 71 percent.\nDr. Andrew Larder, a medical officer in Fraser Valley, said Friday\nthat the spread of the disease is likely because there are many\n'conscientious objectors' to vaccines in the Valley, as well as a\nlarge number of children who have been vaccinated but who have since\nlost the 5-year immunity the shot affords [indicating, I think, that\nthe boosters for starting school were not always given. - Mod.LL].\n[Byline: Christina Montgomery]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The above represent additional reports of the increasing recognition\nof pertussis reservoirs in adults (Australia) and increasing\npertussis (Canada). Undoubtedly lower-than-ideal DTaP vaccination\ncoverage in children and waning vaccine immunity in adults are major\nfactors. Several reports have questioned whether the organism itself\nhas become able to break though vaccine protection. If that were the\ncase, however, there should be more cases in fully immunized young\nchildren. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Dr. Andrew Larder, a medical officer in Fraser Valley, said Friday\nthat the spread of the disease is likely because there are many\n'conscientious objectors' to vaccines in the Valley, as well as a\nlarge number of children who have been vaccinated but who have since\nlost the 5-year immunity the shot affords [indicating, I think, that\nthe boosters for starting school were not always given. Dr. Peter McIntyre, deputy director of the National Center for\nImmunization Research, noted that adults should be aware that they,\ntoo, can become infected with pertussis, adding that 'anyone who is\nthinking about getting pregnant or who has just had a baby should\nthink seriously about having a booster.'\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In the past 2 months, there have only been 2 cases recorded in\nVancouver, where the immunization rate for children is over 90\npercent; however, most of the Valley cases are in Chilliwack and\nAgassiz, where the immunization rate for toddlers is just 71 percent. There have been 29 cases\nalready this year (2002), and last year there were 86 confirmed cases\nof the disease -- up significantly from the 20 cases recorded in\n2000. [Byline: Christina Montgomery]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< [The above represent additional reports of the increasing recognition\nof pertussis reservoirs in adults (Australia) and increasing\npertussis (Canada). Undoubtedly lower-than-ideal DTaP vaccination\ncoverage in children and waning vaccine immunity in adults are major\nfactors.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-05-06 00:00:00", "2002-05-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201776", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis - USA ex Russia (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201776", "date": "2002-05-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA EX RUSSIA (02)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 10 May 2002 20:48:39 +0300\nFrom: Stephen A. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on pertussis in the Russian Federation were\nabstracted from GIDEON.\nRoutine infant vaccination (DPT) is administered at ages 3, 4 to 5, 6 and\n18 months.\nYear / Cases reported / Vaccine coverage percent\n1991 / 30 876\n1992 / 24 004 / 73\n1993 / 39 218 / 79\n1994 / 48 614 / 88\n1995 / 20 626 / 78\n1996 / 13 842 / 84\n1997 / 27 279 / 88\n1998 / 28 045 / 91\n1999 / 22 222 / 95\n2000 / 29 983 / 97\n--\nStephen A. Berger, M.D.\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n[Once again Steve Berger keeps us honest with a reminder of the\ndata. Thank you Steve! The reported DPT3 coverage rate of 97 percent for\n2000 is impressive (DPT3 coverage rate refers to the percentage of children\nless than one year of age having received 3 or more doses of DPT), but\ndoesn't erase the discussion of whether vaccination histories of adoptive\nchildren should be reviewed prior to travel to their adoptive country. In\nfact, this particular case highlights pockets of unvaccinated in areas that\nhave high overall vaccination coverages.\nMore information on the status of the immunization program activities in the\nRussian Federation can be\nfound at the WHO Vaccines website:\n<http://www-nt.who.int/vaccines/GlobalSummary/Immunization/CountryProfileRes\nult.cfm>\n- Mod.MPP]\n***\n[2]\nDate: Sat, 11 May 2002 02:20:49 +0000\nFrom: 'padmanabhan badrinath' <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nWith reference to the posting on whooping cough in a child adopted from\nRussia the moderator states 'This case also begs the question of whether\nchildhood vaccinations should be part of pre-adoptive recommendations,\nespecially for children coming from countries where childhood vaccination\nlevels are lower'.\nUS immigration laws already require immigrant visa applicants (including\nadopted children) to obtain certain vaccinations prior to the issuance of an\nimmigrant visa. The vaccination requirement table from one of the US\nembassies (Korea) shows that DPT is required for children aged 2 months to 6\nyears.\nhttp://usembassy.state.gov/seoul/wwwh2420.html\nThe US government also has produced country specific flyers for prospective\nparents of adopted children. The flyer for Russia is available @\nhttp://www.travel.state.gov/adoption_russia.html\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,M.Phil,(Epid)PhD(Cantab)DFPHM(UK),MPH(Distinc)\nClinical Assistant Professor & Hon Consultant in Preventive Medicine,\nDepartment of Community Medicine,\nUAE University, PO Box 17666, Al Ain,\nUnited Arab Emirates\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[Checking the weblinks provided by Dr. Badrinath is very informative. The\ninformation for adoption of Russian children provides the names of\nphysicians who could care for the children if ill while waiting for\nadoption, including one physician who is listed as providing vaccinations.\nThe document from the US Embassy in Korea clearly states the immunization\nrequirements for adoptive children prior to getting a visa for entry in the\nUSA. 'Panel physicians who conduct medical examinations on behalf of\nimmigrant visa applicants are now required to verify that immigrant visa\napplicants have met the new vaccination requirement, or that it is medically\ninappropriate for the visa applicant to receive one or more of the listed\nvaccinations. Certain waivers of the vaccination requirement are available\nupon the recommendation of the panel physician.' Given the wording of this,\none wonders if the case discussed in the previous ProMED posting was a case\nthat was not vaccinated because of having been granted a waiver for one of\nthe stated acceptable reasons. - Mod. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The reported DPT3 coverage rate of 97 percent for\n2000 is impressive (DPT3 coverage rate refers to the percentage of children\nless than one year of age having received 3 or more doses of DPT), but\ndoesn't erase the discussion of whether vaccination histories of adoptive\nchildren should be reviewed prior to travel to their adoptive country. Panel physicians who conduct medical examinations on behalf of\nimmigrant visa applicants are now required to verify that immigrant visa\napplicants have met the new vaccination requirement, or that it is medically\ninappropriate for the visa applicant to receive one or more of the listed\nvaccinations. From: 'padmanabhan badrinath' <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nWith reference to the posting on whooping cough in a child adopted from\nRussia the moderator states 'This case also begs the question of whether\nchildhood vaccinations should be part of pre-adoptive recommendations,\nespecially for children coming from countries where childhood vaccination\nlevels are lower'. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-05-11 00:00:00", "2002-05-10 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "M.D.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Arab Emirates", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PO", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201796", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis - USA ex Russia (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201796", "date": "2002-05-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA EX RUSSIA (04)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 14 May 2002 14:33:32 -0400\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Moscow Times 14 May 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.moscowtimes.ru/stories/2002/05/14/013.html>\nAdopted Baby's Cough Puts Travelers at Risk\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA Russian baby who was adopted by an American family exposed fellow\ntravelers to highly contagious whooping cough as he was flown to his new\nhome in the United States on 24 Apr 2002, said health officials at the U.S.\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention, or CDC.\nThe CDC said it has contacted other passengers on the flights and advised\nthose who sat near the child to take antibiotics if they will be near young\nchildren. There has been no indication that anyone has been infected.\nA U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said one of the doctors accredited by the\nembassy to perform medical checks before visas are issued overlooked the\nwhooping cough, concluding the child had a common cold.\n'The child was 9 months old and had not been vaccinated. Since the embassy\nis allowed to waive those vaccinations, and the family signed an agreement\nto have the vaccinations done in the U.S., the visa was issued,' the\nspokeswoman said in an e-mail response to questions.\nIn its Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report last week, the CDC said the\nadoptive parents picked up the child, described as 10 months old, from an\norphan ward at a hospital in Bryansk on 8 Apr 2002. They noticed he had a\ncough, as did another baby in the same room.\nOn 24 Apr 2002, the baby flew with his adoptive parents from Moscow to New\nYork and on to Raleigh, North Carolina. On 26 Apr 2002, the baby was\ndiagnosed with whooping cough, and he and the parents have been treated,\nthe report said.\n'CDC is collaborating with the U.S. Embassy, adoption agencies, visa\napplicant medical clinics in Moscow, and the airline to identify anyone who\nmight have been exposed to the infant during his flights to North\nCarolina,' the report said. The CDC did not identify the airline or the\nparents.\nWhooping cough, also known as pertussis, is highly contagious, and can be\ntransmitted from personal contact and being close to an infected person who\nis coughing and sneezing, according to the CDC web site.\nKristy Murray-Lillibridge, the doctor in charge of the CDC's response to\nthe case, said the disease is widespread in Russia and the United States.\nAlthough the associated cough is easily recognized, a brief medical\nexamination could result in it being missed.\nAirline passengers are reasonably safe from the spread of disease because\naircraft ventilation systems filter out infected air, she said Monday in a\ntelephone interview from Atlanta, Georgia.\nThe CDC has contacted all 11 people who sat within 2 rows of the infant and\nhis family during the flights, she said. The main concern had been that\nthey could infect other infants, but no other children were within the\n2-seat range, she said. The flight to New York often has one or more\nadopted children among the passengers.\nEmbassy staff and adoption agency staff and other children who had been in\nthe Bryansk hospital were alerted to the infection, she added.\n[By Robin Munro]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[While this thread was closed yesterday, I'm exercising editor's\nprerogative, as this newswire article does provide more information on the\nbackground and vaccination history of the case discussed in the thread. In\naddition, the CDC statement that 'airline passengers are reasonably safe\nfrom the spread of disease because aircraft ventilation systems filter out\ninfected air' has kept me busy tracking down the available data. In recent\nyears there have been 2 documented instances of transmission of\ntuberculosis during airline flights (refs 1 & 6). In both instances\ntransmission was limited to close proximity to infected/contagious\nindividuals over a prolonged amount of time (greater than 8 hours). In\nother instances there were skin-test conversions (a sign of infection with\n_M. tuberculosis_) among airplane contacts, but results were inconclusive\nas to whether the airplane contact was responsible for the skin test\nconversion (as opposed to the person having been exposed prior to the\nairline flight).\nOther diseases that have been transmitted during airline flights include\ninfluenza and measles. The National Academy of Sciences study on The\nAirliner Cabin Environment and the Health of Passengers and Crew (2002)\n(ref 5) discussed that while the risk of spread of disease was\ntheoretically there, it was more likely to be associated with droplet\ninfection with the usual observed spread of droplet infections in closed\nenvironments. It did conclude that 'Presence of some infectious agent is\nlikely, but the frequency of exposures that result in infection is not\nknown.' and 'Little information is available on the transmission of\ninfectious agents on aircraft.'\n1: Whitlock G, Calder L, Perry H. A case of infectious tuberculosis on\ntwo long-haul aircraft flights: contact investigation. N Z Med J. 2001 Aug\n10;114(1137):353-5.\n2: CDC. Exposure to patients with meningococcal disease on\naircrafts--United States, 1999-2001. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2001 Jun\n15;50(23):485-9. <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm>\n3: Kenyon TA, Valway SE, Ihle WW, Onorato IM, Castro KG. Transmission of\nmultidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis during a long airplane\nflight. N Engl J Med. 1996 Apr 11;334(15):933-8.\n4: Wick RL Jr, Irvine LA. The microbiological composition of airliner\ncabin air. Aviat Space Environ Med. 1995 Mar;66(3):220-4.\n5: National Academy of Sciences report on cabin air quality. Aviat Space\nEnviron Med. 2002 Mar;73(3):319.\n(The full copy of this report from the National Academy Press can be read\nonline: Chapter 4 on Biologics is fairly extensive:\nThe Airliner Cabin Environment and the Health of Passengers and Crew\n(2002), The Airliner Cabin Environment and the Health of Passengers and\nCrew Committee on Air Quality in passenger Cabins of Commercial Aircraft,\nBoard on Environmental Studies and Toxicology, National Research Council\n<http://search.nap.edu/books/0309082897/html/>)\n6. CDC. Exposure of Passengers and Flight Crew to Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis on Commercial Aircraft, 1992-1995. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep.\n1995 Mar\n3;44(08);137-140. <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00036502.htm>\n\nOnce again this thread is closed. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "In\nother instances there were skin-test conversions (a sign of infection with\n_M. tuberculosis_) among airplane contacts, but results were inconclusive\nas to whether the airplane contact was responsible for the skin test\nconversion (as opposed to the person having been exposed prior to the\nairline flight). The Airliner Cabin Environment and the Health of Passengers and Crew\n(2002), The Airliner Cabin Environment and the Health of Passengers and\nCrew Committee on Air Quality in passenger Cabins of Commercial Aircraft,\nBoard on Environmental Studies and Toxicology, National Research Council\n<http://search.nap.edu/books/0309082897/html/>)\n6. [By Robin Munro]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org Airline passengers are reasonably safe from the spread of disease because\naircraft ventilation systems filter out infected air, she said Monday in a\ntelephone interview from Atlanta, Georgia. Source: The Moscow Times 14 May 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.moscowtimes.ru/stories/2002/05/14/013.html>\n (The full copy of this report from the National Academy Press can be read\nonline: Chapter 4 on Biologics is fairly extensive:\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-04-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-04-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-04-08 00:00:00", "2002-05-14 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bryansk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Castro KG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North \n Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New \n York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valway", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201790", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis - USA ex Russia (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201790", "date": "2002-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA EX RUSSIA (03)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon, 13 May 2002 13:25:09 -0400\nFrom: Robert Steinglass <rsteinglass@basics.org>\n\nI am replying to your posting on pertussis in Russia. I worked in 11\ncountries of the former Soviet Union, including Russia, starting from 1992\nuntil 1999 to provide technical support for vaccination programs. This\nwork was funded by USAID and carried out by the REACH and BASICS projects.\n\nIt will come as a surprise to most of your readers that most of the\ncountries of the former Soviet Union do not collect data on coverage with\n'DPT'. It is true that when reporting to international agencies, they\nreport their coverage invariably as DPT. However, these countries\ninternally reported, and most still report, coverage separately by each\nspecific antigen: that is, coverage with D, P, and T.\n\nIn the case of Russia, the difference between reported coverage with D and\ncoverage with P was significant, as much as 15 absolute percentage points\nin the late 1980s and early 1990s. This disparity reflected the concerns\ntypically heard from pediatricians that the DPT vaccine was 'too strong'\nand the children had become 'too weak' to be able to tolerate the pertussis\ncomponent of DPT. Consequently, many providers opted to use DT (and even Td\n!!) for pediatric immunization. Practitioners in the USA need to make\ncareful evaluation of adopted children's vaccination records to determine\nwhether or not they indeed received the pertussis component.\n\nThe countries of the former Soviet Union also never reported coverage on\nchildren under 12 months of age, which is the international standard. While\nthe countries of the former Soviet Union had an excellent system of\ntracking individual children in need of vaccination by pediatric catchment\nareas, they did not adopt this global standard of monitoring and reporting\nvaccination coverage by 12 months of age. Instead the numerator to\ncalculate coverage typically included children irrespective of age of\nvaccination and the denominator excluded the sizeable number of children\nwith permanent or temporary contraindications to vaccination. Consequently,\ntimely vaccination coverage was (and is) considerably less well reported in\nmany of these countries. In fact, as part of their applications for funding\nfrom GAVI (the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization), several of\nthe former Soviet countries conducted population-based 30-cluster\nvaccination coverage surveys. These surveys have all shown coverage by 12\nmonths of age to be about 20 percent (or more in some cases) lower than the\nreported figures.\n\nEach of these surveys also shows that the mean age of DPT vaccination is\nquite delayed, most likely due to the frequency of temporary contraindications.\n\nMuch of our work in collaboration with WHO was devoted to exposing these\nnew countries to recent developments in western science to guide policy\nreformulation, to encourage them to streamline their immunization\nschedules, to reduce their excessive lists of contraindications, and to\nestablish active monitoring systems (in Kyrgyzstan and Ukraine) so that\nhealth workers at all levels could indeed start to track their cumulative\nmonthly DPT coverage in infants. In most of the other countries of the\nformer Soviet Union, coverage is still monitored in the former Soviet\nfashion as described above.\n--\nRobert Steinglass\nImmunization Team Leader\nBASICS\n1600 Wilson Blvd., Suite 300\nArlington, VA. 22209\nUSA\n<rsteingl@basics.org>\n\n[Thank you very much for this clarification Robert. As someone who had\nworked fairly extensively in vaccination program activities internationally\n(but never in the Russian Federation), I still was unaware that the\npertussis component had been optionally removed as part of routine\nvaccination activities in that region. Hence, it is possible that many of\nthe children coming from the Russian Federation are behind in the pertussis\nvaccine component and that a careful review of the vaccination histories\nmight identify this. The additional information that many children's\nvaccinations are delayed for 'temporary reasons' may also explain the lower\ncoverages. Adjusting the reported coverage of 97 percent for the\ninformation from the coverage surveys would have the DPT coverages by age\n12 months to be approximately 77 percent overall, and indicative of the\nneed to improve vaccination activities, as well as highlighting the need to\ncarefully screen vaccination histories of children coming from the Russian\nFederation. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon, 13 May 2002 15:11:02 -0400\nFrom: Sharon Ludwig <SLudwig@comdt.uscg.mil>\n\nAlthough the immunization records of internationally adopted children are\ncarefully reviewed by the US Embassy and INS officials, the children are\noften routinely completely re-vaccinated when they visit their primary care\nphysician in the US. The same goes for pre-adoption screening for HIV,\nHepatitis B, and TB. CF: Aronson, Jane, 'Medical Evaluation and\nInfectious Considerations on Arrival' in 'Medical Issues in International\nAdoptions,' Pediatric Annals 29:4/April 2000\n\nApparently, the prevailing belief is that the records may be inaccurate and\nthe original records cannot be read by officials in US public schools (and\ncopies may not be considered official). It is simpler and safer to\nrevaccinate, even though it is rather traumatic for the already\nculture-shocked little new arrivals.\n--\nSharon L. Ludwig, MD MPH MA\nCommander, US Public Health Service\nChief, Operational Preventive Medicine/\nDisease Control Epidemiology\nUS Coast Guard Commandant (G-WKH-1)\n2100 Second Street SW\nWashington, DC 20593\n<sludwig@comdt.uscg.mil>\n\n[Taking into consideration the information given by Robert Steinglass\nabove, it does not appear to be unwise to consider revaccination as\nmentioned here. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sat, 11 May 2002 09:25:56 -0500\nFrom: R&M Whitworth <rmwhit@aaahawk.com>\n\nI write regarding the vaccination of adoptive children and the review of\nimmunization records prior to traveling to the adopted (or to be adopted)\nchild's country of origin. While every attempt is made to understand the\nadoptive child's health and needs before traveling, certain cultural\ndifferences, as well as governmental procedures, preclude obtaining all\ninformation one would like to have. The INS does require adoptive parents\nto obtain all immunizations, or start obtaining them, within the first 30\ndays after returning to the United States.\n\nThe American Medical Association also recommends that, in most cases, all\ninternationally adopted children repeat their immunization series once in\nthe US. (This was recently reported in the MMWR)\n--\nRandy G. Whitworth, R.Ph.\nClinical Pharmacist\n(and father to one girl from China, traveling in 3 days for the second)\n<rmwhit@aaahawk.com>\n\n[The MMWR issue mentioned by Randy G. Whitworth is: General Recommendations\non Immunization: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization\nPractices (ACIP) and the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP). 8\nFeb 2002. 51 (RR02);1-36\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5102a1.htm>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Mon, 13 May 2002 09:44:20 -0400\nFrom: ProMED-mail subscriber who wishes name to be withheld\n\nThe moderator posed the question about 'whether vaccination histories\nof adoptive children should be reviewed prior to travel to their adoptive\ncountry.'\n\nThey are! As a US parent of a child adopted from a Russian orphanage, I\ncan attest to the mountains of paperwork required and reviewed. The\nimmunization history is reviewed by a physician during the medical exam\nrequired to obtain a visa. Additionally, in order to obtain a visa, parents\nof young children must sign an affidavit that they will update and complete\nvaccinations upon return to the US. No measure will be 100 percent\neffective, but the mechanism for review of vaccine history is in place.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Clearly there are regulations in place that would ensure that adopted\nchildren are appropriately vaccinated for age prior to obtaining a visa for\nentry to the USA. But, as pointed out, no measure is 100 percent. The\nreference kindly provided by Dr. Sharon Ludwick demonstrates that the\npediatric community has recognized the special circumstances related to\ninternational adoptions. Having gotten the predicted barrage of emails in\nresponse to my comments, I think it's now time to cut this thread. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "\n\nMuch of our work in collaboration with WHO was devoted to exposing these\nnew countries to recent developments in western science to guide policy\nreformulation, to encourage them to streamline their immunization\nschedules, to reduce their excessive lists of contraindications, and to\nestablish active monitoring systems (in Kyrgyzstan and Ukraine) so that\nhealth workers at all levels could indeed start to track their cumulative\nmonthly DPT coverage in infants. Adjusting the reported coverage of 97 percent for the\ninformation from the coverage surveys would have the DPT coverages by age\n12 months to be approximately 77 percent overall, and indicative of the\nneed to improve vaccination activities, as well as highlighting the need to\ncarefully screen vaccination histories of children coming from the Russian\nFederation. --\nSharon L. Ludwig, MD MPH MA\nCommander, US Public Health Service\nChief, Operational Preventive Medicine/\nDisease Control Epidemiology\nUS Coast Guard Commandant (G-WKH-1)\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon, 13 May 2002 13:25:09 -0400\n \nRobert Steinglass\nImmunization Team Leader\nBASICS\n1600 Wilson Blvd., Suite 300\n However, these countries\ninternally reported, and most still report, coverage separately by each\nspecific antigen: that is, coverage with D, P, and T.\n\nIn the case of Russia, the difference between reported coverage with D and\ncoverage with P was significant, as much as 15 absolute percentage points\nin the late 1980s and early 1990s. While\nthe countries of the former Soviet Union had an excellent system of\ntracking individual children in need of vaccination by pediatric catchment\nareas, they did not adopt this global standard of monitoring and reporting\nvaccination coverage by 12 months of age. 2100 Second Street SW\nWashington, DC 20593\n<sludwig@comdt.uscg.mil>\n\n[Taking into consideration the information given by Robert Steinglass\nabove, it does not appear to be unwise to consider revaccination as\nmentioned here. Instead the numerator to\ncalculate coverage typically included children irrespective of age of\nvaccination and the denominator excluded the sizeable number of children\nwith permanent or temporary contraindications to vaccination. Although the immunization records of internationally adopted children are\ncarefully reviewed by the US Embassy and INS officials, the children are\noften routinely completely re-vaccinated when they visit their primary care\nphysician in the US. In fact, as part of their applications for funding\nfrom GAVI (the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization), several of\nthe former Soviet countries conducted population-based 30-cluster\nvaccination coverage surveys. Hence, it is possible that many of\nthe children coming from the Russian Federation are behind in the pertussis\nvaccine component and that a careful review of the vaccination histories\nmight identify this. (and father to one girl from China, traveling in 3 days for the second)\n<rmwhit@aaahawk.com>\n\n[The MMWR issue mentioned by Randy G. Whitworth is: General Recommendations\non Immunization: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization\nPractices (ACIP) and the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP). This disparity reflected the concerns\ntypically heard from pediatricians that the DPT vaccine was 'too strong'\nand the children had become 'too weak' to be able to tolerate the pertussis\ncomponent of DPT. While every attempt is made to understand the\nadoptive child's health and needs before traveling, certain cultural\ndifferences, as well as governmental procedures, preclude obtaining all\ninformation one would like to have. In most of the other countries of the\nformer Soviet Union, coverage is still monitored in the former Soviet\nfashion as described above.\n The\nreference kindly provided by Dr. Sharon Ludwick demonstrates that the\npediatric community has recognized the special circumstances related to\ninternational adoptions. It is simpler and safer to\nrevaccinate, even though it is rather traumatic for the already\nculture-shocked little new arrivals.\n From: R&M Whitworth <rmwhit@aaahawk.com>\n\nI write regarding the vaccination of adoptive children and the review of\nimmunization records prior to traveling to the adopted (or to be adopted)\nchild's country of origin. From: ProMED-mail subscriber who wishes name to be withheld\n\nThe moderator posed the question about 'whether vaccination histories\nof adoptive children should be reviewed prior to travel to their adoptive\ncountry.' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Clearly there are regulations in place that would ensure that adopted\nchildren are appropriately vaccinated for age prior to obtaining a visa for\nentry to the USA.
