USA (UTAH) (02)\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2194125", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194125", "date": "1998-08-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS IN ADULTS, CURRENT TRENDS - USA (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html> PERTUSSIS IN ADULTS, CURRENT TRENDS - USA (02)\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2194115", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis in adults, current trends - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194115", "date": "1998-08-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS IN ADULTS, CURRENT TRENDS - USA\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2201744", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, worldwide increase, change in epi. (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201744", "date": "2002-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, WORLDWIDE INCREASE, CHANGE IN EPIDEMIOLOGY (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon, 6 May 2002 13:30:38 -0400\nFrom: LeAnna Hatcher <LHatcher@HCNetwork.org>\n\nI have read the postings which 'back-up' mine and others concerns\nregarding many vaccine preventable diseases. With DTaP now in\nincreasingly short supply with delays on 4th and 5th doses this seems\nominous -- We talk of vaccinating adults but do not have enough for\nour children at this point in time! With the possible decrease in MMR\nvaccine we risk measles outbreaks as seen in previous decades --\nDecrease in Prevnar - Long time hold on ALL routine Dt vaccines which\nrisk increasing tetanus - I would think before we worry about\nincreasing number/age of persons vaccinated maybe we need to look at\nhow we can resolve the current shortages and remove risk for future\nones.\n--\nLeAnna Hatcher, RN, CIC\nPerformance Improvement/Employee Health/Infection Control\nFort Myers, FL 33902\n<lhatcher@hcnetwork.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 4 Jan 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR 50(51);1159 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5051a3.htm>\n\nNotice to Readers: Update: Supply of Diphtheria and Tetanus Toxoids\nand Acellular Pertussis Vaccine\n-----------------------\nDiphtheria and tetanus toxoids and acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP)\nremains in short supply, and the shortage will continue into mid-2002\n(1). Shortages are greatest in the public sector. Despite high\nvaccination rates, pertussis continues to cause serious illness and\ndeath, particularly among infants aged over 6 months who are too\nyoung to have completed the 3-dose primary series of DTaP. In 2000, a\ntotal of 1873 pertussis cases (rate: 99 per 100,000 infants aged over\n6 months) and 16 deaths were reported among infants aged over 6\nmonths. Vaccinating infants on time with the 3-dose primary series of\nDTaP to protect them from serious disease remains a priority during\nthis vaccine shortage.\nThe shortage began in 2000 when 2 manufacturers (Wyeth Lederle, Pearl\nRiver, New York, and Baxter Hyland Immuno Vaccines, Baltimore,\nMaryland) stopped production of DTaP (1). Aventis Pasteur\n(Swiftwater, Pennsylvania) and GlaxoSmithKline (Philadelphia,\nPennsylvania), producers of Tripedia and Infanrix, respectively, are\nthe only 2 U.S. suppliers.\nDTaP is recommended as a 5-dose series: 3 doses administered to\ninfants at ages 2, 4, and 6 months, followed by 2 additional doses at\nage 15--18 months and at age 4--6 years (2). During the shortage of\nDTaP, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommends\nthat providers who do not have enough DTaP to vaccinate all children\nwith 5 doses give priority to vaccinating infants with the first 3\ndoses. To ensure an adequate supply of DTaP to vaccinate infants,\nproviders should first defer vaccination of children aged 15--18\nmonths with the fourth DTaP dose. If deferring the fourth dose does\nnot leave enough DTaP to vaccinate infants, then the fifth DTaP dose\n(given to children aged 4--6 years) also should be deferred*. In\nareas with severe DTaP shortages, local public health officials might\nelect to recommend communitywide deferral of the fourth DTaP dose,\nand, if necessary, the fifth DTaP dose.\nWhen the DTaP shortage ends, providers should recall and administer\nDTaP to all children who missed a dose. Vaccination of children aged\n4--6 years is needed to ensure immunity to pertussis, diphtheria, and\ntetanus during the elementary school years (2).\nReferences\n1. CDC. Update on the supply of tetanus and diphtheria toxoids and of\ntetanus and diphtheria toxoids and acellular pertussis vaccine. MMWR\n2001;50:189--90.\n2. CDC. Pertussis vaccination: use of acellular pertussis vaccine\namong infants and young children---recommendations of the Advisory\nCommittee on Immunization Practices. MMWR 1997;46(no. RR-7).\n3. CDC. Recommended childhood immunization schedule---United States,\n2001. MMWR 2001;50:7--10,19.\n*Children traveling to countries where the risk for diphtheria is\nhigh should be vaccinated according to the Recommended Childhood\nImmunization Schedule (3). Travelers might be at increased risk for\nexposure to toxigenic strains of _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_,\nespecially with prolonged travel, extensive contact with children, or\nexposure to poor hygiene. High-risk countries include\nAfrica---Algeria, Egypt, and sub-Saharan Africa; Americas---Brazil,\nDominican Republic, Ecuador, and Haiti; Asia/Oceania---Afghanistan,\nBangladesh, Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Laos,\nMongolia, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, Syria, Thailand,\nTurkey, Vietnam, and Yemen; and Europe---Albania and all countries of\nthe former Soviet Union.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Ms. Hatcher's comment is very well placed given the current vaccine\nshortages -- relevant in terms of triaging who should get vaccine as\na priority, but doesn't eliminate the need to pay attention to the\nchanging epidemiology of the disease if one aims to really control\nthe disease and reduce the morbidity in the long term.\nThe MMWR article advising on recommended priorities for vaccination\nwith the DTaP vaccine where insufficient doses are available was\nincluded above for readers. More information on the vaccine\nshortages currently experienced in the USA can be found at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nip/news/shortages/default.htm#Why> - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "High-risk countries include\nAfrica---Algeria, Egypt, and sub-Saharan Africa; Americas---Brazil,\nDominican Republic, Ecuador, and Haiti; Asia/Oceania---Afghanistan,\nBangladesh, Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Laos,\nMongolia, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, Syria, Thailand,\nTurkey, Vietnam, and Yemen; and Europe---Albania and all countries of\nthe former Soviet Union. Dt vaccines which\nrisk increasing tetanus - I would think before we worry about\nincreasing number/age of persons vaccinated maybe we need to look at\nhow we can resolve the current shortages and remove risk for future\nones.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Ms. Hatcher's comment is very well placed given the current vaccine\nshortages -- relevant in terms of triaging who should get vaccine as\na priority, but doesn't eliminate the need to pay attention to the\nchanging epidemiology of the disease if one aims to really control\nthe disease and reduce the morbidity in the long term. During the shortage of\nDTaP, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommends\nthat providers who do not have enough DTaP to vaccinate all children\nwith 5 doses give priority to vaccinating infants with the first 3\ndoses. In 2000, a\ntotal of 1873 pertussis cases (rate: 99 per 100,000 infants aged over\n6 months) and 16 deaths were reported among infants aged over 6\nmonths. Despite high\nvaccination rates, pertussis continues to cause serious illness and\ndeath, particularly among infants aged over 6 months who are too\nyoung to have completed the 3-dose primary series of DTaP. \nDiphtheria and tetanus toxoids and acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP)\nremains in short supply, and the shortage will continue into mid-2002\n Source: MMWR 50(51);1159 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5051a3.htm>\n\nNotice to Readers: Update: Supply of Diphtheria and Tetanus Toxoids\nand Acellular Pertussis Vaccine\n In\nareas with severe DTaP shortages, local public health officials might\nelect to recommend communitywide deferral of the fourth DTaP dose,\nand, if necessary, the fifth DTaP dose. Travelers might be at increased risk for\nexposure to toxigenic strains of _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_,\nespecially with prolonged travel, extensive contact with children, or\nexposure to poor hygiene. Date: Fri, 26 Jun 1998 23:42:34 -0700 (MST)\n PERTUSSIS - USA (ARIZONA)\n From: Peter Petrisko <ptp@primenet.com>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maricopa County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2193666", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (California)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193666", "date": "1998-07-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192374", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192374", "date": "1997-12-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (04)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192371", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Guatemala", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192371", "date": "1997-12-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - GUATEMALA\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 10 Dec 1997 18:15:11 -0500\nFrom: Dr. James Chin, CDPC-mail\nSource: From the Nando Net\n\nAn epidemic of pertussis, or whooping cough, has killed 42 people and\ninfected about 400 in northern Guatemala, a public official said Tuesday.\nChajul Mayor Manuel Asicona was in Guatemala City to plead for help from\nthe government of President Alvaro Arzu. The health ministry sent teams to\nIndian towns in the thinly populated north to fight the disease. 'The\nhealth situation in Chajul is a disaster because there are no vaccinations,\nno medicine or health personnel,' he said in an interview. Most of the\ndead and ill are children or young people, said Asicona, who acknowledged\nthat some help was coming from people who had made the lengthy trek,\nportions of it by donkey. 'But it's very little since it is difficult to\nget to the towns because there are no highways and the area (of the\nepidemic) is very remote,' he said. The affected area has been\nquarantined, said epidemiologist Weldemar Velez. Pertussis, identifiable\nby a peculiar whooping noise made as the person breathes in after coughing,\ncan be prevented by use of vaccinations and treated with antibiotics.\nChildren are most vulnerable to the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[The case fatality rate suggested by this report is high. Assuming that\nthe diagnoses are correct, this outbreak serves to remind us of the danger\nof pertussis in unvaccinated children. Sometimes emotional discussions of\nthe pros and cons of vaccination tend to forget the lessons of history. -\nMod.ES]\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Australia (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192366", "date": "1997-12-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA (02)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192361", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192361", "date": "1997-12-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192359", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (Iowa)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192359", "date": "1997-12-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (IOWA)\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192048", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis outbreak - Netherlands, Comment & RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192048", "date": "1997-10-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS OUTBREAK - NETHERLANDS, COMMENT & RFI\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192038", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis outbreak - Netherlands (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192038", "date": "1997-10-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSUS OUTBREAK - NETHERLANDS (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "PERTUSSUS OUTBREAK - NETHERLANDS (02)\n **\n A ProMED-mail post", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192081", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis outbreak - Netherlands (02), response", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192081", "date": "1997-10-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS OUTBREAK - NETHERLANDS (02), RESPONSE\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n[see also:\nPertussis outbreak - Netherlands (02) 971009232752\nPertussis outbreak - Netherlands 970518213103]\nDate: Tue, 14 Oct 1997 16:58:46 +0200\nFrom: J. Schellekens and F.R. Mooi\n[On October 9, 1997, ProMED-mail posted a report derived from a media\nsummary of an article that appeared in a well-respected magazine describing\nthe current state of pertussis in the Netherlands. Some of the information\nwas attributed by direct quotation or inference to Dr. J. Schellekens, who\nhas since requested an opportunity to place the information attributed to\nhim in context. We invite our readers to do just as Dr. Schellekens has\ndone, because we strive for accuracy in our postings, and also wish to post\nmedia-based items to apprise our subscribers articles that the public is\nreading about specific emerging infectious diseases. After all, the public\nresponse may have an important impact on the outcome of a specific\noutbreak, or on the field in general. The original posting of ProMED-mail\nis reproduced below followed by the response of Dr. Schellekens and his\ncolleague Dr. Mooi for the convenience of our readers. -Mod. ES]\n>PERTUSSUS OUTBREAK - NETHERLANDS (02)\n>*************************************\n>A ProMED-mail post\n>", "summary": "We invite our readers to do just as Dr. Schellekens has\ndone, because we strive for accuracy in our postings, and also wish to post\nmedia-based items to apprise our subscribers articles that the public is\nreading about specific emerging infectious diseases. Some of the information\nwas attributed by direct quotation or inference to Dr. J. Schellekens, who\nhas since requested an opportunity to place the information attributed to\nhim in context. ES]\n>PERTUSSUS OUTBREAK - NETHERLANDS (02)\n>*************************************\n [On October 9, 1997, ProMED-mail posted a report derived from a media\nsummary of an article that appeared in a well-respected magazine describing\nthe current state of pertussis in the Netherlands. The original posting of ProMED-mail\nis reproduced below followed by the response of Dr. Schellekens and his\ncolleague Dr. Mooi for the convenience of our readers.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-10-09 00:00:00", "1997-10-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192044", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (Idaho)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192044", "date": "1997-10-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (IDAHO)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2190799", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis outbreak - Netherlands", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190799", "date": "1997-05-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS OUTBREAK - NETHERLANDS\n=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=\n=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D\nDate: Fri, 09 May 1997 18:20:20 -0400\nFrom: EID Listserver Manager <EIDLISTMGR@cidod1.em.cdc.gov>\n\nEmerging Infectious Diseases * Volume 3 * Number 2 * April-June 1997=20\nAdvance Dispatches=20\nPertussis in the Netherlands: an Outbreak Despite High Levels of\nImmunization with Whole-Cell Vaccine\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn 1996, a sudden increase in pertussis incidence was reported\nin the Netherlands (2.1 per 100,000 in 1995, 18 per 100,000 in\n1996). Although not all potential surveillance artifacts could\nbe excluded, it is highly probable that the data reflect a true\noutbreak. However, the cause of this increase has not yet been\ndetermined. Further research is directed to the severity of\ndisease and a possible mismatch between the vaccine and the\ncirculating Bordetella strains.\n[Excerpts]\nIn 1996, 2,771 cases of pertussis were reported to the Inspectorate of\nHealth in the Netherlands (population 15 million), compared with 319 cases\nin 1995. With epidemic cycles expected every 3 to 5 years and a recent\noutbreak in 1994, this rise was unexpected (1). After the introduction of\npertussis immunization with a whole-cell vaccine in the National\nImmunization Program (1952), the incidence of pertussis in the Netherlands\ndecreased significantly. Children are immunized at ages 3, 4, 5, and 11\nmonths with a diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, and inactivated polio vaccine\n(DTP-IPV), and vaccine coverage for pertussis, for at least three\nimmunizations, is 96% at the age of 12 months. Until the 1980s, the\nincidence of pertussis seemed very low, because only incidental cases were\nreported. However, in the last two decades, pertussis has been endemic, and\nepidemic peaks have appeared......\nAlthough not all potential surveillance artifacts could be excluded, it is\nhighly probable that the surveillance data reflect a true pertussis\noutbreak. The outbreak could have been caused by 1) decrease in vaccination\ncoverage, 2) decrease in vaccine quality, 3) interference with other\nvaccines, 4) changes in circulating strains of B. pertussis that are not\ncovered by vaccine-induced immunity, or 5) a combination of these factors.\nA decrease in vaccination coverage has not been observed in the (accurate)\nreporting system. The whole-cell vaccine used was produced in the National\nInstitute of Public Health and the Environment and meets international\nstandards. There was no sign of a gradual deterioration of vaccine quality\nas determined for product release by the mouse protection test......\nMolecular typing of B. pertussis isolates collected since 1945 indicated a\nshift in population structure, possibly due to the introduction of\nwhole-cell vaccine (5). Further, antigenic variants of B. pertussis\ndistinct from the strains incorporated in the vaccine appear to have\nemerged (6). It might be possible that circulating strains of B. pertussis\nhave become less sensitive to vaccine-induced immunity. The abrupt increase\nin the proportion of vaccinated patients reported in all age groups\nsuggests such a change.\nData from other countries in Europe indicate that the pertussis epidemic is\nrestricted to the Netherlands. However, a resurgence of pertussis has been\nnoted in the United States since the late 1980s and in Canada since 1991.\nNo single factor has been found to explain this resurgence (7-10).....\nA prospective study is being considered to assess efficacy of the\nwhole-cell vaccine, including differentiation of severity of illness and\nnumber of immunizations received, if the outbreak continues. Cooperative\nstudies to determine the distribution of restriction fragment length\npolymorphism types and antigenic variants of B. pertussis in various\ncountries in Europe, Asia, and North America are under way. Also, the\nimmunogenicity of the Dutch whole-cell vaccine is being assessed: whether\nit has changed over time and how it compares to published immunogenicity\ndata of whole-cell vaccines with known, prospectively determined, vaccine\nefficacy (11).\nIn conclusion, in the Netherlands a sudden increase of pertussis\nnotification has been observed, which seems to reflect a true increase in\nincidence. Nevertheless, the cause of this increase has not been\ndefinitively determined. A possible mismatch between the vaccine and the\ncirculating Bordetella strains is being investigated.\nH.E. de Melker,* M.A.E. Conyn-van Spaendonck,* H.C. R=FCmke,* J.K. van\nWijngaarden,=86 F.R. Mooi,* and J.F.P. Schellekens*\n*National Institute of Public Health and the Environment, Bilthoven, The\nNetherlands; and =86Inspectorate of Health, Rijswijk, The Netherlands\nReferences\n1. Melker HE de, Conyn-van Spaendonck MAE, R=FCmke HC, Sprenger MJW,\nSchellekens JFP. Kinkhoest in Nederland: 1989-1994. Nederlands\nTijdschrift Geneeskunde 1995;139:1280-6.\n2. Zee A van der, Agterberg C, Peeters MF, Mooi F, Schellekens JFP. A\nclinical validation of B. (para)pertussis PCR: comparison with culture\nand serology using samples of patients suspected for whooping cough\nfrom a highly immunized population. J Infect Dis 1996;174:89-96.\n3. Clemens JD, Ferreccio C, Levine MM, Horwitz I, Rao MR, Edwards KM, et\nal. Impact of Haemophilus influenzae type b\npolysaccharide-tetanus-pertussis vaccine. JAMA 1992;267:880-4.\n4. Labadie J, Sundermann LC, R=FCmke HC, and the DTP-IPV~Hib vaccine study\ngroup. Multi-center study on the simultaneous administration of\nDTP-IPV and Hib PRP-T vaccines. Part 1. Immunogenicity. National\nInstitute of Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) Bilthoven, The\nNetherlands. Report No. 124001003, April 1996.\n5. Zee A van der, Vernooij S, Peeters M, Embden J van, Mooi FR. Dynamics\nof the population structure of Bordetella pertussis as measured by\nIS1002-associated RFLP: comparison of pre- and post-vaccination\nstrains and global distribution. Microbiology 1996;142:3479-85.\n6. Mooi FR, Oirschot H van, Peeters J, Willems RJL. Antigenic variation\nof the accellular vaccine component pertactin in the Dutch B.\npertussis population. National Institute of Public Health and the\nEnvironment (RIVM) Bilthoven, The Netherlands. Annual Report 1995.\n7. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Resurgence of pertussis -\nUnited States, 1993. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 1993;42:952-3,959-60.\n8. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Pertussis - United States,\nJanuary 1992-June 1995. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 1995;44:525-9.\n9. De Serres G, Bouliane N, Douville Fradet M, Duval B. Pertussis in\nQuebec: ongoing epidemic since the late 1980s. Can Commun Dis Rep\n1995;21:45-8.\n10. Milord F. Resurgence of pertussis in Monteregie, Quebec - 1990-1994.\nCan Commun Dis Rep 1995;21:40-4.\n11. Greco D, Salmaso S, Mastrantonio P, Giuliano M, Tozzi AE, Anemona A,\net al. A controlled trial of two acellular vaccines and one whole cell\nvaccine against pertussis. N Engl J Med 1996;334:341-8.\n..........................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
